title: Edges and Order
description: The heavy winds that blew through the Northeast a couple of weeks ago mostly missed our place. They took only the dead boughs, which now lie scattered along the edges of the pastures like porous old bones. The farmers up here will have a lot of cleaning to do along the fencelines before they bale hay next June or they will be baling kindling. In the woods across from our house, the wind snapped off the top of a sugar maple. The crown lies jagged, uneven, on the ground, not yet weighed down by gravity or moss. It exaggerates the disorder of nature, which seems so apparent in the absence of snow this time of year.

A professor of New Testament studies at Vanderbilt Divinity School, Ms. Levine has spent a lifetime exploring the profound connections and equally profound divisions between Christianity and Judaism  and, perhaps more important, between Christians and Jews.

The first time was in 1995, when the Gingrich Republicans swept into Washington determined to roll back environmental laws, a threat averted by President Bill Clintons veto pen and the exertions of a group of moderate Republicans. The second challenge occurred during the Congress that has now thankfully drawn to a close.

title: Follys Antidote
description: MANY signs point to a growing historical consciousness among the American people. I trust that this is so. It is useful to remember that history is to the nation as memory is to the individual. As persons deprived of memory become disoriented and lost, not knowing where they have been and where they are going, so a nation denied a conception of the past will be disabled in dealing with its present and its future. The longer you look back, said Winston Churchill, the farther you can look forward.

title: Queens: Driver Killed in Racing Accident
description: A driver killed on Saturday when his car flipped and overturned in a parking lot was racing another driver, the police said yesterday. The driver who died was identified as John Southern, 35, of South Jamaica, Queens. The second driver, Edwin Washington, 22, of Jamaica, was charged with criminally negligent homicide, reckless endangerment and reckless driving, the police said. The two men were racing about 5:30 p.m. on Saturday along North Conduit Avenue near 78th Street in Jamaica when Mr. Southerns white Mitsubishi Galant overturned, the police said. A passenger in Mr. Southerns car, Cory Sapp, 18, of Queens, was also arrested and charged, after police officers found a gun in the Galant, the police said.

The victim, who was too badly burned to be immediately identified, was found in an apartment building on Manor Drive, south of Ivy Hill Park, said John Brown, a Fire Department spokesman. The one-alarm fire apparently started sometime before 10:30 p.m. in the bedroom, Chief Michael Lalor said. The cause was still being investigated.

title: Queens: Man Charged in Accident
description: A driver from New Rochelle ran another vehicle off the Long Island Expressway yesterday morning, then pulled over, and at the sight of a severely injured passenger in the other vehicle, fled on foot, the police said. Two of the three men in the injured passengers vehicle, a GMC Yukon, and a passing off-duty police officer, Michael Leone, caught up with the driver, the police said. The collision occurred shortly before 6 a.m. on the eastbound lanes of the expressway at 69th Street in Maspeth, Queens, the police said. The mans sport utility vehicle veered into the GMC Yukon, pushing it onto the shoulder, the police said. The badly injured passenger, a woman who was in the back seat, was said to be in critical condition yesterday evening at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. All three men in the Yukon suffered minor injuries. The driver of the first vehicle, Alexie Quiles, 26, was charged with vehicular assault and driving while intoxicated, the police said. He was also charged with illegal possession of a weapon after officers found a gun in his vehicle, the police said.

There is no civic agenda, no liturgical content, only the sense of something ended, something begun. It is a good day to clean the ashes out of the wood stove, to consider the possibilities of next summers garden, to wonder how many weeks into the new year you will be before you marvel at how quickly 2007 is going. This will be the year ..., you find yourself thinking, but before you can finish the thought you remember what all the previous years have taught you  that theres just no telling.

Williams never got home. Hours after the Broncos lost to the San Francisco 49ers to be knocked from the playoff race, Williams was shot to death in what the police said was a drive-by shooting in downtown Denver early on New Years Day.

They did not identify the victims, but said the two people killed had been in the same car, a red Ford Fusion. According to a witness, a woman walked out of the Days Inn at 2750 Tonnelle Avenue about 6 p.m. and got into the drivers seat of the Ford. She left the motels driveway and tried to cut across the northbound lane of Route 1 and 9, but a Dodge Durango plowed into her car, causing serious damage to the drivers side, said Amir Kadri, 26, a witness. The driver of the Dodge, a man, was taken to Jersey City Medical Center in serious condition, the police said.

title: Playbook Full of Tricks Gives Boise State Dramatic and Defining Victory
description: GLENDALE, Ariz., Monday, Jan. 2  After a hook-and-lateral, a Statue of Liberty play and a halfback toss launched the Boise State football team to an upset that will long resonate in college football lore, the star tailback Ian Johnson might have saved the nights most memorable surprise for the postgame interview. With the national television cameras focused on him after the chaos of Boise States 43-42 overtime victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night, Johnson proposed to his girlfriend, the Boise State cheerleader Christine Barbara Popadics. Popadics was so stunned and thrilled that she could barely speak. Just like everyone else watching. She had no idea it was coming, Johnson said. Neither did Oklahoma. Johnsons proposal capped a dizzying, riveting, back-and-forth game that will be remembered as one of the most exciting in college football history. Boise squandered an 18-point second-half lead, tied the score with seven seconds remaining on a hook-and-lateral play, then used two more trick plays in overtime to cap a perfect 13-0 season. (Ohio State is the only other undefeated team.) This probably goes down in the history of college football, Boise quarterback Jared Zabransky said. It can be argued as the best game ever. The lasting memory of the game will most likely be the combination of three crazy trick plays  called Statue, Toss Halfback Pass and Circus. But the lasting effect  with a team that plays on blue turf competing against one of college footballs bluebloods  may be the removal of doubt about whether teams from smaller conferences can beat champions of the six major conferences. No one can doubt the daring of Boises play-calling. On the final play, Broncos Coach Chris Petersen decided to leave his offense on the field for a 2-point conversion attempt after Boise matched Oklahomas touchdown to open overtime. The call was for Statue, in which Boise lines up with three wide receivers stacked on the right side. The real guts by Petersen and Bryan Harsin, Boises 30-year old offensive coordinator, may have come with sticking with the play after Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops called a timeout. Boise went with the same look, with the stacked right side, showing a formation from which they often throw a wide receiver screen. Instead, Zabransky faked a screen pass to Legedu Naanee on his right, then hid the ball behind his back with his left hand. Johnson never moved, staying frozen until the fake was properly sold. Johnson then broke left against the grain of play, grabbed the ball from behind Zabranskys back and strolled untouched around the left side into the end zone. The final 2 yards of his 101-yard night will forever be remembered in Boise history. The 2-point conversion made it 43-42 and set off a wild celebration on the Boise sideline and in the stands, where a majority of the 73,719 fans were decked out in Bronco blue and orange. We needed a play like that to get it over with, Petersen said after the game with a smile. But the two plays that got them there may have been even more creative. After Oklahoma tailback Adrian Peterson took the first play of overtime 25 yards for a touchdown, Boise needed to convert on a fourth-and-2 from the 5-yard line. Things got crazy, though, when Zabransky left his usual spot under center and broke in motion to the left. Vinny Perretta, a tailback who hadnt thrown a pass all year, then lined up under center and threw a 5-yard touchdown pass to tight end Derek Schouman. That call was for Toss Halfback Pass, and it was the first time Boise had run it in a game this season. Weve been practicing it for the past month or so, and it couldnt have worked out any better, said Schouman, who also caught a 10-yard pass on third-and-8 to extend the overtime drive. Just to get to overtime, though, Boise pulled off perhaps the grandest of its three trick plays. On fourth-and-18 play from midfield, the Broncos called a hook-and-lateral play, Circus. They think so little of it that they hadnt run it in a game or practice all season. They only did it while goofing off during informal Friday walk-through sessions. And even then it didnt really work. Usually we just run it when were joking around, Schouman said. I never thought that wed actually run it, never mind for a touchdown. Boise lined up with three wide receivers to the right and Drisan James alone on the left. James caught the ball about 12 yards from the line of scrimmage, with the defense playing soft to prevent him from getting a first down. The key to the play was Jamess ability to fake that he was going to try and run for a first down. He tucked the ball and ran about 4 yards, which drew all the Oklahoma defenders toward him. Then he pitched the ball 4 yards behind him to Jerard Rabb, who had run over from the cluster of receivers on the other side of the field. I didnt even want to look after I pitched it, James said. But the pitch went seamlessly, and Rabb knew almost instantly that James had executed the perfect fake. When he caught it, he sucked the defensive backs, safeties and corners, they all came straight to him, Rabb said. He held it just long enough for me to escape around the side. As soon as I got the ball and took about two steps, I was gone. Other than the time I was getting chased by a pit bull, it was the fastest Ive run in my life. Rabbs mad dash to force overtime with seven seconds left also chased away some of Boises demons. Thanks to Paul Thompsons four turnovers, which included a pick-six by Boise defensive back Marty Tadman and a fumble deep in Oklahoma territory, Boise was able to build a 28-10 third-quarter lead. But Oklahoma gutted its way back into the game, and scored two touchdowns in the final 90 seconds of regulation to go ahead. The first score came on a 5-yard pass from Thompson to Quentin Chaney to cut the Boise lead to 28-26. The drama came on the 2-point conversion; Oklahoma attempted it three times, thanks to a pass-interference call on Boise and a pre-snap motion penalty on the Sooners. On the third play, Thompson found Jauquin Iglesias in the end zone to tie the score at 28-28. Oklahoma cornerback Marcus Walker then seemingly decided matters when he returned an interception 33 yards for a touchdown with 1:02 remaining. The game isnt over until the clock hits zero, Walker said in a stunned Oklahoma locker room. Many players wept openly. But you would think the game is over then, right? By then, it had only just begun. And on a deeper level, the Broncos were able to legitimize the very game that they were permitted to play. For the first time this season, there are five B.C.S. games this season instead of four because the smaller conferences fought hard for access to the B.C.S. and won. In one surreal night, the long battle spearheaded by Tulanes president, Scott Cowan, seemed worthwhile. The gap is decreasing fast, Johnson said. The smaller schools are going to start getting recognition now. Just because we havent been around forever doesnt mean we dont play great football. Johnson and his teammates showed the college football establishment they have a few tricks up their sleeves. And if you dont believe him, just ask a certain Boise State cheerleader.

title: Second Thoughts on Gays in the Military
description: Steilacoom, Wash.

title: The Fine Art of Watching a Bugs Life to Explain a Death
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.  For a man with a truly curious profession, Robert D. Hall, 59, has a relaxed way of talking about his work.

title: Cookie Conundrum in the Doctor-Patient Drama
description: She always came on time to our sessions, even in the thick of a Boston blizzard. She always wore the best clothing her hardscrabble life in the projects permitted her. And after each session, she would place a small bag of her homemade cookies on my desk, leaving with a shy smile that flickered with pride.

title: Raging Against the Dying of the Good Old Ways
description: A nagging question may come to mind throughout the film A Fish Story, tonight on the PBS series Independent Lens: Would anyone bother telling or watching this tale if it didnt lend itself to all those picturesque shots of weather-hardened men working the ocean?

title: Jets and Patriots Echo a Past N.F.L. Reunion
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 1  The family reunion featured the usual menu of gratitude mixed with grudges. Those who follow football ate it up and asked for seconds and thirds. It got to the point where the players in the postseason game between the rookie head coach and his mentor wished they could be excused from the table.

title: In the Long Run, Great Arms Come With Big Risks
description: Pete Seeger wrote it and Peter, Paul and Mary sang it and made it hugely popular during the Vietnam War. It could apply to the war in Iraq, but the refrain in Where Have All the Flowers Gone applies to baseball as well:

title: Exposed: Celebrities, Tabloids and Sleaze!
description: There is no role as delicious as a truly nasty, sneaky gossipmonger. Burt Lancaster shone as J. J. Hunsecker, the Walter Winchellesque villain of Sweet Smell of Success. George Sanders stole scenes as the poison pen Addison DeWitt in All About Eve, and Henry Daniell was weasel incarnate as Sidney Kidd, the editor of Spy magazine in The Philadelphia Story.

title: Romania and Bulgaria Celebrate Entry Into European Union
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 1  Romania and Bulgaria joined the European Union on Monday, helping to end geographic divisions left over from the cold war and extending the borders of the now 27-member bloc eastward to the Black Sea.

title: A Party, With Pelosi Front and Center
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1  During her first 100 hours as House speaker, Nancy Pelosi has vowed, she will sweep an aggressive legislative agenda through the newly Democratic-controlled House.

title: Celebrating Movie Musicals That Are Never Out of Date
description: You cant accuse the New York Philharmonic of not having a sense of occasion. As it often does, the orchestra set aside the formalities of the classical repertory on New Years Eve in favor of lighter fare, although this time another kind of formality was evident. With Audra McDonald in the spotlight, her regular conductor, Ted Sperling, on the podium, and a jazz rhythm section deployed within the orchestra, the Philharmonic offered an evening of songs drawn mostly from film musicals of the 1930s through the 50s.

title: Kicking an Addiction, With Real People
description: Smokers are lectured enough by nonsmokers, so some advertisers say the best way to persuade people to give up cigarettes is to tell the stories of other smokers.

title: Henry A. Kissingers Eulogy for President Ford
description: Following is the transcript of the eulogy for former President Gerald R. Ford delivered today by Henry A. Kissinger in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Holding the Line
description: The old year was certainly a boom one for American business, with record profits for companies and record bonuses on Wall Street. But in the background a major accounting scandal has quietly spread, now encompassing more than 120 companies. Fudging the grant date for stock options doesnt quite have the spotlight-grabbing immediacy of Enrons collapse, but it is still gaming the system at the expense of shareholders.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Past That Makes Us Squirm
description: Crawford, Colo.

title: Squirrels That Predict the Future
description: Its like the Beach Boys said: Catch a wave and youre sitting on top of the world.

title: From Far Beneath the Israeli Desert, Water Sustains a Fertile Enterprise
description: KIBBUTZ MASHABBE SADE, Israel  The days coppery last light reflects off the backs of sea bass swimming in fish ponds lined in neat rows on this desert farm.

title: Auburn and Bowl Try to Find Their Place
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1  Forget poignant toasts or sappy resolutions for the new year. The Auburn Tigers were still living in the present and believed they needed to define this season once and for all.

title: Wi-Fi Is Hitting the Road in Cars From Avis, but Technical and Legal Bumps Lie Ahead
description: Try connecting to a high-speed wireless network from a car, and you are pretty much limited to one method: rigging your laptop computer with a special modem and subscribing to a costly, and sometimes temperamental, wireless service.

title: Top Israeli General Admits Errors in Lebanon War
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2  The Israeli chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, conceded today that the military made serious errors during last summers war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, but he said he would not resign his post.

title: After 15 Years, Someones in Charge in Somalia, if Barely
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 1  After Somalias Islamist forces abandoned their final outpost on Monday, the transitional government moved aggressively to assert control, setting a three-day deadline for all weapons to be turned in and calling for international peacekeeping troops to be sent immediately.

title: Broncos Cornerback Dies in Shooting
description: About a month ago, the Denver Broncos starting cornerback Darrent Williams said he looked forward to returning to Fort Worth during the off-season to warn young people in his hometown about staying away from violence and drugs.

title: Dollars in the Sand
description: Ocho Rios, Jamaica

title: When Bad Things Come From Good Food
description: People in the United States have gotten used to the repulsive fact that raw chicken, meat and eggs are often contaminated with dangerous bacteria. Scrub the cutting board, we are warned, dont nibble the cookie dough, dont eat burgers rare. In other words, handle meat like a biohazard  and then eat it.

title: Should Boise State Get a Share?
description: The Boise State-Oklahoma game last night had one of the greatest finishes for a big game in football history. Click here, then go to the fourth-quarter video highlights.

title: Rome: The Sequel
description: Can a made-for-TV empire stand up to the real thing?

title: A Villa in Valencia
description: Joe and Lucrecia Neira, and their two children, moved from Westchester County, N.Y., to a sun-drenched home outside the Spanish port city of Valencia.

title: Efforts to Save a London Museum
description: The Theater Museum in London, Britains national museum of the performing arts, is scheduled to close to the public on Sunday after almost 20 years at its Russell Street location in Covent Garden.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Yale Repertory Theater will present "In the Continuum," written and performed by Danai Gurira and Nikkole Salter, beginning on Jan. 12 at that New Haven theater. The production, which had a critically acclaimed Off Broadway run in the fall of 2005, is on an international tour.

title: A Year of Wheeling, Dealing and Reeling
description: To commemorate a banner year for deals, we raised a glass to some of the notable names of 2006 in DealBooks annual closing dinner column. We toasted the likes of Lloyd Blankfein, who ascended to the role of chief executive at investment banking giant Goldman Sachs, and Stephen Schwarzman, whose Blackstone Group raised record sums of money for its buyout fund. We also lobbed zingers at some of the players who failed to wow Wall Street in the past year. To them, we say better luck in 2007.

title: Not the Case
description: Even among those who opposed the Iraq war from the start, there was always hope that bringing Saddam Hussein to justice would be a saving grace of the entire misbegotten enterprise. Now it seems that even this comfort will be denied. Far from healing old wounds, as some suggested it would, his conviction by the Iraqi special tribunal has exerted little effect on the deepening civil conflict between Shiites and Sunnis. The often circuslike atmosphere of the trial, as well as the murder of three defense lawyers, led groups like Human Rights Watch to condemn the tribunal as flawed and illegitimate. And the charge for which Saddam Hussein received the death penalty did not include his most heinous acts. His execution must still remind the world of the horror of the atrocities he committed while in power. But unfortunately, the disarray of the legal process calls greater attention to the failings of the United States, the Iraqis and the international community in dealing with all that has come after.

title: Blodget Warns on Hedge-Fund Investing
description: Average investors should be wary of taking the plunge into hedge funds, the former Internet analyst Henry Blodget cautions in a Slate article adapted from his book, The Wall Street Self-Defense Manual.

title: Pinault Keeps Door Open to $92 Billion Suez Bid
description: Is one of Frances biggest corporate raiders looking to break up a government-engineered energy merger? According to The New York Times, Franois Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the luxury fashion house Gucci, is exploring a bid for the French utility Suez that could be as high as 70 billion euros ($92 billion). In an e-mailed statement Tuesday, Mr. Pinaults holding company, Artemis, said that all options remain open for a possible bid, sending shares of the worlds second-largest water company to a record.

title: Loaded With Personalities, Now Satellite Radio May Try a Merger
description: Will 2007 be the year that Sirius Satellite Radio and its larger rival XM Satellite Radio do a deal? Following persistent speculation that the two satellite radio companies may merge (egged on by determined cheerleading from pugnacious market pundit Jim Cramer), The New York Times takes a look at why this year may be the year for a deal.

title: CITIC of China Buys Kazakhstan Oil Assets
description: China, which is aggressively seeking overseas energy assets to run its booming economy, said Sunday that one of its biggest conglomerates had bought the Kazakhstan oil assets of a Canadian company for $1.91 billion. The CITIC Group of China bought the oil assets of the Nations Energy Company of Canada and granted KazMunaiGas, Kazakhstans state-owned oil company, an option to a 50 percent interest in Nations Energy, the official Xinhua Agency said.

title: Whither Nasdaqs Bid for the L.S.E.?
description: The Nasdaq Stock Markets chief executive, Robert Greifeld, will begin a second round of meetings with investors in the London Stock Exchange this week, in a sign that the exchange has no intention of raising its 12.43-pound-a-share ($24.48-a-share) bid for its British rival, The Telegraph reported.

title: Israeli Property Consortium Buys Marriott Hotels from Royal Bank of Scotland
description: Delek Real Estate, an Israeli property company, and its partners have agreed to buy 47 British hotels operated by Marriott International from Royal Bank of Scotland for about $2.1 billion. Delek will purchase a 17 percent stake in the hotels through its Delek-Belron International unit, while Electra Real Estate will buy a 9.9 percent stake.

title: Chinese Bank Buys Indonesian Rival
description: The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, which had a record initial public offering in October, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Bank Halim of Indonesia in its first such overseas purchase. Industrial & Commercial, which did not disclose the deal price, said it would buy 90 percent of Bank Halim and take an option to buy the rest from shareholders in three years.

title: Banks Get Noticed for Their Artsy Side
description: Since its creation in 2002, ArtReview magazines authoritative Power 100, the annual ranking of those who hold sway in the art world, has included artists like Damien Hirst of Britain, collectors like the French billionaire Franois Pinault or art dealers n the United States like Larry Gagosian. Last year, for the first time, banks were added to the list.

title: A Nouvelle Vague for Tech I.P.O.s?
description: Will 2007 be the year that the tech I.P.O. makes its comeback? A steadying of interest rates and inflation, a recent rally in the tech-heavy Nasdaq, and exceptional performance of tech offerings since the summer of 2006 have given observers hope of a significant rise in initial public offerings of technology start-ups this year, BusinessWeek writes. Already, 2006 saw a 31 percent rise in I.P.O. filings, with 67 tech companies filing to go public.

title: L.S.E. Moves to Tighten Rules for Alternative Exchange
description: The London Stock Exchange is planning to tighten regulations in a move that would make it easier to take disciplinary action against brokers that bring unsuccessful companies to the Alternative Investment Market. The change is part of a bid to toughen rules governing the nominated advisers, or nomads, that oversee companies coming to the alternative market, which is administered by the London exchange.

title: Sinclair Pharma Plans I.P.O.
description: Sinclair Pharma, the oral hygiene and skincare specialist, will list its shares on Euronext in the first half of the year as the company gears up for further acquisitions in Europe. Valued at about 100 milion pounds ($197 million), the company is one of Britains larger healthcare firms and is expected by analysts to be planning a string of deals this year.

title: In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
description: As Google continues to outmaneuver its main search rivals, Yahoo and Microsoft, plenty of newcomers  with names like Powerset, hakia, ChaCha and Snap  are trying to beat the company at its own game. And Wikia, a company started by a founder of Wikipedia, plans to develop a search engine that, like the popular Web-based encyclopedia, would be built by a community of programmers and users.

title: Leases to Hedge Funds Raise Questions
description: They are known as hedge fund hotels: Offices that investment banks lease out to upstart hedge-fund traders, usually in hopes that the traders-in-residence will become big clients. As The New York Timess Jenny Anderson reports, they often come with luxurious amenities, such as receptionists, espresso machines and consultants to help manage their information systems. But, Ms. Anderson wrties, they are also raising questions. William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of state, has subpoenaed UBS, the leader in this business, and is examining other banks with hedge fund hotels in Boston to determine how they are charging for their services.

title: Virgin in Investment Talks With AirAsia, Report Says
description: Virgin Group has re-entered talks with AirAsia about taking a stake in the Malaysia-based low-cost airline, in a move that would give the British company a wider foothold in the Asian market. The Times of London reported that AirAsia has approached Virgin in the hope that its Virgin Atlantic subsidiary would invest in the Malaysian airline.

title: Using Web Cams but Few Inhibitions, the Young Turn to Risky Social Sites
description: How far will uptsarts go to try and topple popular web starts like YouTube and MySpace? Quite a bit further, it seems. Increasingly, new Web sites like Stickam.com, Dailymotion, and LiveLeak are building their businesses by going where others fear to tread: into the realm of unmonitored downloading, depictions of nudity and violence and unfiltered live broadcasts from Web cameras, writes The New York Times.

title: Wi-Fi Is Hitting the Road in Cars From Avis
description: Autonet Mobile, a start-up wireless technology company based in San Francisco, is expected to announce this week that it has reached an agreement with Avis Rent A Car System to provide a rolling Wi-Fi hotspot to Avis customers by March.

title: CVC Capital Partners Gears Up to Go Hostile
description: One of Europes largest private equity houses plans to carry out hostile bids on public companies. The fund, CVC Capital Partners, has changed the terms of agreement with its investors so that it can attempt to take over businesses without the support of management, The Telegraph reported. The move will no doubt be unwelcome for directors of many publicly quoted companies who had previously thought they could resist a private equity bid, so long as they declined to play ball.

title: The Lonely Newspaper Reader
description: Recalling the recent surprise announcement by McClatchy that it had decided to sell The Minneapolis Star Tribune for $530 million to a group of private equity bidders, The New York Timess David Carr takes a look at what has happened to reading the newspaper at the breakfast table.

title: Insurers to Pay DaimlerChrysler $221 Million
description: DaimlerChrysler will recover about 168 million euros ($221.5 million) from insurers in settling a dispute over the costs of a 2003 class-action lawsuit in the United States, the Financial Times Deutschland reported.DaimlerChrysler and a group of insurance companies led by the insurer ACE had reached an agreement shortly before the end of the year, the report said. The suit was related to the acquisition of Chrysler by Daimler.

title: Sony BMG Inks First Podcast Pacts
description: Rock River Communications has struck some of the first deals to license major-label content for podcasts, downloadable audio programs. Rock River, which specializes in making the mix CDs sold at the check-out counters of retailers like Gap and Williams-Sonomas Pottery Barn, is creating a series of promotional podcasts on behalf of corporate clients including DaimlerChrysler and Ford Motor, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: A Long Way to Learn How to Help Those Back in Nepal
description: Kunsang Sherpa volunteers at Elmhust Hospital Center, and got aid to start in a nursing assistants program.

title: Loose Ends in Enrons Tangled Web
description: You might think that after last years trials of Enrons former top two corporate chiefs, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, that the corporate fraud saga would finally be over. But several loose ends of the scandal that burst open when the company collapsed in December 2001 are still pending, although they are expected to be resolved in 2007.

title: The Merger Outlook and This Years Targets
description: After helping to drive a record year for mergers and buyouts, will deal makers take a breather in 2007? Dont count on it, several market watchers are saying this week. Among these M&A bulls is talk-show host and former hedge-fund manager James Cramer, who writes in the latest issue of New York magazine that 2007 will be even bigger than 2006 in terms of deals. He also ticks off a series of well-known companies that he thinks are logical targets.

title: $575,000 Homes
description: A chalet-style home in Maryland, a Mediterranean in Texas, and a condo in Marina del Rey, Calif.

title: Essar Lines Up Financial Pledges for Cellphone Company Bid
description: Essar of India has secured financing pledges for a potential bid for the 67 percent that it does not own of Hutchison Essar, the cellphone operator it jointly owns with Hong Kongs Hutchison Telecommunication International, The Financial Times reported. The paper said that Essars move underscores its seriousness and proves its toughness against rival bidders Vodafone and Reliance Communications.

title: A New Year Marked by Mortal Transitions  and Debate
description: We wish all Lede readers the very best in the New Year.

title: Story Schmory II
description: A while ago, the Bagger linked to Ray Prides interview with Alfonso Cuarn, in which he said that story qua story was waaaaaay overrated. The point was well made, but the Bagger thought again about the value of narrative this weekend when he made his way through several screeners, including The Painted Veil and Water.

title: Now, for Even Longer Odds
description: Tired of all this years predictions? Why not switch to next year? Yes, thats right, over at Oscar Igloo, they are working on the favorites for February, 2007.Turns out that making picks for this year is childs play. Its next year you should be thinking about. The Bagger will take The Kite Runner for now.

title: Paper Hardware
description: Like millions of Americans yesterday, the Bagger was tired of staring into the faces of his loved ones, making small talk at parties and eating ham. So he opened up the paper to see what movie he should see  that way he could be with his loved ones, but not have to speak with them.

title: Rethinking Middle School
description: Driven by slumps in learning and by high dropout rates, educators are struggling to rethink middle school.

title: Downloading the Downbeat
description: David Denby of the New Yorker looks deep into his iPod and sees  a murky future for Hollywood.

title: Bounty Hunting Online
description: People tend to use online personas to say things in print they otherwise would not. Take the Bagger: in real life, he is a complete nerd, scared of his own shadow. But give him a nom-de-blog and he suddenly blossoms into an avatar of cool, able to towel snap anyone with the greatest of ease.

title: Republicans Turn Against the War
The Democrats Hill: Drawing the Battle Lines
description: With the opening of the 110th Congress set for later this week, Carl Hulse, the Timess chief congressional correspondent writes today:

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Giuliani Exposed
description: This is probably not how former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani envisioned starting off the year. Well, actually, we can figure out exactly how he meant to start the year because he lost his campaign playbook (yes, an actual 140-page set of documents). It was left in one of the cities where hes campaigning, and someone sympathetic to one of Giulianis rivals for the White House passed it off to The New York Daily News. The dossier detailed schedules, ambitious fundraising plans and possible liabilities for Mr. Giuliani:

title: Lennar and Cerberus Sell LandSource Stake
description: The Home builder Lennar and LNR Property, a holding of Cerberus Capital Management, said on Tuesday they were selling a 62 percent stake in their LandSource joint venture to MW Housing Partners. Lennar also slashed its fourth-quarter profit forecast by as much as 46 percent, citing lower profit margins amid the deteriorating housing market in the United States

title: Comment Zone: Dear Mr. Spitzer
description: So, Empire Zone readers, what should be at the top of Eliot Spitzers agenda as governor of New York? (He is expected to talk about his plans tomorrow in his first State of the State address.)

title: Will Bill Miller Have a Happier New Year?
description: There has been a lot of talk about Wall Streets many winners in 2006. It was a record year for worldwide merger activity and for profits at the bulge-bracket investment banks. Goldman Sachss chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein, received the largest annual bonus ever awarded to a Wall Street chief. But there is at least one person on Wall Street who was probably very glad to ring out the old year: Bill Miller, the legendary mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason.

title: Nucor to Acquire Harris Steel for $1.07 Billion
description: Nucor, the second-largest steel producer in the United States, agreed to acquire the Harris Steel Group of Canada for about $1.07 billion as the steel industry continues to see record consolidation. Nucor agreed to pay 46.25 Canadian dollars ($39.76) for each Harris Steel share, or 6.3 percent above the closing price Dec. 29.

title: Qatars Contributions Curtailed at Wikipedia
description: A bit of controversy was brewing this morning over at Wikipedia, the freewheeling transcription of human knowledge by a hive of transient, often pseudonymous Internet users, when it was reported by CNet, BBC News, Slashdot and others that the site would no longer reflect the singular contributions of Qataris.

title: Shoneys Chain Finds New Buyer
description: Private equity firm Lone Star Funds has lined up a new buyer for Shoneys, after a previous deal to sell the restaurant chain reportedly fell through. A unit of Royal Capital said Tuesday it would acquire the chain, known across the South for its buffets, for an undisclosed price. In July, Lone Star announced that it would sell Shoneys, which it took private in 2002, to an affiliate of a Chicago real estate developer, Centrum Properties. But the Nashville Post reported in September that the deal collapsed, prompting a lawsuit.

title: Execution Samizdat Investigated in Iraq
description: Iraqi officials have begun an investigation into the widespread distribution of shaky cellphone video footage (warning: its disturbingly graphic)  of the hanging of Saddam Hussein on Saturday. The video revealed that Mr. Hussein exchanged taunts and jeers with jailers in his final moments, and was told to go to hell by someone witnessing the event.

title: Developer Accuses Hard Rock of Rigging Sale
description: Management of Hard Rock International, the chain of music-themed restaurants, hotels and casinos, rigged the $965 million sale of the company to favor the Seminole Tribe of Florida, a would-be bidder alleged in court filings Friday. The suit was filed by Cordish, a real-estate developer that worked with the Seminoles in developing its Hard Rock properties, accusing the franchise and its chief executive, Hamish Dodds, of collaborating with the tribe on the sale to insure that management was kept in place.

title: The NYSEs Electronic Man
description: In a long profile of the NYSE Groups chief executive, John Thain, New York magazine says Mr. Thains modus operandi has always been to give the coming technocracy a human face. It can be a tricky strategy to pull off, however. The essential functions of Wall Street, like trading on the New York Stock Exchange, are increasingly being handled by machines, threatening to uproot many of the Streets long-standing traditions, the article notes.

title: National Mourning
description: Theres nothing in Washington like the somber pageantry of a presidential funeral, from the camera studies of a frail but stoic widow, to the honor guard carrying the flag-draped coffin down the Capitol steps, the visages of an aging inner circle of a cabinet and the eulogies recalling memorable moments. And of course, the 21-gun salute.

title: Vacation Home Resolutions
description: When you are obsessed with building a new home, your New Years resolutions have much more to do with tracking down the perfect flooring for the guest room than they do with diet and exercise.

title: For Dodd, Wall Street Looms Large
description: Democrats take control of Congress this week, and many in the financial services industry are wondering what legal or regulatory changes are in store. An important figure to watch is Christopher Dodd, the Connecticut senator who will become chair of the powerful Senate Banking Committee. On Tuesday, the Associated Press suggested that Mr. Dodds potential presidential ambitions may temper any zeal to slap additional regulations on Wall Street.

title: Why Go Cold Turkey? Try Playoff Fantasy
description: According to the semireliable end-all/be-all source of universal knowledge, Wikipedia, addiction is described as a mental or physical disorder proposed to be precipitated by a combination of genetic, biological/pharmacological and social factors. Addiction is characterized by the repeated use of substances or behaviors despite clear evidence of morbidity secondary to such use. Using these parameters, fantasy football is clearly an addiction.Mental disorder. Check. Anything that makes you worry incessantly about, say, Fred Taylors job security in light of Maurice Jones-Drews rising production  and do so during (allegedly) more important moments like client meetings, late night baby-feedings and/or intercourse with your significant other  clearly qualifies.

title: Floating Away From New York
description: It was a hardly a bad year for the NYSE Group, whose shares have roughly doubled since June. But 2006 did bring one unhappy milestone for the NYSE, which operates the New York Stock Exchange. Thomson Financial notes that for the first time ever, the NYSEs New York Stock Exchange was bested in the global market for initial public offerings. Both the London Stock Exchange and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange were bigger venues for public floats in 2006, as measured by the volume of proceeds raised, the research firm said.

title: Blogtalk: Day 2
description: What good government groups hope to hear in Eliot Spitzers State of the State address tomorrow. An 8th graders perspective on the inaugural speech yesterday: kind of mean to George Pataki. [The Politicker]An anonymous speechwriter critiques the inaugural address, saying the closing line was good (Day One is now), but that Eliot should have skipped the Lincoln and Kennedyesque phrases. Praise for this line: No matter how great the challenge  no matter how impossible the odds - our destiny will never be a path to follow, but always a trail to blaze. [Capitol Confidential]

title: Study: Being Abused Is Not An Uplifting Experience
description: This might seem to have been better published in the Journal of Obvious Outcomes, but Reuters reports that a study published in this months Archives of General Psychiatry finds that physically abused children have a 59 percent increased risk of lifetime major depression compared with similar children who were not abused.

title: Boise State and the Top 3 List
description: Driving back to the hotel with a few sportswriters after Boise States 43-42 victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl, we began kicking around the notion about whether it was the best game wed ever covered.

title: Corporate America Gets the (McNulty) Memo
description: Last year will be remembered for introducing the phrase stock options backdating to the general public, law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen and Katz declared in a recent letter to clients. But it added that the years more-important legal catch phrase may be the McNulty Memo, which did not get quite as much attention in the media. Wachtell Lipton suggests that the memo was part of a significant retreat by the Justice Department, which was reacting to the beginning of a true push-back against what have come to be perceived as overly aggressive government enforcement policies and practices.

title: For a Much-Mocked Resume, One More Dig
description: Michael Cera, who played George Michael, the would-be scion of the Bluth family, on the late, lamented TV show Arrested Development, has found new work: He is starring in an online video that parodies the egomaniacal video resume of Alexey Vayner. Mr. Vayner, a Yale student, sent his video, called Impossible Is Nothing, to investment banks in hopes of securing a job. But it was leaked to YouTube and beyond last summer, prompting a flood of ridicule and many comments on DealBook.

title: A Congressman, a Muslim and a Buddhist Walk Into a Bar
description: With all the uproar over the decision by Representative-elect Keith Ellison, the first Muslim to serve in Congress, to swear-in using the Koran, weve neglected the fact that another faith is making its first showing in the Capitol with not one but two freshmen.

title: The State of the State
description: Governor Eliot Spitzers staff just released excerpts from his State of the State speech, which takes place at 1 p.m. tomorrow.

title: U.F.O. Hits Congestion at OHare, Turns Back
description: A column in The Chicago Tribune yesterday has had many skywatchers atwitter over the last 24 hours, in that it details the apparent sighting by several United Airlines workers at Chicagos OHare airport of  something hovering over Concourse C on Nov. 7.

title: Pork Tenderloin
description: Food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares twice cooked pork tenderloin.

title: Completely
Too Good to Be Real?
description: Happy New Year, dudes!

title: Fords Lost Legacy
description: With the passing of Gerald Ford, we have lost more than a former president who served the nation honorably in trying times. The Republican Party has also lost its last link to a tradition it once embraced. Gone now is any trace of the solid Midwestern ethics that Ford personified  things like not spending more than you take in, being skeptical about the use of force, and not imposing ones values on others.

title: Its the Year to Keep an Eye on Paychecks
description: What do you think will happen to the economy and to Americans paychecks in 2007?

title: Peterson Considers Jump From Oklahoma to N.F.L.
description: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 2  Lost in the aftermath of Oklahomas wild overtime loss to Boise State in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night was what might have been the final college game of the star tailback Adrian Peterson.

title: Recipe: Bucatini With Raw Nut Pesto and Tomato Sauce (Bucatini alla Lipari)
description: Time: About 40 minutes

title: Patent Lawsuit Names Leading Technology Firms
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2  In 1997, Jonathan T. Taplin, a veteran film and television producer, stood up at a cable industry convention and asserted that in the future all movies would be distributed over the Internet. He recalls being laughed out of the room.

title: Totals
Bronx: Man Sentenced for Killing Son
description: A Bronx man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 25 years in prison for beating his 5-week-old son to death in a homeless shelter, the Bronx district attorneys office said. The man, Michael Williams, 25, was convicted last month of second-degree murder in the death of Michael Williams Jr., his son. The boy died in December 2003 after he had 12 broken ribs, bruises all over his body and signs of chronic trauma to the spinal cord, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson said in a statement. Prosecutors said the child had been abused his entire life.

title: After a Fire, a Beloved California Restaurant Vows to Rebuild
description: TO the people who found inspiration and solace at Mankas Inverness Lodge, word that a fire took down the small restaurant and lodge two hours northwest of San Francisco last week was akin to news that a brilliant, eccentric and dear old friend had passed away.

title: Daylight in Boeings Shadow
description: When Bob Baker at Harvest Partners, a real estate development company, tells people he is putting up a shopping center across the street from Boeings commercial jet factory, he usually gets quizzical looks. Although Renton, Wash., is a town better known for airplanes than Armani, Mr. Baker is convinced his mall will do well.

title: Political Paper Stolen, Giuliani Camp Says
description: Advisers to former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that someone infiltrated the Giuliani camp last fall and stole a document about his presidential prospects and political liabilities. It was then leaked, they said, as a dirty trick to embarrass Mr. Giuliani and highlight such headaches as his controversial former aide, Bernard B. Kerik, and one of his ex-wives, Donna Hanover.

title: Queens: Vigil by Shooting Victims Mother
description: The mother of Sean Bell, the unarmed man fatally shot by the police in November outside a Jamaica nightclub, said yesterday that she would stand vigil outside the police station for the 103rd Precinct, where the shooting occurred. The mother, Valerie Bell, said she would continue the vigil for 50 days, the number of bullets fired in the Nov. 25 shooting, or until indictments were filed in the case. Mr. Bell and a group of friends were in a car after his bachelor party when the shooting occurred. Two of Mr. Bells friends were wounded in the shooting. The officers have said that they thought one of the men in the car had a gun. The five police officers involved have been on desk duty since the shooting. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, is investigating.

title: As Costs of Wildfires Grow, So Does a Question: Who Should Pay?
description: DENVER, Jan. 2  The steeply rising cost of preventing and suppressing wildfires, which burned more of the American landscape in 2006 than in any other year since at least 1960, is creating a rift between Washington and state and local governments over how the burden ought to be shouldered.

title: Excerpts From Eulogies
description: Following are excerpts from eulogies yesterday for former President Gerald R. Ford by former President George Bush; former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger; Tom Brokaw, the former NBC News anchor; and President Bush. A full transcript: nytimes.com/washington.

title: White House Says It Would Have Handled Execution Differently
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  The Bush administration sought today to distance the United States and President Bush from the handling of Saddam Husseins execution, asserting that the growing controversy is a matter for the Iraqi government to investigate.

title: A Princeton Maverick Succumbs to a Cultural Shift
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 29  Logan Fox cant quite pinpoint the moment when movies and television shows replaced books as the cultural topics people liked to talk about over dinner, at cocktail parties, at work. He does know that at Micawber Books, his 26-year-old independent bookstore here that is to close for good in March, his own employees prefer to come in every morning and gossip about Survivor or that fashion reality show whose title he cant quite place.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Oprah Winfrey Opens Her South African School

title: Sri Lanka: Tigers Say Air Raids Killed 15 Civilians
description: The Tamil Tiger rebels said that 15 people, including 4 children, had been killed in government airstrikes in the northwestern coastal town of Mannar and that dozens more had beeb wounded. The military said it bombed a rebel naval position and denied it had hit any civilians.

title: Venezuela: 16 Dead in Prison Melee
description: Sixteen inmates were killed as rival gangs clashed at a prison in Uribana, in western Lara State. Violent deaths have plagued the countrys prisons, a system with about 19,000 inmates, as the authorities struggle with crowding and a shortage of trained guards. More than 300 inmates were killed in the first nine months of 2006. Almost 50 prisoners were killed in 2006 in Uribana, a six-year-old prison considered the most violent in Venezuela.

title: China: Venture to Build Vans
description: DaimlerChrysler said a joint venture with the China Motor Corporation to make vans won state approval, allowing the company to add capacity in China. DaimlerChrysler, China Motor and the Fujian Motor Industry Group received permission from the Ministry of Commerce in China for a 200 million euro ($264 million) venture to build as many as 40,000 Mercedes-Benz vans a year, said Trevor Hale, the Beijing-based spokesman for DaimlerChrysler.

title: Man Sentenced to 26 Years for Reporters Murder
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  One of the two men convicted of murdering a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced today to 26 years in prison.

title: New U.N. Chief Invites Controversy by Declining to Oppose Hussein Execution
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 2  On his first day of work as secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, the mild-spoken South Korean diplomat who had suggested he would bring new caution to the post, invited controversy by declining to criticize the death penalty applied to Saddam Hussein.

title: Ford Will Quit Minivan Market
description: Ford Motor said yesterday that it would abandon the minivan market in the United States by discontinuing its Freestar model and instead seek to bolster output of two new so-called crossover vehicles.

title: Sprint Nextel Puts Its Big Ad Account in Review
description: Sprint Nextel, one of the countrys biggest marketers, said late today that it had placed the creative part of its advertising account in review. Sprint Nextel spends an estimated $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion each year on advertising.

title: U.S. and Brazil to Talk About Talks
description: The top trade negotiators for the United States and Brazil will meet in New York to discuss global trade talks that collapsed last year, Brazils Foreign Ministry said. The foreign minister, Celso Amorim, and the United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, will talk today about how to reopen the negotiations and overcome obstacles that have prevented a World Trade Organization deal aimed at strengthening the global economy. A round of talks began in 2001 in Doha, Qatar, but they collapsed last year over disagreements on farm subsidies and tariffs.

title: A Long Way to Learn How to Help Those Back in Nepal
description: Growing up in Nepal, Kunsang Sherpa, 23, knew what it was like to go without. His family farmed for a living, but in the mountainous landscape they grew only enough crops to eat. They mostly went without money and without medical care.

title: Stained Glass and Strained Egos
description: Washington

title: Bush Says Plan Would Balance Budget by 12
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  President Bush said on Tuesday that he would propose a plan that he insists would, if followed, achieve a balanced budget by 2012, the most optimistic he has been in at least five years, and he said the goal could be achieved without rescinding any of his big tax cuts.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Film entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report of Arts & Leisure about a Robert Altman retrospective gave an incorrect address and phone number for the theater, IFC Center. It is at 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village  not at 209 West Houston Street, South Village. The number is (212) 924-7771.

title: Ethiopian Premier Says His Troops Wont Stay in Somalia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 2  Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia said Tuesday that his country, one of the poorest in the world, could not afford to keep troops in Somalia much longer and that it was ill equipped to play the role of peacekeeper there.

title: New Evidence of Liquid Methane on Saturns Moon
description: As scientists predicted but have had a hard time proving, the surface of Titan, Saturns largest moon, appears to be dotted with an abundance of lakes of liquid methane. The lakes are more intriguing evidence of the active phenomena at play on the only moon in the solar system that has a dense atmosphere.

title: Bracing for Higher Premiums
description: To the mantra of lifes certainties, add higher home-insurance rates to death and taxes.

title: For Some Moviegoers, Its Hooray for Bollywood
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Dec. 27  Swollen ticket lines, shouting children, tempers rising as the movies sold out: This was any suburban multiplex during the holidays.

description: To the Editor:

title: At Service for Ford, a Gathering of Ex-Presidents and Family
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  In a moment of presidential empathy, former President George Bush recalled a skill he had learned from Gerald R. Ford: how to handle being ridiculed on Saturday Night Live.

title: Amgen Acquires Option for a Heart Failure Drug
description: Making a further move into the market for cardiovascular drugs, the biotechnology giant Amgen has formed an alliance with Cytokinetics, a smaller company developing an experimental drug to treat heart failure.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music column yesterday about pop songs on war misstated the title of the song, about a lover killed in combat, that starts the Norah Jones album due out this month. It is Wish I Could  not Thinking About You, which is the title of another song on the album.

title: MoMA to Gain Exhibition Space by Selling Adjacent Lot for $125 Million
description: Capitalizing on Manhattans robust real estate prices, the Museum of Modern Art is selling its last vacant parcel of land in Midtown for $125 million to Hines, an international real estate developer based in Houston, the museums director said yesterday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about possible ways to curb sharp increases in executive pay misstated the percentage increase in the value of a pension for Lee R. Raymond, the former chief executive for Exxon Mobil, because of bonuses from 2003 to 2005. It was a 50 percent increase, to $98.4 million from just under $66 million  not 33 percent.

title: Trying to Find Solutions in Chaotic Middle Schools
description: Sit in with a seventh-grade science class at Seth Low, a cavernous Brooklyn middle school, as paper balls fly and pens are flicked from desk to desk.

title: Spitzer Speech Will Urge Fiscal Restraint
description: ALBANY, Jan. 2  Gov. Eliot Spitzer will call for the state government to rein in spending, cut property taxes and overhaul the workers compensation system in his first address to state lawmakers on Wednesday.

title: Democrats Plan First 100 Hours, Give or Take a Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  House Democrats intend to kick off their new regime with a 100-hour legislative blitz that would allow them to post a series of quick victories before President Bush even delivers his State of the Union address toward the end of this month.

title: Louisville Hoping Big Finish Carries Over to Next Season
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2  The long path to respect and recognition was about to be completed by Louisville. The Cardinals had only recently raised their national profile with the move to the Big East from Conference USA two seasons ago, and the Orange Bowl on Tuesday night at Dolphin Stadium was to be the final step in Louisvilles ascension to the short list of national contenders for next season.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Monday about the Knicks 90-80 loss to the Clippers in Los Angeles misidentified the team that drafted guard Nate Robinson in 2005. It was the Phoenix Suns, who selected him at the Knicks request, then traded him and Quentin Richardson to the Knicks for Kurt Thomas the same day; the Knicks did not draft Robinson.

title: Its More or Less Natural, and Its Getting Bigger by the Day
description: EACH year grocery manufacturers roll out tens of thousands of products, ever hopeful that a new box of crackers or a frozen entree will be a hit with consumers.

title: Home Prices Fall Just a Bit; Brokers See Soft Landing
description: Sale prices for Manhattan apartments fell in the last quarter of 2006, while the pace of sales was reported to be strong and the backlog of unsold apartments fell, according to several market studies released yesterday by large real estate brokerage firms.

title: After the Rip van Winkle Years
description: The mood at Eliot Spitzers Jan. 1 inauguration was exuberant, and that was hardly surprising. Few politicians are offered the opportunity that greets Mr. Spitzer as he becomes New Yorks 54th governor.

title: McGreevey Finds Way Back to the State House, on Canvas
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2  The last time James E. McGreevey was inside the governors office, his name was painted on the glass door.

title: From Banker to Baker in TriBeCa
description: You cant open a bakery in New York without cupcakes these days, so Rachel Thebault, a former investment banker who has opened Tribeca Treats, offers small ones ($2 each) aswirl with chocolate, vanilla, coconut, espresso, peanut butter, caramel or marshmallow frostings. There is even a red velvet one with cream cheese icing. Her sandwich cookies are also modest in size and come in chocolate, vanilla, peanut and graham cracker with various cream fillings, $1.25 each or $18 a dozen. Chocolates and cakes round out the inventory. The shop also sells gift items. Its at 94 Reade Street (Church Street), (212) 571-0500.

title: Itche Goldberg, Yiddish Advocate, 102, Dies
description: Itche Goldberg, a champion of Yiddish who wrote and edited and taught his beloved language in the face of all those who said keeping Yiddish alive was a lost cause, died last Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 102.

title: The Fiesta Bowl: And Now, a Few More Words
description: This is the first college football postseason I can recall without Keith Jackson, whose voice defined bowl games. Although Jackson was frustrated with his performance in his finale, last years Rose Bowl, his presence was welcome. His retirement coincided with the conclusion of ABCs era of dominance over televising the Bowl Championship Series.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an investigation into the possibility that banks are luring hedge funds as tenants in order to solicit their trading business misstated the nature of a request made by the Massachusetts secretary of state, William F. Galvin, to UBS, the Swiss bank. While Mr. Galvin has requested information from UBS, he has not issued a subpoena. UBS is cooperating with the inquiry. (Go to Article)

title: New York Transit Chief Plans to Resign
description: Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the branch of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the citys subways and buses, said today that he would resign, clearing the way for new leadership at the agency he has run since 1996.

title: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 2  The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles for the company, officials said on Tuesday.

title: Bag Handlers Held in Theft of Luggage in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 2  Wondering what happened to your lost airline luggage?

title: Embattled Chief Executive Resigns at Home Depot
description: Robert L. Nardelli, the chief executive of Home Depot, who came under heavy criticism for his pay package and failure to lift the chains stagnant stock price, has abruptly resigned, the company said today.

title: A Time of Temptation for the Thrifty of Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 2  A government effort to cool Irelands roaring economy by encouraging people to save is threatening to backfire.

title: Fighting Over Gold in the Land of Dracula
description: ROSIA MONTANA, Romania  Eugen David, a small-time farmer with a chipped tooth and muddy boots in this obscure wrinkle of Transylvania, is an unlikely man to attract the attention of movie stars and moguls. But he counts Vanessa Redgrave, George Soros and Teddy Goldsmith among his backers in a land battle with a Canadian gold mining company.

title: Sawyer Signals Commitment to Morning Show
description: Diane Sawyer, whose continued commitment to Good Morning America has been the subject of speculation since Charles Gibson departed the show in June, has in recent weeks left some executives at ABC with the impression that she intends to remain with the program until at least early summer, according to one executive briefed directly on Ms. Sawyers status.

title: When She Speaks, Hes Breaking All of Islams Taboos
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 2  Ali Saleem may have devised the perfect, if improbable, cover for breaking taboos in conservative, Muslim Pakistan.

title: Bridgeport: Campaign Law Partly Halted
description: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction yesterday blocking part of a state lobbying and campaign finance law that is one of the toughest in the country. The provision, blocked by Judge Stefan R. Underhill of Federal District Court, would have required the executives of companies seeking state contracts to disclose the names of their children on a Web site to ensure that the executives do not make illegal campaign contributions through their dependents. Contractors must still disclose the names of their spouses. Contractors and their family members are still barred from contributing to officials who control state contracts. The law, enacted in response to a state payoff scandal, was set to take effect at the start of the year. The request for an injunction was filed by a securities industry trade group. The American Civil Liberties Union has also sought to overturn elements of the law.

description: Time: 3 hours

title: Global Rally on First Day of Trading in New Year
description: Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers would support global equities for a fifth year.

title: Cancer Patients Wait Times Cost Billions
description: A new study says that $2.3 billion worth of time is spent in waiting rooms, doctors offices, hospitals and transportation in the first year after cancer is diagnosed. Patients with gastric and ovarian cancers lost the most time, valued around $5,300 and $5,600 per person, compared with costs associated with skin and prostate cancers of $300 and $800 each, according to a study in todays issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute. Researchers looked at records from 764,000 Americans 65 years old or older who had received a diagnosis of 11 common forms of cancer from 1995 to 2001. They estimated the average amount of time spent seeking treatment and multiplied it by $15.23 an hour, the median United States wage rate in 2002. The study did not look at the value of time spent by members of a patients family.

title: Artest Reminds the Knicks What Theyre Missing
description: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 2  There is no shortage of ghosts in the Knicks file cabinet of misguided transactions, and perhaps none more haunting than the image of Ron Artest, all muscle and swagger, hitting shots from every panel of the hardwood.

title: In Rustic Greek Dishes, a Fresh Approach to Ancient Flavors
description: ASK New Yorkers to name a classic Greek dish, and many would say moussaka  gooey layers of eggplant, ground meat and comfort. But a new breed of Greek restaurants here also serves dishes like rabbit phyllo, grilled branzino with artichoke confit and dandelion greens, and Cretan honey-braised lamb shank with yogurt pasta.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Wednesday about Irans effort to exert greater influence in Afghanistan omitted a credit. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London.

title: A Surprising Secret to a Long Life: Stay in School
description: James Smith, a health economist at the RAND Corporation, has heard a variety of hypotheses about what it takes to live a long life  money, lack of stress, a loving family, lots of friends. But he has been a skeptic.

title: Layoffs Imminent at Philadelphia Inquirer
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to announce today that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper and its sister publication, The Daily News.

title: A Hanging and a Funeral
description: Last Saturday was a strange day. It started with the hanging of Saddam Hussein. The more I read about the hasty, quasi-legal maneuvers used by Iraqs Shiite leaders to rush Saddam to the gallows on a Muslim holiday, Id al-Adha, and the more I watched the grainy cellphone video of the event, in which a guard is heard taunting Saddam with chants of Moktada! Moktada!  the Shiite cleric whose death squads have killed hundreds of Sunnis  and the more I read of the insults Saddam spat back, the more it resembled a tribal revenge ritual rather than the culmination of a constitutional process in which America should be proud to have participated.

title: Now Its Belaruss Turn
description: A year after Russia put the gas squeeze on Ukraine, it was Belaruss turn. Unlike Ukraine, Belarus blinked two minutes before the Jan. 1 deadline and Russia had its booty: a 50 percent share of Belaruss pipeline network and a more than doubling of the price Belarus will now pay for Russian gas.

title: After Bringing Adu to Utah, Checketts Wants Him to Stay
description: Few people would accuse Dave Checketts of not thinking ahead, whether in the N.B.A., the N.H.L. or M.L.S.

title: Spitzer Seeks Sweeping Changes in Albany
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  In his first annual address to the Legislature, Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed to overhaul almost every corner of the states operations and policies, saying he would move swiftly to guarantee health insurance for all children in the state, publicly finance state elections, rein in spending and draft a constitutional amendment to overhaul the states courts.

title: In Croatia, an Empty Life in Full View
description: I Love You, a bleak drama from the Croatian writer and director Dalibor Matanic, is an unusually perceptive scrutiny of absence and emptiness. Set in the filmmakers hometown, Zagreb, the movie follows a young advertising hotshot named Kreso (Kresimir Mikic), whose life is a thoughtless round of drinking, drugs and sex. When he gets into trouble, his lawyer father bails him out; when he is lonely, his gym buddies are preferable to the live-in girlfriend he barely speaks to. Then he learns he is H.I.V.-positive.

title: Blairs Deputy Calls Taunting of Hussein at Execution Deplorable
description: LONDON, Jan. 2  Britains deputy prime minister said Tuesday that the taunting and baiting that accompanied Saddam Husseins execution was unacceptable and that the people responsible should be condemned for taking part.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about American military members who have died in the Iraq war misstated the number of crewmates who survived an explosion that killed a tank driver, Specialist Jordan W. Hess. There were three, not four.

title: An American University for Iraq but Not in Baghdad
description: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq  It would be an ambitious project even in a Middle Eastern country not embroiled in war: build an American-style university where classes are taught in English, teachers come from around the world and graduates compete for lucrative jobs in fields like business and computer science.

title: Panel Seeks End to Death Penalty for New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2  A legislative commission recommended on Tuesday that New Jersey become the first state to abolish the death penalty since states began reinstating their capital punishment laws 35 years ago. Its report found no compelling evidence that capital punishment serves a legitimate purpose, and increasing evidence that it is inconsistent with evolving standards of decency.

title: Luring Americans to Spain
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Long neglected as one of Spains secondary cities, Valencias role as host of the Americas Cup this year and its ambitious efforts to showcase new architecture are enticing an increasing number of expatriates to visit the City of Oranges.

description: Bad habits can be hard to break. So its great news that Wal-Mart is putting its considerable heft behind one of the easiest ways to reduce energy consumption and the production of global-warming gases: the corkscrew-shaped light bulbs of the future.

title: SoHo Bounces Back as a Fashion Center
description: Before Sept. 11, 2001, SoHo seemed on the way to emerging as one of the most prestigious shopping districts in Manhattan. But after the attack on the World Trade Center, many retailers eventually left their stores after it appeared that shoppers had abandoned the district.

title: Yankees Crave Young Pitchers, but Have One Eye on Clemens
description: The Yankees hope to have at least one 44-year-old starting pitcher later this year. If they can trade Randy Johnson to the Arizona Diamondbacks, they will have more money available to sign Roger Clemens.

description: A picture caption with an article on Dec. 27 about land that is being rented from farmers in Skagit County, Wash., to create a habitat for birds misidentified the birds shown on flooded land. They were waterfowl, not shorebirds.

description: The dollar slumped yesterday and the euro climbed to a three-week high against the currency.

description: An art review in Weekend on Dec. 15 about Queens International 2006, at the Queens Museum of Art, misspelled the given name of the artist whose embroidered panels explore female sexuality. She is Blanka Amezcua, not Blanca.

title: Iraq Defends Hussein Execution, but Detains Guard
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 3  The Iraqi prime ministers office on Wednesday mounted its first public defense of the way the government carried out the execution of Saddam Hussein, and it said that Iraqi authorities had detained a guard whom they believed was involved in recording the moment in a macabre and unauthorized video that has generated revulsion around the world.

description: College stinks. Just ask Emily Watson, a sophomore at Dartmouth, who sprays her dorm room once a week and her clothes two to three times a week with fresheners, usually in citrus or other fruity flavors.

title: Singapore: Growth Spurt in Quarter
description: Singapores economic growth unexpectedly accelerated in the fourth quarter to the fastest pace in a year as a record number of tourists and an all-time high stock market spurred service industries and helped offset lower electronics exports. Its economy grew an annualized 7.6 percent in the final three months of 2006, after expanding a revised 5.6 percent in the third quarter, the trade ministry said. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in his New Years message that the pace of expansion may ease in 2007 because of an economic slowdown in the United States and weaker global demand for electronics, which account for about half the $118 billion economys exports. The economy may expand between 4 percent and 6 percent this year, Mr. Lee said.

title: Protecting Internet Democracy
description: One of the big winners in the last election may turn out to be the principle, known as net neutrality, that Internet service providers should not be able to favor some content over others. Democrats who are moving into the majority in Congress  led by Ron Wyden in the Senate and Edward Markey in the House  say they plan to fight hard to pass a net neutrality bill, and we hope that they do. It is vital to preserve the Internets role in promoting entrepreneurship and free expression.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Setback in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2  Massachusetts, the only state where same-sex marriage is legal, took a first step toward possibly banning it Tuesday when legislators voted to advance a constitutional amendment defining marriage as the union between a man and a woman.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about mourning for former President Gerald R. Ford in Palm Desert, Calif., misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976.

title: Police Call Womans Death Murder for Hire
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 2  A man accused of fatally shooting the owner of a beauty salon here had been hired by a companion she was trying to break up with, the police said on Tuesday.

title: Trying to Clear Absinthes Reputation
description: READERS of Ernest Hemingway know Death in the Afternoon as a book about bullfighting. But to drinkers with a taste for obscure booze, it is also a cocktail that Hemingway contributed to a 1935 collection of celebrity recipes. His directions: Pour one jigger absinthe into a Champagne glass. Add iced Champagne until it attains the proper opalescent milkiness. Drink three to five of these slowly.

title: Israeli Admits Big Errors in Lebanon War, but Wont Resign
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2  The Israeli chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, conceded Tuesday that the military had made serious errors during last summers war against Hezbollah in Lebanon but said he would not resign his post.

description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Have you ever made a profit from a catering business or dog walking? Do you prefer to work alone or in groups? Have you ever set a world record in anything?

description: If medical researchers were to pick someone who might defy national life expectancy statistics, few would pick Irma Lara.

description: Ensco International Inc., a United States oil and natural gas driller, will join the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, replacing BellSouth, S.& P. said yesterday in a statement posted on its Web site.

description: EGL, a manager of freight services for customers, said yesterday that its chief executive, James R. Crane, and a private equity firm had offered to buy the company for $1.2 billion.

description: The topic was the Democratic sweep in New Hampshire in November, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton couldnt get enough of it.
