title: Annie Leibovitz Gets Her Close-Up (No Need for Touch-Ups)
description: Annie Leibovitz: Life Through a Lens, which makes its debut on PBS tonight, reminds us how profoundly American culture values branding, not only from software packagers and congressional candidates but also from artists high and low. Just as a Whopper can be confused with no other hamburger, Ms. Leibovitzs photographs of the beloved and ignominious are virtually impossible to mistake for someone elses. Her work raises interesting questions about the primacy of creative signature  to what extent should we consider distinctiveness its own merit? But the failure of Life Through a Lens is its refusal to embark on this inquiry at all.

title: Teddy Kollek Dies at 95; Led Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2  Teddy Kollek, who as mayor of Jerusalem for nearly three decades did more to build and develop the city as Israels capital than any other figure while promoting coexistence with a sometimes hostile Arab population, died Tuesday in Jerusalem. He was 95.

title: Hossa Delivers for Rangers in Shootout With Devils
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 2  In the excitement of a shootout against the Devils on Tuesday night, a game the Rangers felt they desperately needed to win, Marcel Hossa took the ice as the Rangers eighth shooter.

title: Brown, Slice, Brown, Sauce
description: PORK tenderloin, like its relative the beef tenderloin (sometimes called filet mignon), is among the leanest cuts of meat. Its versatility, ease of cooking and eating  there are no bones and essentially no fat  and relatively low price have made it popular.

title: Giving Minority Students a Push Along the Path to Leadership Roles
description: On a recent cold Saturday, when most children around the city were relaxing after a week at school, 320 boys and girls, ages 10 to 13, filed into Nightingale-Bamford, a private girls school in a stately brick building on the Upper East Side.

title: Ensuring College Access (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Recipe: Slow-Cooked Beef With Cracked Wheat
description: Time: 3 hours

title: From the Stage to the Movie Screen, Seeing the Dancer in a Different Light
description: In the very best of this years Dance on Camera offerings, there is a sense of looking back. Documentaries celebrate artists who have transformed the field; stage adaptations preserve treasured productions for the long haul; and stylistic experiments show the way directors radically changed the approach of filming dance.

title: A Brooklyn Furrier and Artist Finds Soul Mates Among the Indians of the West
Muslims in the Melting Pot: Portraits of a Post-9/11 World
description: A few weeks ago a conference of accomplished Muslim women gathered at the Westin Hotel near Times Square to debate how women might exert greater influence on the interpretation of Islamic Scriptures. During a panel discussion, an Iranian-born anthropologist from Britain said she seconded the position taken by the Labor politician Jack Straw, that the full facial veils worn by some Muslims have no place in Western society because they erase a womans humanity.

title: Cuomos Opening Moves Echo Spitzers Reform Ideas
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo began his first full day in office yesterday by meeting with officials who could play a pivotal role in investigating any state corruption cases in Albany. This opening step signals that he intends to join in Gov. Eliot Spitzers calls for major reform of the capitals political culture.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Thursday with an article about Dance Theater Workshops program to provide subsidized rehearsal space outside Manhattan carried an erroneous credit. While the picture of the dancer Miguel Gutierrez was indeed by Julieta Cervantes, the picture of his rehearsal space in Woodside, Queens, was by Todd Richmond.

title: The Two Sides of Jim Tressel
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Jim Tressels six years of coaching Ohio State have presented a jarring contrast of Ozzie and Harriet virtue and Ozzy Osbourne excess.

title: For Boise State, Winning Respect Is the Real Trick
description: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 2  After scoring the winning 2-point conversion on a Statue of Liberty play and proposing to his girlfriend on national television, Boise State tailback Ian Johnson could have completed the storybook night by saying he was going to Disneyland.

title: Controversy Rules Oscar Contenders
description: I didnt go there to make a point, said Laura Poitras, a documentary filmmaker, about traveling in Iraq to make My Country, My Country, one of four documentaries about the war contending for Oscar nominations this year.

title: Serving Memory
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ford Is Remembered at Funeral in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  In a soaring tribute to a modest man, Gerald R. Ford was remembered on Tuesday as bringing the ordinary virtues of decency, integrity and humility to mend a broken government after the pain of war and scandal.

title: N.F.L. Parity Ensures Anxiety Is Shared Equally
description: It was not Michael Vick and the ingenuity required to coach him that unraveled Jim Mora in Atlanta or Arizonas genetic losing disorder that vanquished Dennis Green in the desert.

title: Parolee With Violent Past Is Charged in 2 L.I. Killings
description: A parolee who has served more than 30 years in prison for two separate homicides and other violent crimes in New York City was arrested yesterday by the Suffolk County police and charged in the shooting deaths of a 52-year-old woman and her 30-year-old son over the weekend.

title: Euro-Wary Slovenians Already Miss Their Tolar
description: Ivanka Rihtar has seen four currencies come and go in Slovenia during her lifetime. Ms. Rihtar, a 70-year-old storekeeper, has little nostalgia for any of them today.

title: Music and Food? The Pros Step In
description: DREW NIEPORENT still remembers the afternoon in the 1970s when Warner LeRoy ordered him to turn off the Barbra Streisand eight-track.

title: Hey! Never Underestimate the Average Joe
description: The King of Queens, the longest-running live-action comedy currently on television, is the opposite of an acquired taste. Like pizza or the Doors, the show just hits the spot  the simple, happy sitcom spot.

title: Chrysler Is Only U.S. Carmaker to See Sales Gains
description: DETROIT, Jan. 3  The Chrysler Group was the only Detroit carmaker to report a sales increase for December, while the Japanese carmakers Toyota and Honda both saw their sales grow last month, figures from the auto companies showed today.

title: Ill Have What They Dont Know About Yet
description: OFF the menu. Have sweeter words ever been spoken, especially by New Yorkers? We all believe we deserve something more special than the people at the next table, and whos to say were wrong?

title: Indonesian Officials Now Say They Dont Know Fate of Missing Jet
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 2  Indonesian officials reversed themselves on Tuesday and admitted that they did not know what had happened to a passenger jet that disappeared from radar screens in bad weather on Monday shortly after issuing a distress signal.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about four shows at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens misstated the name of the artist who has a large embroidered silk screen in the Gold Standard show. He is Kent Henricksen, not Kurt Hendrickson.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ANNIE LEIBOVITZ: LIFE THROUGH A LENS Ms. Leibovitz is arguably the most influential woman photographer in the country. But her private life is rarely exposed. In this documentary, which closes the 20th season of American Masters, Ms. Leibovitz shares her artistic process with her younger sister, the filmmaker Barbara Leibovitz, as she travels from her Manhattan studio to her idyllic farm in upstate New York, and through countless photo shoots and the creation of her latest retrospective book, while trying to balance career and motherhood.

title: Agency Lifts Restrictions on Caviar
description: ALL the nations surrounding the Caspian Sea can resume exporting sevruga and osetra caviar, an international environmental agency ruled yesterday. The agency, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or Cites, said the nations efforts to monitor the depletion of endangered sturgeon had improved.

title: Iraq to Review Husseins Execution
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 2  Iraqs Shiite-led government said Tuesday that it had ordered an investigation into the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, who was subjected to a battery of taunts by official Shiite witnesses and guards as he awaited his hanging.

title: What You Get for ... $575,000
description: McHenry, Md.

title: Enron's Last Victim: American Markets
description: Washington

title: Weis Has His Focus On Game, Not Giants
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2  Notre Dame Coach Charlie Weis tried his best Tuesday to remove his name from consideration for the not-yet-vacant Giants coaching job, saying emphatically that he was not a liar.

title: Two Governors Brace for a Showdown Over How Deep a River Should Run
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2  The Delaware River, which separates New Jersey and Pennsylvania, is putting distance between the Democratic governors of the two states, who are at a standoff over the financing and environmental implications of a plan to deepen the river for larger cargo ships and oil tankers.

title: Male Misery Just Loves Female Company
description: Time magazine shocked America by asking Is God Dead? on its cover in 1966. Vanity Fair is now needling the nation with Christopher Hitchenss essay Why Women Arent Funny.

title: Knicks Francis Is Forgotten, but Not Officially Gone
description: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 2  Steve Francis is gone, whether for days, weeks or months, and it is possible the Knicks will be better for it. For all of his innate talent, Francis has spent an entirely forgettable 11 months in a city that has not embraced him and with a franchise that perhaps did not want him.

title: Ethics Overhaul Tops Agenda for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  On the precipice of regaining power after 12 years, House Democrats Wednesday said they would move immediately to try to sever ties between lawmakers and lobbyists that figured into scandals that helped Democrats win control of Congress.

title: The Ex-Presidents Club Bids a Member Goodbye
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  In a moment of presidential empathy, former President George Bush recalled a skill he had learned from Gerald R. Ford: how to handle being ridiculed on Saturday Night Live.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Numbers Put Up by the Defense Dont Add Up to a Giants Title
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 2  Lost behind the stir of a fired offensive coordinator and the unbending focus on offensive stars  Tiki this, Eli that, Shockey here, Plaxico there  toils the part of the Giants that most threatens their chance to win a championship:

title: From Sex Trade to Vultures: Asia Outside In
description: Film Forums omnibus of work by the writer-director-cinematographer-editor Ellen Bruno covers a spectrum of Asian subjects. The 50-minute featurette Sacrifice depicts young Burmese girls conscripted into prostitution in Thailand; the bill also includes shorts about a village of Nepalese lepers and a Tibetan monastery where body breakers feed the stripped flesh and ground bones of the dead to giant vultures.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an investigation into the possibility that banks are luring hedge funds as tenants in order to solicit their trading business misstated the nature of a request made by the Massachusetts secretary of state, William F. Galvin, to UBS, the Swiss bank. While Mr. Galvin has requested information from UBS, he has not issued a subpoena. UBS is cooperating with the inquiry.

title: Sick and Cant Go to School? Or, Sick Because You Didnt Go?
Tillie Olsen, Feminist Writer, Dies at 94
description: Tillie Olsen, whose short stories, books and essays lent a heartfelt voice to the struggles of women and working-class people, died on Monday in Oakland, Calif. She was 94.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Bowl for the Ages
description: Boise State's victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl will be remembered as one of the most exciting in college football history.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Mantels, screens and glass to add sparkle.

title: Currents Slide Show
description: Accents for the home, brushed with darkness, turning 60 and reflecting on the past and more.

title: A Pocketful of Better Skiing
description: Wax your skis and snowboards at home.

title: Galvin Sees Broader Hedge-Fund Concerns
description: William F. Galvin, Massachusetts secretary of state, said yesterday that his investigation of UBSs relationship with certain hedge funds, reported in Tuesdays New York Times, stems from broader concerns about the practices of a lightly regulated corner of the financial services industry, The Boston Globe reported. He said UBS officials have agreed to provide testimony about the firms relationship with hedge fund traders who operate out of UBSs Boston office.

title: BenQ to Liquidate German Unit As White Knight Fails to Emerge
description: The German mobile phone unit that the Taiwan company BenQ bought from Siemens will shut down, after no investor stepped in to rescue it. Once among the top phone brands, the phone maker first stumbled under Siemens and then collapsed under BenQ because both owners failed to compete on a global scale with rivals like Nokia.

title: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
description: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

title: At Home With Ann Brashares and Jacob Collins
description: A visit to the renovated New York City carriage house of Ann Brashares, author of the "Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants" books.

title: Global Rally on First Day of Trading in New Year
description: Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers would support global equities for a fifth year. Share indexes in all 16 West European markets gained, while benchmarks in Australia, Hong Kong and Indonesia climbed to records. In Latin America, equity gauges in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico headed toward all-time highs.

title: Unicredit Buys Stake in Moscow Bank
description: The Eastern European division of Unicredit of Italy agreed Tuesday to buy a 20 percent stake in a Russian lender, the International Moscow Bank.

title: CheckFree Takes Carreker into the Fold
description: CheckFree, an Atlanta-based provider of electronic bill payment and electronic banking services, said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Carreker for $8.05 a share, or a total of $206 million. CheckFree said the deal for Carreker, a Dallas-based provider of payments technology and consulting services for the financial services industry, will help it expand in software and consulting.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Close Deal for Nortel Unit
description: Alcatel-Lucent, a maker of telecommunications network equipment, said Tuesday it had completed its acquisition of Nortel Networks UMTS radio access business after winning regulatory approval.

title: Undertaker to Start-Ups Evolves Amid Good Times for Entrepeneurs
description: While times may be good for venture capitalists and the start-ups they fund, things are not looking so hot for firms like Sherwood Partners, long known in the industry as the undertaker. Firms like Sherwood are in the business of shutting down failed start-ups, and The San Jose Mercury News reports that Sherwood wound down 180 start-ups in its heyday during the dot-com bust.

title: A New Sheriff With a Different Agenda?
description: Now that Eliot Spitzer, whom some called the Sheriff of Wall Street, has moved into the New York governors mansion, financial-industry observers are turning their eyes to his successor as New York attorney general, the freshly sworn-in Andrew Cuomo.

title: Venture-Backed I.P.O.s on Deck Double
description: The number of venture-backed initial public offerings awaiting their stock market debut more than doubled at the start of 2007 with a tech filing from Omneon Video Networks marking a late-entry addition to the roster. Hailing largely from the tech sector, the ranks of venture-backed I.P.O.s swelled to 36 as of Tuesday, up from 16 in the same period last year, according to a survey by the National Venture Capital Association and Thomson Financial. The numbers, however, are down from the start of the busy fourth quarter of 2006, when 51 were waiting to take a crack at the public markets.

title: Refco Emerges From Bankruptcy
description: Refco, the commodities broker that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2005, has exited Chapter 11 and is starting to make initial payouts to creditors. The firm formally emerged on Dec. 26 under a liquidation plan, although its estate still faces disputed claims and expected lawsuits from creditors, The Deal reported.

title: EGL Gets Buyout Bid From Its Chief
description: EGL, a manager of freight services for customers, said yesterday that its chief executive, James R. Crane, and a private equity firm had offered to buy the company for $1.2 billion. Mr. Crane, EGLs founder and largest shareholder with an 18 percent stake, and the equity firm General Atlantic want to pay $36 a share for the rest of the stock, EGL said yesterday.

title: Winter Garden's Drive Time Ends
description: The Winter Garden Theater officially returned to Broadway on Monday as simply the Winter Garden Theater, after almost five years of working under another name: the Cadillac Winter Garden.

title: Layoffs Imminent at Philadelphia Inquirer
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to announce Wednesday that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper and its sister publication, The Daily News. The Philadelphia papers were sold in March by Knight Ridder to the McClatchy newspaper group, which in turn sold them to a group of businessmen, led by Brian P. Tierney, an advertising and public relations executive.

title: Shanghai May Overtake Hong Kong in I.P.O.s This Year
description: After beating out the New York Stock Exchange in initial public offerings this year to take the I.P.O. crown, Hong Kongs stock market might see itself outdone by its mainland competitor. Shanghais bourse is expected to attract $26 billion in fundraising this year, overtaking Hong Kong, as more of the nations largest companies sell shares domestically, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers. Hong Kong, by contrast, is expected to receive 150 billion Hong Kong dollars ($19.3 billion) in I.P.O.s in 2007.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Previews dont begin until next Wednesday, but the run of the Classic Stage Companys presentation of the American premiere of A Spanish Play, written by Yasmina Reza, directed by John Turturro and featuring Zoe Caldwell, has been extended by two weeks, through March 4, at the theater at 136 East 13th Street, East Village.

title: Amgen Acquires Option for a Heart Failure Drug
description: Making a further move into the market for cardiovascular drugs, the biotechnology giant Amgen has formed an alliance with Cytokinetics, a smaller company developing an experimental drug to treat heart failure. Under the agreement, which is expected to be announced Wednesday, Amgen will pay Cytokinetics $75 million to gain an option on the drug, which is about to enter the second of three stages of clinical trials.

title: Energy Investments Likely to Burn Even Hotter This Year
description: Venture capitalists are expected to pump even more money into energy ventures in 2007 after doubling their bets last year amid shifting politics and global-warming worries. Venture capital investment in energy start-ups exploded in the first three quarters of 2006, hitting $536 million, compared with $224 million in all of 2005, according to industry tracker Dow Jones VentureOne. Now, V.C.s are returning to the sector, following a sea change of interest in alternatives to conventional energy sources, John Denniston, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, told USA Today.

title: Industry Ventures Bags $105 Million for New Fund
description: A secondary fund operator, Industry Ventures, raised $105 million in committed capital for its fourth fund aimed at buying up venture capital investments from corporate portfolios, liquidating funds and special situation investors looking for early liquidity.

title: ICV and Palladium Sell Eyewear Supplier Hilsinger
description: ICV Capital Partners and Palladium Equity Partners said Tuesday they sold a vision-products business, Hilsinger Holdings to PNC Equity Partners in a secondary buyout that The Deal.com said was valued at more than $100 million. The sale allowed ICV and Palladium to pocket 2.5 times their original money and yielded an internal rate of return of more than 30 percent.

title: Apple, Google and Napster Named in Patent Lawsuit
description: Intertainer, a video-on-demand company, last week filed a broad lawsuit asserting that Apple, Google and Napster are infringing on a 2005 patent that covers the commercial distribution of audio and video over the Internet.

title: Sharper Image Cuts Chiefs Severance to Offset Options Gain
description: The specialty retailer Sharper Image chopped more than $3 million from the severance pay of its founder and recently departed chief executive, Richard Thalheimer, to offset his past windfalls from favorably priced stock options. The package, disclosed in a regulatory filing late last week, includes retirement benefits of $3.9 million and a severance payment of $1.78 million, below the $5 million minimum guaranteed to Mr. Thalheimer under a contract signed in 2002.

title: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency
description: The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles for the company, officials said on Tuesday. In Japan, Europe and the United States, Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego, faces accusations by rivals that it has abused its market dominance in wireless technology to demand excessive royalties and block fair competition.

title: Class Action Suits Hit All-Time Low in 2006
description: Class action lawsuits filed over securities fraud reached an all-time low in 2006, according to a Stanford Law School report. The drop is linked to tougher federal enforcement on securities fraud, a stronger stock market with lower price volatility and the settlements of the slew of securities fraud lawsuits filed in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the report said.

title: Enron Accountant Heads to Jail
description: Richard A. Causey, Enrons former chief accounting officer, was on his way Tuesday to a federal prison in Bastrop, Tex., to begin a 5 1/2-year sentence for his role in the fraud that destroyed the company. Mr. Causey, 46, pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud in December 2005, less than a month before he was to stand trial with former chief executives Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, both of whom were found guilty.

title: Malone and Dolans Talk about Cable Networks Deal, Report Says
description: As shareholders await Cablevisions decision on a $19.2 billion buyout offer from the controlling Dolan clan, Liberty Medias John Malone has reached out to the family to talk about selling Rainbow Media, the unit that manages cable networks AMC, IFC and WE: Womens Entertainment, sources told The New York Post.

title: Home Depots Chief Resigns as Proxy Fight Looms
description: Home Depot, the giant home-improvement chain, said Wednesday that Robert L. Nardelli resigned as its chairman and chief executive. Mr. Nardellis departure, which the company said was part of a mutual agreement, comes amid mounting criticism of Home Depots executive compensation practices and its flagging stock price.

title: Specter of Saddam Shopping in Baghdad?
description: According to a recent gem in the India Daily, some people in Baghdad are claiming that they are seeing Saddam Husseins ghost in Baghdad public areas.

title: Alleged Hussein-Execution Auteur Arrested
description: The Times of London is reporting that the Iraqi government has arrested a prison guard  for filming and posting to the Internet the unauthorized video showing the hanging of Saddam Hussein on Saturday.

title: The Day the Earth Stood Still
description: Those of you who have been drinking a bit too deeply from the Oscar cup may not have heard that Gerald R. Ford, a common man who came to the presidency in an uncommon way, has died. The funeral for the 38th president of the United States took place yesterday at Washington National Cathedral.

title: The Democrats Hill: First 100-plus Hours
description: The schedule for the much-touted first 100 hours in the House is shaping upit starts late, and it takes more than 100 hours, as Carl Hulse explains:

title: The President Restates His Principles
description: President Bush shows up on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal to explain to the new Democratic Congress how he views his principles and his key legislative accomplishments of the previous six years. He also previews his administrations forthcoming new strategy in Iraq. Bush writes:

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Lost and Found
description: Rudy Giulianis camp is crying dirty trickery, saying that a campaign dossier obtained by the Daily News was stolen last fall. His aides played down the importance of the documents, with spokeswoman Sunny Mindel calling it akin to a grocery list from October, written in pencil. Still, the camp has its theories on how it fell from custody. Maggie Haberman at the New York Post traces the broken chain of custody to lost luggage of an aide while Mr. Giuliani was campaigning in Florida for the states soon-to-be elected governor, Charles Crist.Senator Barack Obamas dirty laundry wasnt aired through some dastardly deed, but rather by every politicians own worst enemy: himself. Mr. Obama never really suffered from confessions about drug use in his first book, Dreams from my Father, during his Senate race, but the narrative could be problematic in a presidential campaign, writes Lois Romano in The Washington Post. Then theres also more name confusion. Why, it was just on Tuesday that CNNs Wolf Blitzer had to apologize to Mr. Obama for mistakenly using his name in a headline _ Wheres Obama _ on a graphic when they meant Osama, as in bin Laden.

title: Color Combos: Can You Name the School?
description: Many schools use these colors, but they're most identified with famous universities (among the 10 top earners for merchandise licensed by the Collegiate Licensing Company). So name them.

title: Chinas New Cultural Revolution
description: More images from some emerging Chinese contemporary artists.

title: The Tech Expert Is Stumped
description: For a year or so, I contributed monthly answers to the Ask a Tech Expert column in Best Life magazine. One reader question, Im embarrassed to say, stumped me (I wrote about something else that month):

title: Kravis and Roberts on the Buyout Boom
description: Two of the three names behind private equity behemoth Kohlberg Kravis Roberts weighed in on the state of the buyout industry in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. Henry Kravis and George Roberts told the newspaper that much has changed since the firms first leveraged buyout in 1979 (price: $355 million). These days, banks are eager to lend billions of dollars to help take companies private, although Mr. Roberts suggests that debt is used more judiciously than it was in the go-go 1980s. He said:

title: Should U.S. C.E.O.s Prepare for a Tougher 2007?
description: Despite recommendations that federal regulations over corporate governance be lightened, American chief executives expect further challenges this year to their control over the companies they run, according to The Financial Times. Developments like stock-options backdating, anger over executive compensation and increased shareholder activism have contributed to a more hostile environment for chief executives, who have been departing in greater numbers.

title: Second Life and the Peoples House
description: We can just see it now: the scantily clad women, flying chipmunks and robots roaming around the House of Representatives, debating health care policy and energy independence.

title: Gvle Goat Survives, But Will Interest?
description: This just in to update our story from last month  on the famous Christmas Goat of Gvle, Sweden.

title: Goldman Sachs: An Embarassment of Riches?
description: Lloyd Blankfein appears to have little in common with Marie Antoinette, but readers of Michael M. Thomass fiery opinion column in this weeks New York Observer can be forgiven for thinking otherwise. Mr. Thomas, a former investment banker and observer of Wall Street manners, has produced an incendiary diatribe that focuses on the year-end bonuses recently doled out at Goldman Sachs, where Mr. Blankfein is chief executive. Using revolutionary imagery, Mr. Thomas suggests that Goldmans bonuses could become a touchstone for a national (and possibly irrational) debate on the wealth gap.

title: Getting Touchy
description: Is this waiter too close for comfort?(Reuters/Lee Celano)

title: Paterson Returns to the Senate
description: Lieutenant Governor David A. Paterson returned to his old haunting grounds  the State Senate  where he now presides as one of his few official duties. He asked if all the Senators had been sworn in. Sworn in, not sworn at, he clarified.

title: Goldman, Citi Top List of 2006 M&A Deal Makers
description: After giving us a preview late last year, Thomson Financial this week sent DealBook its official tally of last years merger and acquisitions activity. Global M&A topped $3.8 trillion in 2006, a bump of nearly 38 percent over the previous year. Nearly 20 percent of the years deals involved private-equity buyers. And large swaths of the deal-making were handled by two investment banks, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

title: A Golden Goodbye for Home Depot Chief
description: When you are carrying $210 million in goodies, it is hard to make a quiet exit. This is especially true when you are Robert Nardelli, whose pay as the chief executive of Home Depot has long been a source of controversy. Hours after his resignation was announced early Wednesday, there were some strong reactions to Mr. Nardellis severance package, which the company valued at $210 million.

title: Should U.S. Airlines Give Foreign Owners a Try?
description: The Federal Aviation Act prohibits foreign investors from owning more than 25 percent of an American airline. This, writes Daniel Gross at Slate, is an example of sometimes misplaced hostility to foreigners, national-security paranoia, and plain-old protectionism. The law may be old, but its relevance is new, as many analysts think the United States airline industry is due a round of transformational mergers.

title: Revolving Door: Weil Gotshal
description: Law firm Weil Gotshal & Manges said Wednesday that it hired Michael J. Aiello as a partner in the mergers and acquisitions group of its corporate department. Mr. Aiello was previously a partner at Dewey Ballantine, where he was part of the legal team that advised Walt Disney as it fought off Comcasts unsolicited bid in 2004.

title: As Ben Tells It
description: Ben Affleck, who made something of a comeback last year with Hollywoodland, sits in on a roundtable conversation at the Hollywood Reporter  with Nicole Kidman, Edward Norton and Forest Whitaker. Mr. Affleck employs a little-used tactic in celebrity communications strategy: Telling the truth.

title: Eliot: Democrat? Republican? Other?
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers first State of the State is over, and large swaths of the speech struck a few of us as language that a Republican governor couldve easily delivered.

title: The Stealth Campaign
description: Trying to arrange to screen Factory Girl continues to be like tackling a blob of mercury. When the Baguette e-mailed a publicist at the Weinstein Company today she was told no screenings were planned for this week so far. But if not this week, when? The press has had so little chance to see and write about the actual film  as opposed to the hoopla around it  that Factory Girl seems basically to have been shut out of any awards consideration. Sure theres a one week run of the film in Los Angeles going on, but thats probably not going to be enough to get it in the mix.

title: An Investment Banking Love Story
description: How does a harried investment banker send love notes? By BlackBerry, of course.

title: Joy, Finally, From Buffalo
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers announcement that he would name a co-chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, based in Buffalo, to focus on revitalizating the upstate economy brought joy to Byron W. Brown.

title: War Protest Mom Upstages Democrats
description: Representative Rahm Emanuel was starting to address about 70 media types who had waited patiently for him to emerge from a meeting of the House Democratic Caucus on Capitol Hill. He wished everyone a Happy New Year, apologized for being late  45 minutes, if youre counting at home  and was promptly drowned out by a group of anti-war protestors.

title: The Producers Speak in Tongues
description: The first of the guilds is in, no thanks to the mail, and Babel, which got significant love from the Golden Globes, continues to be on a roll. The multi-lingual triptych, which stars Cate Blanchett and Brad Pitt, was selected as a nominee in the feature film category, along with The Departed, Dreamgirls, The Queen and Little Miss Sunshine. The inclusion of the wacky family in the van is good news for the backers of Little Miss, who have hoped that it will be the little movie that could. More than a few people have talked about how the movie has managed to hang on in the midst of it much larger competition. Letters From Iwo Jima was skunked.

title: The Mike Crew in Town
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his top aides are used to being the center of attention. But in the world of New York politics, City Hall has been eclipsed by the State Capitol this week.

title: Turning a Statistic On Its Head
description: In an op-ed article in todays Times, William A. Niskanen, the president of the Cato Institute, fails to understand a statistic on which he bases his conclusion that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act should be repealed.

title: F.B.I.: Witness to Guantnamo Abuses
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation on Tuesday released documents relating to a survey of 493 FBI personnel who were asked whether they observed aggressive mistreatment, interrogations or interview techniques used on detainees held at the U.S. military base at Guantnamo Bay in Cuba.

title: It Takes a Village
description: Patrick Healy and Adam Nagourney of The Times  describe  many interesting details from a series of nearly nonstop political consultations that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has engaged in since November as she prepares a probable run for the White House.

title: Thanks for Writing
description: We have been delighted by how many comments we have received. And not just from our relatives, though it is certainly good to hear from our parents and our cousin Keri.

title: Blogtalk
description: Reactions to Eliot Spitzers State of the State Address: Joe Bruno and an assortment of others, including a Pataki spokesman. [Capitol Confidential]Oh, and Larry Schwartz, deputy county executive in Westchester: great speechboldvisionary. [Politics on the Hudson]

title: Teatime With Pelosi
description: Pelosi-palooza (were totally stealing that from our colleague Anne Kornblut) kicked off today on a somber note, but the next round shifted into a celebration of gals in government.

title: Ethics Changes Proposed for House Trips, K Street
description: On the Houses first day of really any business, Representative Louise Slaughter, chairwoman of the Rules Committee, released a set of proposed ethics changes that would considerably alter how business is done on the Hill and might crimp the interchange between lobbyists and lawmakers.

title: For Your Consideration
description: Damn. So, as you surely know by now, one unsigned entry for the big 2006 Online Video Awards appeared just under the wire. December 30, 2006.

title: Construction Worker One Day, Celebrity Subway Hero the Next
description: Would you jump onto the subway tracks to save a stranger?

title: Spitzers Health Care Pledge Focuses on Easing the Way for Those Entitled
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer vowed yesterday to make health insurance available to all children and enroll all eligible adults in Medicaid. If carried out fully, his pledges would cut the number of uninsured New Yorkers in half.

title: Yonkers: Doctor Found Fatally Shot
description: A 46-year-old physician was found fatally shot on his bedroom floor yesterday afternoon, the Yonkers police said. The body of the physician, Dr. Leandro Lozada, who had a practice in the Bronx, was discovered by a friend around 3 p.m. at 43 Brendon Hill Road, the police said. They said that Dr. Lozada lived alone and that there was no sign of forced entry or a weapon.

title: Samsung to Unveil Slimmer Rear-Projection TVs
description: Samsung, the world's largest seller of televisions, will introduce at next week's Consumer Electronics Show a new line of rear-projection D.L.P. televisions that will not be much thicker than flat-panel TVs but will cost about 30 percent less.

title: Below Haze, Saturns Biggest Moon Has Lakes
description: As scientists have predicted but have had a hard time proving, the surface of Titan, Saturns largest moon, appears to be dotted with lakes of liquid methane. The lakes are more intriguing evidence of the active phenomena at play on the only moon in the solar system with a dense atmosphere.

title: Pakistan Wants Afghan Refugees Resettled
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 4  Pakistans prime minister, Shaukat Aziz, said today that three million Afghan refugees living in Pakistan must be resettled in their native country so that their refugee camps can no longer be used as safe havens by insurgents.

title: Lilly to Pay Up to $500 Million to Settle Claims
description: Eli Lilly agreed today to pay up to $500 million to settle 18,000 lawsuits from people who claimed they developed diabetes or other diseases after taking Zyprexa, Lillys drug for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder

title: Awaiting Bushs Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Some key Senate Democrats say they could consider supporting a short-term increase in American troop levels in Iraq, a stance that reflects division within the party and could provide an opening for President Bush as he prepares to announce his revised plan for Iraq as early as next week.

title: Harriet Miers Plans to Leave White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Harriet E. Miers, the White House counsel who endured a brief moment in the spotlight as President Bushs Supreme Court nominee in 2005, is leaving the administration, Mr. Bushs chief spokesman said today.

title: Britain: First Female Beefeater Appointed
description: The Tower of London, one of Britains most popular tourist attractions, has appointed a female guard for the first time in its 900-year history. She will join the ranks of the Yeoman Warders who wear a red-and-gold ceremonial uniform and are known as Beefeaters. The Yeoman Warders were officially appointed to guard the tower in 1485 and trace their origins even further back, to William the Conquerors reign in the 11th century. The origin of the term Beefeater is unclear. One theory is that the first guards were paid in beef. To join the 35-strong ranks of the Beefeaters, a candidate must have served 22 years in the armed forces.

title: The Ugly Death of Saddam Hussein
description: Saddam Hussein deserves no ones pity. But as anyone who has seen the graphic cellphone video of his hanging can testify, his execution bore little resemblance to dispassionate, state-administered justice. The condemned dictator appeared to have been delivered from United States military custody into the hands of a Shiite lynch mob.

title: A Big Hero in the Big City
description: New Yorkers have long rolled their eyes when politicians, TV commercials and after-dinner speakers endlessly extolled small-town values. The truth is that integrity, compassion and heroism are no scarcer on the sidewalks of Chicago or Harlem than they are in Dubuque. If anyone doubts this, they should consider Wesley Autreys heroic turn at the 137th Street and Broadway subway station this week.

title: Town Considers Guards for Library Disrupted by Students
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 3  The Maplewood Township Committee is asking the public librarys board of trustees not to follow through with a plan to close its two buildings during after-school hours and is considering providing security guards to help quell disruptive behavior, Mayor Fred R. Profeta Jr. said Wednesday.

title: And Now, the Eyes of Texas Are Upon Jones and Parcells
description: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 3  Bill Parcells was careful with his words, even as he picked a curious time to hint at his future as Dallas Cowboys coach.

title: Helping Make the Shift From Combat to Commerce
description: Coming home from their respective tours of duty in Iraq, John Reid and Alina Gutierrez had never met but they had a lot in common. Both were sergeants in the 42nd Infantry Division of the Army and were deployed in Iraq from autumn 2004 to autumn 2005. And both had a strong interest in running their own businesses when they got home.

title: Manhattan: Injuries From Fire Kill Man
description: A 65-year-old Washington Heights man was killed in his apartment last night by a fire that residents say was started with a hair dryer left on a bed by a neighbor living one floor below him, city officials and witnesses said. Neighbors said that fire alarms in the building did not go off, so they only became aware of the fire when they felt the heat of the flames and smelled the smoke in their building, at 517 West 160th Street. The man, identified by his brother as Miguel Grullon, was pronounced dead at a hospital a short while later.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit brought by Intertainer, a digital media company, against Apple Computer, Google and Napster misstated the nature of the litigation. It involves a patent, not a copyright.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture credit on Dec. 26 with the Books of The Times Review, about The Girl With the Gallery: Edith Gregor Halpert and the Making of the Modern Art Market, by Lindsay Pollock, misspelled the surname of the man whose estate holds the copyright to the picture of Mrs. Halpert. He was Louis Faurer, not Fauer.

title: Costly Calls From Prison (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Misgivings, White House Says Little Against Hanging
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  The White House declined Wednesday to criticize the conduct of the execution of Saddam Hussein, even as State Department officials and military leaders in Baghdad raised questions about the timing of the hanging and the way the condemned dictator was taunted by Shiite guards as he stood on the gallows.

title: France: Bill to Redress Homelessness
description: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin introduced legislation that would give the homeless an enforceable right to housing. The move was in response to a yearlong campaign on behalf of the homeless that included the distribution of tents for people living on the street. A concentration of the tents in the 10th Arrondissement in Paris brought the issue to a head, and on New Years Eve, President Jacques Chirac promised to ask the government to work on legislation. The proposed law, Mr. de Villepin said, would put the right to housing on the same level as the right to medical care or education.

title: A Store to Make Your Feet Say Ol
description: MANY years ago, I lived in Spain for a summer, teaching English at 5:45 a.m. to a group of pharmaceutical executives, most of whom knew only three words in English at the onset of the season: yes (enthusiastic bobbing of heads), no (sad frowns) and marketing (big smiles and thumbs-up gestures).

title: Giants See the Angles in a Prism Tinted Blue
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 3  At one end of the range of possibilities is a blowout first-round playoff loss to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday. On the opposite end is a Super Bowl victory next month.

title: From Hussein, a Florid Farewell to the Iraqi People
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 3  The dictator sat alone in his cell, three years in American custody. His beard had gone gray, his sons were dead and the gallows were being readied.

title: France: Deadline for Suez Bid Disclosure
description: The French stock market regulator, Autorit des Marchs Financiers, will set a deadline next week for the billionaire Franois Pinault to say whether he plans to make an offer for the utility Suez. Failure to meet the deadline would prevent Mr. Pinaults holding company, Artemis, from bidding for the company for six months, unless there were significant changes in Suezs situation or shareholder structure, the regulatory agency said. Suez, which supplies water and electric power, asked the regulator on Tuesday to set a deadline after reports surfaced that Artemis was considering the acquisition.

title: The Sky Wasnt Falling, Just a Tiny Chunk of It
description: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 3  Whatever it was, the object that fell from the sky was not part of an airplane. That was all anyone knew for sure.

title: Resisting the Big Contract and the Quick Fix
description: This being the fourth day of January, it is not too early to talk about baseball  even in New York, with our two local pro football teams in the playoffs.

title: New Disc May Sway DVD Wars
description: Consumers wary of buying new high-definition DVD players because of a technology war reminiscent of the days of Betamax versus VHS will soon have a new kind of DVD that might make the decision less daunting.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an Iraqi government investigation of the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, including the unauthorized cellphone camera recording of it, misstated the account of a witness who said he saw two others there holding cellphone cameras aloft to record Mr. Husseins final moments. While the witness, Munkith al-Faroun, a prosecutor at Mr. Husseins trial, said both of the others were officials, he did not identify one of them as Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser. Mr. Rubaie, who could not be reached for comment in the article, said yesterday that he had handed his cellphone to security officials an hour before the hanging and had not recorded it. title: Another Thousand Lives
description: How long can this go on?

title: Big East Nearing Perfection in Bowl Games
description: With just a handful of days remaining in the college football season, it is not too early to declare which conference had the best year in 2006.

title: Kenya Closes Border but Denies Turning Back Refugees
description: BAIDOA, Somalia, Jan. 3  Kenyan officials announced Wednesday that they were closing their northern border because of the conflict in Somalia, but denied that they had turned back hundreds of refugees.

title: Giuliani Leak: Attention Turns to Florida
description: Mischief in presidential politics in Florida?

title: Romney Takes Step Toward an 08 Run
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  On his last full day as governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney created a presidential exploratory committee Wednesday, the first formal step in a likely run for the 2008 Republican nomination.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Barbara Walters Sails Into Troubled Waters

title: Taiwans Bullet Trains Cant Outrun Controversy
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 28  The sleek, bulbous-nosed new bullet trains here look like they are designed to whisk passengers across wide-open spaces. But on this congested island, they represent the start of a 180-mile-per-hour commuter train system.

title: Markets Finish Mixed as Fed Hints at Nagging Concern With Inflation
description: Stocks surged early yesterday, the first trading day of 2007, but fell sharply after minutes from a Federal Reserve meeting indicated that inflation remained the chief concern of policy makers even as they started to worry about a weakening economy. Markets closed mixed for the day.

title: Tennessees Tax on Illegal Drugs Nets $3.5 Million
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 3  Tennessee has collected nearly $3.5 million since it began enforcing its tax on illegal drugs two years ago, officials from the Department of Revenue said Wednesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the debate over free will misstated the location of Elizabethtown College, where Michael Silberstein, who commented on free will and popular culture, is a science philosopher. It is in Pennsylvania, not Maryland.

title: Catch the Next Chapter on Your iPod (Its Even Cheaper)
description: On a recent afternoon Laura Wilson was speaking through a microphone to Oliver Wyman, who was on the other side of a pane of glass. Just hit Samaritan a little harder, she said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the most popular movies of 2006 and others that did not do as well at the box office referred incorrectly to two languages spoken in Babel, one of the films with subtitles that did not draw big crowds. They are Spanish and Berber, not Mexican and Moroccan.

title: To Sleep, Perchance to Succeed
description: FOR those who have failed in a decade or threes worth of New Years resolutions to become better workers, spouses, parents, athletes or lovers, there is a new frontier in personal growth  or at least a proliferation of products, mostly hawked over the Internet, that promise to help turn the last bit of untrammeled downtime (sleep) into an opportunity for improvement.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The On Education column yesterday, about A Better Chance, a nonprofit group that helps minority children apply to private day and boarding high schools, misstated the surname of the president of the group and omitted her middle initial. She is Sandra E. Timmons, not Simmons.

title: Comptroller Voices Concern About Brooklyn Golf Deal
description: A $9.6 million city contract to renovate and operate a golf course in Marine Park in Brooklyn was headed for further review yesterday after the city comptroller raised concerns about ties between the contractor and a man accused of being a soldier in the Colombo crime family.

title: Exxon Accused of Trying to Mislead Public
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 3  The Union of Concerned Scientists released a report on Wednesday accusing Exxon Mobil of spending millions of dollars to manipulate public opinion on the seriousness of global warming.

title: Dress Their Way
description: WHEN self-improvement begins at home, alone, in the closet, it most often ends on the couch, alone, watching television. Fortunately, as marathon viewings of What Not to Wear on TLC remind us, reforming our errant ways in fashion is best done with professional help, of which there is a sudden outpouring.

title: A Snit in First Class
description: I have a dream, my friends. I have a dream that we are approaching the day when a ranch-owning millionaire Republican like George Bush will make peace with a vineyard-owning millionaire Democrat like Nancy Pelosi.

title: Importing Contacts From Eudora
description: Q. Is there a way to transfer a large address book from Eudora to another e-mail program?

title: Chasing Solar Power in the Northeast
description: HOME solar systems in the Northeast can produce up to 90 percent of the electricity generated by those in California, said Michael Hall, chief marketing officer for Borrego Solar Systems, a company in California. It is not surprising, then, that some California installers are expanding nationally. They include PowerLight and Akeena Solar, which opened offices in New Jersey in the last two years.

title: Childhood Friends, Partners in Crime
description: Marcus Sakey is a first-time author who successfully jump-starts his first book, The Blade Itself. He does this with a nod to Dennis Lehanes Mystic River, which is never a bad gambit for a hard-charging thriller. So Mr. Sakey presents a group of young Irish guys from the Old Neighborhood (in this case on the South Side of Chicago). He describes a crime committed in their shadowy past. And he guarantees that the crime will come back to bite them.

title: Vietnam: Bird Flu Measures Stepped Up
description: Vietnam, which wiped out avian flu in its poultry in 2005, is facing a resurgence and has ordered millions of vaccine doses from China to quell it, health officials said. Since last month, the disease has been found in more than 25 villages in three provinces. Officials blamed farmers who evaded twice-yearly vaccination drives and the smuggling of chickens and ducks from China as demand surges for next months celebration of Tet, the Vietnamese New Year. Vietnam has had more confirmed human cases than any other country  93, with 42 deaths  but had none last year.

title: Indications of a Slowdown in Sex Entertainment Trade
description: The sex-related entertainment industrys leading performers, owners and fans gather in Las Vegas for three conferences starting next week amid indications that pornographys robust growth since it came out from behind the counter in the 1970s is slowing.

title: Empty Seat on Giants Bus to Philadelphia
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Spitzer Requests Sweeping Array of New Measures
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed overhauling almost every corner of the states operations and policies in his first address to the Legislature on Wednesday. He said he would move swiftly to guarantee health insurance for all children in the state, toughen campaign finance laws, cut property taxes by $6 billion and draft constitutional amendments to overhaul the states courts.

title: Jets Kendall Not Afraid to Talk One for the Team
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 3  Pete Kendall strolled out of the training room Monday clutching a three-week-old U.S. News & World Report magazine.

title: In Chinas New Revolution, Art Greets Capitalism
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 3  After the peppered beef carpaccio and before the pan-fried sea bass there were raucous toasts and the clinking of wine glasses in the V.I.P. room of New Heights, a jazzy restaurant in this citys most luxurious location, overlooking the Bund.

title: Plugging Into the Sun
description: WILLIAM LEININGER is not your typical environmental zealot. A Navy commander who works as a doctor at the Naval Medical Center San Diego, he is a Republican and lives in one of Californias most conservative counties, in a development of neat lawns and Spanish-style houses. His 2,400-square-foot, single-level house  the usual Southern California design, he said recently  is barely distinguishable from its neighbors, apart from one detail: the red-tile roof is crammed with solar panels.

title: Fans Track Air Traffic for Hints on Coaching Vacancies
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 3  As rumors about Alabamas coaching search reached a fever pitch here in recent weeks, many fans seeking clues about who might fill the Crimson Tides vacancy looked to the skies.

title: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
description: Arrogance has never been attractive in a leader. Now, in corporate chief executives anyhow, it may be a career ender.

title: After Rotation, Yankees Still Seek Help at First
description: The Yankees continued their attempt to trade Randy Johnson yesterday, talking with multiple teams about a deal. The most likely match remains Johnsons former team, the Arizona Diamondbacks, but Arizona has not been granted a 72-hour window to speak with him. Johnson must approve a trade and it is not clear how the Diamondbacks would afford him.

title: With Ad Deal, Insurer Wades Into Bridge Traffic
description: Drivers crossing the George Washington Bridge must contend with 18-wheelers, infuriating delays and noxious exhaust. Soon, they will also have advertisements from Geico.

title: Brooklyn: Four Shot Outside Rink
description: Two women and two men were shot early yesterday in front of a roller skating rink just east of Prospect Park, the police said. Gunfire broke out shortly before 1 a.m. outside the Empire Roller Skating Center at 200 Empire Boulevard, the police said. Two people were hit in the leg, one in the foot and the fourth in the abdomen, the police said. All four victims, whose names were not released, were in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center yesterday, the police said. No arrests have been made.

title: In Nod to Realpolitik, Offering Carrots to Both Sides
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  Sure, some of Gov. Eliot Spitzers calls in his first address to the Legislature on Wednesday  for spending less money, ending gerrymandering and limiting campaign donations  were met with the kind of icy reception he might have received if he had worn a Red Sox cap to Yankee Stadium.

title: Lack of Rules on Protective Gear Brings Suit Against Labor Dept.
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United Food and Commercial Workers sued the Department of Labor yesterday, asserting that it broke the law by failing to issue regulations requiring employers to pay for protective equipment for their workers.

title: A Guitar That Plugs Into a Computer via U.S.B.? Oh, It Makes Me Wonder
description: With the right equipment, future guitar virtuosos and Stairway to Heaven fanatics dont have to be chained to bulky amplifiers in the basement to practice and record their riffs. Hammacher Schlemmer offers the PC Recording Studio Guitar, a six-string electric instrument that comes with a U.S.B. port to connect it directly to a PC or Mac.

title: In Meetings With Allies, Clinton Hones 08 Strategy
description: The topic was the Democratic sweep in New Hampshire in November, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton could not get enough of it.

title: A Crop of Azure, Scarlet and Gold
description: A FEW years ago, when I first glimpsed the azure wing of a bluebird in the hedgerow that borders my meadow, I could hardly believe my eyes.

title: Congress Renews Vows of Civility  for a Day
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Like baseball and nature, Washington runs in cycles, replete with power shifts, reversals of fortune and, of course, renewed vows of civility and bipartisanship.

title: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  In an article published on a friendly op-ed page, and from the regal confines of the White House, President Bush greeted the incoming Democratic leadership of Congress on Wednesday with a message of bipartisanship.

title: Defensive Strategies and Fast Food Cravings
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. - The media poured into town this week for the Bowl Championship Series national title game between Florida and Ohio State. The first day of news conferences Tuesday offered a nice snapshot of some of the storylines emerging this week.

title: Irans President Promises More Nuclear Fuel and a Celebration
description: TEHRAN, Jan. 3  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad warned Wednesday that Iran would not back down from its nuclear ambitions and said his country would soon start producing nuclear fuel on an industrial scale.

title: Bronx: Construction Worker Killed
description: A 47-year-old laborer was killed yesterday after the machine he was operating fell off a building and crashed to the ground two stories below, the police and City Building Department officials said. The accident happened around 8:30 a.m. as workers were demolishing an eight-story commercial building at 587 River Avenue. City officials said the laborer, Carlos Reinoso, of Jackson Heights, Queens, was using a Bobcat excavator to push a concrete beam over the buildings side, and fell after the beam snagged the Bobcat and dragged it over the edge. The contractor, Bedroc Contracting, was issued a citation alleging unsafe practices. Bedrocs managing partner, Frank Weidner, said in a statement that his company was also looking into the accident. The police said no charges would be filed.

title: Free the Mind and Fewer Injuries May Follow
description: IN a high school locker room in Worthington, Ohio, Sam Maniar handed a piece of string tied to a washer to each of the field hockey players sitting around him. He told the athletes to use their minds to move the washer from side to side, and he watched as each girls washer started to swing.

title: Addenda
description: Sprint Nextel Reviews Its Creative Account

title: School Is Shut After Outbreak of Encephalitis Kills a Pupil
description: WARWICK, R.I., Jan. 3  State and federal health officials are investigating an extremely rare outbreak of encephalitis here that killed a second grader last month and led officials to close his elementary school this week.

title: Pulling It All Together
description: WILLIAM D. WATKINS has seven terabytes of data storage tucked into a cabinet in the media room of his beach home in Aptos, Calif. That is not a big thing for Mr. Watkins, the chief executive of Seagate, which makes hard disk drives. But it is enough space to hold 600,000 songs, 584,000 photographs and 1,000 hours of TV shows.

title: The Cosmetics Restriction Diet
description: DR. FRAN E. COOK-BOLDEN, a dermatologist in Manhattan, is an advocate of skin-care minimalism. When a patient recently arrived for an appointment toting 20 different products she was using regularly  including an eye cream, a vitamin C cream, a wrinkle serum, a pigmentation cream, a mask, a peel, a scrub and some sort of special oxygen detoxifying cream  Dr. Cook-Bolden said she confiscated all but three.

title: And Now for Something Classically Odd
description: Going to a P. D. Q. Bach concert is like listening to a Beethoven symphony: You know whats coming but still like it when it gets there. The tradition (or is it habit?) survives after more than 40 years; so do its ritual formats. Both were greeted at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday by a large and unusually smart-mouthed audience. Members of the New York Philharmonic played along mostly with good grace, though some looked to be salvaging what they could of their dignity.

title: U.S. Requiring Port Workers to Have IDs and Reviews
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  More than 750,000 port workers will be required to have criminal background and immigration checks in an antiterrorism program that the Homeland Security Department announced on Wednesday, and industry leaders say the effort could disrupt port traffic nationally.

title: Who Is That Wearing That Milk Mustache?
description: BRAND mascots and other types of brand ambassadors  meant to bring a brand to life in tangible form  are everywhere these days, as marketers look for new ways to spread their messages across a variety of media.
