title: A Country Less Dependent on Oil Is Free to Make Other New Years Resolutions
description: Well, another New Years Day has come and gone. A string of holiday meals and sitting on the couch have, no doubt, started another wave of resolutions to get some exercise and go on a diet. But after seeing gas prices pass $3 a gallon last year, hearing all the talk about global warming and having a bad feeling about all the bluster coming from the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, a great many folks wish the economy would go on a diet, too, and stop using so much energy.

title: Bud Delp, 74, Who Trained Derby Winner Spectacular Bid, Is Dead
description: Bud Delp, the Hall of Fame thoroughbred trainer who saddled the brilliant colt Spectacular Bid, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in 1979, died last Friday in Ellicott City, Md. He was 74.

title: L.S.U. Swarms Quinn, and Offense Does the Rest
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3  JaMarcus Russell came into the Sugar Bowl as the other quarterback, a gifted one but not the one wearing the iconic gold helmet or the one trying to put a happy ending on a storybook career at Notre Dame, like Brady Quinn. But Russell left the Superdome on Wednesday night as a Louisiana State legend and may just leave college football altogether as the N.F.Ls next No. 1 pick.

title: 2 Top Hollywood Agents Move to a Rival Firm
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3  Two leading Hollywood agents with top-ranked writer and director clients in movies and television joined the Endeavor talent agency on Wednesday, after many years at the rival International Creative Management.

title: Wheeldon Forms a Dance Company
description: Christopher Wheeldon, one of the worlds most sought-after choreographers, who recently announced an end to his residency at New York City Ballet, has formed his own company, a major event in the dance world.

title: Stepping Back From the Ledge of the Overly Appointed Life
description: Dan Ho is right. Something is wrong when scraping honeycomb candle wax off the bathtub is a justifiable household chore, and (whats worse) evidence that one is living well, since everyone knows that me time is nothing without bathroom atmospherics.

title: Mexican U.N. Insider Gets Managers Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 3  Ban Ki-moon, on his second day as secretary general, appointed a high-level United Nations insider, Alicia Brcena Ibarra, to the top management post, a signal that he does not plan aggressive reforms in the much-criticized bureaucracy.

title: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
description: A soldier from the 101st Airborne Division is scheduled to plead guilty next Tuesday to a reduced charge for mercy killing in connection with the death of three unarmed Iraqi men shot by American infantrymen last spring, according to lawyers for other defendants in the case.

title: Seton Hall Starts Big East Play on Right Track, Beating Rutgers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 3  For now, Seton Hall looks like the best Big East basketball team from the state of New Jersey. For the Pirates, that may be as good as it gets the rest of this season.

title: New Congress, Leftover Challenge
description: The nation should welcome the ambitious agenda being offered today by the new Congresss Democratic majority, from raising the minimum wage to advancing stem cell research to restoring oversight of the executive branch. But the real test for the 110th Congress will be its willingness to clean up its own act by adopting forceful and credible ethics reform. That is what the Democratic leadership promised voters. Any hesitation will be rightly seen as a cynical re-endorsement of the Capitols lobbyist-enabling, corruption-steeped business as usual.

title: Boy, 17, Dies in School Shooting in Tacoma, and Student Is Held
description: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 3  A student shot and killed another student at a public high school here on Wednesday, and the accused gunman was arrested a few hours later while walking down a nearby street, the police said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,991 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Owner of Sardis Restaurant Dies at 91
description: Vincent Sardi Jr., who owned and managed Sardis restaurant, his fathers theater-district landmark, for more than half a century and became, by wide agreement, the unofficial mayor of Broadway, died today. He was 91 and had lived in Warren, Vt., since retiring in 1997.

title: For the Well-Dressed iPod, a Leather Jacket in the Color of Your Choice
description: Like reggae? Encase your iPod in Rasta colors. Rooting for Manchester United or the Giants? Get an iPod case in your team colors. Vaja offers its i-Volution cases in thousands of color combinations, all in Argentine leather.

title: Not an iPod, but Its Child-Friendly and Uses One AAA Battery
description: Playaway is known for its Ready-to-Go line of audio book players, which are about the size of an iPod and play one book each. It is a concept that seems easy to apply to music, and thats the idea behind the companys $30 Kidz Bop to Go players, each featuring 20 songs aimed at children.

title: Scenes From Another Deadly Bombing in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 4  The foot was balanced on a shopping bag after being scooped up off the dirty street by a man in a track suit. There was no person to go with the limb. Nearby a charred body was still smoldering, smoke coming off the black corpse 45 minutes after the attack. For 50 yards, the dead were scattered about, some in pieces, some whole but badly burned.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Q. We have heard that Australian laurel is a great houseplant: pretty, fragrant and easy to grow. But our local nursery doesnt have it and it isnt in our houseplant book. Can you help?

title: Israeli Raid Overshadows Meeting in Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met this evening to discuss how to restore momentum to negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article on Saturday about adult children who take care of their aging parents referred incorrectly to expenses for the care of a spouse that are tax deductible if they exceed 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income. They are medical expenses, not any expenses.

title: Staten Island Sees a Decline in New Homes
description: The 20-year building boom on Staten Island, long the citys fastest-growing borough, is decelerating drastically, thanks largely to a reining-in of the islands freewheeling zoning laws, officials say. According to city figures released yesterday, permits for new buildings plunged by 43 percent last year.

title: Beware the No. 2 Fighter With a Fierce Mission
description: Afro Samurai, a friend said recently, picking up the DVD from my desk. Cool.

title: Drugstores Bank on Snob Appeal (but Can You Pronounce It?)
description: LUMENE. Lierac. Ol. Arnaud. Proraso.

title: Construction Worker One Day, Subway Hero the Next
description: Wesley Autrey teetered back and forth on the edge of a subway platform yesterday, re-enacting how he dived onto the tracks of a southbound No. 1 train in Manhattan on Tuesday to save another mans life.

title: Where Up Is Still Down, but the Rest Is Changing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  There were comparisons to Alice in Wonderland, Star Trek, The Twilight Zone, and all manner of clichs to convey the strangeness engulfing Washington this week as the Democrats prepared to assume control of Congress after 12 years in the minority wilderness. But nothing distilled the new aura of things like this conceit: Steny Hoyer, Rock Star.

title: Iraq Defends Hanging, but Holds Hussein Guard
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 3  The Iraqi prime ministers office on Wednesday mounted its first public defense of the way the government carried out the execution of Saddam Hussein, and said that Iraqi authorities had detained a guard who they believed was involved in recording the moment in a macabre and unauthorized video that has generated revulsion around the world.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday misstated the surname of the artist whose Urban Air Scrubber was at the Tribes Gallery on East Third Street in the East Village. He is William Meyer, not Brent. (Adam Brent is the artist who made another work that was on display.)

title: Calendar
description: Landscapes in America

title: The Paths to Universal Health Care (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title:
Democrats Taking Reins 
as New Session Opens on Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  On the brink of regaining power after 12 years, House Democrats said Wednesday that they would move immediately to try to sever ties between lawmakers and lobbyists who figured into scandals that helped Democrats win control of Congress.

title: Intelligence Chief to Shift to  Deputy State Dept. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  John D. Negroponte, whom President Bush installed less than two years ago as the first director of national intelligence, will soon leave his post to become the State Departments second-ranking official, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Chvez Plans One Big Venezuela Leftist Party, Led by Him
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 3  President Hugo Chvez has begun forging a single Socialist party among his varied supporters, one of his recent efforts to create momentum for far-reaching changes to Venezuelas political system that analysts say will effectively concentrate greater political power in his hands.

title: Studies Find Harm in 2 Parkinsons Drugs
description: Two drugs used to treat Parkinsons disease and other disorders can seriously damage heart valves, researchers are reporting.

title: Adelphia Bankruptcy Plan Is Approved
description: Adelphia Communications plan to pay creditors and end one of the biggest bankruptcy cases in United States history was approved yesterday by a judge in New York.

title: Ford Is Buried After Thousands in Hometown Pay Respects
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 3  Gerald R. Ford was buried on Wednesday on a grassy hill beside the rushing waters of the Grand River as the sun set, a final farewell in a week of remembrances for the nations 38th president.

title: Home Depot Ousts Highly Paid Chief
description: In May, in a nearly empty basement ballroom at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del., Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, stood between huge timers, intended to limit questions from the handful of shareholders present. After dismissing questions about his compensation or the independence of the board, Mr. Nardelli abruptly ended the meeting after only 30 minutes.

title: Garry Betty, 49, Chief of the Internet Provider EarthLink, Dies
description: Garry Betty, who built the EarthLink Corporation from a struggling start-up into a public company that took on telecommunications giants, died Tuesday in Atlanta. He was 49.

title: Accessorizing at the Buena Vista Scrabble Club
description: LAST week a winter storm blew into town like a stranger with a bad attitude.

title: Iona Seeks a Change, or at Least a Victory
description: There have been times when Iona, one of the nations better midmajor basketball programs in recent seasons, might have had a legitimate chance to beat an opponent like Maryland. They did not expect last night to be one of them.

title: China: Sabmiller Expands Venture
description: SABMiller said its China venture would buy a local partner for $320 million to expand in the worlds biggest beer market. China Resources Snow Breweries, 49 percent owned by SABMiller, agreed to buy the shares it does not already own in the Blue Sword Group, which owns 38 percent stakes in 14 breweries in central Sichuan province. The remaining shares are owned by China Resources Snow. In October, SABMiller said that its China Resources Snow venture had become Chinas largest brewer by sales volume, beating its domestic rival Tsingtao Brewery.

title: U.S. Is Looking Into Brunos Ties to an Investment Firm
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  The federal investigation into the business activities of Joseph L. Bruno, who was re-elected majority leader of the State Senate on Wednesday, has widened to include an Albany investment firm that has had close ties to him, public records show.

title: Elections for 2 Council Seats Will Be on Feb. 20
description: A special election will be held on Feb. 20 to fill two City Council seats left vacant in Brooklyn and on Staten Island, the citys Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: The Democrats Cautious Tiptoe Around the Presidents Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  President Bush is all but daring Democratic leaders to attack his signature tax cuts as they take over Congress. But Democrats, perhaps to his frustration, are having none of it.

title: Citing Egregious Misconduct, Panel Removes a Town Justice
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct announced yesterday that it had removed an upstate town justice for a number of improper acts, including efforts to intimidate prosecutors to keep them from complaining to the commission.

title: Duke Players Once Accused of Rape Can Return to School
description: Duke University invited two former lacrosse players to return to school yesterday while they fight charges of sexual offense and kidnapping arising from a strippers complaint after a team party last March.

title: Totals
A ThinkPad Tablet Tries to Find Its Place in the Sun
description: Tablet PCs have not gained much traction in the marketplace, but Lenovos latest may rev up the genre. The X60 ThinkPad Tablet has a 12-inch screen that flips around to fold flat, and it is brighter than usual, with a polarizing filter to cut glare  perhaps for those who would walk in the sun while Web surfing. There is a stylus for writing on the touch screen, and its other end has an electronic eraser for quick deletions.

title: Deconstructing Meaning by Truly Mincing Words
description: There is more than one way to take the measure of books. You can of course read them. You can count pages, lines or words. Or you can dissect their texts, parsing and weighing words until they lose meaning while gaining literal substance, and then arrange the physical remnants of this concrete poetry into an epic of their own.

title: Switzerland: Nestl Sells Composting Unit
description: Nestl, the food company, agreed to sell a soil-composting unit in the United States to the Garick Corporation for an undisclosed price. Garick, which is based in Cleveland, said it would add the unit, New Milford Farms, to its reusable waste business. New Milford, part of a Nestl unit in New Milford, Conn., turns processed food byproducts into compost. Terms were not disclosed. Nestl is based in Vevey, Switzerland.

title: Nets Save About $5 Million by Trading McInnis to Bobcats
description: The Nets traded the disgruntled point guard Jeff McInnis to the Charlotte Bobcats yesterday for the swingman Bernard Robinson.

title: In the Albany of 2007, Many Familiar Faces and a Few New Names
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  Change is in the air at the State Capitol, but the top faces in the Legislature are staying the same. The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, were both confirmed on Wednesday as the leaders of their respective chambers  positions they have held since 1994.

title: Fewer Excuses for Not Doing a PC Backup
description: If theres one New Years resolution even more likely to fail than I vow to lose weight, its I vow to start backing up my computer.

title: New York Times to Sell 9 Local TV Stations
description: The New York Times Company announced today that it had agreed to sell its nine local television stations to Oak Hill Capital Partners, a private equity firm, for $575 million.

title: Judge Drops KPMG Charge in Tax Case
description: A federal judge has dismissed a criminal charge accusing KPMG, the accounting firm, of conspiring to sell illegal tax shelters, after prosecutors said that the firm had met its obligations under a 2005 deferred- prosecution agreement.

title: Saban Leaving the Dolphins for Alabama
description: DAVIE, Fla., Jan. 3  Nick Saban had been saying for more than a month that he would not leave the Miami Dolphins. Nearly two weeks ago, he said, Im not going to be the Alabama coach.

title: After String of Crises, a Family Finds Some Security
description: When Destiny-Rae was quiet at 18 months old, Delores Pryce knew that something was wrong. All my children talked early, she said. But she wasnt speaking.

title: U.S. Bars Lab From Testing Electronic Voting
description: A laboratory that has tested most of the nations electronic voting systems has been temporarily barred from approving new machines after federal officials found that it was not following its quality-control procedures and could not document that it was conducting all the required tests.

title: Somali Government Compound Hit by Grenade
description: KISMAYO, Somalia, Jan. 4  A hand grenade was tossed into a government compound today in Mogadishu, Somalias capital, in yet another sign of a growing insurgency as security seems to be unraveling across the country.

title: Agitprop Tactics, Spoofs and Semantics in the Bronx
description: A favorite sport in todays bloated art world is to lament the surfeit of commercial galleries, biennials and art fairs, which have replaced the genuine art experience provided by nonprofit organizations. But as Matthew Higgs, director of White Columns, the citys oldest alternative art space, recently pointed out in Artforum, the nonprofit scene in New York is thriving.

title: A New Entry in Push-to-Talk
description: Push-to-talk, another name for walkie-talkie cellphone features, has been popular for years, but until recently it was largely available on Nextel phones. Now you can get push-to-talk from Cingular as well, and the LG CU400 cellphone it recently began offering adds high-speed data services to the mix.

title: Garden City: Judges Sue, Seeking Raise
description: Demanding raises for 1,300 state and local judges, four jurists have taken the rare step of suing the governor, Legislature and court system. The suit, filed Friday in State Supreme Court, contends that inflation has effectively cut salaries 28 percent since the last raise, in 1999, violating a constitutional bar against reducing judges compensation. The suit also accuses legislators of linking judicial pay to their own, violating the separation of powers and ignoring the fact that judges work full time with limited outside work, unlike legislators. The lawyer filing the suit, Steven Cohn, said he had been inundated with support from judges. A court spokesman declined to comment but said court officials were pushing hard for raises. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has said he also supports raises for judges. Legislative leaders declined to comment.

title: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of Jihad Case
description: In 1997, as the government listened in on their phone call, Adham Hassoun, a computer programmer in Broward County, Fla., proposed a road trip to Jose Padilla, a low-wage worker there. The excursion to Tampa would be his treat, Mr. Hassoun said, and a chance to meet some nice, uh, brothers.

title: An Ousted Chiefs Going-Away Pay Is Seen by Many as Typically Excessive
description: Robert L. Nardellis rich compensation and poor performance at Home Depot have long been cited by shareholder activists as a prime example of what they view as excessive executive pay. Some union members dressed up in giant chicken outfits to protest the boards reluctance to clip Mr. Nardellis wings.

title: Hussein Poem: Baathists Bloom, Enemy Is Hollow
description: Following is the first half of a poem attributed to Saddam Hussein, as transcribed and translated by The New York Times from a reading by his cousin Muayed Dhamin al-Hazza.

title: Auto Sales at Big 3 Fall Further
description: DETROIT, Jan. 3  The Detroit auto show, which opens next week, is all about new concepts, building buzz and making fresh starts. And the Detroit auto companies can use all of that.

title: Health Scare Closes More Rhode Island Schools
description: More than 21,000 students in public schools in three communities in Rhode Island were told today to stay home for the rest of the week after a child who attended one of the schools was admitted to a hospital with a probable case of meningitis.

title: Dismantling the Beat to Get to the Heart of It
description: All good musicians have a physical relationship to their instruments, but a few make it really apparent. They tend to be big people with big instruments. Charles Mingus was this way, as are the Brazilian percussionist Carlinhos Brown and the trombonist Wycliffe Gordon. And so is the drummer Tyshawn Sorey, who isnt yet so well known outside inner-circle jazz audiences, who may have heard him play in bands with Dave Douglas or Vijay Iyer or Steve Coleman.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Bermuda: New Insurer to Focus on Coasts
description: The Bear Stearns Companies, Greenhill & Company and three other firms have invested $1 billion to create Ironshore Insurance, an insurer that will be based in Bermuda and will specialize in disaster-prone commercial properties along the Southeast and Gulf coasts of the United States. Robert Clements, who helped start various Bermuda-based insurers including ACE and XL Capital, arranged the financing with his son John Clements. We see a marketplace that is starved for quality capacity, Robert V. Deutsch, Ironshores chief executive, above, said in a telephone interview.

title: G.E. Magic Can Fade, After G.E.
description: When boards of directors go shopping for a new chief executive, their first stop is often General Electric.

title: Liebermans Party Now Has Critic as Its Chief
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 3  Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut was able to beat back a fierce challenge last fall, but now his critics are joining the very party he created to win his way back to Washington for a fourth term.

title: Mother Wonders if Psychosis Drug Helped Kill Son
description: At first, the psychiatric drug Zyprexa may have saved John Eric Kauffmans life, rescuing him from his hallucinations and other symptoms of acute psychosis.

title: Getting the Middle East Back on Our Side
description: Washington

title: Democrats Take the Gavels in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Jubilant Democrats took the gavels in the Senate and House today for the first time in 12 years, pledging a new era in Congress and a new effort at bipartisan progress.

title: Defense May Be Ultimate Measure of Colts Success
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 3  Running backs have relished playing against the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Web sites that offer unfiltered video clips misstated the type of aircraft shown attacking Taliban forces in Afghanistan in one such video. It was an A-10 Thunderbolt, not an A-20 Havoc.

title: Not Quite a Dtente in Belichick-Mangini Relations
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 3  Nick Saban had left the Miami Dolphins only minutes earlier Wednesday morning when Patriots Coach Bill Belichick was asked what he thought of the move. He praised Sabans intelligence. He revealed that he and Saban had spoken by phone Tuesday night. He called him a good friend.

title: A 180 View of a Hotbed of Housing Design
description: Venice, Calif.

title: East Orange, N.J.: Store Owner Is Killed
description: EAST ORANGE: STORE OWNER IS KILLED The owner of a clothing store was fatally shot yesterday afternoon in his shop by a gunman who entered it and opened fire, the authorities said. The shooting took place around 2:30 p.m. inside 353 Clothing on Main Street, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutors office. No arrests had been made as of last night, and investigators were trying to determine a motive. The victim was identified by the East Orange Police Department as Allan Cuff, 34, of East Orange.

title: Seymour Martin Lipset, Sociologist, Dies at 84
description: Seymour Martin Lipset, who ignored family pressure to be a dentist and instead became a pre-eminent sociologist, political scientist and incisive theorist on American uniqueness, died on Dec. 31 in Arlington, Va. He was 84.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Out With the Old
description: There was good news and bad news yesterday for shareholders of Home Depot. The good news is that Robert Nardelli, the imperious chief executive who had presided over a difficult, stagnant period for the company, has resigned. The bad news is that hell be taking $210 million worth of compensation with him, one of the highest severance packages ever, which is saying a lot in this era of runaway executive pay.

title: Where You Least Expect It
description: HAS it ever seemed clearer that fashion is not about clothes? Has it ever appeared more inevitable that the cult of the designer is slated for the cultural slag heap, there to join all those other monuments to the outmoded notion of the grand career (retrospective albums, DVD collections, the Great Novel)?

title: Knicks Troubles Extend to Defense and Jeffries
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3  Disillusionment blanketed the small visitors locker room at Arco Arena in Sacramento late Tuesday night. In one corner, Eddy Curry sat glumly, hardly looking up as he blamed himself for the Knicks latest defeat. A few feet over and a few minutes later, Stephon Marbury later spoke in low tones that conveyed distress. It was hard to find even a resigned grin or a hopeful glance in the crowd.

title: The Building That Wouldnt Go Away
description: THE dismantling of the Deutsche Bank building will begin this fall and  after careful, systematic deconstruction  it will be gone next year.

title: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., Jan. 3  In a rare reprise to a rare trial, the jury that convicted a Long Island man of murder by depraved indifference last October in a drunken-driving crash that killed a limousine driver and a 7-year-old girl may be brought back to court for hearings on whether some members acted improperly during deliberations.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.My kitchen cabinets are scarred and scuffed. Should I repair or replace them?

title: Florida: Hotel Is Sued Over Carbon Monoxide
description: An Iowa family that fell ill at a Key West hotel nearly a week before a man who stayed in the same room died of carbon monoxide poisoning has sued the hotel, claiming they were injured. David and Jody Smith and their son Nathan, of Ankeny, Iowa, stayed at the hotel, the Doubletree Grand Key Resort, and were treated at a local hospital on Dec. 21, less than a week before Thomas Lueders, 26, died from inhaling carbon monoxide fumes that came from a boiler adjacent to his room. The Smiths lawsuit seeks compensation for hospital expenses and emotional anguish. Ira Leesfield, the lawyer for the Smiths, said he expected at least three other families to join the suit.

title: Pondering Six Diamonds and Contemplating the Other Table
description: The premier event at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Midtown Manhattan, which finished last Saturday, was the Truscott Board-a-Match Teams.

title: Art Above and Below, With Life in the Middle
description: IT has been more than five years since the first of Ann Brasharess Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants novels, which would become a sensation among teenage girls, hit the best-seller list. The last book in the series, Forever in Blue: The Fourth Summer of the Sisterhood, will be published on Tuesday, but during that half decade, the characters have aged only about three years.

title: Manhattan: Transit Chief to Resign
description: Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the branch of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the subways and buses, announced his resignation yesterday, clearing the way for new leadership at the agency he has run since 1996. Finding a replacement for Mr. Reuter, above, will now become one of the first tasks for the transportation authoritys incoming executive director and chief executive, Elliot G. Sander. Mr. Sander was chosen to head the authority by Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who has frequently called for a management shake-up at the agency. Mr. Reuter said his departure was not influenced by the change in administration. He plans to leave the authority in early February and will take a job in Miami with Parsons Brinckerhoff, a large engineering company.

title: 26-year Sentence in Reporters Death
description: One of two men convicted in the killing of a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced to 26 years in prison. The defendant, Michael C. Hamlin, had faced a term of up to 60 years after pleading guilty late last year to second-degree murder, robbery and conspiracy to commit robbery for his part in the attack on the reporter, David E. Rosenbaum, near Mr. Rosenbaums Washington home a year ago. At the trial of his cousin Percey Jordan Jr., Mr. Hamlin, 24, testified that he had stolen Mr. Rosenbaums wallet but that it was Mr. Jordan, wielding a pipe, who had delivered a fatal blow to the victims head. Mr. Rosenbaum, 63, died two days later. Mr. Jordan is to be sentenced before the same judge, Erik P. Christian of District of Columbia Superior Court, later this month. Convicted of first-degree murder, he faces at least 30 years in prison and a maximum of life without the possibility of parole.

title: Travails of Adolescence? Hes Been There
description: What makes ninth grade funny? Having your mom beat you in basketball? Figuring out why girls like bad boys? Learning to be a team player only after not making the basketball team? James Lewis, popularly known as Lil J J, a 16-year-old stand-up comedian from Little Rock, Ark., is plying those examples of teenage angst as the character Jordan Lewis, on Just Jordan, a new Nickelodeon series about Jordan, his friends and family in Los Angeles that begins Sunday.

title: Curry Finds Form and Knicks Find a Way to Win
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3  Eddy Curry found daylight on a dull gray evening in the Pacific Northwest. It was perhaps the most pleasant sight the Knicks had seen on their extended tour of the N.B.A.s better conference.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the handling of the video of Saddam Husseins execution by television networks and Web sites referred imprecisely to the site littlegreenfootballs.com. It posted a link to the video, not the video itself.

title: Words We Understand (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pomp and Promises as Rell Begins Full Term
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 3  Casting her first full term as governor as a chance to guide the state through a crossroads of needed economic, social, cultural and educational change, M. Jodi Rell was sworn in as Connecticuts 87th governor on Wednesday, promising to lead and inspire.

title: Spin Around League
description: (Andrew Das, Toni Monkovic, Naila-Jean Meyers, Benjamin Hoffman and John Woods contributed items)

title: After the Flood, the Debris
description: Floodwall, an installation of hundreds of drawers salvaged from Katrina's trash heaps by New Orleans artist Jana Napoli, can now be found in Lower Manhattan.

title: N.F.L. vs. College Football
description: Boise State-Oklahoma still resonates. In our department, we havent hooted and hollered over a game like that in a long time. Moments after Jared Zabranskys Statue of Liberty handoff to Ian Johnson for the winning 2-point conversion, a colleague did a little hop and said: Thats why college football is so much better! Youll never see that in the N.F.L.! Youll never see it!

title: It Is What It Is (Aaaargh)
description: Gene Colliers column on sports cliches is an annual delight for us editor types. (O.K., so were easily amused)

title: Low-Key Punta del Este
description: Despite its jet-set reputation, Punta has other charms, like surprisingly nice people, blond beaches and flawless architectural vistas.

title: Shakespeare's Church Is Crumbling
description: The church where Shakespeare is buried is urgently seeking nearly $400,000 for repairs to its tower and spire, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Stone's Village
A Fairy Tale for Fractured Times
description: Anyone who dismisses the Shrek movies as lowbrow junk should see Happily NEver After, a cartoon feature that apes those films visuals, soundtrack choices and rude jokes, while throwing away their sweetness and conviction.

title: Online Job Sites: Ripe for Consolidation?
description: The proliferation of niche help-wanted Web sites, as well as networking sites like Craigslist and LinkedIn, could lead to consolidation among more general jobs sites like Monster, HotJobs, and CareerBuilder. Niche sites made up 64 percent of the market in 2005, according to BusinessWeek, up from 39 percent in 2004. And visits to the big three jobs sites are falling fast, though sales are rising thanks to the strength of the job market.

title: Adelphia Bankruptcy Plan Is Approved
description: Adelphia Communicationss plan to pay creditors and end one of the biggest bankruptcy cases in United States history was approved Wednesday by a judge in New York. Adelphia, once one of the biggest American cable television companies, filed for protection from creditors in June 2002, a month before its founder, John J. Rigas, was arrested and charged with looting the company.

title: Finance Firm Hercules Raises $11 Million in Stock Sale
description: Hercules Technology Growth Capital, a specialty finance company, said Wednesday it had raised about $11 million when its underwriters exercised their option to buy an additional 840,000 shares of common stock. Hercules, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the net proceeds will be used to reduce borrowings under its credit facilities, to originate new investments and provide funds for existing investments, and for general corporate purposes.

title: Silicon Valleys Macrovision Buys Mediabolic
description: Macrovision has acquired a consumer electronics software provider, Mediabolic, for $43.5 million, the company said Tuesday. Macrovision is best known for its DVD copy-protection software and programs that secure entertainment content like movies and games.

title: R.R. Donnelly to Acquire Von Hoffmann, a Trade Printer
description: R.R. Donnelley & Sons, the largest North American printing company and the printer of titles like Sports Illustrated and TV Guide, agreed to buy Von Hoffmann from Visant for $412.5 million in cash, furthering its strategy of increasing production capacity for educational and business publishers.

title: Whirlpool Unloads Maytag Properties
description: Whirlpool said Wednesday that it had sold a number of properties belonging to Maytag, including most of Maytags headquarters complex in Newton, Iowa. Whirlpool said it also had sold former Maytag manufacturing sites in Galesburg and Herrin, Ill.; Searcy, Ark.; and Ranson, W.Va. The company did not disclose the terms of the deals.

title: Nestl Sells Composting Unit
description: Nestl, the Swiss food company, agreed to sell a soil-composting unit in the United States to Garick for an undisclosed price. Garick, which is based in Cleveland, said it would add the unit, New Milford Farms, to its reusable waste business. New Milford, part of a Nestl unit in New Milford, Conn., turns processed food byproducts into compost.

title: Judge Drops KPMG Charge in Tax Case
description: A federal judge has dismissed a criminal charge accusing KPMG, the accounting firm, of conspiring to sell illegal tax shelters, after prosecutors said that the firm had met its obligations under a 2005 deferred-prosecution agreement.

title: 3 Cellphone Makers Are Sued Over Bluetooth Technology
description: A United States research institute has sued three cellphone makers, accusing them of violating a patent for Bluetooth technology. The Washington Research Foundation, which markets technology from universities and other nonprofit research institutions in Washington State, is seeking damages from Nokia, Samsung Electronics and Panasonic, owned by Matsushita, contending that the three companies were using a radio frequency receiver technology patented by a University of Washington scientist in 1999.

title: Cisco to Buy Network Security Firm IronPort
description: Cisco Systems said Thursday it would buy a Web messaging and e-mail security company, IronPort Systems, for $830 million to tap growing demand for anti-virus and anti-spam software. The deal for IronPort would be Ciscos biggest since its $6.9 billion purchase of Scientific-Atlanta, announced in 2005.

title: Everbright Bank Said to Seek Investor
description: China Everbright Bank, which plans to hold an initial public offering this year, has hired China International Capital and Morgan Stanley to find a foreign investor before the offering, according to Bloomberg News. Everbright Bank, which in 1996 became the first Chinese bank to sell stock to an overseas financial institution, is trying to bolster its capital to comply with government guidelines, Bloomberg said.

title: Macquarie to Outsource Jobs to India, Report Says
description: Macquarie Bank, Australias largest securities firm, plans to shift as many as 100 administrative jobs, including positions from payroll services in Sydney and London, to India, according to Bloomberg News. The bank plans to combine its global human resources functions as part of a strategic review, a Macquarie spokesman told Bloomberg. Macquarie joins the Credit Suisse Group and the Australia & New Zealand Banking Group among banks that are hiring in India to take advantage of the nations lower labor costs and pool of skilled workers.

title: Morgan Stanley Faces Age-Bias Suit
description: A former Morgan Stanley regional director in wealth management sued the company on Wednesday, saying he was fired because of his age. The executive, Edward Sullivan, 56, who had been a managing director, accused human resources executives Jeffrey Brodsky and Eric Kayne of conspiring to end his employment, in part to make room for a friend of Mr. Brodskys who lacked an assignment.

title: Bezos Offers Glimpse into Space Venture
description: Amazon.coms founder, Jeff Bezos, wants engineers to join his fledgling and secretive private aerospace business, Blue Origin, breaking a long silence about his operation by posting photos and videos on the companys Web site of a test launch of a reusable spacecraft. The posting, dated Tuesday, shows a cone-shaped vehicle with four metal legs, launching in a cloud of smoke, reaching an altitude of about 285 feet, according to Blue Origin, then landing on its legs.

title: Bank of America Steps Back from Venture Arm
description: Bank of America is distancing itself from its venture capital arm, BA Venture Partners, to concentrate on its middle-market private equity unit, BA Capital Investors. BA Ventures said Wednesday that it would rename itself Scale Venture Partners as Bank of America repositions itself as a minority investor.

title: Private Equity Boom Racks Up Bankers Fees
description: Bankers enjoying their record bonuses from 2006 have, at least in part, private equity to thank, as the industry is poised to pay $11 billion in fees in an unprecedented year for leveraged buyouts. Taking the crown is Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which will pay out more than $837 million in fees to investment banks in 2006, more than any other private equity firm.

title: Pinault Faces Deadline for 70 Billion Euro Suez Bid
description: The French financial markets regulator said Wednesday that it would decide Tuesday on a target date by which Franois Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the fashion house Gucci, must make a bid for Suez or else abstain from bidding for six months. A bid could derail a government-orchestrated plan for an 80 billion euro ($106.2 billion) merger between Suez, a water and energy group, and the state-controlled Gaz de France.

title: AGL Makes Pass at Origin to Create Australias Largest Energy Retailer
description: AGL Energy, Australias biggest power and gas retailer, has made an initial approach to its biggest rival, Origin Energy, about a merger valued at 13 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to create the countrys biggest gas and electricity supplier.

title: Wall Streets Not-So-Green Deal
description: As a big battle over global warming is unfolding in Texas, Fortune takes a look at how green Wall Streets investment banks really are. At the heart of the controversy is a Dallas-based energy company that wants to build 11 coal-fired plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air. In an effort to stop the plants, environmentalists, along with a coalition of institutional investors, have turned their attention to Merrill Lynch, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, the three lead arrangers of TXUs financing.

title: Radio One Picks Up Giant Magazine
description: Radio One, an urban-music radio broadcaster, has purchased the struggling magazine Giant for a song. The broadcaster, which owns 70 radio stations in 22 urban markets, paid $275,000 for the magazine, which was founded by Jamie Hooper, a one-time publisher of Stuff.

title: Home Depot Moves Put G.E., Martin Lipton in Spotlight
description: As shareholders, industry watchers and lawmakers continued to express outrage over the $210 million golden farewell that Home Depot awarded its ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, The New York Times takes a look at where it all began: General Electric, which has become a kind of high-end boutique where company directors go when they are looking for the cream of the crop in chief executives.

title: Icahn May Take Sands Stake from Troubled GB Holdings
description: GB Holdings, which is liquidating its assets, will seek approval of a plan anchored by Carl Icahns $53 million offer to buy the debtors stake in Atlantic Citys Sands Hotel & Casino. Chief Judge Judith Wizmur in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey in Camden set Jan. 30 for a confirmation hearing on GBs eighth modified disclosure statement, records show. The plan requires Mr. Icahn to pay $53 million for GBs remaining 28.2 percent interest in Atlantic Coast Entertainment Holdings, one of his affiliates.

title: After Newspaper Deal, Avista Strikes Again
description: Avista Capital Partners, fresh off last weeks purchase of the Minneapolis Star Tribune, agreed Wednesday to acquire a self-directed investment advisory firm, Phillips Investment Resources, for an amount The Deal.com put between $140 million and $160 million. Phillips, a well-known provider of independent advice, offers 23 different subscription-based services for delivery in digital forms as well as print newsletters.

title: Polygon Drops Pursuit of Soccer Club
description: A consortium led by the hedge fund Polygon Investment Partners said Thursday that it had dropped plans to make a bid for the British soccer club Newcastle United, which is valued at 91 million pounds ($177 million). Last month, the team confirmed that it was in talks with the consortium, St. James Park Group, about a possible bid, and rumors swirled that Polygon had approached the clubs former chairman, Sir John Hall, about buying his 28.8 percent stake. The Times of London said that the Belgravia Group, a British investment company, confirmed that it is still in talks with Newcastle about a possible bid.

title: Major Tribune Shareholder to Review Stake
description: Tribune shareholder McCormick Tribune Foundation said Thursday in a regulatory filing that it is considering various options for its investment in the publishing and broadcasting company. The disclosure comes as Tribune, which owns the Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Tribune newspapers, is conducting a strategic review that could lead to a sale of all or part of the company.

title: Backing Up Online
description: David Pogue experiences the ups and downs of YouTube while reviewing backup services.

title: Whats Mine Is Mine, Even if Its Yours
description: Bob Yari is a sought-after guy in Hollywood. He has money, is willing to finance adventurous films, and did the Bagger mention he has a lot of loot? Last year, Mr. Yari ended up in an unseemly tussle over credits. He sued every which way  he named both the Producers Guild of America and the Academy  for what he felt was rightfully his, but his suit was eventually thrown out. Now Mr. Yari is back in the news, actually at the top of Page Six, almost never a friendly place, because he is said to have dumped a project directed by Don Cheadle and based on a book by Elmore Leonard.

title: This, Too, Belongs to Me
description: One would think that things were pretty jolly over at the Paramount lot yesterday, after the Producer Guild Awards nominees were announced.

title: Fiji Update: President Returns; Prime Minister Still Banished
description: A bit of news from post-putsch Fiji: The militarys commander, Frank Bainimarama, who seized power last month in the coup-prone Pacific nation (it was the fourth in the last 20 years), reinstated the president, Ratu Josefa Iloilo, according to The Australian.

title: Conrad Black: a Media King Dethroned
description: New York, according to Vanity Fairs Maureen Orth, was Conrad Blacks downfall.

title: CNN Steps Into Osama/Obama Bramble; Blogs Document It
description: Readers might recall the Baltimore radio host who cheekily asked passers-by last fall whether Barack Obama posed a threat to the nation. Said one respondent:

description: The five nominess for best ensemble were:

title: The SAG Nominees for Motion Pictures
description: For this years entire SAG Awards nominees list, click here.

title: Berkeley Bubble
description: With a mandate that says merit trumps all, the University of California, Berkeley, finds itself looking across the Pacific for its identity.

title: Acting, As If
description: It was another helping of love for Babel, which had picked up seven Globes, a producers nomination yesterday, and this morning, a best ensemble nod from the Screen Actors Guild.

title: Obamas Approach on Congressional Ethics
2008 Like Its Today: Romney In
description: Gov. Mitt Romney is now officially exploring. That means he can start raising money. And his campaign wasted no time in doing that, sending an e-mail to supporters around 7:15 Wednesday evening.

title: How Secure Is Your Wi-Fi Connection?
description: Long-time readers know that I'm not exactly one of the privacy paranoid.

title: The Democrats Hill: First Official Day, Still Adjusting
description: Today, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California will become the first female speaker of the House, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada will become Senate majority leader, and Democrats will control both chambers as new members are sworn in. The Caucus will be on the Hill, too, reporting on all the pomp and circumstance.

title: The Pleasing Sound of Hawks
description: Do hawks have a genetic advantage when it comes to political argument? Writing in Foreign Policy, Daniel Kahneman and Jonathan Renshon say yes. Kahneman, a Princeton professor of psychology and public affairs, and Rehnson, the author of Why Leaders Choose War: The Psychology of Prevention, write:

title: Bushs First Shot at the Dems
description: Jim Rutenberg, The Timess White House correspondent, parses the messages in President Bushs Wall Street Journal op-ed.

title: Just Another Bric-a-Brac on the Wall
description: Audio antiques as wall art, courtesy of mom and pop's record collection.

title: Banking Looks Brighter in Europe, Analyst Says
description: After forecasting that Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and UBS would all face declining fees from investment-banking work in 2007, Bear Stearns analyst Christopher Wheeler has turned much more upbeat. In a note published Thursday, Mr. Wheeler said each of those banks should be able to match last years revenue from investment banking compared with his previous expectation of a 7 percent to 8 percent year-over-year decline.

title: Good Sense for a New Year
description: Melissa Clark, left, and Robin Aronson, divas of restraint. (Courtesy of The Skinny)

title: Snickerdoodle Spillage in Puget Sound?
description: The United States Geological Survey has famously found all manner of funky chemicals  in groundwater, floodwater runoff, snowpack and even in animals who hang about the edges of our water systems. (Yes, were talking the usual PCBs and pesticides, but also more interesting stuff like, say,  perfume, or the antidepressant drug Venlafaxine.)

title: Newark: Death Sentence Changed to Life
description: After nearly 19 years on death row, a man who admitted killing a pizzeria owner was resentenced to life in prison in State Superior Court. The resentencing came after the State Supreme Court overturned a death sentence for the man, Anthony DiFrisco, 46, last summer. Mr. DiFrisco said he was paid $2,500 to kill Edward Potcher, the owner of Jacks Pizzeria in Maplewood, in 1986, prosecutors said.

title: On the Senate Side of the 110th Congress
description: The new Senate met in the old Senate chamber today, with most senators, from both parties, in attendance. Slowly, people trickled out. Ben Cardin, Marylands newly elected senator, ducked out well before the restmaybe to go visit his old friends in the House of Representatives, where he just completed his tenth term.

title: How Secure Is Your Wi-Fi Connection?
description: Long-time readers know that Im not exactly one of the privacy paranoid.

title: Cuomo to Feast on Pork
description: The death watch continues for the member item system that proliferated in the Pataki era, as Attorney General Andrew Cuomo said this morning he will review the roughly 6,000 items sponsored by legislators this year and seek to recover any misspent funds.

title: Wells Fargo and Wachovia: Is This the Year?
description: The latest financial pundit to unfurl 2007 predictions is David Weidner of MarketWatch, who offers a list of events he expects to see in the next year. A few of them are pretty safe bets: Executive pay will rise, he says; brokerage profits will fall. But his prediction that Wachovia will merge with Wells Fargo  a banking combination that he is not the first to propose  comes with a considerable amount of detail. He writes:

title: L.S.U. Routs Notre Dame in Sugar Bowl
description: Overshadowed by Notre Dame quarterback Brady Quinn going into the Sugar Bowl, L.S.U. quarterback JaMarcus Russell emerged as the games true star.

title: The More Things Change
description: One of the enduring truths of Washington is that for as much as everyone rails against the place  even runs against same old Washington  few people ever leave.

title: Fired SEC Lawyer Answers Wall Street Journal Editorial
description: Gary Aguirre, who criticized his former bosses at the Securities and Exchange Commission at a Senate hearing last month, is now taking the Wall Street Journal editorial page to task.

title: Law Firms Dewey and Orrick Cancel Merger
description: The wedding between Dewey Ballantine and Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe is off, the two law firms said Thursday afternoon. In a joint statement, the firms attributed the failure of the proposed merger to unspecified complexities in bringing the firms together.

title: Sullivan & Cromwell Adds M&A Partner in London
description: The law firm Sullivan & Cromwell said Thursday that Tim Emmerson will join its London office as a partner, where he will focus on mergers and acquisitions, private equity and equity capital markets law. Mr. Emmerson was previously a partner at Milbank Tweed Hadley and McCloy in London.

title: Nardellis Departure
description: There is a wonderful irony to the departure of Bob Nardelli from Home Depot.

title: The Obama Watch Continues
description: Senator Barack Obama is back from his Hawaiian holiday vacation, but those waiting to find out whether hes going to run for president will have to wait at least a little while longer.

title: A New Racing Web Site
description: If I dont talk much about discovering other racing Web sites or blogs, its not by design. Theres usually just too much other news. But I just learned of a new project that seems worthy of mentioning in this fairly quiet period of F1 news (the calm before the storm). Racer magazine today announced the launch of a new interactive racing Web site that looks interesting: Myracer.com

title: Building a Better TiVo
description: In three days, 140,000 gadget-minded geeks and 2,700 publicity-hungry companies will cram into Las Vegas to jostle each other on 1.7 million square feet of trade show floor. The cab lines will be long, dinner reservations scarce and sleep nonexistent. Im looking forward to it.

title: Macworld Rumors
description: Next week, Ill be in San Francisco to cover the Macworld Expo. Its nominally a show about Apple products, but as everyone knows, what Apple does is usually adopted shortly thereafter by the rest of the industry (think CD-ROM, Wi-Fi, music player/online music store). So its a big deal, and loads of fun.

title: The Other Clinton on the Hill
description: The opening day of Congress always brings spouses to Capitol Hill and today was no exception.

title: Blogtalk
description: Marriage, Spitzer and the legislature. [The Politicker]

title: My Outfits Have Audiences
description: If someone turned a camera on you RIGHT NOW, and asked you about your clothes, do you know what youd say?

title: On the Hill: All Their Children
description: Most of the time, Congress looks as if its run by children.

title: Aon May Sell Combined Unit, Analyst Says
description: Insurance broker Marsh & McLennan has been slimming down its business mix, and at least one analyst thinks that rival Aon will make a similar move. Credit Suisse analyst Charles Gates said Thursday that he expects Aon to sell its Combined Insurance unit as it transitions completely away from retaining and underwriting risk. In his research note, Mr. Gates estimates the unit, which sells accident, health and life insurance, could fetch $2.4 billion.

title: The Product E-Mails Pile Up
description: Spam pales in quantity compared to the number of e-mails you receive when youre on the CES press list. Not only is the Consumer Electronics Show the biggest convention in the U.S., but it must also generate the largest number of electronic messages for any event. For six weeks prior to the show, anyone whos registered begins to receive hundreds of e-mails from P.R. agents, practically begging you to check out their latest products. Unfortunately, many of the agencies dont seem to do their homework because like spam, most of these messages dont seem to have any particular target audience in mind.

title: An Odd Couple
description: You would have to forgive Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee if he felt a little lonely today. He was, after all, the only new Republican elected to the Senate in the 110th Congress.

title: Texas Pacific Thinks Smaller With Latest Fund
description: Here is a twist on the biggest fund ever stories that have become routine in the booming private-equity industry. Reuters notes that Texas Pacific Group is raising eyebrows with its new  and relatively puny  buyout fund. At about $1 billion, the latest fund is really midsized, but it is tiny compared with Texas Pacifics previous investment vehicle, which came in at $15 billion.

title: Whats the Theme?
description: Last year, when you asked industry analysts and marketing executives what the theme of the Consumer Electronics show was going to be they said, home networking. Yes, 2006 was the year wed connect all our TVs in our homes to all our PCs and move movies and videos around between them.

title: East Coast-West Coast Beef
description: The Bagger watched with some amusement as the gatekeepers of journalistic Hollywood gently knocked down David Denbys big heave about movies in the New Yorker.

title: Heap of the Top
description: What came out on top of the rock pile at Metacritic, the place where criticism is a common endeavor? The best reviewed film of the year is from El Gordo, Guillermo del Toro: Pans Labyrinth. Other critical beanie babies among the top ten include LEnfant, United 93, and yes, Borat. The Departed just missed, coming in at number 11.

title: Race to Replace Balboni Begins
description: Now that State Senator Michael A.L. Balboni, a Nassau County Republican, has joined the Spitzer administration, Republicans are wasting no time trying to hold on to his seat.

title: Wheres the Beef? Snowbound After Two Blizzards
description: While those of us in Eastern climes have been enjoying unseasonably balmy weather, the fallout from heavy snows in several Western states may well leave some residents without power for weeks.

title: Smut Revenue Growth Slows  But Theres Always the Stiflers Mom Effect
description: This little nugget is worth noting from The Times own David Cay Johnston: Seems the trafficking of smut  an inimitable boom industry since the dawn of video tape, cable television and the Internet  may be slowing overall.

title: From the Kitchen to the Congress
description: Theres so much talk about breaking through the marble ceilings on the Hill today that we wondered whether any ceiling had literally cracked by the time Nancy Pelosi assumed the speakership of the House this afternoon. (Certainly not the cast iron of the Capitol dome.)

title: Cattle Call at the Capitol
description: In the Capitol, understandably, congressmen and women get special treatment. They get their own elevators, they dont have to go through security and, of course, a staff to handle the day-to-day chores. But just in case the new members were starting to let their newly acquired power go to their heads, the cattle call that was the ceremonial swearing-in/photo-op with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, served as a reminder of real life.

title: The Times's John Burns
description: The Times's Baghdad bureau chief, John F. Burns, appeared on The Charlie Rose Show to discuss the situation in Iraq.

title: Exit and Election Strategies
description: Its true that politicians are polarizedtheyre often either over-eager to talk or they wont talk at all. Today, Representative Dennis Kucinich enthusiastically told us about his presidential plans (he even drew us a rough map of the Middle East), while Howard Dean, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was fairly restrained, about, well, everything.

title: A Day on the Hill: Democrats Take It Over
description: Weve had a small caucus of a caucus from The Times up here on the Hill today, culling color and some substance from the mainly ceremonial moments of the day. Both chambers have promised to make ethics reform their top priority, and the House jumped onto the floor to start debating some of the procedural matters surrounding the newly proposed rules that would ban most gifts and corporate jet travel, among other things.

title: Movie Minutes: Best of 2006
description: A. O. Scott, The Times's chief movie critic, revisits his ten favorite movies of 2006.

title: Movie Minutes: Worst of 2006
description: A. O. Scott, The Times's chief movie critic, revisits his five least favorite movies of 2006.

title: The People Predict
description: David Carr (a k a The Carpetbagger) asks moviegoers in Times Square what films they think should be nominated for Academy Awards.

title: Survey Finds Embezzlement in Many Catholic Dioceses
description: A survey by researchers at Villanova University has found that 85 percent of Roman Catholic dioceses that responded had discovered embezzlement of church money in the last five years, with 11 percent reporting that more than $500,000 had been stolen.

title: Pedestrian Video
description: The Bagger left his office with Matt the camera guy, walked 200 feet due east to Times Square and found a bunch of actual human beings walking around who were willing to talk about what movies should be in Oscar contention. Try doing that on the 405.

title: Bush Recycles the Trash
description: George W. Bush has not been known as a great proponent of recycling  except when it comes to ideas. It seems he has never proposed a single one that he doesnt think deserves repeated consideration, no matter how hopeless or discredited it may be.

title: I Feel Bad About My Face
description: Last week, I took a few delicious days off from work and read Nora Ephrons latest book, I Feel Bad About My Neck.

title: China: Google Invests in Internet Firm
description: In a move to expand beyond the search business in the worlds second-largest Internet market, Google has made an investment in Xunlei NetworkTechnology, a Chinese Internet video firm, the company said. A Google spokesman said that the investment in Xunlei would be announced today in Beijing, but he declined to give details. According to wire services, the China Daily reported that Google will team up with Ceyuan Ventures, a venture capital firm in Shangai, to buy a stake in Xunlei, which is in Shenzhen. According to the reports, Xunleis Web site attracts more than 50 million visitors a day and more than 80 million users have downloaded its software. The Xunlei deal would be Googles second in as many days in China. Google is also teaming with China Mobile, that countrys largest mobile telecommunications carrier, to deliver search services to cellphones.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed high-definition videodisc that will play on rival technologies referred incorrectly to one capability of the Blu-ray players, a rival to the HD-DVD technology. Blu-Ray players do, in fact, play standard DVDs, as do HD-DVD players. One difference is that some new HD-DVD discs are sold in a combination format that will also play on standard DVD players, while Blu-Ray discs currently do not have this feature.

title: At Least the Hero Was on Time
description: The year may be young, but it is not too early to nominate the No. 1 feel-good story of 2007. Somebody is going to have to work awfully hard to outdo Wesley Autrey, a true hero in a city where the word hero is overworked to the point of losing all meaning.

title: After Soaring to the Top, Romo Tumbles Back to Earth
description: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 4  Tony Romo and the football have parted ways at such an alarming rate in the past five games that Romo was forced to wear gloves during practice this week.

title: Administrator Is Dismissed From Nuclear Security Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Energy Secretary fired the head of the departments nuclear weapons program on Thursday, citing a series of security failures at national laboratories, including the discovery of a computer device containing thousands of classified documents in the home of a former worker during a drug raid by the police.

title: Florida: New Leader of Juvenile Justice Department
description: Gov. Charlie Crist named Chief Walter A. McNeil of the Tallahassee police as secretary of the State Department of Juvenile Justice. Anthony Schembri, a former New York City commissioner of corrections, held the post under former Gov. Jeb Bush and was in charge a year ago when Martin Lee Anderson, 14, died a day after being admitted to a juvenile boot camp in Panama City. In November, seven guards and a nurse were charged with manslaughter in connection with Martins death. Mr. McNeil, a Democrat, said he would balance prevention and treatment programs with punishment.

title: Backup Tight End Can Talk the Shockey Talk
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 4  There is nothing subtle about Jeremy Shockey. His hair is surfer-dude blond, his arms are emblazoned with tattoos, and he barks at opponents and officials when things do not bounce his way.

title: In War of Vague Borders, Detainee Longs for Court
description: Ali al-Marri, whom the government calls a sleeper agent for Al Qaeda and who is the only person on the American mainland still held as an enemy combatant, spends his days in a small cell in solitary confinement at the Navy brig in Charleston, S.C. When he is in an ironic mood, his lawyers say, he calls the cell his villa.

title: Hedge Fund Plans to Solicit Proxies
description: Pirate Capital, a $1.7 billion hedge fund, plans to solicit proxies in support of its push to persuade the Brinks Company, the armored-truck and security provider, to hire an investment bank for a possible sale.

description: WHAT Resort and residential community at a ski area.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 4  The president of the New Jersey State Senate on Thursday proposed a ban on all gifts to lawmakers as part of a sweeping package of bills intended to stiffen penalties for ethics violations.

description: JAZZ

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Re On the Demanding Guest Diet (Dec. 29): I had always wondered about the flip side of hosts who invite you to their palatial homes, but dont actually want you to enter  not without first taking off your shoes and donning a hazmat suit. Now I learn what it is. When they go visiting, they switch from being imperious hosts to demanding guest dieters.

title: Smiles, Backslaps, Even a Civility Meeting: For a Day, at Least, Bipartisanship Reigns

description: Book publishers braced themselves for a financial blow this week after a bankruptcy filing by Advanced Marketing Services, a book distributor.

title: Rise in Ethanol Raises Concerns About Corn as a Food
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 4  Renewing concerns about whether there will be enough corn to support the demand for both fuel and food, a new study has found that ethanol plants could use as much as half of Americas corn crop next year.

title: Looking Forward to Looking Back
description: EVERY year anniversaries of significant historic events provide opportunities for scholars, pundits, bloggers and even less voluble Americans to reflect on the past as well as the present. In 2006, the news media marked the 100th anniversary of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, the 50th anniversary of Elvis Presleys first hits, the 20th anniversary of the Challenger disaster, the 5th anniversary of 9/11. Heres a look ahead at what well be looking back on in 2007.

title: A Director Decides to Override a Friendship
description: Everyone who knows him says it: In a tough fight, Kenneth G. Langone is a guy you want in your corner.

title: With a 3-Goal Barrage, Straka Humbles the Flyers
description: When his turn came to absorb the cheers after he was named the games first star last night, Rangers forward Martin Straka skated a small circle on the Madison Square Garden ice. He raised his stick, lowered his eyes and disappeared into the tunnel as quickly as he could.

title: Albany: Lawyer Advertising Rules
description: The New York State court system has adopted revised advertising rules for lawyers meant to protect consumers from misleading or predatory marketing. The rules, which take effect on Feb. 1, permit client testimonials if they are factually supported and require the ads to disclose any payment made to those giving testimonials. Dramatizations are permitted if the use of actors is disclosed, according to Mark H. Alcott, president of the State Bar Association.

title: Illinois: Lawsuit Against Governors Administration
description: A government watchdog group filed a lawsuit in state court against the administration of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, seeking to obtain copies of subpoenas issued to his office in a continuing federal investigation into hiring practices. The watchdog, the Better Government Association, asserted that the subpoenas, which it tried unsuccessfully to obtain last summer under the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, were a matter of public record. But a spokeswoman for the governors office, Abby Ottenhoff, said the administration had received clear instructions from prosecutors not to discuss or disclose any information related to subpoenas. Though Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, has not been accused of any wrongdoing in the investigation, his administration has been dogged by accusations of hiring fraud and a kickback scheme in a state pension program.

title: Bush Announces Pick for Intelligence Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  From the start, John D. Negroponte felt miscast as the nations first director of national intelligence, a diplomat who never seemed comfortable in spooks clothing, colleagues and friends of his said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the hiring practices of Google reversed the names of the two employees looking over a job application. Laszlo Bock, a Google vice president, was at right; Todd Carlisle, an analyst at the company, was at left.

title: Players Off-Season Regimens Are as Different as Their Swings
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  After Christina Kim struck her final golf shot last season, she suddenly had a number of options at her disposal for the off-season.

title: Brooklyn: Mulching Sites
description: Saying that it was not mulch ado about nothing, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the opening of 66 sites this weekend where New Yorkers will be able to drop off Christmas trees for recycling into wood chips. During the 11th annual MulchFest, the sites, available on the citys Web site, nyc.gov, and on 311 will accept trees from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. tomorrow and Sunday. Many of the sites will be equipped with chippers, allowing the public, even those who come fir-free, to carry home mulch, officials said. Mr. Bloomberg cautioned that only trees and wreaths cleaned of decoration, and not in plastic bags, would be accepted, saying, No fruitcakes, Christmas socks or Hanukkah gelt.

title: For Knicks Lee, Benchwarmers Seat Is Usually Cool
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 4  David Lee leads the Knicks in rebounds and field-goal percentage, converts free throws at a better rate than Stephon Marbury and averages more assists than Nate Robinson.

title: No Place for a Zamboni: A Hockey Rink Where Players Sink
description: IN the raw context of the human condition, of life and survival on this planet, all sports are unnecessary, silly even.

title: Saying the No. 1 Ranking Is Worth Keeping, G.M.s Chief Vows to Fight Toyota
description: DETROIT, Jan. 4  General Motors is not ready to concede its position as the worlds largest automaker, the chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said Thursday, but he offered scant evidence that the company could fend off a challenge from Toyota, its Japanese rival.

title: Spare Times - Floodwall
description: FLOODWALL When Jana K. Napoli, an artist born and bred in New Orleans, returned to her hometown a few weeks after Hurricane Katrina hit, she sifted through the detritus in her neighborhood. She found sofas and pianos and hand-sewn lace, but she picked up only the abandoned dresser drawers. Originally she envisioned them as receptacles for a new project. But the more drawers she salvaged, the more she saw promise in them alone. I began to realize that these drawers could be a symbol of the households that were lost, Ms. Napoli said. She collected 700 drawers from across the city, meticulously labeling each with the address where it was found. They became the basis for Floodwall, above, an installation now on view on the Liberty Street Bridge, near the World Financial Center. Balanced along the span of the bridge like luggage left behind, the drawers are revealingly empty: once home to family secrets and worldly goods, they now contain only layers of liner paper and imprints from letters and photographs. But they are not anonymous. Working with neighborhood associations, Ms. Napoli found some of their owners. With a partner, she began an ambitious oral history and database, cataloging the lives of New Orleans residents through this most steadfast of possessions. My father surprised me with that cedar chest for my trousseau, one woman recalled; another kept her sons belongings in a drawer, decades after he was murdered. In Floodwall, comments like these are broadcast on LED signs as reminders of the lives these wooden survivors touched. (On the Liberty Street Bridge; enter at One World Financial Center on Liberty Street and South End Avenue, Lower Manhattan. Through Feb. 9. For more information or to be a part of the oral history project: floodwall.org.)

title: When a Woman Rattles a Man's World of Fraud
description: Comedy of Power is the name of Claude Chabrols latest film to be released in the United States, but the phrase could describe much of this directors work. Though his films tend to be witty and ironical rather than laugh-out-loud funny, they often concern themselves with the behavior and misbehavior  both intimate and public  of the French ruling classes.

title: Boulevard in Newark Runs From Decline to Rebirth
description: NEWARK, Jan. 2  Carolyn Whigham stood on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and took in the landscape of tattered brownstones, trash-strewn lots and skinny addicts by the front door of the funeral home that has been in her family for three generations. Then she closed her eyes and a vision of the street in the 1950s took hold, a reverie of mansions, graceful oak trees and the reassuring roar of a bustling industrial city.

title: Self-Portraits That Obscure the Self
description: Photographers and painters have always made self-portraits; doing your own likeness is part of an artists franchise. But sometimes the cameras potential nudges photographers further, encouraging a theatrical impulse: to portray themselves as a clown, or a person of the opposite sex, or even, say, Jesus. That was the case with F. Holland Day (1864-1933), a wealthy and eccentric Bostonian influenced by artists like Oscar Wilde and Aubrey Beardsley. Starting out as a publisher of belles lettres, in the late 1880s he began making photographs, and rather exotic ones, at that.

title: Canada: Environment Minister Loses Portfolio

The main move was the removal of Rona Ambrose, left, as environment minister after months of condemnation. Clean air and climate change are likely to be major issues in the next national election, with the opposition Liberal Party now led by a former environment minister, Stphane Dion. Ms. Ambrose was replaced by John Baird, who had been head of the Treasury Board. She is now intergovernmental affairs minister.

title: Manhattan: School Complaints Rise

The commissioner, Richard J. Condon, said his office received 2,552 complaints in 2006, compared with 1,849 in 2005. Complaints can include allegations of cheating, abuse of students and theft. The report said 259 cases were substantiated, with 101 referred to prosecutors, compared with 251 substantiated cases and 60 referrals to prosecutors in 2005. Mr. Condon attributed the increase to use of the citys 311 hot line and pressure on workers to report misdeeds.

He was named special counsel. Also appointed were two people who served under Mr. Spitzer while he was attorney general: Joe Baker was named assistant deputy secretary for health and human services, and Marlene Turner was named chief of staff.

And within a certain range of tempo  anywhere between a stroll and a jaunt  its imperative is a hard, foot-tapping swing.

title: Spare Times
description: FLOODWALL When Jana K. Napoli, an artist born and bred in New Orleans, returned to her hometown a few weeks after Hurricane Katrina hit, she sifted through the detritus in her neighborhood. She found sofas and pianos and hand-sewn lace, but she picked up only the abandoned dresser drawers. Originally she envisioned them as receptacles for a new project. But the more drawers she salvaged, the more she saw promise in them alone. I began to realize that these drawers could be a symbol of the households that were lost, Ms. Napoli said. She collected 700 drawers from across the city, meticulously labeling each with the address where it was found. They became the basis for Floodwall, above, an installation now on view on the Liberty Street Bridge, near the World Financial Center. Balanced along the span of the bridge like luggage left behind, the drawers are revealingly empty: once home to family secrets and worldly goods, they now contain only layers of liner paper and imprints from letters and photographs. But they are not anonymous. Working with neighborhood associations, Ms. Napoli found some of their owners. With a partner, she began an ambitious oral history and database, cataloging the lives of New Orleans residents through this most steadfast of possessions. My father surprised me with that cedar chest for my trousseau, one woman recalled; another kept her sons belongings in a drawer, decades after he was murdered. In Floodwall, comments like these are broadcast on LED signs as reminders of the lives these wooden survivors touched. (On the Liberty Street Bridge; enter at One World Financial Center on Liberty Street and South End Avenue, Lower Manhattan. Through Feb. 9. For more information or to be a part of the oral history project: floodwall.org.)

Whether by Degas or Rockwell, these scenes frequently combine the allure of intimate, taboo or arcane knowledge with an irresistibility similar to that exerted by small cute things, like puppies or babies. They let us inside and they soften us up, offering a mix of reality and romance that is the visual equivalent of a backstage tour or a behind-the-music video. We see an artists process, circumstances or sense of self, and glimpse the tools and tricks of a given trade. The seeming collapse of arts fourth wall is almost inevitably thrilling.
