title: Remain Silent? Some in Custody Spell It All Out
description: The Beast of Broadway, as the tabloids call him, a successful actor, has been accused of sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl. But his grade-school teacher would be proud of him in at least one respect: He is a good speller.

title: Spy Chiefs Choice to Step Back Feeds Speculation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  From the start, John D. Negroponte felt miscast as the nations first director of national intelligence, a diplomat who never seemed comfortable in spooks clothing, colleagues and friends of his said.

title: Senate Feels Heat as House Cranks Up Ethics Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Unexpectedly broad ethics rule changes that the House passed Thursday are putting new pressure on the Senate.

title: New York Mayor Plays Down Expectations for 2008 Convention
description: With a decision from the Democratic National Committee on where it will hold its 2008 presidential nominating convention on the horizon, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared to dampen expectations yesterday that the party would choose New York over Denver, the other city still in contention.

title: Defending the Printed Page as the New China Stirred
description: Chinas growing prosperity and the soaring prices for contemporary Chinese art make it easy to forget that the country first opened its doors to modernization in the late 1970s, when Maos successor Deng Xiaoping introduced capitalist-oriented market reforms. Deng also removed restrictions on the flow of information in China, which allowed foreign ideas to flourish. Most of this information arrived not via the Internet, of course, but in the form of books.

title: Handshakes, Hoodies and Hostility
description: Hempstead, N.Y.

title: As Trees Blossom in N.Y., More Snow Out West
description: In New York City, where there has been no snow at all this season, the cherry trees are beginning to blossom in temperatures that have been inching up all week and could hit 70 degrees on Saturday.

title: Bush to Name a New General to Oversee Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  President Bush has decided to name Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus as the top American military commander in Iraq, part of a broad revamping of the military team that will carry out the administrations new Iraq strategy, administration officials said Thursday.

title: Snowbound Neverland in Colorado
description: SAM BUCKMELTER, who is 10 years old and lives in Denver, has spent most of his waking life studying the vainglorious snowboard acrobatics of the Great Ones  riders like Danny Kass, Jeremy Jones and Andreas Wiig whose names and sponsors logos are etched in the margins of his fifth-grade notebooks.

title: 30 Seconds of Fame at Super Bowl XLI Will Cost $2.6 Million
description: A MONTH before Super Bowl XLI, it remains unclear which teams will face off on Feb. 4 in Miami. In the other big game that night  the battle of the Super Bowl advertisers  the lineup is becoming clearer.

title: Massachusetts Swears in a Black Democrat as Governor
description: BOSTON, Jan. 4  In a ceremony rich with gestures of openness and symbols of conquering adversity, Deval L. Patrick, the first black governor of Massachusetts, took his oath of office on Thursday. He promised far-reaching changes in attitude and policy and asked people to see our stake in each others dreams and struggles as well as our own, and act on that.

title: Turkmen Leader Proposes Vast Change to Lift Isolation
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Jan. 4  Turkmenistans acting president, Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, who had promised only continuity with the severely authoritarian policies of his predecessor, on Thursday proposed measures that would help lift the nation from its fortresslike isolation.

title: Comeback Player Award Validates Pennington
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 4  Chad Pennington does not have to be standing in the pocket to draw attention. Pennington, the Jets quarterback, faced a dogged rush last Sunday when he and a few teammates gathered at a Japanese restaurant near the teams practice facility to celebrate receiver Laveranues Coless 29th birthday. Pennington was attracting so much attention, Coles said he finally stepped in and said, Hey, its my day!

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about some of the more captivating events in the New York region in 2006 referred incorrectly to a federal investigation of Jared Paul Stern, a former contributor to the Page Six section of The New York Post whom Ronald W. Burkle, the supermarket magnate, has accused of an extortion attempt. The investigation came to light when it was reported by The Post; it was not announced by federal authorities. In addition, allegations that Mr. Stern had been caught on video demanding a $100,000 payment, as well as monthly stipends, for keeping negative accounts of Mr. Burkle from the press were made by Mr. Burkle, not by federal authorities. (Go to Article)

title: U.S. and Japan Warn North Korea Against 2nd Test
description: The United States and Japan warned North Korea today against conducting a second nuclear test, as South Korean officials reported suspicious activities at the Norths test site but no evidence of preparations for a nuclear blast.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the scene in Congress as Democrats prepared to assume control for the first time in 12 years, included an erroneous distinction for the late Ann Richards, whose photograph appeared prominently at a tea for Democratic women. She was not the first woman to be Texas governor; that was Miriam Ferguson, elected in 1924.

title: New Members of Congress in New York Region Take Office
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  One tucked photographs of two young constituents who had died fighting in Iraq inside the Bible he used to be sworn into office. Another held an open house in her new office here in the Capitol for the busload of supporters her staff invited from New York. And a third met with prominent liberals on a newly created bloggers alley here and appeared on C-Span to introduce himself to a new national audience.

description: CLASSICAL

title: A. Richard Newton, Pioneer in Electronic Design, Dies at 55
description: A. Richard Newton, a pioneer in electronic design technology who directly influenced the industry and was a mentor to countless engineering students, died on Tuesday in San Francisco. He was 55.

description: In Miss Potter, Rene Zellweger, her face pickled in cheeriness, is Beatrix Potter, the creator of Peter Rabbit, Squirrel Nutkin and Mrs. Tittlemouse, among other beloved characters in childrens literature.

title: Writing Funny
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Israeli Raid Overshadows Olmerts Talks With Mubarak
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert met President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on Thursday evening in an effort to give momentum to the Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations. But the meeting was overshadowed by an Israeli raid in the West Bank in which four Palestinians were killed and 20 wounded.

title: Taliban Leader Promises More Afghan War
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 4  In what appears to be the first exchange with a journalist since going into hiding five years ago, the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, said that he had not seen Al Qaedas chief, Osama bin Laden, in five years and that he would never negotiate with the United States-backed government of Hamid Karzai in Afghanistan. He also threatened to continue the war until foreign troops withdraw from Afghanistan.

title: Rethinking the Death Penalty
description: New Jersey could take the lead among states in abolishing the death penalty if it follows the recommendation that a legislative commission made this week. It is the right thing to do, and not just because capital punishment is barbaric and a poor deterrent. It has become increasingly clear as the use of DNA evidence has grown that there is simply too great a risk of making an irreversible mistake.

title: Bush Is Expected to Shift U.S. Ambassador in Iraq to U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  President Bush intends to name Zalmay Khalilzad, the Afghan-born diplomat who has been ambassador to Iraq for the past 21 months, to be the new envoy to the United Nations, part of a diplomatic shakeup as Mr. Bush prepares to announce a new strategy for the war.

title: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Husseins Final Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The execution of Saddam Hussein was initially hailed as an example of democratic justice being served in Iraq, but leading members of Congress said Thursday that the conduct surrounding the hanging could undermine United States strategy in Iraq and complicate efforts to help the new Iraqi government succeed.

title: The First Energy President
description: Now that President Gerald Ford has been buried with all the honors he deserved, it is time to discuss a proper memorial. I would suggest the Gerald Ford Energy Independence Act.

title: Cuomo to Review Spending on State Lawmakers Pet Projects
description: ALBANY, Jan. 4  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said Thursday that his office would review thousands of individual grants known as member items, the spending Albany lawmakers doled out for pet projects last year, staking out a potentially vast new front in efforts to reform the ways of the state capital.

title: Correction: A Side of San Antonio That Nearly Forgets the Alamo
description: An article about San Antonio last Friday included outdated information about a barbecue stand in the city. The Pig Stand at 801 South Presa Street is no longer in business. The article also referred incorrectly to the San Antonio River along the River Walk. The bulk of the River Walk follows the natural flow of the river, not a diverted section.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the funeral of former President Gerald R. Ford drew an erroneous comparison between Chelsea Clinton and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who sat next to each other. Ms. Rice received degrees from the University of Denver and Notre Dame. She is not an alumna of Stanford University, where Ms. Clinton received a bachelors degree. (Ms. Rice is a former Stanford provost.)

title: Warsaw Archbishop Denies He Was an Informant
description: PARIS, Jan. 5  Archbishop Stanislaw Wielgus, the new Catholic prelate of Warsaw who is caught in eastern Europes widening hunt for former collaborators with the Communist-era secret police, denied today that he had ever spied for Polands Sluzba Bezpieczenstwa, the security service known by its initials. He insisted that recently uncovered files naming him as an informant were filled with fabrications.

title: President of Venezuela Fires Deputy and Interior Minister
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 4  President Hugo Chvez abruptly fired his vice president and his interior minister on Wednesday night, issuing a rare public acknowledgment that violent crime and prison killings were severe problems.

title: More Rhode Island Schools Closed in Disease Outbreak
description: COVENTRY, R.I., Jan. 4  More than 20,000 Rhode Island students were told Thursday to stay home from school at least until Monday as officials investigate the case of a student hospitalized Wednesday with meningitis.

title: Miers Steps Down as White House Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Harriet E. Miers, President Bushs longtime confidante and onetime Supreme Court nominee, has resigned as White House counsel, officials said Thursday.

description: Designers' cars don't always fit real-world demands.

description: The most viewed health articles on nytimes.com for 2006 covered topics including aging, low-fat diets, dress codes for doctors and breast-feeding.

description: The strategy seems simple. The Eagles will blitz Eli Manning.

description: Those who take descriptive nouns as surnames tacitly subscribe to a recertification process of sorts. Vlad the Impaler was presumably expected to impale someone now and then. Bob the Builder would be demoted to mere Bob if he didnt occasionally build something.

title: Xerox Sells Coporate Headquarters
description: Xerox has sold its corporate headquarters to a developer in Norwalk, Conn., for $54.8 million. The sale to a division of Building and Land Technology closed Friday. It came less than two months after the company announced plans to leave its office complex at 800 Long Ridge Road.

title: Marvell Executives to Return Money From Backdated Options
description: The Marvell Technology Group said yesterday that it had found incorrect dating of some stock-option grants and that top executives had agreed to pay back extra money they received as a result. The company, which makes microchips for hard-disk drives, wireless networks and DVD drives, said an internal review of its stock-option accounting practices had found that the actual dates of some grants differed from the recorded dates.

title: Distributors Bankruptcy Rattles Book Industry
description: Book publishers braced themselves for a financial blow this week after a bankruptcy filing by Advanced Marketing Services, a book distributor. The company filed for bankruptcy protection last Friday, reporting more than $200 million in debt to dozens of publishing companies. Its creditors included publishers large and small, among them Random House, which is owed $43.3 million, and Good Books of Intercourse, Pa.., which specializes in books about the Amish and the Mennonites and is owed nearly $1 million.

title: Australian Insurer Buys 2nd U.S. Firm
description: The QBE Insurance Group, Australias largest property and casualty insurer, has agreed to buy the United States arm of Winterthur for $1.16 billion, its biggest purchase ever and its second American acquisition in three weeks. The deal will add $1.45 billion in annual sales to QBE, which is based in Sydney, the company said Thursday.

title: Northwest Reaches Deal to Buy Feeder Airline
description: Northwest Airlines said Thursday that it had reached an agreement to buy the regional feeder airline Mesaba, although it was not clear that Mesabas parent company would accept it. Both airlines are in bankruptcy protection.

title: Can the Deal Boom Continue in 2007?
description: In 2006, a heady cocktail of rapidly growing emerging markets, floods of private equity and hedge fund money, buoyant chief executive confidence and a hungry debt market created an environment so fertile that mergers surpassed all records.

title: Chirac Issues Veiled Warning Over Suez Bid
description: Pesident Jacques Chirac of France threw his weight behind the planned merger of the utilities Suez and Gaz de France on Thursday amid doubts over the future of the government-backed tie-up, issuing a veiled warning to those who might interfere with the deal.

title: Parmalat Gets Green Light to Pursue Banks
description: Italys constitutional court has upheld the legitimacy of attempts by Parmalat to seek funds from banks that lent it money before the dairy companys 2003 bankruptcy. The Dec. 28 court ruling affects several banks including Intesa Sanpaolo, Banco Popolare di Verona & Novara, Credit Suisse, Unipol Banca and Banca Popolare dellEtruria & del Lazio.

title: German Lawmaker Charged in Volkswagen Scandal
description: German prosecutors brought charges Thursday against a second suspect in a corruption scandal at Volkswagen, accusing a federal lawmaker and former employee representative of involvement in events that featured prostitutes. Hans-Jrgen Uhl was accused of being an accessory to breach of trust over his alleged participation in events in Barcelona and Seoul in 2001 during the course of which the services of prostitutes allegedly were called upon, prosecutors in Braunschweig said in a statement.

title: Siemens Hires Former Prosecutor to Help Root Out Corruption
description: A former public prosecutor has started work at Siemens to help the company track down hundreds of millions of euros suspected of having been transferred illegally into foreign accounts and used for bribes. The former prosecutor, Daniel Noa, until recently a senior public prosecutor in Stuttgart, Germany, started Jan. 1 as the chief compliance officer for Siemens and will have direct access to the financial records needed for an internal company investigation. Mr. Noa managed substantial white-collar crimes cases for more than 20 years, the company, based in Munich, said.

title: Ford Chief Squashes Talks of a Toyota Alliance
description: The chief executive of Ford Motor, Alan Mulally, has said he traveled to Japan last month to meet with Toyota Motor executives just to show his respect for what they had accomplished, not in an effort to bring the companies any closer. Reports that the chairman of Toyota, Fujio Cho, had met in Tokyo with Mr. Mulally at Mr. Mullalys request had sparked talk of a potential alliance. Mr. Mulally squelched that speculation again Wednesday, saying that manufacturing methods  along with safety engineering, fuel economy and environmental issues  were topics that all automakers discussed with one another.

title: Rival Caremark Suitors in War of Words
description: The high-stakes battle to acquire Caremark Rx, pharmacy benefits manager, escalated on Thursday when Express Scripts urged Caremark shareholders to reject an offer from the drugstore chain CVS. In a letter to Caremark shareholders, Express Scripts said that the CVS deal would have a lasting negative impact and called the CVS offer insufficient.

title: Times Co. Sells TV Stations to Buyout Firm
description: The New York Times Company has agreed to sell its nine local television stations to Oak Hill Capital Partners, a private equity firm, for $575 million, as the industry struggles to find ways to bolster the troubled newspaper business amid flagging advertising revenues. For The Times Company, which owns The New York Times, The Boston Globe and The International Herald Tribune as well as 15 local newspapers, in particular, total ad revenue has been down more than 3 percent every month since July compared with the same month in the previous year, reversing gains in the earlier months of 2006.

title: 2 Canadian Drug Companies to Merge
description: Shares of Ecopia BioSciences fell more than 24 percent Thursday after the company announced a merger with Caprion Pharmaceuticals to create a new company specializing in developing treatments for cancer and infectious diseases.

title: In Year of Record Fees, UBS and Deutsche Get Left Behind
description: Much ink has been spilled on the banks that topped last years league tables (Goldman Sachs and Citigroup), but what about the losers? In a year when securities firms collected a record $36.7 billion for arranging stock and bond offerings, UBS and Deutsche Bank got left behind. Fees earned by the two banks climbed at less than half the pace of the worlds 25 top underwriters, which collectively posted a 23 percent increase in commissions in 2006, data compiled by Bloomberg News show.

title: Goldman and CanWest Team Up for Alliance Bid, Report Says
description: Goldman Sachs has teamed up with CanWest Global Communications to make an offer for Alliance Atlantis Communications, a Canadian media company, The Globe and Mail said. The report said that the two could offer as much as 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.1 billion) for Alliance, which was put on the block in December.

title: Most Viewed Education Articles of 2006
description: 1) At Colleges, Women Are Leaving Men in the Dust

title: Producers to Start Club for Real First Wives
description: In advance of the spring 2008 opening of their Broadway production of The First Wives Clubbased on the popular book and movieproducers Paul Lambert and Jonas Neilson plan to start up First Wives World, an online social networking site for divorcees, according to BusinessWeek. The two producers will invest $8 million to $10 million to get the site, which will offer ticket sales, forums, blogs, and, soon after, a dating service, off the ground this spring.

title: Tax Plan on Income Trusts Slows Canadian I.P.O.s
description: With no new income trust issues coming to Canadas public markets after the Oct. 31 federal government announcement that it would begin taxing trusts in 2011, the countrys initial public offering activity slowed dramatically in the final quarter of 2006 and the outlook for 2007 looks very dim, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers Canada.

title: Surprising No One, Power Confirms Talks for Putnam
description: Power Financial confirmed Thursday that it was in discussions to buy the money manager Putnam Investments of Boston, but it said no agreement had been reached. Media reports have been rife with the news that Power Financial, a unit of the holding company Power Corporation of Canada, has agreed to buy Putnam from its parent, the financial services company Marsh & McLennan, for $3.9 billion. A statement from Power said that because of media speculation and discussions with the Toronto Stock Exchange it was confirming the talks, but that at this time, no agreement has been reached by the participants in the process.

title: Broadcom Raises Options Price for Executives
description: The wireless chip maker Broadcom said Thursday it had reached agreement with a number of executives, including its acting chief financial officer, to increase the per share exercise prices previously in effect for certain stock options. The disclosure came after the company, which faces a federal investigation of the matter, announced late last year that an internal probe had found a number of option grants between 1998 and 2003 were improperly dated.

title: Most Viewed Politics Articles of 2006
description: 1) Guardedly, Democrats Are Daring to Believe

title: How Langone Lost Faith in Nardelli
description: Everyone who knows him says it: In a tough fight, Kenneth G. Langone is a guy you want in your corner. But when Robert L. Nardelli, the former chief executive of Home Depot, refused to bend to the will of an exasperated board and accept a pay cut, he lost the crucial support of a friend who as lead director not only recruited him but presided over his compensation contract that would later draw so much fire, according to a report in The New York Times.

title: Rival Bidder Emerges in Battle for Hutchinson Essar, Report Says
description: The bidding war for Hutchison Essar, Indias fourth-largest cellular phone operator, may turn into a four-way battle, according to a report that Indias Hinduja Group has entered the fray. According to The Wall Street Journal, Hinduja Group, a conglomerate with interests in steel, trucks and telecommunications, has approached Hutchison Whampoa about buying its 67 percent stake in Hutchison Essar.

title: Google Buys Stake in Chinese Multimedia Site
description: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in Chinas Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. The move was widely seen as an attempt by Google, which dominates the Internet search market in the United States, to compete better with Baidu.com, which controlled nearly 57 percent of Chinas search-engine market at the end of June, according to Analysis International, an information technology research company based in Beijing.

title: Industrial Bank Plans China I.P.O.
description: Industrial Bank, which is part-owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, plans an initial public offering in China after shares of rival banks soared. The China Securities Regulatory Commissions listing committee will meet on Jan. 8 to review the banks plan to sell as many as 1.33 billion new shares. The lender, 16 percent owned by Hang Seng Bank the HSBC unit, plans to sell 20 percent to 25 percent of its share capital in the so-called A-share offering.

title: Most Viewed Washington Articles of 2006
description: 1) Kerry Pressing Swift Boat Case Long After Loss

title: Brinks Investors Pushing for Sale of Company
description: Pirate Capital, a $1.7 billion hedge fund, plans to solicit proxies in support of its push to persuade Brinks, the armored-truck and security provider, to hire an investment bank for a possible sale. In a regulatory filing yesterday, Pirate Capital also proposed electing its founder and another Pirate executive to Brinks board. Pirate owns 8.5 percent of Brinks and is its largest shareholder. Both Pirate and MMI Investments, which owns 8.3 percent of Brinks shares, want the company to hire an investment bank for a possible sale, in the belief that it is undervalued.

title: Little Dog Laughs Its Last
description: The producers of Douglas Carter Beanes new play The Little Dog Laughed, about a gay Hollywood star who is kept in the closet by his agent, have announced that the show will close after the matinee on Feb. 18.

title: Amaranth Founder Said to Plan New Firm
description: The founder of Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that is winding down after losing more than $6 billion last year, is considering launching a firm with some former colleagues, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.

title: Gadfly Investors Get Respect
description: For decades, activist shareholders were an entertaining, but largely ignored, Wall Street sideshow. Today, however, it seems that activists have captured the center ring and are directing the main event. On Wednesday, shareholder advocates like Relational Investors Ralph V. Whitworth could claim one of their biggest prizes yet when Home Depot announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, long a target of shareholders ire for his large compensation and the companys flagging stock price.

title: Foundation Hires Blackstone to Advise on Tribune Moves
description: The McCormick Tribune Foundation, the second-largest shareholder in Tribune, said Thursday that it had hired the Blackstone Group to advise it on a course of action while the media conglomerate is on the block. The foundations five directors are all current or former members of Tribune management and could influence the companys decision whether to sell some or all of its assets. The foundation and the company said they had taken steps to avoid any conflicts of interest.

title: 2 Law Firms Call Off Their Plans for a Merger
description: One of the biggest proposed law firm mergers of the last year has been called off, the victim of too many insurmountable issues. Dewey Ballantine and Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe, who jointly announced the news Thursday, had been in talks to create one of the nations largest legal advisers, with 1,500 lawyers based in New York and San Francisco. But questions about a variety of problems, ranging from management seniority to Deweys unfunded pension system, undermined the deal.

title: Germanys Merck May Sell Generic Drugs Unit
description: Merck of Germany said Friday that it is considering the sale of its generic drugs business, which could fetch more than $5 billion, according to some estimates. Reuters reported that the German drugs and chemicals group seems eager to cut debt from its recent $13.3 billion acquisition of Serono, which it is financing largely through loans.

title: Former Prosecutor Joins Gibson Dunn
description: Douglas Fuchs, an assistant United States attorney in Los Angeles, will join the white-collar crimes practice at Gibson Dunn & Crutcher, starting Monday, The Los Angeles Times said. Mr. Fuchs led the prosecution of 11 former executives of Homestore, an online real estate listings company, for a $67 million accounting fraud scheme. The companys founder and former chief executive, Stuart Wolff, was sentenced last October to 15 years in federal prison after being found guilty of inflating revenue.

title: Akzo Insists on an I.P.O. for Drug Unit, as Buyout Firms Circle
description: Despite increasing interest from private equity firms, Akzo Nobel insisted Thursday that it would push for an initial public offering of its 8 billion euro ($10.4 billion) pharmaceutical unit, Organon Biosciences, The Financial Times reported. While the Dutch conglomerate said an I.P.O. of Organon Biosciences was its preferred option, at least three consortiums may be preparing bids, the paper said. These include a group of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Warburg Pincus and CVC Capital Partners; another led by the Blackstone Group; and a third headed by Cinven. The Carlyle Group has also expressed interest.

title: Jamil Hussein Found, Questions Linger
description: The Iraq interior ministry has suddenly discovered that it does have a police captain named Jamil Hussein in its employ  Jamil Gholaiem Hussein, to be exact  and it is now seeking that officers arrest for speaking to the press.

title: The Presidential Campaign of 2007
Despair Over a Botched Execution
description: Signs that Charles Krauthammer was souring on the Iraq war began to appear in the spring, when Krauthammer wrote in his Washington Post column that there is only one hope for success in Iraq: an effective, broad-based national unity government that, during its mandatory four-year term, presides over an American withdrawal. Now, the manner in which Saddam Hussein was executed has led Krauthammer to conclude that the current Iraq government is not worth defending. We should not be surging American troops in defense of such a government, he argues in The Washington Post. Krauthammer writes:

title: On the Hill: Bang the Gavel Slowly
description: This year, Congress is going to be civil and bipartisan. And were going to actually lose those 20 pounds! But seriously, folks, leave it to Carl Hulse to dig under the jubilation to find the real meaning in yesterdays Democratic takeover:

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Read His Lips
description: Mitt Romney refused to sign a no new taxes pledge while he was running for governor of Massachusetts, but now that he is shooting for the presidency, he has done just that.

title: Will It Blend?
description: Im not alone when I say that Ill happily watch your ad if its entertaining and worth my while. The number of hilarious ad videos circulating on YouTubemillions of people VOLUNTARILY watching corporate adsis testimony to that.

description: Brian Bistrong (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

title: The Plumbing Stops Up, and Owners Get the Bill
description: Q Recently, the two apartments below me had a plumbing problem. There are four apartments on the same septic system, including my own. Normally, the co-op is responsible for plumbing problems, but our president felt that since the problem was caused by paper towels blocking the system, and since only my apartment and my next-door neighbors were occupied when the problem occurred, the co-op should not pay for the repairs.

title: Kerkorians MGM Offer Comes Up Short
description: The year is starting with another underwhelming showing from Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor and corporate agitator who backed out of his General Motors investment late last year. Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorians holding vehicle, said Friday its offer to buy up to 15 million shares of MGM Mirage ended with a paltry 445,000 shares tendered, potentially quelling for now speculation that Mr. Kerkorian will mount a takeover of the casino operator.

title: Wheres Eddie?
description: The nominations for Eddie Murphy in the best supporting category for Dreamgirls have been piling up. Yesterday, he received one from the Screen Actors Guild, and hes already gotten a Golden Globe, so it looks like he may have a shot at dancing with Oscar.

title: A Father Teaches the Son
description: A.O. Scott suggests that parents who find themselves condemned to mediocre family movies, try something new.

title: CSI Continues to Take Over the Universe
description: Fresh off the announcement of yesterdays nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards, Alan Rosenberg, SAGs president, said he would seek a second two-year term when elections are held later this year, subject to an O.K. from his spouse, Marg Helgenberger.

title: Nightmare at the Museum
description: Lets say youre a museum in pursuit of additional traffic. Youve tried brochures, gussying up your Web site, and even bus-side advertising. But nothing worked like having a blockbuster movie made about your collection. According to Reuters, Night at the Museum boosted attendance at American Museum of Natural history by 50,000 over last year, and the movie has only been around a few weeks.

title: Her Majesty and Her Agent
description: Breaking news: The Brits love Casino Royale and The Queen.Variety breaks down the British Academy Film Awards, their Oscars, thusly:

title: The War at Home: Staff Shake-Ups
description: The White House is denying claims that a statement Mr. Bush issued after signing postal legislation last month asserted new executive authority to allow the opening of mail without a warrant in exigent circumstances.

title: Amorous Brazilian Banker Wins Round With YouTube
description: As if YouTube  did not have enough trouble with its users posting clips that violate copyrights, the video-sharing site, newly acquired by Google, must now find a way to remove a video depicting a Merrill Lynch banker and a supermodel in what the Associated Press calls intimate scenes. A Brazilian judge this week ordered YouTube to filter out the video, which was the talk of Brazil when it first surfaced last fall.

title: Tijuana Streets Are Too Dangerous, So Police Are Disarmed
description: The entire Tijuana police force walked off the job yesterday after being effectively disarmed by 3,000 Mexican troops and federal agents  themselves dispatched two days ago to the crime-ridden border city to try to combat drug-cartel violence and chaos.

title: Former Merrill Analyst Sentenced in Insider-Trading Case
description: Stanislav Shpigelman, the former Merrill Lynch analyst who pleaded guilty to leaking confidential information to a $6.7 million insider-trading ring, was sentenced to three years and one month in prison in Manhattan federal court Friday. He was the second person and the first banker sentenced in connection with the conspiracy. Mr. Shpigelman, 24, admitted in July that he had given material nonpublic information about upcoming deals to Eugene Plotkin and David Pajcin, both former Goldman Sachs employees.

title: The Hill: Not Exactly 8 Days a Week
description: Democrats are already grumbling about the five-day work week  at least among themselves.

title: Viacoms Deal Strategist Expands Role
description: The former investment banker who has overseen Viacoms acquisition strategy for the past year just got a longer title for his business card. Wade Davis, the media groups senior vice president of mergers and acquisitions since December 2005, has become senior vice president of strategy, mergers and acquisitions, Viacom said Friday.

title: Cablevision Buyout Offer Is a Drag, Analyst Says
description: A takeover bid is usually seen as something that props up a companys share price. But a Pali Research analyst, Richard Greenfield, argues that just the reverse is true for Cablevision, the giant cable operator. In a research report on Friday, he suggests that Cablevisions stock is worth far more than what its controlling family, the Dolans, has said it is willing to pay.

title: Comment Zone: Advice for Spitzer
description: The other day, we asked Empire Zone readers to give advice to New Yorks new governor. There were suggestions to improve the upstate economy, provide affordable housing and health care for all, reform workers compensation and workplace safety, impose term limits on legislators, reduce  pollution, raise the minimum wage, repeal the Rockefeller-era drug laws, pass legislation allowing same-sex marriage or civil unions, and more. Following is an edited selection.As a student, my main concern is college tuition, writes  the commenter Amy. I believe that Governor Spitzer should investigate and take a look at how college funds are truly used. As a student I am extremely disappointed in the education I am paying to receive, and also extremely broke.

title: Macworld Bingo
description: As the rumor mill for Apples big announcements on Tuesday goes into overdrive, this witty programmer has treated viewers of the presentation to a game of Macworld Bingo. As Apple chief Steve Jobs goes through his speech, check off the typical Apple presentation elements as they occur. Get one row across, down or diagonally, and YOU WIN!

title: Stop Yer Engines
description: After mulling it for a day, the New York State Board of Elections has ordered Ciber, the Colorado-based information systems company contracted to test new voting machines for the state, to stop their tests. The board wants to figure out why a federal election assistance committee delayed giving Ciber permission last summer to accredit new voting machines. The word went out early this morning, and Ciber agreed to stop testing. Meanwhile, state elections officials are trying to get access to the federal committees internal assessment of Cibers problems.

title: Dem Leaders to Bush: Dont Surge
description: As President Bush inches closer to presenting his Iraq strategy, he is scheduling a series of meetings with members of Congress this afternoon and Monday. The White House is hoping to find support for its plan by reaching out to moderate Democrats and friendly Republicans. A meeting has not been scheduled with Democratic Congressional leaders, so Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California have just sent a letter to Mr. Bush.

title: Purnick on the Real Rudy
description: In a Political Memo, Joyce Purnick riffs on the recent brouhaha over the the Giuliani campaign papers. To get a more concrete view of his campaign strategy, she suggests, look at the Giuliani 2000 Web site, in which he glosses over his three marriages, the Kerik affair and other potentially troublesome matters.

title: Hewlett-Packard
description: The most requested ad of the day, from AdForum.

title: Windfall Awaits Readers Digest Banker
description: February 2 is likely to be a happy day for Michael Lynch. That is when shareholders of Readers Digest Association are set to vote on Ripplewood Holdings offer to take the publishing company private. If the deal closes, Mr. Lynch, who advised Readers Digest alongside his former employer, Goldman Sachs, is individually eligible for a $2.75 million fee. TheStreet.com wrote about the fee Friday, labelling it quite a coup for Mr. Lynch and calling the tag-team advisory arrangement highly unusual.

title: A Good Selling Point: A Small, Nearby Airport
description: The smallest things can influence where you end up living. It could be that the location provides an easy commute, or you love the early morning light, or it might be that you are right next door is the worlds best fly-fishing.

title: Who Needs Web 2.0 Anyway?
description: Some venture-capital types are sounding awfully weary about Web 2.0, a much-hyped term that The New York Timess David Pogue recently defined as participatory Web sites, like YouTube, MySpace, Wikipedia, Digg and Flickr, which [rely] on material supplied by the audience itself.

title: Carlyle Names Managing Directors
description: Carlyle Group, the giant private equity firm based in Washington, D.C., said this week it promoted 16 professionals to managing director, including three members of its New York office. It also promoted 18 people to principal or director, titles it said are equivalent in rank, principal being used in the United States and director in Europe and Asia.

title: King of Queens Sex Video!
description: Its official: everyone has a secret.

title: British Cartoon Protester Found Guilty of Soliciting Murder
description: BBC News  reports that Umran Javed, a 27-year-old British Muslim, has been found guilty of soliciting murder during a London rally last year, where he and others were protesting the publication in Denmark of cartoons that satirized the prophet Muhammad.

title: Blogtalk
description: According to a CNN transcript of the program Glenn Beck on Headline News, when it was suggested that a hurricane could cause a 20- to 25-foot storm surge in New York City, Mr. Beck said, Actually, that would clean the streets out. It might not be bad. Liberal blogs have cried foul, noting that studies show such a storm would cause heavy loss of life. One local blogs summary: Glenn Beck wants to kill you. (It should be noted his show is based here.) [Raw Story, AmericaBlog, My Two Senses and The Daily Gotham]

title: Whats in a Slogan?
description: President Bush is said to be calling his shift in Iraq war policy the New Way Forward.

title: Anti-Surge Protests Against McCain, Lieberman
description: Dont expect Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and anti-war activists to be kissing and making up anytime soon. Demonstrators were out in full force, despite the light sprinkle of rain, to protest his appearance at the American Enterprise Institute here in the nations capital. The self-styled Democrat-Independent joined Senator John McCain to speak about Iraq at the conservative think tank, and their call for more troops in Iraq was a foregone conclusion.

title: Vows: Kathryn and Michael
description: Kathryn Berger and Michael Herrington met during a business trip.

title: And This Is Detroit Once the Aliens Showed Up
description: The remake of War of the Worlds starring Tom Cruise is one of the movies lampooned in Scary Movie 4. In one scene, a newscaster narrates a video of a shattered cityskyscrapers are on fire, gunshots ring out, people are screaming. This is Detroit, the newscaster says solemnly, pausing a moment before the punch line, And this is Detroit once the aliens showed up! It is, of course, the exact same scene, but with aliens. Last spring, The Onion ran a story entitled, Detroit Sold for Scrap. And so on.

title: A Pregnant Pause
description: Looking forward to next weeks director and writer guild nominations, OscarWatch ovulates, gestates and cogitates. The process eventually produces  some pretty keen guesses.

title: A Status Quo Secretary General
description: The big powers in the United Nations Security Council chose Ban Ki-moon as secretary general because they wanted a low-key bureaucrat who wouldnt rock the boat. Judging by Mr. Bans early moves, the world has gotten exactly that.

title: Zalmay Khalilzad, on to a New Trouble Spot
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  In successive tours in Afghanistan and Iraq, Zalmay Khalilzad earned a reputation as a high-flying, independent, smooth operator  an Afghan-born problem solver who worked with two fragile countries recently invaded by the United States to try to cobble together stability.

title: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  The new Democratic leaders of the Senate and the House warned President Bush on Friday against sending additional troops to Iraq, setting the stage for what could become a major confrontation over a new war strategy.

title: Rival Coaches Share Bond, Except on Game Days
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 5  The longtime friendship between Tony Dungy and Herman Edwards was severely tested in 1996.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the side effects of the psychiatric drug Zyprexa misstated the name of a older drug tested against Zyprexa in a federally sponsored clinical trial. It was perphenazine (also called Trilafon), not Stelazine.

title: Jack Myers, 93, Editor Who Geared Science to Children, Dies
description: Jack E. Myers, a molecular biologist who not only researched algae as a food source that could be grown in space but also made science comprehensible to youngsters as an editor of Highlights for Children magazine, died Dec. 28 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 93.

title: Patriots' Recipe for Success Is Envy of the League
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 5  The huge Super Bowl banners hang from the upper deck of the stadium. Images of the Lombardi Trophy  three of them  are silhouetted on the front marquee at Gillette Stadium.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A museum entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday, about the New-York Historical Society, included an outdated closing date for an exhibition there. The exhibition, Elegy in the Dust: September 11th and the Chelsea Jeans Memorial, has been extended through July 1. It will not close tomorrow.

title: Leaked Notes on 08 Show Giuliani Without the Spin
description: The country sure has been enjoying itself reading about the Rudy Caper, feasting on the inside dish gleaned from Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential playbook.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) MUNICH (2005). Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this storys historical impetus  the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli hostages were murdered by members of a Palestinian terrorist group known as Black September  to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath, when Israel purportedly waged a campaign of vengeance with five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects over months and then years. Eric Bana plays the films moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the murders. Daniel Craig (the newest James Bond), Ciaran Hinds, Hans Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas.

title: Eagles Look to the Past to Bring Future Success
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5  When the phone rang Monday morning, Koy Detmer let his answering machine pick up.

title: Knicks Take Lead Early and Keep Adding to It
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 5  Eddy Curry found perfection Friday night, Jamal Crawford had a happy homecoming and the Knicks transformed a once-miserable trip into a modest sign of hope for the coming months.

title: Faces on a Coin (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Friday about notable anniversaries this year misspelled the name of a former Soviet premier. It is Nikita Khrushchev, not Kruschev.

title: Totals
The Land of Rising Conservation
description: TOKYO, Jan. 5  In many countries, higher oil prices have hurt pocketbooks and led to worries about economic slowdowns. But here in Japan, Kiminobu Kimura, an architect, says he has not felt the pinch. In fact, his monthly energy bill is lower than a year ago.

title: For Record-Setting Recruit, Full-Throated Praise and Whispered Doubts
description: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 5  Jimmy Clausen, one of the nations top-rated high school football players, watched most of Notre Dames dismal 41-14 loss to Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl on Wednesday night.

title: San Franciscans Hurl Their Rage at Parking Patrol
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5  It bears the hallmarks of a classic urban scourge: back-channel sales, assaults on enforcement officials and even death.

title: Marching Their Way Before Title Games Cameras
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5  On the sideline of a scruffy practice field late this week, the leader of the Florida Gators gathered his players after a long workout in the heat and the humidity to remind them that they would face more celebrated Ohio State opponents Monday.

title: Two Teenagers Confess to Committing Deadly Spree of Robberies in Queens Park, Police Say
description: The trail of the crime spree is brutal and damning: a burned-out minivan, a string of victims viciously beaten and robbed, a dead mans body found floating near a boathouse in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.

title: Reunion of Meyer and Smith Succeeds at Florida
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., Jan. 5  When Florida Coach Urban Meyer scored his biggest recruiting victory last summer, it was not achieved by beating out Miami, Florida State or Tennessee.

title: Monument to the Planet Suffers a Hard Fall to Earth
description: An artist who hoped to stir debate over global warming with his 175-ton quartzite and bronze sculpture Spaceship Earth is instead struggling to solve the mystery of its spectacular crash at Kennesaw State University last week.

title: Pursuing Writers, but Letting Them Lead the Chase
description: Opinions at length grow ugly, and so does talking about yourself: two traps the journalistic interview can fall into. One way out is to arm it with a needle of challenge. The subject, instead of standing to pronounce from a podium, is led to scurry, dodge and perhaps fight back, displaying paces and not just poundage.

title: A Blending of Euripides, Martial Arts and Noh
description: Something must have happened to Company Easts well-reviewed Medea on its way from the Edinburgh Festival Fringe to New York, where it opened on Thursday night for two weeks at La MaMa. Directed, choreographed and designed by Kenji Kawarasaki, this staging of Medea looked hastily put together and insubstantial, with a sudden last conceit suggesting some indecision about what it means to be.

title: Urgent Tasks for the New Congress (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Future With the Wind
description: AES, the big power company, is branching out to wind power generation and other alternative energy. The company, which generates and distributes electricity in 26 countries, is also entering the $28 billion carbon trading market, where credits are exchanged to reduce or offset greenhouse gas emissions. Its chief executive, Paul Hanrahan, sat down in his office at the companys sleek new headquarters in Arlington, Va., to discuss these developments. Following are excerpts:

title: Higher Pay Is Set for Transit Chief
description: The new leader of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will be paid $42,000 more than his predecessor, a raise that is justified because he will have a wider role in running the agency and shaping policy, a spokesman for Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday.

title: A Little Folk, a Little Rock and a Lot of Minimalism
description: White Magic is an entity in flux. It began in 2004 as a trio, led by the singer and keyboardist Mira Billotte. Then it became a duo, with Ms. Billotte and the guitarist Doug Shaw. For now its a shambly, spooked quartet, not quite folk and not quite rock, and as such it played with the bassist Brad Truax and the drummer Jim White on Thursday night at the Mercury Lounge.

title: The Vanishing Man of the Forest
description: ONCE again, I am driving, under the blazing equatorial sun, down an uncomfortable, rutty relic of a road into the interior of central Borneo. With me are two uniformed police men, one armed with a machine gun. The landscape is bleak, no trees, no shade as far as the eye can see. Our mission is to confiscate orangutan orphans whose mothers have been killed as a result of the sweeping forest clearance taking place throughout Borneo.

title: Knicks Eager to Have Robinson Back in Mix
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 5  The last 24 hours of Nate Robinsons league-mandated penance were packed with conflicting emotions  adulation and comfort mixed with sorrow and regret.

title: What's on Monday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO His first film role was a one-liner in Mystic Pizza. And that was about it, career-wise, for the next few years. But then he and his childhood friend Ben Affleck came up with a project called Good Will Hunting, and suddenly he was ascending the A-list, with an Oscar nomination for best actor and a win for best screenplay. Tonight, Mr. Damon, considered one of Hollywoods most good-natured actors (have you ever seen the man frown?), talks about a career that has included Steven Speilbergs Saving Private Ryan, Anthony Minghellas Talented Mr. Ripley  not to mention Steven Soderberghs Oceans Eleven, Twelve and, soon, Thirteen  and his latest role, with Angelina Jolie, as the operative Edward Wilson in Robert De Niros Good Shepherd.

title: Highly Paid Chief Is Paid $210 Million to Go Away
description: THE new year began with a series of surprises, not all of them pleasant.

title: At Home Depot, the New Chief Needs to Sell an Old Story to Wall Street
description: Frank Blake, the new chief at Home Depot, has a challenge.

title: China Media Battle Hints at Shift on Intellectual Property
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 3  One of Chinas largest newspapers has filed a lawsuit against one of the countrys leading Internet portals claiming that it violated copyright laws, setting off a media war and highlighting the first signs of a possible shift in policies toward intellectual property rights here.

title: Justices to Consider Impact of Mental Illness on Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to use the case of a schizophrenic death row inmate in Texas to set the standard for determining when a mental illness is so severe that execution would be constitutionally impermissible.

title: Tanzanian Woman Is Chosen for U.N.s 2nd Highest Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 5  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday appointed Asha-Rose Mtengeti-Migiro, the foreign minister of Tanzania, to be deputy secretary general and said he intended to give her responsibility for day-to-day management of the world organization.

title: At Armenian Churches, a Distinct Observance Today
description: Today the Armenian Church, one of the most ancient branches of Christianity, celebrates the birth of Jesus. One wonders, admittedly a bit fancifully, if there is a lesson in the Armenian practice for the many Christians who desperately wish that the religious meaning of Jesus birth could be rescued from angry culture wars and commercial frenzy.

title: Cowher Resigns; Stops Short of Retiring
description: In 15 years as the coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, Bill Cowher compiled a brilliant record: 161-99-1, 10 playoff seasons, 6 American Football Conference championship games, 2 Super Bowl appearances and, a year ago, a Super Bowl championship. His reign as the N.F.L. coach with the longest tenure ended yesterday, when he resigned, not unexpectedly, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family.

title: Britain: New Restaurant on Radiation Trail
description: The authorities investigating the killing of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer who died in London in November of a high dose of the radioactive isotope polonium 210, said they had detected radiation contamination at a restaurant in the Mayfair district of London. The Health Protection Agency said the restaurant, Pescatori, had been closed, decontaminated and reopened for business. The authorities have found traces of radiation in several other restaurants and hotels visited by Mr. Litvinenko and his associates just before he fell ill. This week, a staff member at the Best Western Shaftesbury Hotel in central London reportedly tested positive for low levels of polonium 210, bringing to 12 the number of people said by the authorities to have been contaminated in Britain. The others are nine staff members at two other London hotels and Mr. Litvinenkos widow, Marina.

title: Copyrights and Congress
description: ADVOCATES for looser restrictions on copyrights had high hopes for the new Democratic Congress. Those hopes faded somewhat last month when Representative Howard L. Berman was named chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the Internet and intellectual property.

title: Dows Dogs Still Having Their Day
description: EVERY dog has its day, but the Dogs of the Dow have had their day for seven years. During that span, the Dogs  the 10 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average with the highest dividend yields at the end of each year  have handily outperformed the index itself and other benchmarks of blue-chip stocks.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Religion Journal last Saturday, about the complexities of tithing, misstated the name of a company where Tom Norwood, a Presbyterian minister, advises churches on how to increase giving by their congregants. It is Capstone Advancement Partners, not Capstone Investment Partners.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Movie Dividends

title: A Renegades Tale of His Scorn for Japans Club of Old Men
description: TOKYO

title: DuPont Drops Plan for Nerve Gas Wastewater
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5  Bringing an abrupt end to a three-year fight between environmentalists and federal officials, the DuPont Company announced on Friday that it would not participate in an Army plan to dispose of wastewater from neutralized VX nerve gas by dumping it into the Delaware River.

title: In Upton Sinclairs Spirit (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Either Victory Song After Title Game Will Please Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, has not had a World Series champion since 2000, but he will back a winner in Mondays title game of the Bowl Championship Series between Ohio State and Florida.

title: Tipping Over a Defense of Enron
description: Malcolm Gladwell is one smart cookie.

title: X-Ray Vision Would Be Nice, but Sometimes a Nudge Will Do
description: Most bridge deals would cease to be interesting if everyone knew where all of the cards were located  what is called playing double-dummy. If declarer could peek into his opponents hands, he would almost always make his contract. But since he is not blessed with X-ray vision, sometimes the defenders can nudge declarer off the road to Rome and onto a dead end.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Dec. 15 about Queens International 2006, at the Queens Museum of Art, misspelled the given name and surname of the artist whose embroidered panels explore female sexuality, and a correction in this space on Wednesday repeated the misspelling of her surname. She is Blanka Amezkua, not Blanca Amezcua.

title: China Currency Near Parity With Hong Kongs Dollar
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 5  For more than half a century, residents of Hong Kong have taken pride in being more prosperous than their cousins nearby in mainland China, and have enjoyed feeling like big spenders whenever they crossed the border.

title: 6 Ohio Cities Rush to File Suits Against Makers of Lead Paint
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 5  Racing against a proposed state law that would limit paint manufacturers liability for lead poisoning in aging neighborhoods, Cincinnati has joined five other Ohio cities in filing suits that seek millions of dollars from the companies to clean up lead paint.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: How I Spent My Summer Vacation: Now a Major Motionless Book
description: I COME from a family that has a somewhat odd relationship with technology. My father, for instance, refused to give up his manual typewriter when newfangled electric typewriters came onto the market. But now his computer system has more bells and whistles than mine.

title: New Diet Drug Is Approved for Pudgy Dogs
description: Too many dogs are lounging around at home all day while their owners work, then stuffing on table scraps in front of the television at night, so much so that veterinarians say there is an epidemic of canine obesity in this country.

title: Encouraging More Reality in Economics
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5  The annual meeting of the American Economic Association, which opened here on Friday, is usually a pretty esoteric affair.

title: First-Baby Sweepstakes Fuels Immigration Debate
description: It seemed like a perfect formula for good publicity: A national sweepstakes would award a $25,000 United States savings bond to the first American baby born in 2007, courtesy of the toy chain Toys R Us and its Babies R Us division.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article and picture caption on Dec. 27 about David A. Paterson, the incoming lieutenant governor of New York, and his father, Basil A. Paterson, the Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor in 1970, referred incorrectly to the senior Mr. Paterson. He was the second black politician nominated for statewide office in New York, not the first. (Edward R. Dudley, nominated for attorney general at the Democratic State Convention in 1962, holds that distinction.)

title: Who Is Best at R&D?
description: TODAYS quiz: What do Apple, Caterpillar, Google, Kellogg and Toyota have in common?

title: Ties to Communist Secret Police Snare Polish Bishop
description: PARIS, Jan. 5  Warsaws new archbishop, Stanislaw W. Wielgus, caught in Eastern Europes widening witch hunt for former Communist secret police informers, admitted Friday that he had collaborated with the Sluzba Bezpieczenstwa, or Security Service, known as the S.B.

title: For This Broadway Musical, the Casting Agents Are TV Viewers
description: In almost every way, Youre the One That I Want, the American Idol-like reality show in which viewers pick actors to play Sandy Dumbrowski and Danny Zuko in a Broadway production of Grease, was inevitable.

title: Job Growth Is Strong, Surprising Economists
description: Job growth was brisk last month as businesses added to their payrolls with surprising confidence, further evidence that the economy is not likely to slip into a recession.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column last Saturday about criticism of officials at the J. Paul Getty Museum by the former antiquities curator referred imprecisely to the origin of two artifacts that the museum agreed to hand over to Greece last month. Although the Greek government contends they were looted from Greek soil, and the Getty says they should rightfully be returned, there has been no independent finding that the objects were illegally excavated.

title: Safe as Milk?
description: The Food and Drug Administrations assessment that food from cloned animals is safe to eat is a victory for biotech companies and a loss for everyone else. Like many decisions on the cutting edge of agricultural technology, it was hurried along in a way that is more sensitive to political and economic pressure than to the long-term welfare of animals, humans and the world they inhabit. Asking whether cloned meat and milk are safe is not even the right question. The right question is, why clone at all?

title: Best Buy and Circuit City Report Brisk Sales for December
description: Best Buy and Circuit City Stores, the nations largest electronics retailers, reported December sales yesterday that exceeded analysts estimates.

title: U.N. Expels 6 in Sex Case
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 5  Six United Nations peacekeeping soldiers have been sent home from duty in Sudan in recent months after they were investigated in connection with sexual crimes, officials here said Friday.

title: San Francisco to Go Wireless
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5  After eight months of sometimes difficult negotiations, EarthLink and the city of San Francisco said on Friday that they had reached an agreement to create a citywide wireless broadband network.

title: A New Commander, in Step With the White House on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  The selection of Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus to serve as the senior American commander in Iraq signals an important turn in United States strategy.

title: With Mild Winter, the City Revisits Fall Fashion and the Record Books
description: The last recorded time the snowfall in Central Park came so late in the season, the date was Jan. 4, 1878.

title: Grand-Scale Lawn Art Stirs a Debate in Connecticut
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 5  Talk about making waves.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the McCormick Tribune Foundation, a large shareholder in the Tribune Company, to hire the Blackstone Group as an adviser while the Tribune is up for sale, misstated the role of the companys chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in the sales process. Mr. FitzSimons, who is also chairman of the foundations board, has recused himself from issues regarding the sale; he is not a member of the special committee dealing with the Blackstone Group. (Go to Article)

title: City Ballet Brings Passion to Podium
description: As the house lights dimmed in the New York State Theater last Saturday night before Act II of George Balanchines Nutcracker, the conductor, Fayal Karoui, turned around and presented a red rose to a woman in the first row. Mr. Karoui became the New York City Ballets music director on Dec. 1, and his tenure seems to have started with a flourish. Earlier he had given each female player in the orchestra a rose for the end of the Nutcracker season, and upon finding a spare flower on his podium, he appeared to see no point in letting a chance for a charming gesture go to waste.

title: Making No Small Plans
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is fond of saying that you cant change the world by whispering. What New Yorkers saw in his first week in office was a governor in full trumpet about how to overhaul their state government. While some veterans of state politics saw Mr. Spitzers State of the State speech on Wednesday as too ambitious, former Gov. Hugh Carey got it just right. Its a very big agenda, he said, but its not too big for New York.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the McCormick Tribune Foundation, a large shareholder in the Tribune Company, to hire the Blackstone Group as an adviser while the Tribune is up for sale, misstated the role of the companys chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in the sales process. Mr. FitzSimons, who is also chairman of the foundations board, has recused himself from issues regarding the sale; he is not a member of the special committee dealing with the Blackstone Group.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture in Business Day on Thursday of the home of Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Chris Rank of Bloomberg News, not by Home Depot.

title: With Mientkiewicz at First, Giambi Likely to Shift to D.H.
description: When Doug Mientkiewicz was a rookie, struggling to stick with the Minnesota Twins, Jason Giambi pulled him aside for a pep talk. Giambi was a star for the Oakland Athletics at the time, and Mientkiewicz did not know him. But the encouragement helped.

title: City Backs Union Wages in Tax-Break Buildings
description: The Bloomberg administration said this week that it planned to require many developers who construct apartment buildings under a popular tax break to pay the superintendents and janitors the prevailing wage, essentially a union-level wage of $18 an hour and health benefits.

title: Return Is Made Away From Crowds and Disease
description: For the most part, it was a typical day at Aqueduct, New Yorks no-frills racetrack. It was gray and drizzly, the place was virtually empty and most of the horses on the card have not and never will do anything special. It was hardly the place where you would expect to find a Belmont Stakes winner returning to action.

title: Abroad at Home
description: HOUSTON  Like many illegal immigrants, Javier Huete did not dare plan a trip home for the holidays for fear he would not be able to re-enter the United States. But he was able to see his mother, in-laws and cousins in Honduras anyway thanks to videoconferencing services provided at an Order Express storefront in Houston.

title: Health Guidelines Suggested for Models
description: The fashion industry sells modish trapeze dresses and $800 platform ankle boots. But it also sells women an ideal of beauty embodied by the models who walk the runways and appear in fashion magazines.

title: American Diplomat to Visit Strife-Torn Somali Capital
description: KISMAYO, Somalia, Jan. 5  The State Departments top diplomat for Africa plans to visit Mogadishu, the violence-scarred Somali capital, on Sunday, American officials said Friday. It would be the first time in more than a decade that a high-ranking United States official has set foot there.

title: What Landed in New Jersey? It Came From Outer Space
description: It was not from the neighborhood.

title: Bernard Meltzer, 92, Labor Expert and Nuremberg Prosecutor, Dies
description: Bernard D. Meltzer, a law professor who helped bring clarity to labor-management issues at a time of great change in the field, who was a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials and who helped draft the United Nations Charter, died Thursday at his home in Chicago. He was 92.

title: Images of Hanging Make Hussein a Martyr to Many
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5  In the week since Saddam Hussein was hanged in an execution steeped in sectarian overtones, his public image in the Arab world, formerly that of a convicted dictator, has undergone a resurgence of admiration and awe.

title: Six Women, All Headed in Different Directions
description: Fresh Tracks, an annual series of new choreography, has been presented by Dance Theater Workshop since the organizations creation in 1965, giving more than 400 artists  Bill T. Jones, David Parsons, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker among them  their first opportunity to try their craft onstage.
