title: Caremark Rejects Express Scripts Offer
description: Caremark Rx, the nations second-largest manager of pharmacy benefits, said Sunday that it had rejected a $26 billion unsolicited merger bid from Express Scripts, choosing a lower offer from the drugstore chain CVS.

title: Alliance Deal May Reshape Canadian Media Landscape
description: The potential sale of Alliance Atlantis Communications to CanWest Global Communications has cast a cloud over the growth prospects of two rival broadcasters, and could pressure them to do their own deal to keep pace in Canadas consolidating media environment, The Globe and Mail reported. Astral Media and Corus Entertainment are each vying for Alliances stable of 13 specialty television channels, but the newspaper reported last week that CanWest, in concert with Goldman Sachs, are the clear front-runners to acquire its broadcast assets.

title: R.I.M. Directors Leave Options Audit
description: Research In Motion said Friday that two board members will no longer be involved in the audit committees discussions regarding the companys internal review of stock option grants. The two board members, Douglas Wright and Kendall Cork, who are also members of RIMs compensation committee, decided to recuse themselves from such deliberations to avoid the appearance of conflicts of interest.

title: Britain May Opt for a Light Touch in Hedge Fund Rules, Report Says
description: The Bank of England wants London-based hedge funds to agree to a voluntary code of conduct to encourage greater transparency and provide better governance in the contentious industry, The Guardian reported. Rather than go for heavy-handed regulation, which could push many out of their plush Mayfair offices and into other countries, British financial authorities are leaning toward the lighter touch of a voluntary code.

title: Fox Rothschild Acquires Boutique Law Firm
description: Fox Rothschild, a New York law firm, has acquired a boutique law firm, Young Moriwaki and Greenfader. The acquisition comes just a few months after Fox Rothschild acquired a labor and employment boutique in New Jersey with more than 50 lawyers. Young Moriwaki & Greenfader has six attorneys and offices in Manhattan and Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A Book Review and an Apology and Conrad Black in Headlines Again
description: Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, has been relatively quiet lately as he awaits his trial this spring on fraud and racketeering charges in Chicago. But a literary spat and apology to the author of a book he reviewed critically put him back in the gossip pages last week, writes The New York Times.

title: G.E. to Buy Energy Company From Investment Firms
description: General Electric has agreed to buy Vetco Gray, a maker of oil and gas-drilling and production equipment, for $1.9 billion to profit from surging demand for energy exploration. G.E., the worlds second-biggest company by market value, is acquiring Houston-based Vetco from three private equity firms, the 3i Group, Candover Investments  and J.P. Morgan Partners.

title: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
description: For investors who have been missing out on the prolonged run-up in the shares of real estate investment trusts, or maybe jumped in only recently, the end may not be in sight: there are growing opportunities overseas, The New York Times reports. Some industry experts say that this is an opportune time to make a move into these nascent markets.

title: Highbridge Buys Stake in Energy Business
description: The Highbridge Capital Management hedge fund said Monday that it had invested in the energy business of the Louis Dreyfus Group, the old-line commodities trading firm, forming a venture with an enterprise value of more than $1 billion. Highbridge Capital, a $17 billion hedge fund based in New York that is majority owned by J.P. Morgan Chase, said it had invested in Louis Dreyfus to gain more access to energy delivery and trading markets on its own.

title: Time Warner Cable May Come to Market Without an I.P.O.
description: Shares of Time Warner Cable, the second largest cable company in the nation, could hit the market within the next few weeks, analysts said. But Time Warner may bring its cable unit to market without having to go through the costly and time-consuming process of an initial public offering.

title: For Journalists, Politics Not as Usual
description: As many newspapers across the country are cutting their staffs and trimming back on Washington coverage, The Politico  the (mostly) online political news venture starting publication in two weeks  is finding younger journalists and some veterans who are willing to leave the once-secure confines of traditional print to join a start-up. And if The Politico succeeds, it could signal that the Web has become a more plausible alternative for mainstream journalists, says The New York Times. But, it notes, there are skeptics who say that the focus of The Politico is too narrow and that the marketplace too crowded with sources of political news.

title: Taiwan Firm Sues Apple in Shuffle Skirmish
description: Luxpro, fresh from a legal victory against Apple Computer over whether its portable music players are ripoffs of Apples iPod Shuffle, is seeking $100 million in damages in the case.

title: Mr. Moneyball Joins Board of Ellisons NetSuite
description: NetSuite, a rising Silicon Valley company backed by the computer software mogul Larry Ellison, has scored Oakland Athletics General Manager Billy Beane as a director. The move represents a public-relations coup for NetSuite, an Internet-based maker of business management software preparing for an initial public offering later this year.

title: Hedge Fund Has InFocus Board in Its Sights
description: A hedge fund, Caxton Associates, has raised its stake in InFocus, a provider of digital protection technology, in a move that might signal a proxy battle. Caxton said in a filing that it had raised its stake to 11.2 percent from 9.9 percent after discussions with InFocus management in the fourth quarter of last year had yielded unsatisfactory results.

title: Will Tribune Managers Enter the Bidding Fray?
description: The announcement Thursday by two foundations with close ties to the Tribune that they had hired New Yorks Blackstone Group to advise them as they consider alternatives for their combined 13.1 percent stake in Tribune stock, has put the focus on what role, if any, Tribune management will have in a possible deal for the media company.

title: Equity Office Bondholders Pressure Blackstone for More Money
description: A group of Equity Office Properties Trust bondholders said Friday that they had received commitments from enough investors to block the Blackstone Groups tender offer for $725 million of their bonds. Investors owning a majority of bonds have agreed not to tender their securities, according to a statement from the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York. While Equity Office can still move ahead with the sale without approval from the bondholders, the group could force Blackstone to increase its offer, raising the $36 billion cost of what would be the biggest leveraged buyout ever.

title: Highland Capital Raises Ruckus Over Delphi Plan
description: Delphi is facing objections to its bid for a six-month extension of its right to develop its bankruptcy-reorganization plan without interference from creditors or investors. Delphi, an auto parts supplier, said it needs the extra time to meet the terms of a framework agreement that proposes a $3.4 billion capital infusion from a pair of hedge funds and a private equity firm.

title: Reed Elsevier Seen as Possible Takeover Target
description: Shares in the Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier rose Friday amid market speculation that the company is a takeover target of Wolters Kluwer, a smaller publishing house. But the companies have circled each other before and regulatory issues and size could prove an impediment to a deal.

title: Frances Weinberg Capital Cooks Up Bakery Deal
description: Weinberg Capital Partners, a French buyout fund headed by the former head of luxury goods group PPR, Serge Weinberg, said Friday it had agreed to buy 60 percent of French baking equipment maker Sasa Industrie in a deal that values the group at 80.7 million euros ($106 million). The acquisition is the fourth by Weinberg Capital, which was founded in July 2005 by Mr. Weinberg, one of Frances highest-profile managers, and three partners, Guillaume dAngerville, Henri Gagnaire and Philippe Klocanas.

title: Private Firms Lure C.E.O.s With Top Pay
description: Robert L. Nardellis unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation is emerging elsewhere. Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that the firms have bought out.

title: At Electronics Show, A Cool Gadget Here, an A-List Chieftain There
description: With the end of the holidays comes a fresh start and new resolve to lead a loftier, healthier, simpler life. Then, before you know it, everyone in the media business hops on planes to Las Vegas and swarms the Consumer Electronics Show, which started Saturday. More than big awards shows or investment bank conferences and guru gatherings, C.E.S. has emerged as the Super Bowl of cluster-huddles, writes The New York Times Richard Siklos. And it has increasingly become a conference not just for tech aficionados, but for the heads of the media companies who create the content for said gadgets as well.

title: State Farm Negotiating Gulf Claims Settlement
description: State Farm, the biggest home insurer in the nation, is in the final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, lawyers briefed on the talks said yesterday.

title: Appeals Court Reverses Convictions of 2 Westar Energy Executives
description: An appeals court on Friday overturned convictions against two former executives of Westar Energy who were accused of looting the Kansas utility and said the most serious charges cannot be retried. The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit said the case against the former chief executive, David Wittig, and the former chief strategy officer, Douglas Lake, hung by a thin legal thread, based on claims that the men tried to hide their personal use of corporate aircraft from securities officials.

title: Jumbo Bonuses: Dial Your Envy Down a Notch
description: Its time to put the record Wall Street bonuses youve heard about in perspective. Yes, a few investment stars did reap tens of millions, topped by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who received $53.4 million. But these people were the exception, writes The New York Times Phyllis Korkki, pointing to data that show the average 2006 bonus in the New York securities industry was about $137,000, an increase of 15 percent from the year before.

title: Viacom Selects President for MTV International Unit
description: In a series of appointments expected to solidify the management at Viacom, the company named Robert M. Bakish as president of MTV Networks International. He will report to William H. Roedy, who is global chairman of MTV Networks and has oversight of MTVs international operation.

title: Florida Wins B.C.S. Title
description: Florida shocked the college football world by blowing out top-ranked Ohio State to win the national championship on Monday night.

title: HSBC Tries Tag-Team Approach
description: HSBCs chairman, Stephen Green, told The Financial Times he planned to run the bank as a double act with the chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, who would lead its management team to deliver the strategy. In an interview in Mondays edition of the newspaper, Mr. Green also said the bank, the biggest in Europe, did make mistakes but always moved to fix the problem. He detailed the division of labor between the post of chairman and the chief executive, calling it an evolution of the respective roles under his predecessor, John Bond.

title: First Glances
description: A look at The 2007 North American International Auto Show.

title: Bull Riding at the Garden
description: Meeting the judges, the bulls and the riders at Madison Square Garden's first top-tier professional bull-riding event.

title: Ford C.E.O. Says Jaguar Not for Sale
description: Ford Motors British luxury division Jaguar is not for sale, the chief executive, Alan Mulally, told reporters on the sidelines of an auto show on Sunday. Mr. Mulally, who became Fords chief execlutive in September, had earlier declined to rule out the sale of money-losing Jaguar and other premium brands in its portfolio.

title: Citigroup Raises $3.3 Billion for Buyout Fund
description: Citigroup has raised $3.3 billion for private equity investments, highlighting the growing eagerness of Wall Street banks to take part in the high-risk, high-return boom in leveraged buyouts. The fresh pool of money, to be announced on Monday, exceeds the banks $2.5 billion target and includes commitments from clients and employees, as well as $1 billion of the banks own balance sheet. The fund, Citigroup Capital Partners II, will be used to strike deals in a variety of industries and regions alongside other private equity firms.

title: NCR to Spin Off Teradata Unit
description: NCR, the worlds largest maker of automated-teller machines, said it would split into two public companies, spinning off its Teradata data warehousing business. The spinoff should be completed in six to nine months, separating their businesses into NCRs banking and checkout systems and Teradatas corporate data storage operations, NCR said in a statement Monday. J.P. Morgan Chase is serving as financial adviser in the move.

title: United Surgical to Be Acquired by Welsh Carson for $1.8 Billion
description: United Surgical Partners International agreed Monday to be acquired by Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe, the buyout firm that helped create the surgery center operator, for $1.8 billion in cash. UNCN Acquisition, a unit of the New York private-equity firm, offered $31.05 a share for United Surgical, a 13 percent premium over Fridays closing price.

title: Forest Oil to Acquire Houston Exploration for $1.5 Billion
description: Houston Exploration agreed Sunday to be acquired by Forest Oil for $1.5 billion. A natural-gas driller, Houston Exploration had put itself up for sale after rejecting an unsolicited $62-a-share bid by a hedge fund, Jana Partners, last year. Jana Partners, the largest shareholder of Houston Exploration with a 14.7 percent stake, supports the transaction, Houston Exploration said.

title: FIA Acts on New Role for Car Manufacturers
description: In keeping with the announcement in November by the International Automobile Federation and the Grand Prix Manufacturers Association that peace had broken out between the two groups, the FIA today announced the creation of a Formula One Manufacturers Advisory Commission.

title: On The Trail of Bigger and Better Swag
description: One of the joys of covering the North American International Auto Show is comparing the swag that the various manufacturers hand out with or within their press kit materials after each event (fancy food and drink dont count).

title: Link Rolling in Our Time
description: The House of Many Doors weighed in big-time with Oscarnalia yesterday, and if you spent your Sunday watching football, you might want to catch up, now that youre back at work and on the clock. The papers three film critics dissected pivotal moments in particular films: A.O. Scott looked at a potentially brutal moment in Letters From Iwo Jima; Manohla Dargis unpacked an intimate transaction amidst the mayhem of Children of Men; and Stephen Holden dissected the unforgettable pool scene in Little Children. In a year where all of the movies ran together on occasion for the Bagger, these pieces reminded him that great filmmaking can stop time.

title: Sony Dips Its Toes Into Internet TV
description: The day when consumers can download content from the Internet directly to their TV may not be that far off. Last night, Sony announced a plan to sell a module that, when connected to their next generation of flat panel TVs, will allow customers to watch music, short videos, and other high-def content thats streaming off the Internet.

title: Taking the Grid Down
description: The Bagger stopped the Four Seasons for one of those schmoozy cocktails parties designed to make people warm and gooey about a particular project  in this case United 93. The Bagger stayed away from the very open bar, but tucked in some free groceries, as is his habit. He got a chance to talk to Paul Greengrass, the director, who emphasized that the film was a kind of partnership with the families who lost loved ones on that flight. This was more than just another movie for those of us who were involved in making it, he said, adding that he was happy to take time off from shooting The Bourne Ultimatum to help the films award prospects.

title: Good to the Last Person
description: Cheeky! Sacha Baron Cohen said in a deep, genteel British accent to the young man in the front row who had just taken a photogrph of him. The Baguette was at a Q&A following a screening of Borat at the Lighthouse Theater on East 59th Street Saturday night. (The big mystery was how someone got a camera past the army of security guys, who combed backpacks, handbags and pockets.)

title: Portugal Telecom Bid Is Expected after Buyout Firms Withdraw
description: Portugal Telecom, the countrys largest network operator, is expected to receive a $14 billion hostile bid from a rival, Sonae, this week, after a private-equity consortium dropped out of the running, The Financial Times reported Monday. That group, comprising Texas Pacific, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Blackstone Group, Cinven, Permira and Providence, was formed last March.

title: Should Democrats Keep Committee-Chair Term Limits?
description: Are term limits for committee chairmen in Congress a bad thing? While guest-blogging at Ezra Kleins eponymous site, Nicholas Beaudrot of Electoral Math wants to know why Nancy Pelosi is retaining one of Newt Gingrichs ideas. [I]t really seems odd to me to adopt Republican reforms that preceded the most insular, beholden-to-leadership Congress in the last century, Beaudrot writes.

title: The Hill: In the Shadow of a Veto
description: With the opposing party controlling Congress, its likely that President Bush may exercise his veto authority more often than he has in the past. (He has only vetoed one bill during his entire time in office.) The Associated Presss Tom Raum takes a shot at guessing what hell strike down:

title: Critical Mass
description: The Bagger was a little late to the New York Film Critics Circle Awards at the Supper Club, after spending some quality time with J.J. Abrams in a public interview for the House of Many Doors. So he was disappointed to find when he walked in that there was nothing but dessert on the table. As it turned out, only dessert was served, which improved his mood.

title: S.E.C. Sues Hedge Fund Employee Over PIPEs Trading
description: A former employee of Spinner Asset Management, a $200 million New York hedge fund, has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of illegal short selling as part of trades in private investments. The former executive, Joseph Spiegel, paid a $110,000 fine and accepted a three-year ban for trades meant to hedge investments in private investments in public equity, or PIPEs. In December, the S.E.C. sued Edwin Buchanan Bucky Lyon IV of Gryphon, a Dallas-based hedge fund, for similar violations.

title: East Coast-West Coast Continued
description: It turns out there are various camps  and plenty of camp  on the road to the statue. OscarWatch posts a scorecard so you can keep track of who is backing what.

title: Credit Suisse Names Head of European M&A
description: A few months after announcing his resignation as HSBCs European head of investment banking, David Livingstone has resurfaced as Credit Suisses head of mergers and acquisitions in Europe. Mr. Livingstone started his new position in Credit Suisses London office on Monday, the firm said. Susan Kilsby, who had been Credit Suisses head of European M&A since 2002, was named chairman of European M&A at the investment bank, Credit Suisse said Monday.

title: The Gas Mystery
description: Updated 6 p.m.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Week in Review Editor Katy Roberts
description: Katy Roberts, editor of the Week in Review, answered reader questions.

title: At Least He Didnt Write About Yellowcake
description: The Washington Post editorial page, adopting a favorite tactic of the blogosphere, bashes the op-ed President Bush published last week in The Wall Street Journal. (Its not a Fisking, but its close.) The editorial begins:

title: Breaking: Gas Odor Overwhelms Manhattan
description: A powerful gas odor is affecting much of the West side of Manhattan this morning, reports New York 1  and early-morning employees of The New York Times, who have personally described themselves as feeling a bit lightheaded, heachachy, and nauseous as the fumes waft through the 43rd Street headquarters.

title: A Source of Stem Cells Without Controversy?
description: Scientists say theyve found a new way to harvest stem cells without using human embryos. Describing them as nearly as powerful as embryonic stem cells, Reuters reports that the cells are capable of creating muscle, bone, fat, blood vessel, nerve and liver cells in the laboratory.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Maria Antonelli, a partner at the Star Group, Cherry Hill, N.J., was promoted to managing partner. She continues as senior vice president and general manager at StarShipley, the Wilmington, Del., office of the Star Group.

title: 2008 Like Its Today
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware confirmed that hell be seeking the Democratic nomination for president during an appearance on NBCs Meet the Press Sunday. Im going to be Joe Biden, and Im going to try to be the best Biden I can be, he said. If I can, I got a shot. If I cant, I lose, he told Tim Russert, the host, adding that he would file formal papework by the end of this month.

title: Bloomberg: Odor Is Not Dangerous
description: At a news conference, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said a small natural gas leak downtown was too minor to account for the pervasive odor so it is obvious the smell is coming from something else.The citys air sensors do not report any elevated level of natural gas, he said, but he said officials were confident the odor was not dangerous.

title: Quadrangle Announces Promotions
description: Quadrangle Group, an investment firm that focuses on media and communications companies, said Monday it had promoted several professionals in its private equity and distressed debt groups. Jeffrey Nordhaus, who joined the firm from Goldman Sachs in 2001, was promoted to managing principal from principal. Mr. Nordhaus leads several of Quadrangles investment sectors, including cable and leisure, the firm said.

title: Best Buy Calls for New Venture
description: Look for In Advertising next week on Tues., Jan. 16, rather than Mon., Jan. 15, in honor of the Dr. King holiday.

title: The War at Home: Glimpses at the New Strategy
description: The Timess Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny preview President Bushs new Iraq strategy, which includes a series of benchmarks that Iraqi leaders must meet:

title: Has Fraud Followed I.P.O.s to London?
description: The London Stock Exchange snagged more initial public offerings than the New York Stock Exchange in 2006, putting a dent in an otherwise impressive year for the NYSE Group, which runs the New York exchange. But there may be a downside for the L.S.E. as well: British regulators are fighting a 40 percent spike in business fraud, according to the New York Post. Citing a report by BDO Stoy Hayward, problems such as stock swindles and profit-rigging have cropped up in increasing numbers, costing at least $2.7 billion.

title: Manhattan Smells Like Mercaptan
description: UPDATE: New Yorks Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg just held a press conference updating the known wisdom on the odor situation in New York City and parts of New Jersey. (More about that on our Empire Zone blog.)

title: How the Mighty Have Fallen
description: Remember Zenith? It used to be one of Americas premiere television brands, along with Magnavox and RCA. The company invented the remote control and was part of an early experiment in pay TV back in the 1960s. When every other company was bought up by overseas rivals, Zenith prided itself on the fact it was still American-owned and American-made.

title: Everything Is Networking
description: Do you want to be able to send pictures, music and movies around the house, from one PC, TV or stereo to another? Many major consumer electronics companies are convinced you do, judging by the number of networkable products that were discussed at yesterdays CES press conferences.

title: LCD vs. Plasma: And the Winner Is
description: LCD may be winning the battle of the marketplace, but the industry has long known that its technology has come up short in a number of areas, when compared to plasmas overall picture quality.

title: TV in Your Carat 80 Miles Per Hour
description: The great thing about digital broadcast television is that the picture looks perfect. The bad thing about digital broadcast television is that when the signal is too weak, you get absolutely nothing.

title: It Gets Angry When You Drop It
description: Maybe Ive been attending these events for too long, but there wasnt much that impressed me at yesterdays Digital Experience, a nighttime show-within-a-show here at CES. There were ho-hum digital picture frames, high-def TVs, new mobile phones and plenty of companies about to ask regular people to do incomprehensible things with home networks.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: A New Vaccination Timetable
SACs (Teddy) Bearish Investment
description: Who says hedge funds cant be warm and fuzzy? SAC Capital, the large and secretive investment pool run by Steven A. Cohen, made a regulatory filing Monday disclosing that the fund and its affiliates owned a 5 percent stake in Build-a-Bear Workshop, a publicly traded company that sells custom-made plush toys such as the Taking Care of Business bear, which comes complete with two-piece suit and black briefcase.

title: When Worlds Collide
description: The New York Film Critics Circle is an intimate affair, but both the Bagger and the Baguette graced the scene. Their talents divide nicely: the Bagger sits in the back row and comes up with the occasional swipe while the Baguette actually works, engaging in conversation that rare and delicate species, the Movie Star, and carefully transcribing their words. Heres what she found:

title: Inside Tiggers Furry Brain
description: The Walt Disney Co., which is hoping that Apocalyptos violence wont put off the kudos crews, is dealing with some alleged mayhem elsewhere in the kingdom. Tigger, generally a friendly sort, allegedly clobbered some kid.

title: Maybe If Im Really Still, They Wont See Me
description: You know who has the worst job at the Detroit Auto Show? No, its not the German Shepherds at the Cobo Hall gates who have to sniff-test automotive journalists all day. Its the poor saps tasked with driving concept cars during introductions.

title: UBS Names Chief of U.S. Brokerage Unit
description: Teresa Mullett Ressel was appointed chief executive of UBS Securities, the United States broker-dealer unit of UBS, the securities firm said Monday. The promotion comes as UBS, based in Switzerland, has been rearranging the executive suite at its North American business. In her new role, Ms. Ressel will report to the recently named chief executive and chairman of UBS Group Americas, Robert Wolf.

title: Something in the Air: Meanwhile, Out West
description: Its freaky Monday. In Austin, authorities cleared a full 10 blocks of the downtown business district early this morning after dozens of birds were found dead in the streets, according to the Associated Press.

title: Praise for Apple
description: John Sculley, the former CEO of Apple Computer from 1983 to 1993, may have gotten the boot from Steve Jobs, but hey, no hard feelings. Mr. Sculley had nothing but praise for the company and his former colleague.

title: Everything Must Not Go!
description: At the introduction for the 2008 Porsche Cayenne this morning, Peter Schwarzenbauer, Porsche Cars North America president and chief executive, launched into an unprompted diatribe. He made one thing very clear: Porsche has no intention of ever using sales incentives!

title: Keeping Count of Silicon Valleys Casualties
description: Is Silicon Valley getting a bit too ghoulish? Fred Wilson, a well-known venture capitalist, seemed to suggest as much as he criticized the dead pool on TechCrunch, a closely watched blog that focuses on the technology business. Mr. Wilsons comments came soon after TechCrunchs editor, Michael Arrington, wrote that the number of entries in his dead pool has been growing more quickly and startup ranks are starting to thin.

title: Out of Sync
description: Fords announcement on Sunday of its relationship with Microsoft drew a lot of oohs and aahs when journalists learned the automaker would enable music players, phones and smart devices to work seamlessly with in-car systems. But the big pizzazz on the Cobo Arena screen drew reactions of Huh? Why them? from some suppliers who are already providing such systems to automakers, and who have been connecting Bluetooth devices to vehicles for several years.Mega-supplier Johnson Controls, Inc. is one of them.

title: Mulally Rhymes With Sally
description: Ever since he was named Ford chief executive in September, Alan R.Mulallys name has been twisted in a number of ways. Some have saidMulay-lly (as in daily); others Mu-lahlly (as in dolly.) On Sunday, the announcer at Fords noontime news conference seemed to pronounce it Mu-lelly, as if it rhymed with nelly.

title: Office Real-Estate Market Feels Wall Street Effect
description: Flush with record-breaking bonuses, investment bankers and hedge funders are said to be driving up demand for all kinds of luxury goods, including expensive cars and multimillion-dollar apartments. (Whether or not that is true is another story.) Now, Bloomberg News suggests that Wall Streets very good year could be raising prices in another area: office space rents. The cost of renting commercial space in Manhattan has jumped by as much as 35 percent, according to reports by two commercial brokers, which Bloomberg traces in part to the expanding financial-services sector.

title: The Story of Skin
description: Dr. Nina Jablonski says the human canvas offers something different and deeply personal for a world where fashions are mass produced.

title: Romney Dials for 2008 Cash
description: BOSTON  Could things be changing in the way presidential candidates raise money?

title: The Story of Skin: Vanity
description: Modern anthropologist Nina Jablonski says the work of cosmetologists may signify a leap forward in overcoming the ageist bias of our primate ancestors.

title: Eliot in the Elephants Den
description: Nixon goes to China? Daniel in the Lions Den? Eliot in the Elephants Den? Governor Eliot Spitzer paid a visit today to the private conference that Republican State Senators held before going into session today.

title: Porsche 101
description: In my ongoing attempt to rate the theatricality and effectiveness of the press conferences here, we can report that, unlike many of the manufacturers, Porsche decided that its audience of journalists might actually like to know some facts instead of being entertained by inane skits that a high-school drama teacher would give a failing grade to.

title: HDTV Heavy
description: You know that HDTV has arrived when even CNN and The Weather Channel are converting to the high-resolution format.

title: For Skaddens Deal Lawyers, a Year to Remember
description: When the time came to hammer out legal issues in last years megadeals, chances are someone from Skadden Arps Slate Meagher and Flom was there. The New York-based law firm came in first place both in the United States and worldwide as an adviser on announced mergers and acquisitions, as measured by the combined transaction value, according to Thomson Financials rankings.

title: Blogtalk: Something in the Air
description: Gas fears in the gossip-sphere. [Gawker]

title: Gap Said to Hire Goldman to Consider Options
description: Gap, the struggling clothes retailer, has hired Goldman Sachs to consider strategic alternatives for the company, CNBC and other news outlets reported Monday. An unnamed source told Reuters that Gap hired the investment bank last month, but it was unclear exactly what the bank was hired to do. Gap would not comment on the reports, but its stock surged more than 7 percent Monday to close at $20.26 amid speculation it might be up for sale.

title: That R2 Unit Is a Real Bargain
description: From the same trade show that told us Bluetooth earpieces looked fashionable

title: New York, Austin and Now, Miami
description: Uncracking the third seal of urban Armageddon today, a package that was destined to be loaded onto a cruise ship in Miami was determined thought to contain plastic explosives. The package was tested six times and each time it came back positive for C4, reported The Associated Press.

title: Odor Mystery Persists
description: The investigation into the odd odor, which has dissipated, continues.

title: Analysis From Alex Smith
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.  Perhaps few people know the offense that Florida will run in the Bowl Championship Series title game better than the former Utah quarterback Alex Smith.

title: B.C.S. Final Tonight
description: Quick programming note: Join us during the B.C.S. title game at 8 Eastern tonight. John Woods, a Nebraska fan (remember when the Cornhuskers used to play in these big games, John?), will provide live tracking and commentary.

title: Spitzers Sense of Smell
description: Up in Albany today, Gov. Eliot Spitzer did not appear overly concerned about the smell that obsessed Manhattan this morning.

title: Insurgent TV
description: Video originally aired on Al Zawra, a banned Iraqi satellite television station.

title: Its the End of the World as We Know It
description: Waiting to be interviewed on Japanese television on Sunday, a New York-based editor wondered aloud what he might say to explain the show to an Asian audience. A former P.R. rep standing nearby volunteered this succinct summary:

title: Express Scripts Takes Aim at Caremarks Board
description: After failing to win over Caremark Rx with words, Express Scripts is trying some stronger medicine. Like it promised, the prescription benefits manager said Monday it would nominate four directors to the board of Caremark, the rival company that spurned its unsolicited, $26 billion merger offer. Caremark instead chose a $22.2 billion bid from drugstore chain CVS, a transaction Caremark said would generate fewer legal problems.

title: Another Cuomo Taps Hynes
description: This time it is the son, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who has asked Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, to provide a thorough review of the attorney generals Medicaid Fraud Control Unit, known by it vaguely rude-sounding abbreviation, M.F.C.U.A news release from the attorney generals office says that Mr. Hynes launched the first state M.F.C.U. in the nation, and that he will oversee a team of four specialists who have been asked to submit their recommendations to Mr. Cuomo on Feb. 15.

title: Dysfunction Junction
description: The Albany Project has started a wiki  TAPopedia  that aims to be a complete database of information about the dysfunctional NYS government.

title: Eliot Works the Other House
description: Soon after his meeting with Senate Republicans, Gov. Eliot Spitzer appeared, to a standing ovation, in the State Assembly as it began to get down to businesses.

title: Kimberly-Clark May Draw Buyout Interest, Analyst Says
description: It would be a tall order, but consumer products giant Kimberly-Clark could be a good candidate for a leveraged buyout, according to credit-research firm GimmeCredit, MarketWatch reports. With a market capitalization of about $31.6 billion, Kimberly-Clark would rank among the largest buyout targets ever. Though it acknowledged that size could be a deterrent, GimmeCredit said Kimberly-Clarks relatively low price-to-earnings ratio could attract buyout firms.

title: Tales From the Crypt
description: The second day of my second year here and I just found out there was a basement. Its the home of the not ready for prime time exhibits. Its the auto show equivalent of the Worlds Largest Ball of Twine or the Museum of Subway Odors.

title: The War at Home: Bush and Congress
description: Well, it would seem that the first 100 hours agenda in Congress could use a stopwatch, with President Bush about to take the stage on Wednesday to tell the public about his way forward. All else on the agenda will become background material.

title: What the Weatherman Knew
description: As a reader pointed out earlier today, the strength and duration of the mysterious gas-like odor in Manhattan  but not the odor itself  may have been caused by a weather phenomenon known as a temperature inversion.Inversions, which often occur when a warm front moves over a cooler, denser air mass, cause the temperature closer to the ground to be cooler and the air higher up to be warmer  a reversal of the usual pattern. Inversions can effectively trap pollutants and odors, preventing them from being dispersed upward.

title: Springtime in January
description: If I had a nickel for every time someone asked me if I wanted to rethink our plan to build in Florida, in light of the pleasant weather we are experiencing in the Northeast, I would have had a lot of nickels.

title: Amid the Loud Bugle Calls, the Workers are Awakened
description: Theres a little bit of everything down stairs at Cobo Hall. I intended to write about the good, the bad and the ugly at the Detroit Auto Show. But I didnt count on was spending most of my time down in the basement watching the Changfeng Motors Image Propaganda Film.

title: The Year of the Healthy American
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 1 column, A Healthy New Year.

title: Additional Information for January 5 Column
description: Here are the information sources for my Jan. 5 column.

title: Let the Iraqis Be
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 3 column, A Hanging and a Funeral.

title: Blood Oil
description: In America its bling bling, but out here its bling bang, says Leonardo DiCaprios character in the movie Blood Diamond, explaining how diamonds on American fingers play a role in conflict and death in Africa. Thanks to this film, diamonds are the taboo commodity of the moment  All who touch it are left with blood on their hands, intones the voice-over in the preview.

title: Another Puzzled Conservative
description: One of the most frustrating things about being a conservative these days is suffering from both sides in the debate about George W. Bush. As soon as one admits to being conservative, one is assumed to be a supporter of the administration. It takes a lot of effort to explain why almost nothing this administration has done is conservative by the standards of what conservatism has meant historically.

title: The Senate on Ethics
description: Democratic Senators Russ Feingold of Wisconsin and Barack Obama of Illinois announced a series of proposals on ethics reform today, and trotted out for support several of the new Senate freshmen who campaigned (in part) on anti-corruption measures in the wake of the Abramoff lobbying scandal. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, in calling ethics reform the Senates first order of business, likened the breadth of the proposals to those passed after Watergate.

title: Swag of the Day: Bongos
description: Dont tell Matthew McConaughey, but right now Cobo Hall contains more bongo drums than you can shake a patchouli-scented tie-dyed Peter Tosh tee-shirt at. DaimlerChrysler is the party responsible for the bongo outbreak, having distributed the drums at the introduction for the Chrysler Nassau and Jeep Trailhawk concept S.U.V.s. Since I didnt go to the press conference, I can only speculate on the relationship between bongos and the Nassau and Trailhawk, neither of which seem particularly geared toward hippies.

title: Join the Toyota Marketing Machine
description: We all know that Toyota is on a roll in terms of strong sales, great profits and all around global domination of the car world. But now the Japanese auto giant has gone one step further, turning journalists and auto enthusiasts into marketing pawns for the new Toyota Tundra pickup.

title: Bloomberg Criticizes Security Fund Distribution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg criticized the way federal antiterrorism money is distributed, testifying today at a crowded Senate hearing that New York City had been shortchanged compared with other cities, given too little money for bioterrorism preparedness and denied financing to upgrade its communication systems.

title: Bolivia Leader Lets Venezuela Send Soldiers, Angering Foes
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 8  Political opponents of President Evo Morales of Bolivia have in recent days stepped up criticism of the countrys strengthening military relationship with Venezuela after Bolivian officials acknowledged that more than two dozen uniformed members of the Venezuelan military had recently entered the country without congressional approval.

title: Movement to Change the Bowl System Starts at the Top
description: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 8  San Francisco 49ers quarterback Alex Smith watched Boise States upset of Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl last week and again felt a pinch of regret.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Tuesday about Wal-Marts struggle to market a long-lasting, energy-saving light bulb known as a compact fluorescent lamp misstated the time period in which the retailer sold 40 million of the bulbs compared with about 350 million incandescent bulbs. It was from August 2005 to August 2006  not in 2005.

title: Brown Returns to the N.B.A. With a Smile
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8  Larry Brown, whose dream job of coaching the Knicks turned into a nightmare last season and led to a hiatus from the N.B.A., resurfaced with the Philadelphia 76ers on Monday, looking relaxed, offering a smile and saying that he had no immediate plans to return to coaching.

title: State Farm in Talks to Settle Gulf Claims
description: State Farm, the biggest home insurer in the nation, is in the final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, lawyers briefed on the talks said yesterday.

title: Manhattan: Former Union Leader Sentenced
description: The former manager of a pension fund for New York Citys main union of school bus drivers, who pleaded guilty last August to obstructing justice, was sentenced yesterday to five months in prison and five months of home confinement. Judge Kimba Wood of Federal District Court sentenced the former manager, Ann Chiarovano. The union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, has been placed in trusteeship, and Salvatore Battaglia, its president, has pleaded not guilty to federal charges of extortion, bribery and cooperating with the Genovese crime family.

title: Borrowing Rose in November
description: Borrowing by United States households rose in November by the most in three months as Americans loaded up on credit card debt to purchase gifts at the start of the holiday shopping season.

title: Common Sense on the Census
description: Last November, the director of the Census Bureau, C. Louis Kincannon, and the deputy director, Hermann Habermann, abruptly decided to quit, acknowledging tensions with their bosses in the Bush administration but giving no other details. Both men are statisticians who had served in their positions since 2002 and, before that, had decades of experience as civil servants.

title: Text of Corzines State of the State Address
description: Following is the text of Gov. Jon S. Corzines State of the State address as prepared for delivery today in Trenton.

title: New Congress, Older Look
description: The winds of change have blown through the 110th Congress, but only to a point. There are more women (90) and, obviously, more Democrats. But according to the Congressional Research Service, the average age of lawmakers in the new Congress is possibly the oldest in history. The average age of senators is 61.7  two years older than in the previous Congress. The oldest senator is Robert C. Byrd, 89, Democrat of West Virginia, and the youngest is John E. Sununu, 42, Republican of New Hampshire. The average age of representatives is 55.9, with Ralph M. Hall, Republican of Texas, the oldest at 83, and Patrick T. McHenry, Republican of North Carolina, the youngest at 31. More demographics: there are more Protestants than any other religious affiliation, but Roman Catholics account for the largest single religious denomination.

title: Albany: Bloomberg Aide Urges Judicial Overhaul
description: Citing an unprecedented crisis of confidence in the states judiciary, the New York City corporation counsel, Michael A. Cardozo, yesterday urged quick reform of the states judicial selection process at a State Senate hearing. Last year, a federal appeals court found that the nominating system for electing State Supreme Court justices was unconstitutional, and imposed an interim process of direct primary elections. Mr. Cardozo, representing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, suggested changes to the nominating conventions rather than the use of open primaries in choosing judicial candidates. He also urged that independent commissions be used to weigh Supreme Court candidates qualifications.

title: Blasts From the Bebop Past of an Elusive Trumpeter
description: Disappearing acts are not uncommon in jazz, but Dizzy Reece is an extreme case. A Jamaican-born trumpeter who first made his name in London in the mid-1950s, Mr. Reece briefly enjoyed a reputation as a formidable voice in hard bop. He made four strong albums for Blue Note in the Eisenhower era, three with top-shelf American rhythm sections. But then came a period of struggle, followed by unexplained oblivion. For much of the last 40 years, Mr. Reece has essentially led a nonpublic life.

title: Middle School: It's, Like, Awkward (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany: Manufacturing Orders Rise
description: Manufacturing orders rose for the first time in three months in November, led by an increase in demand for trucks and cars. Orders, adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation, rose 1.5 percent from October, when they declined 0.7 percent, the Economy and Technology Ministry said. The figure for October factory orders was revised up from an initially reported decline of 1.1 percent. Domestic orders gained 0.6 percent in November, and foreign orders rose 2.3 percent. Demand for consumer goods advanced 2.7 percent.

title: Drew Is a Red Sox in Waiting ... and Waiting
description: J. D. Drew could not be reached for comment yesterday. He changed his telephone number or had a problem with his phone service, because the automated message said his number had been disconnected or was not in service.

title: Two Elected to Hall of Fame; McGwire Misses
description: Cal Ripken Jr. was the iron man who played in 2,632 consecutive games, Tony Gwynn was the hitting machine who won eight batting titles and yesterday both were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in near-unanimous votes that reflected their standing within the sport. But their achievement was overshadowed by the voters rejection of Mark McGwire, a slugger who seemed like a modern-day Paul Bunyan before he fell into disrepute because of suspected steroid use.

title: Retrofitting Operetta for a 21st-Century Crowd
description: Heres a Jeopardy! answer: its a musical genre that features pointed, witty texts; catchy tunes; strong music; and cutting-edge visuals, presented in an intimate setting.

title: Mazdas Chapter Two Rakes the Garden
description: Introduced on Monday: Mazda Ryuga design study

title: Nutrition: So Now Youre What Your Children Eat?
description: Adults who live with children eat more fat, and more saturated fat, than those who do not, according to a new study.

title: South Korea: Samsung Forecast
description: The Samsung Electronics Company forecast record profit from consumer electronics this year, helped by television sales. Profit this year from the digital media division, including earnings from overseas affiliates, will probably exceed 1 trillion won ($1.1 billion) for the first time, Choi Gee Sung, president of the division, said in a statement. Samsung plans to sell 11 million L.C.D. televisions in 2007, up from 6.2 million units last year, the company said. Samsung, which is based in Suwon, South Korea, also forecast its shipments of plasma TVs to rise to 2.5 million units this year, compared with 1.3 million sets in 2006.

title: Yet Another Worry for Those Who Believe the Glass Is Half-Empty
A Mother Helped the Homeless. Then She Joined Them.
description: It was like going through the looking glass. Not long ago, Brenda Francis, who had worked in shelters helping the homeless, found her world turned upside down when she and her teenage son, Bryant Dukes, were suddenly left without a home.

title: Reins Off, French Retailers Rush to Buy TV Time
description: FRANCE may never be a nation of shopkeepers, but on television, at least, the countrys retailers are no longer getting a frosty reception.

title: Spitzer Orders Sharp Cuts in Cost of Prisoner Phone Calls
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8  Gov. Eliot Spitzer struck an early blow at the policies of his predecessor on Monday, sharply reducing steep Pataki-era charges that relatives and friends of inmates in New York States prisons have had to pay on collect telephone calls from them.

title: Patriots, Hitting the Road, Will Run Into Tomlinson
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 8  After the New England Patriots throttled the Jets on Sunday, 37-16, someone asked Patriots linebacker Tedy Bruschi if the Patriots took their game to another level during the playoffs.

title: Mr. Noodle
description: The news last Friday of the death of the ramen noodle guy surprised those of us who had never suspected that there was  such an individual. It was easy to assume that instant noodle soup was a team invention, one of those depersonalized corporate miracles, like the Honda Civic, the Sony Walkman and Hello Kitty, that sprang from that ingenious consumer-product collective known as postwar Japan.

title: Reagan Lawyer Ready to Return to White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  President Bush has chosen Fred F. Fielding as the new chief White House lawyer, adding to his team a longtime Washington legal hand and veteran of the post.

title: Newark: Youth Worker Charged With Abuse
description: Investigators for the Essex County prosecutor have arrested an Irvington man who worked for a youth program financed by the state and charged him with molesting an 11-year-old girl whose family he befriended. The man, Lawrence Tyler, 56, worked for the Youth Advocacy Program, a private agency that has a state contract. He was arrested at his home late Friday night and charged with five counts of sexual assault and five counts of endangering the welfare of a child, said Mark Ali, director of the countys Child Abuse Unit. Mr. Tyler had been working for the girls uncle, Mr. Ali said.

title: A New Video Posted on Web Shows Hussein After His Death
description: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, Jan. 9  A graphic new video of Saddam Husseins dead body, apparently taken shortly after he was hanged, was posted on the Internet on Tuesday by a group sympathetic to the former dictator.

title: California Plan for Health Care Would Cover All
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Monday proposed extending health care coverage to all of Californias 36 million residents as part of a sweeping package of changes to the states huge, troubled health care system.

title: Dance of the Continents
Yahoo Introduces Mobile Service Software
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8  After falling behind Google in Internet search and advertising, Yahoo is trying to remain No. 1 in the battle to deliver information and online services to mobile phones.

title: 9/11 Associate Is Sentenced in Germany to 15 Years
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 8  A German court on Monday sentenced a friend of the Sept. 11 hijackers to 15 years in prison for being an accessory in the murders of 246 people aboard the commercial planes used in the terrorist attacks.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Strands of Undesirable DNA Roam With Buffalo
description: MALTA, Mont.  The animals certainly looked like bison, with the characteristic humps and beards. But just to make sure, a pick-up truck slowly rolled up to them, and a bison wrangler shot a drug-filled dart into one of several calves.

title: Louisville Looks to Tulsa to Fill Coaching Opening
description: Louisville is courting Tulsa Coach Steve Kragthorpe to replace Bobby Petrino as the Cardinals football coach.

title: The Viennese Way (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Always Revealing, Human Skin Is an Anthropologists Map
description: In an era of academic hyper-specialization, Dr. Nina G. Jablonski has an amazingly broad rsum. At 53, she heads the anthropology department at Pennsylvania State University. Shes also a primatologist, an evolutionary biologist and a paleontologist.

title: Husseins Voice Speaks in Court in Praise of Chemical Atrocities
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 8  The courtroom he dominated for 15 months seemed much smaller on Monday without him there to mock the judges and assert his menacing place in history.

title: Fissures Grow on Eve of Bush Speech on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- On the eve of President Bushs planned speech on Iraq, both the White House and a prominent Democratic critic of the president said the United States was at a decisive moment, not just in Iraq but in American history.

title: U.S. Warns Europe on Air Travel Emissions Rules
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 9  A senior American diplomat warned the European Commission today against adopting rules that would impose emissions controls on all commercial flights to and within Europe.

title: Push to End Use of Private Debt Collectors by U.S.
description: The national taxpayer advocate called on Congress today to repeal the authority it gave the Internal Revenue Service to use private debt collectors.

title: Early Rout Is Challenge to Fox Team
description: Fox Sportss first year of carrying Bowl Championship Series games has hardly been the happy collegiate football tortilla chip bash it intended when it acquired a four-year package of the Fiesta, Orange and Sugar Bowls, and the newly added national championship game, for $320 million.

title: Kazakhstan: Prime Minister Steps Down
description: Prime Minister Daniyal Akhmetov resigned. Long considered an influential ally of the powerful president, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, who appointed him to the post in 2003, Mr. Akhmetov has lately come under public criticism from Mr. Nazarbayev for poor oversight of the economy. Mr. Nazarbayev, who has been Kazakhstans president since its inception as an oil-rich independent state in 1991, is known for frequently replacing members of his cabinet.

title: Democrats Push for Changes to No Child Left Behind Law
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Democratic Congressional leaders on Monday called President Bushs signature education law too punitive in its sanctions on public schools and pledged to increase educational spending, signaling the stance they will take this year in negotiations over the laws renewal.

title: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The new Democratic majority in Congress is divided over how to assert its power in opposing President Bushs plan to send more troops to Baghdad, as leaders explore ways to block financing for a military expansion without being accused of abandoning American forces already in Iraq.

title: Paterson: Reward Offered in Officers Shooting
description: The Paterson police said yesterday that a reward for information about a man who fatally shot an off-duty police officer Sunday morning has been increased to more than $40,000 from an initial $1,000. The officer, Tyron D. Franklin, 23, was killed shortly after 1 a.m. in what the police said was a holdup at Broadway Fried Chicken. The extra money is being offered by a combination of foundations and private donors, the police said. Detectives have interviewed several witnesses and the police said yesterday that the shooting might be linked to a surge in robberies.

title: The Ungulate Effect on an Ecosystem
description: In studies of the ripple effects of animals on an ecosystem, carnivores are the celebrities. Researchers have given the most attention to the impact these top predators have on the animals, plants and insects beneath them in the food chain, whats termed a trophic cascade.

title: McGwire Unlikely for Hall of Fame
description: When the results of Baseballs Hall of Fame balloting are announced at 2 p.m. today, Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn will surely be smiling. Goose Gossage and Jim Rice have a chance to join them. But Mark McGwire is not likely to exhibit that same happy emotion.

title: Exercise: Surfing, It Seems, Is Safer Than Some Sports
description: It may be safer to go surfing than to play college football, soccer or basketball, according to a six-year study of professional and amateur surfing competitions.

title: Newark: A Former Mayor Admits Bribes
description: Joseph C. Scarpelli, left, the former mayor of Brick Township, pleaded guilty to bribery and conspiracy charges yesterday in Federal District Court, officials announced. Mr. Scarpelli, 67, admitted that he accepted and agreed to accept cash payments from an unnamed real estate developer, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Scarpelli said he received $5,000 in payments, Mr. Christie said. Mr. Scarpelli is free on $50,000 bail and faces 24 to 30 months in jail at sentencing, set for May 29.

title: French, With a Twist of Wagner
description: It is hard to say why works that were once staples of the concert repertory lose popularity. A good example is Csar Francks Symphony in D minor. This once ubiquitous work was the focus of the conductor Leon Botsteins concert with the American Symphony Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: More Races and Extra Day Are Added to Breeders Cup
description: Looking to expand the Breeders Cup and broaden its appeal, the organizers of the series announced yesterday that three races have been added to the event and that it will be held over two days.

title: Bushs Task: Thrusting New Strategy on a Sovereign Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Its a refrain that President Bush and his top deputies have uttered many times over:

title: Man Is Found Fatally Shot on Brooklyn Street
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot yesterday evening, two blocks from his home in Flatbush, the police said.

title: Stern Likes His New Censor: Himself
description: Howard Stern, who today marks his first anniversary on satellite radio, wasted little time over that period before setting off on an expedition deep into the wild, forested territories of a medium patrolled by neither the Federal Communications Commission nor, apparently, his own employer.

title: Restoring a Mud-Brick Tribute to a Departed Egyptian King
description: Before the great pyramids, ancient Egyptian kings left less grandiose monuments to themselves: fortresslike sanctuaries enclosed by mud-brick walls. Inside these mortuary complexes, people presumably gathered to worship and perpetuate the memory of their departed ruler.

title: Home Court Helps Badger Guard Come of Age
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 8  The backyard court where Wisconsin guard Kammron Taylor learned his harshest basketball lessons is gone. Taylors father, Kenneth, took down the basket about three years ago, and it hangs, faded and rusty, inside their garage.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review on Jan. 1 about Govt Mule and Los Lobos, at the Beacon Theater, misstated the surname of a member of Los Lobos. He is Cesar Rosas, not Rojas.

title: New York Given High Marks for Laws to Reduce Smoking
description: New York ranks second in the nation in the strength of its antitobacco laws, and New Jersey and Connecticut are also well above average, according to a report to be released today by the American Lung Association.

title: When the Fur Flies
description: Increasing numbers of people are taking pets on business trips. But imagine the challenge when the animal is not the typical dog or cat.

title: In Lobster Land, a Whale-Friendly Proposal
description: A threat to endangered North Atlantic right whales posed by dense arrays of lobster traps, lines and floating buoys off the coast of Maine could be greatly reduced without hurting profits if boats switch to fishing patterns that are the norm in nearby Nova Scotia, according to a study by Canadian and American researchers. The Maine lobster season is year-round, but Canadian lobstermen with far fewer traps have similar catches with a 180-day season, said the authors of the study, published in the journal Current Biology. They said Canadian lobster boats also had lower costs for fuel and bait. The executive director of the Maine Lobstermens Association told The Associated Press that almost all traps were set in waters not frequented by the whales.

title: Indonesia: Boy Has Bird Flu; 6 Others Tested
description: A new human cluster of avian flu cases could be emerging in a suburb of the capital, Jakarta, according to Indonesian news reports. One case of H5N1 flu, the countrys 75th, was confirmed by the Health Ministry over the weekend; it was in a 14-year-old boy who had reportedly buried a flock of backyard ducks that died suddenly. He was alive but using a respirator to breathe. A local radio station and news outlets said six other people from the same town  at least three of them related to him  were hospitalized with flu symptoms in Jakarta, being treated with Tamiflu and awaiting test results. Indonesia has failed to get its poultry epidemic under control since it emerged in 2005.

title: Its Detroit, but Accents Are Foreign
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8  The auto show in Detroit has always been something of a living time capsule. The cars may change, but the auto companies, their place in the universe, and the faces here always seemed to remain the same.

title: Paying in Pollution for Energy Hunger
description: BAHARBARI, India  A toxic purple haze of diesel exhaust hangs over the rice and jute fields here in northeastern India, and bird songs are frequently drowned out by the chug-a-chug-a-chug of diesel generators.

title: 31 Ex-Prosecutors Join Effort to Overturn 1990 Conviction of L.I. Man in Murder of Parents
description: The campaign to overturn the conviction of a Long Island man for the murders of his parents has gained a very unusual group of supporters: 31 former federal, state and local prosecutors.

title: In Effort to Cut Homicide Rate, Newark Mayor Creates Narcotics Unit
description: NEWARK, Jan. 8  Mayor Cory A. Booker and his police director announced the formation of a new narcotics division on Monday to try to reduce the citys stubbornly high homicide rate, firmly linking the illegal drug trade to the persistent violence.

title: White Plains: Group Says County Fails on Housing
description: A fair-housing group accused Westchester County yesterday of failing to pressure towns to accept more low-cost housing as a way to reduce racial segregation. In a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the group, the Anti-Discrimination Center of Metro New York, said the county had neither tracked towns efforts to bring in housing for lower-income people nor penalized those that did nothing. The group said the county was obliged, in return for federal funds, to take steps to further fair housing. Norma Drummond, the countys deputy planning commissioner, denied the charges. She said that 751 units of low-cost housing had been built since 2000, often with county help, and that 1,174 more units were planned.

title: At Jaguar, Out With the Old, In With the Bold
description: Introduced on Sunday: Jaguar C-XF design study

title: A Rotten Smell Raises Alarms and Questions
description: It was the odor associated with natural gas  the telltale, unpleasant sulfur scent that typically signals a gas leak. But this time, it was lingering in many areas of Manhattan and northeastern New Jersey, coursing through buildings and leading to fears that it could ignite or that a dangerous chemical had been deliberately released.

title: The Coming Escalation in Iraq (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Kraft Takes a Charge for a Poor-Selling Coffee Machine
description: Kraft Foods said yesterday that weaker-than-projected sales of its Tassimo single-serve coffee-brewing machines led to a noncash charge of $245 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Brooklyn Man, 38, Dies After Jolt From Police Taser
description: The day after a disturbed man died after being shocked with a Taser stun gun in Queens by a police sergeant, a city police official yesterday provided a fuller account of the moments before the man apparently went into cardiac arrest.

title: Express Scripts Moves to Derail a Merger
description: EXPRESS SCRIPTS opened a proxy war in the pharmacy benefits industry yesterday, moving to derail the pending acquisition of its rival Caremark Rx by the drugstore chain CVS.

title: Arrest of Activist Troubles Hartford Officials
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 8  The arrest of a political activist and freelance journalist at the inaugural parade of Gov. M. Jodi Rell last week has raised questions about a state law enforcement list of people who pose potential threats to the government.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review on Thursday about the exhibition South Bronx Contemporary: Longwood Arts Projects 25th Anniversary, at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, omitted a curator. The wall of art hung salon-style was organized by Edwin Ramoran under the title Everyday Is Like Sunday; it is not part of Iconoclasm, organized by Eddie Torres and hanging in the same room.

title: Clearing the Air
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi is poised to extinguish one of the last true perquisites of House service: the right to smoke just off the floor in an area known as the Speakers Lobby. Lawmakers and aides say they expect that Mrs. Pelosi will soon use the substantial powers of her new office to bar smokers from the lobby and force them outside. Opponents of smoking have complained about the practice for years. The impact of the change will be bipartisan; members of both parties regularly enjoy cigarettes and cigars as they relax in the lobbys leather chairs between votes. The highest ranking smoker is Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio and the minority leader, who was perhaps anticipating the change when he headed to an outer balcony last week for a quick cigarette. Ever defiant, some smokers said they would still light up in their personal offices.

title: An Escalation of American Blood
description: A surge in the number of troops in Iraq might have helped in 2003 or early 2004.

title: Computers Join Actors in Hybrids On Screen
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  James Cameron, the director whose Titanic set a record for ticket sales around the world, will join 20th Century Fox in tackling a similarly ambitious and costly film, Avatar, which will test new technologies on a scale unseen before in Hollywood, the studio and the filmmaker said on Monday.

title: Ill Have Fries and a Glass of Your Best Champagne
description: AT a recent wine tasting in Napa, Calif., my hosts made a tragic mistake: They served a big zinfandel with warm apple pie for dessert. The sweet pie stripped the fruit flavors from the wine, leaving us with mouthfuls of what tasted like tannic water.

title: Many Chances to Be a Hero in New York
description: For the last week, New Yorkers have thrilled to the heroics of Wesley Autrey, Julio Gonzalez and Pedro Nevarez  profiles in courage, all. Mr. Autrey risked his life to rescue a young man who had tumbled from a subway platform into the path of an oncoming train. Messrs. Gonzalez and Nevarez caught a little boy who fell from a fourth-floor fire escape.

title: Thailand Tightens Foreign Investment Laws
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 9  Thailand pressed ahead today with a long-debated tightening of its foreign investment laws, ignoring warnings that the move could damage the countrys fragile economy at a time when it is already struggling to overcome the stigma of a recent military coup and a wave of bombings in Bangkok.

title: Totals
Don't Play With Maps
description: Washington

title: Iranian Leader Vows to Resist U.N. Sanctions
description: TEHRAN, Jan. 8  Irans supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Monday that Iran would not back down from developing its nuclear program, despite sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Council last month.

title: When 510 Horsepower Just Isnt Enough, Go For 600!
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2008 Dodge Viper SRT10

title: Decisions on the Horizon
description: Dont look for presidential announcements from Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton anytime soon, but stay tuned.

title: Dispute Over Bus Fare Ends in Stabbing in New Jersey
description: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan 9  It should have been just another routine bus ride. Passengers boarded the No. 34 bus on Monday evening at Newarks Pennsylvania Station, paid their fare and sat down. But as the bus entered East Orange, en route to Montclair, an argument about a zone fare erupted between the driver and a passenger who eventually wound up with a knife in his shoulder.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about announcements by Sony and Microsoft regarding sales of their latest game consoles carried an incorrect dateline. The reporter was in San Francisco  not Las Vegas, where the announcements were made at the Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Man Gets 30 Years in Subway Bomb Plot
description: A federal judge sentenced a 24-year-old Pakistani immigrant yesterday to 30 years in prison for plotting to bomb the Herald Square subway station in 2004, moments after the defendant apologized to the judge and prosecutors but blamed a police informer for his fate.

title: Duke President Renews Call for District Attorney to Leave Case
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 8  The president of Duke University renewed his call on Monday for the district attorney to step aside from the sexual offense case against three former lacrosse players and give control to an independent party who can restore confidence in the fairness of the process.

title: A Rogue Wave Hits Nissan
description: Introduced on Sunday: 2008 Nissan Rogue

title: Romania: a Bid for Draculas Castle
description: Draculas castle may sell for 60 million euros ($78 million) after the local government offered to buy the Transylvanian fortress to increase tourism revenue. The Brasov County Council in central Romania is in talks with a foreign bank on a 10-year loan for that amount to get back the castle from its current owners living abroad, Aristotel Cancescu, president of the municipality, said in a telephone interview. Built in 1212 by Teutonic knights, the castle was briefly used two centuries later by the Romanian ruler Vlad the Impaler, who inspired Bram Stokers legend of Count Dracula. The castles current owners are Dominic von Habsburg, an industrial designer who lives in New York, and his sisters, Elisabeth Sandhofer and Maria-Magdalena Holzhausen, who both live in Austria.

title: Momofuku Ando, 96, Dies; Invented Instant Ramen
description: Momofuku Ando, who  to the delight of dormitory students and other kitchen-resistant customers worldwide  invented those small packets of preflavored dried noodles that require just a three-minute boil, died Friday at a hospital in Osaka, Japan. Mr. Ando, the founder of the Nissin Food Products Company, was 96.

title: The Claim:  Hot Leftovers Should Cool at Room Temperature
description: THE FACTS What to do with leftovers? One common bromide is that leftovers stored in the refrigerator must be allowed to cool first at room temperature.

title: Second Church Official Resigns in Poland
description: WARSAW, Jan. 8  The Roman Catholic Church in Poland was in turmoil on Monday as a second prelate stepped down because of his Communist-era secret police ties, after Sundays resignation of this citys archbishop over similar allegations.

title: Newark: Hockey Arena to Be Named for Prudential
description: Newarks new hockey arena will be called the Prudential Center under an agreement announced yesterday by the New Jersey Devils and Prudential Financial Inc., the Newark-based financial services company. Prudential will pay about $100 million over 20 years under the terms of the agreement. The 18,000-seat, $375 million arena is scheduled to open in the fall.

title: Bronx: Search for Missing Baby
description: The police said they were searching yesterday for an infant boy whose mother reported him missing about 1:30 p.m. at Jacobi Hospital Medical Center. The woman, 28, whose identity was not released, first reported that a man had held a hard object to her back and abducted her son while she was outside the hospital, the police said, but they determined that there had been no abduction.

title: Albany: More Teachers Meet State Requirement
description: The number of public school teachers who met the highly qualified standard required under the federal No Child Left Behind Law increased last year, Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, said yesterday. The law requires that teachers have at least a bachelors degree, meet state certification requirements and demonstrate knowledge in the subject they teach. State rules require teachers to have a degree in the subject they are certified to teach. In 2005-6, 4.9 percent of English classes in the state were taught by a teacher who failed to meet the requirement, compared with 8.7 percent in 2004-5, Mr. Mills said. The same statistic for math teachers dropped to 5.7 percent from 7.9 percent, he said.

title: Buckeyes Big Return Is Quickly Forgotten
description: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 8  The Ohio State Buckeyes took turns tackling one another in the back of the end zone, a dog pile that was as raucous as it was premature.

title: Screen All Pregnancies for Down Syndrome, Doctors Say
description: For decades, pregnant women 35 and older have routinely been tested for chromosomal abnormalities that might affect their fetus, most notably Down syndrome. Younger women were tested much less often because the risk of birth defects was low and invasive procedures like amniocentesis carried risks of their own.

title: Illinois: Chicago Alderman Arrested
description: A Chicago alderman who is running for re-election was arrested on federal bribery charges, the authorities said. Prosecutors say an undercover investigation revealed that the alderman, Arenda Troutman, accepted a $5,000 cash bribe and agreed to accept $10,000 more, as well as a $5,000 political contribution, in exchange for using her office to support zoning changes on behalf of a private developer  a developer that was, in fact, a fictitious entity set up as part of the investigation. Bond for Ms. Troutman was set at $10,000. She plans to plead not guilty, her lawyer told The Associated Press.

title: Gap Is Said to Explore Selling Itself
description: Gap, the casual clothing chain that turned staples like T-shirts into must-have fashions and spawned scores of imitators that nibbled away at its business, is exploring a sale of the company, people briefed on the matter said yesterday.

title: U.S. Strikes Insurgents in Fierce Battle in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 9  More than 1,000 American and Iraqi troops, backed by Apache attack helicopters and F-18 fighter jets, battled insurgents all day Tuesday and late into the night in downtown Baghdad, in one of the most dramatic operations in the capital since the invasion nearly four years ago.

title: Britain: Diana Inquest Judge Wants Ordinary Jurors
description: Lady Butler-Sloss, the judge presiding over the inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, said at a preliminary hearing that she had not yet decided whether to convene a jury to hear the case. But she said that in any case it would be inappropriate to empanel a jury made up of members of the royal household, as is the usual custom in deaths that involve the royal family. The inquest  whose purpose is to determine the identity of the deceased and the time, place and manner of death  has been delayed by, among other things, long investigations by France and Britain. In a report released last month, the British police concluded that the car crash that killed Diana in Paris in 1997 was a result of an accident caused by a drunk driver, and that it was not a murderous conspiracy. Lady Butler-Sloss said she hoped to schedule the full inquest for the beginning of May at the latest.

title: Bloomfield: Bus Driver Arrested in Stabbing
description: A New Jersey Transit bus driver was arrested last night, suspected of stabbing a passenger during a dispute over the fare, officials said. About 8:50 p.m. a passenger boarded the No. 34 bus, which runs from Newark to Montclair, and began to argue with the driver, a transit company spokesman said. The driver radioed a dispatcher requesting that the police be sent to the scene, but before they s arrived, Mr. Stessel said, the argument escalated, the passenger spit in the drivers face and the driver responded by stabbing the man. The names of the driver and victim were not released last night. The victim was taken to University Hospital in Newark with injuries that were not life threatening, Mr. Stessel said. Officers from Bloomfield and New Jersey Transit were interviewing witnesses last night.
