title: Love, Bludgeoned and Bent by the Camps
description: Martin Amiss new novel, House of Meetings, tackles the same sobering material his 2002 nonfiction book Koba the Dread did: Stalins slave labor camps and the atrocities committed by the government during the failed Soviet experiment. The novel is everything that misguided earlier book was not. Whereas Koba weirdly mixed chilling, secondhand historical accounts of Stalins crimes with self-indulgent asides about Mr. Amiss upper-middle-class life in England, House of Meetings is a powerful, unrelenting and deeply affecting performance: a bullet train of a novel that barrels deep into the heart of darkness that was the Soviet gulag and takes the reader along on an unnerving journey into one of historys most harrowing chapters.

title: Another Wound From War: Perversely Eroticized Power
description: Josh Fox, an esteemed member of the avant-garde theater world in New York, is a young playwright of ferocious passion who seems to consider himself a big pitchfork hurtling toward our most egregiously held cultural and political fictions. His themes  that Americans are anxious and alienated from one another, that estrangement breeds violence, and impulsivity, misfortune  lack the controversial effect that his visually elaborate stagings assume. And so it is to his credit that his latest piece, You Belong to Me: Death of Nations, Part V, produced by his International WOW Company, engages an idea with which his audience may not find easy and immediate sympathy.

title: Manhattan: Diamond Club to Stay Put
description: In a setback for the developer Gary Barnett, the Diamond Dealers Club, a mainstay of the diamond district, has renewed its lease at its longtime home, 580 Fifth Avenue, near 47th Street. Mr. Barnett had hoped to lure the club to his planned 35-story tower on 47th Street, which he said would revitalize the citys diamond and jewelry industry. In November, the developer got a $49.6 million subsidy package from the city, to the annoyance of the owners of 580 Fifth and other landlords. Jacob Banda, president of the diamond club, said yesterday that in the end he had doubts about whether Mr. Barnetts tower would materialize. He said his landlord offered him a good deal on a 10-year lease, so he took it. Mr. Barnett insisted yesterday that his project was going forward, and he said the club had made a major, major mistake.

An audience became her extended family, encouraged to rest its collective head in her lap as she poured out musical bedtime stories for grown-ups. Though written by others, those stories, told in her voice, came across as nuggets of personal experience.

title: Book to Tell Litvinenkos Story
description: A friend and the widow of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko are collaborating on a book to be published by Free Press in May, "Death of a Dissident: Alexander Litvinenko and the Death of Russian Democracy." Alex Goldfarb with Marina Litvinenko will tell the story of Mr. Litvinenko and his career as a spy in the style of a political thriller. Mr. Litvinenko died of a high dose of the radioactive isotope polonium 210 in London in November, and before his death he accused the Russian government of poisoning him. Free Press is an imprint of Simon & Schuster.  The Sobol Award for Fiction, an online contest recruiting unpublished fiction writers, has been canceled, according to a statement on the contest's Web site (sobolaward.com). The statement said that an insufficient number of manuscripts were submitted. The promised prize for the winner of the contest, first announced in September, was representation with Sobol Literary Enterprises and a book deal with Touchstone, an imprint of Simon & Schuster. All entrants will be refunded the mandatory $85 entry fee, the statement said. The creators of the contest have endured criticism that the contest unfairly exploited unknown writers for money.  The Central Intelligence Agency has blocked Valerie Wilson from writing about her experience as an undercover officer for the agency in a new book, Newsweek reported. But the flagship imprint of Simon & Schuster is still planning to publish her book sometime this year. Adam Rothberg, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, declined comment.

The cash deal, valued at $25 a share, represents a 12.5 percent premium over IntraLases closing price of $22.23 on Friday. Advanced Medical Optics said it expected to complete the acquisition early in the second quarter.

title: Citigroup Makes Cutbacks in Japan

The actions will cut Citigroups fourth-quarter profit by 8 cents a share, a spokeswoman, Shannon Bell, said.

title: Ex-Chief of Aspen Technology Accused of Inflating Revenue

The executive, David L. McQuillin, 48, of Sudbury, Mass., was accused in Federal District Court in Manhattan of plotting to exaggerate the companys software revenue from January 2001 to September 2002. In court filings, prosecutors accused Mr. McQuillin of trying to inflate the revenue while he was competing against the companys other chief operating officer to become chief executive. He became chief executive in October 2002.

title: G.E. Woos Private Equity in Plastics Auction
description: In a move that has been expected for months, General Electric has begun shopping its plastics business to private equity funds, according to The New York Times. Goldman Sachs, the investment bank that G.E. retained to find buyers, approached at least four equity groups, including Apollo Management, Bain Capital, the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, in a deal could be worth $10 billion, the report said.

title: Black Engaged in Insider Trading, Prosecutors Allege
description: Conrad Black engaged in insider trading with the help of Toronto-based Brascan in 1998 to prop up the share price of Hollinger International, according to part of an expanded series of allegations by prosecutors in the United States Attorneys office in Chicago. The filing alleges that Lord Black split profits from the trading with a group of associates and Brascan, and that he circumvented securities laws. Lord Black and three other former Hollinger executives face a variety of criminal charges over allegations they looted more than $80 million from the media company.

title: Canadas Imperial Metals Raises Bid for Rival
description: Imperial Metals raised its bid to acquire BcMetals on Monday by increasing its all-cash bid to about $43.2 million Canadian dollars ($36.7 million) in a move to woo shareholders considering a competing offer. Imperial increased its offer to $1.125 Canadian dollars a share and reduced the minimum tendering condition to 50 percent plus one.

title: Yahoo Brings MyBlogLog into the Fold
description: Yahoo has purchased MyBlogLog, a social-networking site that aims to build communities among like-minded blog readers. Yahoo did not disclose what it paid for the Florida-based MyBlogLog, first launched in July, but the report put the price tag at a little over $10 million. Mybloglog also looks at reader behavior inside blogs, like what is being read and where readers go next, delivering information it can sell to web advertisers.

title: Morgan Stanley Gets on Board US Airways Bid
description: US Airways Group said Monday that it has enlisted Morgan Stanley to join Citigroup in providing the financing for its hostile $8.5 billion bid for Delta Air Lines. US Airways, which made its unsolicited bid for Delta in November, said at the time that it had tapped Citigroup for a $7.2 billion debt package intended to provide the cash portion of its offer as well as to refinance the merged company. Delta management strongly opposes the bid, seeking instead to exit bankruptcy as a stand-alone company.

title: Leader of Revived Fidelity Unit to Retire
description: Fidelity Investments said on Monday that Stephen P. Jonas, who engineered a makeover in less than two years as head of the investment management unit of the giant mutual fund firm, would retire at the end of this month. The news surprised analysts and investors, who said Mr. Jonas was the engine that drove Fidelitys makeover, doubling the size of its United States team of equities analysts, appointing new fund managers at some critical portfolios, including the flagship Magellan fund, and overseeing the move to new offices in Boston. As one of the worlds largest investors, with more than $1.3 trillion in assets, Fidelity has often played a role in pushing for change in the industry, and changes within its executive ranks draw attention.

title: ABN Amro Spins Off Biotech Venture
description: ABN Amro Capital, the private equity arm of the banking giant ABN Amro, has spun its life-sciences division off into an independent venture capital firm, Forbion Capital Partners, the new group said Monday, while announcing the close of a 200 million euros ($260 million) fund to take advantage of the companys successful track record in a difficult sector.

title: List of Golden Globe Nominees and Winners
description: Motion picture and television nominees and winners for the 64th annual Golden Globe Awards. denotes the winning nominee in each category.MOTION PICTURES:

title: Home Depot to Review Nardellis Pay
description: Home Depot, the home improvement store chain, said Monday that its board would require that two-thirds of its independent directors approve any compensation granted to Robert L. Nardelli, the former chairman and chief executive. The decision, made last Thursday but not disclosed until Monday in a regulatory filing, follows an uproar over Mr. Nardellis pay.

title: A Bud by Any Other Name
description: Anheuser-Busch has cut an importing and distribution deal with a Czech brewer  the same one it has been warring with for years over who owns the rights to the Budweiser trademark. Budejovicky Budvar and Anheuser-Busch have been fighting for almost 100 years in a country-by-country spat over the brand  and the deal will not stop that  but the two have now joined hands in a pact that will make the St. Louis-based brewer the importer of Czechvar, the name under which Budvar has been sold in the United States since 2001.

title: N.Y.S.E. Asks S.E.C. To Delay New Trading Rules
description: The New York Stock Exchange is a little behind schedule, it seems. Its parent, the NYSE Group, requested Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission postpone the implementation date of Regulation NMS, a series of sweeping changes designed to update United States markets for new, rapid trading technologies, from Feb. 5 to March 5.

title: Vodafone Gets Exclusive Look at Essars Books, Report Says
description: Vodafone will start examining Hutchison Essars books on Tuesday as it mulls a bid of $18 billion to $19 billion for the company, Indias fourth-largest mobile phone operator, The Financial Times reported. The newspaper said Vodafone had appointed Ernst & Young to help it with the due diligence process. The report said that fifteen Vodafone executives flew to Mumbai over the weekend to undertake parallel due diligence on the operational side of the business.

title: Is de Mol Looking to Take Back Endemol?
description: A Dutch billionaire, John de Mol, has taken a 5.15 percent stake in a television production company, Endemol, a business he founded in 1994 and sold to the Spanish telecom giant Telefonica six years later. The small holding in the company, which produces the Big Brother and Deal or No Deal television shows, was announced Monday by de Mols investment vehicle, Cyrte Investments, and could mark the first step in a campaign to regain control of the company.

title: In Software, More Deals But Smaller Prices
description: Mergers and acquisitions in the software industry, once characterized by multibillion-dollar transactions, entered into a phase of leftover consolidation in 2006, a report from The 451 Group, a research firm, concludes. While the number of transactions increased 20 percent from 2005 to 947, the aggregate value of those deals dropped 20 percent to $27 billion. Many of last years software deals involved second-tier vendors and vertical-market specialists, the report said.

title: Analysts Left Cold by Xerox Takeover Speculation
description: Xerox options trading surged Monday as trader speculation spread that Eastman Kodak could acquire the printer maker, options analysts told Reuters. But analysts downplayed the speculation, noting that such a transaction is unlikely to occur because film maker Kodak is less than half the size of Xerox by market capitalization and is in the midst of a restructuring following years of turmoil in its business.

title: McAfee to Take Charges Related to Stock Options
description: McAfee, the security software developer, said late Monday that it expects to record charges of $25 million to $45 million over several periods commencing with the fourth quarter of 2006 related to the improper granting of stock options. In October, McAfee announced that it had discovered the improper accounting of up to $150 million in option grants, and Chairman and Chief Executive George Samenuk subsequently resigned.

title: Barbs Traded in Nasdaq Bid for Exchange in London
description: Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange traded trans-Atlantic insults on Monday, as London exchange shareholders consider Nasdaqs $5.3 billion hostile takeover offer. Nasdaq has been trying to take over the London exchange since March, but has failed to lure London executives to the negotiating table.

title: Australian Energy Giant Receives Buyout Offer
description: Alinta, Australias biggest energy transmission company, has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank in what would be the countrys largest utility buyout. Alinta shares surged as much as 14 percent, valuing the company at 6.3 billion Australian dollars ($4.9 billion). Macquarie, Australias biggest investment bank, is advising the group and may take a stake in the buyout, Alinta said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

title: Kirkland Opens Hong Kong Office to Pursue Asian Buyouts
description: Smelling buyout opportunities in Asia, the law firm Kirkland & Ellis announced Monday that it has opened an office in Hong Kong after receiving regulatory approval. The bureau will be led by David Patrick Eich, a partner specializing in private equity deals who played a key role in the the $10.2 billion buyout of Philips Semiconductors by a consortium of private equity funds.

title: Investors Applaud NCRs Spin-Off Plan
description: Investors appeared pleased with Mondays announcement by NCR, the largest maker of automated teller machines and airport check-in kiosks, that it is planning to spin off its data management business, driving up the companys stock. Shares of NCR rose as much as 7.1 percent, to $45.42, before falling back to close at $43.79, an increase of $1.39, or 3.3 percent, over Fridays close, after NCR said it would spin off Teradata in what it expects to be a tax-free deal.

title: Grasso Spars With New York Over Taxes
description: Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, whose pay package has been the subject of a legal battle, is getting hit on another front as well. The New York Post reports that the New York State Department of Taxation wants to impose a $1.8 million penalty on Mr. Grasso related to New York City tax returns it believes he should have filed in 2002 and 2003. The dispute, according to the Post, hinges on the location of Mr. Grassos main residence during that time.

title: Gap Said to Explore Selling Itself
description: If Gap, the casual clothing chain, ends up putting itself on the block, the potential buyer may end up shelling out more than $18 billion, in a deal that could be one of the largest buyouts in retail history, according to The New York Times. The companys current market value is $16.4 billion, but analysts expect that a buyer would have to pay more than $18 billion.

title: To Charter or Not to Charter, That Is the Question
description: As Wall Streets record $44 billion in bonuses begin to circulate, private jets and charter flights are one of the many luxuries industry watchers are betting will reap the benefits of all this ready cash. But before spending their money on a luxury charter service, bankers may want to asses the pros and cons of such travel.

title: The Morning After
description: Some news and notes as you ponder that Boise State defeated Oregon State, which defeated U.S.C., which defeated Arkansas, which defeated Auburn, which defeated  Florida.

title: Breaking: Damon Drinks Beer, Pays Cash, Tips Well
description: The Baguette admits she crushed on Matt Damon at the New York Film Critics Circle Awards ceremony. His Everyman routine  drinking a beer and talking to everyone, while Leo DiCaprio took off like he was fleeing a sinking ship  was endearing.

title: Let Them Eat Cake, and Nothing Else
description: In his day job, the Bagger covers the rise and fall of MSM. He frequently suggests the sky is falling and often worries a piece the size of piano will hit his head. But nothing filled him with darker foreboding about the future of print media than walking into the New York Critics Circle Awards ceremony and finding that only dessert, not dinner, was served.

title: Express Scripts Moves to Derail Caremark Deal
description: Express Scripts opened a proxy war in the pharmacy benefits industry on Monday, saying it would nominate four directors to the 11-member board of Caremark Rx, which has agreed to merge with the drugstore chain CVS. The Financial Timess Lex column suggested that in rejecting Express Scriptss unsolicited takeover offer, Caremark may be blinded by its vision of transforming the industry.

title: Electronic Voting
description: Netroots has become a real force in real elections, so it is not surprising that some digital campaigning is underway for various films, including Children of Men. Reel Pop, a blog about on-line vid, shares a link to a homemade campaign document for the darkly wonderful film. So far, the document has been viewed over 40,000 times on YouTube.

title: Stifel Financial to Buy Ryan Beck
description: Stifel Financial said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Ryan Beck Holdings, a financial firm that postponed its initial public offering last summer. Stifel, which is based in St. Louis, will pay about $91.1 million in stock for Ryan Beck, a unit of a Florida regional bank, BankAtlantic Bancorp, and will additional payments if certain performance targets are met.

title: The Golden Cheese Award
description: Companies that contribute swag to the Golden Globes gift suite are allowed two company representatives to heap the stuff on people who already have too much of it. But the folks at Bluetooth Wristwatch decided to play every angle and auctioned off one of their employee slots on eBay.

title: Jumping the Gun, and Maybe, the Shark
description: The Directors Guild Awards are a tidy affair. Five guys  yeah, its almost always guys  get nominated for directorial achievement and we all get a nice, vigorous stirring of the Oscar tea leaves. Come back about 1:00 p.m. and the Baguette will be putting up the results. In the meantime, the Bagger has rolled the Magic Eight Ball across the floor and come up with the following assessments.

title: News Quiz: Accolades
description: O.K., we know this wasnt exactly the toughest challenge  more of a scavenger hunt. But on the flip side, this was a banner week for contextualizing, that elusive tidbit that seems to regularly be ignored most weeks. In that sense, wed dare play the Pollyanna and declare everyone an Egghead!

title: Citing Sarbanes-Oxley Reins, Chairman Leaves Shutterfly
description: Shutterfly, an online photo service, said Monday that the chairman, Jim Clark, co-founder of Web pioneer Netscape Communications, had resigned. In explaining his departure, Mr. Clark said securities regulations, and more specifically the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, had gone too far. The harsh comments from one of Silicon Valleys best-known entrepreneurs are likely to add to the debate about whether tougher laws are stifling innovation in the United States.

title: Clearing the Air
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi is poised to extinguish one of the last true perquisites of House service: the right to smoke just off the floor in an area known as the Speakers Lobby. Lawmakers and aides say they expect that Mrs. Pelosi will soon use the substantial powers of her new office to bar smokers from the lobby and force them outside. Opponents of smoking have complained about the practice for years. The impact of the change will be bipartisan; members of both parties regularly enjoy cigarettes and cigars as they relax in the lobbys leather chairs between votes. The highest ranking smoker is Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio and the minority leader, who was perhaps anticipating the change when he headed to an outer balcony last week for a quick cigarette. Ever defiant, some smokers said they would still light up in their personal offices.

title: New Congress, Older Look
description: The winds of change have blown through the 110th Congress, but only to a point. There are more women (90) and, obviously, more Democrats. But according to the Congressional Research Service, the average age of lawmakers in the new Congress is possibly the oldest in history. The average age of senators is 61.7  two years older than in the previous Congress. The oldest senator is Robert C. Byrd, 89, Democrat of West Virginia, and the youngest is John E. Sununu, 42, Republican of New Hampshire. The average age of representatives is 55.9, with Ralph M. Hall, Republican of Texas, the oldest at 83, and Patrick T. McHenry, Republican of North Carolina, the youngest at 31. More demographics: there are more Protestants than any other religious affiliation, but Roman Catholics account for the largest single religious denomination.

title: On the Hill: Homeland Security
description: House Democrats are pushing expansive plans for homeland securitymaybe a little too big for the Senate and the Bush administration. From The Timess Eric Lipton:

title: The LCD JuggernautNot So Fast!
description: Panasonic, which has most of its eggs in the plasma TV basket, takes exception to the idea that liquid-crystal display TVs are going to dominate the big-screen HDTV market. Yoshi Yamada, chief executive of its North American operations, told me, You are going to see a slow down in production of LCD and investment in LCD.

title: Black is the New Aluminum
description: Henry Ford supposedly said at the dawn of the automotive age, You can have the car in any color you want, as long as it is black.

title: D.L.P. Is Not Dead
description: Texas Instruments says reports of the demise of its digital light processing technology are premature. We believe DLP will be the third flat-panel technology, John Van Scoter, TIs senior vice president for DLP, told a small group of journalists over dinner last night.

title: The War at Home: Hearts and Minds
description: When it comes to Iraq, the White House knows it has to win over hearts and mindsof the Congress and the American people, that isif it wants to send more troops. President Bush reportedly made it clear to Republican senators yesterday that talk of a strategy involving escalation was true, and hell fill in the extra details Wednesday at 9 p.m.

title: Samsung vs. Apple
description: Samsung has bested Sony as the No. 1 maker of TVs in the United States. Now the Korean company has set its target on another company known for great design and unassailable market share.

title: The Trouble With Schwarzeneggers Health Care Plan
Kennedy Tackles Troop Surge
description: Today, Senator Edward M. Kennedy will deliver a speech at the National Press Club. As recently as a week ago, the focus was expected to be on domestic policy  particularly health care  and other points of his agenda for the new Democratic Congress.

title: The Readers Turn
description: From a reader: Instead of a 50-day layoff, how bout a playoff? (Editors note: Jesse Jackson couldnt have said it better)

title:
Getting to Know Wine?
The Only Thing to Fear Is Fear Itself
description: Ive had my long rest, and while I know its getting annoyingly late to say so, Happy New Year!

title: Blogs to Hannity: What About Mystic River?
description: Fox Newss Sean Hannity has launched a thousand blog discussions with the birthing of a segment called Enemy of the State on his new Sunday night program, Hannitys America.

title: And Baby Makes Five
description: Michael Lewis brings his Dad Again column, which had been about his second child, back to Slate for the birth of child No. 3: It was up to me to prevent it, which is to say that it was only a matter of time before it happened. Now a three-time veteran of the delivery room, Lewis offers this advice to expectant fathers:

title: As Battle Looms, CVS and Caremark Add Advisers
description: Caremark Rx seems to be girding for a serious fight. The pharmacy benefits manager, which recently rejected a $26 billion takeover bid from its rival Express Scripts in favor of a deal with the drugstore chain CVS, has hired Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz as a legal adviser. Wachtell Lipton is well-versed in the art of the takeover feud, having advised Walt Disney as it sought to fend off Comcasts hostile bid (which was withdrawn) and drug giant Sanofi in its hostile offer for Aventis (which succeeded).

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Make Up Your Minds Already
description: Mitt Romneys high-tech, highly public fund-raising blitz yesterday amounted to a de facto campaign kick-off after he formed an exploratory committee last week. In addition to raising $6.5 million, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts also won the endorsement of his fellow former Massachusetts governor, William Weld, despite Mr. Welds friendship with Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: The Candidates: Where They Stand on Iraq
description: As the nation awaits President Bushs speech on Wednesday night outlining his new approach to Iraq, a sampling of announced or likely 2008 presidential candidates are staking out positions on a spectrum from hawk to dove.

title: Buffalo: Abortion Provider's Killer Apologizes
description: A man convicted of killing a doctor who performed abortions as part of his practice apologized to the victims widow in Federal District Court yesterday, the first day of his trial on charges of violating a federal law forbidding forceful interference with reproductive services. The man, James C. Kopp, 52, who is acting as his own lawyer, told Lynne Slepian, whose husband, Dr. Barnett Slepian, was killed by a rifle shot from woods outside their suburban home on the evening of Oct. 23, 1998, I respect you and your family. Mr. Kopp, who spent more than two years as a fugitive in Mexico and France, is serving a sentence of 25 years to life after his conviction on state murder charges. If convicted in federal court, he faces a possible sentence of life without parole.

title: Pinault Is Given 3 Weeks to Decide on Suez Bid
description: The French billionaire Franois Pinault has until Feb. 2, or about three weeks, to decide whether to bid for the water and energy utility Suez, Frances stock-market regulator said Tuesday. If his holding company, Artemis, decides against a bid, he must steer clear of making a bid for Suez for six months unless there are significant changes in the environment, situation or shareholder structure in the company.

title: The Way We Were
description: Yesterdays lingering odor was attributed in part to a temperature inversion settling over the New York region. Of course, that wasnt the first time this has happened. Before the Clean Air Act, such inversions were linked to hundreds of deaths, as they trapped the deadly toxins from the citys factories and other agents of pollution.

title: The Surreal Life, Detroit Auto Show Edition
description: Across the street from Cobo, DaimlerChrysler throws a party each day of the auto show that begins at 4 p.m. and lasts till well past the witching hour. The venue is an old firehouse thats temporarily turned into a pub, complete with a massive square bar that dominates the cavernous tiled room. And the drinks are priced just right for journalists: free.

title: Gap Deal Would Face Many Hurdles, Analysts Say
description: Investors sent Gaps stock surging 7 percent on Monday amid reports that it might be considering a sale. But Wall Street analysts quickly pointed out some obstacles to an acquisition of the retail chain, whose casual fashions have been languishing on the racks in recent months. These include a generally lackluster demand for retail companies (as shown by last years failed auctions for Jones Apparel and Pep Boys) and Gaps relatively small amount of real-estate assets, which could be used to defray the cost of a buyout.

title: Back in Somalia, With al Qaedas Connection More Clear
description: SundayMondays attack in Somalia by a U.S. Air Force AC-130 gunship against suspected al-Qaeda members  a story that is only today beginning to take real shape  is something of a historic moment. As The Washington Post notes:

title: Torch It
description: The strangest new material featured in a high-end vehicle at the Detroit Auto Show: burned wood.

title: New York City Subway Hero Gets Free Jeep
description: Thomas W. LaSorda, chief executive of Chrysler, and Jason Vines, vice president for public relations, have quietly arranged for the New York City subway hero, Wesley Autrey, to receive a new Jeep Patriot as part of Jeeps ongoing Everyday Heroes program.

title: Sending Mercenaries Into Darfur
description: Anne from New Jersey raised an interesting question: You wrote in a recent column that President Bush could partly restore his legacy by establishing a no-fly zone over the Darfur region of Sudan. And, a few weeks before, you suggested that France, which maintains an airbase in Chad, could send military planes to strafe the Janjaweed, who, as groups of horsemen in the dessert, would be readily visible from the air.

title: The DGA Announces Its Nominees
description: Michael Apted, president of the Directors Guild of America, announced today that the five nominees for outstanding directing achievement in a feature film are:

title: The Return of Sean Patrick Maloney
description: The governors top deputy has a new top deputy.

title: The Company They Will Keep
description: Politics will not play a role in the selection of a replacement for former Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. At least, thats what the powers that be  Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, and Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno  said today.

title: For Apple Chief, Gadgets Glitter Outshines Scandal
description: As Steve Jobs was preparing to take the stage at the MacWorld trade show to make his buzz-drenched annual keynote address, pundits were piling on to excoriate him for Apples options-backdating scandal.

title: What, No Odorama?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today that the source of the smell that wafted across Manhattan yesterday remained a mystery  and more a matter for entertainment than anything else.

title: Kennedy: George Bushs Vietnam
description: Senator Ted Kennedy spoke at the National Press Club this afternoon, detailing a resolution he plans to introduce today that would require Congress to vote on President Bushs anticipated plan to send more troops to Iraq and any additional funding for those troops. In his speech, Mr. Kennedy, a Democrat from Massachusetts, called the Iraq war George Bushs Vietnam.

title: Cunningham Leaves 1199
description: A major development in New York politics. What does this mean, vis-a-vis Spitzer?

title: Blogtalk: Dissent, Jodi and Joe
description: Connecticut state police are taking some heat for arresting a freelance journalist/law student/activist (or put more succinctly - a blogger) at Gov. Jodi Rells inauguration parade last week.

title: Pricing the iPhone
description: Rob Glaser, chief executive of Real Networks, on Apples new iPhone:

title: In Praise of Names
description: Coming up with a name is hard work. Just ask Gwyneth Paltrowor, more accurately, just ask her daughter, Apple. Names, particularly creative names, are risky. On the topic of his sons name, Magnus, Will Ferrell told Regis and Kelly, We wanted to make sure he gets teased a lot.

title: The iPhone Rumors Are RightFinally
description: OK, so after three years of being wrong, the rumor sites were finally right. Now there IS an Apple cellphone. Or, rather, will be one in June.

title: Maybe Its His Deep Pockets
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared this morning before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee and the hearing - on implementation of the 9/11 Commissions recommendations - at times took on the appearance of a lovefest.

title: Schumers Hidden Assets?
description: Or, maybe not.

title: McGwire Haunted by His Own Silence
description: Members of the Baseball Writers Association of America, the body charged with voting new members into the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., settled on Cal Ripken Jr. and Tony Gwynn  both of whom were named on the necessary 75 percent of the 545 ballots cast.

title: Tim Johnsons Condition Upgraded
description: Senator Tim Johnson, the South Dakota Democrat who underwent emergency brain surgery in mid-December following a brain hemmorrhage, is making gradual improvement. His office announced today that his condition has been upgraded from critical to fair. Heres what his office had to say in a press release:

title: Flawed or Flawless
description: It may be a curiously extreme way to pose the question, but that phrase is the subtitle of a new oral biography of Rudolph W. Giuliani to be published Jan. 20.

title: No More Middleman
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 5 column, First, Do Less Harm.

title: 2008 Nuggets: South Rising
description: Senator John McCain has just signed on Alec Poitevint, currently the chairman of the Georgia G.O.P., to be his organizations Southern co-chairman. The Atlanta Journal-Constitutions Political Insiders have more:

title: Blogtalk
description: Is New York City behind the curve on wireless Internet? Apparently. [The Politicker]

title: Leggo My Ego
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 8 column, Quagmire of the Vanities.

title: Tired of Taking It On the Chin
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Jan. 8 column, Working Harder for the Man.

title: Creating a Heavier Footprint in Iraq
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Jan. 7 column, Making the Surge Work.

title: Blogtalk: To Not Go Gently
description: With the Democrats beginning their first 100 hours in control of Congress and with President Bush preparing to reveal his newest new strategy for Iraq, two streams joined this week to form a river of criticism and prediction on the conservative blogs.

title: To Surge or Not
description: Much has been made in recent weeks of the Bush administrations use of the term troop surge, to describe the option it is considering of sending more troops (say 20,000) into Iraq, presumably for a specified amount of time, with a mission to quell the sectarian violence that everyone agrees has been unrelenting.

title: Moved to New Address
description: Im blogging away this week, but youll find my posts at  this special trade-show address.

title: Some Hands-On Time With the iPhone
description: Update: This post is from David Pogues initial look at the iPhone in January. For updated information, click on the following links:

title: Two Stars Enter Hall; Steroid Cloud Stops 3rd
description: Mark McGwire hit 70 home runs in 1998 to shatter Roger Mariss single-season mark of 61 and help restore popularity to a sport damaged by a strike that led to the cancellation of the 1994 World Series. But since then, McGwires image had been increasingly damaged.

title: Les Moonves on the Digital Future of CBS
description: Early in his keynote speech this afternoon at CES, CBS chief Les Moonves said that the music business suffered from not listening to Internet audiences. He vowed that CBS would not hesitate to take risks, invest in start-ups and exploit online communities. The place for any media company is right up front, ripping, burning and mashing up the new beat we are all marching to, he said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Wednesday about prominent people who attended the funeral of former President Gerald R. Ford referred incorrectly to George Allen, Republican of Virginia. His Senate term ended at noon last Wednesday. At the time he arrived for the funeral, he was not a former lawmaker.

title: Moving Ahead on Stem Cells
description: House Democrats are poised to push through a bill this week that would loosen President Bushs restrictions on federal support of embryonic stem cell research. The bill will be opposed by legislators beholden to religious conservatives. Many are likely to cite a new study suggesting that broadly useful stem cells can be derived from amniotic fluid without destroying embryos to get them.

title: Home Depot Board Faces New Outcry
description: Now that the board has ousted Home Depots chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, shareholders are expecting big changes at the home improvement retailing giant.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Dec. 19, about the financial problems that health plans for retired government workers are causing in some cities, misstated the amount that New York City intends to set aside in a trust fund to pay for its retired workers health care. It is $2 billion, which is to be paid over fiscal years 2006 and 2007  not $2.2 billion, which is the citys contribution to the trust fund in fiscal 2006 as well as its outlay for retiree health care in the same year.

title: Slot Machines May Ring Where Steel Was Once Forged
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 4  Since its coke ovens shut down for the last time in 1998, the mile-long Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant has been a rusty reminder of this small Lehigh Valley citys proud industrial past. Trees have sprouted between the red bricks, and birds have nested in wire baskets in which steel workers once stored their belongings.

title: Starting New Term, Chvez Defends Recent Moves
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 10  President Hugo Chvez was sworn in to a new six-year term at a ceremony here today, calling Jesus Christ the greatest socialist in history and pledging to speed Venezuelas metamorphosis into a socialist state.

title: Earthy Cuban Sounds, Rendered With an Urban Complexity
description: If youve been curious about the state of new music in Cuba, Sequitur offered an answer of sorts in its program at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening. But it was an answer with an asterisk, for although the six composers on the program were all born in Cuba, and most began their musical training there, they live elsewhere now.

title: Queens: Four Charged With Attempted Murder
description: Four young men from Queens have been charged with trying to kill a man in Woodside on Friday because they suspected him of spraying graffiti on the house of one member of the group, prosecutors said yesterday. The four  Ali Khan, 19, Aamer Khan, 18, Christian Diaz, 17, and Joseph Piazza, 18  are charged with attempted murder and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said the group was riding in a Ford Explorer with the victim, Anthony Albaricci, 24, when one man looped a belt around Mr. Albariccis neck and began strangling him. Another stabbed Mr. Albaricci, while one slashed him with a razor. Aamer Khan, who was driving, turned and tried to shoot him with a pistol, Mr. Brown said. The Explorer crashed and Mr. Albaricci fled, only to be chased and beaten with a wooden chair by two of the teenagers, Mr. Brown said, while the other two ran him down with the Explorer.

title: Doctor Confronts the Human Dramas Inevitable Finale

By instinct and by training, they avoid what Pauline W. Chen calls the final exam, the emotional challenges posed by terminally ill patients. Death represents failure. It asks unanswerable questions. Perhaps most vexingly, it threatens to crack the hard professional shell of detachment that medical training puts in place. In modern American medicine, death is everywhere and nowhere at the same time.

China and Russia both oppose the move, but Alejandro D. Wolff, the acting American ambassador, said he hoped for a vote this week. Mr. Wolff said that the release of 2,831 prisoners announced last week had focused on petty criminals. If you look at the facts, he said. youll find that there are more political prisoners today than there were a year ago.

title: Brooklyn: Case Against Ex-F.B.I. Agent Can Proceed
description: A retired F.B.I. supervisor accused of aiding in Mafia murders is not immune from prosecution in state court, a Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday. The retired agent, R. Lindley DeVecchio, 66, was charged with four counts of murder last March in State Supreme Court. Prosecutors say Mr. DeVecchio, who was responsible for managing confidential informants, played a role in four killings between 1984 and 1992 by giving information to the Colombo crime family. In April, Mr. DeVecchios lawyers sought to remove the case to federal court, arguing that the evidence was subject to federal grants of immunity and that his defense was based on federal law. But Judge Frederic Block ruled that Mr. DeVecchio had not presented a valid argument.

United Healthcare Workers East  said yesterday that she was leaving the union to join a political consulting firm in New York City and a lobbying firm in Albany. Ms. Cunningham, a former deputy counsel to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, will become a partner at Knickerbocker SKD, a consulting firm. She will also be of counsel to Featherstonhaugh, Wiley, Clyne & Cordo, a lobbying and law firm in Albany. Ms. Cunningham said she would represent 1199 on many matters. She said she was leaving 1199 to spend more time with her 14-year-old daughter. I dont see it as leaving the union so much as changing the nature of my relations with the union, she said. Dennis Rivera, 1199s president, said, We look forward to working with her for many years to come.

title: Britain: Terrorism Warnings by E-Mail
description: The British security service known as MI5 is using e-mail to alert the public to changes in the security threat level. Internet users may register on MI5s Web site to receive the electronic updates. On Nov. 9, the agencys director general, Dame Eliza Manningham-Buller, said that Britain was facing as many as 30 terrorist plots and that terrorists might soon be using nuclear or biological weapons. Dame Eliza, who is retiring in April, has been more public than her predecessors in warning of suspected threats. In August, MI5 began posting details of the threat level, which is set by the governments Joint Terrorism Analysis Center, on its Web site. The threat level has five tiers and is now at severe, the second highest, which means an attack is considered highly likely.

Such was the resort staffs understanding of talent that the little girls were asked to wear bathing suits and swoon over a 10-year-old playing a lifeguard, while the little boys removed the slickers they were wearing in a simulated striptease to the tune of Its Raining Men. Most children catch on fairly easily after this, figuring out how to use the meaning of words and sentences as a guide to greater fluency. But at age 9, when he was a third grader at a school in rural Massachusetts, this boy had never made that leap. While most children his age could read simple chapter books, he could not even read the short phrases in a picture book.

title: Britain: An Increase in Profit at the London Stock Exchange

Net income rose to 31 million ($59.8 million) in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from 28.2 million a year earlier, the exchange said. Revenue increased 11 percent, to 89.9 million ($173.5 million). The third-quarter results support the boards rejection of Nasdaqs offer, which significantly undervalues the business and the exchanges unique strategic position, the exchanges chief executive, Clara Furse, said. Our strong growth prospects will continue to enhance the quality of our markets. The exchange, Europes biggest equity market, released its earnings about three weeks ahead of schedule and two days before Nasdaqs offer to pay 12.43 a share expires.

title: Emissions Plan for Airlines Opposed by U.S. Diplomat
description: A United States diplomat warned the European Commission against adopting rules that would impose emission controls on all flights landing at European airports, a signal that Washington may take legal action if the measure became law. The diplomat, John R. Byerly, left, deputy assistant secretary of state for transportation affairs, called the proposal unworkable and unlawful. The plan would force foreign airlines flying in Europe to pay for carbon dioxide emissions. Under the proposal, airlines would have to meet emissions targets starting Jan. 1, 2011, for all flights landing within the 27-member European Union. Mr. Byerlys comments came on the eve of two days of formal talks with European officials aimed at concluding an open skies treaty to open up the trans-Atlantic aviation market.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: In Cingular-Apple Deal, Only Phone Was Missing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9  When Cingular executives went to the companys board last year to get approval for a deal with Apple, they did so without so much as a prototype of an Apple phone to show the directors. The board signed off anyway.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart last Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about links between education and longevity misstated a correlation. People with more education are more likely  not less  to have had at least one alcoholic drink per month. (Go to Article)

title: Today in Business
description: CHVEZ PLAN DRAWS ALARM Investors reacted with alarm in the United States and throughout Latin America as they measured the impact of a plan by Venezuelas president, Hugo Chvez, left, to nationalize critical areas of the economy. Flashbacks of past nationalizations during another turbulent era, in places like Cuba and Chile, helped drive down the Caracas stock exchanges main index by almost 19 percent. [Page A1.]

title: Just a Simple Taxi Ride (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Circuit in Europe Bedeviled by Heat Wave in the Alps
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 9  Another heat wave is wreaking havoc with the World Cup skiing circuit this week, and this time warm temperatures melting the snow in the Alps are threatening the most important races in the sport.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the energy efficient ways of the Japanese misstated the amount of energy consumed in Japan and the United States as measured in tons of oil per person. Japan consumed the energy equivalent of 2.8 tons of oil per person in 2004, not 2.8 million tons. Likewise, the United States consumed 5.4 tons of oil per person, not 5.4 million tons. The article also referred imprecisely to the output from a home fuel cell used by a Japanese homeowner, Kiminobu Kimura. The cell produces one kilowatt of power per hour; not one kilowatt per hour.

title: Schwarzenegger Orders Cuts in Emissions
description: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 9  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Tuesday that he would ask regulators to require the states petroleum refiners and gasoline sellers to cut by 10 percent the emissions of heat-trapping gases associated with the production and use of their products.

title: The Colts Say Manning Just Wants Perfection
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9  Peyton Manning views the forward pass as an extension of his very being, the result of a life spent punching the clock in the family business.

title: U.S. to Raise Royalty Rates for Oil and Gas Leases in the Gulf
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Bush administration, accused of failing to collect billions of dollars from companies that drill for oil and gas in federal waters, announced on Tuesday that it would demand higher royalties on all new deepwater leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: The Breakfast Wars
description: LAST Wednesday at a Starbucks in Times Square, Katie Voss, a nursing student, was drinking one of the chains new coffee creations, a cinnamon-flavored low-fat latte. Ms. Voss, who was visiting from Maryland, said she visits Starbucks every day  up to three times a day, in fact  but rarely eats anything.

title: G.M. Officer Says Toyota Is Stronger in Washington
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9  Toyota has not yet passed General Motors to become the worlds biggest carmaker, but Robert A. Lutz, G.M.s vice chairman, says his company has fallen behind its rival in terms of clout on Capitol Hill.

title: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  President Bush announced tonight that he was sending more than 21,000 American troops to Iraq to quell the sectarian violence there, as he conceded for the first time that he had provided neither enough troops nor enough resources to halt the countrys descent into chaos over the past year.

title: Insurgents Battle Somali Forces in Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 10  The capital of Somalia exploded in violence this morning after insurgents attacked a government barracks overnight and soldiers responded by sealing off large swaths of the city and searching house to house for weapons.

title: Letters
description: Outfoxed by Sara Lee

title: Judge Sends Public Defender to Jail
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9  The chief judge in the citys juvenile courts had a top public defender arrested Tuesday in a bizarre escalation of a fight over changes in the citys troubled program for representing indigent defendants.

title: In Testing for Gifted Programs, a Few Knots
description: A new admissions process for highly coveted gifted-and-talented programs in the New York City elementary schools has been riddled with glitches, including last-minute notice of entrance exam dates in some areas, fraying the nerves of parents already frazzled about finding schools for their children.

title: Recipe: Oven-Roasted Branzino With Hazelnut Picada
description: Oven-Roasted Branzino with Hazelnut Picada Adapted from The Zuni Cafe Cookbook, by Judy Rodgers (W.W. Norton, 2002)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music column on Saturday about the View, a Scottish band from Dundee that made its American debut last week in New York, misstated the name of a Dundee suburb that one of its songs apparently refers to. It is Broughty Ferry, not Broughton Ferry.

title: 3 Relatives of Plotter Are Held by Officials
description: The parents and sister of a man convicted of conspiring to bomb the Herald Square subway station were detained yesterday by federal immigration authorities, who have been seeking to deport them to Pakistan.

description: Dow Jones Plans Layoffs at Newswires and Factiva

description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Considers Alternatives to Oil Pipeline Through Belarus
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9  An unyielding President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday raised the possibility of diverting oil transit routes away from Belarus, a day after Moscow cut off pipeline deliveries of crude oil headed to customers in Eastern and Central Europe through the country.

title: Recipe: Crunchy Granola
description: Time: 40 minutes

title: At Yale, Renovation Puts Africa in Spotlight
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 3  Fans of air, light and it-just-feels-right in architecture will find everything to admire in the revamped and revivified version of the Yale University Art Gallerys Louis Kahn building. Post-Kahnian partitions have been pulled down, picture windows uncovered. Rangy Modernist space  the space of the future when the building opened in 1953  unfurls in all directions.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) CHINA FROM THE INSIDE For all of Chinas vaunted power, much of the country remains a mystery to the outside world. This four-part documentary travels from the Great Wall, temples in Tibet and the border areas of Muslim Xinjiang to courtrooms, newspaper offices and a womens labor camp to paint of a portrait of its 1.3 billion people in all their contradictions. Tonights episodes look at the Communist Party, at 9; and the countrys women, who have one of the highest suicide rates in the world, at 10. The series continues on Jan. 17.

title: Iwao Takamoto, 81, the Animation Artist Who Created Scooby-Doo, Dies
description: Iwao Takamoto, the artist who created the mystery-solving Great Dane, Scooby-Doo, among many other indelible cartoon characters, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: Ex-Putnam Chief Settles
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (Dow Jones/AP)  The former chief executive of Putnam, Lawrence J. Lasser, will pay $75,000 to settle accusations that he failed to disclose that the investment company used fund assets to pay brokerage firms for preferred marketing agreements, regulators announced Tuesday.

title: Defense Dept. Settles Suit on Database for Recruiting
description: The Defense Department yesterday announced changes in how it will treat information in an enormous military recruiting database.

title: Big Names Competing for Indias 2-a-Minute Caller
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 9  When Krishnadeo Prasad Verma calls you from his mobile phone, there is a flicker of a ring, then silence.

title: The World Has Nearly Ended, but Movies Manage to Survive
description: A faux documentary with a twist, Ever Since the World Ended unfolds in and around an eerily depopulated San Francisco 10 years after a mysterious plague has decimated humanity. But instead of making a movie about the aftermath of a disaster, the filmmakers, Calum Grant and Joshua Atesh Litle, have tried something a little more clever and a lot cheaper: to envision what the first movie made after that disaster might look like.

title: President of Paramount to Leave After Brief Term
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10  After a brief reign of two years, Gail Berman will be leaving her job as the president of Viacoms Paramount Pictures unit, according to a film executive at the studio.

title: Massachusetts: Commuter Train Kills 2 Workers
description: Two track workers were killed, and four were injured when a commuter train plowed into track maintenance equipment. The train, with 43 passengers, was headed to Boston from Lowell when it hit the equipment shortly before 2 p.m. Ten passengers were taken to hospitals with minor injuries, and no crew members were hurt. Scott Farmelant, a spokesman for Massachusetts Bay Commuter Rail, said the crew was performing routine track maintenance work.

title: Mall REIT Warns That It Might Be Forced Into Bankruptcy
description: The Mills Corporation, the real estate investment trust known for off-price malls in outlying suburbs that combine entertainment and shopping, said yesterday that it was running out of cash and might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection, putting its shareholders at risk of losing their investment.

title: Bushs Troop-Increase Plan Is Expected to Draw Six Guard Brigades to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  President Bushs plan to increase troop levels in Iraq is expected to require the Army eventually to send as many as six National Guard combat brigades to Iraq, beginning in 2008.

title: Wage Increase Could Hinge on Tax Cuts
description: As part of their 100-hour legislative blitz, House Democrats are expected to vote today to increase the minimum wage for the first time in a decade, to $7.25 an hour, in a move that economists say will raise pay for 13 million workers.

title: Democrats Skeptical About Bushs New Iraq Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Hours before President Bushs speech on Iraq, Democrats carried out what amounted to a pre-emptive strike, with several top lawmakers voicing deep skepticism about whether the presidents vision is really a new way in Iraq.

title: Calendar
description: Beer, With Cheese

title: Off-Duty Correction Officer Kills Man in Traffic Dispute
description: An off-duty New York State correction officer fatally shot a man during a traffic dispute last night near La Guardia Airport in Queens, the police said. It was unclear how the dispute, which apparently began with a honked horn, escalated to gunfire.

title: Manhattan: City Projects Surplus
description: New York Citys short-term fiscal outlook looks very bright because the local economy remains strong and tax revenues have been coming in at higher rates than expected, according to a report released yesterday by the citys Independent Budget Office. The office projected a surplus of $2.1 billion for the 2007 fiscal year, which ends on June 30, and, assuming that that money is used to pay future expenses in advance, a surplus of $688 million for the 2008 fiscal year. The office said it expected deficits of $2.9 billion in fiscal 2009 and $2.7 billion in fiscal 2010, the last year of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs term  but added that those projected shortfalls were smaller than what the mayors Office of Management and Budget had projected.

description: Turbot Poached in St.-milion Adapted from Gordon Ramsay at the London

title: Venezuela Inc.s Hostile Takeover
description: President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela  the very portrait of a modern Latin American strongman  is not content to exercise near-total political and military control of his country. Now he is tightening his grip on the Venezuelan economy. Thats bad news for foreign investors, but even more so for the Venezuelan people who will have to pay the price for an economy plagued by increasing inefficiency and corruption.

title: Among His Official Duties, Keeping on Top of the 100-Hour Clock
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Rob Cogorno is busy watching the clock. And not just any clock.

title: Brooklyn: Teenager Sought in Subway Stabbing
description: A 17-year-old boy was stabbed once in the chest by another teenager yesterday afternoon on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said. The victim, whom the authorities did not identify, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was listed in stable condition, the police said. The stabbing occurred about 3 p.m. aboard a Manhattan-bound J train that was stopped in the elevated Norwood Avenue station, near Fulton Street in Highland Park, officials said. Detectives were investigating whether it followed an argument between the two teenagers earlier in the day. Charles Seaton, a spokesman for New York City Transit, said that train service was suspended in the area through the early evening. A witness to the stabbing said that the dispute arose among members of separate gangs at a nearby school yesterday and that members of the gang agreed to take the fight off school grounds.

title: Drivers Letter to Yoko Ono Is Released, and Rebutted
description: When prosecutors arrested Yoko Onos chauffeur in December, they said he was a disgruntled, potentially violent employee trying to extort money from her.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The headline for a film review in Weekend on Friday about Freedom Writers misidentified the California city in which the movie is set. It is Long Beach, not Los Angeles.

title: Two Views of Artists, Two Visions of the World
description: Im very careful not to have ideas, because theyre inaccurate, the artist Agnes Martin says in Mary Lances touching documentary about her, but its a lie. Ms. Martin was full of ideas, and she dispenses them engagingly in the course of the film, Agnes Martin: With My Back to the World, made from 1998 to 2002.

title: As Giants Wait, Maras on His Own for Tough Calls
description: The Giants president, John Mara, typically affable and approachable, increasingly avoided reporters as the teams season deteriorated. He knew that tough decisions were coming, and that he was about to begin shaping his true legacy.

title: I.R.S. Use of Private Debt Collectors Is Criticized
description: The national taxpayer advocate called on Congress yesterday to repeal the authority of the Internal Revenue Service to use private debt collectors.

title: Apple Introduces Innovative Cellphone
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9  With characteristic showmanship, Steven P. Jobs introduced Apples long-awaited entry into the cellphone world Tuesday, pronouncing it an achievement on a par with the Macintosh and the iPod.

title: In Poland, New Wave of Charges Against Clerics
description: KRAKOW, Poland, Jan. 9  Poland was convulsed in finger-pointing and recrimination on Tuesday as more allegations of former secret-police collaborators among the Roman Catholic clergy members spilled onto the countrys front pages, sullying an institution that for decades was considered spotless in its fight against Communism.

title: My Favorite Green Lump
description: Colstrip, Montana

title: Its Another Big Night in the City for the Isles
description: For all the dominance the Islanders have had over the Rangers in this seasons installment of their rivalry, they were not flexing it particularly proudly after last nights 5-3 victory at Madison Square Garden.

description: Wilson, Wyo.
