description: WASHINGTON

title: Pakistan: Plan for Border Mines Reconsidered
description: The Foreign Ministry said it had taken note of the statement this week by the United Nations deputy special representative in Afghanistan, Chris Alexander, that Pakistan and Afghanistan had to end their war of words over their border and said it would reconsider Pakistans announcement last month that it would lay mines along the border. The ministry said it agreed that blocking undesirable elements  a reference to the resurgent Taliban  from entering Pakistan was the responsibility of the forces operating on the Afghan side. President Hamid Karzai had voiced strong opposition to the plan for mines.

title: Finding the Green in Building Renovation
description: It is a rare announcement for a new commercial office building these days that does not trumpet the new structures green features. In fact, nearly 5,000 buildings across the country, 90 percent of them new construction, are awaiting evaluation by the United States Green Building Council.

title: Flavored With Flame and Stone
description: IT started with an offhand comment from Eric Ripert, the chef of Le Bernardin.

title: Airstrike Rekindles Somalis Anger at the U.S.
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 9  Somali officials said Tuesday that dozens of people were killed in an American airstrike on Sunday, most of them Islamist fighters fleeing in armed pickup trucks across a remote, muddy stretch of the KenyaSomalia border.

title: Making Impressionism Move to a Ballet Beat
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  After carefully trolling the North Carolina Museum of Arts Monet in Normandy exhibition, seeking inspiration for a new dance, the choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett ended up using a painting not in the show: Monets Djeuner sur lHerbe. Thats right, Monets  not Manets better-known 1863 painting of the same title, depicting a languid luncheon party of four, including unabashedly naked women, but Monets more decorous 1865-66 scene of a luncheon party of a dozen or so ladies and gentlemen, elegantly dressed.

title: Ruling Seen as Giving an Edge to Challengers of Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Supreme Court opened the door Tuesday to a category of patent lawsuits that a lower court had barred, issuing a decision that will probably shift power in the courtroom from bigger patent-owning companies to smaller start-up companies that rely on obtaining licenses for patented technology.

title: Spitzer Office Finds E-Mail Can Be Revealing
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10  Gov. Eliot Spitzer made his name, in part, on indiscreet e-mails, as any number of executives who were pursued by the attorney generals office in recent years can attest. Now his administration has sent out an indiscreet e-mail of its own: an e-mailed response to people seeking jobs as spokesmen was addressed to 227 other applicants, including many reporters and local and city government employees.

title: Schwarzeneggers Plan for Universal Care Draws No Universal Agreement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9  When Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger took the oath of office last Friday, he called on legislators in Sacramento to set aside party loyalty in favor of the Party of California.

title: Personal Shopper
description: New looks for a classic table.

title: Currents
description: A new vacuum promises power without heft, the holidays are over but discount shopping isn't and more.

title: Apple Waves Its Wand, Again
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 - Remember the fairy godmother in Cinderella? Shed wave her wand and turn some homely and utilitarian object, like a pumpkin or a mouse, into something glamorous and amazing, like a carriage or fully accessorized coachman.

title: Saving a Broken Angel
description: Scenes from the Broken Angel, an eccentric building at 4 Downing Street in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, which the owners, and others, are trying to save from demolition.

title: Clip-Ons Are Back
description: The return of clip-on earrings.

title: Philharmonic Casts 'My Fair Lady'
description: The cast of the New York Philharmonics semistaged performance of My Fair Lady from March 7 to 10 has been announced: Kelli OHara (The Pajama Game) will play Eliza Doolittle, and Kelsey Grammer (Frasier) will play Prof. Henry Higgins.

title: Ted Hughes Letters Go to Emory University
description: Emory University has acquired letters from Ted Hughes to Assia Wevill, his mistress during his marriage to Sylvia Plath. Mr. Hughes continued his relationship with Ms. Wevill after Ms. Plaths suicide in 1963, but the two never married. The letters allow unprecedented access to Hughess state of mind at a time of crisis in his personal and professional life, said a statement from Stephen Enniss, the director of Emorys Manuscript, Archives and Rare Book Library. The collection includes more than 60 letters from 1963 to 1969, sketches, diary entries and photographs. One letter implores Ms. Wevill to burn all my letters. A biography of Ms. Wevill, Lover of Unreason, by Yehuda Koren and Eilat Negev, was published in December.

title: French National Library Recovers Stolen Manuscript
description: A 13th-century Hebrew Bible, stolen from the French National Library in the late 1990s, has been recovered after complex negotiations between French officials, Christies and a Brooklyn antiquities dealer, Yosef Goldman, who bought the leatherbound book from the auction house in 2000 for $368,000. Library officials said Mr. Goldman purchased the manuscript in good faith and had already resold it when its theft was discovered. France sued Mr. Goldman for the return of the book, but the case was later settled, with France reportedly agreeing to cover some of Mr. Goldmans legal expenses. Michel Garel, the former chief curator of manuscripts at the library, was convicted last March of stealing the Bible and sentenced to a two-year suspended prison term and a fine of 400,000 euros ($520,000). He has appealed the verdict, and a ruling is expected this month.

title: Philharmonic Chooses 'My Fair Lady'
description: My Fair Lady will be presented by the New York Philharmonic in four semi-staged performances in March.

title: The Geodesic Dome
Home Depot Board Faces New Outcry
description: Home Depots ousted chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, may not be the only one to walk the plank at the home improvement retailing giant. Some shareholder activists and corporate governance watchdogs are now turning their attention to the companys board, criticizing Home Depots decision to allow three directors to remain even after reaching the mandatory retirement age of 72.

title: Let the Iceman Come
description: Gear test with Ellen Miller, mountain running team manager.

title: Dow Jones Plans Layoffs at Newswires and Factiva
description: Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, is planning to cut jobs at Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva to reduce overlap between the news groups. The number of positions to be eliminated will be announced at a company meeting Wednesday, and employees who will lose their jobs were to be contacted yesterday. The cuts follow Dow Joness purchase in October of the Reuters Groups 50 percent stake in the Factiva.com news database for $153 million.

title: Deadline for Your Turn to Tell the Story
description: Todays the deadline for Your Turn to Tell the Story: The Darfur Genocide.

title: U.S. Prohibits All Transactions With a Major Iranian Bank
description: The United States, moving to raise pressure on Iran, on Tuesday barred American financial institutions from doing business with a major Iranian bank after concluding that it had been involved in illicit weapons programs. The move against Bank Sepah, announced by the Treasury Department, also affected North Korea, which American officials said had used the bank to facilitate payments to a North Korean group that exports missile technologies.

title: Storm Clouds Gather as Congress Takes Up Nets Future
description: The starting gun was fired in what could turn into a battle royale between major Internet players. Senior lawmakers, emboldened by the recent restrictions on AT&T and the change in control of Congress, have begun drafting legislation that would prevent high-speed Internet companies from charging content providers for priority access.

title: Endemol Brings French Unit Back Into the Fold
description: Endemol, the TV production company behind Big Brother, agreed to buy its French unit from the Spanish company Telefonica for as much as 450 million euros. The deal could accelerate Telefonicas effort to sell its stake in Endemol, analysts said.

title: Vivendi and Deutsche Telekom Both Claim Victory in PTC Ruling
description: Vivendi and Deutsche Telekom both claimed victory Tuesday in their long-running dispute over ownership of the Polish mobile phone network PTC.

title: Holland & Knight Hires Securities Lawyers From a Rival
description: A law firm, Holland & Knight said Monday that it had hired three lawyers from a smaller rival, Akerman Senterfitt, to join its securities and public companies practice.

title: China Life Shares Surge in Shanghai Debut
description: The share price of China Life, the countrys No. 1 life insurer, soar Tuesday in its widely anticipated debut on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. China Lifes shares opened trading at 37 yuan ($4.74), up from the companys initial public offering price of 18.88 yuan, and closed at 38.93 yuan.

title: Rank Shareholders Approve Hard Rock Sale
description: Shareholders in the Rank Group have approved the $965 million sale of the Hard Rock cafes and associated businesses to the Seminole Tribe of Florida, despite a lawsuit from a spurned suitor that claims the sale process was unfair.

title: Former U.S. Foodservice Executive Settles Fraud Charges
description: The former controller at U.S. Foodservice, a unit of the Dutch supermarket operator Royal Ahold, has agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to settle accusations that she participated in a fraud that overstated income by $700 million in fiscal 2001 and 2002, the Securities and Exchange Commission says.

title: London Stock Exchange Reports Higher Profit
description: The London Stock Exchange, seeking to fend off a hostile takeover by the Nasdaq Stock Market, got some more ammunition yesterday when it reported a 9.9 percent increase in third-quarter profit and forecast a strong performance in fiscal 2008.

title: Bahrain Royal Family Takes Stake in Formula One Team
description: McLaren Formula Ones chairman, Ron Dennis, and a Saudi investor, Mansour Ojjeh, are selling half their stakes in the company to an entity owned by the Kingdom of Bahrain, which will hold 30 percent of the racing business.

title: For Bidders, Indias 2-a-Minute Caller Is a Caller Nonetheless
description: The three-way struggle for the Indian mobile phone provider Hutchison Essar is emerging as one of the largest corporate takeover battles in Indian history. Hutchison could overnight become one of Asias largest companies if it fetches an expected valuation of $16 billion to $20 billion.

title: Former Chief of Putnam Settles in Disclosure Case
description: The former chief executive of Putnam, Lawrence J. Lasser, will pay $75,000 to settle accusations that he failed to disclose that the investment company used fund assets to pay brokerage firms for preferred marketing agreements, regulators announced Tuesday.

title: Banks Settle Claims in Auction Inquiry
description: A subsidiary of Deutsche Bank, the Bank of New York and Wilmington Trust have agreed to pay a combined $1.6 million to settle claims in an investigation of the $200 billion auction-rate securities market. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlements on Tuesday, the second set of settlements to grow out of an inquiry into the auction-rate bond market. In May, 15 brokerage firms agreed to settle accusations of violations in the same market.

title: Cryptologic Buys Scandinavian Poker Brand
description: A Canadian gambling software firm CryptoLogic has agreed to pay up to 20 million Canadian dollars ($17 million) for the poker brand and related assets of Parbet.com, a popular Scandinavian online poker room.

title: YouTube Is Back Online in Brazil
description: A Brazilian court said Tuesday that Internet service providers could allow Web surfers access to the popular video-sharing site YouTube, a day after they started blocking it because of a racy sex video featuring an MTV veejay and model and a Merrill Lynch banker. The move follows a hue and cry raised by devoted Brazilian YouTube fans over the loss of their favorite site.

title: WetPaint Gets Fresh Funding
description: Wetpaint, a startup that provides hosting and tools for building wiki-based Web sites, said on Tuesday that it had raised $9.5 million in a second round of venture funding from Accel Partners. Wetpaint, which is aimed mainly at consumers building community-oriented sites, is one of several do-it-yourself Web site services that have emerged over the past two years.

title: Japans Mizuho Plans to Merge Brokers, Report Says
description: Japans Mizuho Financial Group plans to merge two of its group brokerages next year to create the countrys fourth-biggest securities house by assets, Reuters reported. The merger of Mizuho Securities and Shinko Securities would create a full-service brokerage and investment bank with $260 billion of assets under management.

title: Wachovias Evergreen Buys British Investment Firm
description: Wachovias asset management unit, Evergreen Investments, agreed to buy a majority stake in European Credit Management, a privately held, fixed-income investment management firm based in London. European Credit has about $26 billion in assets under management, which would lift Evergreens international total to more than $280 billion.

title: Goldman Said to Lead in Broadcasting Bid
description: The private equity arm of Goldman Sachs has taken the lead position in the bidding for Canadas Alliance Atlantis Communications, according to The Globe and Mail. Goldman, which has has teamed up with CanWest Global Communications, is offering to pay the majority of the purchase price, with CanWest making a cash contribution of less than 20 percent of the value of Alliances specialty TV channels, the report said.

title: The Contradictions of Tom Coughlin
description: Update: The Giants have decided to retain Coughlin and extend his contract one season, through 2008. We are satisfied with how he planned to move forward and we remain convinced that he is the right man for the job, the team co-owner John Mara told reporters.

title: NYSE and Goldman Take Stakes in Indian Exchange
description: The NYSE Group and three other foreign investors have bought a 20 percent stake in Indias biggest stock exchange, the National Stock Exchange. It was the latest move in a wave of consolidation sweeping global exchanges.

title: Facing Bankruptcy, Mills May Have to Sell
description: The Mills Corporation, the real estate investment trust known for off-price malls in outlying suburbs that combine entertainment and shopping, said yesterday that it was running out of cash and might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection, putting its shareholders at risk of losing their investment.

title: Kodak to Sell Health Group to Onex
description: Eastman Kodak, the photography company, said Wednesday it plans to sell its medical imaging business to a subsidiary of a Canadian conglomerate, Onex, for up to $2.55 billion. Kodak said the move would help it focus on its consumer and professional imaging business.

title: Quattrone to Take the Podium
description: Frank P. Quattrone, the former star technology banker from Credit Suisse whose years-long exile from the securities industry came to an end this fall, has been chosen to speak to a group of venture capitalists at an industry event. The New York Post notes that in doing so, Mr. Quattrone will join the ranks of Eliot Spitzer, the former New York attorney general who vigorously policed Wall Street.

title: Loans to Hedge Funds Face Scrutiny
description: The financial regulators in the United States and several European Union countries have begun a joint investigation into whether banks prime brokerages are taking too many risks as they increase lending to hedge funds. Officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission, Britains Financial Services Authority, the New York Federal Reserve and several European agencies met last month to discuss whether a relaxation in credit standards could spark trouble down the road.

title: President Bushs Address to the Nation
description: The following is the prepared text of President Bush's address to the nation tonight, as released by the White House:

title: NovaVision Scores $20 Million Third Round
description: NovaVision, a developer of neurological therapy technology, raised $20 million in a third round of funding, which it will use to expand its network of stroke and brain trauma treatment centers. Late-stage venture investor Chicago Growth Partners led the round.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Project Runway
description: While Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton takes the best dressed competition in New York, shes also mulling over whether to base her campaign headquarters in New York or Washington and all but confirms that shes made up her mind about another question.

title: Cerberus Is Weighing a $38 Billion Offer for an Office REIT
description: Cerberus Capital Management is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, people involved in the discussions said last night.

title: An Ideal Middle East?
As the Dust Clears, Assessing the Air Strikes in Somalia
description: There is some speculation today that American air strikes in Somalia may have taken out the Qaeda operative suspected of masterminding the 1998 bombings of the American embassies Kenya and Tanzania that killed 225 people, Fazul Abdullah Mohammed.

title: Hush Tactics for the iPhone
description: I asked Steve Jobs if he knew of the work of Jeffrey Han, whos been demonstrating his big multi-touch screen technology since at least August 2005. (I mentioned this similarity in my last blog post.)

title: The Hill: The Clock is (Finally) Ticking

title: US Airways Raises Delta Offer to $10.2 Billion
description: US Airways said Wednesday it had raised its bid to acquire Delta Air Lines out of bankruptcy to $10.2 billion in cash and stock, hoping to persuade Deltas creditors to support its proposal over the stand-alone reorganization plan that Delta has endorsed.

title: New Orleans Violence Boils Over
description: An already fragile social structure in the citys poorest wards has been all but destroyed by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Bronx: Hospital Closing Blocked
description: A State Supreme Court judge has issued a temporary restraining order halting the state from proceeding with plans to close Westchester Square Medical Center in the East Bronx. The ruling last week by Justice Mary Ann Brigantti-Hughes, will remain in effect until a hearing on Jan. 29. Westchester Square is one of nine hospitals statewide that a state panel recommended be closed. Several other hospitals are seeking to reverse the commissions decision.

title: Making Granola
description: There are two reasons for making your granola. One: it tastes better. Two: it contains better ingredients. Mark Bittman demonstrates.

title: Name That Would-Be Newspaper Baron
description: Even as newspapers struggle with declining readership and rising costs, the ranks of billionaires who might step in to buy them seems to be growing. Among those reported to be considering acquiring a newspaper are David Geffen, John F. Welch Jr. and Maurice Hank Greenberg.

title: The War at Home: Looking Forward to The Way
description: Today is the first day of the rest of the Iraq war. President Bush will tell us the way forward during an address tonight at 9 p.m., even though most of his plan has already been leaked. Mr. Bush reportedly will call for 20,000 more troops (The Times has just reported that those troops would have a limited role, according to the White House). He will also unveil a major economic development plan and detail benchmarks the Iraqi government must meet (a plan that isnt all that new, according to The Associated Presss Tom Raum). The call for increasing troops marks the first time that Mr. Bush has acted counter to the advice of his top military brass.

title: What Competition?
description: The nice thing about the National Board of Review, which filled Ciprianis restaurant and then some last night, is that the competitive issues are settled and the program is not televised, so all the Hollywood wattage can unwind and enjoy themselves. The fact that they had several long hours, and 42 speeches, to do so may have bothered some  the Bagger, who has stamina issues, did not make it to the end  but the Baguette drank from the celebrity cup deep into the night.

title: Fires Out in the Speakers Lobby
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the new speaker of the House, has just banned smoking in the Speakers Lobby, the room right outside the House chamber where reporters wait to tackle members and members go, err, went, for a smoking break. With studies showing the risks of secondhand smoke and a new restaurant smoking ban in Washington, D.C., Mrs. Pelosis press release said that as Members of Congress, we must be held to a higher standard. We can no longer risk the health of colleagues, staff, pages, reporters and others who pass through the Speakers Lobby each day.

BusinessWeek.com cited the report, called The 2007 Private Equity Compensation Report, in Tuesdays article about salaries in the financial-services sector. Hedge Fund Daily gave highlights from the report last month.

After presiding over the biggest hedge fund collapse in history, Mr. Maounis is reportedly looking for financial backers for a new investment fund, which he and some former colleagues would run.

So it comes as quite a surprise that applicants for press jobs to his administration were sent back e-mails with the return addresses of other applicants.Michael Cooper talks to some of those applicants in this article.

description: Steve Jobs said yesterday that he hopes Apples new iPhone will eventually garner one percent of the world-wide market. Judging by readers comments, enthusiastic commentary on Good Morning America, and a constant discussion of the phones features in the Consumer Electronics Show pressroom, he may very well meet that goal.

title: Moonves Speaks, But Offers Few Hints on M&A

CBS Chief Executive Leslie Moonves offered little in the way of hints either during his keynote address Tuesday at the Consumer Electronics Show or in a backstage interview with paidContents Staci D. Kramer.

description: After crunching the numbers on US Airways latest bid for Delta Air Lines, several equity analysts said Wednesday that it seemed to present a better payout for creditors than Deltas standalone reorganization plan. Their estimates were slightly different, but three of them calculated that US Airways was offering at least $2 billion more than Delta would be worth if it emerged from bankruptcy on its own. Their analysis suggests that US Airways new offer, consisting of $10.2 billion in cash and stock, may get serious consideration from Deltas creditors.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The House overwhelmingly approved a $2.10-an-hour increase in the federal minimum wage on Wednesday, in a vote that Democrats hailed as overdue and a symbol of new leadership on Capitol Hill.

description: The stained-glass windows in the eccentric building at 4 Downing Street in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn are made from discarded salt shakers, ashtrays and coffee tables, bottles dug up in the backyard and the detritus of neighborhood car accidents. It is only from the inside that you can see the windows brilliant colors.

title: James Weeks, Ex-Times Co. Executive, Dies at 64
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Jan. 10  James C. Weeks, a former president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Regional Media Group and a former publisher of The Press Democrat of Santa Rosa, died Monday in New York. He was 64 and had homes in Atlanta and Aspen, Colo.

title: U.S. Governor Brokers Truce for Darfur
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Jan. 10  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan and leaders of several rebel factions in Darfur, the western Sudanese region, agreed Wednesday to a 60-day cease-fire in separate meetings with Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a former American ambassador to the United Nations, according to a statement by Mr. Richardson and Mr. Bashir.

title: 46 New York City Schools Join List of Those Failing in Student Performance Standards Under U.S. Law
description: Forty-six New York City schools have been newly identified as failing under the federal No Child Left Behind law based on their students performance in the 2005-6 school year, the State Education Department said yesterday.

title: Britain Wont Follow U.S. in Adding Troops in Iraq
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  Britain, Americas closest ally in Iraq, said today that it would not follow the United States in raising troop levels there and signaled that it would pursue its own planned handover of security responsibilities to Iraqi forces in the south.

title: Bushs Strategy for Iraq Risks Confrontations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  By stepping up the American military presence in Iraq, President Bush is not only inviting an epic clash with the Democrats who run Capitol Hill. He is ignoring the results of the November elections, rejecting the central thrust of the bipartisan Iraq Study Group and flouting the advice of some of his own generals, as well as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq.

title: Skull Provides Signs of When Humans Left Africa
description: From a new analysis of a human skull discovered in South Africa more than 50 years ago, scientists say they have obtained the first fossil evidence establishing the relatively recent time for the dispersal of modern Homo sapiens out of Africa.

description: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 10  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Wednesday that he was in pain. A lot of pain.

description: A report in the World Business Briefing column last Thursday about the start up of Ironshore Insurance in Bermuda carried an incorrect credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not The Associated Press.

title: NASA Schedules Flight to Update Space Telescope
description: The Hubble Space Telescope has a new, resonant date with destiny. NASA has set Sept. 11, 2008, as the target date for launching a mission intended to revitalize the telescope and keep it spaceworthy into the next decade, according to a planning document made public by nasawatch.com, an independent Web site.

title: ImClone Shares Rise on an Erbitux Study
description: ImClone Systems said yesterday that its Erbitux cancer drug works as a first-choice treatment for bowel cancer. The companys shares rose 5.3 percent.

title: Rights of Unions and Nonmembers Vie at Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  A case argued before the Supreme Court on Wednesday about how labor unions must handle the fees paid by nonmembers could turn out to be little more than a footnote to a long line of decisions about the respective rights of labor unions and dissident employees.

title: Body Mass and the Student Body
description: Over the last three decades, the number of overweight children in America has tripled to 16 percent, so it would seem that anything that can help kids get to a healthy weight is worth considering. But schools arent helping if children think theyre being labeled as fat. That could be the effect of a program pioneered in Arkansas, which three years ago began measuring students body mass index  or B.M.I., a calculation based on weight and height  and then sending home what kids are calling obesity report cards. Pennsylvania and West Virginia do similar surveys, and about a dozen states, including New York, have bills to follow suit.

title: Hard Work Helps Nets Tune Out Distractions
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 10  The Nets did not win the road game some of the players considered their best of the season  a 1-point loss to the Detroit Pistons on Dec. 26 that ended on a controversial call. Since then, the Nets have won four of six games and appear to be playing closer to preseason expectations.

title: EBay Will Buy StubHub for $310 Million
description: EBay said yesterday that it had agreed to buy online ticket reseller StubHub Inc. for $310 million to bolster its share in the multibillion-dollar market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.

title: Bail Set in Greece for Ex-Curator of Getty
description: ATHENS, Jan. 10  Appearing before an investigating magistrate and prosecutors, Marion True, the former antiquities curator of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, was ordered on Wednesday to post $19,500 in bail pending trial on charges that she conspired to buy an ancient funerary wreath that prosecutors say was illegally removed from Greek soil about 15 years ago.

description: GRAFTON, N.Y.  Pond View Way, a dirt road in this town of 2,125 residents, was completed late last year, but it is so new, and in such a remote location  eight miles west of the Vermont-Massachusetts border  that much of it does not appear on local maps.

description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Jan. 10  Despite the burst of colder weather on Wednesday, in the Hamptons it was the day of the dolphin.

title: Back to 'Talking Smack' With Rosie, Donald and Barbara
description: If someone had to describe the feud between Donald Trump and Rosie ODonnell to a television viewer whose power had been off the last three weeks, there are worse analogies than that of a WWE title bout, complete with a little off-camera brawling in the locker rooms and high-stakes ratings on the line.

title: A Reversal of Fortune as Giants Keep Coughlin
description: The owners of the Giants and the man who coaches the team had differing perspectives after their meetings on Monday and Tuesday.

title: The New Palette of Gansevoort
description: RUTH RO, an artist whose studio overlooks the intersection of Little West 12th Street and Washington Street, sees two ways to look at the state of the meatpacking district. You can bemoan the luxury whitewashing of the neighborhoods once gritty character (and its sanguinary sidewalks), or you can view the change as a rebirth, bringing life to streets that once belonged to carcasses.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 3 about Teddy Kollek, the former mayor of Jerusalem, incorrectly rendered his birth name. He was Theodor Kollek, not Theodor Herzl Kollek. (Although he was named after Theodor Herzl, the founder of modern Zionism, he was not given a middle name, according to the Jerusalem Foundation, which he founded.)

title: Queens: Election Fraud Alleged
description: A former aide to Jimmy Meng, the first Asian-American member of the State Assembly, has been charged with voter registration fraud, the Queens district attorneys office said yesterday. Simon Ting, 42, of Flushing, who resigned after Mr. Meng chose not to run for re-election last year, submitted voter registration paperwork in 2004 for 36 people who did not live in Mr. Mengs district. None of the people voted or attempted to vote in the 2004 election, prosecutors said. Mr. Ting was charged with offering a false instrument for filing and procuring false documents, and faces up to four years in prison if convicted.

title: Unfilled City Manager Posts Hint at Future Gap
description: TECUMSEH, Okla.  Bent over a yellow 1969 Camaro Super Sport, David Johnson said he much preferred restoring muscle cars to solving his neighbors utility and garbage woes as Tecumsehs city manager.

title: Large Beasts, Mean Weapons and a Terrifying Judge
description: Many people believe that energy conservation is the way to deal with dwindling energy resources, but Capcoms action game Lost Planet: Extreme Condition offers a different solution  kill house-size spiders and suck out their glowing orange blood to power advanced weapons that can be used to kill even bigger spiders.

title: Um, Uh, Like Call in the Speech Coach
description: Whether to appear more confident, better organized or to stop the ums, entrepreneurs are realizing good voice and presentation skills can help them come into their own and even compete against larger competitors with big marketing budgets.

description: Calling himself the dark horse in the crowded field of candidates, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, announced this morning that he is running for president.

description: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend on Friday about a walk in the East Village with Robert Stone, who has a new memoir about the 1960s, Prime Green, misstated the history of Andy Warhols connection with the Polski Dom, or Polish Home, on St. Marks Place. The nightclub Warhol opened there, in 1966, was called Dom, not the Electric Circus. (The Electric Circus, not run by Warhol, opened at the site in 1967.)

title: The Real Disaster
description: President Bush told Americans last night that failure in Iraq would be a disaster. The disaster is Mr. Bushs war, and he has already failed. Last night was his chance to stop offering more fog and be honest with the nation, and he did not take it.

description: IT is common to see advertisements that offer to meet or beat any price. The most natural interpretation of such offers is that they signal strongly competitive behavior.

title: Manhattan: Reducing Animal Euthanasia
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday that it would spend $2.4 million in an effort to reduce the euthanasia of stray animals in Austin, Tex.; Gulfport-Biloxi, Miss.; Philadelphia; and Tampa, Fla. Edwin J. Sayres, the president of the society, which is based in Manhattan, said it would commit $600,000 in each of the cities over three years to develop collaborations between public and private agencies.

title: N.J. High School Mourns Students Killed in Crash
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 11  Grief came to school today at Freehold Regional High School as students mourning three students who were killed in an after-school automobile accident on Wednesday filed into a building staffed with grief counselors as well as teachers and administrators.

Then came the partnerships between hotels and high-end brands  Molton Brown, LOccitane, Remde  that had guests salivating and fighting back thoughts of raiding the housekeepers cart.

title: In Germany, a Hitler Comedy Goes Over With a Thud
description: BERLIN, Jan. 10  Perhaps it was inevitable that the first German-made film comedy about Hitler would get a mixed reception in Germany  a country still haunted, six decades after the fall of the Third Reich, by the mystery of how this strange madman once held it in thrall.

title: A Mideast Pawn, and a Fathers Agony
description: MITZPE HILA, Israel  Noam Shalit takes in the view of freezing rain and wind pounding olive groves of the Galilee outside his living room window and speaks of the danger of delay  more than half a year since the warm summer day when his son, Gilad, a young Israeli corporal, was captured by Palestinian militants in a cross-border raid and trundled into the Gaza Strip.

title: Comedy Writer, Litigant, Frog Lover
description: A man is more than the sum of his eccentricities, but the equation for Jack Winter is particularly complicated. For someone who spent hours a day talking on the phone, had an enormous range of acquaintances and wrote a memoir (The Answer to Everything, self-published), he was, to many, an enigma.

title: Dispute Erupts Over Flag Decals on the Lockers of Firefighters
description: The image still resonates in the minds of New Yorkers: three city firefighters raising an American flag over the smoldering ruins of ground zero. Now the flag, which has become inexorably tied to New York firefighters as symbols of courage since the 9/11 attacks, has become a wedge between the Fire Department and the citys largest fire union.

title: Keeping a Girl Off the Streets, and on the Road to Success

There are drugs on the streets of their Bronx neighborhood, said Ms. Burton, 70. She lost her daughter to them and vowed not to lose her granddaughter, too.

title: For $7.93 an Hour, Its Worth a Trip Across a State Line
description: LIBERTY LAKE, Wash., Jan. 9  Just eight miles separate this town on the Washington side of the state border from Post Falls on the Idaho side. But the towns are nearly $3 an hour apart in the required minimum wage. Washington pays the highest in the nation, just under $8 an hour, and Idaho has among the lowest, matching 21 states that have not raised the hourly wage beyond the federal minimum of $5.15.

title: Storm Left New Orleans Ripe for Violence
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10  The storm of violence that has burst over this city since New Years Day can be traced in part to dysfunctional law enforcement institutions, aggravated by a natural disaster that turned the physical and social landscape of New Orleans into an ideal terrain for criminals.

title: Kodak Selling X-Ray and Medical Image Lines
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10  Eastman Kodak, as part of its struggle with the digital conversion of photography, said Wednesday that it would sell its X-ray film and medical-imaging equipment operations to an investment company, Onex of Toronto, for $2.35 billion in cash.

title: And Today, Work Begins on First Wall
description: It looks like nothing more than a 22-foot-long, 4-foot-wide hole in the ground. But today, when a 180-foot-tall crane lowers a gigantic steel cage down into the trench, construction will begin on the first section of a $174 million wall more than 1,200 feet long.

title: Shopping for a Villa, He Wound Up With a Village
description: Buonconvento, Italy

title: Michigan: University to Comply With Ruling
description: The University of Michigan acceded to a federal appeals court decision and said it would immediately comply with the states new ban on affirmative action in public education, employment or contracting. The Michigan ballot initiative banning preferences based on race or gender passed overwhelmingly in November and was to go into effect on Dec. 23. But the University of Michigan, together with Michigan State University and Wayne State University, went to court seeking a six-month delay, on the ground that they were midway through an admissions cycle. A federal district judge granted the delay on Dec. 19, but on Dec. 29, a federal appeals court ordered immediate compliance.

title: A Printer Meant to Produce Images That Last a Lifetime
description: Digital photographers and graphic designers with limited budgets will want to note Epsons replacement for its venerable 1280 ink-jet printer, introduced in 2000. The Stylus Photo 1400, which will reach the market early next month, will cost the same as the older model  $400  and will still use six inks, but they will be Epsons new Claria inks.

title: Senator Dodd May Be Joining Democratic Race for President
description: HARTFORD, Jan 10  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, is to announce on Thursday morning that he is running for president, some of his friends say.

title: Mets Are Near Multiyear Deal With Schoeneweis
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Jan. 10  The Mets were busy on two pitching fronts yesterday, welcoming an enthusiastic Pedro Martnez to the teams minicamp to check on his rehabilitation from shoulder surgery while closing in on a multiyear contract with Scott Schoeneweis, a versatile left-handed reliever.

title: Protecting Our Skin (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Bestows Medal of Honor on Fallen Marine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  In April 2004, Cpl. Jason L. Dunham, a Marine Corps recruit from a small town in upstate New York, did something extraordinary: he threw himself on an exploding grenade to shield two men in his unit as they battled insurgents on a road in Iraq, losing his own life.

title: Tax Cuts and Consequences
description: The tax system in the United States is supposed to mitigate inequality. But a recent report by Congresss budget agency provides fresh evidence that Bush-era tax cuts have done more to reinforce inequality than to redress it.

title: New Operas at the Met: What Works?
description: The Metropolitan Opera has to be discouraged by the mostly negative critical reactions to The First Emperor, Tan Duns ambitious opera, which had its world premiere at the house on Dec. 21. The good news for the Met, though, is that its run, through Jan. 25, is sold out, including this Saturdays matinee, to be broadcast on radio and in high-definition screenings at more than 100 movie theaters around the world. Could opera companies have better proof that todays audiences are hungry for new works?

title: Spitzer Vote Tally Is Slightly Lower in Official Count
description: In last Novembers election, which made Eliot Spitzer governor, the press and politicians made much of the size of his record victory. In the initial vote totals, based largely on unofficial election data and exit polls, Mr. Spitzer had about 70 percent of the vote.

title: Police Detective in Fatal Shooting Is Questioned by Prosecutors
description: The undercover detective who fired the first of 50 shots at a car driven by a groom-to-be, killing him and wounding two friends, was questioned yesterday by Queens prosecutors investigating the shooting, the detectives lawyer said.

title: Giants Need Some Players Who Are Pillars
description: In the State of the Giants address yesterday by the teams co-owners, John Mara and Jonathan Tisch, Mara mentioned how the players we have spoken to overwhelmingly supported retaining Tom Coughlin as coach. But the more serious issue is that none of those players resemble the locker-room pillars that made the Giants an elite pro football team in two glorious eras.

title: Maureen Orcutt, Early Woman Golfer and Sportswriter, Dies at 99
description: Maureen Orcutt, one of the nations outstanding golfers for almost a half-century and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, died Tuesday in Durham, N.C. She was 99.

title: A Shuffle at Paramount, and More to Come
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10  The resignation of the president of Paramount Pictures, Gail Berman, one of Hollywoods highest-ranking female executives, carried a message this week for those with a stake in the success of her boss, Brad Grey: The turmoil is not over.

title: China Says Its Trade Surplus in 2006 Climbed to a Record
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 10  Chinas trade surplus soared to a record $177.47 billion last year as exports continued to rise briskly, Chinas customs administration announced Wednesday night.

title: Inwood: Arrest in Robbery Attempt
description: A New Jersey man accused of being involved in a robbery attempt at an Inwood home in which a 9-year-old boy was shot through the eye has been arrested, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The man, Raseed Watson, 21, of Paterson, N.J., was extradited to Nassau County on Tuesday and arraigned yesterday on one count of first-degree robbery, the police said. The police said they believed that Mr. Watson fired the shot that injured the boy, John Henry Romano Jr., now 10, and expected to file additional charges against him. Investigators said Mr. Watson was one of three men who entered the Inwood home in September and engaged in a gunfight with the owner. A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested in the case in October, and a third suspect remains at large, the police said.

title: Staten Island: More Bad Smells
description: A foul odor reported yesterday over Staten Island, particularly at Curtis High School and in New Brighton, was identified by fire officials and the Department of Environmental Protection as gas fumes. No injuries were reported, but students could be seen covering their noses and mouths. Unlike the odors over Manhattan and New Jersey on Monday, believed to be mercaptan, a chemical added to natural gas that smells like rotten eggs, the Staten Island smell is believed to be petroleum-based, said Charles Sturcken, spokesman for the environmental department. The preliminary results in the field are that there is nothing hazardous in the air, he said. After the first reports of the odor about 2 p.m., officials sampled the air along the waterfront across from an industrial area of Bayonne, N.J. The source of the odor was not determined.

title: In 2 Pennsylvania Towns, Skepticism and Resignation
description: CLIFTON HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 11  Hunched over a beer with a crowd of other veterans at the American Legion here, Rocco Polidoro, said he is sure of one thing: the President Bushs plan to send some 20,000 more troops into Iraq will only make matters worse.

title: Murcer Says Brain Tumor Is Malignant
description: Bobby Murcer, a former Yankees outfielder and their longest-serving current announcer, said yesterday that a tumor removed from his brain during surgery on Dec. 28 was malignant. He did not describe his prognosis.

title: Apple Waves Its Wand at the Phone
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Judith Vladeck, 83, Who Fought for Womens Rights, Dies
description: Judith P. Vladeck, a prominent labor lawyer and ardent advocate of womens rights in the workplace, particularly on college campuses, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Transcript of President Bushs Address to Nation on U.S. Policy in Iraq
description: Following is a transcript of President Bushs address to the nation last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Barbaro Set Back by Damage to a Hoof
description: Barbaro was said to be resting comfortably last night after his months of slow, smooth recovery were interrupted by 36 hours of pain caused by damaged tissue in his left hind hoof.

title: Goldman and Canadian Firm in Deal for 13 Cable Channels
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10  CanWest Global Communications, a Canadian broadcaster and newspaper publisher, joined Goldman Sachs on Wednesday to buy Alliance Atlantis Communications, producer of CSI: Crime Scene Investigation and owner of 13 Canadian cable channels, for about 2.3 billion Canadian dollars (about $1.95 billion) in cash.

title: Bushs Speech Is Vindication for a General
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  After President Bush told the nation Wednesday night that he was ordering a rapid increase of American forces in Iraq, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki was not among the retired officers to offer instant analysis on television.

title: A Discreet Voice Recorder for Your 275-Hour Podcast
description: Podcasters and others in need of audio recordings no longer need to stick a microphone in their subjects faces. The Olympus DS-50 voice recorder has a clip-on stereo microphone that will pick up both sides of a conversation.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart on the Street Scene page of Business Day last Thursday that listed the leading merger and acquisition advisers misstated the value of the deals in 2006. For Goldman, Sachs, the sector leader, it was $1.088 trillion, not $108.8 trillion. For the industry as a whole, the value of the deals was $3.805 trillion, not $380.5 trillion. A corrected chart can be found online.

title: Democrats Plan to Fight Expansion of Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The new Democratic leaders of Congress on Wednesday accused President Bush of ignoring strong American sentiment against the war in Iraq and said they would build a bipartisan campaign against his proposed military expansion.

title: Bid to Secure Baghdad Relies on Troops and Iraqi Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  With his new plan to secure Iraq, President Bush is in effect betting that Iraqi leaders are committed to building a multisectarian state, and his strategy will stand or fall on that assumption.

description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 10  As President Bush challenges public opinion at home by committing more American troops, he is confronted by a paradox: an Iraqi government that does not really want them.

title: Belarus Signals Resolution in Oil Dispute
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10  Belarus announced Wednesday that it had reached a compromise with Russia to end a dispute that had shut a Russian oil pipeline to Europe since Monday, but the Kremlin did not confirm any agreement.

title: Carlo Ponti, Film Producer, Dies at 94
description: Carlo Ponti, the influential film producer whose vast body of work encompassed Italian realism, French New Wave and Hollywood fluff but who etched his name in popular legend by defying law and church to marry Sophia Loren, died on Tuesday in Geneva. He was 94.

title: E.W. Scripps Explores Options for Its Newspaper Holdings
description: Newspapers may have lost their luster for yet another media company.

title: AIDS Drug to Protect Fetus Is Safe for Infected Mothers, Study Finds
description: Women can take the anti-AIDS drug nevirapine to protect their unborn children without endangering their ability to undergo life-saving antiretroviral treatment later on, a new study has found.

title: A Soak to Remember
description: RACHEL LANG said she is happy when she is drawing a bath and laying out the luxuries that symbolize pure enjoyment. Who isnt? But what is unusual is that she does it for total strangers.

title: A Whole Lot of Thinking Going On
description: SHORT of a 20 percent markup! sign in the window, the owners of Project No. 8 have created one of the least inviting store facades in the city.

title: A New Focus on Delta Air as Deal Bait
description: Delta Air Lines, in such dire straits a year ago that its chief financial officer called it a company Im not sure we could have given away, is suddenly in great demand.

title: Moving Down the Road to Recovery
description: I WAS injured on a nighttime run on Oct. 10. I had run nine and a half miles two days before, which was long for me. Then, the night of my injury, I got lost trying to check out a 10 kilometer course and ran way too far. By the time I got back to my car, my left forefoot ached. The next day I could barely walk.

title: Threat and Harassment for New Jersey Towns First Black Mayor
description: SOUTH HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 10  Like a lot of mayors in small towns throughout New Jersey, Charles T. Tyson took office here on New Years Day with grand ambitions and little fanfare. But unlike most of them, Mr. Tyson started his term by trying to figure out who was threatening to kill him.

title: Canada: Stomach Virus Sweeps Quebec
description: Dozens of hospitals and nursing homes in Quebec are struggling to contain an epidemic of viral gastroenteritis. The illness is suspected to be a new strain of the Norwalk virus and causes fever, vomiting and diarrhea. Montreal has been hit the hardest, with 29 health care institutions having reported outbreaks. At least eight players and one coach for the Montreal Canadiens hockey team have also contracted the illness. Officials said they expected the number of cases to increase.

title: A Dance Fling to Salute the Soul Man
description: Dwight Rhodens hip and slinky Chapters has Broadway dance musical written all over it. The balance of the program presented by the Complexions Contemporary Ballet on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater was an up-and-down affair, with two of the most appealing dances coming from guest artists. But Mr. Rhoden, the companys chief choreographer and its founder with Desmond Richardson, has a promising thing going in Chapters, which celebrates the music of Marvin Gaye.

title: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
description: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the companys $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.

title: Still, the Question of Displaying the Names of 9/11
description: TO the dispute over how 2,979 victims names are to be inscribed and arranged at the World Trade Center memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg contributed an indisputable truth last month.

title: Bombings Hit Philippines on Eve of Conference
description: CEBU, the Philippines, Jan. 11  A series of terrorist bombings in the southern Philippines on the eve of the annual summit meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, has highlighted a growing need to address terrorism in the region, officials said today.

title: Excerpts and Audio: The Pellicano Case
description: Following are excerpts of calls between the private eye Anthony Pellicano and Kirk Kerkorians lawyer, Terry N. Christensen, about a legal fight with Kerkorians ex-wife, Lisa Bonder Kerkorian, as transcribed by The New York Times. Digital recordings of the calls were turned over last year by prosecutors to defense lawyers as part of the discovery process. Prosecutors said the recordings were recovered from Pellicanos computers. The recordings included date and time stamps placing them between March and May of 2002.

title: Celebration Continues, as Does Talk of Steroids
description: A day after being elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn reflected fondly upon their careers during a news conference at a Manhattan hotel yesterday. But for the second consecutive day, the issue of steroids, and Mark McGwire, arose, following them like a tin can attached to a car.

title: A Superpowered Defense, or a Chunk of Kryptonite at the Table?
description: As has been observed by many, if we all enjoyed X-ray vision, this game  not to mention life  would lose almost all of its appeal. But at the bridge table sometimes it is possible to play, or appear to play, as if one were blessed with Superman-style eyesight. The diagramed deal, which was played late last year on Bridge Base Online (www.bridgebase.com), gave East a chance to look as if he had just emerged from a phone booth with bulging muscles.

title: Television That's Rude, Crude, Hilarious and Only on the Web
description: Spending eight hours in residence on Comedy Centrals MotherLoad, the thousands of funny and free videos now offered on the channels Web site, closed the case on something thats been confusing me.

title: Malden Mills Returns to Bankruptcy
description: Malden Mills Industries, maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, less than four years after an earlier reorganization, and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million.

title: Nazi U-Boat Imperils Norwegians Decades After the War
description: FEDJE, Norway, Jan. 8  World War II was edging to a close as Kristoffer Karlsen peered from this rocky outcrop off Norways coast and saw what he took to be a huge explosion some way out to sea.

title: When Its O.K. to Run Hurt
description: JUST before the end of last year, a prominent orthopedic surgeon was stretching to lift a heavy box and twisted his back. The pain was agonizing. He could not sit, and when he lay down he could barely get up.

title: Eau de New York City
description: New Yorkers have spent the last few days getting sneering phone calls and e-mail from friends in distant places. Some recommended their favorite air fresheners or asked if we washed our socks. Others worried that this weeks big stink was a plot of some kind  perhaps terrorists, of course, since we always think that first now. But perhaps it was the work of somebody launching a fancy new oxygen atomizer: fresh air from the islands at only $5 a whiff.

title: Trade Deficit Drops for Third Consecutive Month
description: American companies sold more goods like airplanes, cars and precious metals overseas in November, helping to narrow the trade deficit for a third consecutive month.

title: Law Firm Employee Is Accused of Posing as Lawyer in Court
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 10  A man who prosecutors said had been representing clients of a prominent New York law firm for two years was arrested here on Wednesday and charged with impersonating a lawyer, state prosecutors said.

title: Talk to Her (or Him)
description: MARGARET SHAPIRO of the Council for Relationships offered this script for hammering out design disagreements using ideas gleaned from a program developed by Dr. Howard Markman, director of the Center for Marital and Family Studies at the University of Denver:

title: Former Official Is Said to Be a Focus of Lobbyist Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The former No. 2 official in the Interior Department has been notified by federal prosecutors that he will most likely be indicted for lying about his relationship with the corrupt lobbyist Jack Abramoff, people with knowledge of the investigation said Wednesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the corporate takeover battle emerging in Asia for Hutchinson Essar, the telecommunications company, misstated its revenue in American dollars in some copies for the four quarters ended in June 2006. It was $1.58 billion  not $12.38 billion, which is the amount of revenue in Hong Kong dollars.

title: Hurdles in Harvard Yard and the World Beyond
description: Louis Begleys latest novel, Matters of Honor, is a kind of pale, male version of Mary McCarthys novel The Group  moved from Vassar to Harvard, from the class of 1933 to the class of 1950-something. It is also devoid of McCarthys biting, satirical wit and keen eye for social distinctions; none of its central protagonists emerges as a compelling or even believable individual.

title: Wal-Mart Says Health Plan Is Covering More Workers
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nations largest employer, is expected to announce today that the number of workers enrolled in the companys health plan rose 8 percent last fall, the result of its introduction of cheaper insurance policies.

title: Florida Adopts Plan for Mentally Ill Inmates
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 10  About 300 mentally ill inmates in county jails throughout Florida will eventually be moved to psychiatric hospitals and residential centers for treatment after state lawmakers agreed on Wednesday to an emergency spending measure.

title: Firms Fret as Office E-Mail Jumps Security Walls
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10  Companies spend millions on systems to keep corporate e-mail safe. If only their employees were as paranoid.

title: The Computer With a TV, and a Family's Virtual Bulletin Board
description: The notion of a computer at the heart of every home gets a little bump with the multitasking Hewlett-Packard TouchSmart PC, unveiled at the Consumer Electronics Show this week as part of the introduction of the Windows Vista operating system from Microsoft.

title: Childrens Quality of Life Is on the Rise, Report Finds
description: Compared with a decade ago, Americas children appear to be marginally better off, according to a Census Bureau analysis. More are performing at grade level in school, more are taking lessons after class and on weekends and more parents  especially in black households  are imposing limits on television viewing.

title: Green Is the Color of Coaches Parachutes
description: If Florida Coach Urban Meyer is the type of fellow to watch his money roll in, then he has had plenty to admire since he took the job in 2004, and even more since his Gators won the national championship Monday.

title: Brooklyn: Arrest in Rape of Student
description: A man who works at an organization that collaborates with a school in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a teenage student, city school officials said. The man, Ivory Gordon, 24, of Brooklyn, was charged with rape, sex abuse and criminal sexual conduct, according to the office of Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools. The student, a girl attending the New Beginnings School, was assaulted several times on school premises and at Mr. Gordons home, according to Mr. Condons office. Mr. Gordon was suspended without pay on Monday from his job as a case manager at the Madison Square Boys and Girls Clubs Navy Yard clubhouse, said Joseph Patuleia, the organizations executive director. He said the city ran New Beginnings in the clubhouse under a contract.

title: Roberta Wohlstetter, 94, Military Policy Analyst, Dies
description: Roberta Wohlstetter, a military and foreign policy analyst whose work on the intelligence failures before the attack on Pearl Harbor was cited by the 9/11 commission, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Big Macs Big Night
description: ON a September night in 1998, Mark McGwire hit his 62nd home run of the season, breaking Roger Mariss record in front of a frenzied crowd in St. Louis. The moment was perfect.

title: Europe Union Proposes Cleaner, More Competitive Energy Market
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 10  European Union officials on Wednesday challenged governments to loosen their grip on national energy sectors, calling for a fresh wave of competition and investment in infrastructure and technology to ease dependence on powerful exporters like Russia and to combat global warming.

title: Knicks Look at the Sixers and See a Reflection
description: While unsure just yet where they are going, the Knicks got a long, hard look last night at where they have been. The team on the opposite bench lacked personality, direction and hope, and it was not so long ago that the Knicks suffered from a similar disease.

title: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  President Bush embraced a major tactical shift on Wednesday evening in the war in Iraq when he declared that the only way to quell sectarian violence there was to send more than 20,000 additional American troops into combat.

title: Jets Coaching Blueprint May Appeal to Dolphins
description: The Miami Dolphins are considering Brian Schottenheimer, the Jets offensive coordinator, for their head-coaching position left vacant when Nick Saban departed for Alabama. Yesterday they interviewed Schottenheimer, who is 33 years old, has never been a head coach and just finished his first season as a coordinator.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bushs Plan for Iraq Runs Into Opposition in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 President Bushs call to increase the American military commitment in Iraq ran into intense Congressional opposition Thursday from Democrats and from moderate Republicans who expressed profound skepticism.

title: A Tough Defense Lawyer Finds Hes in Need of One
description: Back in the 1980s, Paul W. Bergrin was a hard-hitting prosecutor in Essex County, N.J., who then became an assistant United States attorney in Newark.

title: Uncruel Beauty
description: HADASS KANTOROWICZ is on the fence. I eat less meat than I used to, said Ms. Kantorowicz, a self-described tantric healer who stopped in last week at Organic Avenue, a vegan general store in downtown Manhattan. Im definitely a lot more conscious than I used to be. While she appreciates the virtues of a meat-free diet, she stops short of embracing a vegan way of life, one that would ask her to forsake a croc-embossed bag or patent leather pumps. And Im not ready to wear hemp, she confided.

title: Opponents of Nevada Bomb Test Fault Impact Studies
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 10  A twice-postponed nonnuclear bomb test in the middle of the Nevada desert may face additional legal challenges over its potential to propel dangerous radioactive particles from the soil into the air over four states.

title: What's on Thursday Night
description: 10 P.M. (USA) NASHVILLE STAR Jewel and Cowboy Trent are hosts of the fifth season of this competition series in which the grand prize is a recording contract with Warner Music Group. Among the 10 contestants, chosen from 20,000 aspiring country musicians, are Angela and Zac Hacker, sibling competitors.

title: The Fog Over Iraq
description: If the Democrats dont like the U.S. policy on Iraq over the next six months, they have themselves partly to blame. There were millions of disaffected Republicans and independents ready to coalesce around some alternative way forward, but the Democrats never came up with anything remotely serious.

title: 3 at Florida-Based Hedge Fund Accused of Misleading Investors
description: The three principals of the KL Group in West Palm Beach, Fla., a firm that operated many hedge funds that collapsed in early 2005, were indicted yesterday, accused of orchestrating an extensive fraud that raised more than $194 million from at least 250 investors.

title: Drexel Claims a Spot on the Philadelphia Stage
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10  The Daskalakis Athletic Center, the Drexel Dragons cramped home gym, is a brisk four-block walk from the Palestra, the arena on the University of Pennsylvania campus that has been a basketball shrine for generations.

title: Rutgers Cant Get Shots to Drop Against Tough Syracuse Defense
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan 10  A young, rebuilding Rutgers team might have learned something Wednesday night. It probably is not going to win a jump-shooting contest.

title: Bangladesh Leader Declares State of Emergency
description: NEW DELHI, Friday, Jan. 12  The president of Bangladesh declared a state of emergency Thursday evening, suspending certain fundamental rights, imposing a nighttime curfew, and effectively postponing elections that were scheduled to be held in less than two weeks. He then resigned as the head of the caretaker government entrusted to run the polls, though he remains chief of state.

title: Ivory Coast: U.N. Extends Mandate of Troops
description: The Security Council voted to keep a 12,000-strong force of United Nations and French peacekeepers another six months to help disarm militias, prepare for elections and monitor a buffer zone and fragile cease-fire between the government-run south and rebel-held north. The Council has twice extended the term of President Laurent Gbagbo, which ran out in 2005, in anticipation of elections but has authorized a political opponent, Charles Konan Banny, the prime minister, to organize the vote, an arrangement that Mr. Gbagbo has challenged.

title: E-Mail Gaffe Publicizes Job Seekers in Albany
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10  Gov. Eliot Spitzer made his name, in part, on indiscreet e-mail messages, as any number of executives who were pursued by the attorney generals office in recent years can attest. Now his administration has sent out an indiscreet e-mail message of its own: An e-mail response to people seeking jobs as spokesmen included the e-mail addresses of 227 other job applicants, including reporters and local and city government employees.

title: A Dream Government Goes Sour in Thailand
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 10  When Thailands military-appointed government took office in October, it was hailed in the country as a dream team, with experienced Western-educated technocrats who had the rare quality of being above politics.

title: House Bans Smoking, and Few Complain
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Democrats banned smoking inside the House on Wednesday. Then they quickly congratulated themselves, squeezing as much symbolism out of the moment as they could.

title: Estonia: Monuments to Soviet Soldiers to Go
description: Parliament voted to allow the relocation of war memorials and soldiers graves, a move critics have said was intended to eliminate Soviet-era monuments. The countrys ethnic Russians, joined by lawmakers and officials in Russia, have denounced the proposal, saying it was meant to remove the Bronze Soldier, a monument in the capital, Tallinn, to the Red Army soldiers who died in World War II, as well as other Soviet objects. For many in Estonia, absorbed into the Soviet Union during the war, the monuments symbolize occupation and totalitarianism.

title: Irreconcilable Interiors: When Mates Dont Match
description: SANDI SLONE and Bruce Ehrmann have been a love story for 25 years. She is a painter, he is a newspaper and television reporter turned real estate broker. They met in Harvard Square one afternoon  she had a show nearby, he was meeting a friend  and they have been together ever since. Where she is dainty and precise, he is expansive, voluble and quick to self-criticism. Their rapport is terrific, an affectionate, Nick-and-Nora-style back-and-forth, honed and polished to a glittering sheen.

title: Solution Appears Near for Oil Tariff Dispute
description: Top stories from Russian newspapers on Thursday.

title: Ex-Counsel to Settle Suit
description: Comverse Technologys former general counsel, William F. Sorin, will pay $3.1 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations he conspired with the companys former chief executive, Jacob Alexander, to backdate stock options.

title: Wars Rorschach Test
description: Providence, R.I.

title: Eagles' Andrews Loses Weight and Gains Finesse
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8  Each week, the Eagles players have a culinary ritual called Junk Food Friday. The problem, guard Shawn Andrews said, is that Junk Food Friday too often became Junk Food Saturday, Junk Food Sunday and Junk Food Monday.

title: Kansas: City to Demolish Killers House
description: The mayor of a Wichita suburb said the city planned to tear down the house where Dennis Rader, known as the B.T.K. serial killer, lived for 25 years while he carried out a string of murders. The suburb, Park City, bought the house from Mr. Raders wife for just under $60,000 and plans to demolish it in the next month, Mayor Dee Stuart said. The property will be converted into an entry to an existing city park, Ms. Stuart said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about cellphones and other small devices that take on desktop computers functions referred incorrectly to four officials from Oqo, which makes a pocket-sized computer. While the four pictured are executives, only three were among its founders. Bob Rosin, second from right, is the senior vice president for marketing and alliances and joined the company later.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a controversy over a national sweepstakes awarding a $25,000 savings bond to the first American baby born in 2007 gave an erroneous birth weight in some copies for a Chinese-American girl, born in Manhattan, who was disqualified because her mother was not a legal resident. The girl, Yuki Lin, weighed 6.5 pounds, not 6.5 ounces. (The sponsor of the sweepstakes, Toys R Us, has since reversed its decision and awarded Yuki and two other babies born shortly after midnight $25,000 each.)

title: To Say Bon Apptit, Oui or Non
description: PARIS

title: God, Mom and Country: A Filmmakers Odyssey
description: You are a young documentary filmmaker with a reputation for capturing politicians antics. In a deliberate departure from politics, your latest film is a road trip into the world of evangelical Christians that includes a drive-through church, a Christian wrestling federation, a stand-up Christian comic, an evangelical Elvis and a biblical miniature golf course complete with the empty tomb of Jesus.

title: Weapons Raids in Somalia After Violent Night
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 10  Mogadishu exploded in violence on Wednesday morning after unknown insurgents attacked a transitional government barracks during the night and soldiers responded by sealing off large swaths of the city, searching house to house for guns.

title: The Dome Gains Weight and Settles Down
description: BRUCE NELKIN decided in the 10th grade that he would someday live in a geodesic dome, after seeing a picture of one in a science book. It looked like something out of Star Wars,  Mr. Nelkin said. I thought it was the coolest thing Id ever seen, and I said to myself, When I grow up Im going to build one of those.

title: White House Is Opposed to New Bill on Stem Cells
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The Bush administration jumped back into the bitter debate surrounding embryonic stem cell research on Wednesday, urging lawmakers to vote against House legislation to expand such research and calling for a new focus on scientific studies that would not harm embryos.

title: Lawyer Gave Information to Kerkorian
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10  When Kirk Kerkorians longtime lawyer was indicted on wiretapping and conspiracy charges last February in the federal investigation of the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano, the billionaire investor was mentioned almost as an afterthought.

title: Queens: Man Charged in Traffic Dispute
description: A man whose brother was shot and killed late Tuesday by an off-duty state corrections officer during a traffic dispute was charged yesterday with second-degree assault, the police said. The man, Leroi Kenner, 45, and his brother, Chris Kenner, 36, both of Queens, attacked the officer, Emilio Maldonado, 29, after he honked at them near La Guardia Airport when they failed to accelerate after their traffic light turned green, the police said. According to a witness, the police said, the men punched the officer in the face through an open car window. Then, realizing that he was an officer, they shouted, Shoot the cop, shoot the cop. According to the witness, the police said, one of the brothers reached for his waistband as if to retrieve a gun, and the officer shot once, striking Chris Kenner in the torso. He was taken to a Elmhurst Hospital Center, where he died. The investigation is continuing, but Officer Maldonado has not been charged. A spokeswoman for the Department of Correctional Services, Linda Foglia, said Officer Maldonados use of his weapon appeared to be proper procedure.

title: To Counter Irans Role in Iraq, Bush Moves Beyond Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  In promising to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, President Bush returned Wednesday night to a strategy of confrontation in dealing with Tehran, casting aside what had been a limited flirtation with a more diplomatic approach toward it.

title: Chvez Begins New Term Vowing Socialism
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 10  President Hugo Chvez was sworn in to a new six-year term at a ceremony here on Wednesday in which he described Jesus as the greatest socialist in history and pledged to speed Venezuelas metamorphosis into a Socialist country.

title: Residential Sales: New York
description: Manhattan

title: Sales of Sonys PlayStation 3 Fall Short in Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 10  The first results are out in the hotly contested market for video game consoles in Japan, and so far, the results do not look too promising for Sony and its much-promoted PlayStation 3.

title: Announcing a New Iraq Policy
The Ultimate iPhone Frequently Asked Questions
description: Wow. Predictably, the torrent  and I do mean torrent  of iPhone commentary from the citizens of the Web is practically outflooding spam this week. Most of it comes from people whose shirt fronts are practically drenched in drool. Plenty is negative and bitter.

title: The Apple of Their Eyes
description: Judging from the first bunch of comments we got about the iPhone, Mr. Jobs has another hit on his hands.

title: William Boyd Novel Honored
description: William Boyds Restless has won the new Costa prize for novels, previously known as the Whitbread Novel Award. Mr. Boyd, who won the Whitbread First Novel Award for A Good Man in Africa (1981), will receive 5,000 (about $9,700) and become eligible, with winners in four other categories, for the 2006 Costa Book of the Year prize, to be announced in London on Feb. 7. The awards honor books of the last year by writers based in Britain and Ireland. Restless, published in the United States by Bloomsbury, tells of an aging British woman who reveals to her daughter that she was a counterintelligence operative.

title: Starbucks Backs a Book
description: Starbucks has made its second book selection, and its no Mitch Albom. A Long Way Gone by Ishmael Beah, a memoir of that first-time authors life as a child soldier in war-ravaged Sierra Leone, will be sold in about 6,000 Starbucks stores beginning on Feb. 15, the company plans to announce today. Mr. Alboms For One More Day, the sentimental novel that inaugurated the companys book-sale program, has sold roughly 92,000 copies in Starbucks stores since going on sale on Sept. 26. Comparing the two titles, Ken Lombard, the president of Starbucks Entertainment, said A Long Way Gone was opposite in terms of the type of book, but consistent with our overall strategy of quality books. The company, he added, is convinced our customers are going to love this. Beginning next month, Mr. Beah will give readings at Starbucks in 10 cities. A Long Way Gone is published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Senator Barbara Boxer and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice
description: The following is the exchange between Senator Barbara Boxer and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice during the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Iraq.

title: Not Steroids, But for Bonds, a Bitter Pill Is Uncovered
description: On the heels of home run slugger Mark McGwires snub by the Baseball Writers Association of America for his first ballot election to Cooperstown  largely due to swirling suspicions relating to steroid use during his career  The New York Daily News reports this morning that San Franciscos Barry Bonds, who ranks No. 2 on baseballs career home run list, tested positive for amphetamine use in 2006.

title: Another Aircraft Odyssey for Warburg Pincus
description: For the second time since 2003, Odyssey Investment Partners is selling an aircraft parts maker to a rival buyout shop, Warburg Pincus. A Warburg Pincus portfolio company, TransDigm Group, said late Tuesday it would acquire Aviation Technologies, a Seattle parts producer, from Odyssey for $430 million in cash. Warburg Pincus bought TransDigm itself from Odyssey for $1.2 billion in June 2003, producing nearly a 300 percent gain on a $100 million equity investment for Odyssey in five years.

title: Former Fastclick Executives Open Venture Capital Firm
description: Two former executives at an online advertising company, Fastclick, have launched Great Pacific Capital, a locally focused venture firm based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Managing partner Dave Gross, the founding chief executive of Fastclick, told The Deal.com the firms first fund, Great Pacific Capital Partners I, had not yet closed, but that it would be capped at less than $50 million. In addition to putting in their own money, Mr. Gross and co-founder Rusty Reed have tapped primarily individuals in the region for funds, although Mr. Gross said other high-net-worth individuals from elsewhere could contribute as well.

title: New Chateaux for London Bankers?
description: Property in France, the United States and Italy is topping the shopping lists of bankers in Londons City this bonus season, with many putting down large deposits to reserve their second homes without even bothering to view the house, according to a report in The Guardian.
