About 51 percent of City bankers plan to invest in overseas property in 2007, according to a poll by Populus for the property agency PURE International, with France topping the list with 28 percent, followed by the United States with 21 percent.

title: Icahn on Chiefs, Morons and Leased Jets
description: Earlier this week, several blogs and the New York Post picked up a funny and harrowing anecdote about the billionaire financier Carl Icahn that appeared in a profile in Avenue magazine: Aboard his leased aircraft, the activist investor (or corporate raider as he was known in the 1980s) had just finished instructing Apollos Leon Black on the virtues of leasing jets as compared to buying them when he saw smoke coming from the engine.

title: The Unvarnished Reality of the Holocaust
description: The timing may be coincidental, but for perspective on the hanging of Saddam Hussein it would be difficult to do better than a viewing of Verdict on Auschwitz, a stark, emotionally draining documentary on the trial in Frankfurt of 22 defendants accused of being part of the Nazi death machine.

title: Kerkorian Caught Up in Pellicano Wiretapping Case
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who controls MGM Mirage and led a failed bid to push General Motors into an alliance with Nissan and Renault, is more deeply involved in the federal case against the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano than previously known, according to The New York Times. The Times has tapes of telephone conversations between Mr. Pellicano, who is currently in jail awaiting trial, and Mr. Kerkorians long-time lawyer that suggest that Mr. Kerkorian was aware that the private detective was listening in on his ex-wifes conversations.

title: Goldman and CanWest Win Alliance
description: CanWest Global Communications and the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs said late Wednesday that they had reached a deal to acquire Alliance Atlantis for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($2 billion). Under the terms of the long-anticipated takeover, CanWest will put down just 132 million Canadian dollars to gain control of the companys specialty cable television channels valued at 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail.

title: Personal Foul on Belichick
description: For those who havent seen it, Bill Belichick has drawn criticism for mashing a camera into a photographers face while trying to reach Eric Mangini for their postgame meeting Sunday.

title: Arcelor Mittal Wont Force Dofasco Sale
description: the steelmaker Arcelor Mittal on Wednesday said it would not take legal action to force the sale of Dofasco of Canada to Germanys ThyssenKrupp, leaving Dofascos ownership unchanged for now. During Mittal Steels contentious acquisition of Arcelor last year, the company pledged to sell the Dofasco unit to ThyssenKrupp if the merger was successful. But Arcelor, in a bid to stymie the Mittal bid, put 89 percent of Dofasco into a Dutch legal entity, called a stichting, to prevent its sale.

title: Accountant Pleads Guilty in KPMG Shelter Case
description: A California accountant pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges of conspiracy, tax fraud and obstructing a federal investigation, and pledged to help prosecutors as they conduct a widening criminal investigation of questionable tax shelters. The accountant, Steven Michael Acosta, the fourth person in the inquiry to plead guilty, is a relatively minor figure in the investigation, which has led to the indictment of 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. The inquiry has also ensnared Deutsche Bank, Germanys largest bank, and other banks, accounting, law and investment firms.

title: Malden Mills Returns to Bankruptcy
description: Malden Mills Industries, the maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, less than four years after an earlier reorganization, and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million. Gordon Brothers, a Boston-based firm that advises restructuring companies, will also assume an unspecified amount of debt. Any sale of the company, which employs 835 workers, is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.

title: Former Comverse Counsel to Settle Suit
description: Comverse Technologys former general counsel, William F. Sorin, will pay $3.1 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations he conspired with the companys former chief executive, Jacob Alexander, to backdate stock options. Mr. Sorin will forfeit $1.7 million in profit, plus $818,000 in interest, and will pay a $600,000 fine, according to an agreement filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. He played a critical role in backdating options at Comverse, the worlds biggest maker of voice-mail software, the agency said.

title: Grassso Should Keep Pay, Lawyers Argue
description: Attorneys for the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso, argued Wednesday that Mr. Grasso had fulfilled his fiduciary duty to the exchange and should be allowed to keep his $187.5 million compensation package. [He acted] as a reasonably prudent person would act, Gerson A. Zweifach, a Washington D.C.-based partner at Williams & Connolly, who represents Mr. Grasso, said in oral arguments before a New York appeals court panel.

title: Identity Theft Charge in H.P. Spying Case
description: A private investigator accused of posing as a journalist to read the reporters private phone records as part of the boardroom spying scandal at Hewlett-Packard was charged Wednesday with federal identity theft and conspiracy charges. The investigator, Bryan Wagner, is accused of using the Social Security number of the unidentified journalist to gain access illegally to the phone logs, according to the criminal charges filed by a United States attorney, Kevin V. Ryan, in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif.

title: EBay Will Buy StubHub for $310 Million
description: EBay said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the online ticket reseller StubHub for $310 million to bolster its share in the multibillion-dollar market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.

title: 3 at Florida-Based Hedge Fund Accused of Misleading Investors
description: The three principals of the KL Group in West Palm Beach, Fla., a firm that operated many hedge funds that collapsed in early 2005, were indicted Wednesday, accused of orchestrating an extensive fraud that raised more than $194 million from at least 250 investors. The three, Won Sok Lee, Yung Bae Kim and his brother Jung Bae Kim, who was also known as John B. Kim, are accused of promoting the KL hedge funds as successful, when, in fact, some of the funds suffered losses every quarter of their existence.

title: Group Considers $38 Billion Bid for Equity Office
description: The biggest leveraged buyout in history may get even bigger. A consortium of investors is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, The New York Times reported. The bid may not happen, but if it does, it would challenge the record-setting deal that Equity Office and the Blackstone Group agreed to in November.

title: Satellite Radio Merger Talk Gets a Lift from Citigroup
description: A possible merger of XM Satellite Radio Holdings and its rival, Sirius Satellite Radio, snagged another believer Wednesday when a Citigroup analyst raised her price target on XM. Shares of the company made a double-digit leap Wednesday after the analyst, Eileen Furukawa, lifted her 12-month price target on the company to $21 from $16 a share, telling clients that she believed a merger between the two companies could happen before the fall.

title: Deephaven Adds Shine to Knight Capital
description: Doom and gloom surrounded hedge funds last year as lawmakers threatened increased regulation and several high-profile players were blown out, but at least one bright spot for fans of the unregulated pools of capital has emerged. A stellar fourth quarter by Deephaven Capital Management will likely incresae earnings of the broker Knight Capital Group, which owns the $4 billion hedge fund firm, according to an analysts report.

title: Scripps May Spin Off Newspapers
description: Newspapers may have lost their luster for yet another media company. E. W. Scripps, the parent company of The Rocky Mountain News, The Commercial Appeal in Memphis and 18 other dailies, told an investor conference Wednesday that it was exploring separating its newspaper business from its more profitable cable television and syndication ventures.

title: President Bush's Speech Analysis
A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
description: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the companys $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.

title: A New Focus on Delta Air as Deal Bait
description: In fighting off a hostile offer from one rival, it seems Delta Air Lines has been talking about linking up with another. As US Airways increased its unsolicited merger bid to $10.2 billion Wednesday, reports said that Delta has been holding talks with Northwest Airlines and United Airlines about a possible combination with either of those carriers, according to reports. Discussions between Delta and Northwest, both of which filed for bankruptcy the same day in 2005, have apparently been occurring regularly for weeks. A Northwest bid would probably be preferable to Delta managers because the two airlines route networks overlap less than with Delta and US Airways, leading to fewer grounded planes, if any.

title: Kelso Gets Global Geophysical Stake
description: Kelso and Company is investing $140 million in Global Geophysical Services in a deal that is expected to give the buyout shop a substantial minority stake in the energy services business, Moodys Investors Service said. Global Geophysical. which also has offices in Lima, Peru, Boumerdes, Algeria, and Buenos Aires, provides hydrocarbon reservoir location services to oil and gas exploration and production companies via three-dimensional seismic-mapping services.

title: Software Maker Nimsoft Raises $10.3 Million
description: Nimsoft, a Norwegian infrastructure software maker, raised $10.3 million from JMI Equity of San Diego and Oslo-based Northzone Ventures. The company will use the venture funding to increase sales and marketing of products in the fast-growing service-level management market.

title: Madison Dearborn Sells Pizza Chain
description: Madison Dearborn Partners has sold Peter Piper Pizza, a restaurant chain, to Acon Investments for an undisclosed price, TheDeal.com reported. Peter Piper said its annual revenue is expected to exceed $200 million in 2007.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Said to Be Near Cap in $16 Billion Fund
description: Contributing to a record-breaking fund-raising year in 2006, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has now closed on $16.1 billion for its newest buyout fund, according to LBO Wire. The New York-based buyout shop has yet to hold a final closing for the fund, KKR Associates 2006 Fund LP, which has a cap of $16.625 billion, the report said.

title: Ameriquest Looks for Hedge-Fund Buyer, Reports Say
description: Ameriquest, the largest subprime mortgage lender in the United States, may be sold to a bond hedge fund as it and its competitors face an increasingly difficult business environment, reports said. J.P. Morgan Securities, which owns the lender, has approached several buyers recently, including Ellington Capital Management, a $4.5 billion fund with a specialty in hedging mortgage credit risk. Sources told The New York Post that Ellington executives have not yet decided if they want to receive an offering circular. A price has not been given.

title: The War at Home: The Morning After
description: In the lead up to the presidents speech, there had been a lot of debate about the distinctions between surge and escalation, with opponents of President Bushs expected troop increase arguing that surge misleadingly implied a short-term infusion. But when Mr. Bush spoke last night, he did not imply that the over 20,000 additional troops going to Iraq would be there briefly.

title: AirTran Raises Midwest Offer to $345 Million
description: Just after US Airways bumped up its unsolicited bid for Delta Air Lines, AirTran Airways has applied the gas to its own efforts to acquire Midwest Air Group. AirTran, a discount airline based in Orlando, Fla., raised its bid 19 percent, to $345 million Thursday, making the offer directly to shareholders and putting pressure on Midwest Airs management. Last month, Midwest rejected AirTrans initial offer of $290 million as too low, and on Wednesday, the airline unveiled a plan to add routes and update its fleet to help convince shareholders it should remain independent.

title: A Portrait of Lives Transformed by Trauma
description: Abduction: The Megumi Yokota Story is an engrossing nonfiction detective tale about the 13-year-old girl of the title, who vanished on the way home from school in Niigata, Japan, in 1977. But it also succeeds as a thumbnail review of a painful chapter of Asian history, and as a portrait of lives transformed by trauma.

title: A Cry From Guantanamo
Living With Pain
description: After Lorraine Kipper fell behind in her rent, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund provided her with $300.

title: IRS Digs Into Swag
description: Defamer points out that the IRS is not above rummaging around in gift bags when it comes to looking for loot. But this year, the tables at the Golden Globes will be laden with food, not tons of merch.

title: The Hill: Congress vs. White House
description: Guaranteeing that the presidents speech will not be the last word on his new strategy, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has been summoned to the Capitol today, and she is scheduled to appear before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this morning and the House Foreign Affairs Committee this afternoon.

title: Heavy Lies the Crown
description: Gail Berman, Brad Greys handpicked president of Paramount Studios, is out and the studio has announced an executive overhaul.

title: Pellicano: The Sequel
description: Its sort of hard to get worked up about the implications of various pre-Oscar awards when a real-life drama seems deeper and darker than most of the movies out there.

title: Coughlin Caricature
description: Tom Coughlin is the first coach to lead the Giants to two straight playoff appearances since Bill Parcells. He is a hard worker and a good man.

title: EMI Group Said to Dismiss Its Music Chief
description: In an unexpected shakeup, the British music giant EMI Group has sacked its recorded music chief, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company, according to executives briefed on the plan.

title: Turner Warms Up to Solar Venture
description: Following on a pledge by Californias governor to increase solar-energy production, the outspoken billionaire Ted Turner has partnered with Dome-Tech Solar of New Jersey to create a solar-energy venture to address the states power needs. Mr. Turner and Dome Tech intend to make the venture, DT Solar, one of the biggest solar power system integrators in California. Financial terms of the venture were not disclosed, but Dome-Techs chief operating officer told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Turner wont be a passive partner.

title: Picking Apart Bushs New War Plan
description: President Bushs latest plan for Iraq has the feel of an overdue high school book report, says the Los Angeles Times editorial page. It looks nice, reads well and is persuasive in parts. If only he had handed it in on time. Its editorial concludes:

title: Julius Baer Sells Fixed-Income Unit in M.B.O.
description: The management of Julius Baers fixed income investment boutique in London bought the $9 billion unit, less than two years after Julius Baer bought it when it acquired the global asset management operation from UBS. The division, now Augustus Asset Managers, will continue running hedge funds for Julius Baer and intends to expand in the United States. The first task for the unit and its new nonexecutive chairman, Howard Carter, will be to right a listing ship in which its two flagship funds generated anemic returns in 2006.

title: Bushs Belligerence Toward Iran and Syria
description: Several writers think President Bush buried the lede in his address to the nation last night. We will interrupt the flow of support from Iran and Syria, Bush said midway through the speech. William M. Arkin, who writes the Early Warning blog for The Washington Post, says this was the real news of the night: If theres anything in the President Bushs remarks tonight that we didnt already know or didnt anticipate him saying militarily about Iraq, it is his evident willingness to go to war with Syria and Iran to seek peace.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Dodd In, All the Way
description: Senator Chris Dodd has held the status of potential presidential candidate for years. So now that hes finally decided to go for it, hes going straight for it, skipping the exploratory committee to directly file as a candidate with the Federal Election Commission. He announced the move earlier today on Imus in the Morning, and later today hell head to Iowa, and then to South Carolina on Sunday.

title: A Tough Audience for a New Plan in Iraq
description: Reactions to the Presidents plan to send 21,000 more troops in an attempt to settle a still roiling Iraq  a gambit that was fleshed out a bit this morning in a press conference held by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert Gates  were developing across the land, and across the globe today.

title: Will Bondholders Play Spoiler in Blackstone Deal?
description: In a deal valued at $36 billion, quibbling over $100 million or so may seem absurd. But that is just what is happening in the background as Blackstone Group tries to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust in what would be the largest leverage buyout in history. A group of Equity Offices bondholders, including insurance giant American International Group, say they are being shortchanged under a proposed debt buyback that would facilitate the sale. And at least one analyst points to the dispute as one of the reasons that Equity Office may be put back in play.

title: Democrats Pick Denver as Convention Site
description: Its not exactly a New York: Drop Dead kind of moment, but the Democratic National Committee has decided to hold the partys 2008 nominating convention in Denver, according to Democrats familiar with the decision, heading West in rejecting a bid from New York to hold it there.

title: Dems Choose Denver
description: That will be the site of the next Democratic convention, as New York lost its bid to host amid Bloombergs concerns about raising money for it.

title: Albany: Full Ban on Smoking in Dorms
description: The State University of New Yorks trustees adopted a policy yesterday banning smoking in all dormitories on all SUNY campuses starting July 1. The policy will affect the remaining 9 percent of SUNY residence hall beds where smoking is currently permitted, primarily at Stony Brook, Morrisville and Buffalo State, according to a statement issued by the university board.

title: E-Mail Goof Postscript
description: The Spitzer administration sent this e-mail out to all the job-seekers who were inadvertently outed when their e-mail addresses were shared with other job-seekers:

title: Video: He Types for a Reason
Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "The Scene," "You Belong to Me" and "Purity."

title: Democrats Pick Denver for 08 Convention
description: It's not exactly a "New York: Drop Dead" kind of moment, but the Democratic National Committee has decided to hold the party's 2008 nominating convention in Denver, according to Democrats familiar with the decision, heading West in rejecting a bid from New York to hold it there.

title: The Van Picks Up Speed
description: Could Little Miss Sunshine be this years Crash? Jeffrey Wells offers a  theory to back up that view. This time of year, the plot not only thickens, it morphs by the hour.

title: Knock, Knock, Microsoft. Its SanDisk
description: Despite the Redmond, Wash., giants famously deep pockets and well-documented commitment to the success of its first digital music player, the Zune, Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the players release last fall. I overheard a litany of disparaging remarks (Its kinda clunky, for example) from would-be consumers shuffling past a Zune display at the Consumer Electronics Show yesterday.

title: Espionage Tip in Canada: Dont Keep the Change
description: Not only will those Canadian coins jam up the soda machine, now it appears they may be tracking your movements. At least thats a warning that came down from the Defense Department to American contractors, who were told to be on the lookout for Canadian change embedded with tiny radio transmitters.

title: Six Flags to Sell Seven Parks
description: Six Flags said Thursday that it had agreed to sell seven of its amusement parks for $312 million, and the news sent its stock on quite a ride. Shares of Six Flags, which is struggling with falling attendance at its parks, surged 9 percent in late-morning trading after the deal was announced. Six Flags was the subject of a bitter proxy battle in 2005, which resulted in a former ESPN executive, Mark Shapiro, being named chief executive. Since then, the company has sought to make its parks more family-friendly and to pay down some of its debt.

title: Soares and Cuomo, Part II
description: Attorney General Andrew Cuomo is moving quickly to claim the mantle of a corruption fighter, offering details at a morning press conference today on his plans to work closely with Albany County District Attorney David Soares on cases involving state officials.

title: Romney Adds Key G.O.P. Aide
description: Former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney has snagged another highly regarded Republican operative for his presidential campaign as the fight among the presidential campaigns for brains and bodies slogs on.

title: Mr. Craigslist at City Hall
description: Craig Newmark may be one of the most important players in New Yorks apartment rental market, but admits that most of what he knows about it he learns from watching re-runs of Seinfeld.

title: U.S. Official: Somalia Air Strikes Miss Their Marks
description: Updating the murky and chaotic story of American air strikes in Somalia, BBC News is reporting that an unnamed top U.S. official is now saying that none of the major al Qaeda targets in that country are thought to have been killed.

title: Whos Worried About Iraq?
description: Oil prices were falling fast before President Bush added tough talk on Iran to his speech last night, in ways that had commentators wondering if a military confrontation loomed.

title: Club Rules: Another View of G.E.s Plastics Auction
description: Is Goldman Sachs being unusually careful to avoid group bids as it shops General Electrics plastics unit to potential buyers? PE Week Wires Dan Primack says no. And he argues that The Wall Street Journal got it wrong earlier this week when it suggested that the sale process shows the influence of a recent Justice Department investigation into so-called club deals.

title: Families of Troops React to Bush Speech
description: Around the country, the wire services and local newspapers sought out the families of U.S. troops to get their reactions to President Bushs speech Wednesday. Heres a sampling:

title: The iPhone Up Close
description: An inside look at Steve Jobs's speech at the Macworld convention.

title: An Uncertain Somalia
description: The Times's Jeffrey Gettleman explains the challenges facing the Somali government after two weeks of violence.

title: Whither Private Equity? Fortune Asks Dealmakers
description: If a substantial number of private-equity deals do not eventually crash and burn, it would be a complete historical aberration, Steve Rattner of Quadrangle Group tells Fortune magazine, offering a completely reasonable but rather dire observation for the magazines 2007 outlook piece. Fortune asked players such as Mr. Rattner and the Carlyle Groups David Rubenstein to assess where things stand. Mr. Rubenstein repeated what seems to be a favorite phrase of his, telling Fortune, as he told the Financial Times in December, that private equity is the face of 21st-century American capitalism.

title: Blogtalk
description: Rather than get out of politics, Tom Suozzi may seek a third term as Nassau executive. [Capitol Confidential]

title: Teaching an Old Fuel New Tricks
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 10 column, My Favorite Green Lump.

title: The Ultimate iPhone Frequently Asked Questions
description: Wow. Predictably, the torrent  and I do mean torrent  of iPhone commentary from the citizens of the Web is practically outflooding spam this week. Most of it comes from people whose shirt fronts are practically drenched in drool. Plenty is negative and bitter.

title: The Ultimate iPhone Frequently Asked Questions
description: Video: The iPhone Up Close

title: eBays Latest Deal Looks Expensive, Analyst Says
description: EBay is paying a rich price for the online ticket vendor StubHub, Bear Stearns analyst Richard S. Peck suggests, writing in a research note that the deal could be dilutive to eBays valuation. His comments come as eBay is still trying to convince Wall Street that its $2.6 billion acquisition of the Internet-phone service Skype in September 2005, a deal whose final price tag could eventually hit $4.1 billion if bonuses are paid, was worth it.

title: Writers Guild Finds Funny Bone
description: The writers have spoken, or typed. In any case, they have voted and the Writers Guild Award nominees are out. Among them: Borat and Thank You for Smoking showed up in the adapted screenplay category; Little Miss Sunshine was cited as one of five original screenplay nominees. For a complete list of nominees, click here.

title: Tilting at Yahoo With a Web Site and Wiki
description: Eric Jackson is not happy that Yahoo has lost more than a third of its market value over the past year. But since he holds fewer than 1,000 shares of the Internet giant, he lacks the muscle of big-time activist shareholders such as Carl Icahn, Nelson Peltz or Ralph Whitworth, who have wrested concessions from the likes of ImClone Systems, Wendys International and Home Depot in recent months. Still, Mr. Jackson hopes to use the Internet to consolidate the anger of other small shareholders, attempting to become what TheStreet.coms Vishesh Kumar describes as a virtual activist investor.

title: Beckham to U.S.: Do You Care?
description: We take a short break from talking about football to talk about  football. The kind that has a professional team in Los Angeles.

title: Blogtalk: The Speech
description: President Bushs speech last night calling for 20,000 additional troops to help secure Iraq scored with the bloggers along predictable partisan lines.

title: Editorials Elsewhere
description: Heres a smattering of editorial opinions published today and Wednesday in newspapers around the country, including some in early primary states and others near military bases that will be deploying additional troops to Iraq.

title: Wynn Sues Insurer Over Pierced Picasso
description: The Picasso painting that nearly inspired hedge fund billionaire Steven Cohen to shell out $139 million has inspired something else: a lawsuit. Casino mogul Stephen Wynn, who accidentially poked a silver-dollar-size hole in the painting shortly after agreeing to sell it to Mr. Cohen, has sued insurer Lloyds of London over the damaged painting, called Le Reve. If the deal with Mr. Cohen had gone through, it would have been the most-expensive sale of a work of art in history. (What Mr. Wynn reportedly said after discovering he had torn the painting is not fit for a family blog.)

title: Portion Patrol
description: Some of the comments in response to a recent post about a book called The Skinny surprised me, because they took exception to diners who deliberately dont finish the food on their plates and to restaurants that dont scale portions down so that every morsel is guaranteed to be eaten.

title: Debating Troop Increases on Guantnamos Anniversary
description: Even as President Bush and his Cabinet set about trying to sell the idea of increasing troop levels in Iraq to a reticent public and a sometimes-hostile Congress today, protesters at the site of another touchstone in what critics consider to be the mishandled war on terror  the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba  rallied for its closure.

title: Senator Johnson: Health Update
description: The office of Senator Tim Johnson released an update on his condition this afternoon, saying the South Dakota Democrat was being moved to an inpatient rehabilitation unit at George Washington University Hospital, where he has been hospitalized since undergoing brain surgery last month.

title: Do You Get What You Pay For?
description: A bottle being filled directly from a barrel of Brouilly, Cru du Beaujolais, at Chez Denise in Paris. (Ed Alcock for The New York Times).

title: Spitzer Intervenes in LI Race
description: The race for Michael Balbonis Long Island Senate seat continues to percolate.

title: Post-Katrina Rejections Get Expensive for Insurance Companies
description: Sounding what must feel, at the very least, like a moral victory, if not quite yet a financial one (given that appeals are guaranteed) for families across the hurricane-ravaged Gulf Coast, a jury awarded $2.5 million in punitive damages to a couple in Mississippi who sued State Farm Fire and Casualty, after the company denied their post-Katrina claim.

title: The National Board of Review, Continued
description: The Baguette stayed up too late on Tuesday, the night of the National Board of Review Awards, so she is only now getting around to reporting on her conversation with Pedro Almodovar, whose Volver won for best foreign film.

title: Battle Lines Being Drawn
description: Its been a weighty day of debate over the war in Iraq, with hearings on Capitol Hill replete with Bush administration officials and senators and representatives announcing their positions, and in many cases denouncing President Bushs just-released plan to add nearly 22,000 troops in the field in Baghdad and the Anbar province.

title: Still the Most Powerful Form of Protest
description: Great lessons can still be learned from the work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  not just for Americans but for people staging protests in other countries.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Black Tiger'
description: A. O. Scott of The New York Times reviews a colorful Thai western that is a loving pastiche of classic film genres.

title: The Good Old-Fashioned Playground
description: New York City planners, blessed with a patch of prime real estate, an infusion of private funding and the participation of a hot architect, have hatched a plan to endow Lower Manhattan with a play space that will feature no swings, slides or monkey bars (too dangerous, as a New York Times story put it). Instead, this bold experiment in child-development-theory-made-real will have low wooden ramps, zones of sand and water, and enchanting, innovative playthings like foam blocks and gaskets.

title: Accounting Games
description: Companies are still playing games when they do their financials, and auditors are still allowing them to be played.

title: Duke Accuser Contradicts Herself and Says 2, Not 3, Attacked Her
description: Defense lawyers for three Duke lacrosse players made public a new account from the woman who has accused them of sexually assaulting her. She said two players, not three as she had originally alleged, attacked her in the bathroom at a team party in March. She also gave a new version of the timing and revised some of the mens descriptions.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a proposal by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to extend health care coverage to all of Californias residents misstated a requirement for insurers. They would have to contribute 85 percent of premiums to health care services, not 85 percent of profits. The article also referred incorrectly to the precedent for universal coverage. California would be the fifth state, not the fourth, to try near universal coverage. (Besides Maine, Massachusetts and Vermont, Hawaii has also tried.)

title: Southeast Asians Consider Pact Against Terrorism
description: CEBU, the Philippines, Jan. 11  Ten Southeast Asian countries meeting here are hammering out a regional antiterrorism agreement, officials said Thursday, the day after a series of terrorist bombings in the southern Philippines underscored the need for such a measure.

title: German Leaders Status Grows as Voice of Europe
description: BERLIN, Jan. 11  When Angela Merkel was sworn in 14 months ago as Germanys chancellor, the first woman to hold the post, she seemed less a phenomenon than a fluke  squeaking into office amid predictions that her government would be hobbled by internal problems and might soon collapse.

title: Where Youll Find a Small-Town Feeling on the Big Island
description: LIKE many visitors to the Hawaiian Islands, Donna Rehling was smitten right away with the lush landscape, temperate breezes, indigo ocean and, of course, the near-perfect weather year-round. She even invested in a time share on Maui 14 years ago, so she and her family could revel in it all at least once a year.

title: Knicks Are Not Among Webbers Choices
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 11  Isiah Thomas could not hide his warm feelings and deep appreciation for Chris Webber  as a player, as a person and as a figure who could change the N.B.A.s playoff landscape this spring.

title: New York Loses Out to Denver in Quest for the 08 Democratic Convention
description: DENVER, Jan. 11  The Democratic Party chose Denver over New York on Thursday as the site for its next national convention, capping months of debate about which city had better logistics, deeper pockets and a more compelling backdrop to frame the partys message.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Skull Supports Theory of Human Migration
description: From a new analysis of a human skull discovered in South Africa more than 50 years ago, scientists say they have obtained the first fossil evidence establishing the relatively recent time for the dispersal of modern Homo sapiens out of Africa.

title: Russian Billionaire Detained in Prostitution Ring Inquiry
description: PARIS, Jan. 11  Mikhail Prokhorov, a billionaire often described as Russias most eligible bachelor, was detained during an investigation into a suspected international prostitution ring operating at an upscale ski resort, a French prosecutor said Thursday.

title: Steve Krantz, 83, Maker of TV Mini-Series, Dies
description: Steve Krantz, a producer and writer who pushed his wife, Judith, into starting her first novel at 48, then turned her signature sex and shopping best sellers into television mini-series, died on Jan. 4 in Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: Negotiating Lower Drug Prices
description: From all the ruckus raised by the administration and its patrons in the pharmaceutical industry, you would think that Congressional Democrats were out to destroy the free market system when they call for the government to negotiate the prices of prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries. Yet a bill scheduled for a vote in the House of Representatives today is sufficiently flexible to allow older Americans to benefit from the best efforts of both the government and the private drug plans.

title: Exchange Turns Into Political Flashpoint
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 12  A passing exchange during a Senate hearing on Thursday turned into a political flashpoint overnight as Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat, and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice accused one another of insensitivity in comments about motherhood and the war in Iraq.

title: Hackensack: Lawsuit in Police Shooting
description: The family of a 45-year-old man who was fatally shot last year by a New Jersey Park Police officer filed a wrongful-death suit yesterday in State Superior Court. The suit names the officer and several colleagues, the State of New Jersey and the Park Police. The man, Emil Mann, a member of the Ramapough Mountain Indians, had been at a barbecue in the woods of Mahwah on April 1 when the officer, Chad Walder, shot him twice without justification, the suit alleges. Officer Walder, who has said he fired in self-defense, and two other officers also delayed getting medical help to Mr. Mann, the suit says. A lawyer for Officer Walder, Robert Galantucci, said the shooting was justified. No criminal charges have been filed in the case, and the Bergen County prosecutors office has said the investigation is still open. Mr. Mann, who grew up on the mountain where he was shot, lived in Monroe, N.Y., and had three children.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article Wednesday about efforts by Massachusetts to extend health care coverage to all residents reversed the names in some copies of two people who helped an immigrant from Bangladesh sign up for insurance. Feroza Bashar, a translator, was at right, and Goretti Macedo of Cambridge Health Alliance was at left.

title: Administration Offers Plan to Ease Rules on Asylum
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  After months of pressure from lawmakers, conservative groups and advocates for immigrants, the Bush administration announced plans on Thursday to seek legislation that would provide relief to thousands of refugees and asylum seekers who have been inadvertently denied refuge because of antiterrorism laws.

title: State Farm Told to Pay Gulf Claim
description: A federal jury ordered State Farm insurance yesterday to pay a $2.5 million penalty for refusing to cover damages to a Mississippi couples house that was destroyed in Hurricane Katrina, throwing into question settlement talks intended to resolve hundreds of lawsuits filed after the 2005 storm.

title: Demand Outpaced Supply for New Game Consoles
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11  The Xbox 360 outsold the Wii, which outsold the PlayStation 3.

title: Iraq Dominates World Politics, Not Markets
description: As Washington squares off over Iraq, with President Bush warning of disaster if the United States withdraws and Democrats saying that another 20,000 troops will not reverse what has gone wrong, two questions come to mind:

title: Bush Threatens Veto of Medicare Drug Bill, but a Senator Is Seeking a Middle Ground
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  President Bush threatened on Thursday to veto legislation that would require the government to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies to obtain lower drug prices for Medicare beneficiaries.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture on Sunday of members of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, who protested the unseasonably warm weather by refusing to take a winter swim, carried an incorrect credit in some copies. It was by Andrea Mohin of The New York Times.

title: Gun-Slinging Cowboys in Colorful Thailand
description: There may be crazier movies than Tears of the Black Tiger, Wisit Sasanatiengs Thai cowboy melodrama of betrayal and forbidden love, but I cant think of one that is quite so mad about its own craziness. What is most startling is not Mr. Sasanatiengs compulsive, fetishistic assembly of bits and pieces of the movie past; this kind of pastiche has, over the past decade and a half, gone from novelty to clich. The source of the movies seductive appeal lies less in its vivid fakery  the mock vintage-Technicolor hues, the musical and visual quotations, the miasma of camp hanging in the air  than in its disarming sincerity.

title: 5th Defendant Pleads Guilty in Shelter Case
description: A former accountant pleaded guilty yesterday to one felony count of lying to federal investigators as part of a widening criminal inquiry into questionable tax shelters.

title: New Law in Poland Is Aimed at Former Secret Police Agents
description: PARIS, Jan. 11  Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski of Poland on Thursday promised a new law that would take aim at former secret police agents, excluding them from serving in numerous public posts and leaving many of them with reduced or no pensions.

title: G.I.s in Iraq Raid Iranians Offices
description: ERBIL, Iraq, Jan. 11  American troops backed by attack helicopters and armored vehicles raided an Iranian diplomatic office in the dead of night early Thursday and detained as many as six of the Iranians working inside.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about separatist rebel attacks in the northeast Indian state of Assam misstated its precise location. Assam borders several other Indian states and the kingdom of Bhutan; it does not border Myanmar.

title: Hussein Cousin Says He Ordered Executions
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 11  In the Baghdad courtroom where Saddam Hussein was sentenced to die in November, new testimony on Thursday featured a startling admission by his cousin Ali Hassan al-Majid, known to Iraqis as Chemical Ali.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the difficulty in filling city manager jobs misspelled the surname of the longtime manager of Charlotte, N.C., who announced her retirement. She is Pam Syfert, not Seyfert.

title: House Passes Bill Mandating Drug Price Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Defying a veto threat, the House today passed legislation requiring the government to negotiate with drug manufacturers to obtain lower drug prices for Medicare beneficiaries.

title: On the Speed Channel, the Lead Roles in a New Show Are Played by 2 Toyotas
description: TOYOTA feels the need ... the need for speed  Speed Channel, that is, as the automaker and cable network join forces for an unusual program in which the Toyota FJ Cruiser plays a starring role.

title: In TV Land, Barber Is Able to Run Free
description: A fantasy about the future employment of the in-demand former Giants running back Tiki Barber.

title: As States Innovate, Schwarzenegger Blurs Lines
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11  So, who is Arnold Schwarzenegger anyway?

title: Sugarbush Tries to Regain Its Buzz
description: THERE once was a mountain they called the Aspen of the East. It had boundless terrain, lavish dining, a pulsing nightlife and a clientele of gossip-page celebrities. Every Friday evening in winter, a chartered Greyhound bus called the Sugarbush Special would pull away from Park Avenue and the onboard party would be rocking by the time the bus rolled out of Manhattan.

title: Letters: Nuclear Past and Present
description: To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in Strange Love (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins, the once formidable planes are a shell of their former selves, their sawed-off fuselages lying sadly in the dust. What used to be terrifying has somehow become poignant, as if a great epoch had ended. I suppose we can find cathartic relief in the mummification of a Titan II missile, but this may be cold comfort. The United States has spent more than $5 trillion on nuclear weapons since 1940, and judging from the current administrations Nuclear Posture Review, which was made public in 2002 and calls for a complete revitalization of the countrys nuclear infrastructure, this spending is far from done. Dont be fooled by moth balls. Old nukes are like old rock stars  they never go away. Jeff Porter

title: No. 1 Gophers Keep Them on the Pond
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 11  The pull that the University of Minnesota mens hockey program exerts on many of the states top high school players is such that after Erik Johnson and Kyle Okposo were selected first and seventh in the N.H.L. draft in June, both chose to delay their pro careers in favor of playing for the Gophers.

title: Make Them Fight All of Us
description: Ive heard the presidents surge speech, and I have a reaction, an observation and some advice.

title: A 2-Month Debate on Iraq, Capped by the Big Push
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Even before the November elections, President Bush and his national security adviser, Stephen J. Hadley, were informally discussing what Mr. Hadley was calling the big push  whether it made sense to make a show of increased American force in Baghdad to take back the city.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the media company E.W. Scripps, and the possible sale of some of its newspapers, misattributed a quotation explaining the reason for the strategy. It was the chief financial officer Joseph G. NeCastro  not the chief executive Kenneth W. Lowe  who said: Clearly the most advantageous route is to separate the newspaper business in some fashion.

title: The Westin St. Maarten Dawn Beach Residences and the Star Tower
description: The Westin St. Maarten Dawn Beach Residences

title: Shiite Radicalism Could Fuel Wider Violence, Official Warns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The nations top intelligence official said Thursday that the spiraling violence in Iraq, along with Irans ascendancy in the Middle East, had led to a rebirth of Shiite Islamic radicalism that could fuel sectarian violence and destabilize nations across the region.

title: Meditation Retreats Calm Those Jangled Nerves
description: FINDING calm and clarity is a tall order for frenzied urbanites, but theres help  in the form of guidance, serenity and natural beauty  at meditation retreats. Buddhist, yogic or eclectic, most provide anxious beginning meditators with instruction and practice. Several are scheduled around the country in the next few weeks.

title: In the Company of Eakins
description: PHILADELPHIA  In art, as in love, you dont always know what youve got until it has one foot out the door. Thomas Eakinss Gross Clinic, as great as any American painting of the 19th century, was about to leave Philadelphia but will now stay in the city that has always been home to it.

title: Friends, Romans, Countrymen, Lovers, Haters, Murderers, Barbarians ...
description: On the season premiere of HBOs Rome, decline, fall and foul-smelling Visigoths seem just around the corner. Its true that the upheaval that followed Caesars assassination in 44 B.C. made life bleak and oppressive, but it was centuries before the empire turned really rotten to its core.

title: Tears Are Shed at the White House for a Marines Bravery in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  In April 2004, Cpl. Jason L. Dunham, an ordinary recruit from a small town in upstate New York, did something extraordinary: he threw himself on a grenade to shield two men in his unit as they battled insurgents on a road in Iraq.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,005 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Bush Speaks and Base Is Subdued
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 11  President Bush came to this Georgia military base looking for a friendly audience to sell his new Iraq strategy. But his lunchtime talk received a restrained response from soldiers who clapped politely but showed little of the wild enthusiasm that they ordinarily shower on the commander in chief.

title: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Arent Going Away
description: SOMETIMES it feels as if there is a red state-blue state divide when it comes to hedge funds.

title: Nice Night for a Norse Shout-Along (Bring Devil Horns)
description: They came to the B. B. King Blues Club & Grill on Wednesday night: two groups of traveling musicians, one from Sweden and one from Norway, both playing traditional Scandinavian music for an audience of connoisseurs. Religious sagas were retold, ancient Norse runes were evoked, festive costumes were worn. Who says Americans dont appreciate world music?

title: AT&T Prepares to De-Brand the Cingular Wireless Name
description: One of the biggest de-brandings in advertising history is to begin Monday when AT&T, now the sole owner of Cingular Wireless, starts changing all Cingular marketing to adopt the AT&T name.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Connections column on Monday, about music in the films of Alfred Hitchcock, misspelled the surname of a composer who worked with him. He was Miklos Rozsa, not Rosza.

title: Risk-Assessment Plan Is Withdrawn
description: The Bush administration yesterday withdrew a proposal to change the way federal agencies assess environmental hazards, health threats and other risks, after an expert panel declared that it was so scientifically flawed that it could not be rescued.

title: Pork, Peanut Butter and Security
description: Making his umpteenth pitch to Congress to provide more security money for New York City, Mayor Michael Bloomberg stated the obvious when he said that money to defend against terrorism should be divvied up based on an assessment of risks, not spread across the country like peanut butter. After all, his testimony to the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee echoed one of the key recommendations of the 9/11 Commission. The mayor estimated that more than $3 billion had been distributed in this lunatic way to date.

title: Giving Up a Republican Future to Work for a Democrat
description: MICHAEL A. L. BALBONI, the man who might have been New Yorks next Republican governor, or maybe Republican attorney general, is instead the man who gave up his Senate seat and any dibs on being a Republican candidate for statewide office, to run the homeland security team for Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a Democrat he barely knows. They are strange bedfellows, but they both say the politics involved are nonpartisan.

title: The Physical Pain of Spinal Disease Eclipses Povertys Mental Anguish
description: The dozen or so old cookie jars, all that remain of a collection, glisten on the living room shelves, each alive in its bright details: the fiery red of Lucille Balls hair, Howdy Doodys ruddy cheeks.

title: Texas: Two Parades for King Day
description: A federal judge in Houston has ruled that two competing organizations must both be allowed to hold parades on Monday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A lawsuit filed by the Black Heritage Society challenged a city ordinance that allows only one parade per day downtown, alleging infringements on freedom of expression. The city revised the ordinance in 2005, in part to deal with a continuing dispute between the society and the M.L.K. Grande Parade group, which had been given the parade permit. The city said it would review the ordinance before to returning to court in March in an effort to resolve the issue.

title: Forstmann Is Leader of the Pack at IMG
description: The financier Teddy Forstmann beckoned one of his public-relations executives to hold up a recent issue of Global People, a magazine published by Peoples Daily, the Chinese Communist Partys leading official newspaper.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend last Friday about Complexions Contemporary Ballet, which is at the Joyce Theater this week, misstated the date its engagement ends. It is Sunday; it did not end yesterday.

title: Executive Who Stirred Up Volkswagen Will Step Down
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 11  Wolfgang Bernhard, the hard-charging executive who pared costs at Volkswagen but ruffled the feathers of its labor unions and chairman, will leave the company as part of a broad shake-up of its managing board, the company announced Thursday.

title: Defense Chief Warns Against Failure in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told senators today that Iraqi government officials seem committed, finally, to meeting their obligations to secure their own country, and that an American failure there would be a setback of historic proportions.

title: Murder Trial Paints Portrait of a Family Torn by Strife
description: Wearing a black velvet coat and a patterned blouse, the 86-year-old mother of the dead woman looked birdlike and frail as she walked to the witness stand.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit filed by a pension fund over the proposed merger between Caremark RX and CVS misstated the amount of exit pay that Caremarks chief executive, Edwin M. Crawford, would receive if a rival bid was accepted. If Express Scripts succeeds in its rival bid, Mr. Crawford would receive $57.6 million to $62.4 million, not an estimated $48 million.

title: Bushs Plan for Iraq Runs Into Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 President Bushs call to increase the American military commitment in Iraq ran into intense Congressional opposition Thursday from Democrats and from moderate Republicans who expressed profound skepticism.

title: New Strategy Vindicates Ex-Army Chief Shinseki
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  After President Bush told the nation on Wednesday night that he was ordering a rapid increase of American forces in Iraq, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki was not among the retired officers to offer instant analysis on television.

title: Correction: Strange Love
description: A picture credit with an article last Friday about visits to Atomic Age sites misstated the photographers given name. He is Jeff Topping, not Jess.

title: Doctors Stay Optimistic on Barbaro
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 11  A day after it was announced that Barbaro had had a setback in his recovery from the painful hoof disease laminitis, his condition remained largely unchanged Thursday, but his surgeon was cautiously optimistic.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about possible campaign headquarters for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misidentified one of the places she has considered home. It is Washington, D.C., not Washington State.

title: U.S. Embassy in Athens Is Attacked
description: ATHENS, Jan. 12  An antitank grenade was fired into the heavily fortified American Embassy here just before dawn today. The building was empty, but the attack underscored deep anti-American sentiment here and revived fears of a new round of homegrown terror.

title: Manhattan: 2 Stabbed Outside School
description: Two teenage boys were stabbed yesterday outside Landmark High School and the Coalition School for Social Change, which share a building on West 58th Street, the police said. They were attacked by a group of 11 other teenagers, the police said. The victims, both 16, were not identified. One was stabbed in the thigh, the other in the lower back, the police said, but both were in stable condition yesterday at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital. The stabbings apparently followed a dispute on Wednesday between two girls who attend school there, the police said.

title: Concerns of Dashed Hopes From Promised Miracles
description: It was a day of promised miracles in the House of Representatives. Almost every other lawmaker who spoke during the debate on the stem cell bill told of a close relative with a deadly affliction whose cure depended on generating new human embryonic stem cell lines.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about the popularity of penguin characters among marketers, misidentifed the agency that created a holiday commercial for Coca-Cola, based on information supplied by Coca-Cola. The agency was Berlin Cameron United, which previously worked for the company  not Wieden & Kennedy, the current agency. The article also misspelled the surname of a founder of Club Penguin, a Web site for children. He is Dave Krysko, not Krisko.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Scalpel and Palette
description: These are the places visited by Michael Kimmelman on his Eakins tour. Except St. Charles Borromeo Seminary, they are all in Philadelphia.

title: Explosion Hits U.S. Embassy in Athens
description: ATHENS, Friday, Jan. 12  A powerful explosion, reportedly caused by a rocket, rocked the American Embassy in Athens Friday morning.

title: Winter? What Winter?
description: THE final New Hope & Ivyland Railroad steam locomotive of the day had just lurched out of New Hope, Pa., station last Sunday afternoon, leaving Ed Hoy hunched at his desk in the ticket office to crunch the numbers from an unusually warm and profitable weekend.

title: After a Struggle to Escape Comes an Effort to Adjust
description: God Grew Tired of Us, a sober, uplifting documentary that follows the resettlement in the United States of three young men uprooted as children by the civil war in Sudan, is the softer, Hollywood-sanctioned version of an earlier documentary, The Lost Boys of Sudan. A National Geographic production, directed by Christopher Quinn and narrated by Nicole Kidman in her loftiest A-student elocution, God won both the Grand Jury Prize and the Audience Award at the 2006 Sundance Film Festival. How could it not? Handsomely photographed and inspirational, but not cloyingly so, it is the rare contemporary documentary that doesnt leave a residue of cynicism and outrage.

title: Theater Listings
description: TWAINATHON Samuel Langhorne Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, made a famous declaration after his obituary was published in 1897. The report of my death was an exaggeration, Twain said, and he went right on living for nearly 13 years.

title: Bonds Is One Problem Baseball Cant Escape
description: Barry, Barry, Barry. There you go again. This time it isnt flaxseed oil but amphetamines. You cant get yourself suspended for using flaxseed oil; you can get people laughing at you for saying thats what you thought you used, but suspended, no. Greenies, however, will get you suspended if you test positive a second time.

title: For Police Involved in Fatal Shooting, Talking May Be Risky
description: The decision by four of the five police officers involved in the killing of an unarmed Queens man to voluntarily speak to prosecutors, giving investigators their version of events for the first time, poses certain risks for both sides, lawyers and legal experts say.

title: A Psychedelic Boat Trip Down a Sea of Ambiguity
description: Fluke, which ran at Performance Space 122 in April, reopened yesterday and continues through Jan. 28 at Collapsable Hole, 146 Metropolitan Avenue, at Berry Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 388-2251. Following are excerpts from Jason Zinomans review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 29; the full text is here.

title: High-Toned Scats and Purrs by a Low-Profile Jazz Singer
description: The jazz singer Nancy King has a fairly deep voice, a comfortable, well-worn purr. But during every song she sang in her late set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, whether she was improvising while singing lyrics or scatting, she jumped an octave.

title: Seven Hours in a Swirl of Jazz With a French Accent
description: The NYC Winter Jazzfest, now in its third year, carries off a small thing on a large scale. A profusion of small things, actually: well over a dozen separate acts in 40-minute sets, spread out over all three stages of the Knitting Factory. In essence the event conspires to produce the sensation, not common enough in New York jazz circles, of plunging into an enveloping atmosphere. All it asks of its patrons is a dash of curiosity, a dose of patience and the will to trudge repeatedly up and down several flights of stairs.

title: Rock/Pop Listings
description: POP

title: Mexico: Troops to Acapulco
description: President Felipe Caldern continued a crackdown on drug cartels and sent more than 1,000 soldiers into the Pacific resort town of Acapulco and other areas of Guerrero State. The deployments follow similar operations in the states of Michoacn and Baja California involving 10,000 troops and agents since Mr. Caldern took office in December.

title: Russia: Arrest in Killing of Central Banker
description: The General Prosecutors Office announced the arrest of what it called the organizer of the killing of Andrei A. Kozlov, the first deputy chairman of Russias central bank, in September. The office declined to identify the suspect, but the mans lawyer told Russian news agencies that he was Andrei Y. Frenkel, the director of two banks that Mr. Kozlov shut down last year over accusations of money laundering and other irregularities. Mr. Kozlovs killing, which came a month before the killing of the journalist Anna Politkovskaya, raised alarms about the safety of prominent reformers. Arrests have been rare in contract-style murders.

title: 3,000 Tests for Amphetamines, but Only Bonds Is in the Spotlight
description: The statement was not a direct admission of guilt. But the 64 words attached to Barry Bondss name last night will probably be viewed as an acknowledgment by the embattled 42-year-old outfielder that he indeed tested positive for amphetamines at some point in 2006, thus raising questions about his status for 2007.

title: Ex-Investigator for H.P. Is Expected to Plead Guilty
description: A former Hewlett-Packard private investigator is expected to plead guilty today to federal charges that he posed as a reporter to get phone records for the companys internal investigation of boardroom leaks.

title: Bristol Finds Alliances, and Perhaps a Suitor
description: THE drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb brings to mind that vacant colonial for sale down the street. In real estate parlance, both are expensive and might seem to need too much tender loving care.

title: Correction: A Revised Edition
description: A picture caption with an article last Friday about the writer Maya Angelous part-time home in New York misstated the number of its rooms. It has 12 rooms  not 18, which is the number of rooms in her home in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Where Covering a Wedding Can Bring Death Threats
description: The north of Mexico is under siege. Gang wars for control of the drug market and cocaine routes to the United States took at least 2,000 lives in Mexico last year, most of them in border states. Serious journalism is also a victim.

title: Mexico: Vatican Punishment Asked for Priest
description: The leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in Mexico have asked the Vatican to defrock the Rev. Nicols Aguilar, a priest with a long history of sex-abuse allegations who has evaded prosecution for nearly two decades. Cardinal Norberto Rivera, the archbishop of Mexico, along with two other high-ranking bishops, sent the request in late December to a special ecclesiastical committee in the Vatican charged with investigating sexual abuse by priests. The decision came after new reports about Father Aguilars case. Although wanted in Los Angeles since 1989 on 19 counts of sexually molesting children, he continued to work as a priest in Mexico. He has been accused of similar crimes in Mexico in the 1990s, including the brutal rape of an alter boy in 1994.

title: Britain Signals Plans to Reduce, Not Increase, Troop Levels in Iraq
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  Britain, which had been Americas closest and most pliant ally in Iraq, said Thursday that it would not follow the United States in raising troop levels there and signaled that it would proceed with plans to hand over security responsibilities to Iraqi forces in the south.

title: In Texas, Monarchs Flutter and Admirals Alight
description: MEXICAN blue wing butterflies defy stereotype. They prefer shade to sunlight. They are dark, not bright. They seek tree bark, rather than blooms. And they are one of the reasons Mel and Maris Midgley traveled from Gloucestershire, England, to southern Texas and the Lower Rio Grande Valley.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: She Solves the Crime but Remains a Mystery
description: When it comes to the writing and reading of mystery series, certain rules of the road apply. Each novel features a stellar main character, possibly with a cast of devoted sidekicks. These books are cranked out at regular intervals. Theyre also read in sequence by readers who are as compulsive as the authors, so that it is unthinkable to pick up a current title without wading through the earlier ones. Unthinkable, that is, unless an established but not yet mainstream writer like Carol OConnell blows this whole orderly process out of the water.

title: Coughlin Fires His Defensive Coordinator
description: Part of the deal that allowed Giants Coach Tom Coughlin to keep his job was the promise to the teams owners that he would make changes. The status quo, following an 8-8 record and a first-round playoff exit, was not good enough.

title: Hire by the Contract Now, Risk a Big Regret Later
description: The new heads of Exxon Mobil, PepsiCo and Pfizer dont have one. Nor do the chief executives at Citigroup, General Electric and Procter & Gamble. And some corporate governance experts say shareholders are better off as a result.

title: Golden State Gamble
description: A few days ago. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger unveiled an ambitious plan to bring universal health insurance to California. And Im of two minds about it.

title: Prosecutor Asks State to Take Over Duke Case
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 12  The district attorney has asked the state attorney general to take over prosecution of the sexual offense and kidnapping case against three Duke University lacrosse players, an official involved in the case said today.

title: Stepping Up the War: Will the Bush Plan Work? (13 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenwich: Concession Dispute Over
description: The operators of the coffee concession at the Old Greenwich train station have reached an agreement with town officials in which they will vacate that stand in exchange for an assurance that the town would try to help them keep their other stand at the Riverside station, officials said yesterday. The operators, Greg and Mary Maher, a married couple who have had the Old Greenwich stand for some years, were told in December that they had to leave after Adam Fairbanks, a 23-year-old Greenwich man who is blind, invoked laws giving the blind preference at running government-owned concessions.

title: New U.N. Chief Steps Gingerly Into the City
description: Nobody mentioned parking tickets.

title: In Obliging Waco, Dr Pepper Is the King
description: YOU step off the plane, rent a car and notice a gun club off the side of the airport access road. Fifteen minutes later, with a strangers shotgun in your hand, youre merrily blasting away at clay pigeons across a poplar-lined field within site of the control tower. Welcome to the Wild West as its lived in the old cowboy town of Waco, Tex.  hospitable, liberating and as broad as the dry, grassy plains around town.

title: All About Ego, Showbiz and a Little Black Dress
description: Blondes dont come any more toxic than Clea, the weapon of mass destruction accessorized with it bag and alpine heels who lays waste to a seemingly solid marriage in The Scene, Theresa Rebecks sharp-witted, sharp-elbowed comedy about the savage economies of sex and show business in contemporary Manhattan.

title: Democrats in Senate Fail to Block Bill on Ethics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  After campaigning for months on a promise to tighten ethics rules, Senate Democratic leaders tried unsuccessfully Thursday to block a measure that would shine a light on the shadowy practice of earmarking federal money for lawmakers pet projects.

title: Police Dog Is Seriously Injured During Pursuit
description: After the life, or at least the career, of one of New Yorks finest was imperiled in the line of duty yesterday, police officials and reporters gathered inside a Manhattan hospital, awaiting news from doctors.

title: Britain: Jury Selection in Failed 2005 Bomb Plot
description: Jury selection began in the trial of six men accused of conspiring to murder in the attempted bombings in London on July 21, 2005, when explosives failed to detonate. The trial is expected to open with prosecution evidence next week. The accused men are Ibrahim Muktar Said, Ramzi Mohamed, Yassin Hassan Omar, Hussain Osman, Manfo Asiedu and Adel Yahya.

title: Rangers, Listless Then Resilient, Fall Short
description: The comeback sprang from almost nothing last night; there was no outward sign that the Rangers had hit rock bottom and were plotting their way back into a game that seemed disastrous.

title: Stem Cell Bill Sails Through the House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to broaden federal support for embryonic stem cell research, stepping up a confrontation with President Bush over a thorny scientific and ethical issue that Democrats hope to capitalize on in the next election.

title: Manhattan: Prostitution Sentence
description: The operator of an escort service in TriBeCa was sentenced to a year and a half to three years in prison yesterday for money laundering and attempted promotion of prostitution. Judge Daniel P. FitzGerald sentenced the operator, Jason Itzler, 39, under the terms of a plea agreement. Ive grown up, Ive matured, Ive learned a lot, Mr. Itzler, who once proclaimed himself to be King of all Pimps in an interview with New York magazine, told the court. I will never run an escort agency again.

title: Spitzer Names 11 to Top Posts; Some Key Spots Remain Open
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  Gov. Eliot Spitzer named 11 members of his administration Thursday, including veterans of the Clinton White House, members of policy research groups, and two of the Democrats who ran unsuccessfully last year to succeed him as the New York State attorney general.

title: Rise in Child Abuse Reports Has Family Court Reeling
description: The surge in child abuse and neglect reports in the year since Nixzmary Brown was killed has overwhelmed judges and lawyers in New York City Family Court, government officials and lawyers for children testified at a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: The South Rises in the Northeast
description: THE SOUTH RISES

title: Devastating Criticism on Iraq by Both Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  From the very first remarks, the tone was set: courteous, serious  and devastating.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about separatist rebel attacks in the northeast Indian state of Assam misstated its precise location. Assam borders several other Indian states and the kingdom of Bhutan; it does not border Myanmar. (Go to Article)

title: Bombers Strike, and America Is in Turmoil. Its Just Another Day for Jack Bauer.
description: Its morning again on 24, and Day 6 is looking bleak. Among other things, teams of suicide bombers are blowing up buses and subway cars all across the United States.

title: A Soccer Star Heeds Lure of Hollywood
description: David Beckham has never been simply a sports star. He is a brand, and one who briefly lived at the spot where fashion, celebrity and soccer met. The soccer component of that equation has eroded, but his star power still reverberates worldwide, so much that Major League Soccer has lured Beckham to Los Angeles.

title: Duke Accuser Contradicts Herself
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 11  In an interview last month with a district attorneys investigator, the woman who has accused three Duke lacrosse players of sexual assault contradicted critical evidence and parts of her earlier accounts, dealing a new blow to a faltering case.

title: Newark: Transit Director Leaving
description: George D. Warrington, executive director of New Jersey Transit, said yesterday that he would step down at the end of March to pursue other opportunities. Mr. Warrington has spent more than three decades in transportation and started at New Jersey Transit when it was formed in 1979. After working his way up to manager in charge of rail operations, he took jobs at the New Jersey Department of Transportation and later Amtrak, where he became president in 1998 and oversaw the introduction of the Acela Express. Mr. Warrington returned to New Jersey Transit in 2002. Under his tenure, ridership reached record highs and multilevel trains were introduced. Gov. Jon S. Corzine will appoint his successor.

title: In Surprise Move, British Bank Lifts Rate
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  The Bank of England surprised investors on Thursday and raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent, to head off rising inflation amid a boom in the housing market and strong economic growth.

title: In Pennsylvania, Presidents Plan Draws Mixed Responses and Hardens Opinions
description: CLIFTON HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 11  Hunched over a beer with a crowd of other veterans at the American Legion here Thursday, Rocco Polidoro was sure of one thing: President Bushs plan to send some 20,000 more troops to Iraq would only make matters worse.

title: Bushs Iraq Plan, Between the Lines
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has presented a new strategy for the war in Iraq that he feels can reverse the countrys drift toward large-scale civil war. The new plan focuses on stabilizing Baghdad by adding thousands of American troops with newly expanded powers to take on Shiite as well as Sunni rebels. It also includes a limited increase in United States forces in Anbar Province, and calls for Iraqi forces to take formal control of the security mission in November. The president was refreshingly candid, saying that where mistakes have been made, the responsibility rests with me.

title: Second Man Sentenced in Killing of Reporter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The second of two men convicted in the killing of a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced to 65 years in prison today.

title: Klein Says Privatizing Not Planned for Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein flatly denied yesterday that he would hire private managers to run city schools, but he did not rule out a wide role for outside groups in advising and supporting networks of schools.

title: Maureen Orcutt, 99, Golf Champion, Dies
description: Maureen Orcutt, one of the nations outstanding golfers for almost a half-century and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, died Tuesday in Durham, N.C. She was 99.

title: Florida: Chemical Substance Found on Envelopes
description: The outside of two envelopes delivered to the Palm Beach County Courthouse held a white powdery substance that tested positive for tellurium, a chemical hazardous to the liver and central nervous system, the authorities said. The chemical did not pose a threat because it was not airborne, but five people who came in contact with the envelopes were decontaminated, said Teri Barbera, a spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County Sheriffs Office, which was investigating the origin of the substance.

title: Newark: Man Guilty in Fatal Crash
description: An Old Bridge man was convicted of vehicular homicide and manslaughter in State Superior Court yesterday for a 2004 crash in Newark that killed two sisters, said Christopher Iu, an Essex County assistant prosecutor. The man, Kevin McGrath, 43, hit the sisters, Venessa Pereira, 19, and Maressa Farias, 13, both of Newark, as they walked into the street. Mr. McGrath, who was driving 50 miles per hour in a 25 m.p.h. zone, told investigators that he had fallen asleep behind the wheel.

title: An Updraft for the Airlines
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  A good mood can be infectious, and W. Douglas Parker, chief executive of US Airways, with a sunny disposition and a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta Air Lines, has helped make the airline industry feel better about itself again.

title: Military Eases Its Rules for Mobilizing Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Pentagon announced steps Thursday to make more reservists available for duty in Iraq and Afghanistan by changing the policies that govern how often members of the Army National Guard and Reserve can be mobilized.

title: Wal-Mart Chooses New Ad Agencies
description: For the third time in less than three months, Wal-Mart Stores has made major decisions affecting the advertising agencies that handle its giant marketing assignments.

title: Mets Say Mota Saga Is a Thing of the Past
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Jan. 11  An assortment of Mets players and front-office officials were on hand Thursday in the Dominican Republic, as the organization presented a $25,000 donation to Esperanza International, which assists families in starting small businesses.

title: Sensitivity and a Surprise for La Traviata at the Met
description: What might have been just a routine revival of Franco Zeffirellis extravagant 1998 production of Verdis Traviata turned out to be an affecting performance thanks to the inspired work of two South Korean-born artists and a stalwart American baritone who saved the day.

title: New York City Property Values Jump 19 Percent
description: Defying fears of a cooling real estate market, the total value of all New York City property jumped 19 percent, to $802.4 billion this year from $674.1 billion last year, officials announced today. The increases were greatest in Brooklyn and the Bronx and among apartment buildings and commercial properties.

title: Massachusetts Rescinds Deal on Policing Immigration
description: BOSTON, Jan. 11  Gov. Deval L. Patrick said Thursday that as expected, he had rescinded a new agreement between Massachusetts and federal officials that empowered the state police to arrest illegal immigrants on charges of violating immigration law.

title: Carter Center Advisers Quit to Protest Book
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 11  Fourteen of the citys business and civic leaders resigned from the Carter Centers advisory board on Thursday to protest former President Jimmy Carters recent criticisms of Israel and American Jewish political power.

title: Inquiry Planned in Poland Over Secret Police Ties
description: PARIS, Jan. 12 The church leadership of Poland called today for all the countrys bishops to be investigated for past ties to the secret police.

title: Harvard Outlines Plans to Expand Campus Across the Charles River
description: BOSTON, Jan. 11  Harvard University released details on Thursday of a multibillion-dollar plan to expand from Cambridge across the Charles River to the Allston neighborhood of Boston. The university wants to transform more than 200 acres into a second, more modern, Harvard Square, with retail space, academic buildings, athletic and cultural facilities and student housing.

title: Radical Reads
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Totals
Revisiting Issue, U.N. Chief Clarifies Death-Penalty Stance
