description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 11  Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, sought Thursday to change the impression he left in his first public utterance as United Nations head last week about his position on the death penalty.

title: Times Co. to Cut Jobs in New England
description: The New York Times Company is offering a voluntary buyout plan to newsroom and business-office employees in its New England Media Group as part of an effort to cut 125 jobs at The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, according to memorandums sent yesterday by the head of the group and the editor of The Globe.

title: In an Unforgiving Kingdom, the Tyranny of the Strong
description: Go on, rouse yourself to watch The Best of Nature  25 Years on Sunday night. Its the 25th anniversary of this august and spectacular series, which since 1982 has featured some of the greatest nature cinematography on earth. You can make time for a highlight reel.

title: Tales of the Urban Jungle and a Forest Full of Music
description: Is it blasphemous to suggest that in the world of urbane American child rearing there simply seems to be too much love between parents and teenagers? Too much trading of Ugg boots and playlists, too much consensus on Bob Dylan, David Sedaris and gnocchi? When precisely did the taste for rebellion expire?

title: Steve Jobs Walks the Tightrope Again
description: Apples new iPhone appears to be the clearest statement yet of what Steven P. Jobss impact has been in the world of consumer electronics.

title: A Setback for Prosecutors in the Enron of Kansas Case
description: It was called the Enron of Kansas.

title: Art in Review
description: ROBERT IRWIN Whos Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue3 PaceWildenstein 545 West 22nd Street, Chelsea  Through Feb. 3

title: After Adjustment, the Ravens Offense Makes Up Ground
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md., Jan. 11  It was the price to be paid last season for leaving the house.

title: In Downtown New Orleans, Thousands March Against Killings
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11  Thousands of residents here, mostly whites, marched through downtown on Thursday in a show of anger over recent killings and local officials ineffective response.

title: Fun With Studio Crafts: When the Traditional Gets Quirky
description: Who but the California funk ceramicist Robert Arneson (1930-92) could turn the mother of the 16th-century painter and printmaker Albrecht Drer from a figure of pathos into a witty incarnation of worldly wisdom? His satirical take on the dour 1514 drawing by Drer is but one of the quirky, provocative, funny and sometimes gorgeous things to be found in One of a Kind: The Studio Craft Movement, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: The $250,000 Question
description: WHAT kind of second home can you get these days for $250,000? It depends on where youre looking.

title: Belarus Learns That Days of Wine and Roses Are Over
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11  President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus appeared to be the last leader in the old Soviet neighborhood to realize that he was dealing with a different Russia.

title: Head of MTV Networks Leaving
description: In another management change at Viacom, Michael Wolf, the president and chief operating officer of MTV Networks, is leaving the company.

title: NATO Says Afghan Clash May Have Killed Scores of Rebels
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 11  Afghan and NATO troops clashed with a large group of insurgents crossing from Pakistan into eastern Afghanistan in the early morning hours on Thursday. NATO said up to 150 insurgents might have been killed in the fighting.

title: New Jersey Says Clerics Arent Required to Unite Gay Couples
description: Allaying the fears of some clergy members, the New Jersey attorney general announced yesterday that the state would not require clerics to unite same-sex couples in civil unions.

title: Grooming a Weatherman for His TV Debut, and Hoping He Doesnt Bite the Host
description: Chuck the groundhog waddled out of his open carrier and onto the desk in the tiny reception office in the Staten Island Zoo. He walked onto the phone and stepped on a few buttons. A house line rang. Thank you for calling the Staten Island Zoo, the female voice said on the speaker. You have reached the directors office.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Going Commercial
description: WHO Jason Goldwater, 35, of Las Vegas, an associate creative director at an advertising agency and a co-owner of a waxing salon, shown with his wife, Bree Goldwater, 34, also a co-owner of the salon

title: Revamping of EMI Begins With Management Shake-Up
description: In an unexpected shake-up, the British music giant EMI Group has fired its chief of recorded music, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company, according to executives briefed on the plan.

title: Coping With Grief, and the Causes of a Fatal Crash
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 11  Patrick Cornell had already been to the morgue. A few minutes later, he planned to visit the scene of the fiery collision that claimed the life of his mother, Ruth A. MacArthur, and three students from Freehold Borough High School.

title: Somalias Clashes Move to Doorstep of New Rulers
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 12  More violence exploded in Somalias capital today, and this time it was right at the doorstep of the newly-installed government.

title: Wake Up Your Computer
description: With great computing power comes great responsibility. Unsecured computers hurt their owners by exposing them to identity theft and stolen passwords. But they can also be conscripted as foot soldiers in a destructive online army: At best, it inconveniences all users by spewing noisome spam. At worst, it generates large-scale attacks on the Web sites of companies and even governments that can shut down networks at enormous cost.

title: In Traffics Jam, Whos Driving May Be Surprising
description: Its a common enough thought among city drivers inching through traffic: Everyone around me came from the suburbs, making my life miserable. But its wrong, because more than half the drivers who crowd into Manhattan each workday come from the five boroughs.

title: Who Needs Objects? Rev Up the Flashing Sign, and Run the Video
description: In an object-craving moment in American art  has there ever really not been one?  its good to see SculptureCenter go a little way in the other direction. Its winter lineup of nine installations includes video, sound, a zine, two light shows and a mural. It may be worth noting that the most object-intensive work is also the least interesting.

title: Albany: Brodsky Makes Ethics Pledge
description: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky told lawmakers yesterday that if he was chosen as the next state comptroller, he would issue an order prohibiting people and businesses who do business with the state pension fund from making political contributions to candidates for comptroller. Mr. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, is one of several assemblymen vying to succeed Alan G. Hevesi, who resigned last month. Mr. Hevesi and other past comptrollers took large donations from people and businesses who earned big fees from the pension funds. Another candidate, Assemblyman Joseph D. Morelle, resigned as chairman of the Monroe County Democratic Committee to focus on the race, which will be decided by the Legislature after a panel screens the applicants.

title: American Soccer Takes a Bold Gamble on a Boldface Name
description: It was the night of Aug. 12 that Dave Checketts was enlightened to the magnetic appeal of Posh Spices significant other. David Beckham entered a game in Salt Lake City for Real Madrid and, as Checketts recalled, Thousands of flashbulbs went off.

title: Senator Dodd of Connecticut Announces Bid for Presidency
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 11  As he formally announced his candidacy for president on Thursday, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut said he saw himself as the dark horse in the expanding Democratic field, an unknown quantity with experience.

title: Neo-Splendor in American Wing
description: NEO-SPLENDOR

title: In Bangladesh, State of Emergency and Election Delay
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 11  The president of Bangladesh declared a state of emergency on Thursday evening, suspending certain fundamental rights, imposing a nighttime curfew, and effectively postponing elections that were scheduled to be held in less than two weeks. He then resigned as the chief of the caretaker government entrusted to run the vote.

title: Voters Who Take Chances on Politicians May Get a New Way to Test Their Luck
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11  The next time a New Jersey resident steps into a voting booth and hopes to pull the lever, think of a one-armed bandit.

title: Just a Bunch of Kids Who Kidnap and Kill
description: Alpha Dog is a true-crime story inspired by a pipsqueak thug improbably named Jesse James Hollywood, who once reigned over a modern Sodom and Gomorrah in  you know it  Los Angeles.

title: A Familiar Face Returns, Bringing Hope That Another Follows
description: The marquee atop Yankee Stadium yesterday told motorists there were 33 days until pitchers and catchers report for spring training. Reversing the calendar would show it has been 34 days since the Yankees agreed to contract terms with Andy Pettitte.

title: Canadian Court Rules Lesbian Partner Is a Parent
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 11  Last week, a 5-year-old Ontario boy became a member of a larger family. An appeals court ruled that he has three parents: a father and two mothers.

title: Crude Oil Falls Further, Gratifying Consumers More Than Investors
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11  Oil prices sank on Thursday to the lowest level in 19 months, providing potential relief to consumers. But investors in energy stocks may wish for a cold spell after they see the fourth-quarter earnings of their stocks in the next few weeks.

title: Despite Distractions, Kidd Leads the Way in Nets Unlikely Victory
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11  Jason Kidd, 33, had played nearly 43 minutes against the Chicago Bulls and still was relentlessly pursuing Kirk Hinrich, a point guard who is seven years younger.

title: Nets Hanging On to Their Core, for Now
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11  The unpredictability of the Nets play this season may have made the job of their president, Rod Thorn, more difficult.

title: Picassos Theft Contributes to Mystery of Eccentric Collectors Art Trove
description: When the colorful Manhattan gadfly known as William M. V. Kingsland died in March, leaving an unexpected trove of important art in his Upper East Side apartment, a mystifying art world caper began to unfold.

title: U.S. Preparing for Trials of Top Qaeda Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Bush administration has set up a secret war room in a Virginia suburb where it is assembling evidence to prosecute high-ranking detainees from Al Qaeda including the man accused of being the mastermind of the September 2001 attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, government officials said this week.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Is There an Actor In the House?

title: Preparing for Farm Bill Cuts, or Not
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  With a costly war in Iraq, mounting budget deficits and record-high crop prices, administration officials said this week that farmers should expect to receive smaller agricultural payments in this years Farm Bill.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Fatal Raid Linked to Lies for Warrant in Drug Case
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 11  A narcotics team that shot and killed an elderly woman while raiding her home lied to obtain the search warrant, one team member has told federal investigators, according to news reports confirmed by a person familiar with the investigation who requested anonymity.

title: Costco Bias Suit Is Given Class-Action Status
description: A federal judge granted class-action status yesterday to a lawsuit filed on behalf of more than 700 female workers at Costco Wholesale claiming that the retailer had systematically discriminated against women seeking jobs as managers.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about digital technology that rotates advertiser images on highway billboards, carried incorrect estimates from the Outdoor Advertising Association of America on the number of billboards that are expected to be converted to digital in the next 10 years. It is 4,000, not 90,000.

title: Agents Say Fast Audits Hurt I.R.S.
description: Top officials at the Internal Revenue Service are pushing agents to prematurely close audits of big companies with agreements to have them pay only a fraction of the additional taxes that could be collected, according to dozens of I.R.S. employees who say that the policy is costing the government billions of dollars a year.

description: Top stories from Russian newspapers on Friday:

description: People

title: In Baghdad, Bush Policy Is Met With Resentment
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 11  Iraqs Shiite-led government offered only a grudging endorsement on Thursday of President Bushs proposal to deploy more than 20,000 additional troops in an effort to curb sectarian violence and regain control of Baghdad. The tepid response immediately raised questions about whether the government would make a good-faith effort to prosecute the new war plan.

title: Blair Urges Britain to Stay Aggressive Abroad
description: LONDON, Jan. 12  As he seeks to define his legacy and stamp his imprint on the future, Prime Minister Tony Blair urged his successors today to maintain the warlike foreign policy that he promoted, sending troops into battle in Africa and the Balkans, Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: On the Market
The Prozzos Meet Alona
description: Marino and Debbie Prozzo hosted 7-year-old Alona Malyovana over the holidays, falling head-over-heels for a Ukranian orphan they may be unable to adopt.

description:

with Marc

title: Streep to Star in Film Version of ABBA Musical
description: Meryl Streep will take on the role of a mother with a rebel streak when she stars in the film version of the international hit musical Mamma Mia!, Reuters reported.

title: Analysis: Bush's Iraq Plan, Between the Lines
description: Below, Ive selected a number of important phrases from the address that beg for more detailed discussion, and included my own analysis of the validity and practicality of what the president seems to have in mind.

title: Is There an Actor in the House?
description: Todd Weeks, who plays Hugh Voysey in the Atlantic Theater Companys production of The Voysey Inheritance, left the show for a few days this week after his father died suddenly on Monday. There were no understudies; either performances would have to be canceled or someone familiar with the play would have to jump into the role.

title: Stomping His Way to Brotherhood
description: Brotherhood is powerful. Thats the message of Stomp the Yard, a strange and at times strangely compelling mix of black fraternity recruitment video and inspirational tale about a hip-hop boy in a stepping world.

title: The Human and the Animated, Shrunk to Size
description: In the latest wowzer merging of the real and the fabricated, Arthur and the Invisibles takes actual human actors and, through a complex process involving Slim-Fast and a Maytag dryer, shrinks them to the size of bacteria so they can interact with the microscopic beings who live in your backyard along with Rick Moranis and his family.

title: For Many M.B.A.s, Dream Job May Be Just That
description: What do business schoolers want these days? A job in private equity, apparently. But their dreams of high payouts may not come true, according to BusinessWeek, which reports that there are fewer private equity jobs out there than one might think. While many of the biggest funds will hire about 20 percent more M.B.A.s this year, there are about five candidates for each job available, the magazine said. And the positions typically go to those with experience.

title: Executive Who Stirred Up Volkswagen Will Step Down
description: Wolfgang Bernhard, the hard-charging executive who pared costs at Volkswagen but ruffled the feathers of its labor unions and chairman, will leave the company as part of a broad shake-up of its managing board, the company announced Thursday.

title: Carter and His Critics: The Skirmishes Continue
description: As Brenda Goodman reports this morning, 14 members of the Carter Center Board of Councilors, a leadership advisory group that serves to promote understanding of and support for The Carter Center, the human rights organization founded by former President Jimmy Carter, resigned their posts this week in protest over views expressed by Mr. Carter in his book, Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid.

title: 5th Defendant Pleads Guilty in Shelter Case
description: A former accountant pleaded guilty Thursday to one felony count of lying to federal investigators as part of a widening criminal inquiry into questionable tax shelters. The former accountant, Michael Grandinetti, entered his plea before Judge Thomas P. Griesa in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Grandinetti, 49, is expected to serve as a witness for the prosecution in a mammoth tax shelter case against 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. Mr. Grandinetti, a resident of the Northern Mariana Islands, a United States territory in the Pacific, becomes the fifth person to plead guilty and agree to cooperate with prosecutors in the inquiry, which has also ensnared major accounting firms, banks, law firms and investment boutiques.

title: Ex-Investigator for H.P. Is Expected to Plead Guilty
description: A former Hewlett-Packard private investigator is expected to plead guilty Friday to federal charges that he posed as a reporter to get phone records for the companys internal investigation of boardroom leaks. The former investigator, Bryan Wagner of Littleton, Colo., will plead guilty to identification theft and conspiracy in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., said his lawyer, Stephen Naratil.

title: French Optics Giant May But Cooper Companies
description: A French optics company, Essilor International, might acquire a United States contact lens maker, the Cooper Companies for 2.1 billion euros ($2.7 billion), brokerage Oddo Securities said in a research note this week. Essilor has been on an acquisition spree in recent years, snapping up prescription lens laboratories in North America, Europe and India.

title: A Setback for Prosecutors in the Enron of Kansas Case
description: After two men won their appeal to have their convictions overturned in a case referred to as the Enron of Kansas, The New York Times takes a look at the latest in a recent series of setbacks for the government in white-collar cases. In September 2005, David C. Wittig, a former star investment banker, and his lieutenant, Douglas T. Lake, were convicted of looting the company they ran, Westar Energy of Topeka, the largest electric utility in Kansas. Mr. Wittig was sentenced to 18 years in prison, and Mr. Lake, 15 years. But last Friday, a federal appeals court overturned the convictions of the two men on all 40 counts  most of which cannot be retried.

title: A Genial C.E.O. Provides an Updraft for the Airline Industry
description: Despite robust resistance by Delta Air Lines management and employees to US Airways unsolicited $10.5 billion bid for the rival carrier, there may be one positive outcome everyone can agree on. A good mood can be infectious, and W. Douglas Parker, chief executive of US Airways, with a sunny disposition and a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta, has helped make the airline industry feel better about itself again, writes The New York Times Jeff Bailey.

title: Sun Life Buys Genworth Unit
description: Canadas Sun Life Financial said on Thursday it would buy Genworth Financials group benefits business in the United States for $650 million. Sun Life, Canadas third largest insurer by market value, said the acquisition would expand its business in the United States. A Morgan Stanley analyst, Ken Zerbe, said in a research note that the deal appeared to be positive for Sun Life, which had been a sub-scale player in the United States group insurance market and was searching for a chance to bulk up.

title: Former Siemens C.F.O. Questioned in Corruption Scandal
description: Prosecutors looking into charges of corruption at Siemens said Thursday that they were investigating the companys former chief financial officer, Heinz-Joachim Neubrger. Mr. Neubrger was questioned Tuesday, the Munich state prosecutor Christian Schmidt-Sommerfeld said.

title: China Stocks Top $1 Trillion
description: Chinas stocks have surpassed $1 trillion in value after indexes more than doubled last year and the government encouraged the domestic listing of state-owned companies like Industrial & Commercial Bank of China. The combined value of shares listed on the stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen rose to $1.01 trillion, making mainland China the worlds 10th biggest equity market, according to data compiled by Bloomberg News.

title: Nasdaq Extends Bid for London Exhange
description: The Nasdaq stock market on Thursday extended by two weeks the deadline for shareholders to accept its offer to buy the London Stock Exchange after the New York bourse got a tepid response. The Nasdaq bid for the London exchange was to have ended Thursday, but it said the new deadline would be Jan. 26. The Nasdaq, which is offering 12.43 pounds ($24.22) a share for the London exchange, said it had received acceptances from investors holding 0.61 percent of the exchanges shares outstanding.

title: Vengence Is Mine, Saith the Executive
description: While many chief executives and other high-level managers cite challenges, passion for their industry and even money as their motivating forces, BusinessWeek takes a look at a little mentioned engine that pushes executives to perform: revenge. Examining some high-profile spats, as well as some lesser-known battles, the magazine reminds us of how sweet getting even can be.

title: V.C. Investment in Clean Tech Up 78% in 2006
description: For clean technology start-ups, a year definitely made a difference. Venture capitalists poured $2.9 billion into clean technologies, including energy, in 2006, representing a 78 percent increase over the year before. The Cleantech Venture Network on Thursday published investment data for 2006, reflecting a surge in investment in technologies related to energy generation, storage, recycling and waste, and transportation.

title: Goldmans Alliance Stake May End in an I.P.O.
description: The combined television assets of CanWest Global Communications and Alliance Atlantis Communications could be spun off in a multibillion-dollar public offering four years from now under one of several scenarios set out in CanWests $2 billion deal with its financial partner, Goldman Sachs, to buy the business, The Globe and Mail reported. The specifics of how the private equity arm of the New York investment banker will cash out on this weeks blockbuster takeover of Alliance are not yet public, but the pact with CanWest includes a limited number of outcomes, including an I.P.O.

title: Ritchie Capital Sells Financing Unit to BlueCrest
description: Ritchie Capital Management has sold its start-up finance business to BlueCrest Capital, a hedge fund firm partly owned by the British industry giant Man Group, MarketWatch reported. In a letter to investors cited by MarketWatch, Bluecrest said it had bought the finance vehicle, Ritchie Technology & Life Sciences, for an undisclosed price.

title: Cinema Ad Group Aims High in I.P.O.
description: National CineMedia, the advertising network for theater chain operators, on Thursday outlined plans to offer 38 million shares at $18 to $20 apiece in a bid to raise about $722 million in its initial public offering. The planned I.P.O. raises the number of offerings set to kick off in the $500 million to $1 billion range, joining theater chain AMC Entertainment, Time Warner Cable and MetroPCS, a wireless broadband provider. The I.P.O. backlog in the United States stands at a healthy level of 104 deals expected to raise $16 billion, down from 106 deals expected to raise $17.4 billion in the year-ago period, according to Dealogic.

title: CVC and Macquarie Said to Eye Chinese Lumber Firm
description: CVC Asia Pacific and Macquarie Bank may offer to buy the Sino-Forest Corporation, the largest foreign-owned lumber company in China, according to Bloomberg News. An acquisition of Sino-Forest, which has a market capitalization of $1 billion, would give the buyout firms control of a wood-products maker that increased sales 34 percent annually between 1994 and 2005. Shares in Sino-Forest, which is based in Toronto, are poised for the biggest weekly gain since September 2005.

title: Why Hedge Funds Arent Going Away
description: Whether youre among those who believe that hedge funds are Satan (much of the news media and the Connecticut attorney general) or savior (hedge fund employees and investors), it looks like theyre here to stay, writes The New York Timess Jenny Anderson. The money continues to flow into hedge funds. Hedge Fund Research, a Chicago-based research firm, estimates that $110 billion flowed into new funds through November. A study released by Deutsche Bank yesterday surveyed investors who represent $900 billion of the total $1.4 trillion in the industry and predicted that $110 billion will flow into the sector in 2007.

title: Bristol Finds Alliances, and Perhaps a Suitor
description: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb brings to mind that vacant colonial for sale down the street. In real estate parlance, both are expensive and might seem to need too much tender loving care. The companys leaders all but announced it was for sale last September. Four months later, though, no potential suitor has emerged  at least not publicly. Instead, Bristol-Myers has entered several comparatively small deals, including one yesterday in which it announced a $1.35 billion partnership with the British company AstraZeneca to develop two diabetes compounds.

title: Banks Answer Need for Charity Advice
description: Spurred on by Warren E. Buffetts June announcement that he would hand most of his $40 billion fortune to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, philanthropy is increasingly attracting cash infusions from hedge fund managers, real estate moguls and technology entrepreneurs, Bloomberg News reports. And this year, Wall Street bankers and traders sharing more than $36 billion in bonuses may help drive the donations up even more.

title: This (Naughty) Message Will Self-Destruct in 30 Seconds
description: Real life may have taken a cue from Mission: Impossible, albeit a little too late for those like one-time investment banking star Frank Quattrone who found themselves in hot water over undeleted e-mails. The New York Post writes of new e-mail that self-destructs in just seconds, with no traces left. The vanishing text and video are the brainchild of a small e-mail provider, BigString of Redbank, N.J., founded a year ago by a former Wall Street dot-com trader and several dot-com survivors from the late 1990s. Data can be timed to vanish after just three readings, for example, or in just 30 seconds or as long as several weeks or more.

title: Zebra Snaps Up WhereNet
description: Zebra Technologies said Thursday it had agreed to buy WhereNet, bolstering its position in an up-and-coming technology known as radio frequency identification. Zebra, which primarily makes printers that spit out bar code labels, will pay $126 million in cash for the privately-held WhereNet, based in Santa Clara, Calif. Analysts believe that radio frequency identification  RFID for the cognoscente  will one day supplant bar code technology in supply chain tracking.

title: Mystery Investor Sells Off $131 Million Esprit Stake
description: An unidentified institutional shareholder last night sold 1.02 billion Hong Kong dollars ($131 million) worth of shares in Esprit Holdings, the second placement in the fashion retailer in less than four months. The sale came on a day when Esprits share price turned higher again after six days of mainly declines and could suggest that more shareholders are getting nervous about the current weakness in the market and are taking the opportunity to secure some profit on days of strength.

title: After Brief Hospital Stay, Kozlowski Returns to Prison
description: The former chairman of Tyco International, Dennis Kozlowski, returned to prison Thursday after being hospitalized, according to a prison spokeswoman. Mr. Kozlowski is currently being housed in the Mid-State Correctional Facilitys infirmary in New York, after being treated for an undisclosed ailment. Mr. Kozlowksi is serving a sentence of 8-1/3 to 25 years after being found guilty in June 2005 of looting the company.

title: Revamping of EMI Begins With Management Shake-Up
description: In an unexpected shake-up, the British music giant EMI Group has fired its chief of recorded music, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company. The sudden move, announced Friday, follows a series of setbacks at EMI, including a string of failed merger negotiations with a rival, the Warner Music Group, and the poor sales performance of the pop star Janet Jackson.

title: Snarky Annotation Not Required
description: From a press release:

title: Forstmann Is Leader of the Pack at IMG
description: Forstmann Littles Teddy Forstmann has said that IMG, the sports, fashion, entertainment and media marketer, would be one of his last big acquisitions. To sell it at the steep profit he envisions, Mr. Forstmann has overhauled the ingrained agent culture nurtured in Cleveland by its founder, Mark H. McCormack, and is running it like a profit-driven, even obsessed, property.

title: Pulse
description: The choice of glamorous pack rats, strewing riches at your feet and more.

title: Fearing Beheading, Gibson Ducks Mexican Premiere
description: Okay, thats a little excessive, but it is a true known fact that Mel Gibson will attend a private screening of his movie in Mexico, but skip the public premiere.

title: McDonalds May Serve Up Boston Market Sale
description: After spinning off its Chipotle Mexican Grill business last year, the fast-food giant McDonalds is considering putting its Boston Market restaurant chain up for sale, The Chicago Tribune reported. Employees of Boston Market, whose menu includes chicken dinners, were told about the potential sale Thursday, a McDonalds spokeswoman told the Tribune.

title: The Hill: 20 Hours Later
description: After six years with only one veto, we can now see two possible presidential vetoes on the horizon after just a week of Democratic control in Congress.

title: Casino Pulls Up to the Table
description: Is it just the Bagger, or is it pretty darn swell that the America Cinema Editors chose Casino Royale and its ace, Stuart Baird, as one of the five best-edited dramatic films of 2006? In a heady group that included The Departed, The Queen, United 93 and Babel, the spy snuck in. Was the blond Bond the crowning cinematic achievement of the year? Nah, but you try making making a cartoon character seem fresh and contemporary.

title: Marsh & McLennan Looks to Shop in 2007
description: Marsh & McLennans chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, will look to acquisitions to help the financial-services company grow in 2007 as it tries to recover from an aggressive investigation by the former New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. The company is looking to go to market after completing a possible $3.9 billion sale of its Putnam Investments unit to the Power Corporation of Canada, The Telegraph reported. Our first priority is growth as opposed to a share buy-back, Mr Cherkasky told the paper.

title: The Bagger Takes a Beatdown
description: Dave Poland hopped in his 96 Huffy and delivered a fairly righteous beatdown of the Bagger for suggesting that there might be a connection between Gail Bermans departure from Paramount and the failure of Dreamgirls to soar past the competition in the awards season. Watching two bloggers go at it has all the aesthetic value of watching Freddy vs. Jason  you wish theyd hurry up and slice each other to ribbons before falling down an elevator shaft together.

title: El Gordo Speaks, and Then Some
description: OscarWatch has a lengthy, lucid interview/profile, by Sasha Stone, with Guillermo del Toro, director of Pans Labyrinth.

title: Unit of Germanys Merck Said to Attract Buyout Firms
description: The German drugmaker Merck KGaA has attracted interest in its generic drugs unit from Cinven, Permira and the Texas Pacific Group, people familiar with the matter told Reuters. Merck  no relation to the United States company of the same name  said last week it was considering selling the business, valued at more than 4 billion euros ($5.2 billion), as it retrains its focus on higher-revenue branded products. Merck declined to comment, as did Permira and Cinven, while Texas Pacific was not available to comment, Reuters said.

title: The Question of the Hour, or At Least the Next 30 Seconds
description: I was wondering how far the three of you would be willing to go to help very small movies  and I mean really small, he said. Like if somebody put the best movie youve ever seen on YouTube, would you put it on your Top 10 list?  from a panel of critics at Makor in New York that included David Edelstein (New York Magazine), Owen Gleiberman (Entertainment Weekly) and Stephanie Zacharek (Salon), hosted by The Reeler.

title: A Left-Handed Hammer?
Fact-Checking the President
description: Theres a new truth squad report on President Bushs Iraq speech by www.factcheck.org, a terrific non-partisan group that regularly tries to reel people back to reality. It says that the facts that Bush included in his speech are largely accurate, but that he omitted inconvenient ones. Then it looks at Dick Durbins Democratic response and comes to the same conclusion. Check it out.

title: Senator Clinton Heads to Iraq, Afghanistan
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton left last night for Iraq and Afghanistan on a four-day trip to meet with United States military commanders and troops to further ground herself on the war as she prepares for a likely presidential bid.

title: This is Classified!
description: Or it was. Back in 1999, the U.S. military conducted a secret report on what a military intervention in Iraq would look like, and what should be done to minimize the risks. Documents about the effort, conducted by Centcom and called Desert Crossing, were recently declassified and can be found on line at the National Security Archive  and they make fascinating reading.

title: Plus Ca Change
description: Bob Edgar, the head of the National Council of Churches, has written a fascinating account of another attempted surge.

title: On the Road With Hillary
description: Hillary Clinton is off to Iraq and Afghanistan. The details are here.

title: A New Campaign Against Gitmo Lawyers
description: The Bush administration appears to have decided that its time to kill all the lawyers  or at least time to pressure big business into refusing to pay legal fees to law firms that represent detainees at Guantanamo Bay.

title: Dolan Family Raises Offer for Cablevision
description: Cablevision Systemss controlling family, the Dolans, said Friday that they had raised their offer to buy out the public shareholders of their cable television empire to $30 per share in cash, up from the $27-per-share cash offer they presented in October. In a press release, the family said their latest proposal valued Cablevisions equity at $8.9 billion and implied a total entreprise value of $20.1 billion. The Dolans said the bid was their best and final offer and would expire on Jan. 17.

title: Modern Game Consoles: Glorified Sex Machines?
description: Techsperts are deconstructing a report from a Dallas/Fort Worth television station, which held up Nintendos popular Wii and other gaming consoles as potential mother lodes of smut for little Johnny and Susie.

title: Tranquil Vientiane
description: Get off the beaten tourist track with a visit to Laos's relaxed capital, which can be a tonic for those who have been hopscotching across the region.

title: Evercore Adds Co-Head of Private Equity
description: The Investment bank Evercore Partners said Friday it had hired James Matthews as a senior managing director to co-lead its private equity business, which makes investments in midsize companies. He will oversee the group alongside the senior managing director Neeraj Mital. Mr. Matthews, previously a general partner at the private equity firm Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe, will bring expertise in the business-services and mature technology sectors, Evercores co-chief executive, Austin Beutner, said in a news release.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Politics and Friendship
description: Senator Christopher Dodd of Connecticut has long supported his home-state colleague, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. He lobbied for Mr. Libermans nomination as the Democratic Partys vice presidential candidate in 2000 and, some say, stayed out of the 2004 presidential primary in deference to Mr. Lieberman, who was briefly a candidate.

title: Equity Office Bondholders Agree to Revised Buyback
description: At least one of the Blackstone Groups headaches seems to have gone away. Late Thursday, dissident bondholders of Equity Office Properties Trust relented and said they would accept the companys debt buyback, part of Blackstones $36 billion buyout of the trust. The bondholders, including the insurance giant American International Group, said that they would accept a revised offer by the Jan. 18 deadline, even though it fell short of their initial demands.

title: Placing Ads Anywhere and Everywhere
description: In an attempt to break through to consumers, advertisers have started to migrate from traditional media to almost anywhere outside the home with a little blank space.

title: Can a Garage Space Be Rent-Stabilized?
description: Q When a tenant living in a rent-stabilized apartment rents a parking space in the buildings garage, is the garage rent subject to stabilization, too?

title: What Keeps Lloyd Blankfein Up at Night?
description: What keeps Lloyd Blankfein up at night? The trouble with being at the top of your game is that there is so much room to fall. That may be why Forbess profile of Goldman Sachs, like some other recent media coverage, tends to characterize the giant securities firm as beset by potential peril. Once you are on a pedestal, everyone wonders what will knock you off, and when.

title: New Orleans Violence Boils Over
First Impressions: Fig & Olive (downtown)
description: Theres something a bit different going on here. The proprietors of this new, downtown branch of Fig & Olive, an Upper East Side caf, have taken the kind of location, big-box format, hyper-segmented menu and booming lounge soundtrack usually associated with this citys Asian mega-restaurants and wed it to Mediterranean cuisine.

title: The War at Home: Pivot Point
description: Robert M. Gates, the new secretary of defense, and Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were in front of the Senate Armed Services Committee this morning.

title: Northwest Files Basic Reorganization Plan
description: Northwest Airlines filed its bankruptcy reorganization plan on Friday, expecting to emerge from bankruptcy sometime in the second quarter this year. In a filing with federal bankruptcy court, the carrier said that its shares, which are currently trading over the counter, would be canceled, and its unsecured creditors will not be paid in full.

title: Proxy Season Preview: Pay in the Crosshairs
description: Last year was a contentious one for corporate governance and shareholder proposals. What will 2007 bring? Institutional Shareholder Services, one of the main proxy advisory firms, has issued its 2007 Proxy Season Watch List, which offers some clues. One notable statistic: There are 39 shareholder proposals so far that would link executive pay more closely to a companys performance, compared with just 17 such proposals in last years proxy season.

title: Whos to Blame?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Jan. 11 column, The Fog Over Iraq.

title: A Roof Over New Orleans Head
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Jan. 11 column, Home in the Ruins.

title: Readers Have Say on Saban, Role of College Sports
description: Andrew Zimbalist wrote an article for The Times last Sunday in which he argued that:

title: More on Black
description: I had mentioned a few days ago that every TV frame now seems to be glossy black.

title: Taking a Flyer
description: Helen Mirren and Meryl Streep sat still, sort of, for EWs big Oscar thingie. They return fire on one of the age-old H-wood questions.

title: A Cry for Help
description: While the rest of you were sleeping the sleep of the wicked, Anne Thompson of the Hollywood Report snapped awake wondering what had happened at the BAFTAs thats the British Academy of Film and Television Arts to you civilians. She pointed out that because Oscar ballots are due tomorrow, the BAFTAs will probably have significant impact.

title: Hit and Miss: Cars of the Detroit Auto Show
description: The media preview is over, but the North American International Auto Show opens to the public on Saturday. Here is a breakdown of the hits and misses of the sohw, as I see them. What do you think?

title: Best and Worst of Show
description: The C.E.S. is winding down, so now it is time for the reflecting and summing up.

title: Is Little Miss Sunshine a Used Car?
description: Writing in the Bagger comments section, John surfs around and comes across some eerie parallels between Little Miss Sunshine and the shining cinematic achievement of National Lampoons Family Vacation:

title: Radio Deal Looks Like a Take-Under, Analyst Says
description: The Dolans, who just raised their bid to take Cablevision Systems private, may not be the only media-owning family compelled to reach deeper into their pockets. At least one stock analyst is questioning whether the Mays family and their bidding partners are offering enough cash to shareholders of Clear Channel Communications, the nations largest network of radio stations.

title: Farewell to the D
description: My first Detroit auto show is behind me. If I were to give someone else advice on how to plan for the show, the first thing I would say is, dont bring gym clothes. First of all, journalists at the show have less free time than an Industrial Revolution-era mill worker. And second, you tend to get so wrapped up in what youre doing that you dont even have time to eat, let alone hit the elyptical trainer. Call it the NAIAS diet.

title: The Professor Responds
description: Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of Economics at Smith College, responds to the letters from readers (from the previous post):

title: The Myth of the Suburban Driver
description: This article  from the front page today is a must-read for anyone who ever wondered where all those cars on the citys streets come from. Hint: Not New Jersey.

title: Counting the Days Bush Stays at Camp David
description: Mark Knoller, the longtime White House correspondent for CBS Radio, keeps such good records of President Bushs travels that the White House often refers inquiries to him. But Mr. Knoller, who reports today that the president has officially spent 365 days  a full year  at Camp David, now finds himself in a little record-keeping tiff with the commander in chief.

title: Looking for Exploited Children in All the Wrong Places?
description: Meanwhile, speaking of pornography, the always-interesting Los Angeles Times reports today that the F.B.I. has been conducting raids of adult-film studios in the steamier parts of the San Fernando Valley  on the hunt, it seems, for exploited children.

title: Money-Money-Money-Mon-ey. Money!
description: The Spitzer administration has released salaries for the governors top political appointees and commissioners. Aspiring pols can find out how much government service really pays, below the jump:Titles/salaries below presume senate confirmation.Commissioner salaries are statutory.

title: First New Hampshire Debates Set (No Kidding)
description: Enter April 4 and April 5 on your political calendar.

title: We Win a Case!
description: I just heard that the U.S. District Court has in effect tossed out the libel case against the New York Times for articles that I wrote about the anthrax case. The case was brought by Dr. Steve Hatfill, the person that the Justice Department described as a person of interest in the case. In more technical terms, the judge said he would grant our motion for summary judgment, meaning that the case wont go to trial.

title: China Needs to Embrace Its Feminine Side
description: This came down the pike this morning, but is worth highlighting: A national report in China indicates that the country could face a rather staggering gender imbalance over the next 15 years, with as many as 30 million more men of marriageable age than women by 2020.

title: Seduced by an Airport, and a Hotel
description: Now that my wife is done making fun of me  and all I can say in my defense about her comments posted last time is, well, ah, nothing  we return to our regularly scheduled story.

title: Blogtalk
description: A thought for the Dr. King holiday, and background on Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a Somali-born former member of the Dutch parliament, who will be honored on Monday at the Congress for Racial Equalitys Living the Dream banquet. [The Daily Politics]

title: Blogtalk: The Boxer-Rice Slugfest
description: Several blogs on the center to the right are hammering California Senator Barbara Boxer for the childless, family-less remarks she made to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday. Some are demanding apologies. (Full transcript and audio excerpts of the Boxer-Rice exchange)

title: Bird Flu Persists in Indonesia
description: Avian flu continues its spread across Indonesia. This two-part series explains one country's failure to control a disease that remains a threat to become a pandemic.

title: Bird Flu in Indonesia - Part 2
description: A variety of factors, both cultural and economic, help explain Indonesia's failure to stamp out avian flu, which remains a threat to become a pandemic.

title: Art World Luminaries Recall Marcia Tucker
description: Marcia Tucker, the influential curator and founder of the New Museum, was remembered yesterday at a memorial service as a woman whose insatiable curiosity and ability to ignore her fears led her to alter New Yorks museum landscape and become a mentor to a generation of curators and artists.

title: The Bride Became Debt-Free
description: IF you stopped to name some recent innovations that had enhanced your quality of life, a few things might come to mind  Netflix, leave-in hair conditioner and the proliferation of those big cheap boxes of clementines. But would any financial services top your list?

title: NATOs Afghan Struggle: Build, and Fight Taliban
description: SPERWAN GHAR, Afghanistan  The road that cuts through the heart of Panjwai district here tells all that is going wrong with NATOs war in Afghanistan.

title: In London, a Peek at New York Playgrounds Ahead
description: LONDON, Jan. 12  At some point in its long history, St. Stephens stopped being just another playground and, like a hospital that metamorphoses into a medical center, became St. Stephens Play Project.

title: Tenants Sue Agency Over Brooklyn Project
description: Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of the planned $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, has insisted during the long public debate over the project that it will do anything to ensure that displaced residents will not be left out in the cold.

title: Highway Walker Struck by 2 Cars
description: A man walking along a westbound lane of the Grand Central Parkway near La Guardia Airport last night was hit by two cars and killed, the police said.

title: A Taste of U.S. Family Life, but Adoption in Limbo
description: TERRYVILLE, Conn.  During the two weeks that Marino and Debbie Prozzo welcomed a Ukrainian orphan in their home, they fell head over heels for a 7-year-old child they may never be able to adopt.

title: In Reversal, Senate Endorses Plan on Disclosing Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Senate Democratic leaders on Friday embraced a proposal to shed light on the murky practice of Congressional earmarks, reversing themselves after trying to block an almost identical measure the day before.

title: Imagining, and Reimagining, the Globe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Of all the debates about Shakespeare, it is perhaps second only to the enduring controversy over the identity of the author himself: what exactly did the Globe Theater, where many of his plays were first performed and his troupe resided, look like?

title: An Out-of-Towner Arrives to Show Shes Kept the Faith
description: In American cities outside New York, modern dance thrives by the grit of individuals like Jean Isaacs, who has lived in San Diego since 1970 and has devoted much of her life to spreading its faith. So her choreographic output, judging from a performance by her San Diego Dance Theater at Danspace Project on Thursday, is fairly traditional, with few surprises in her highly structured, emotionally wrought dances.

title: For Human Eyes Only
description: LeIpzig, Germany

title: Sounds to Accompany an Outdoors of the Imagination
description: The Kitchen was where the wild things were on Thursday night. Eighth Blackbird, the new music sextet based in Chicago, offered an aural feast for the imagination with works from Strange Imaginary Animals, their new disc on the Cedille label.

title: Bruno Bought Stock With Campaign Funds
description: Over the past six years, State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, has invested hundreds of thousands of dollars from two campaign accounts that he controls in at least four Albany-area companies, which have all had personal business dealings with him, a review of state campaign finance records shows.

title: Fire Officials Relax Position on Lockers
description: The New York Fire Department, under threat of a lawsuit from the citys largest fire union, has sent a memo to city firehouses stating that firefighters may post American flags and Mass cards memorializing fallen colleagues on their lockers.

title: Nice Phone, Mr. Jobs, But ...
description: IS there anyone who introduces products with more panache than Steven P. Jobs? Let me rephrase that: has there ever been anybody in the history of marketing to introduce products with the sheer, dazzling showmanship of the legendary Apple chief executive?

title: Banks Gone Wild
description: Lexington, Ky.

title: Student Gets Some Help From a Sympathetic Mother
description: Jill Rappaport had just finished talking to her son, Alex, who is a freshman at Duke University, when she read an article about Steguer Wilson, a young man from the Bronx adjusting to his first semester at Hunter College.

title: Safe-Haven Laws Fail to End Discarding of Babies
description: Their lives ended almost as soon as they began. And every time their tiny bodies were found, in Dumpsters, garbage cans or, in the case of a newborn girl in Queens last fall, on the conveyor belt of a recycling plant, dismay and bewilderment followed.

title: Rights Group Says Conditions in China Worsen as Olympics Near
description: BEIJING, Jan. 12  Human rights conditions in China deteriorated last year even as China sought to portray itself as an increasingly open, modern society ahead of the 2008 Olympics, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Friday.

title: Passing Exchange Becomes Political Flashpoint
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  A passing exchange during a Senate hearing on Thursday turned into a political flashpoint overnight as Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat, and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice accused one another of insensitivity in comments about motherhood and the war in Iraq.

title: Totals
At Marist, Passing First Has Pro Scouts Taking a Second Look
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  Jared Jordan was in the fourth grade when his parents moved from the suburbs of Hartford into the city, to a neighborhood known as the West End. title: Russia Cuts Belarus Oil Duty

Fradkov, announced that Russia had agreed to lower significantly an export duty on oil to Belarus. Russia had imposed a duty of $180 per ton on oil shipped to Belarus, but agreed to lower it to $53 after the conflict prompted a halt in supplies to Europe through the Druzhba, or Friendship, pipeline, according to news accounts. Belarus on Wednesday agreed to drop a tit-for-tat fee it had imposed in response to Russias new duty, causing Russia to close the pipeline. Belarus has refined subsidized Russian oil and resold it at significant profit. Belarus will continue to receive a subsidy, but Mr. Fradkov said the new agreement, which appeared to end the dispute between the countries, would still raise $1 billion for Russia.

title: Just Dump Him Already
description: You know that woman friend of yours who has been inexplicably, miserably, annoyingly hung up on the wrong guy for years  or has it been a decade? You know who I mean: shes smart, funny and attractive. Lots of men  even desirable ones  fall for her, although she never seems to like any of them. Or else, just when she begins to notice their existence, he steps back into the picture, pulling her focus away once more. Shes the friend to whom you had to issue a ban on ever mentioning his name in your presence again, and then broke it repeatedly because she seemed so desperately in need of advice (which she promptly ignored). Well, shes the heroine of a very funny novel, Him Her Him Again the End of Him by the former Saturday Night Live writer Patricia Marx. Unfortunately, hes in here, too.

title: Doodles  la Carte

title: All Together Now
description: Take me out with the crowd, goes the old baseball song. I love this crowd, repeats the classic stand-up comic. Every lecturer knows: the larger the group, the more they become an event for themselves, heightening the attention, the laughs or the emotions. At our national political conventions, people wear silly hats and bob up and down to music so stupid it is a parody of music, in order to demonstrate a political feeling. Participating in a demonstrative crowd gives joy, as being a mere spectator cannot. Even in a culture where recorded performance has become central, people crave the live event, largely for that group joy.

title: Its Not Easy Staying Green

I believed in recycling and saving the planet; I wasnt an activist out on the barricades or sitting at the top of a threatened redwood tree, but I certainly supported the people who were. I recycled back in the days when going to the recycling center meant a 20-mile round trip. I used cloth napkins and unbleached paper towels. I didnt use disposable coffee filters. I shopped with string bags to keep plastic out of the landfill and embarrassed my daughter by packing her school lunch in reused bread bags. I bought my cleaning products at the health food store, refilling bottles to save on packaging.

Im thinking of lone avengers like Michael Connellys aging homicide detective, Harry Bosch, bringing belated justice to a cold case he might have botched in Echo Park, as well as precinct-house saints like the Oracle, wising up the rookie cops in Joseph Wambaughs Hollywood Station. And how about those old lions who came roaring out of retirement in new novels by George Pelecanos and John Lutz?

title: Does Abe Foxman Have an Anti-Anti-Semite Problem?
description: In certain precincts of the Jewish community, a person who insists that the sky is falling, despite ample evidence to the contrary, is said to gevaltize  a neologism derived from the famous Yiddish cry of shock or alarm. The word is sometimes applied to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, known as Aipac, the hard-line and notoriously successful pro-Israel lobby. But in the world of Jewish leaders, one man stands alone in the annals of gevalthood  Abraham Foxman, director of the Anti-Defamation League and scourge of anti-Semites of high estate and low, in Hollywood and Tehran, on campus and in the tabloids.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Poor Mary, Queen of Scots. The infant ruler cried on her coronation day. Her second husband murdered her adviser in front of her. And later, she was imprisoned for 19 years by Queen Elizabeth I (her first cousin), who then sentenced her to death. Even Marys beheading was full of drama, requiring three swings of the ax. The Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh, where Mary lived, prayed and  most scandalously  saw her adviser killed, is now inviting the public to take a gander at her private chambers, as well as those of her murderous husband, Lord Darnley. New additions to the chambers, which reopened last month after a six-year restoration, include an oak-paneled oratory and a 17th-century portrait of Mary (below), painted by an unknown artist, which hung at Windsor Castle for 300 years (www.royalcollection.org.uk). ... Tomorrow, the Langham Hotel in London is scheduled to open a swanky bar, Artesian. Named after a 360-foot-deep artesian well that once provided water for the property, this watering hole specializes in rum and was designed by David Collins, who also created the modern looks behind the Blue Bar at the Berkeley and Claridges Bar at Claridges Hotel (www.langhamhotels.com). ... Wanderlust, a company based in Oakland, Calif., is offering a new getaway from March 3 to 9, called A Winters Moon Over Yosemite Valley. Scheduled so that participants will be able to visit Yosemite National Park during a full moon, the seven-day tour includes round-trip tickets aboard a vintage streamliner train (all meals and beverages included), a one-night predeparture stay in Oakland, two nights at the Ahwanhee or Yosemite Lodge and three nights of lodging, as well as dinner and a show, in San Francisco. Rates start at $1,995 a person. For more information, call (877) 625-1717 or visit www.wanderlustevents.com. .... Starting Feb. 15, all Delta flights (www.delta.com) from La Guardia Airport in New York to Chicago will land at Midway Airport instead of OHare. Midway is closer to downtown Chicago, which should cut down on travel time. ... Globetrotters reluctant to share private information on borrowed computers might be interested in RoboForm2Go. The software, which is designed to be carried around in a U.S.B. drive, organizes passwords, address books and banking and credit card information. It can be downloaded from www.roboform.com for $39.95. HILARY HOWARD

title: Up Front
description: To most readers, Robert Pinsky is familiar as a former poet laureate of the United States, the author of an acclaimed translation of Dantes Inferno and the creator of the Favorite Poem Project, which invited ordinary people to submit poems with particular meaning to them, along with personal commentary. This week, in his review of Barbara Ehrenreichs Dancing in the Streets: A History of Collective Joy, Pinsky considers the cultural importance of Carnival, rock concerts and other celebratory mass events  phenomena not as far from the world of poetry as it might seem. The emotional force of mass gatherings has profound importance, he explained in an e-mail message. I think we are desperate for something to counterbalance performances, great though they may be, that we experience electronically. We crave something else, something more personal as well as communal. The public readings sponsored by the Favorite Poem Project, he says, are among the most interesting group events I have witnessed: less performance than participation, and with a spirit hard to name, but unforgettable, and generated not just by each reader or poem, but by everyone there, together. Click here for his review.

It seems the bottles must have a commercial label indicating the contents. I dont know if this is a local interpretation.
