description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 9  By his own admission, Michael Natale is just a small-time homebuilder who wants to get back the nearly $3 million he paid for 112 acres of land in Sparta, about half an hour from here.

title: Cheney Defends Efforts to Obtain Records
description: Vice President Dick Cheney yesterday defended efforts by the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency to obtain financial records of Americans suspected of terrorism or espionage, calling the practice a perfectly legitimate activity used partly to protect troops stationed on military bases in the United States.

title: For McAllister, Long Wait to Taste a Playoff Win
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14  He has long been a good soldier on a bad team, always professional and personable, hugely popular, but seemingly destined to play in frustration in a city where seemingly everybody has a drink but nobody has toasted a local champion.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about Staten Island Chuck, a groundhog being prepared for his first Groundhog Day duty, omitted a credit in some copies. The pictures of Chuck and his trainer, Douglas Schwartz, were by Chang W. Lee of The New York Times.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about faculty opposition to a proposal to make Southern Methodist University the site of President Bushs presidential library misstated the venue in which Brad Cheves, the universitys vice president for development and external affairs, commented on the debate. He was interviewed after leaving a campus meeting, but not the faculty meeting where objections were raised. (Go to Article)

title: Opening a New Front in the War, Against Iranians in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  For more than two years after Saddam Husseins fall, the war in Iraq was about chasing down insurgents and Al Qaeda in Iraq. Last year it expanded to tamping down sectarian warfare.

title: Totals
Surprisingly, Colts Thrive in Spite of Their Offense
description: The Indianapolis Colts noticed the difference last week, when the highlights of their playoff victory against the Kansas City Chiefs were buried behind a field-goal attempt that was botched by a boy wonder quarterback and when few reporters showed up to ask about how they would play the Baltimore Ravens.

title: Descending to New Depths
description: New Orleans

title: Where Snow Is All That Glitters, Worry Over Growths Effect
description: DILLON, Colo., Jan. 9  Chuck Shirk is the kind of loyal skier Arapahoe Basin Ski Area is famous for. Mr. Shirk hates almost everything about modern ski resorts  fancy stores, snooty restaurants, expensive real estate. A-Basin, as Arapahoe is called by just about everybody, is unencumbered by such trappings, he said.

title: With Each Anthem Sung, Familys Philadelphia Legacy Carries On
description: Lauren Hart, a Philadelphia Flyers fan for her entire life, plans to keep going to home games even though the teams season appears to be circling the drain. She has sung the national anthem at Flyers games for 10 seasons and has no plans to quit now.

title: Alice Coltrane, Jazz Artist and Spiritual Leader, Dies at 69
description: Alice Coltrane, widow of the jazz saxophonist John Coltrane and the pianist in his later bands, who extended her musical searches into a vocation as a spiritual leader, died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 69.

title: Classic Viennese Music, the Prequel
description: Music history tells us of two great traditions that emanated from Vienna. The first was the classical period of the late 18th century, in which Haydn and Mozart standardized the symphony, string quartet and keyboard sonata into an international norm. Then, at the turn of the 20th century, the Second Viennese School of Schoenberg, Berg and Webern swept the old rules under the rug.

title: Busywork for Nuclear Scientists
description: The Bush administration is eager to start work on a new nuclear warhead with all sorts of admirable qualities: sturdy, reliable and secure from terrorists. To sweeten the deal, officials say that if they can replace the current arsenal with Reliable Replacement Warheads (what could sound more comforting?), they probably wont have to keep so many extra warheads to hedge against technical failure. If youre still not sold, the warhead comes with something of a guarantee  that scientists can build the new bombs without ever testing them.

title: Patriots Rookie Kicker Ignores Pressure and Fills Large Shoes
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 14  Stephen Gostkowski said he cleared his mind as he searched for a kicking path between distant uprights, the road that might deliver the New England Patriots to the American Football Conference championship game.

title: Fed Up in San Francisco: Tales From the Parking Wars (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: He-Men Strut Stuff to Romance New York
description: I Love New York, the VH1 reality show on which men with nicknames vie for the favor of a woman known as New York, only started last week. But oh, the downloadable moments  theyre already piling up.

title: Spitzer Selects a Black Jurist for Top Court
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that he would nominate Theodore T. Jones Jr., a black judge who has served in Brooklyn for 17 years, to a seat on the Court of Appeals. It is the new governors first appointment to the states highest court.

title: Echoing King in New York, Edwards Calls for Wars End
description: Former Senator John Edwards was greeted by thunderous applause in Manhattan yesterday when he called for an immediate pullback of troops from Iraq.

title: December and May: Desire vs. Ick Factor
description: As a decrepit womanizer in Venus, Peter OToole has a mouth that hangs open much of the time: a sign of advanced age, and the better to drool over the young woman he desires. He is meant to be a sly old goat not a dirty old man, so harmless that the films creators actually make the poor guy impotent. But while Mr. OToole can be wonderfully charming as Maurice, an actor savoring his final lust, this film needs a reality check: there is a significant ick factor in watching Maurice leer.

title: Democrats Are Unified in Opposition to Troop Increase, but Split Over What to Do About It
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  The White House sought Sunday to head off building pressure in Congress to cut off or limit financing for sending more troops to Iraq.

title: U.S. Commander Warns of Long Struggle in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 15  With the first wave of additional soldiers already arriving in Iraq to bolster a new campaign to secure this beleaguered capital city, the top American military commander warned that it could take months before there are any real signs of progress.

title: U.S. Defense Chief Meets Blair, Seeking Support for Iraq Plan
description: LONDON, Jan. 14  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates met with Prime Minister Tony Blair here late Sunday on the first stop of a weeklong trip to Europe and the Middle East aimed at winning support for the White House plan for stabilizing Iraq.

title: China and Asean in Services Pact
description: CEBU, Philippines, Jan. 14  China signed a new trade agreement on services with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations here on Sunday, and won support for its initiative to reconvene negotiations with North Korea over its nuclear weapons program.

title: BPs Chief to Join Apax, a Private Firm
description: LONDON, Jan. 14  John Browne, chief executive of BP, will become chairman of the advisory board of the private equity firm Apax Partners when he leaves the oil company in July.

title: After the Months of Marketing Comes the Day of Reckoning
description: For video-game players, the holidays are clearly the busiest, most wonderful time of the year. The shopping season is when most of the biggest games are released and when hardware makers like Nintendo and Sony usually unveil their snazziest products. (Think of Novembers Wii and PlayStation 3 debuts.)

title: Scaling a Bach Monument With a Masterly Touch
description: It seems remarkable at first glance that the annual weeklong Carnegie Hall choral workshops, founded by Robert Shaw in 1990, have only now gotten around to Bachs St. Matthew Passion, perhaps the cornerstone of the Western choral literature. But anyone who attended any of the workshop sessions last week must have come away with a new appreciation of just how vast and varied a canvas the St. Matthew is, and how difficult to prepare in a mere six days with an ad-hoc chorus.

title: Bill Moyers and Ken Burns Are Back on the PBS Schedule
description: Bill Moyers will again have a regular presence on PBS on a Friday-night public-affairs series, while the documentarian Ken Burns, 53, has agreed to work for the public broadcaster for 15 more years, the network announced on Saturday. It also revealed the slate for its America at a Crossroads series of documentaries, scheduled for April.

title: Bloggers Take on Talk Radio Hosts
description: A San Francisco talk radio station pre-empted three hours of programming on Friday in response to a campaign by bloggers who have recorded extreme comments by several hosts and passed on digital copies to advertisers.

title: California Freeze Threatens States Citrus Crop
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15  California farmers braced for the worst today, as a bitterly persistent cold snap seemed likely to deal a serious blow to the states billion-dollar citrus industry.

title: Frolicsome L.I. Dolphin Visit Turns Fatal
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Jan. 14  The enchantment with a school of dolphins, feeding and frolicking in the local bays north of here last week, has turned to alarm, after four of them died over the weekend and the others grew increasingly sluggish and showed signs of distress.

title: New York Rabbi Finds Friends in Iran and Enemies at Home
description: MONSEY, N.Y.  It was a bizarre sight: a cadre of Orthodox Jews, with their distinctive hats, beards and sidelocks, standing alongside President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran last month at a conference in Tehran on the Holocaust.

title: Building a Church, and Paying Off a Sacred Debt
description: As his 7-year-old daughter lay near death, Danilo Florian raged. The doctors could do no more. His prayers  a desperate turn to the religion he had abandoned long ago to pursue a successful jewelry business  seemed equally futile.

title: New CDs
description: SLOAN Never Hear the End of It (Yep Roc)

title: Politicizing Prosecutors
description: The Bush administration has appointed an extreme political partisan as the new United States attorney for Arkansas. Normally, the Senate would have vetted him, and quite possibly blocked his appointment. But the White House took advantage of a little-noticed provision of the Patriot Act, which allows it to do an end run around the Senate.

title: Library Decides Not to Close to Thwart Rowdiness
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 14  The townships libraries will remain open during after-school hours, now that local officials have come up with ideas on how to help keep unruly students from disrupting other patrons.

title: Manhattan: Officers Claim Harassment
description: A group of black and Latino police officers have accused the Police Department of singling some of them out for harassment by noting, in their personnel files, which officers were part of a 1999 discrimination lawsuit. Several officers who have reviewed their files recently found notes identifying them as complainants in the discrimination suit against the department, which the city settled for $26.8 million in 2004, said the officers lawyer, Norman Siegel. The notes effectively label them as troublemakers and could hamper their chances for promotions or transfers, he said at a news conference yesterday with members of the National Latino Officers Association of America and 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care. A spokesman for the department, Chief Michael Collins, declined to comment.

title: Boys and Girls Use Social Sites Differently
description: Older teenage girls are far more likely than younger girls, or boys of any age, to use social-networking sites like MySpace or Facebook, according to a recent study by the Pew Internet & American Life Project.

title: Dora E. McDonald, Secretary to Martin Luther King in 60s, Dies at 81
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 14  Dora E. McDonald, who served as secretary and confidante to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the most turbulent years of the civil rights movement, died on Saturday. She was 81.

title: Trial Is Set to Begin for Former Cheney Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, will go on trial on Tuesday, nearly three years after a C.I.A. operatives name appeared in a newspaper column, setting off a major investigation of who leaked the name and why.

title: Hollywood Asks YouTube: Friend or Foe?
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14  Did you miss Eminems hit movie 8 Mile? Youre in luck: Many of its rap battles and other major scenes are available for viewing on YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google. Indeed, until recently, the entire film was there, broken up into 12 nine-minute chunks to get around YouTubes ban on longer clips.

title: A Pianist With a Soft Touch, Except When It Becomes Grand
description: The young pianist Gerald Clayton doesnt play too long or too loud, except by precise strategy. He uses swing rhythm as a foursquare entity, rather than warping it or battling against it; hes averse to dissonance except as tiny, unobtrusive details in a powerful euphony. Hes unusually presentable.

title: The Texas Strategy
description: Hundreds of news articles and opinion pieces have described President Bushs decision to escalate the Iraq war as a Hail Mary pass.

title: U.S. and Iraqis Are Wrangling Over War Plans
description: This article was reported by John F. Burns, Sabrina Tavernise and Marc Santora, and written by Mr. Burns.

title: Gates Says U.S. Resolved to Remain in Persian Gulf
description: KABUL, Jan 15  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that Iran was acting in a very negative way in the Middle East and that the United States was building up its forces to demonstrate its resolve to remain in the Persian Gulf.

title: Keeping Tabs on Our Kids Weight (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Hussein Allies Are Hanged; One Is Decapitated
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 15 Iraqs turbulent effort to reckon with the violence of its past took a macabre turn today when the execution of Saddam Husseins half-brother ended with the hangmans noose severing his head from his body after he fell through the trapdoor.

title: Step 1
description: Welcome to a new blog about science. Ill spare you a grand opening statement or plan of action. Im hoping to follow the scientific method: experiment to see what works and what doesnt. I want to give you a chance not just to discuss science but to participate in it. Ill be guided by whats in the news, whats intriguing, whats fun. And, of course, by what you want to explore. Please keep me posted.

title: Misbegotten Schedules Its Broadway Run
description: As expected, the Brooks Atkinson Theater will be home to Eugene ONeills Moon for the Misbegotten when that Old Vic production, starring Kevin Spacey, Eve Best and Colm Meaney of the London cast, arrives on Broadway in the spring for an 84-performance run.

title: London Rings Cast Is Announced
description: The Shakespearean actor Malcolm Storry will play the role of the wizard Gandalf in the London production of the $25 million musical "The Lord of the Rings," the BBC reported.

title: Red Carpet Arrivals
description: Photos from the red carpet at the 2007 Golden Globe Awards.

title: The Spy Who Did Not Come In From the Cold
description: Director Billy Ray  Shattered Glass  has a movie about Robert Hanssen, the FBI guy turned spy. Writing in CQ, Jeff Stein points to a few things not to look for in the upcoming movie.

title: The War at Home: Purse Power
description: Democrats have, for the first time during this administration, the power of the purse. But will they wield it to prevent a troop increase?

title: Fright Wig
description: How epic is the appeal of the And I Am Telling You shout from Dreamgirls? Well, Anne Thompson points us to Jake Gyllenhaals version on SNL in drag, and he sort of pulls if off. A combination of great stage moves, a decent frock and well-cut biceps decorates the song, much to the delight of two cowboy lovers in the audience. The song has legs, and the boys got arms.

title: The Not-So-Smart Money
description: The Bagger almost forgot to make his predictions because he knows not a single member of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and thinks the inside tips he got from one of the guys building the scaffolding over the pool for the HBO party might be riven with agendas:

title: A U-Turn Into the Ditch
description: Ah, the Golden Globes, those snowballs of ephemera that set stars hearts atwitter and serve as an excuse for seven, count em seven, huge parties in and around the event. For those of you who dont live and die on this stuff, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association divides up the movies into two categories: dramatic and comedy/musical. The big throwdown in the dramatic category is between Babel, which received seven Globe nominations, the most of any film, and The Departed, which won best picture at the Broadcast Critics awards on Friday. Dreamgirls and Little Miss Sunshine are the major contenders in the comedy/musical category.

title: Saddam Video Is Blamed for Deaths of More Children
description: Saddam Husseins half-brother and a close aide were hanged before dawn in Iraq today, but unlike the former leaders trip to the gallows, the video of the executions (and apparently there was video taken) is being withheld  though protecting young children is probably the last thing on the Iraqi governments mind.

title: Putting Jack in a Box
description: If all goes as planned, Jack Nicholson will have a large supporting role at the Globes. Heck, he can just sit there, all inscrutable and jolly at the same time behind the glasses, and own the joint. The Bagger saw the secret, multi-layered seating chart  from a certain angle it looked a lot like the presidents diagram of victory in Iraq  and Jack is front and center. And then the Bagger saw this video and it reminded him why theres Jack and then theres everybody else.

title: Manhattan: Subway Rider Dies on Tracks
description: A 58-year-old subway rider died early yesterday when he fell to the tracks beneath a moving No. 6 train just south of Brooklyn Bridge station, the police said. The man, Jose Montanez, of Brooklyn, was standing between two cars, urinating, when the train began to loop around, having come to the last stop on the line, the police said. During the tight turn, Mr. Montanez's head was pinched between the ends of the cars and he was thrown to the tracks, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene

title: This Is Only a Test
description: Repeat offenders at this blog know that last year, the Bagger made a lot of rookie blunders when it came time to fly west and actually cover events.

title: 8,000 Antennas (And Nothing on TV)
description: What will it take to get a decent extraterrestrial DVR?

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Edwards-Clinton New York Rumble
description: The 2008 presidential campaign (yes, we know it is January of 2007) is beginning to get a bit testy. On Sunday night, John Edwards implicitly criticized Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons position (or, as he charges, lack thereof) on the war in Iraq while speaking at a church in Manhattan. In response, a Clinton adviser attacked Mr. Edwards by name for using negative campaign tactics.

title: Golden Preparation
description: The Carpetbagger finds swag and Tom Hanks, of all people, as the Golden Globes ramp up.

title: Golden Globe Winners
description: Some of the actors, actresses and directors who won at the 2007 Golden Globe awards.

title: Too High a Price for a Wii
description: This tragedy speaks for itself.

title: Video: Golden Preparation
description: The Bagger finds himself deep in the ramp-up to the Golden Globes. Luckily, he gets some help from swag, a seating chart and Tom Hanks, of all people.

title: Vows: Jordan & Joseph
description: Jordan Chattman is glad she was patient when Joseph Shumofsky told her he was not ready for an exclusive relationship.

title: Its Really, Really, Really All About the Work. Really.
description: The Bagger will be looking for the most disingenuous sound bite from a Globe nominee. Join in the hunt from in front of your television and if your choice is picked, some fabulous Times swag  if there was any such thing  could be yours. Enter early and often as the evening progresses. Remember, they lie because they must.

title: Whither the Historians of Science in the Age of E-mail?
description: In his Critical Point column for the January issue of PhysicsWorld, Robert P. Crease, chairman of the Department of Philosophy at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and a historian at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, suggests that the steady rise of e-mail over letter writing is affecting not only how scientists communicate, but also how future science historians will have to work.

title: The New  And Not-so-new  Miss Brazil
description: Sir John Harington would not entirely approve of what the graphics people in the Week in Review section did to Miss Brazil on Sunday. Sir John, a 17th century British poet, had a rigid idea of what constituted beauty:

title: Tangled Up in Blue
description: The Bagger stepped out to his battle station on the carpet at the Golden Globes. This carpet is longer than the Cross Bronx Expressway and quite a bit busier. When he found his spot, it was ensnared in enough television wires to take down the bulls of Pamplona. Through a series of fist fights careful negotiations with trolls who work in television his colleagues who are also working the carpet, he was able to find a place to stand.

title: Secure Connection
description: Tony Angellotti, the veteran Oscar consultant who is pushing United 93, came by and marveled at the level of security. I have never seen anything like it, he said, staring at all the guys in sunglasses and earpieces. Did someone receive a threat or something?

title: Crypt Keeper
description: Okay, the Bagger is sorry he insulted Joan Rivers. She just stopped to see the reporter standing next to the Bagger  Aniko Navai of Hungarian television  and seemed very nice. She explained that the brooch she was wearing once belonged Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. When asked where she got it, she cracked, From the grave. After pausing a beat, she admitted she bought it at Sothebys.

title: Who Cares About the Price of Gas?
description: The Detroit Auto Show, which is going on right now, is full of cars purporting to solve the problem of the moment: the political, economic and environmental damage done by Americas dependence on oil. GM is showing off an electric Chevy; Ford has an adorable diesel hybrid that gets 65 miles per gallon, and Toyota is parading not only its hybrid Prius but also a huge truck that next year will be available in a model that runs on ethanol.

title: The Vanishing Pension
description: It is an old tactic of corporate America. Put the pretty stuff in the news release. The not-so-nice things get buried in lengthy filings.

title: Tightwads and Spendthrifts
description: As promised in my column today, heres a survey you can take to see where you fall on the Tightwad-Spendthrift scale developed by economists at Carnegie Mellon University. I took it, and the result independently confirms the shopping brain-scan experiment I describe in the Science Times column: Im a spendthrift.

title: Winning, By Design
description: Hugh Laurie, beautifully fumbling for the right words, suggested that Dolce & Gabbana write acceptance speeches. Thats funny. Does Laurie have any idea what a pair of single-minded fashion designers would say? I want to thank my tailor. And, anyway, do designers need any more plugs tonight? I like the way some of the actresses casually sweep a manicured hand over their costume, turn out a foot, and say, My dress is by Carmen Marc Valvo, my jewelry is from Fred Leighton and so forth and so on. I feel as though Im watching Lets Make a Deal.

title: What Joke?
description: Eddie Murphy was asked whether his victory in the supporting actor category was especially sweet because late night comedians were making jokes about his turn as a James Brown wannabe.

title: The View From a Distance
description: One of the members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which tends to bow and scrap in the presence of celebs, mentioned to Meryl Streep, who was in the interview room, that she looked 25 years old.

title: A Hairs Breadth
description: Red-carpet hair is apparently like a mood swing. One season all the young actresses wear their hair down and loose, the fashion police accuse them of being hopeless slobs, and the next year were looking at Mildred Pierce. I found

title: In the Ruins: Tell Hamoukar
description: Archaeologists are discovering that the first cities may have developed in multiple places at the same time.

title: Dreams Fulfilled?
description: Is it just the Bagger or does it seem like the Dreamgirls machine is roaring back to life? With wins in both supporting roles, the mojo seems to be there. As one studio exec said on his way in, Dreamgirls will win because it has to.

title: Those Heroes of Darfur
description: Id wanted to cite many more examples of ordinary people taking on the cause of Darfur in extraordinary ways in my Tuesday column, but there just wasnt space.

title: Looking East, Veering West
description: The Bagger was just about to pounce on Clint Eastwood after he came off the stage, when this guy totally cut me off. The Bagger turned to give him his Bad Look, when he found himself staring into the face of Hugh Grant. Never mind.

title: The Red  Catwalk?
description: The runway season is about to begin, and Im starting a new blog on nytimes.com called On the Runway (look for it early next month) and I was thinking tonight how closely the resembles the runway. This is not entirely surprising, given that many of the dresses at the Globes  Cate Blanchetts black lace Alexander McQueen gown, for instance  came directly from the catwalk. Its good for fashion and, I suppose, it means that someone is actually paying attention to the direction and creativity that designers have to offer, especially designers who know something about fit and proportion. Its a little like Warren Beatty saying its nice to have the freedom as an actor and a director to say what you think.

title: Plenty of Shine in the Globes
description: In spite of the casual-cosy atmosphere of the Globes, the fashion tonight looked every bit as glamorous as what we now expect from the Oscars. The TV actresses seem inseparable from the movie stars; no longer on the designer short-straw list. Even the women of Desperate Housewives seemed a little less eager to please this time. Of course theres a freakishness about Hollywood glamour, hugely aided by Botox-smoothed faces and bad dye jobs. But even that didnt seem as conspicuous this time. As a run-up to the Oscars, at least a couple of trends emerged  namely, the amount of colorful dresses (Drew Barrymore in pale pink Dior, America Ferrera in a purple Brian Reyes) and abstract flower prints (Sienna Miller in Marchesa, Chloe Sevigny in Yves Saint Laurent). Lacquered sequined dresses looked boring, and generally the emphasis was on drapery rather than embellishment. I wondered about the flower ornament behind Hilary Swanks ear. It looked faintly self-conscious, and I bet she couldnt wait to have a good scratch.

title: A Bonbon  for Everyone
description: The Bagger likes the way the story turned out, with everybody getting a taste. Babel, which had seven nominations but got blanked most of the night, ended up with the ultimate prize. But Martin Scorsese finally has a major directing award for The Departed, and boy did he seem happy.

title: Blood and History
description: Q. Is there an evolutionary reason for human blood types?

title: Obama Takes First Step Toward Running in 08
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama took his first step into the Democratic presidential race today by opening an exploratory committee to raise money and begin building a campaign designed to change our politics. He said he would make a formal declaration Feb. 10 in his home state of Illinois.

title: Somali Government Ends Ban on Radio Stations
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 16  Mogadishus radio stations were back on the air today after Somali authorities lifted a short-lived media ban.

title: Pap Test, a Mainstay Against Cervical Cancer, May Be Fading
description: The big news in the war on cervical cancer is the new vaccine recently approved to prevent the disease. But another major change that will affect millions of women is also under way, though more slowly and quietly.

title: For the Record
description: A listing of credits in Weekend on Friday with a film review of God Grew Tired of Us omitted an editor and a producer. In addition to Geoffrey Richman, Johanna Giebelhaus edited the film, and Tommy Walker was a producer, along with Molly Bradford Pace and Christopher Quinn.

title: Report Faults BP for Safety Procedures
description: LONDON, Jan. 16  Poor management and cost-cutting created a dangerous work environment at oil giant BP, according to a report released today based on hundreds of interviews with employees.

title: Man Arrested in Killing of Police Officer in N.J.
description: Following an intense weeklong manhunt, authorities arrested a man on this morning and charged him with the shooting death of an off-duty police officer from Paterson, N.J.

title: At Some Airports, Cellphones Can Check In Passengers
description: MILAN, Jan. 15  Cellphone users anticipating the arrival of in-flight chatting and text messaging can also use their phones to expedite check-in at some airports in Japan and Europe.

title: Kidnapping Suspects Co-Workers Stunned
description: KIRKWOOD, Mo., Jan. 15  Behind the counter at Imos, a pizzeria on one of the main strips in this affluent suburb southwest of St. Louis, the cooks and cleaners have a penchant for joking around. So when they realized that a kidnapping suspect in the area had a vehicle that matched the description of the managers white pickup truck, they had a few rounds of fun with it.

title: Castro Serious; Report Details Many Surgeries
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 15  Fidel Castro has had a series of surgeries in recent months to repair pouches that formed in his large intestine and later the onset of a serious infection in the lining of the abdominal cavity, a Spanish newspaper reported Monday.

title: Bears Coach Notes Milestone
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 15  Three years ago Monday, Lovie Smith was named to succeed Dick Jauron as the Chicago Bears head coach. This year, the anniversary of his hiring coincided with the day set aside to remember the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Anne Ophelia Todd Dowden, 99, Artist, Dies
description: Anne Ophelia Todd Dowden, a renowned and popular botanical artist whose subjects ranged from the flowers found in Shakespeare to the weeds found in New York City, died Thursday in Boulder, Colo. She was 99.

title: G.E. Buying a British Aerospace Company
description: General Electric said yesterday that it would pay $4.8 billion in cash for Smiths Aerospace, the cockpit electronics arm of the London conglomerate Smiths Group. The two companies also said they would pool their technologies for detecting bombs, chemicals and other dangerous items into a joint venture, Smiths GE Detection.

title: Queens: Shortcut Through Airport Screening
description: For the first time in the New York area, starting today some passengers will be able to pay to bypass an airport security screening line through a program that has come to Kennedy International Airport. But for now, they will still have to take off their shoes. Clear Registered Traveler, a private service that prescreens travelers for a $100 annual fee, will open a kiosk at Terminal 7 today, making Kennedy the second American airport  after Orlando International Airport in Florida  to provide an express lane through security, said Steven Brill, the chief executive of Clear. The kiosk at Kennedy is equipped with a device that scans travelers shoes on their feet, but so far the Transportation Security Administration has not given final approval for its use at Kennedy, Mr. Brill said.

title: Chiefs Departure Ignites Criticism of BPs Structure and Environmental Policies
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  Is the oil and gas giant BP that John Browne built fundamentally flawed?

title: Rangers Have International Flavor; Devils Go Native
description: The Rangers and the Devils have always been separated by more than the Hudson River and a few miles of swampland. Their bitter rivalry has pushed them to opposite ends of many scales  playing style, free-agent signings  making it often seem as if one serves as the others N.H.L. counterweight.

title: Serious German Violinist Gets a Rock Star Ovation
description: There were several hallmarks to the concert on Sunday afternoon by the Met Orchestra. This was the orchestras 50th program at Carnegie Hall since James Levine and his players emerged from the pit at the Metropolitan Opera to present a full-fledged symphonic concert in the hall in 1991. The program offered Mr. Levines restrained take on Brahmss Third Symphony, and a major premiere by the formidable modernist composer Charles Wuorinen.

title: Bradford Washburn, Explorer, 96, Dies
description: Bradford Washburn, an explorer and cartographer who, as director of the Museum of Science in Boston, led a landmark mapping of the Grand Canyon, died on Wednesday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 96.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Time
description: Al Hubbard, the economic adviser whos coordinating the administrations energy strategy, recently promised that President Bush would produce headlines above the fold that will knock your socks off in terms of our commitment to energy independence. Every president since Richard Nixon has talked this way, while every year the country slides further into dependency. Mr. Bushs overpromising has included a forecast that we would all be buying hydrogen-fueled cars in 20 years and his pledge a year ago to rid the country of its addiction to oil.

title: After Wrong Turn, Bears Manning Retools His Life
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 15  In football and in life, Chicago Bears cornerback Ricky Manning has made mistakes. Messy, public ones. But he cannot complain about the way things have turned out.

title: At Least 70 Killed in Blasts at University in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 16  At least 70 people were killed at a largely Shiite university in northeast Baghdad on Tuesday when a wave of explosions tore through a crowd of students and employees leaving the schools main gate minutes after classes ended.

title: Rules Changes
description: Lobbyists are not the only ones who wine and dine lawmakers and their staff members. Journalists hoping to lubricate sources sit elbow-to-elbow with lobbyists at the same Washington steakhouses and watering holes. And, perhaps inadvertently, the new ethics rules passed by the House require lawmakers and aides to be very careful about letting reporters pick up the tab.

title: Giants Reese Reaches Top of a Long, Steady Climb
description: A boy from a poor, rural corner of Tennessee, who never played professional football, has grown up to become the leader of the Giants football operations.

title: Cold Raises Fear in California Citrus Industry
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15  Farmers braced for the worst on Monday, as a persistent cold snap seemed likely to deal a serious blow to the billion-dollar California citrus industry.

title: Cars on the Edge, and Other Doubts
description: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

title: Humble Brass Was Even Better Than Gold to a 16th-Century Tribe in Cuba
description: Because of its otherworldly brilliance, the 16th-century Tano Indians of Cuba called it turey, their word for the most luminous part of the sky.

title: Wilting in the Heat, Sharapova Pulls Off a Late Escape
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 16  The temperature here had hit and passed 100 degrees, andit was if someone had slowed down reality. Maria Sharapova, usually brisk about her business and eager to wield all that ferocious power, was creeping about Rod Laver Arena between points at a koalas pace, her stomach cramping and her thoughts clouding.

title: Where Theres a Plant, Shes Got an Answer
description: In the long-ago New York of Edith Wharton, during the golden age of estate gardens, big men wanted big things, including big plants. The Horticultural Society of New York, founded in 1900, was the gaudy instrument of their will.

title: 17th-Century Remedy; 21st-Century Potency
description: A 252-year-old botany text may seem an unlikely place to prospect for potential new medical treatments, but a team of scholars have done just that, and the effort may lead to the development of an important new antibiotic.

title: Immunizations: More Education May Not Mean More Vaccination
description: Children of women with less than a high school education are more likely to have received timely childhood vaccinations than the children of college graduates, according to a new study.

title: A Visa Problem in Canada, and an Excursion to Spain
description: Isabel Bayrakdarian, the soprano, and Russell Braun, the baritone, were to have shared a recital on Sunday afternoon at the Morgan Library & Museum. Both singers are Canadian, as are the pianists they work with, and at the last minute, visa problems prevented Mr. Braun from traveling to New York. So Ms. Bayrakdarian and her pianist, Serouj Kradjian (they are also married), added two groups of songs and a solo piano work to the Schubert and Pauline Viardot groups they had planned, and had the recital all to themselves.

title: Are You Ready to Lose?
description: Anne M. Fletcher devised a readiness check for teenagers who are contemplating weight loss. Each question can generally be answered with very, sort of or no/not very.

title: Israeli Leader Faces Inquiry Over Bank Sale
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16  An Israeli prosecutor ordered a criminal investigation today to determine whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert tried to improperly influence the privatization sale of the countrys second-largest bank in 2005.

title: Diet Supplements and Safety: Some Disquieting Data
description: Correction Appended

title: Crawford Does Not Start, but He Finishes for Knicks
description: Charted on a line graph, the zigs and zags of Jamal Crawfords Knicks career would create one long and very jagged mountain range across the page. He zigs between starter and reserve and starter again. He zags from ace shooter to slumping shooter and back again.

title: A Rifle in Every Pot
description: Knoxville, Tenn.

title: Tracking Outsourced Bonanzas
description: The new Congress is promising far tighter oversight of Bush administration spending programs, and few targets are more in need of scrutiny and daylight than the outsourcing of government programs to private contractors. This highly lucrative world quietly ballooned by 86 percent  to $377 billion annually  during the first five years of the Bush administration, according to Congressional estimates. Outsourced spending, on Iraq, Katrina and other bonanzas, has grown twice as fast as other discretionary spending, according to Representative Henry Waxman, the California Democrat who is chairman of the oversight and reform committee.

title: Bush Says Iraq Fumbled Executions
description: President Bush said today that the Iraqis had fumbled the executions of Saddam Hussein and two of his deputies, and that the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has still got some maturation to do.

title: With New Urgency, U.S. and South Korea Seek Free-Trade Deal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15  United States and South Korean officials resumed free-trade talks Monday amid growing skepticism that the two governments can narrow their differences before President Bushs authority to move an agreement quickly through Congress expires.

title: Panel Urges Marshall Plan to Improve Middle Schools
description: A coalition of community groups is calling for the city Department of Education to develop a Marshall Plan for middle-grade schools, saying that all too often, the sixth through eighth grades become pathways to failure.

title: Defense Secretary, in Afghan Capital, Scolds Iran
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 15  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that Iran was acting in a very negative way in the Middle East and that the United States was building up its forces to demonstrate its resolve to remain in the Persian Gulf.

title: Turning the Grief-Stricken Toward Organ Donation
description: There was barely a mark on her 9-year-old daughters head, and when doctors told Surangni Gunaratne that the girl she adored was brain dead, she responded with fury. I yelled at them, I said they had no feelings, she said, and I told them to get out.

title: Jockeying to Be First State
description: Last week New Hampshire seemed to come up with a way to reassert its traditional election-year primacy despite the new 2008 schedule making the so-called first primary state the third to vote in the Democratic nominating process  after the Iowa and Nevada caucuses.

title: Valley Stream: Man Accused in Gym Thefts
description: A 33-year-old man has been accused of stealing car keys from patrons at Nassau County gyms, then stealing wallets and purses from their cars, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The police said the man, Sean A. Gluck, would take a set of keys from a locker room, then would find the car that matched the key using the horn feature on the remote lock button. Mr. Gluck would use the credit and debit cards he found in the cars to buy American Express Gift Cards and go shopping with those, the police said. He was arrested on Sunday and has been charged with seven counts of identity theft, as well as larceny, forgery and possessing stolen property.MANHATTAN: SUBWAY RIDER DIES ON TRACKS A 58-year-old subway rider died early yesterday when he fell to the tracks beneath a moving No. 6 train just south of Brooklyn Bridge station, the police said. The man, Jose Montanez, of Brooklyn, was standing between two cars, urinating, when the train began to loop around, having come to the last stop on the line, the police said. During the tight turn, Mr. Montanezs head was pinched between the ends of the cars and he was thrown to the tracks, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Labradors Still No. 1, but Yorkies, Dahling, Move Into Second Place
description: IN a dog-loving nation, the lists seem to say something.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Pompidou Center Confirms Plans for a Shanghai Outpost

title: After Sale, Rent Increases Give Some Sticker Shock
description: Dara Kane loves almost everything about Peter Cooper Village, from her spacious apartment and friendly neighbors at the complex overlooking the East River near 23rd Street to the park-like grounds and the elementary school her 7-year-old attends.

title: King Day in Atlanta, the One Without Mrs. King
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 15  Politicians, religious leaders and relatives of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. gathered Monday in the chapel that was his spiritual home to celebrate his birthday, but for the first time, they did so without the presence of his widow, Coretta Scott King, who died last year at 78.

title: Elkan R. Blout, 87, Scientist at Harvard and Polaroid, Dies
description: Elkan R. Blout, a biochemist and top science administrator at Harvard whose career included color film developing and sharpening research standards at the Food and Drug Administration, died Dec. 20 in Boston. He was 87.

title: The Claim: Morning Sickness Is a Sign of a Healthy Pregnancy
description: THE FACTS It may be among the most unpleasant aspects of pregnancy, but can morning sickness also indicate a lower risk of miscarriage?

title: An Airport Security Game That Rivals the Real Thing
description: MANY months ago, my wife got into Sudoku, which I assumed was a Japanese noodle dish when I first heard the word. She tried to explain it, but as my eyes glazed over she wisely gave up.

title: Asleep in Exhaustion, on a Sofa or on Pavement
description: I USED to think that being a war correspondent was one of the most difficult jobs in TV journalism. It is, without a doubt, the most dangerous one.

title: An Experiment and a Protest in Shantytown for Homeless
description: MIAMI, Jan. 15  When an emaciated, gray-haired woman staggered into the ragtag encampment complaining of a toothache the other day, Eugene Simpkins fed her peanut butter sandwiches from the communal kitchen and fetched her aspirin from the makeshift medicine cabinet.

title: Venezuela Ends Oil Negotiations
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 15  Venezuela will end negotiations with foreign oil companies over how it will take a majority control of their operations along the Orinoco River, the countrys oil minister, Rafael Ramrez, said on Monday.

title: Mets Clear a Comeback Trail for Sierra
description: How can you like a guy like this?

title: New DVDs
description: SIBERIADE

title: A Bishops Fall Provides a View on Soviet-Era Collaboration
description: Stanislaw Wielgus had to step down as archbishop of Warsaw. The Catholic Church played too central and heroic a role in the Polish resistance to Communist dictatorship (think of Lech Walesa taking communion at the Gdansk shipyard, or Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski, or Pope John Paul II) for anyone who is known to have collaborated with the secret police to have so prominent a role. Yet I find myself pausing to reflect for a moment about Bishop Wielgus and about how surviving in that world, especially for anyone in a position of authority, presented excruciating choices, again and again.

title: Newark: Two Men Injured Fleeing Police
description: Two men fleeing a shootout with the police were critically injured yesterday when their car crashed into an S.U.V., the authorities said. The men, whose names were not immediately released, were part of a group caught stripping a car on 12th Avenue about 8 a.m., the police said. As officers approached, most of the group scattered, but the two men got into an Acura Legend and began to back up toward the officers, said Todd McClendon, a spokesman for the Newark Police Department. Two officers opened fire on the car. The Acura sped off and crashed into a Ford Explorer several blocks away. The men were reported in critical condition at University Hospital. Charges against them were pending, the police said.

title: Netflix to Deliver Movies to the PC
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15  Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, lists more than five dozen personalities whose obituaries were published prematurely. Someone may want to add Netflix to that list.

title: The Voices in My Head Say Buy It! Why Argue?
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: Chemical Train Explosion Forces Evacuations
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 16  A train derailment south of Louisville, Ky., ignited an explosion today that forced the evacuation of area homes and a school, according to Kentucky emergency officials.

title: Fix the Dysfunctional Family Court
description: Nixzmary Brown was just 7 when she died, one year ago this month in Brooklyn, an apparent victim of brutality at home and neglect by the child welfare system. Since then, the city has added staff, upgraded training and addressed faults in the Administration for Childrens Services. Large problems still need fixing, however, and none so urgently as the citys Family Court, which state neglect has left in something between chaos and despair.

title: Second Iraq Hanging Also Went Awry
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 15  Iraqs turbulent effort to reckon with the violence of its past took another macabre turn on Monday when the execution of Saddam Husseins half brother ended with the hangmans noose decapitating him after he dropped through the gallows trapdoor.

title: Risk Reduction: It Might Pay to Remember That Folate Pill
description: Higher folate intake from food and supplements may decrease the risk of Alzheimers disease, a new study suggests.

title: Letters
description: Screening for Down Syndrome

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Saturday about a federal investigation that led to the indictment of a Michigan executive, Patrick J. Harrington, on charges of falsifying information on 76 small-business loans, referred incorrectly to the company under scrutiny. It is Business Loan Express, a unit of the Allied Capital Corporation  not Allied Capital itself. (Go to Article)

title: A Painful Account of Abuse and a Celebration of Family
description: Sadly, there is little the public doesnt know about pedophile priests and the pastors, bishops and cardinals who covered up for them. The scandal that engulfed the Roman Catholic Church peaked in 2002, when Cardinal Bernard F. Law resigned as leader of the Archdiocese of Boston. Other cases have come up, and the church has made many more settlement payments, but that first white-hot fury has eased, replaced by other scandals and disasters.

title: U.N. Puts 06 Death Toll in Iraq Above 34,000
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 16  The United Nations reported Tuesday that more than 34,000 Iraqis were killed in violence last year, a figure that represents the first comprehensive annual count of civilian deaths and a vivid measure of the failure the Iraqi government and American military to provide security.

title: At King Events, Politicians Mount New Calls for Justice
description: As New Yorkers gathered yesterday to pay tribute to the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., it was the memory of another man that asserted itself throughout the day, with political leaders demanding justice for Sean Bell, who was killed in a hail of police bullets last November.

title: Rice Speaks Softly in Egypt, Avoiding Democracy Push
description: CAIRO, Jan. 15  In the days before Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice met with officials in Egypt, the news media here were filled with stories detailing charges of corruption, cronyism, torture and political repression.

title: Population Shifts
description: Census projections analyzed by the firm Election Data Services show that population losses in Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina could cost the state a Congressional seat after the 2010 census. Louisiana is not the only projected loser: seven states in the Northeast and the Midwest would drop Congressional seats as residents migrate to the South and the West, where six states would gain seats. Texas, which has absorbed some Louisiana transplants, would gain two. The trend would seem to be good for Republicans, who have dominated those regions, though Democrats have made inroads. New districts will be drawn by state legislatures.

title: Top U.S. General in Iraq Says New Plan to Pacify Baghdad May Take Months to Show Results
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 15  With the first wave of additional soldiers already arriving to bolster a new campaign to secure this beleaguered capital, the top American military commander in Iraq warned that it could take months before there were any real signs of progress.

title: Saudi Oil Minister Expects Prices to Rebound
description: Saudi Arabias oil minister said today that he saw no need for OPEC to hold an emergency meeting about declining crude oil prices. His remarks quelled speculation that the oil cartel would take steps soon to prop up prices, which have slid by about 16 percent since the beginning of the year.

title: Scientists Warn of Diminished Earth Studies From Space
description: The nations ability to track retreating polar ice and shifting patterns of drought, rainfall and other environmental changes is being put at great risk by faltering efforts to replace aging satellite-borne sensors, a panel convened by the countrys leading scientific advisory group said.

title: Suspect Held in Killings of Women in Buffalo Area in 1990, 1992 and 2006
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 15  A factory worker was arrested on Monday in connection with three killings after forensic testing showed a match between saliva gathered at a restaurant where he had eaten and DNA evidence taken from the homicides as well as several rapes that occurred over 25 years, the authorities said.

title: Task Gets Taller for G.O.P.
description: When Senator Wayne Allard, Republican of Colorado, announced Monday that he would not seek re-election, the uphill battle for his party to reclaim the Senate in 2008 became an even steeper climb.

title: Rice Plans a Joint Meeting With Mideast Leaders
description: LUXOR, Egypt, Jan. 15  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced Monday that she would call together Israeli and Palestinian leaders within the next month for what she described as a high-level yet informal meeting in hopes of pushing along moribund peace efforts.

title: Addenda
description: Accounts

title: And for the Best on the Red Carpet ...
description: One of the bewildering aspects of the red-carpet parade at the Golden Globes last night is how many actresses said they spent little time getting dressed, breathily insisted they had no help, yet looked as if they were auditioning for a camp remake of Cleopatra.

title: At the Globes, Tears Are Fine, but Fast and Mean Is Much Better
description: Its O.K. to be teary and sincere if youre new, like Jennifer Hudson of Dreamgirls, but at the Golden Globe awards, its better to be fast and mean.

title: Gadgets as Tyrants
description: Los Angeles

title: Gulf Airline to Offer Cellphone Service, With Others in Line
description: PARIS, Jan. 15  After years of debate over the use of cellphones aboard airplanes in flight, the moment of truth has very nearly arrived. Emirates, the Dubai-based airline, installed satellite-based technology that allows voice calls and text messaging on one of its Boeing 777s late last year and expects to begin offering the service to passengers on an international route yet to be announced early next month.

title: Brooklyn: Phone Call Foils Carjacking
description: Carjackers who abducted a 29-year-old woman in her S.U.V. yesterday apparently changed their minds after her husband called to tell her that the police had been notified, the authorities said. The woman, visiting with her husband from out of state, had been waiting for him in a rented 2006 Chevrolet Equinox outside an apartment building on Park Place in Crown Heights at 2:45 a.m. when two strangers climbed in, pushed her into the passenger seat and drove off, the police said. The husband, who saw the men jump in, called 911, then called his wife on her cellphone, the police said. Apparently, the carjackers overheard him tell her that the police were on their way. They pulled over and fled on foot, taking only a wallet, the police said.

title: Compassionate Chic (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Single-Engine Plane Crashes and Burns in Driveway of a House in Wayne, N.J.
description: A single-engine plane crashed and exploded in the driveway of a house in Wayne, N.J., last night, killing the pilot, the police said. It was unclear if there were any passengers on board, they said. No one was in the house when the crash occurred, and no one on the ground seemed to be injured, the police and witnesses said.

title: For a Director on the Rise, Sarajevos War Years Linger
description: WARSAW  In December the European Film Awards took place here, the first time the event has been held in Eastern Europe. And in Warsaw, a city still blanketed by the pall of the past, two distinct cultural spheres were evident.

title: Business Briefs
description: DIGITAL TECHNOLOGY DEAL The American communications technology firm Arris has agreed to buy the digital broadcast systems maker Tandberg Television of Norway for $1.2 billion, but Tandbergs shares rose 17.4 percent on speculation of a rival bid. The cash-and-stock takeover, if successful, would create a leader in voice, data and video systems by combining Arriss broadband know-how with Tandberg TVs digital video, compression and interactive television technology.

title: Retreating Statewide, G.O.P. Finds Good News on S.I.
description: Last Novembers election was not particularly kind to the Republicans in New York State. Republican leaders were taken aback by the breadth of their statewide defeat and saw losses in some areas where they once confidently reigned.

title: A Mother Dreams of Job Security, and an End to Scraping By
description: Cassandra Bogen returned to Jamaica, Queens, from North Carolina in 1998 to take care of her dying mother. Being in her childhood home brought back a flood of memories.

title: Out of Sight, Under Fire Over Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Johnnie M. Burton, who runs the Interior Departments troubled program to collect royalties on oil and gas pumped on public lands, is under attack and out of sight.

title: Meatpacking Safety (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Car Washes and Genocide
description: Genocide may be the worst of crimes, but historically it has also brought out the best in some people.

title: H.P. to Report an Advance in Adaptable Circuitry
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15  Hewlett-Packard researchers have developed a novel way to create flexible electronic circuits that could make it routine by the end of the decade to modify and upgrade the circuitry in computer-based consumer products even after they have been sold.

title: Memo Pad
description: REGISTERED TRAVEL AT KENNEDY  The first extension of the Registered Traveler program beyond Orlando, Fla., is scheduled to start today at Terminal 7 at Kennedy International Airport as the expedited security program begins nationally. The program at Kennedy is being operated by Verified Identity Pass under the brand name Clear, in a marketing partnership with British Airways. A Clear program has been in operation at Orlando International Airport since July 2005. Clear is also taking enrollments for airports in Indianapolis, Cincinnati and San Jose, Calif. The program costs $99.95 a year (including a $30 federal fee) and requires a federal background check. Competitors, among them Unisys, are expected to begin operating their own programs later this year.

title: Beard Is Back in the Pool, but Not Over Her Head
description: Her back conspicuously turned to an arresting black-and-white photograph of herself in a bikini, the swimmer Amanda Beard sat at a conference table in a Midtown fashion showroom talking about one of her favorite pastimes, riding dirt bikes.

title: Behind the Success Stories: Adults Who Help but Dont Nag
description: Most teenagers who lose a significant amount of weight and keep it off require the encouragement and cooperation of their parents, Anne M. Fletcher found in her study of 104 adolescents who did just that.

title: Khodorkovsky Partner Disappears
description: A summary of the leading articles in Russian newspapers on Tuesday.

title: Tar Heels Rally to Top Huskies and Extend Win Streak to 20
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 15  Ivory Latta shook her fists and shuddered as the roar from the near-sellout crowd drowned out the players on the floor of Carmichael Auditorium on Monday night. Latta, a compact jitterbug and the leader of North Carolinas womens basketball team, had just swished a tie-breaking 3-pointer from the top of the key with 1 minute 1 second remaining against Connecticut in a battle of two of the best teams in the country.

title: When Being Green Raises the Heat
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: 51% of Women Are Now Living Without Spouse
description: For what experts say is probably the first time, more American women are living without a husband than with one, according to a New York Times analysis of census results.

title: A Smelly Puzzle, Solved
description: Rafflesia arnoldii is no shrinking violet. At up to three feet in diameter, its the worlds largest flower. Its also possibly the most repulsive  it looks and smells like rotting flesh (the better to attract flies, which act as pollinators).

title: Newarks Public Schools: The Path to Improvement (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Endorse New U.S. Strategy for Iraq
description: KUWAIT CITY, Jan. 16  Americas Persian Gulf allies endorsed the goals of President Bushs new Iraq strategy today. But even Saudi Arabia, one of Washingtons staunchest partners in the region, indicated deep concern about whether the Shiite-led government in Baghdad had the ability and will to halt sectarian violence and protect Sunni Arabs.

title: Success of Chechen Amnesty Plan Is Contested
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15  An amnesty program sponsored by Russia that was intended to entice Chechen militants into civilian life ended Monday with official claims that hundreds of militants had accepted the offer and that the program had further weakened the separatist insurgency.

title: Whats on Tuesday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL Theyre back, all of them: the contestants, both the screechers and the soarers; the judges, with their own peculiar brand of wit. And then theres the audience, for whom this show has become more of a popularity contest than a talent audition, leaving some questionable winners in its wake  and some who coulda, and shoulda, been contenders to go back to their garage bands (or, in the case of Jennifer Hudson, on to a different kind of dream). Tonight, the saga continues as Paula Abdul, Simon Cowell and Randy Jackson begin their search for the next singing sensation. Ryan Seacrest, the shows host, keeps the conversation flowing.

title: Little Mosque Defuses Hate With Humor
description: TORONTO, Jan. 15  When it comes to producing a funny television show or movie in Canada, producers here have a reliable stable of topics: French-English relations, urban-rural dynamics and anything that involves a bumbling politician or the United States.

title: Somalias Transitional Government Shuts 3 Radio Stations
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 15  Somalias transitional government shut three of the countrys biggest radio stations on Monday, accusing them of broadcasting incendiary propaganda.

title: A Churchs Challenge: Holding On to Its Young
description: When Frankie Lora chuckles, his bass guitar bounces and he loses the beat. Sometimes the pianist next to him stumbles and cant keep up with the choir. And one singer gets so emotional that she veers off into tearful shouts of praise.

title: She Always Had Hope. She Needed a New Lung.
description: From the time I met her, she had a phlegmy cough, the kind that can linger for months after a bad cold. Her limbs rattled and her body quaked when she coughed, as if she were trying to expel an unwelcome intruder. Her doctors diagnosed asthma, chronic but treatable. Though she was married to a doctor and had many physician friends, no one thought to question things further. It didnt help that she never complained.

title: Ginn Among Top Players Declaring for Draft
description: Brian Schottenheimer, who just completed his first season as the Jets offensive coordinator, removed his name from consideration for the Miami Dolphins coaching job yesterday.

title: After Setbacks, BP May Be Forced to Give Up Some Control of Joint Venture in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15  When BP announced a landmark investment of $6.15 billion in Russia in 2003, the event was celebrated with a healthy dose of British pomp and circumstance.

title: Britain Tries 6 in Bomb Plot That Fizzled
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  The city was still edgy, two weeks after the London bombings of July 2005, when suddenly on a summers day the horror seemed to return. On three subway cars and a bus, young men boarded with backpacks stuffed full of explosives, but there was an all-important difference: this time the explosives failed to detonate.

title: Democrats Seek the Middle on Social Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The promise may not outlast their political honeymoon, but Democratic Congressional leaders say they are committed to governing from the center, and not just on bread-and-butter issues like raising the minimum wage or increasing aid for education. They also hope to bring that philosophy to bear on some of the most divisive social issues in politics, like abortion.

title: U.S. Says Attacks Are Surging in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 15  Senior American officials said Tuesday that they had seen a threefold surge in insurgent attacks in Afghanistan in recent months, caused by militants coming across the border with Pakistan, and they vowed to hold new talks with Pakistani officials on curbing the influx.

title: Pakistan Strikes Militant Hideouts
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 16  The Pakistani military destroyed three militant hideouts in the semi-autonomous tribal area of South Waziristan along the Afghan border, an official said today.

title: Moore Gives Nets an Unexpected Lift on Offense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 15  The Nets success was clear and emphatic Monday.

title: Blazing a Paper Trail in China
description: HONG KONG  Just five years ago, Zhang Yin and her husband were driving around the United States in a used Dodge minivan begging garbage dumps to give them their scrap paper.

title: AOL Agrees to Buy Online Ad Broker for $900 Million
description: LONDON, Jan 15  AOL said Monday that it had agreed to buy TradeDoubler, a Swedish company that matches Internet advertisers with online media owners and e-commerce sites, as AOL tries to grab a bigger share of the booming global market in Internet advertising.

title: The Food Connection
description: Provide a slight prompt for Clark Troy, and he will reminisce about the best diver scallops he has ever had. Succulent, smooth, tender and luscious are words he uses, and his voice holds a certain tone of awe. He can manage similar enthusiasm for a fine steak he once ate.

title: Buyers Scarce, Many Condos Are for Rent
description: WASHINGTON  David Francos illuminated model of a proposed 10-story condominium tower dominates a sales center that, in spite of the Now Selling banner still fluttering outside, is conspicuously closed for business.

title: Promising but Fragile, Knicks Should Shun Artest
description: In his first New York City appearance in almost three years, or since he was that brawling man in the stands at the Palace of Auburn Hills, Ron Artest played it cool. He was a dogged defender, a determined driver, a generous passer.

title: Azerbaijan: Web Site Publisher Held
description: Bakhtiyar Hajiyev, a youth leader who called for protests against corruption and recent price increases for fuel and utilities, was arrested Saturday, opposition members and advocates for a free press said. Mr. Hajiyev founded a Web site, susmayaq.biz, which translates as Lets not keep silent. The site apparently angered the government of President Ilham Aliyev, said Emin Huseynov, director of the Institute for Reporters Freedom and Safety, a private Azeri organization.

title: A Meditation on Mourning, for Mothers and Generals
description: The stage is permeated with the ache of loss. Three middle-aged women and one younger one (who sometimes dons a white beard) fumble for their lines, groping for what they want to say, numbed by battering grief. Their sons have been killed in a senseless war; they want to recover the bodies. Enter the cocky young leader: he strikes poses and theatrically declaims stilted poetry, explaining that what they want is not in the interests of the people. When their emotion finally gets through to him, his delivery stumbles, and he too is at a loss.

title: Ruins in Northern Syria Bear the Scars of a Citys Final Battle
description: Archaeologists digging in Syria, in the upper reaches of what was ancient Mesopotamia, have found new evidence of how one of the worlds earliest cities met a violent end by fire, collapsing walls and roofs, and a fierce rain of clay bullets. The battle left some of the oldest known ruins of organized warfare.

title: Babel and Dreamgirls Win Top Honors at Golden Globe Awards
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 15  As the 64th annual Golden Globes unfolded on Monday, Babel won the award for best dramatic movie. And Martin Scorsese won for directing The Departed, while Dreamgirls scooped up awards for best comedy/musical and for a pair of its actors  keeping the films in tight competition for top honors in the Hollywood awards race.

title: Newark: Hospitals Use of Helicopter Is Questioned
description: New Jerseys state medical school may have improperly billed Medicaid for helicopter ambulance flights, according to a report released yesterday by a federal monitor. A former judge, Herbert J. Stern, who was appointed a year ago to investigate financial irregularities at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, noted in the report that the school had made many policy and personnel changes to address widespread problems with overbilling, nepotism and wasteful spending. But the report said that the universitys hospital in Newark might lack proper certification for its air ambulance program. Anna Farneski, a school spokeswoman, said that university officials were reviewing the certification with the state police, who also participate, to ensure that the school complied with federal regulations.

title: Iraqi Refugees Find Sanctuary, and Fellow Iraqis, in Sweden
description: SODERTALJE, Sweden  Former residents of Baghdad living in this calm Swedish town know why they left. Iraq is finished, said Taghreed Ewas, 34, a chemical engineer who fled last year after she received several death threats and narrowly escaped a kidnapping.

title: Spitzer Wants New York to Enter Stem Cell Race
description: ALBANY, Jan. 12  Five years ago, the Bush administration decided to severely limit federal financing for embryonic stem cell research, a move that set off vigorous competition among the states to provide support for a research field that many scientists say could bring about major medical advances.

title: In Patriots School of Etiquette, Class Is Finally Dismissed
description: For the past five years, the New England Patriots have been the N.F.L.s best team and its moral authority.

title: Odd Couple Ponder Bid for Tribune
description: They seem an unlikely pair: Eli Broad, the straight-talking billionaire whose art collection and philanthropic efforts to revitalize downtown Los Angeles have put him happily in the public eye, and Ronald W. Burkle, the supermarket mogul, Democratic fund-raiser and F.O.B. (friend of Bill Clinton) who tries  usually unsuccessfully  to avoid publicity.

title: East Hampton: More Dolphins Discovered
description: Rescuers discovered two more dolphins in the waters off Long Island yesterday, swimming in Noyack Creek near the eastern entrance to Peconic Bay. They were spotted 10 miles west of the Northwest Harbor cove, where rescuers have been monitoring a school of about 30 common dolphins that have grown increasingly sluggish and distressed in recent days, according to Chuck Hamilton, a regional supervisor for the states Department of Environmental Conservation. Four of those dolphins died over the weekend, possibly of starvation. It was not clear yesterday if the dolphins in Noyack Creek had adequate food. Bad weather yesterday stalled efforts to drive the Northwest Harbor dolphins back into deeper waters, where they have a better chance of surviving.

title: Hong Kong and Shanghai Duel for Financial Capital
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 15  Hong Kong and Shanghai are locked in an increasingly public struggle to become Chinas main financial center as a top-level committee in the capital, Beijing, prepares to meet later this month to map out a national financial regulatory strategy.

title: No Sprinklers in Building Where Fire Killed 9
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Jan. 15  An apartment building where a fire killed at least nine people on Saturday did not have a sprinkler system, and some units did not have smoke detectors, the fire chief said Monday.

title: A Day to Honor a Great Man, Not Low Prices
description: One of the more welcome aspects of Martin Luther Kings Birthday was the way it went unmentioned yesterday in some places. Those places are called stores.

title: Totals
104 Teenagers Who Are Role Models for Weight Loss
description: The problem is undeniable: American children, and especially American teenagers, are fatter than ever. The prevalence of teenage obesity has tripled in the last 30 years, according to Dianne Neumark-Sztainer, the author of Im, Like, So Fat. Fifteen percent of teenage girls and boys are overweight, and another 15 percent to 20 percent are at risk of joining them.

title: Naomi Campbell Pleads Guilty in Assault Case
description: Naomi Campbell pleaded guilty to assault today, telling a judge in Manhattan that she had accidentally thrown a cellphone at her maid.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Sheffield Makes Noise Again, This Time in a Book
description: In an autobiography to be published this spring, Gary Sheffield, a player known for voicing his displeasure, describes his relationship with Barry Bonds, his link to the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative steroid distribution case and his three turbulent seasons with the Yankees, culminating in his trade to Detroit last November.

title: Insights: In a Mans Offspring, a Clue to Prostate Cancer
description: Men who have only daughters may be at greater risk for prostate cancer than those who have at least one son, a new study reports, and the reason may be an alteration in the Y chromosome, the male sex chromosome.

title: Polishing the Silver as a Family of Cannibals Licks Its Chops
description: Lillian Hellman was an only child, and while she found little to envy in that fact, it is hard to imagine what contentment she would have mined from the alternative. Family life is a stifling affair in Hellmans work, the relationships among siblings founded on a will to emotional cannibalism. They replace love with possession, and from the fruits of ownership no happiness is ever squeezed.

title: A Devoted Tour Guide to a Desert of a Soul
description: In a culture that now seems long ago and far, far away, T. S. Eliot was a rock star. The poet made the cover of Time magazine in 1950, and several years later, 14,000 people turned out in Minneapolis to listen to him talk about The Frontiers of Criticism. Modernism was the ruling aesthetic inside and outside academe, Eliot was one of its high priests, and his most famous poem, The Waste Land, was hailed not only for its groundbreaking technique and glittering shards of language, but also for its difficulty  its density, its allusiveness, its recondite knowledge.

title: Money Focus
description: The groups known as 527s spent more than $400 million on federal races in 2006, a big increase over the $258 million they spent in the 2002 midterm elections. But the total was less than half of the $947 million they raised for the 2004 presidential campaign, according to final figures from the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan watchdog group.

title: Hazards: When Red Tide Moves From Ocean to Air
description: Red tides, the blooms of toxic Karenia brevis algae that appear almost every year in Florida, often lasting for months and turning the ocean red, may be dangerous to asthma sufferers  even if they dont go swimming.

title: A Promise That Never Bloomed, a Post-Minimalist Youve Never Heard Of
description: The word is that, with the art industry so flush, nonprofit alternative spaces are thriving. And why shouldnt they be? Some of them now look all but indistinguishable from commercial galleries.

title: A Powerful Storm Ices Six States and Kills Dozens of People
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15 An icy storm has caused the deaths of at least 41 people in six states since Friday, including seven Mexicans in a van in Oklahoma apparently traveling in search of jobs.

title: Caution: Grown-Ups at Play
description: A generation ago, the adult world looked from the ground as it does to a Looney Tunes character: a flash of trouser cuff, a blur of hemline, the jingle of a highball glass and poof!  it was gone. In the age of professional parenting, it is something of a mystery that any of us survived, much less learned to add, dream or brush our teeth.

title: The Warming of Greenland
description: LIVERPOOL LAND, Greenland  Flying over snow-capped peaks and into a thick fog, the helicopter set down on a barren strip of rocks between two glaciers. A dozen bags of supplies, a rifle and a can of cooking gas were tossed out onto the cold ground. Then, with engines whining, the helicopter lifted off, snow and fog swirling in the rotor wash.

title: 51% of Women Are Now Living Without Spouse
description: For what experts say is probably the first time, more American women are living without a husband than with one, according to a New York Times analysis of census results. Married couples have also become a minority of all American households for the first time.

title: Scenes of Stonington
description: In the waters off Stonington, Me., the cod and halibut have disappeared and lobsters have taken over.

title: A Coastal Dilemma
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Making a New Start
description: William McKinney found a job and support at Bible Faith Tabernacle Church in Brooklyn, and found financial assistance from the Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Spring Training
description: Take it from the Croatian national water polo league: this season, nothing beats a great pair of legs.

title: After Setbacks, BP May Lose Some Control of Russian Joint Venture
description: When BP, the oil and gas giant, announced a landmark investment of $6.15 billion in Russia in 2003, the event was celebrated with a healthy dose of British pomp and circumstance. But TNK-BP, as the venture is known, has already suffered many setbacks, and now BP may be forced to cede some control over the venture, as the Russian government steps up control of its natural resources.

title: G.E. Takes Off with a British Aerospace Company
description: General Electric said Monday that it would pay $4.8 billion for Smiths Aerospace, the cockpit electronics arm of the London conglomerate Smiths Group. The two companies said they would pool their technologies for detecting bombs, chemicals and other dangerous items into a joint venture, Smiths GE Detection.

title: AOL Agrees to Buy Online Ad Broker for $900 Million
