description: AOL said Monday that it had agreed to buy TradeDoubler, a Swedish company that matches Internet advertisers with online media owners and e-commerce sites, as AOL tries to grab a bigger share of the booming global market in Internet advertising. The deal, at 6.3 billion Swedish kronor, or $900 million, would be AOLs first major acquisition since Randy Falco was named chief executive in November, after the companys shift to a free, advertiser-supported portal from a subscriber-based service.

title: Liverpool Team Close to Deal With a Sheik
description: The Liverpool soccer club is close to accepting an $882 million takeover offer from a consortium led by the ruler of Dubai, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum. Sheik Mohammed owns Dubai International Capital, which has been examining the clubs finances for the last month. A huge amount of work has been going on from both parts. I imagine well have something concrete to say relatively soon on that, the soccer clubs chief executive, Rick Parry, told BBC radio on Sunday.

title: A Stifling Affair
description: Photos from the Pearl Theater Company's revival of "Toys in the Attic."

title: With a U.S. Partner, First Family of Canadian Media Tests Ownership Rules
description: Leonard J. Asper is part of the best-known family in the Canadian media and one of its most aggressive. The chief executive of CanWest Global Communications, a leading broadcaster and newspaper publisher, Mr. Asper has just concluded the acquisition of Alliance Atlantis Communications, best known in the United States as the creator of CSI: Crime Scene Investigation and in Canada for its lucrative specialty cable channels, for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars. But, The New York Times wonders, have the Aspers picked one fight too many?

title: Bertelsmann Is Days Away from Naming a New Chief
description: Bertelsmann, the privately owned media company, is expected to name its new chief executive in the next few days, and Hartmut Ostrowski, the sober son of a North Westphalian plumber whose favorite corporate dictums run the range from Just do it! and Keep it simple! to Put your fish on the table, is thought to be front-runner for the post.

title: BPs Chief to Join Apax Partners
description: John Browne, chief executive of BP, will become chairman of the advisory board of the private equity firm Apax Partners when he leaves the oil company in July. Mr. Browne told BP executives on Friday of his plans, which would make him one of the biggest names in a new trend of globalism sweeping the private equity industry. His years presiding over an international company are likely to help Apaxs expansion plans.

title: For Top Executives, a Need to Be Aware of the Nearest Exit
description: Being a chief executive has many perks, but job security is not one of them, especially now. A record total of 1,478 chief executive departures were announced last year at United States-based companies, 12 percent more than in 2005. Health care companies had the highest turnover of chiefs, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm. Computer companies were second, and financial firms, affected by heavy merger activity last year, were third.

title: Defending the Big Buyout
description: In a Q&A in The New York Times, William J. Holstein, editor in chief of Directorship magazine, discusses current trends in private equity buyouts with Justin B. Wender, president of Castle Harlan, a private equity firm in New York that specializes in retailing and restaurants. Among the points covered, Mr. Wender addresses the complaint that big take-private deals make money for the private equity owners and fleece the average shareholder. He rejects the notion, calling it apples-to-oranges analysis.

title: H.P. Investigator Pleads Guilty to Identity Theft
description: Federal prosecutors scored their first victory in the investigation of boardroom spying at Hewlett-Packard on Friday, when a private investigator pleaded guilty to identity theft and conspiracy charges. The investigator, Bryan Wagner, 29, of Littleton, Colo., pleaded guilty to the two felony counts during his initial appearance in United States District Court in San Jose.

title: Malden Mills Receives Competing Offer
description: A Philadelphia private equity firm, Chrysalis Capital Partners, said it made an offer to buy and operate Malden Mills Industries, a textile maker, on terms similar to the $44 million sale the company said last week it had arranged with Gordon Brothers Group of Boston. Malden Mills, which is based in Lawrence, Mass., and makes Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection on last week and said it would be sold to Gordon Brothers for $44 million.

title: Hedge Funds Pushes for Ultratech Sale
description: In the latest example of hedge fund activism, the largest shareholder in the struggling chip equipment maker Ultratech has called for management to bolster sales or consider selling the company. In a letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, a New York-based hedge fund, Thales Fund Management, called Ultratech undervalued and suggested management put the company up for sale if it cannot increase its share price this year.

title: French Court Approves Eurotunnel Restructuring Plan
description: A French court on Monday approved a multibillion-dollar restructuring plan for Eurotunnel, making way for the debt-burdened operator of the undersea rail link to emerge from bankruptcy-law protection. This opens a new episode for the company, said Judge Perrette Rey, president of the Paris Commercial Court, who gave management three years to implement a plan that aims to slash Eurotunnels 6.2 billion pounds, or $12.1 billion, of arrears by more than half.

title: Judge Approves Delphi Equity Deal
description: In a blow to the hedge fund Highland Capital Management, a federal bankruptcy judge approved a complex equity plan for Delphi that will inject up to $3.4 billion into the auto-parts supplier. The Judge, Robert Drain, called it a watershed event on Friday as he approved a framework for approaching the remaining issues in the companys reorganization.

title: Indias Power Finance Plans I.P.O.
description: Indian state-owned Power Finance has confirmed its intention to raise up to $225 million from the first sizable initial public offering in the Indian market this year. The announcement came as the Mumbai benchmark index closed at a record high after it finished above 14,000 points for the first time on Friday. Power Finance, which provides financing for Indian power and infrastructure projects within both the public and private sectors, will sell 117.3 million new shares at a price between 73 rupees and 85 rupees apiece.

title: Blackstone Buys Xstrata Stake in Exploration Projects
description: Blackstone Ventures is buying Xstrata Nickels interest in three Norway exploration projects for $15.5 million. The deal will give Blackstone all the outstanding shares of a joint venture partner and Xstrata subsidiary, Sulfidmalm, as well as full control of the Norwegian projects.

title: U.S. Investor May Be Brokering L.S.E. Deal, Report Says
description: The London Stock Exchange is in talks about its future with its second-largest shareholder, the investor Samuel Heyman, according to The Observer. An exchange spokesman confirmed for the first time that the exchange was in ongoing discussions with Mr. Heyman, who owns 10.07 percent of the shares, the report said. The newspaper said that Mr. Heyman may be trying to broker a deal to sell the exchange to Nasdaq, which holds a stake of more than 28 percent and began a 2.7 billion pound ($5.2 billion) hostile bid for the the London exchange in December.

title: Prada Thinks an I.P.O. May Be in Fashion
description: The Italian fashion house Prada confirmed on Monday it could consider an initial public offering of its shares next year and said sales in 2006 probably rose 10 percent. At this point, based on where we are it would make sense to go for an I.P.O. at some point, maybe next year, a spokesman, Tomaso Galli, told Reuters after the companys menswear fashion show. We are reaching all our targets. So obviously we can now look at a potential I.P.O., he said. The chief executive, Patrizio Bertelli, said in November that the company could look again at a listing in 2008 but not in 2007.

title: Canadian Hedge Fund Managers Will Be Required to Register
description: Canadian regulators will require fund managers to be registered with provincial securities commissions as part of a multi-pronged project to improve oversight of the hedge fund sector. The Canadian Securities Administrators, an umbrella group for provincial securities commissions, said Thursday that it would introduce new registration requirements for fund managers in an effort to ensure they have appropriate capital and insurance, and have sufficient experience and proficiency to carry out their duties.

title: Skype Founders Start a YouTube Rival
description: The founders of Skype and Kazaa, Janus Friis and Niklas Zennstrom, have chosen a name for their new online-video start-up: Joost. The start-up had been dubbed The Venice Project by company executives before the the duo came up with the name, which they apparently chose because they liked the ring of it. Joost plans to offer studios, cable stations and anyone else who wants to distribute high-quality video over the Internet, a fast, efficient and cheap distribution method. The site will rely on the peer-to-peer technology that helped Mr. Friis and Mr. Zennstrom build Skype and Kazaa, in an effort to compete in the increasingly crowded online video market.

title: Stanford Experiment Revisited: Could It Be Replicated Today?
description: This via Scientific Americans Sciam Observations blog, which notes that an artifact familiar to any of us who have sat through Psychology 101 has recently been added to the annals of YouTube: The Stanford Prison Experiment.

title: Through the Trees
description: Photos from the Huntington Theater Company's production of "The Cherry Orchard."

title: News Quiz Answers: Cheers & Jeers
description: Well, we had quite a turnout, folks. Thanks to all who participated. No need to mince words, though. Here are the answers to yesterdays quiz:

title: Hong Kong and Shanghai Duel for Financial Capital Title
description: Hong Kong and Shanghai are locked in an increasingly public struggle to become Chinas main financial center as a top-level committee in the capital, Beijing, prepares to meet later this month to map out a national financial regulatory strategy. On Monday, Hong Kongs highest government leaders and best-known business tycoons made the citys case at a series of televised conferences and briefings. They called for China to continue letting the biggest state-owned companies make their initial public offerings in the former British colony, allow the Chinese currency, the yuan, to circulate more widely here and dismantle many remaining financial barriers between the mainland and Hong Kong.

title: Just Citi as the Brand, and a Folded Umbrella
description: Citigroup, the global banking giant, is shrinking  but only its name. Executives are prepared to rebrand the company Citi and to fold up its familiar red umbrella and instead use a logo with a stylized arc above the name. The new name and look will be presented to the Citigroup board this week following a 14-month review of the banks brand, according to The New York Times.

title: An Odd Couple Ponders a Bid for Tribune
description: With the deadline for submitting bids for Tribune a day away, The New York Times examines the unlikely partnership of two possible suitors for the media company: Eli Broad, the straight-talking billionaire whose art collection and philanthropic efforts to revitalize downtown Los Angeles have put him happily in the public eye, and Ronald W. Burkle, the supermarket mogul, Democratic fund-raiser and F.O.B. (friend of Bill Clinton) who tries  usually unsuccessfully  to avoid publicity.

title: BofA Seeks a Lift on Deposit Caps
description: Bank of America has begun a push to raise a regulatory cap that bars any bank in the United States from an acquisition that would give it more than 10 percent of the nations total bank deposits, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The company has argued that United States banks are artificially small and vulnerable to foreign acquirers, the Journal said. It said the bank last year won support for changing the policy in votes before the North Carolina Bankers Association and the New Hampshire Bankers Association. Bank of America has also approached bankers in Massachusetts and other states to support potential legislation this spring in Congress, the Journal reported.

title: Commentary: In Takeovers, Truth Can Be the First Casualty
description: When hostile takeover bids rear their heads, some chief executives declare fiercely that theyre not interested. From Gerald Grinstein of Delta Air Lines to Edwin Crawford of Caremark Rx, these chief executives insist that their suitors take a hike. But the problem, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his Sunday DealBook column, is that they may not be telling the truth  and that theyre simply looking to up the ante. Read on to find out more.

title: With Ousters, EMI Group Is Said to Be Packaging Itself for Sale
description: The ouster of EMI Musics chairman and chief executive, Alain Levy, is seen by many analysts as a precursor to a radical reorganization of the British music company and a new drive to explore a sale or merger. The label, which counts Norah Jones and Coldplay (left) among its ranks, announced on Friday the dismissal of the music units top two executives, Mr. Levy and David Munns, vice chairman. Their responsibilities will be taken on by Eric L. Nicoli, the chief executive of the EMI Group.

title: Knock Three Times
description: Actors frequently speak of brave performances, but in the interview room after his victory, Sacha Baron Cohen had the goods:

title: Predicts Redux
description: The Bagger, who lost his won big bet  The Departed over Babel  correctly guessed that Dreamgirls would hit the podium, and got clobbered for his one deviation from the CW, suggesting Leo would win for The Departed. He got the rest of his picks, but that was all low-hanging fruit.

title: Victory Lap
description: Jordana Lewis, the West Coast Baguette, made the rounds as well last night and brought back this:

title: Always Use Honorifics
description: At the end of the night, as everyone was headed to their limos and cars and shuttles and taxis  no one walks in this city  one man just wanted to get the attention of the Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa. His tactic, of course, was pure unadulterated flattery: he called out Governor to the man from city hall. And of course, it worked.

title: Youre on the List. Not.
description: Los Angeles is a fine city. Great weather, except for last night, and a lot of cool neighborhoods that have nothing to do with The Business. But a night like the Globes brings out the worst in the place.

title: One Thing Led to Another
description: Clint Eastwood in the press room after winning best foreign film for Letters From Iwo Jima: I have been trying to take a vacation since Mystic River, but then Million Dollar Baby came along and then Steven asked me to do Flags of Our Fathers and I said, Ive to do that. Then, while we were doing that, the idea came about to do Letters. So now I am going to sit back and relax see if I can get that golf ball closer to the hole.

title: Gores Nonexistent Campaign
description: -Mary Duenwald

title: Mirant to Sell Six Natural Gas Plants for $1.4 Billion
description: Mirant will sell six natural gas-fired power plants to LS Power Equity Partners, an asset management company, for $1.4 billion, the energy said Tuesday. After accounting for project-level debt, Mirant will reap about $1.3 billion, money that it said it would reinvest in other projects or return to shareholders. Mirant was advised by J.P. Morgan Securities and King & Spalding, while LS Power Equity was advised by Barclays Capital and Latham & Watkins.

title: Cablevision Board Rejects Bid by Dolan Family
description: The board of Cablevision Systems Corporation yesterday rejected an $8.9 billion offer to sell the company to the Dolans, its founding family.

title: A Room With a View
description: So, after the Globes came the Globe parties. (For my colleague Cathy Horyns take on this years Globes fashion, click here.) The weirdly cold weather out here didnt help  the E! party had all the ambience of a meat locker. And the NBC gig was mostly about television types, which is fine and all, but not our thing. The Bagger did see Rupert Murdoch and Sasha Baron Cohen chatting at the Fox thing, and the Lost crew frolicking, but thats about it. He missed the Weinstein party because it was off-site and had a big line. Where to see all those movie stars in full frolic and studio execs banging bellies?

title: Express Scripts Begins $24.8 Billion Offer for Caremark Shares
description: Express Scripts began a $24.8 billion offer for all outstanding shares of Caremark Rx on Tuesday. The move is the latest step in a high-stakes takeover battle after Caremark said last week that it preferred a lower $23.3 billion deal with the drugstore chain CVS. Express Scripts is offering Caremark shareholders $29.25 in cash and 0.426 shares of Express Scripts stock for each Caremark share.

title: Population Shifts  May Help Republicans
description: Census projections analyzed by the firm Election Data Services show that population losses in Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina could cost the state a Congressional seat after the 2010 census.

title: Steve Bartman Moment
description: The Marlon McCree fumble was one of those moments in sports when you just knew the team you were pulling for  even though it was well ahead  was going to lose.

title: A Game of Emotion
description: No dispassionate analysis here. No statistical breakdowns (leave your DVOA behind).

title: In Senate Battle, a Taller Task for G.O.P.
description: When Senator Wayne Allard, Republican of Colorado, announced Monday that he would not seek re-election, the uphill battle for his party to reclaim the Senate in 2008 became an even steeper climb.

title: Race and Violence
description: Civil rights advocates say that ethnic and racial violence in Los Angeles grew at an alarming rate last year.

title: Verizon Spins Off Landlines to FairPoint
description: In an effort to focus on higher-growth wireless and Internet offerings, Verizon Communications will spin off $2.72 billion in landline businesses in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, merging them with FairPoint Communications. Verizon shareholders will own 60 percent of the new company, which will have 1.6 million local lines, 234,000 high-speed Internet subscribers and 600,000 customers. Verizon will also shed $1.7 billion in debt in the spinoff.

title: Rules Change
description: Lobbyists are not the only ones who wine and dine lawmakers and their staff members. Journalists hoping to lubricate sources sit elbow-to-elbow with lobbyists at the same Washington steakhouses and watering holes. And, perhaps inadvertently, the new ethics rules passed by the House require lawmakers and aides to be very careful about letting reporters pick up the tab.

title: Money Focus
description: The groups known as 527s spent more than $400 million on federal races in 2006, a big increase over the $258 million they spent in the 2002 midterm elections. But the total was less than half of the $947 million they raised for the 2004 presidential campaign, according to final figures from the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan watchdog group.

title: Spanish Contingent, Short on Y Chromosomes, Cancels Saudi Speech
description: Seems there was a bit of a culture clash on Monday in Saudi Arabia, where Spains justice minister, Juan Fernando Lopez Aguilar, was slated to give a speech on the challenges of globalization at Imam Muhammad bin Saud Islamic University in Riyadh, according to The Associated Press.

title: The Hill: Bush to Call Budget Bluff
description: You want to cut the deficit? Be my guest, President Bush will effectively say to the Democrats during his State of the Union address next week. Lori Montgomery and Nell Henderson of The Washington Post write:

title: Castros Death Watch
description: A report from the Spanish newspaper El Pais that Fidel Castro is gravely ill with an infection in his stomach lining, following a series of surgeries, could not be independently confirmed. And as Joe Gandelman notes on his blog The Moderate Voice, Castros son Fidel Castro Diaz-Balart has contradicted the report, saying that his father is on the mend. But Gandelman is one of several bloggers who consider it more likely that the Cuban leader will soon die.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Tancredo In (Illegal Immigrants Out?)
description: Representative Tom Tancredo, a Republican from Colorado, announced this morning on Fox and Friends that he is forming a presidential exploratory committee . From his letter to supporters:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Brian Addison joined Wirestone, Chicago, as a director for brand strategy. He had been United States brand manager for Jim Beam bourbon whiskey at Beam Global Spirits and Wine, Deerfield, Ill.

title: Obama Takes Big Step Toward 2008 Bid
description: Senator Barack Obama is announcing today that he is opening an exploratory committee for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: A Nuclear Power Renaissance
description: With concerns about global warming and energy security on the rise, countries the world over are taking a new look at nuclear energy. Some are building new reactors as fast as they can.

title: Pension Group May Throw Wrench into AOLs Swedish Deal
description: In its quest to acquire the Swedish Internet ad broker TradeDoubler for $900 million, Time Warners AOL may have run into a formidable hurdle. Shortly after the deal was announced Monday, a large TradeDoubler shareholder balked, criticizing the board-approved takeover as too low. Alecta, a Swedish pension group, says it holds a 10.1 percent stake in the company, a position that both AOL and TradeDoubler admitted amounted to a blocking stake under the deals provisions.

title: Four Stars for a Tough-Talking Campaign
description: Editors Note: In Advertising comes to you today because of the Dr. King holiday yesterday. Look for In Advertising next week on Jan. 22, its regular publication day, Monday.

title: Vote for Spano, Um, OConnell
description: From the oops file: 1199, the powerful health care workers union, just shared its template for Republican State Senate endorsements.

title: Manhattan: Body Found in Central Park
description: A city parks department employee discovered a mans body yesterday morning near the Ramble and the 77th Street pedestrian entrance to Central Park, the police said. The dead man, Donald Bond, 43, was dressed in blue jeans, cowboy boots and an argyle sweater and was lying face down on a rocky slope leading to a small creek. He had no visible signs of trauma and nothing appeared to have been stolen from him, the police said. Mr. Bond, who lived on Third Avenue and 102nd Street, was found about 8 a.m. and was believed to have died earlier in the morning, the police said.

title: Is This Parent Trying to Disown a Child?
description: Reading the latest news release from Allied Capital, you get the impression that it does not have control over Business Loan Express (BLX), where a scandal has erupted.

title: How Rising C.E.O. Pay Spreads
description: Is Kenneth Langone Patient Zero  the primary carrier of a malady that makes corporate boards feverishly inflate executive pay? At the least, he is what The New Yorkers James Surowiecki dubs a supercarrier, given his track record, which includes that of the recently ousted Home Depot head, Robert L. Nardelli. And abetting Mr. Langone is the clubby world of corporate boards, an increasingly interconnected social network where directors and executives tend to scratch each others back.

title: An Update on Kahan and Kosal
description: Last month I wrote about two young Cambodian women who had been trafficked, Kahan and Kosal. Kahan is the one who had been drugged and had been largely mute since then. Kosal is the one who tried to help her family by selling snacks in Thailand and ended up imprisoned and having to escape  but then ended up severely ill.

title: Clinton Campaign: Illness, Not Obama, Delayed News Conference
description: Yes, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wouldve have been asked all about Barack Obama today if shed held her news conference on Iraq this afternoon, as initially planned. But thats not the reason it was postponed until Wednesday, her advisers say.

title: Genesis Agrees to $1.25 Billion Buyout
description: Genesis HealthCare, a nursing home operator, said Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium of private equity firms for about $1.25 billion. The joint venture, which includes affiliates from Formation Capital and JER Partners, will pay $63 a share (a premium of about 31 percent over Genesis shares average closing price over the past 30 trading days) and assume $450 million in debt.

title: Let a Thousand Critics Bloom
description: Tom Wark, over at his wine blog Fermentations, has put together a sort of Academy Awards for American wine blogs. Here at The Times every fiber in our being screams against tawdry, shameless self-promotion, so it would never occur to me to shill for nominations, which will be accepted only through Jan. 18.

title: Evercores Secret to Getting Big? Staying Small
description: One could almost imagine the story of Roger C. Altman set to the soundtrack of Rudy or Field of Dreams. As written by Investment Dealers Digest, his is a tale of setbacks  a heart transplant and a tenure in the Clinton administration cut short by Whitewater  overcome by courage and savvy. Now Mr. Altman is known as the chief of the boutique investment bank Evercore Partners, a man smart enough to have advised on AT&Ts $90 billion acquisition of BellSouth, humble enough to have refused naming his firm after himself. (He makes sure to point the latter out.)

title: Carlyle Raises $3.1 Billion for European Fund
description: Another day, another near-record private equity fund. This time, it is Washingtons Carlyle Group, which said Tuesday that it has raised 2.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion) for its latest European buyout pool. If it maintains that pace  the private equity firm said in a regulatory filing earlier this month that it aims to raise $5.9 billion for Carlyle European Partners III  it could beat Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 4.5 billion euro fund from last year. As Bloomberg News reported, European buyouts rose to a record $200 billion last year, versus $120 billion in 2005.

title: Ought You to Be in Pictures?
description: In Broadway theaters, there have long been signs saying that photography is prohibited.

title: Lonelygirl  and Away!
description: Hey, Im out of town this week.

title: Private Equitys Profits Line P.R. Firms Pockets, Too
description: Once, private equity mavens responded to inquiries with a firm no comment. Nowadays, the non-answer is just as likely to come from an outside public relations professional.

title: What Is Your 10/20?
description: The Bagger is switching from the head of the snake  the Globes  to its tail  Sundance. Posting will be probably be light while he is getting lost in the mountains, but then again, he always has trouble leaving well enough alone when it comes to the blog.

title: Hospital Closings Mashup
description: Heres an interesting political use of a Google maps mash-up.

title: A Little Campaign Gift
description: The Long Island Republican Senate candidate, Maureen OConnell, got a nice opening gift from the Senate Republican Campaign Committee$330,000 wired into her new campaign account, according to new campaign finance filings, which immediately went out the door to her media consultants. Senators Dean Skelos and Kemp Hannon also chipped in $8,500 apiece from their campaign accounts.

title: Despite Edwards and Obama, Clinton Keeps to Her Own Schedule
description: First one likely rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, John Edwards, trods onto Hillary Rodham Clintons turf on Sunday (for a speech in Harlem) and takes a political shot across her bow on Iraq. Then another possible rival, Barack Obama, announces this morning that he is forming a presidential exploratory committee  just as Mrs. Clinton is returning from Iraq and preparing to hold her first Q&A with the media on Iraq (scheduled for Wednesday afternoon).

title: Behind in Both Houses
description: Since Democrats became the majority party in Congress this month for the first time in 12 years, House members have quietly competed over who could say the cleverest thing to distill the new state of things.

title: The Not-So-Fine Art of Hanging
description: With all the hand-wringing in Iraq over execution etiquette  most of it revolving around inexact send-offs that have sent heads popping here and there, or that left an apparent gash on the neck of Saddam Husseins corpse  perhaps someone is forgetting the harmonious mathematics that human beings have developed for the hanging arts over the centuries.

title: The War at Home: Dueling Messages
description: The battle over President Bushs plan to send more troops to Iraq escalated, no pun intended, on several fronts today, especially the tug-of-war over framing a message. For one, President Bush continued his campaign for public support for moving 21,500 troops to Baghdad and the Anbar province, giving an interview to PBSs Jim Lehrer for tonights program.

title: Blogtalk
description: Obamas big step. And why Hillary canceled her news conference. [The Caucus]

title: CVS Sweetens Caremark Deal with $2 a Share Dividend
description: Fighting back against a higher $24.8 billion offer from Express Scripts, CVS said Tuesday afternoon that it would pay Caremark Rx holders a special $2 a share dividend. The one-time move is an effort by the drugstore chain to shore up its $23.3 billion offer for the prescription benefits manager, as Express Scripts launched its tender offer for Caremark shares. Caremarks board has said it favors the CVS offer despite its lower valuation, citing antitrust concerns in a merger with Express Scripts.

title: Good Reasons to Leave Iraq
description: Foreign policy isnt my specialty, but before the Iraq war began I wrote a column cautiously endorsing it on the basis of what I knew at that time. There was no pressure on me to say anything on the subject, and I could easily have waited to see how the war turned out before offering an opinion. But that seemed cowardly. Given the importance of the issue, I felt that all opinion leaders had a responsibility to state their views beforehand and not pretend to have always been on the side that history eventually endorses.

title: Somewhere to Walk Barefoot in December
description: When we last left our story, Alison had to give a speech in Sarasota and we decided to turn that opportunity into a long weekend on the west coast of Florida  a place neither one of us had ever been  a couple of weeks before Thanksgiving.

title: Biden and, um, Not Clinton, on Obama
description: So what does Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton think of Senator Barack Obamas exploratory entry into the 2008 race? Or, for that matter, her very recent trip to Iraq?

title: Blogtalk: Obamas Presidential Exploration
description: Senator Barack Obamas announcement, on video on his website today that he had filed papers to open an exploratory committee for a 2008 presidential bid, has rocked the Caucus comments all morning and afternoon following Jeff Zelenys breaking news post at 9:54 a.m. Many comments have been of the cheerleading variety, to say the least, while others question whether he has the experience, with just two years in the Senate, to lead the country.

title: Pasta Sauce
description: The New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a midwinter pasta sauce.

title: A Citys Violence Feeds on Black-Hispanic Rivalry
description: Civil rights advocates say that ethnic and racial violence in Los Angeles grew at an alarming rate last year, continuing a trend of more Latino versus black confrontations and prompting street demonstrations and long discussions on talk-radio programs and in community meetings.

title: Already an iPhone Twin?
description: Whew! Its good to be back to regular blogging. For a few days there, it was starting to look like iPhones Posts, not Pogues Posts!

title: A Father and a Son Tell Their Own Tales of Love and Loss
description: Azazel Jacobss unexpectedly beguiling romantic comedy, The GoodTimesKid, opening today at the Anthology Film Archives, boasts a 77-minute running time thats maybe 10 percent dialogue. The remainder is spent watching alienated characters  a young woman named Diaz; her boyfriend, Rodolfo; and another man whos also named Rodolfo  drift through a deadpan-surreal city while remaining lost in their own heads.

title: Sea Sends Distress Call in One-Note Chowders
description: Stonington, Me.

title: Court Rules for Wal-Mart in Maryland Suit
description: A federal appeals court ruled today that Maryland violated federal law when it required Wal-Mart Stores to increase spending on employee health insurance, in a decision that appears likely to end a bitter yearlong legal battle that pitted state legislators, organized labor and health care advocates against the nations largest retailer.

title: HarperCollins to Close Regans Imprint
description: HarperCollins announced today that it plans to close ReganBooks, the imprint created by Judith Regan, the controversial editor who was abruptly fired last month. The imprint will officially close on March 1.

title: The Zoning Policy That Worked Too Well
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  When Simon Lim, president of the Holborn Group, bought a one-block building site in downtown Vancouver last summer, he had plans for a hotel and a commercial and condominium complex. But a few months later, city planners proposed rezoning the site, which is known as the Bay Parkade. The change would require Mr. Lim to double the amount of commercial space, with priority given to a new office tower.

title: Buffalo Suspects Uncle Misled Them in 81, Officials Say
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 16  A succession of rapes and killings stretching back a quarter-century might have been averted if the uncle of the man the police arrested this week had told the police the truth when detectives questioned him back in 1981, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: New Warning on Earnings From Maker of BlackBerry
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 16  Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry, released additional preliminary financial results Tuesday, but they gave investors no better sense of the size of the earnings restatement the company will make after a review of its stock option grants to employees.

title: Another Perspective, or Jihad TV?
description: Los Angeles

title: Working-Class Housing Complex Will Rise as Part of the Greenery
description: The Bloomberg administration, hoping to inspire more imaginative design in working-class housing, intends to turn over one of a dwindling number of large tracts of city-owned land to a development team with an unusual plan  to build a low- and moderate-income housing complex bound together by courtyards and roof gardens that would be used for everything from harvesting rainwater to farming vegetables and fruit.

title: The Missing Partner in Iraq
description: The one crucial assumption behind everything President Bush proposed on Iraq last week was that Washington would have the wholehearted support of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. None of Mr. Bushs ideas  his plan to send more American soldiers to fight alongside Iraqi units in Baghdad, his program for jump-starting the Iraqi economy, his hope of reconciling rival sectarian communities and heading off civil war  can possibly succeed without the full cooperation of the Iraqi government.

title: What $1.2 Trillion Can Buy
description: The human mind isnt very well equipped to make sense of a figure like $1.2 trillion. We dont deal with a trillion of anything in our daily lives, and so when we come across such a big number, it is hard to distinguish it from any other big number. Millions, billions, a trillion  they all start to sound the same.

title: Bo Yibo, Leader Who Helped Reshape Chinese Economy, Dies at 98
description: BEIJING, Jan. 16  Bo Yibo, the last of the Eight Immortals, Communist Party leaders who steered China through a politically volatile shift from Maoism to todays market-oriented economic boom, died Monday. He was 98.

title: Early-Morning Defeat Leaves Qualifier Upset About Officials Decision
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 17  It was shortly after 2 p.m., and Bobby Reynolds was hunched forward on a plush chair in the Australian Open players lounge. He was talking on the phone and yawning, and then yawning some more.

title: Racial Hate Feeds a Gang Wars Senseless Killing
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16  The Latino gang members were looking for a black person, any black person, to shoot, the police said, and they found one. Cheryl Green, perched near her scooter chatting with friends, was shot dead in a spray of bullets that left several other young people injured.

title: In Defeating a Fan Favorite, Monfils Wins Over the Crowd
description: MELBOURNE -- Last years Greek Cypriot celebration inside and outside Rod Laver Arena, complete with the after-midnight dancing and singing, will not be an annual event. Gael Monfils made certain of that on Wednesday night by knocking last years surprise finalist and sentimental favorite Marcos Baghdatis out of the Australian Open in just the second round.

title: Diagnosis: Acute Case of Broadway Melodium Tremens
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16  When a sitcom in the sixth year of its run starts talking about presenting an all-musical episode, it usually means one thing: grab the remote, because the writers have run out of ideas.

title: Revealing the Monet of Pencil and Paper
description: Claude Monet will forever be known for his dreamy Impressionist canvases of grain stacks and cathedrals, the seaside and of course the famous water lilies and gardens that surrounded his beloved home in Giverny. Unlike Degas, Czanne or Pissarro, contemporaries whose reputations rested on works on paper as well as canvases, Monet was the epitome of the plein-air painter.

title: In a Battle of Toothpastes, Its Information vs. Emotion
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE is fighting to be tops in toothpaste again.

title: Benny Parsons, 65, Driver Named One of Nascars Best, Dies
description: Benny Parsons, a popular champion auto racer who became a home-spun analyst for Nascars nationally televised races, died yesterday in Charlotte, N.C. He was 65 and lived in Ellerbe, N.C.

title: Trenton: Call to End Tax Refund Loans
description: As tax season begins, consumer advocacy groups from New Jersey and four other states called on Jackson Hewitt, the nations second-largest tax preparer, to stop offering refund anticipation loans, saying the loans are aimed at low-income taxpayers and carry effective interest rates ranging from 40 percent to 700 percent. The rates are possible in states that cap loan interest at 20 to 35 percent, like New Jersey, because the refund anticipation loans are issued through nationally chartered banks, which are exempt from state caps, said a spokesman for the New Jersey Citizen Action, one of the consumer groups. In a statement, a Jackson Hewitt spokesman did not address the groups charges, but said applicants are told about the terms of the loans.

title: Manhattan: New Leader for Economic Agency
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday appointed Robert C. Lieber, a private-equity executive at Lehman Brothers, as president of the citys Economic Development Corporation, overseeing nearly 400 employees who try to develop city-owned real estate, help businesses, provide financial services and revitalize the waterfront and industrial neighborhoods. Mr. Lieber, 52, who starts on Feb. 1 and will be paid $189,720, was part of a group of Lehman Brothers volunteers who last year helped the city renegotiate the lease for the World Trade Center site, along with the state and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He succeeds Andrew M. Alper, who stepped down in June; Joshua J. Sirefman was interim president of the corporation from July until this month.

title: Accused of Running Brothel, Lawyer Calls Prosecutor Unfair
description: A New Jersey lawyer pleaded not guilty to prostitution and money-laundering charges yesterday as his lawyer accused the Manhattan district attorney of letting his personal feelings influence the prosecution.

title: Iraqi Death Toll Exceeded 34,000 in 2006, U.N. Says
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 16  The United Nations reported Tuesday that more than 34,000 Iraqis were killed in violence last year, a figure that represents the first comprehensive annual count of civilian deaths and a vivid measure of the failure of the Iraqi government and American military to provide security.

title: Israeli General Resigns Over War With Hezbollah
description: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Jan. 17  The Israeli militarys chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, submitted his resignation after facing months of fierce criticism over the militarys performance in last summers war in Lebanon, officials said early Wednesday.

title: Scrappy Opponent Backs Hewitt Into a Corner, but Then Lets Him Out
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 17  It has been a rough stretch by Lleyton Hewitts standards. Once No. 1 in the world, he is seeded 19th at this Australian Open.

title: The Kids Are All Hype, and Hope
description: There is an insatiable public curiosity for teenage prodigies who can convincingly play dress-up as adults and schedule play dates with David Beckham or Ernie Els.

title: Cancer Deaths Decline for Second Straight Year
description: The number of cancer deaths in the United States dropped in 2004 for a second straight year, the American Cancer Society reported today.

title: Even for a Tomato, Looks Arent Everything
description: FOR about three years, flavor has been pitted against form in a bureaucratic battle over tomatoes. And although the governor of Florida took sides against it, flavor has prevailed.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Historians Appeal Da Vinci Code Case

title: G.M. Discloses Talks for Deal in Malaysia
description: The General Motors Corporation has been in talks with Proton Holdings, the Malaysian carmaker that is looking to sell a stake, G.M.s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said last night.

title: Cablevision Board Rejects Offer by the Dolans
description: The board of the Cablevision Systems Corporation rejected an $8.9 billion offer yesterday to sell the company to the Dolans, its founding family.

title: Settling Down
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Antiques Dealer Sues Vagrants for $1 Million
description: A Madison Avenue antiques dealer is suing a group of unidentified homeless people for $1 million, saying that the group has taken up residence outside his posh Upper East Side business, using the sidewalk in front of the shop as a urinal, spittoon and occasional dressing room, according to court papers and a lawyer for the businessman.

title: Bush Widens Iraq Criticism Over Handling of Executions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  President Bush said Tuesday that Iraq had fumbled the executions of Saddam Hussein and two of his deputies, and that the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has still got some maturation to do.

title: 2 Years in Prison for Ex-Software Executive
description: The former general counsel at Computer Associates, Steven Woghin, was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison for his role in a scheme to increase the companys quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts, prosecutors said.

title: 3 Bombs Kill at Least 70 at University in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 16  At least 70 people were killed at a largely Shiite university in northeastern Baghdad on Tuesday when a wave of explosions tore through a crowd of students and employees leaving the main gate minutes after classes ended.

title: Keep Your Shoes On, for a Price
description: Of all the hassles at the airport in this age of heightened security, perhaps the most annoying is the requirement to take off your shoes to send them through the X-ray screener. That burden will be lifted at some airports shortly  for those willing to pay about $100 a year for the privilege.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about an exhibition in Washington focusing on design inspired by Shakespeares Globe Theater omitted a passage. It should have read: And the theaters basic design elements, such as they are known, have inspired loose architectural interpretations that range from the polygonal Festival Theater in Stratford, Ontario, to a Globe made entirely of ice hundreds of miles above the Arctic Circle in Sweden. The continuing fascination with Shakespeares theater and the myriad efforts to replicate its spirit  and, in many cases, its actual form  is the subject of Reinventing the Globe: A Shakespearean Theater for the 21st Century, an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the National Building Museum here as part of the citys six-month Shakespeare in Washington festival.

title: Russia Warns Citizens of Possible Security Threat
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 16  Russian intelligence officials placed the country on an unusual high alert on Tuesday night, appealing to citizens for vigilance and saying that the government had been informed by foreign partners of a possible terrorist act.

title: Wisconsin: Man Charged in Killing of Hunter
description: A white hunter has been charged with first-degree murder in the death of a Hmong immigrant from Laos who was hunting squirrels in a wildlife refuge in northern Wisconsin on Jan. 5. The hunter, James A. Nichols, 28, says he encountered the immigrant, Cha Vang, in the woods while hunting and shot him in self-defense after a confrontation. Mr. Vangs body was discovered a day later hidden beneath leaves and wood, and autopsy results showed he died from multiple stab and gunshot wounds. The criminal complaint states that Mr. Nichols told the police that the Hmong group are bad and that the Hmong are mean and kill everything and go for anything that moves. Many in the Hmong community have said they wonder if the killing was in retaliation for a 2004 episode in which a Hmong hunter shot and killed six white hunters in north-central Wisconsin after they accused him of trespassing.

title: Icahn Takes Aim at Drug and Housing Companies
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has built up stakes in two companies, according to regulatory filings yesterday, because he believes the shares are undervalued.

title: Man Convicted Under Antispam Law
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (Bloomberg News)  A California man who defrauded users of AOL by sending e-mail messages requesting credit data became the first defendant found guilty by a jury under a 2003 federal law barring Internet spam.

title: At Berkeley Law, a Challenge to Overcome All Barriers
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: Boat Rescuers Report Success Herding Dolphins in L.I. Waters
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Jan. 16  More than 30 rescuers withstood cold winds that swept across Northwest Harbor on Tuesday to successfully herd several dolphins out of an inlet off Long Island where they have been stranded for at least a week.

title: At These Golden Globes, Everyone Is a Little Special
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16  The Golden Globes, an awards dance that takes great care to make sure everybody has a place at the table, finessed an almost perfect result on Monday night. At nearly all the various after-parties here studio chieftains had something to cheer about, which is just the way the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which administers the ceremony, likes it.

title: Weeks Notables
description: PLAYER In England, Chelsea goalkeeper Petr Cech returned to training this week for the first time since sustaining a fractured skull in a game in October. I am not saying he will play, but Cech is ready, Manager Jos Mourinho said, referring to Saturdays match at Liverpool. The best goalkeeper in the world is ready to play. After three months, he is ready. Cech will need to wear a helmet during games for the next three years.

title: 3 Lands of Orient Compete With French Holiday Favors
description: CLAMECY, France  For centuries the people of this charming mountain village believed that only blessings came from the East.

title: Checkered Flag, or Red Flag?
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11  After years of expanding its presence in the United States and beyond, the Toyota Motor Company of Japan recently issued a 2007 forecast that would make it first in global sales, ahead of General Motors.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Orthodox Jews from Monsey, N.Y., who belong to Neturei Karta, an anti-Zionist group, and who traveled to Iran last month for a conference questioning the Holocaust, referred incorrectly to the locations where the group has members. They are in the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada, among other places, but not in the Jewish settlements of the West Bank.

title: Obama Starts Bid, Reshaping Democratic Field
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Two years after arriving in Washington, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois made clear on Tuesday his intention to enter the Democratic presidential race, creating an exploratory committee while preparing to open a full-fledged campaign next month to become the nations first black president.

title: Beef Stew: New Haven Counters Texas Burger Claim
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 16  Jeff Lassen, the fourth-generation owner of a legendary hole in the wall here called Louis Lunch, can recite the history with ease.

title: In E.U.s Newest States, a Hotter Market
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Real estate sales in parts of Bulgaria have topped Europes hottest properties lists for the last two years, fed by a booming tourism sector and investment-hungry British and Irish buyers. In contrast, neighboring Romania continues to see big gains, but without yet appearing on the foreign buyers radar.

title: When a Generation That Paid Its Dues Is Asked to Make One More Payment
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Airbus Warns of Operating Loss for 2006
description: PARIS. Jan, 16  Airbus warned investors today that it would probably post an operating loss for 2006, despite delivering more aircraft than ever before, because of delays in producing the new A380 super-jumbo jetliner.

title: A Top Chefs Kitchen Is Far Too Hot, Some Workers Say
description: DANIEL BOULUD cant stand to see a detail out of place. As pans slam around him during dinner service in the Upper East Side restaurant that bears his first name, he will pause to request that a spoon be polished. How best to marry braised endive to seared beef can absorb him as utterly as the lilies in the dining room that havent opened on schedule.

title: Bloomberg Proposes Overhaul of City Schools
description: With the citys fiscal health better than it has been in years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today he would focus new energy on reforming the citys sprawling school system, beginning with empowering school principals and reigning in a teacher tenure system that some critics have said guarantees lifetime jobs to some bad teachers.

title: Islamist Fighters Captured Fleeing Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 17  Several Somali Islamist fighters and possibly some of their leaders were arrested trying to escape into Kenya, Kenyan authorities said today, raising the possibility of a sticky asylum issue.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 8 about announcements by Sony and Microsoft regarding sales of their latest game consoles misstated the price of the high-end configuration of Microsoft Xbox 360. It is $399, not $499.

title: Wall Street Matchmakers Under a New York Inquiry
description: The battle to be Wall Streets top matchmaker is getting messier. The New York State attorney generals office is investigating whether employees at Best Buy, Circuit City and the credit card processor First Data improperly provided nonpublic information to hedge fund traders, a person briefed on the inquiry said.

title: Gulf Allies Support Goals of New U.S. Strategy in Iraq
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 16  Americas Persian Gulf allies on Tuesday endorsed the goals of President Bushs new Iraq strategy. But even one of Washingtons staunchest partners in the region, Saudi Arabia, indicated deep concerns about whether the Shiite-led government in Baghdad had the capacity and will to halt sectarian violence and protect Sunni Arabs.

title: G.I.s in a Tank, Swapping Life Stories in Song
description: Party Time is an aggressively innovative show with attention-grabbing video, an imposing soundscape and other trappings generally associated with the elusive cutting edge of theater. Yet not far into it you come to an incongruous realization: this is nothing but an old-fashioned two-guys-in-a-foxhole story, with a tank replacing the foxhole and the desert replacing the battlefields of Europe.

title: Yes, Tofu. Yes, Dessert. And Yes, Hells Kitchen.
description: HAVE you run out of room for Room 4 Dessert? Up to your eyeballs in ChikaLiciousness? Then until P*Ong and Tailor  the next two scheduled openings in this season of the dessert restaurant  prove their merit, theres only one choice for a second meal of just desserts: Kyotofu.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Johnnie M. Burton, who runs the Interior Departments troubled program to collect royalties on oil and gas pumped on public lands, misstated the circumstances under which Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming, who had named Ms. Burton to run the states Department of Revenue, left office. Wyoming term-limit laws prevented Mr. Geringer, a Republican, from running for re-election in 2002; he was not ousted by voters. (Go to Article)

title: An Italian Spot, Larded With Drive
description: BE it belly or chop, from Niman Ranch or Meadowbrook Farms, as an accessory to seafood or a wellspring of salumi, pork has been staking such a piggy claim to prominence of late that its appearance in a cocktail feels less shocking than inevitable. What took the little oinker so long?

title: Potential Jurors Queried on Views of Bush Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. began Tuesday with his lawyers trying to eliminate as jurors anyone who might have strongly negative feelings about the Bush administration in general and Vice President Dick Cheney in particular.

title: Ausleses Put Sweetness on the Table
description: ALL right, people, take a deep breath, relax, and gather around. Are you ready? Today were going to talk about riesling. Not just any riesling, but German riesling  auslese riesling, to be specific, quite simply the most perplexing great wine around.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Johnnie M. Burton, who runs the Interior Departments troubled program to collect royalties on oil and gas pumped on public lands, misstated the circumstances under which Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming, who had named Ms. Burton to run the states Department of Revenue, left office. Wyoming term-limit laws prevented Mr. Geringer, a Republican, from running for re-election in 2002; he was not ousted by voters.

title: Online, Marketing and Kvetching
description: When promoting his three-bedroom home in Ormond Beach, Fla., Seth Young leaves few corners of the Internet untouched.

title: Real Madrid Club President Says a Mouthful
description: There is no fury like a club president scorned.

description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Our Values (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Totals
Mets Hope Their New Math Leaves Them With 5 Starters
description: With a month to go before pitchers and catchers report to camp, the Mets off-season priority of landing a top-flight starting pitcher remains unfulfilled. Instead, General Manager Omar Minaya indicated yesterday that the Mets would divide eight into three and hope that a group consisting of John Maine, Oliver Prez, Mike Pelfrey, Philip Humber, Alay Soler, Dave Williams, Jorge Sosa and Jason Vargas will fill the Nos. 3, 4 and 5 spots in the rotation.

title: Girls Killer Tries to Reduce Judgment, but Is Dealt Only Rebuke
description: An appeals court refused yesterday to reduce the $15 million award that Joel B. Steinberg owes to the mother of Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old child killed nearly two decades ago by Mr. Steinberg in one of New York Citys most notorious child abuse cases.

title: Justices Decline to Take Up New Eminent Domain Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The Supreme Court on Tuesday bypassed an opportunity to revisit or limit its much-disputed 2005 ruling that upheld governmental power to use eminent domain to foster economic development.

title: Now, a Chicken in Black
description: PET a Silkie chicken and you understand how it got its name. The feathers are fine and flutter in wisps in the breeze.

title: France: Parliament Acts on Presidential Immunity
description: The lower house of Parliament approved a bill that would make a president immune from prosecution while in office but create a United States-style impeachment procedure before Parliament in any case of grave failing. The bill would leave a president exposed to charges once his term ended. If passed by the Senate, the bill would mean that President Jacques Chirac, who has been in office for 12 years and has not ruled out running for a third term as an independent, could be investigated on allegations of corruption in the Paris region during his 18 years as mayor.

title: Hangings Fuel Sectarian Split Across Mideast
description: CAIRO, Jan. 16  The botched hanging of Saddam Hussein and two lieutenants in Iraq by its Shiite-led government has helped to accelerate Sunni-Shiite sectarianism across an already fragile Middle East, according to experts across the region.

title: French Visit to Tehran, Seen as Diplomatic Faux Pas, Is Aborted
description: PARIS, Jan. 16  At a time when most world powers have forged a united front against Iran because of its nuclear program, President Jacques Chirac arranged to send his foreign minister to Tehran to talk about a side issue, then abruptly canceled the visit earlier this month in embarrassing failure.

title: Irvington Man Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Off-Duty Officer
description: PATERSON, N.J., Jan 16  After an intense 10-day manhunt, the Paterson police arrested an Irvington man on Tuesday morning and charged him with fatally shooting an off-duty rookie police officer here.

title: With Eggs, the Scent of a Shellfish
description: OF all the dishes I ate for the first time in 2006, this one stands out. Its amazing how good it is, how simple it is, how easy and fast it is. Its also amazing how puzzled you must be hearing me say these things about scrambled eggs with shrimp. Have faith.

title: A DVD Copy Protection Is Overcome by Hackers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16  The 2005 science fiction film Serenity portrayed a ragtag crew of space pirates fighting to unravel the mysteries of their galaxy.

title: Ending the Prison Windfall
description: The Census Bureau typically uses the decennial census to test data-collection methods that become routine later on. The 2010 census should include a test run at counting the nations 1.4 million prison inmates at their permanent addresses instead of in prisons. That would help bring an end to a corrosive but little known practice that distorts the political process in virtually every corner of the country.

title: U.S. and North Korean Envoys Hold Talks
description: BERLIN, Jan. 17  Seeking to revive stalled negotiations to end North Koreas nuclear weapons program, the United States held two days of substantive talks with North Korean diplomats here on Tuesday and today, according to the chief American envoy, Christopher R. Hill.

title: The Power and the Potential of Indias Economic Change
description: All eyes are on China as it races to become the worlds next great power. Smart bettors would be wise to put some money on India to get there first, and Edward Luce explains why in In Spite of the Gods: The Strange Rise of Modern India, his highly informative, wide-ranging survey.

title: Aux Barricades!
description: WASHINGTON

title: Senator Clinton Calls Bush Plan a Losing Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Fresh from a weekend trip to Iraq, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton this morning intensified her opposition to President Bushs new plan to send more than 20,000 additional troops to Baghdad, calling it a losing strategy and a very bad mission and proposing new limits and conditions on the overall war effort.

title: Escape From the Nursing Home
description: New Haven

title: Unsigned Bonds Awaits Further Review
description: Six weeks after they agreed to terms on new contracts, Barry Bonds and J. D. Drew remain unsigned. Bonds hasnt signed with the Giants; Drew hasnt signed with the Red Sox. That prompts a thought. If both contracts were to fall through, the Red Sox could sign Bonds to play left field and move Manny Ramrez back to his original position in right.

title: Former Chief of U.N. Effort Faces Charges of Corruption
description: Federal prosecutors announced charges yesterday against the former head of the United Nations oil-for-food program, accusing him of receiving $160,000 in kickbacks from sales of Iraqi oil under the government of Saddam Hussein.

title: Inflation Slowed in December
description: A survey of economic conditions across the country found modest growth in the final weeks of 2006, as well as hints in some areas that the skid in the housing market is easing.

title: The Football Is Fine, but the Saints Finances Arent So Bright
description: The New Orleans Saints jubilation at beating the Philadelphia Eagles to advance to the National Football Conference championship game typified the reactions of a winning team: players embracing, Coach Sean Payton high-fiving fans in the box seats, the owner Tom Benson flashing V signs and photographers surrounding Saints players at midfield of the Louisiana Superdome.

title: Defense Portrays Harrowing Childhood as Reason to Spare Killer of 2 Detectives
description: Ronell Wilson had a miserable childhood. There were roaches everywhere. He took beatings, sucked his thumb long past infancy and failed his drivers license exam six times.

title: Talking It Over at Lunch: Toussaint and M.T.A. Chief
description: Pigs were not seen flying around the meatpacking district on Monday afternoon, but they might as well have been. That is when Roger Toussaint, the fiery president of the transit workers union, sat down to lunch with Elliot G. Sander, the new executive director and chief executive of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Oil Lease Chief Knew of Error, Report Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  A top Interior Department official was told nearly three years ago about a legal blunder that allowed drilling companies to avoid billions of dollars in payments for oil and gas pumped from publicly owned waters, a report by the departments chief independent investigator has found.

title: Goldmans Sachs Agrees to Acquire Insurance Brokerage Firm
description: The Goldman Sachs Groups buyout unit has agreed to acquire the insurance brokerage firm USI Holdings for about $1.4 billion including debt.

title: How to Choose a Fiscal Watchdog
description: In the next few weeks, New York legislators will choose a replacement for Alan Hevesi, the state comptroller who was forced to resign after pleading guilty to a felony. The new comptroller will play an enormous but largely unseen role in safeguarding the states finances for the next four years. There will be great pressure to make a political choice, but legislators should resist that instinct and vote for the most able and independent candidate.

title: Loss of a Beloved Department Store Breeds a New Kind of Superfan
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 16  Bundled in a puffy black coat, a navy blue Chicago Bears hat pulled tightly over his ears, Jim McKay worked a corner along State Street.

title: Anti-Buildup Measure to Have Bipartisan Stamp
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, an outspoken Republican critic of the administrations Iraq policy, will join two leading Democrats in introducing a resolution opposing President Bushs buildup of troops in Iraq, putting a bipartisan stamp on the looming Congressional showdown over the war.

title: Somalia Lifts Ban on 3 Radio Stations
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 16  Three radio stations were back on the air on Tuesday after the transitional government, which took control of Mogadishu, the capital, last month, lifted a brief media ban.

title: In Tins, in Cups, Teas Are in Bloom
description: Miriam Novalle had to close her T Salon on East 20th Street last summer when the lease ran out, but that obviously did not discourage her.

title: Is Live Sex On-Demand Coming to Hotel TVs?
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 16  In the world of on-demand viewing of sexually explicit material, the next step could be the ability to watch live performers from the privacy of a hotel room.

title: Text of Mayors Speech
description: The following is the text of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs State of the City address as prepared for delivery at New York City College of Technology in Brooklyn:

title: Rejected by Society, a Woman Struggles to Carry On
description: On its way to bridging past and present, the Chinese film Dam Street opens in the early 1980s with an unwanted pregnancy. Sixteen, beautiful and involved with another student, Yun (Liu Yi) manages to keep her swelling belly hidden until nearly the end of her term, when she and her secret are discovered in a school bathroom. The school expels the lovers and trumpets their moral decadence on loudspeakers that blast the news throughout their small village. The boy leaves to become a carpenters apprentice; Yun stays and delivers a baby that her mother, a teacher at the school, says has died.

title: With Boys Return, Kin Hope Normal Life Returns Soon, Too
description: UNION, Mo., Jan. 16  For a family that has every reason not to be receptive to strangers, the Ownbys home exudes hospitality, nestled among trees on an unpaved road near this town southwest of St. Louis.

title: Saudi Dismisses Call for an OPEC Meeting
description: Saudi Arabias oil minister said yesterday that he saw no reason for OPEC to hold an emergency meeting in response to declining prices, quelling speculation that the cartel would take fresh steps to stem a 16 percent decline in prices since the beginning of the year.

title: Preservation Commission Turns Down Proposal for Upper East Side Tower
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission resoundingly rejected a proposal yesterday to build a 30-story glass tower designed by Norman Foster atop a 1949 building on Madison Avenue. The decision was a major victory for a coalition of Upper East Side residents who argued that the tower would rend the fabric of their historic neighborhood.

title: Cleaner Coal Investment (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Echoes of Grief and Loss, Modulated by Humor
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14  The teddy bear seemed an unpromising portent. Coddled in a junior armchair and bathed in a cool spotlight, the raggedy little creature sat at the front of the stage, looking self-consciously forlorn, as audience members took their seats at the Huntington Theater for Nicholas Martins new production of The Cherry Orchard here.

title: Hes Frail, but Still Rocking and Preening
description: A Little Richard show includes a lot of talking and a lot of fascinating, ephemeral fuss; a couple of songs with the power of mule kicks; and a fair percentage of music that seems to have been created in an Anytown sports bar. But the subtext, now, is the limitations of the body. Age really has no business advancing on this singer, born Richard Penniman, and so what you remember is the disjunction between his lovely, widened, overexcited eyes and the frailty of his joints.

title: Inquiry Faults Management at BP in Blast That Killed 15
description: LONDON, Jan. 16  An investigation led by former Secretary of State James A. Baker III has concluded that weak leadership at BP and a lack of attention to effective safety helped create a dangerous setting that led to 15 deaths at the oil giants Texas refinery, according to the report released Tuesday.

title: Chemical Train Derails in Kentucky; Evacuations Are Ordered
description: A CSX freight train carrying chemical cargo derailed and ignited south of Louisville, Ky., yesterday, forcing the evacuation of homes, shutting down roads and sending students home from school, Kentucky emergency officials said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,008 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Bronx: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing
description: A Bronx man was arrested yesterday in connection with the fatal stabbing of a woman in her Tremont apartment building early Sunday, the police said. The man, Benjamin Waters, 33, another tenant of the womans building on 180th Street, has been charged with murder, the police said. He is accused of stabbing Carolyn Vargas, 28, during a small party in the building, the police said.

description: Opening this Week

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Justice Dept. Names New Prosecutors, Forcing Some Out
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The Justice Department is removing several United States attorneys from their jobs, among them Carol C. Lam, the top federal prosecutor in San Diego, who led the corruption prosecution of former Representative Randy Cunningham.

title: Britain: 12 Jurors or Better
description: The manager of Gutshot, a private poker club in London, was convicted of violating Britains gambling laws after a jury of 12 decided that poker was a game of chance, not pure skill. The manager, Derek Kelly, had argued that he did not need a gambling license because the laws cover games of chance like roulette and blackjack and not skill-based games like chess, or, he said, poker. Prosecutors argued that shuffling a deck of cards was enough to make poker a game of both chance and skill, which falls under the governments interpretation of chance. During the weeklong trial, Mr. Kellys competitors, reporters and men who described themselves only as interested parties jockeyed for a seat at the East London courthouse to hear expert players discuss the skills needed to play games like Texas Hold Em.

title: Letters
description: Silicone, Catching Fire

title: A Young Womans Wish, Entombed in Gazas Isolation
description: During the midnight air raids over Gaza last summer, when the shock waves shattered the terrace windows and woke her little brother shrieking, Eman Albelbeisi reached beside her bed for the comfort of her stack of college catalogues.

title: Intels Fight for Market Cuts Margins
description: Intel reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 39 percent as the company continued to fight for market share and to absorb the high cost of its corporate overhaul.

title: Knicks Count on Jeffries to Help Quiet Arenas
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 16  Coach Isiah Thomas looked ahead Tuesday, staring straight at Gilbert Arenas, whom the Knicks will somehow try to contain when they play the Wizards on Wednesday in Washington.

title: What You Get for ... $300,000
description: Gulf Shores, Ala.

title: Cross-Country Program Picks Up Speed
description: When 18-year-old Alexa Turzian poled past the finish line of the 10-kilometer freestyle race at the United States Nationals in Houghton, Mich., on Jan. 4, she became the youngest person to win a United States title in cross-country skiing. Her coach, Rick Kapala, was amazed. She hadnt been a dominating junior, he said in a telephone interview after the race.

title: The Long Lens of Obsession and Mad Love
description: Fiendishly assured yet ultimately less than the sum of its parts, the writer and director Eric Nicholass latest film, Alone With Her, is a voyeuristic thriller about a young man named Doug (Colin Hanks of Roswell) who becomes smitten with a woman named Amy (Ana Claudia Talancn of The Crime of Father Amaro) and tries to insinuate himself into her life through high-tech means. He videotapes her routines from afar, then plants hidden cameras and microphones in her apartment.

title: Ex-Fund Trader Sentenced to Probation
description: A former Millennium Partners mutual fund trader who pleaded guilty to improper trading in 2003 avoided a prison term after cooperating with a New York State investigation of the mutual fund industry.

title: American Songbook Returns, Horizons Still Expanding
description: What is American song?

title: Unions Endorsing Republican for an Open Senate Seat
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16Several major labor unions are rallying around the Republican candidate for an open State Senate seat in Nassau County, in a sign of the obstacles that labor could present for Gov. Eliot Spitzers efforts to capture the seat for Democrats next month.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page credit yesterday with a picture of a march in Raleigh, N.C., in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., misspelled the photographers surname. He is John Rottet, not Rotter.

title: China: Music Deal for Emi and Web Site
description: The EMI Group, which lost a copyright infringement lawsuit against Baidu.com, a Chinese Internet search site, will drop its appeal of the case and work with the company to win advertising by offering free online samples of its music. Baidu, based in Beijing, will sell online ads for a section of its Web site featuring streaming samples of EMIs Chinese-language music, the company said. EMI and Baidu will share the ad revenue, they said, without providing details. EMI is planning to drop out of an infringement lawsuit brought against Baidu by record companies on claims the Web site violated copyright by offering links to illegally copied music on nonaffiliated sites.

title: Time Stands Still for One Who Never Did
description: In the years when Muhammad Ali, mischief in his eyes, shouted that he was the greatest of all times and correctly predicted the round when his next opponent would fall, he also forecast his impact on boxings future.

title: Germany: Investor Confidence Rises
description: German investor confidence rose more than forecast, reaching a six-month high in January, despite a higher sales tax and a slowdown in export markets. The index of investor and analyst expectations for economic growth in six months, compiled by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research, rose to minus 3.6 from minus 19 in December. The report adds to signs that cooling growth in the German economy may be limited even after the country raised the value-added tax, a sales tax, to 19 percent from 16 percent. The confidence indicator has shown a negative reading, with pessimists outnumbering optimists, in every month since August.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the role that employment contracts play in the large severance payouts for executives gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the name of a company that the chief executive of Wrigley, William D. Perez, mentioned during a discussion of contracts. It is S. C. Johnson, not S. C. Johnston.

title: King Cole, a Grimy Old Soul, Heads for a Cleaning
description: Once upon a time, the 30-foot-wide mural shone brilliantly, and its fairytale king stood forth colorfully, flanked by knights, musicians and assorted minions. Now, the painting suffers from cracking and from a scattering of dents, even splashes of alcohol.

title: Calendar
description: From Far-Flung Vines

title: Issues Left Unresolved on Pensions
description: The Supreme Courts decision yesterday not to hear arguments that I.B.M. illegally discriminated on the basis of age when it changed its traditional pension plan in the 1990s saves I.B.M. a significant amount of money. But it resolves almost nothing for the many other companies that made similar changes to their own pension plans.

description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Denounce Bush Policy Limiting Refuge for Iraqis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Senate lawmakers sharply criticized the Bush administration on Tuesday for failing to provide refuge in the United States for the most vulnerable of the Iraqis fleeing the violence at home.

description: Adam Gillitt does not hate what is on his TV as much as he dislikes what is attached to it.
