description: To the Editor:

title: Commanders in Afghanistan Request More Troops
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 16  American and NATO military commanders in Afghanistan are worried about the resurgent Taliban insurgency and have asked for additional troops, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today, adding that he was sympathetic to the request.

title: Pilot in Crash of Small Plane Had Decades of Experience
description: WAYNE, N.J., Jan. 16  Andrew Coppolo loved flying so much that he volunteered to fly cancer patients from around the Northeast to faraway chemotherapy sessions.

title: Regulators Examining Commerce Bank
description: Commerce Bancorp, which calls itself Americas most convenient bank, rattled investors yesterday after it disclosed that federal regulators were investigating the banks real estate deals with executives.

title: Herminator Encourages Governator
description: The Austrian skier Hermann Maier, who knows a thing or two about bouncing back from injury, has offered encouragement to the Austrian-born governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger, who broke a leg last month on a skiing trip.

title: Letter Tells of Difficulties in Prosecuting Detainee Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  A Justice Department team responsible for reviewing accusations of abuse of detainees by civilian government employees in Iraq and Afghanistan has encountered delays and unique difficulties, the department said in a letter on Tuesday.

title: U.N. Says Global AIDS Effort for Children Falls Far Short
description: Some countries are making progress in treating children with AIDS and preventing others from becoming infected, but the overall global response is tragically insufficient, Unicef said yesterday.

title: Iraqi Leaders Try to Show Progress on Problems
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 17  Iraqi political leaders stepped up efforts to persuade the world that they were tackling the countrys thorniest problems on Wednesday, highlighting crackdowns on militias, progress on a national oil law and new examples of reconciliation with former Baathists.

title: Russia Plans to Divert Gas Around Belarus
description: A summary of the leading articles in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.

title: One Goal and Brodeur Are All the Devils Need
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 16  For much of the second half of the Devils 1-0 victory over the Rangers on Tuesday night, Rangers forward Jaromir Jagr was trying to create a couple of feet of personal space. It was nearly a full-time job for Jagr, staying on the ice for double shifts or jumping out early, all for a few precious seconds without Devils forward Jay Pandolfo hounding him.

title: Even Free, the Price Wasnt Right
description: Yum Brands, the fast-food conglomerate, wanted to buy property for a Taco Bell in Norfolk, Va., on the site of a former appliance store.

title: France: Now There Are Three
description: Ren Riffaud, one of just four known surviving French veterans of World War I, died at the age of 108, according to the national veterans office. His existence was unknown to the authorities until last year, when he emerged from obscurity to claim veteran status under pressure from relatives. Nationwide commemorations are expected at the death of the last member of the group.

title: White House Says Judiciary Will Monitor Spy Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Bush administration, in what appears to be a concession to its critics, said today it will allow an independent court to monitor its warrantless electronic-eavesdropping program.

title: As Raids on Afghan Border Increase, U.S. Military Seeks More Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 16  Attacks by militants crossing into Afghanistan from Pakistan have tripled since September along portions of the border, a senior American intelligence official said Tuesday, prompting calls for a greater effort by Pakistan to curb the influx and a larger deployment of American and other NATO soldiers here.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in the Itineraries pages of Business Day yesterday about finding places to eat while traveling for business misstated the name of a Web site that offers restaurant information. It is www.fodors.com, not www.fodor.com.

title: Record Year Followed by Record Deal
description: The sale of the 41-story skyscraper at 666 Fifth Avenue for $1.8 billion  a record price for an office building in Manhattan  closed last week, and the deal is symbolic of the red-hot demand from big investors for commercial properties.

title: Israeli and Syrian Citizens Wrote Plan for Returning Golan Heights
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16  Prominent private citizens from Israel and Syria drafted a document in secret, unofficial talks that calls for returning the Golan Heights to Syria and offers a possible outline for peace negotiations, one of the participants said Tuesday.

title: John W. Simpson, 92, Dies; Pioneer of Nuclear Power
description: John W. Simpson, a former top executive and engineer for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation who played a major role in developing the nations first commercial nuclear power plant and its first nuclear-powered submarine, the U.S.S. Nautilus, died Jan. 4 near his home on Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 92.

title: Britain: Terrorism Suspect on the Run
description: The government said a terrorism suspect had absconded after being served with what is known as a control order, a form of house arrest that would require him to report daily to the police, surrender his travel documents and reside at an address known to the authorities. The man was not identified by name, but John Reid, the home secretary, said he had recently been radicalized and wanted to travel abroad for terrorism-related purposes. Mr. Reid said the man was not seen as a direct threat to the public in the United Kingdom.

title: As Trial Begins, Cheneys Ex-Aide Is Still a Puzzle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Paradox seems to define I. Lewis Libby Jr., who remains a bit mysterious even to close colleagues. He is the White House policy enforcer who also wrote a literary novel; a buttoned-down Washington lawyer who likes knocking back tequila shots in cowboy bars and hurtling down mountains on skis and bikes; and a 56-year-old intellectual known to all by his childhood nickname, Scooter.

title: Naomi Pleads Guilty to Tossing Phone at Maid
description: Naomi Campbell apologized yesterday for hitting her maid in the head with a cellphone, but said it was an accident.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 6 about White House efforts to find a new chief counsel misstated the working status of Laurence H. Silberman of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, who was considered a contender for the job. On Nov. 1, 2000, he took senior status, which allows a judge to continue to serve while handling fewer cases than a judge in active service; he has not retired. (President Bush has since named Fred F. Fielding to be the White House counsel.)

title: NBCs Today Is Expected to Add a Fourth Hour
description: Meredith Vieira wont appear on it at all, and Matt Lauer will make only an occasional cameo, if that, but NBC is expected to announce formally today that it will expand Today, its morning-program empire and the most profitable program on television, to a fourth hour, beginning at 10 a.m. on weekdays next fall.

title: Gay Lawyers Suit Accuses Firm of Bias
description: An associate at one of the countrys most prestigious law firms, Sullivan & Cromwell, filed a state lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday accusing the firm of a systematic campaign of discrimination and retaliation against him because of his sexual orientation.

title: The Food Pyramid Takes Its Show on the Road
description: New Run at the Dietary Guidelines

title: J.P. Morgans Income Soared in 4th Quarter
description: Net income at J.P. Morgan Chase soared by 68 percent in the fourth quarter, the company reported today. Record-high profits in its investment-banking advisory businesses and vast improvement in its trading results were the reasons, the company said.

title: Senate Passes Disclosure Measure
description: The Senate voted 98 to 0 to require public disclosure of the sponsors of pet projects known as earmarks, attaching the provision to broader ethics legislation. The vote came on an amendment sponsored by Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, that is similar to a provision approved by the House on Jan. 5. It would prevent lawmakers from anonymously inserting special projects or tax breaks for companies into spending legislation.

title: Court Vacates Term of Algerian in Bomb Plot
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16  A federal appeals court on Tuesday vacated the 2005 sentence of an Algerian man convicted of plotting to bomb Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Recipe: Black-Skinned Chicken Soup
description: Adapted from Yvonne Wong

title: Achieving His Goal, Reese Gazes Even Higher
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 16  Jerry Reese, standing on a raised platform and sandwiched between bright spotlights and a backdrop of Giants logos, laughed when he considered just how it was that he got here.

title: Family Life and Other Hazards as Refracted in a Jaundiced Eye
description: The Vietnamization of New Jersey, Christopher Durangs 1977 satire of the arrogant American character, the hypocrisy of middle class family life, consumerism and the branding of just about everything, seems, in retrospect, to have been about more than all that. What seems clear now is that it embodied, as well, a particular prescience about where late-20th-century television would head  or perhaps it even informed that direction.

title: Finding Faith, and Responsibility, After Making a New Start
description: When William McKinney showed up at church one Sunday more than a decade ago, he said he was open to anything that would help him make a fresh start.

title: Opposition to Bushs War Plan Is Mounting
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  A prominent Senate Republican joined senior Democrats today in sponsoring a resolution against the Bush administrations troop buildup in Iraq. But the White House said it would not let its hands be tied.

title: Comptroller Raises $524,000 in Undeclared Bid for Mayor
description: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. raised nearly $524,000 in the last six months, giving him a sizable lead in fund-raising among the potential 2009 mayoral candidates, according to campaign finance disclosures released yesterday.

title: Immigrant Centers Inspected
description: A federal inspection of 5 of the nations 325 immigrant detention centers found that most did not provide timely and responsive health care and sometimes failed to comply with the governments standards of disciplining, classifying and housing detainees. The audit by the Department of Homeland Security also found a rape of a detainee in one center and a failure to provide access to legal services in another. Three centers did not translate handbooks into Spanish and other languages. Homeland security officials said the study was too small to be representative of the countrys detention centers.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a gun battle on Jan. 3 between the police and Islamic extremists in Tunisia misstated the name of a militant Islamic political party that has risen in popularity as part of a religious resurgence across North Africa. The party, based in Egypt, is the Muslim Brotherhood, not Islamic Brotherhood.

title: Bloomberg Plans to Cut New Yorks Property Taxes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is proposing to cut property taxes by roughly 5 percent and eliminate the city sales tax on clothing and footwear as New York enjoys the bounty from its booming economy and real estate market, city officials said yesterday.

title: Budget Reform Pact Augurs a More Transparent Albany
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16  It sounds logical enough: New York State should be required to pass balanced budgets. The budget should not include blank checks to state officials, in the form of giant lump sums to be divvied up later in secret. And lawmakers should have to explain the fiscal impact of the changes they make to the budget.

title: $300,000 Homes
description: Tour a condo on the Gulf Coast of Alabama, a farmhouse near Maines Acadia National Park and a loft in Portland, Ore.

Fedora Style
description: Old hat? Not on a young head.

title: Obama Statement on Iraq
description: The following is a statment released by Senator Barack Obama's office Wednesday.

title: Lighting Your Way
description: Gear test with Paul Romero, adventure racer.

title: Regulators Are Examining Commerce Bank
description: Commerce Bancorp, which calls itself Americas most convenient bank, rattled investors Tuesday after it disclosed that federal regulators were investigating the banks real estate deals with executives. Shares of Commerce fell 8.3 percent, or $2.89, to $31.83, after the bank said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve were conducting an inquiry. Commerce has become one of the fastest-growing banks in the nation, thanks in part to its extended branch hours, and has made an aggressive and successful push into New Yorks crowded banking market. Commerce, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said, The scope of the investigation will include but not be limited to transactions with its officers, directors and related parties, including transactions involving bank premises.

title: Icahn Takes Aim at Drug and Housing Companies
description: Carl C. Icahn is at it again. The billionaire investor has set his activist sights on two new targets, building stakes in the companies because he believes the shares are undervalued. Mr. Icahn now has a 14.57 percent stake in WCI Communities, a developer of housing in Florida, and has increased his holdings in Telik, an unprofitable developer of cancer and diabetes drugs, to 9.92 percent.

title: Ex-Owner at Refco Charged in Fraud Case
description: A former owner of Refco, the commodities brokerage firm, was charged Tuesday in a fraud that cost investors more than $1 billion in losses, prosecutors said as they also added charges against the former chief executive and chief financial officers of the firm. Tone N. Grant, 62, of Chicago, a former owner of Refco, was charged with bank fraud and money laundering along with the former chief executive, Phillip R. Bennett, 58, of Gladstone, N.J., and the former finance chief, Robert C. Trosten, 37, of Sarasota, Fla.

title: Gerson Lehrman Under a New York Inquiry
description: The battle to be Wall Streets top matchmaker is getting messier. The New York State attorney generals office is investigating whether employees at Best Buy, Circuit City and the credit card processor First Data improperly provided nonpublic information to hedge fund traders, according to media reports.

title: Goldmans Sachs Agrees to Acquire Insurance Broker
description: The buyout unit of Goldman Sachs has agreed to acquire the insurance brokerage firm USI Holdings for about $1.4 billion including debt. The Goldman unit, GS Capital Partners, will pay $17 a share, USI said Tuesday. The offer represents a 21 percent premium over the average closing share price in the 30 days before Oct. 24, the day USI announced that it had formed a committee to review a possible takeover. USI is based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: 2 Years in Prison for Ex-Software Executive
description: The former general counsel at Computer Associates, Steven Woghin, was sentenced on Tuesday to two years in prison for his role in a scheme to increase the software makers quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts, prosecutors said. At a hearing in Brooklyn, Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court also sentenced Mr. Woghin to three years of supervised release. Several former executives at the company, now known as CA, including the former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, have pleaded guilty to criminal charges.

title: Ex-Fund Trader Sentenced to Probation
description: A former Millennium Partners mutual fund trader who pleaded guilty to improper trading in 2003 avoided a prison term after cooperating with a New York State investigation of the mutual fund industry. The former trader, Steven Markovitz, 44, was sentenced to five years probation Tuesday after pleading guilty to violating New Yorks General Business Law, a felony, by trading in mutual funds from late 2001 to July 2003 after markets had closed.

title: Two Charged in Payments From Wagers on Internet
description: Two founders of a company that processes Internet gambling transactions were arrested and charged with laundering billions of dollars in gambling proceeds, federal prosecutors announced Tuesday. The charges were filed against John David Lefebvre, 55, and Stephen Eric Lawrence, 46, who founded the company, Neteller, in 1999, in two criminal complaints unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Monday, Michael J. Garcia, a United States attorney, said in a statement.

title: G.M. Discloses Talks for Deal in Malaysia
description: General Motors has been in talks with Proton Holdings, the Malaysian carmaker that is looking to sell a stake, G.M.s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said Tuesday night. There have been conversations, not extensive, Wagoner told reporters after a speech in Dearborn, Mich., last night. Its very early to handicap the potential outcome. G.M. is interested in Proton because it is underrepresented in Malaysia, Southeast Asias largest auto market. G.M., the worlds largest automaker, is focusing growth on 11 emerging markets, including Malaysia, India and China, as its domestic sales shrink, Mr. Wagoner said.

title: Landrys Fields Offer for Smith & Wollensky
description: Landrys Restaurants said Tuesday that it had made a $64.4 million offer to buy the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, whose original steakhouse is a New York City institution and a favorite of the likes of Warren Buffett. Smith & Wollensky, whose shares soared 45 percent, to $7.29, said it had formed a special committee to review the $7.50 per share offer. Shares of Landrys, which operates the Landrys Seafood House, Chart House and Rainforest Cafe restaurants, also got a boost, rising more than 2.5 percent to $31. The Smith & Wollensky Group operates its namesake steakhouses as well as Maloney & Porcelli, Post House, Park Avenue Cafe and Quality Meats.

title: Norwest Outsources $20 Million to Adventity
description: Norwest Venture Partners has invested $20 million in India-focused Adventity, which provides high-end research and analytics to the investment banking, mortgage and financial services industries. The investment closes the second round of financing for Adventity and marks the first funding received from an institutional source. Based in New York, most of Adventitys operations are in India. With more than 2,000 employees, Adventity serves several global investment banks, management consulting firms and some of the largest hedge funds. The funding is one of several investments by Norwest in second-generation services, or business processes that are not traditionally outsourced.

title: E-Mail Start-Up Gets Cash to Take on Microsoft
description: Going head-to-head with Microsoft is a risky business strategy, but investors in a mail server technology developer, PostPath are confident enough to give the company an additional $15 million. The Series C financing for PostPath closed in late December and was led by a new investor, Jafco Ventures. Two previous investors Matrix Partners and Worldview Technology Partners also participated in the financing, which brings the companys total funding to $30 million. PostPath has developed a Linux-based exchange server that integrates fully with Microsofts own Exchange server.

title: Historians Appeal Da Vinci Code Case
description: The two historians who lost their plagiarism case against the British publishers of the best seller The Da Vinci Code by Dan Brown turned to the Court of Appeal in Britain yesterday in an effort to reverse their loss in a case that also saddles them with a legal bill of more than $2 million, The Associated Press reported. Lawyers for the historians, Michael Baigent and Richard Leigh, argued that the vast amount of skill and labor they expended in writing their book The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail, first published in 1982, is protectable. They contend that Mr. Brown stole significant parts of it for his novel. Both books are based on the theory that Jesus and Mary Magdalene married and had a child, and that the bloodline continues to this day. In April, Justice Peter Smith ruled that Random House had not breached the copyright of The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail, and Mr. Baigent and Mr. Leigh were ordered to pay 85 percent of Random Houses legal bill, estimated at $2.6 million. In a statement, Random House expressed regret that more time and money is being spent trying to establish a case that was so comprehensively defeated in the High Court.

title: EMI and Baidu in Chinese Duet
description: The Chinese search engine Baidu.com and EMI Music are teaming up in an Internet venture that will let users listen to streaming music free, adding to Baidus growing entertainment business. Under the terms of the the venture, announced Tuesday, EMI will make its Chinese pop music available on Baidus Web site. Baidu, which has more than 60 percent of Chinas online search market, has been expanding entertainment offerings in an effort to compete with Web sites that combine search with entertainment and games, financial analysts say.

title: Time Runs Out on Bid for N.B.A.s Grizzlies
description: The Memphis Grizzlies are back on the block after a deadline passed for a group led by a former Duke University player, Brian Davis, to assemble a $252 million deal. The window for the Grizzlies Acquisition Holdings, Mr. Daviss acquisition vehicle, to negotiate exclusively for the 70 percent stake owned by a Chicago billionaire, Michael Heisley, expired on Monday. Mr. Heisley, a turnaround specialist , told the Memphis Commercial Appeal that the team is still for sale  to Davis, to the teams local minority-share investors or to someone else making an acceptable offer for the team, which has the NBAS worst record. He wasnt able to get all of his financing together, Mr. Heisley told The Deal. He was able to get some of it. If Mr. Davis comes up with the money, well sell him the team.

title: Court Lifts Hurdle to E.ONs Bid for Endesa
description: A Spanish court lifted the final injunction Tuesday to an offer by the German utility E.ON for Endesa of Spain, a potentially groundbreaking merger that has become one of Europes longest-running takeover battles. The courts decision allows E.ON to move forward with its 36.5 billion euro, or $47.1 billion, bid for Endesa, which is also being pursued by Gas Natural, another Spanish energy concern. That combination is backed by the Spanish government, which would like to see the creation of a national energy champion. Meanwhile, a Spanish building conglomerate, Acciona, has also steadily built up a 21 percent stake in Endesa, but it has not moved to secure full control.

title: Dresdner and Gazprom team Up on Emissions Venture
description: Gazproms banking unit has set up an emissions trading venture with Dresdner Bank to take advantage of the growing market for securities linked to greenhouse-gas quotas under the Kyoto Protocol, the companies said Tuesday. The company, Carbon Trade & Finance Sicar, will invest in projects that earn emissions credits by reducing pollution, and will trade the credits and securities linked to the credits.

title: Millennial Media Rings Up $6.3 Million in Funding
description: Millennial Media, a mobile-advertising services company started by a former Verizon executive, has received $6.3 million in Series A funding, CNet News.com reported. The funding comes from Bessemer Venture Partner, an investor in companies such as Blue Nile, Skype and VeriSign; Columbia Capital, an investor in Mobi, Nextel and XM Satellite Radio; and Acta Wireless.

title: Fearing a Fire Sale, Mills Investors Offer to Lend a Hand
description: Two major shareholders of Mills each offered a plan to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the troubled shopping-mall developer to help it pay off heavy debt and stave off potential bankruptcy. The hedge fund Farallon Capital Partners proposed a $499 million recapitalization plan for Mills, while the Israeli real estate firm Gazit-Globe offered a new, $1.8 billion version of an offer it made last year.

title: Currents
description: What home may look like if you're unusually tall or wide, a muscular design in the marble and more.

title: As Fast as Merill Can Make It, ONeal Is Is Spending It
description: As Merrill Lynch prepares to announce Thursday what analysts expect will be its most profitable year ever, its chief executive will continue to spend those record-breaking profits to make acquisitions to stay competitive, Bloomberg News said. The chief, E. Stanley ONeal, is expected to eye investments in commodities and mortgage-bond trading in efforts to catch up with Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers, respectively.

title: Gay Lawyer Accuses Top Firm of Discrimination
description: An associate at one of the countrys most prestigious law firms, Sullivan & Cromwell, filed a state lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday accusing the firm of a systematic campaign of discrimination and retaliation against him because of his sexual orientation. The associate, Aaron B. Charney, 28, asserts in the lawsuit, filed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, that several partners in Sullivan & Cromwells highly regarded mergers and acquisitions practice subjected him to lewd and illegal conduct, beginning in the fall of 2005. He is seeking a jury trial and unspecified compensatory and punitive damages.

title: Even Free, the Price Wasnt Right
description: In an unusual tale of a real-estate acquisition, Yum Brands, the fast-food conglomerate, wanted to buy property for a Taco Bell in Norfolk, Va., and the owner offered to give it away. On one condition.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Reclaimed or antique, a stump can be used as an end table.

title: Wednesday Morning Excerpts
description: The weekend of football wouldnt be complete without some analysis from Gregg Easterbrook in Tuesday Morning Quarterback . Click here for the full column. Here are a few excerpts:

title: Deja-Vu: Cablevision Board Rejects Offer by the Dolans
description: The board of Cablevision Systems rejected an $8.9 billion offer Tuesday to sell the company to the Dolans, its founding family. The rebuff was a rare example of a board standing up to and denying a request by a controlling shareholder. The rejection by the board, which set up a special committee to review the Dolans proposal, is the second time it has refused to sell the company to the family.

title: N.Y.S.E. Regulators Fine Specialists
description: The regulatory arm of the New York Stock Exchange said Tuesday that it had fined seven specialist firms a combined $2.8 million for trading violations. NYSE Regulation said that the specialists violated the so-called firm quote rule. The rule requires specialist firms execute buy or sell orders that are presented to them at prices that are at least as favorable as the N.Y.S.E.s published bid or offer at the time the orders enter the N.Y.S.E.s electronic-display book. The specialists also were censured.

title: Day of Reckoning for Former Cendant Chief
description: The final chapter in one of the longest-running sagas of corporate crime is scheduled to conclude Wednesday in a Connecticut courtroom. Walter Forbes, the blue-blooded former chairman of Cendant, is set to be sentenced for his role in a $252 million accounting fraud that was exposed nearly a decade ago. At the time, the Cendant fraud was the largest on record, and its exposure in April 1998 wiped out $14 billion of the companys market capitalization, nearly half its total, in a single day.

title: Encore Buys Anadarko Wyoming Properties
description: The oil and gas producer Encore Acquisition said on Wednesday that it would pay $400 million in cash to buy oil and natural gas properties in Wyoming from Anadarko Petroleum. The properties include the Elk Basin Unit and the Gooseberry Unit in Park County, Wyo., and Encore expects them to generate about $50 million in cash flow a year in 2007 and 2008. The transaction is expected to close in March, Encore said.

title: Brady vs. Manning Column Contest
description: No self-respecting blog would miss a chance to address a debate that has been brewing for years, especially with the Patriots and the Colts meeting Sunday.

title: Tribune: All Dressed Up and No One to Bid?
description: Tribune, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, the Los Angeles Times and Newsday, appears to have thrown a takeover party where no one showed up. With the deadline for final bids today, the private-equity firms that have been meeting with Tribunes management and looking over its financial records for the past several months do not plan to submit final offers, according to The New York Post.

title: The Nuremberg Hangings  Not So Smooth Either
description: Before we set aside the topic of Iraqs botched hangings, which continue to cause a fair bit of consternation there, a reader reminds us to flash back to 1946, and the conclusion of the trials at Nuremberg, in which 11 high-ranking Nazi officers were ultimately condemned to death by hanging. One of them, Hermann Gring, managed to finish himself in his cell with a cyanide capsule just hours before the execution was to take place, but the others took their trip to the gallows.

title: EADS May Seek Funding to Buoy Airbus
description: The European aerospace giant EADS, the parent company of Airbus, said on Tuesday it might ask shareholders for permission to go to the financial markets to raise funds. The question is whether it is possible that we will ask the AGM for authorization to go to the market, EADS finance chief, Hans Peter Ring, said at a press conference. The answer is yes, it is possible.

title: As Tomlinson Looks Back, the Patriots Look to the Colts
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 17  New England Coach Bill Belichick is apparently worried about getting to the Super Bowl again, not about LaDainian Tomlinson's feelings.

title: J.P. Morgan Reports A Record 4th-Quarter
description: Helped by gains from investment banking and trading, J.P. Morgan Chase posted a profit of $3.91 billion, or $1.09 a share, for its fourth quarter of 2006, capping its most profitable year ever. The numbers were up from $2.64 billion a year earlier, exceeding the $2.64 billion from a year ago and beating analysts expectations of 94 cents a share. J.P. Morgans windfall arrives as other Wall Street rivals like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley boasted of similarly outsized returns.

title: Colts Confident of Solving Brady
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 17  Tom Brady has an impeccable reputation for postseason heroics. But when the Colts beat the Patriots in November, Brady threw four interceptions. And when the Patriots beat the Chargers last week, Brady was picked off three times.

title: Cerberus Drops Out of Equity Office Bidding Group
description: Cerberus Capital Management dropped out of a consortium considering a rival offer for the Equity Office Properties Group, according to news reports. The group, which still includes Vornado Realty Trust, Barry Sternlichts Starwood Capital and Leon Bluhms Walton Street Capital, has been scrambling to put together an offer for Equity Office that would top its agreement last year to be sold for $36 billion to the Blackstone Group. Without Cerberus, it is unclear whether the consortium will be able to mount an offer.

title: Bears' Grossman Turns Defensive
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan 17  The person at the lectern looked like Rex Grossman, but when he started answering questions Wednesday at Halas Hall, his bearing became so wooden it was as if he was a puppet and somebody was throwing his voice.

title: G.E. Near Deal for Abbotts Diagnostic Unit
description: General Electric was near a deal last night to buy the medical diagnostic unit of Abbott Laboratories for more than $5 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Shrimp and Eggs
description: The Times food columnist Mark Bittman pairs shrimp and eggs in a delightful new brunch recipe.

title: Once More Into the Breach, My Friends
description: The Bagger, at the behest of his betters, gasped out a last bit of Globes prose before hitting security at LAX. Just. One. More. Copy. Inch. Out. Of. The. Globes. Must keep typing.

title: The War at Home: Cracked Egg
description: In a signal of how seriously the Bush administration is taking the task of quelling public doubts about the new way forward, President Bush himself ventured over to PBSs The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer. Heres what he told the shows host on the possibility of success:

title: A Handicapping Handicap
description: For those of you who havent had your fill of prognostication, Kristopher Tapley turns over the upcoming guild awards with a stick and makes some picks at InContention.

title: Mr. Eds Peculiar Brother
description: Jeffrey Wells talks about what happens when man and horse bond in new ways. Zoo will get a long look and a few stares when it premieres at Sundance. The film has a nickname that the Bagger, who works for a family newspaper, has somehow forgotten.

title: Portrait Etched in Acid
description: Dan Klores has a day job spinning and pinning reporters as one of New Yorks heavyweight flacks, if there is such a thing. But what he really wants to do is direct, and so he has. Crazy Love, is Klores fourth film, this time about one of the most obsessive relationships in the history of humankind. The Reeler talks to him about the film, his third outing as filmmaker at Sundance, and a play he has written in his spare time.

title: A Different Boardroom Dance
description: There is a boardroom dance whose steps are known by most directors of companies with controlling shareholders.

title: In Search of That Elusive New York Angle
description: New York magazine does a mega heave on Sundance, which includes pointing out that a walk up Main Street in Park City when the festival is at its height may seem like an average night in the Village. All the usual suspects will be here.

title: Incoming
description: When the Bagger checked into his Sundance condo  well, he did it at three different places before someone actually gave him a key  the locals seemed friendly and correctly surmised that he wasnt here to ski. Except that he is. One day this week the Bagger will take his inimitable downhill style  think bean-bag chair on skis  up to the top of the hill and see if Newtons Laws will once again pull him to the bottom.

title: Macabre Math on Iraqs Death Toll
description: Blogger Marc Cooper finds a way to put the United Nations new tally of 2006 Iraqi war deaths  more than 34,000  in perspective. On a per capita basis, he writes, this death toll would add up in the U.S. to nearly 400,000 dead per year.

title: Bear Stearns Seeks to Expand  Literally
description: Bonus-flush investment bankers may be preparing to spend on pricey new real estate, and now it appears at least one of their companies will, too. Bear Stearns is close to signing a deal to drastically expand its midtown Manhattan location, The New York Observer reported Wednesday. After acquiring 240,000 square feet in two leases signed last year, the investment bank is looking to buy an additional 104,000 square feet at its 237 Park Ave. offices, the Observer said, citing three sources close to the deal. If completed, it would be the largest New York City lease of 2007 thus far.

title: Clinton on Iraq  and Obama
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, just back from Iraq and Afghanistan, appeared this morning on NBCs Today show, among others, and was to hold a news conference this afternoon about the trip with fellow travelers, Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana and Congressman John McHugh, Republican of New York.

title: On the Hill: Spousal Privilege
description: The Senate voted 98-0 for a bill that would require public disclosure of earmark sponsors.

title: Deconstructing Obama
description: Barack Obamas pre-announcement of his 2008 presidential campaign took the form of a five-minute video biography. In his own video analysis, John Dickerson of Slate dissects the ad, pointing out how the announcement emphasizes the Illinois senators biography, his popularity and his experience as an underdog and de-emphasizes his short Senate record. One black-and-white photo, showing the young Obama in a black turtleneck and leather jacket, Dickerson says, appears to be the cover picture from his first jazz album.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Historic Field
description: The 2008 Democratic field could turn out to form one of the most historic and compelling races ever, writes The Washington Posts Dan Balz in an analysis, referring to the potential candidacies of Senators Barack Obama, who just formed an exploratory committee, and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Judy Keen of USA Today tries to answer Mr. Obamas Does he have enough experience? question. The Fix profiles Mr. Obamas inner circle.

title: Text of the Resolution on Iraq Introduced by Joseph R. Biden, Carl Levin and Chuck Hagel
description: The text of the resolution on Iraq introduced Wednesday by Senators Joseph R. Biden of Delaware and Carl Levin of Michigan, both Democrats, and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, a Republican:

title: The Short-er List
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced their short list for the Best Foreign Language Film award, choosing 9 films from the 61 submitted for consideration. In alphabetical order by country they are:

title: Manhattan: Train-to-Plane Use Sets Record
description: A record number of passengers used trains to connect to Kennedy International Airport and Newark Liberty International Airport last year, officials at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Roughly 4 million people rode the train to Kennedy, an increase of about 15 percent over 2005, officials said; 1.6 million took the train to Newark Airport, a jump of about 8 percent.

title: Newark: Man Charged in Fatal Shooting
description: An East Orange man already in custody on charges of setting his uncle on fire was charged with murder on Tuesday in the fatal shooting of a clothing store owner on Jan. 3, the police said yesterday. The man, Lamar A. Tidwell, 24, is charged with walking into the Clothing Wholesale and Retail Urban Warestore on Main Street and shooting the owner, Allen Cuff, 34. The men had argued a week earlier, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant Essex County prosecutor. Mr. Tidwell also faces weapons charges in that case. On Saturday he was charged with attempted murder; the authorities said he set fire to his uncle, Richard Burns, 54, in Mr. Burnss apartment in East Orange after an argument. Mr. Burns suffered injuries over 22 percent of his body and was in critical condition yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. Mr. Tidwell is being held in $1 million bail at the Essex County jail.

title: A House They Could Call Their Own
description: Money from the Neediest Cases fund is helping a familiy of nine move from a shelter, where they've lived for four years, and into a new apartment.

title: Testing a Missile Shield for Airliners
description: A FedEx flight took off from LAX yesterday with a little something extra attached to its belly: an anti-missile system.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardts Jan. 17 column on the cost of the war in Iraq:

title: The Latest Investment-Banking Bonus: A Life
description: Investment banks have long been known as the preserve of hundred-hour weeks, where leaving the office only to change clothes is considered a badge of honor. But according to Fortune, Wall Street is discovering that some of its best people dont believe that being chained to the office is a mark of greatness  and are leaving for saner pastures. Now, Lehman Brothers and its rivals are turning to return to work recruitment programs to lure those employees back. The draw: lighter schedules and less travel.

title: Mills to Be Sold to Brookfield for $1.35 Billion
description: Teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, it appears Mills has found its white knight. The developer of 38 malls throughout the United States said Wednesday morning that it had agreed to a $1.35 billion buyout by Brookfield Asset Management. Mills has struggled to repay loans that it took out as its business has shriveled and it bled cash. Last week, it said that it could be forced into bankruptcy over a loan from Goldman Sachs Mortgage that would come due at the end of March.

title: The Accents Beyond the Plate
description: Do race and ethnicity play roles in the hiring and promotion of restaurant workers? Should they?

title: Map: No-Freedom Zones
description: Online mapping seems to be all the rage lately for New York sites seeking to score political points and encourage activism. Yesterday it was a mashup of hospital closings in the city.

title: Ex-Cendant Chairman Sentenced to 12 Years
description: The former chairman of Cendant, Walter Forbes, was sentenced Wednesday to 12 years and seven months in prison and ordered to pay $3.275 billion in restitution for leading the largest accounting fraud of the 1990s. In October, a jury found Mr. Forbes guilty of conspiracy to commit securities fraud and two counts of making false statements in a massive fraud scheme that cost the travel and real estate company and its investors more than $3 billion. He was found not guilty of a fourth count, securities fraud.

title: The End Is Nearer, Say Atomic Scientists
description: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, which 60 years ago began keeping tabs on humanitys temporal distance from self-annihilation with the concept of a Doomsday Clock, apparently found things sufficiently dire to nudge the minute hand forward two clicks, indicating that we are now five minutes to midnight  or Doomsday.

title: As Districts Turn to Exotic Finances, Banks Reap Rewards
description: Cash-strapped public school districts and other local governments are increasingly making bets on arcane financial derivatives, often in hopes of quickly raising needed funds. But sometimes, as Bloomberg News recounts, those bets go awry. The schools suffer, but the financial firms clean up.

title: Craig Johnson for Something
description: Several readers have pointed out that Craig Johnson, the Democratic candidate for the vacant seat the State Senate, has a new campaign Web site.

title: Speculating About the Energy Speculators
description: While some pundits may blame instability in the Middle East for the recent volatility of oil, and others may decry the machinations of Opec, BusinessWeek speculates that another party may be to blame as well: speculators. As hedge funds, investment banks and other institutional players crowd into the energy market, their trades could be magnifying otherwise small movements in prices and increasing volatility, Peter Fusaro of the Energy Hedge Fund Center told the magazine.

title: Martys World
description: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president and potential mayoral aspirant, was in the spotlight this afternoon, introducing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the start of the mayors State of the City address, at the New York City Technical College in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Pulling a Fast One
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 15 column, The Texas Strategy.

title: Vornado-Led Group Offers $52 a Share for Equity Office
description: A consortium of three real estate companies offered $52 a share for Equity Office Properties Trust after the markets close Wednesday, stirring up what could be the most expensive buyout contest on record. The three companies  Vornado Realty, Starwood Capital and Walton Street Capital  hope to wrest control of Equity Office, the nations largest office-building manager and owner, from the Blackstone Group, which offered a record $36 billion in November, based on a $48 a share bid.

title: Sinking Ever Lower
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Jan. 15 column, Descending to New Depths.

title: Anna Maria, at Last
description: One of the things everyone in our family loves about my co-blogger (and wife) is that she has the ability to solve almost any problem. Even the worlds most obnoxious yellow lab knows this. He has a special sound he lets out when he has a problem  the pig ear has wedged itself under the couch  Buster yips and the trouble goes away.

title: Radio Hosts Sacked for Wii Water Contest
description: Just to update the case of Jennifer Strange, who died of water intoxication last Friday after participating a contest sponsored by a local radio-station in Sacramento that required contestants to drink copious amounts of water in an attempt to win a Nintendo Wii game console. (Weve had quite a heated debate in our forums on the issue of culpability here.)

title: Whos Going to Pay for All of This?
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 12 column, Make Them Fight All of Us.

title: Help Wanted
description: Position: Payroll administrator

title: Subway Hero Returns
description: Wesley Autrey ought to have his own reality-television show.

title: Fox Attending State of the Union
description: From the Guess Whos Coming to Dinner Department: Michael J. Fox, the actor, Parkinsons Disease patient and advocate for embryonic stem cell research, will be in the Capitol gallery when President Bush delivers his State of the Union address next week.

title: Party of Two
description: Senator Joseph I. Liebermans critics frequently enjoy referring to him as a member of the party of one. His supporters created the Connecticut for Lieberman party solely so he could run in the general election after losing the Democratic primary last August.

title: Senator Clinton and Iraq
description: After a trip to Iraq, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke out across Washington to stake out her position on the issue.

title: The Price of Oil in Texas
description: In the history of accidents, the March 2005 explosion at BPs Texas City, Tex., oil refinery might have been another Exxon Valdez  a catastrophe that changed the way we perceive and regulate the industry. But the BP disaster hasnt captured the publics imagination the way the 1989 Alaska oil spill did, even though the explosion killed 15 people and injured 180 more. Yesterday James Baker, the fix-it man for both the Iraq war and BPs safety record, released a 374-page report on how BPs corporate culture contributed to the disaster.

title: Expert Ties Ex-Players Suicide to Brain Damage From Football
description: Andre Waters, the former N.F.L. player who committed suicide last fall, sustained at least 15 concussions during his playing career. After his death at the age of 44, tests revealed that Mr. Waterss brain resembled that of an octogenarian Alzheimers patient.

title: How Gentlemen Disagree
description: A few weeks ago, I singled out an especially poorly written, hostile e-mail from a 15-year-old named Josh to support my theory that in the Internet age, civility is an endangered species.

title: The Elusive Altar
description: If all the world were south of 96th Street, what a happy place it would be! If all the world were south of 96th Street, then we could greet with unalloyed joy the news that after decades of social change, more American women are living without husbands than with them.

title: A Ghastly Toll: 34,000 Iraqi Dead (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Scrutinize Death Penalty in Texas
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The Supreme Court on Wednesday resumed its long-running effort to monitor the use of the death penalty in Texas, hearing arguments in three cases that put the strains and internal contradictions of the courts capital punishment jurisprudence fully on display.

title: Beauty of a String Trio, Free of Distractions
description: Surely some conspiracy theorist can explain what unnatural sequence of events prevented the string trio from becoming one of the most frequently heard ensembles, rather than the oddity it is. The configuration  violin, viola and cello  is perfectly balanced and symmetrical, its seamless range from soprano to bass untroubled by a top-thickening second fiddle or the distraction of a piano. And youd think string players would form trios by the dozen just to have Mozarts E-flat Divertimento in their active repertory.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a record set in 2006 for the amount of borrowed money the New York Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki committed to pet projects included an erroneous reference from David Catalfamo, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, to a museum that Mr. Catalfamo defended as a worthwhile investment. It is the Natural History Museum of the Adirondacks in Tupper Lake  not the Adirondack Museum, which is in Blue Mountain Lake.

title: With Arrest of DJ Drama, the Law Takes Aim at Mixtapes
description: In the world of hip-hop few music executives have more influence than DJ Drama. His Gangsta Grillz compilations have helped define this decades Southern rap explosion. He has been instrumental in the careers of rappers like Young Jeezy and Lil Wayne. He appears on the cover of the March issue of the hip-hop magazine XXL, alongside his friend and business partner T.I., the top-selling rapper of 2006. And later this year DJ Drama is scheduled to make his Atlantic Records debut with Gangsta Grillz: The Album.

title: After Falling Behind Early, Blake Quickly Regains Place
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 18  The mentoring program in American tennis has its limits, as Alex Kuznetsov discovered soon after breaking James Blakes serve twice at the beginning of their second-round match at the Australian Open.

title: Newark: Former Keyport Mayor Admits Taking Bribes
description: The former mayor of Keyport pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to accepting $24,000 in bribes from contractors seeking city construction work, federal prosecutors said. The former mayor, John Merla, 45, admitted accepting the payments while in office in 2003 and 2004, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Merla was one of 13 Monmouth County officials arrested in February 2005 as part of a corruption investigation by federal agents. He is scheduled to be sentenced on May 8 and faces up to 30 months in prison.

title: Universal Plans to Hire Top Executive of Film Rival
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17  Universal Pictures has raided 20th Century Fox and hired away the animation executive who oversaw the hit Ice Age movies, a move intended to fill a void left when Paramount acquired DreamWorks and replaced Universal as distributor of animated films like Over the Hedge.

title: California: $1 Billion in Citrus Losses
description: Californias citrus industry may have lost close to $1 billion after freezing weather devastated oranges and lemons still maturing on the tree, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said after touring some of the states growing regions. As much as 75 percent of the orange crop was damaged, according to the Department of Food and Agriculture, which oversees the states $31.8 billion agricultural industry.

title: Death 31 Years After Shooting Leads to a Murder Indictment

description: A Manhattan antiques dealer has filed a lawsuit against a small group of homeless people claiming that they are disrupting his business by using the sidewalk outside his high-end East Side store as a urinal, a spittoon and an occasional dressing room, according to the suit and the dealers lawyer.

description: SACRAMENTO

title: Bloomberg Seeks Further Changes for City Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg laid out ambitious new plans yesterday to overhaul the school system by giving principals more power and autonomy, requiring teachers to undergo rigorous review in order to gain tenure and revising the school financing system that has allowed more-experienced teachers to cluster in affluent areas.

title: Residential Sales
description: Florida

title: NBC President Says Ratings Are Gaining Momentum
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 17  Even in the face of what he acknowledged will likely be another tsunami of ratings from Foxs American Idol, which again set a viewership record on Tuesday night, Kevin Reilly, the president of NBC Entertainment, said here on Wednesday that his network had established significant momentum this season and had regained its status as the network of what he called quality programs.

title: Appeals Court Rules for Wal-Mart in Maryland Health Care Case
description: When Maryland legislators passed a first-of-its-kind law in 2006 forcing Wal-Mart Stores to spend more on employee health care, the measure was held up as a model for other states grappling with mounting Medicaid bills.

title: The Route From Research to Start-Up
description: HARTMUT NEVEN came from Germany to the University of Southern California a decade ago to lead research efforts in computerized face and object recognition. The aim was to create a tool for the military and law enforcement agencies to identify enemies and suspects as well as for airlines and other companies to check passengers and visitors.

title: Airbus Predicts Operating Loss for 2006
description: PARIS, Jan. 17  Airbus warned Wednesday that major production delays on its twin-deck A380 jet would probably push it to an operating loss for 2006, despite a record number of deliveries.

title: Ravaged by Fires, Australian State Warns of Hot Weathers Danger
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17  Australias second-most-populous state, Victoria, is in the grip of one of the worst bush fire seasons in recorded history, and the states government has issued warnings that with more hot weather on the way the situation is likely to get worse before it gets better.

title: The Lost Voice of Protest
description: On the evening of the fourth of April, 1967, one year to the day (almost to the hour) before his assassination, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. walked into Riverside Church in Manhattan and delivered a speech that was among his least well known, yet most controversial.

title: Balanchine and Stravinsky, Reunited
description: Stravinsky was arguably the most important composer for dance in the 20th century, beginning with a 1910 commission from Serge Diaghilev to score Michel Fokines Firebird. Although Stravinsky wrote only four scores for ballets by George Balanchine, the two artists had a long and mutually fruitful working relationship.

title: Some Signs of Economic Resilience Seen
description: A tight labor market is pushing up many workers wages, consumers are spending more at their local shopping malls and the skid in the housing market is easing in some areas of the country.

title: House Cuts Interest Rate for Some College Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  House Democrats on Wednesday pushed through legislation cutting the interest rate on federally subsidized loans to college students, drawing on large bipartisan support despite opposition by the White House.

title: President Calls for Genetic Privacy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Bush on Wednesday urged Congress to pass long-stalled legislation to safeguard genetic privacy, a measure experts say would encourage millions of Americans to undergo testing that could lead to prevention and treatment of cancer and other diseases.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a dispute between Wendy P. McCaw, the owner of The Santa Barbara News-Press in California and the newsroom staff misspelled the name of the city where Don Murphy, the former deputy managing editor of the paper, has taken a job. It is San Luis Obispo, not San Louis Obispo. The credit for a picture of Ms. McCaw misstated the given name of the photographer. He is Paul Wellman, not Paula.

title: Fraternal Twins in the Showroom
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17  Inside the cavernous Cobo Convention Center where the Detroit auto show is held each year, its easy to lose your way among the hundreds of new models.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Says Rules Bar Satellite Radio Merger
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Kevin Martin, said yesterday that the two satellite radio companies, Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio Holdings, would not win approval of a merger under current regulatory rules.

title: The Netherlands: Chip Supplier Soars
description: ASML Holding, maker of the most expensive machines in chip fabrication, said fourth-quarter profit quadrupled on demand for semiconductors used in iPod music devices and mobile phones. Net income jumped to a record 205.5 million euros ($265.7 million), or 0.42 euro a share, from 51.6 million euros, or 0.11 euro a share, a year earlier, ASML said. Sales surged 95 percent, to a record 1.07 billion euros. The company said orders would be healthy in the first quarter and revenue would gain this year. Demand for Apple iPods and Motorola phones has spurred shipments of ASMLs $18 million machines to clients like Samsung Electronics, Intel and Texas Instruments. ASML is based in Veldhoven, the Netherlands.

title: A Spy Program in From the Cold
description: Of the many ways that President Bush has trampled civil liberties and the balance of powers since the 9/11 attacks, one of the most egregious was his decision to order wiretaps of Americans international calls and e-mail without court approval. It was good news, then, when the administration announced yesterday that it would now seek a warrant from the proper court for that sort of eavesdropping.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about intestinal operations that a Spanish newspaper said had been performed on Fidel Castro referred incorrectly to peritonitis, a serious condition that the newspaper said had afflicted Mr. Castro after one of the operations. Peritonitis is an inflammation of the lining of the abdominal cavity, called the peritoneum; it is not an inflammation of the stomach lining.

title: He Writes the Songs, He Spans the Decades, He Inspires the Karaoke
description: Im 95 years old and I look great, right? That was Barry Manilow at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, telling a fib  maybe, if were honest, telling two fibs  and earning another big ovation.

title: Taming Frizz and Setting Curls Free
description: GROWING up, I yearned to have lustrous straight hair that I could wear parted in the middle and let swing down my back, like Marcia Brady of The Brady Bunch or Laurie Partridge of The Partridge Family.

title: Measure in Senate Urges No Troop Rise in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The Senate set the stage on Wednesday for a direct clash with President Bush over the war, with two senior Democrats and a prominent Republican introducing a symbolic measure to declare that the administrations plan to send additional troops to Iraq runs counter to the national interest.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music column on Saturday about a new album by the Smithereens (Meet the Smithereens!) that reproduces the song lineup and much of the arrangements on Meet the Beatles! misidentified the Smithereens lead guitarist, whose solos were compared to George Harrisons. Although Pat DiNizio does play guitar in the band, it is Jim Babjak who plays lead.

title: Stand Up, Ask Questions, Be Upbeat
description: MANY specialists on coping with difficult people suggest strategies specific to their behavior types.

title: A Family of Nine, Buffeted by an Injury, Remains Intact
description: Christmas presents came a few days late for the Fardan-Daniels children. On Dec. 28, Nadine Bosson, a social worker, took gifts to the Brooklyn shelter where the family was living.

title: Mets Wont Trade Future, So Present Must Wait
description: The telephone calls keep coming, so Mets General Manager Omar Minaya keeps listening. But trading away premium talent for a modest starter is not going to happen. So Minaya has resisted all comers, and will take a chance that the enigmatic Jorge Sosa and seven other candidates will ultimately produce three capable starters for the last three spots in the rotation.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the N.B.A. roundup in some copies last Thursday, about the Toronto Raptors 90-77 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, misstated the team that Toronto tied for the lead in the Atlantic Division as a result. It was the Nets, not the Knicks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Answer Global Critics by Tackling Troubling Issues
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 17  Iraqi political leaders stepped up efforts to persuade the world that they were tackling the countrys thorniest problems on Wednesday, highlighting crackdowns on militias, pressing for more rapid arming of Iraqi troops, and underlining progress on a national oil law and new examples of reconciliation with former Baathists.

title: Changes in Top Leadership Are Expected at Channel 13
description: After two decades under the same leadership, the New York public television station WNET, Channel 13, is planning a change at the top. Under a succession plan to be voted on today by the board of WNETs parent, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, William F. Baker, the chief executive officer, will step down in February 2008, to be replaced by Neal Shapiro, the former president of NBC News.

title: Ex-Convict Testifies in Sentencing Trial of Detectives Killer
description: At 27, Shabucalik Geralds can recall nine years in and out of federal prisons, selling drugs on probation a month after his release, firing guns at people 8 or 10 times and ordering two other shootings. Many of his crimes have gone without punishment, for he has proven more valuable to prosecutors as a serial cooperator.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Granddaughter, Sprouting

title: Appeals for Delayed Travelers
description: The Department of Homeland Security is setting up a new, simplified way for travelers to file an appeal if their journey is disrupted by security queries. The new system will allow travelers who have been denied or delayed boarding an airplane or entering the United States, or have been subjected to more intense searches or questioning by a department official to question why they were the target of such scrutiny. The new system, called the Traveler Redress Inquiry Program, will allow the person to file and track the status of the claim online and is scheduled to start late next month.

title: A Way to Lose the Headset and Still Make Cheap Skype Calls
description: Netgears Dual-Mode Cordless Phone with Skype  or the SPH200D for short  mixes plain old landline communications with cutting-edge Internet calling.

title: Arts, Briefly
Expert Ties Ex-Players Suicide to Brain Damage
description: Since the former National Football League player Andre Waters killed himself in November, an explanation for his suicide has remained a mystery. But after examining remains of Mr. Waterss brain, a neuropathologist in Pittsburgh is claiming that Mr. Waters had sustained brain damage from playing football and he says that led to his depression and ultimate death.

title: Mermaid Approaches, So Beauty Will Close
description: Beauty was no problem; twas actually fish that killed the beast.

title: Shaky Studio 60 Is Counting on Romance to Rouse Ratings
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17  Aaron Sorkin has a new pitch for all those viewers who did not fall in love last fall with Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip, his behind-the scenes look at a late-night comedy show.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary last Thursday about Roberta Wohlstetter, a military and foreign policy analyst, misstated the surname of her mother and reversed the middle name and surname of her father. Her mother was Elsie Morgan, not Morris. Her father was Edmund Morris Morgan  not Morgan Morris.

title: The Titans Return, Carrying Lacrosse Sticks
description: Casey Powell made a big mistake bringing his wife to New York to watch him play Saturday night in the first lacrosse game ever at Madison Square Garden.

title: As Tomlinson Looks Back in Anger, the Patriots Look Forward to the Colts
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 17  New England Coach Bill Belichick is apparently worried about getting to the Super Bowl again, not about LaDainian Tomlinsons feelings.

title: Pentagon Aide Regrets Stance on Law Firms for Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  A senior Pentagon official apologized on Wednesday to the lawyers of Guantnamo Bay detainees for suggesting that corporations should consider severing business ties with law firms that represent the detainees.

title: Is It Spring? Winter? Whats a Flower to Think?
description: ITS that time of year again: mail order catalogs are pouring in, and Web sites are saturated with color images of gorgeous plants that never get eaten by insects or ravaged by disease. Im dreaming of Fresca strawberries, an everbearing variety that will produce fruit all summer, if I start the seeds 16 weeks before my last frost date (kitchengardenseeds.com; (860) 567-6086).

title: Russia: Sakhalin Production Increases
description: Exxon Mobil said output from its $17 billion Sakhalin Island development in the Pacific off Russia jumped 40 percent in the last month. Oil and natural gas production from the Sakhalin-1 development has risen to the equivalent of more than 200,000 barrels of crude a day, according to Stuart McGill, senior vice president. Exxon, which operates and owns a 30 percent stake in the project, expects output eventually to reach the equivalent of 317,000 barrels a day. Production at Sakhalin-1 was about 160,000 barrels a day in early December, a Bear Stearns analyst, Nicole Decker, said in a Dec. 13 note to clients after an analysts lunch with Exxons chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson. Exxon began producing crude from the Chayvo field off Sakhalin Islands ice-choked coastline in October 2005. Exxons partners in Sakhalin-1 are a Japanese group known as Sodeco, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India and the state-run Russian oil company Rosneft.

title: Plan Will Allow 911 and 311 Lines to Accept Digital Images
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who built his fortune on innovations in information technology, announced a plan yesterday that will allow emergency 911 call centers and the popular 311 service line to receive digital photos and videos from callers.

title: The Reckoning: Ralph Rucci at F.I.T.
description: COMMENTATORS on the designer Ralph Rucci tend to vigorously defend him, as though there may be some doubt about his talent.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 4 about Delores Pryce, a Queens woman whose youngest daughter has health problems and who received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help pay an electricity bill, referred incorrectly to New Alternatives for Children, a program that helps families with medically fragile children. (The error was repeated in an article on Jan. 5 about Dorcas Acheampong, a Bronx woman who received help from the fund to help pay her rent.) Although it is a member agency of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, it is not run by the federation.

title: G.E. May Buy Abbotts Diagnostic Unit
description: General Electric is near a deal to buy Abbott Laboratories medical diagnostics unit for as much as $5 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about the appearance of a new island as a result of glacial melting in Greenland referred incorrectly to a region where another such island has appeared. Svalbard, off Norway, is an archipelago, not an island.

title: The Museum as Outdoor Movie Screen
Take an Internet Call and Some Notes, or Just Doodle
description: You cant put the world in your pocket, but you can put the Web there, with Nokias N800 Internet tablet, which is about the size of a paperback (3 by 6 by  inch). Like the earlier N770, it lets you browse the Internet, send and receive e-mail and instant messages, download audio and video and get R.S.S. feeds. The N800 adds a Web cam for videoconferencing and a microphone for Internet phone calls.

title: Democrats Say House Energy Bill Will Pass
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  House Democrats, brushing aside objections from the Bush administration, said on Wednesday that they had ample votes to pass a bill on Thursday that would eliminate $14 billion in subsidies and tax breaks for oil companies and channel the money to renewable-energy projects.

title: Owner of Outlet Malls Agrees to a Buyout
description: One week after disclosing that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection, the Mills Corporation, the owner of suburban outlet malls around the country, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for $1.4 billion by Brookfield Asset Management.

title: Governor Is Challenged on Ethics by Bruno
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17  The honeymoon may be coming to an end. Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader, accused Gov. Eliot Spitzer on Wednesday of being hypocritical for championing campaign finance reform while headlining a $25,000-a-couple fund-raiser later this week for the state Democratic Party.

title: Happy Hours
description: Washington

title: Iraqi Factories, Aging and Shut, Now Give Hope
description: RAMADI, Iraq, Jan. 16  Inside a huge shuttered factory on the gritty western fringes of this outlaw desert town, thousands of ornate porcelain sinks, toilets and other fixtures sit in row after row next to the automated ovens and assembly lines that once churned out the products but lie silent under a thin film of yellow desert dust.

title: Operating Costs Are Imperiling Disaster Fund
description: The federal governments biggest program to help people rebuild after natural disasters is on the verge of running out of operating money because of budgeting problems at the agency that runs it, the Small Business Administration.

title: North Korea and U.S. Envoys Meet in Berlin
description: BERLIN, Jan. 17  Seeking to revive stalled negotiations to end North Koreas nuclear weapons program, the United States held substantive talks with North Korean diplomats here on Tuesday and Wednesday, said the chief American envoy, Christopher R. Hill.

title: Offline Options for Backup
description: Q. What are the alternatives for backing up a computers data if you dont want to use an online service?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about a meeting between the United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, and the head of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, misstated the date of Mr. Lamys discussion with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain about the restart of global trade negotiations. It had already been held, on Jan. 9; it was not scheduled for Tuesday.

title: For a Media Room Away From Home, a Remote for the Laptop
description: Even seasoned business travelers need a bit of downtime. The Interlink ExpressCard Media Remote lets an average laptop act like a media center, complete with a couch-potato-worthy remote control.

title: Casting Blame for Looting in Trial of Getty Ex-Curator
description: ROME, Jan. 17  In a move that seemed to gratify prosecutors, lawyers for a former curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles who is on trial here asked on Wednesday that the court admit as evidence a letter in which the curator railed against her former employer.

title: Publisher Drops Novel About Mantle
description: 7: The Mickey Mantle Novel, a frequently salacious fictional account of the late Yankees life, was canceled yesterday by its publisher, HarperCollins, slightly more than a month before it was to be released.

title: New Chief Looks to U.S. for Peacekeeping Support
description: Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, asked President Bush and members of Congress during a two-day trip to Washington to lift a cap on spending for peacekeeping that limits the United States contribution to 25 percent of the total cost, which he said produced an annual shortfall of $200 million. The United States is the biggest contributor to peacekeeping and used to pay 27 percent, but Congress imposed the 25 percent cap in 2005 in response to instances of sexual abuses by peacekeepers. Mr. Ban said he had stressed that while there was a time when the relationship between the United Nations and the United States was not easy, it is time now to look for better days.

title: Calendar
description: Winter Antiques Show

title: Queens: Man Charged With Murder and Assault
description: A Ridgewood man has been charged with murder and assault in the shooting of two men outside a nightclub in Woodside three months ago, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Victor Gavalo, 24, of Stephens Street, was awaiting arraignment on the charges last evening in Queens Criminal Court. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said that Mr. Gavalo was charged with shooting the men on Oct. 1 as they sat in a car outside Club Phenomenon, which was shuttered last month under the public nuisance abatement law. The dead man was Ernesto Salgado, 22, of Sunnyside; the wounded mans identity was not released. NEW JERSEYNEWARK: MAN CHARGED IN FATAL SHOOTING An East Orange man already in custody on charges of setting his uncle on fire was charged with murder on Tuesday in the fatal shooting of a clothing store owner on Jan. 3, the police said yesterday. The man, Lamar A. Tidwell, 24, is charged with walking into the Clothing Wholesale and Retail Urban Warestore on Main Street and shooting the owner, Allen Cuff, 34. The men had argued a week earlier, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant Essex County prosecutor. Mr. Tidwell also faces weapons charges in that case. On Saturday he was charged with attempted murder; the authorities said he set fire to his uncle, Richard Burns, 54, in Mr. Burnss apartment in East Orange after an argument. Mr. Burns suffered injuries over 22 percent of his body and was in critical condition yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. Mr. Tidwell is being held in $1 million bail at the Essex County jail.

title: Digital Music Up 80% but Shy of Lost Revenue
description: LONDON, Jan. 17  Sales of digitally distributed music rose about 80 percent worldwide in 2006 but failed to make up for falling sales of compact discs, a trade group said Wednesday.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.When shopping online, I often see newsletters or blogs with design advice. Are any worth reading?

description: Boston

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Two Seek Large Stake in Tribune
description: As the deadline for bids for the Tribune Company came and went yesterday, the team of Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle made an audacious $500 million offer to help refinance the company while becoming its largest shareholder.

title: Crew Sensed Trouble Seconds Before Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Seventeen seconds before the crash last August of a Comair flight that took off from the wrong runway in Lexington, Ky., the co-pilot made an odd comment, the first indication that the crew knew something was wrong.

title: New Questions Raised in Bonds Investigation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17  In December 2003, Barry Bonds testified before the grand jury investigating the Balco steroid scandal. That grand jury expired without indicting him. Bondss case was hauled over to a second grand jury, which focused on whether he had perjured himself before the first grand jury. In July 2006, that grand jury also expired without an indictment. A third grand jury continued the investigation.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about General Electrics purchase of Smiths Groups aerospace business misstated G.E.s percentage of ownership of Smiths GE Detection, a joint venture between the companies. G.E. will own 36 percent, not 46 percent.
