title: Above the Fray
description: Photos from productions at the 2007 Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater.

title: Spontaneity and Pizazz
description: The images by Martin Munkacsi and Henri Cartier-Bresson at the International Center of Photography complement each other, highlighting modernism at its peak between the world wars.

title: Spamalot in Quest of Oliviers
description: The London production of the Broadway hit musical "Monty Python's Spamalot" led the field with seven nominations, including best new musical, when the competitors for the Laurence Oliviers, Britain's foremost theater awards, were announced yesterday.

title: Coram Boy Is Broadway Bound
description: The acclaimed English National Theater production of "Coram Boy" is to open on Broadway at the Imperial Theater on May 2, after previews beginning on April 16.

title: G.E. May Buy Abbotts Diagnostic Unit
description: General Electric is near a deal to buy Abbott Laboratories medical diagnostics unit for as much as $5 billion, according to The New York Times. Acquiring the Abbott business, which makes and sells glucose monitoring systems, blood test kits and other chemically based diagnostic tools, would enable G.E.s health care unit to expand its growing stable of diagnostic products and services.

title: Delay Denied on Tax Accounting Rule
description: The board that establishes accounting rules decided unanimously yesterday not to postpone a rule that requires companies to take a new, more stringent approach to reporting uncertain tax positions on their financial statements. The Financial Accounting Standards Board denied a request from Tax Executives International, which represents corporate tax officers, to delay the new rule, which takes effect this year. The rule, known as Fin 48, requires companies to examine and document their tax positions, evaluating whether those positions are likely to withstand a challenge by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Raines Seeks Curb on Fannie Mae Regulator
description: Fannie Maes former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, asked a federal appeals court Wednesday to bar the companys regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him. James B. Lockhart, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, has prejudged the charges against him and cannot serve as the impartial decision maker that due process requires, Mr. Raines said in a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. On Dec. 18, the agency sued Mr. Raines; a former chief financial officer, J. Timothy Howard; and Fannie Maes former controller, Leanne G. Spencer, for more than $215 million, citing their roles in profit overstatements of $6.3 billion from 2001 until mid-2004.

title: Not Playing in a Theater Near You
description: These days, the cosmopolitanism of international filmmaking is matched by the parochialism of American film culture.

title: Barclays Pays Record Price to Put Name on Nets Arena
description: It looks $400 million is the going rate these days to buy naming rights for the play grounds of professional sports teams, at least when investment banks are anteing up. Setting a record price for the naming rights to an American indoor sports arena, the British bank Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the New Jersey Nets planned future home in Brooklyn, according to press reports. The deal follows Citigroups November agreement to shell out $20 million a year over 20 years to have its name attached to the structure replacing Shea Stadium, the most expensive stadium rights deal in the United States.

title: Beacon Capital to Put More Properties on the Block
description: Less than three weeks after selling Bostons John Hancock Tower and other office buildings for about $3.2 billion, Beacon Capital Partners is moving to capitalize on the still-hot commercial real estate market by putting an even larger portfolio of properties in the city on the block, according to The Boston Globe.

title: Volkswagen Executive Confesses in Corruption Case
description: Volkswagens former personnel chief may get a suspended sentence and a fine in exchange for a confession on breach of trust charges, the judge at his trial over a corruption scandal at the automaker said Wednesday. The former executive, Peter Hartz, is charged with 44 counts of breach of trust in the case, which has shone an unsavory light on the cozy relationship between the companys management and labor representatives.

title: R.I.M. Releases More Data on Stock Options
description: Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, released additional preliminary financial results, but gave investors no better sense of the size of the earnings restatement the company would make after a review of its stock option grants to employees. In filings with Canadian and American securities regulators, Research in Motion repeated its earlier warning Tuesday that it could restate more than $45 million in earnings dating back to 1997, and again did not indicate an upper limit.

title: Apples Stellar Results Help Options Medicine Go Down
description: Apparently, nothing effaces the stigma of a scandal like a billion-dollar profit, as BusinessWeek, looking at Apples recent sales figures, points out. Buoyed by record sales of 21 million of its signature iPod digital media players, Apple reaped that billion-dollar bottom line on revenues of $7.1 billion in its fiscal first quarter. Net income surged 78 percent in the period that includes the year-end holiday season, yielding per-share profit of $1.14, Apple said Wednesday.

title: Goldman Said to Be Backing Lionsgate Slate
description: Lionsgate is putting the finishing touches on a $210 million financing pact led by Goldman Sachs, according to Variety, in a sign that private equity and hedge fund money continues to pour into Hollywood, despite mixed results on those investments in 2006. The deal apparently provides backing for 23 films, excluding, among other projects, the Saw movie franchise. Variety said that Lionsgate will receive a distribution fee of 15 percent  on the high side for deals that cover slates of films  showing just how the mini-studio has impressed Wall Street with its track record and its model of modestly priced films.

title: MTV Hooks Up with Campus Start-Up
description: Viacoms MTV Networks announced Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire RateMyProfessors.com. The site, which allows college students to share information on the performance of college professors, has more than 6.6 million ratings on more than 900,000 college professors and is visited by more than 10 million college students, according to MTV Networks. RateMyProssors.com will become a part of MTV Networks mvtU.com, a 24-hour online college channel that covers campus news, music and videos for college students, as well as a campus television production company.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Says Rules Bar Satellite Radio Merger
description: Has the fat lady sung for a possible merger between Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio Holdings? The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Kevin Martin, said Wednesday that the two satellite radio companies would not win approval of a merger under current rules. Speculation has ramped up in the last few weeks over the possibility of such a deal, which has long been championed by a slew of market watchers, as well as Sirius executives. And last week XM officials were apparently showing signs of enthusiasm themselves at a Citigroup entertainment and media conference.

title: Universal Poaches Fox Executive for Animated Venture
description: Universal Pictures has raided 20th Century Fox and hired away the animation executive who oversaw the hit Ice Age movies, a move intended to fill a void left when Paramount acquired DreamWorks and replaced Universal as distributor of animated films like Over the Hedge. Universal has lured Christopher Meledandri, the president of 20th Century Fox Animation, with a deal to initially finance a new company run by Mr. Meledandri, whose animated and live action films would be exclusive to Universal, according to press reports. The plan calls for the firm to ultimately be financed by outside investors.

title: Chandlers Make Competing Bid for Tribune
description: Tribune Companys largest shareholder, the Chandler family, has submitted a bid to buy the company and spin off some of its broadcast and entertainment operations in an offer that values Tribune at $7.6 billion.

title: Canadian Cable Company Begins Share Sale
description: The Canadian cable operator Cogeco Cable said Wednesday it is issuing 4.5 million of its surging subordinate voting shares at 38.50 Canadian dollars ($32.77) each for a total of 173.25 million Canadian dollars ($147.47 million). The net proceeds of the bought deal, underwritten by a syndicate including Scotia Capital, GMP Securities, BMO Nesbitt Burns and CIBC World Markets, are to be used to repay debt and for general corporate purposes.

title: L.S.E. Doubles Down to Win Shareholder Loyalty
description: The London Stock Exchange stepped up its defense against the 2.7 billion pound ($5.3 billion) bid from it rival, Nasdaq, with the promise that it will give up to 250 million pounds back to shareholders. This is more than double the amount that had been expected in the City of London, and the L.S.E. is hoping it will be enough to persuade its investors to remain loyal and reject the offer, The Guardian reported.

title: Broadcom Probe May Focus on Founders
description: As federal investigators ramp up their examination of stock option practices at Broadcom, the chip maker, they are likely to put a spotlight on Henry T. Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, the billionaire founders of the company, legal experts told The Los Angeles Times. Broadcom disclosed last month that the Securities and Exchange Commission had elevated its inquiry to a formal investigation, an action that gives the agency the power to subpoena documents and testimony.

title: Allianz to Buy Out European Stakes for $13.5 Billion
description: The German insurer Allianz said it is offering 10.5 billion euros ($13.5 billion) to buy out the stakes it does not already own in Frances AGF and Germanys Allianz Leben as it tries to get a better grip on its wide array of European operations. Allianz said the deals would strengthen its position in Europe and in growth markets, simplify its ownership structure and lift earnings per share in 2008.

title: Merrill to Pour $4 Billion into Real Estate Venture
description: Merrill Lynch plans to invest up to $4.15 billion in a property development partnership with the Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings, Reuters reported. Merrill Lynchs Japan arm and SBI have agreed to create a special-purpose company to buy land and build condominiums and commercial properties, intending to sell the developments on to real estate funds and other investors, the report said.

title: Citigroup and Goldman Invest in Indian Software Firm
description: Citigroup and Goldman Sachs will invest a total of $52 million in software firm ICSA of India, the company said on Wednesday. Citigroup would pay $30 million for a 14 percent stake, which will be made up of new shares and 284,000 convertible warrants. Goldman would buy $22 million of foreign currency convertible bonds.

title: Brightcove Uploads $59.5 Million in Funding
description: An Internet video company, Brightcove, said Wednesday that it had received $59.5 million in funds from dozens of investors, including The New York Times Company. The company, one of dozens of video-sharing start-ups trying to take on Googles YouTube also took in funding from AllianceBernstein, Brookside Capital, and Maverick Capital.

title: Equity Office: Sharper Elbows in Buyout Battles
description: With the unprecedented amount of cash sloshing around in private equitys pockets, it may have been inevitable, but the gloves have come off in buyouts. Late Wednesday, a group of investors offered $38 billion for the nations largest office landlord, setting off the biggest buyout battle since the landmark fight for RJR Nabisco nearly two decades ago. The upstart bid for Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust that was founded by Samuel Zell, tops a $36 billion deal that Equity Office had reached with the Blackstone Group in November. Either bid would win the crown as the largest buyout ever, surpassing last summers $33 billion deal for HCA.

title: Hedge Funds Boost Knight Capitals Profit
description: Knight Capital Group, the second-largest trader of Nasdaq-listed stocks, said fourth-quarter profit increased 13 percent as it handled more shares and fees rose from its Deephaven hedge funds. Net income rose to $47.4 million from $41.9 million a year earlier, while revenue increased 29 percent, to $260.1 million. Deephaven Capital Management produced $27.4 million in pretax profit from asset-management fees, compared with $6.6 million a year earlier. The hedge funds had $4.2 billion under management as of Dec. 31, up from $2.9 billion a year earlier.

title: Top 10 Responses (So Far)
description: We appreciate all the responses so far, and were also taking note of those who put in a little extra effort for contest purposes (see post below). The readers sports columnist contest will remain open until the kickoff of Colts-Pats on Sunday at 6:30 p.m. Eastern. So feel free to join the Manning-Brady debate, and you can also send in comments judging fellow contestants.

title: The Doomsday Clock  and Schlock
description: This just in from the Royal Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science: The world will end in 2157.

title: An All-Volunteer Army
description: A day before the festival, volunteers were being trained all over the place. The process seemed to involve surgically implanting a chip into their buttocks briefings on significant logistical issues and a reminder that it is credentials, and not rhetoric, that determines entrance into various hot venues. The Bagger listened for a while and tried to fathom what goodness lurked in peoples hearts that they would volunteer to assist a crowd that is steeped in prerogative and entitlement. Friendly but firm was the mantra driving the indoctrination

title: iSundance
description: Those of you who have an interest in the festival, but not in being part of the crush of 50,000 people, can always skip the queue and take in some of the films and many of the panel discussions on iTunes. (There are also streams available at www.sundance.org/watch). The Bagger, who watched Good Will Hunting on his iPod in the airplane on the way out here  he likes to think of Matt and Ben as his little friends who live in a box  thinks that watching films on a tiny little screen with headphones is perfectly acceptable behavior. And on a computer screen, its a fine way to pass the time until that freak of a boss returns from another one of those endless lunches.

title: For $600 More, You Can Buy the Movie
description: The Bagger doesnt know from tickets at Sundance  hes sure theyre around here somewhere  but apparently anything with a whiff of heat will cost you both lots of money and some of your dignity. According to cinematical, if you want to go to Black Snake Moan and dont have tickets already, it will cost you $345 bucks. Thats seems to be the going price of social currency within a small, temporary community.

title: Merrill Posts $2.3 Billion 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Helped by gains from trading and buyouts, Merrill Lynch said its fourth-quarter profit surged 68 percent to $2.35 billion, or $2.41 a share, from $1.39 billion a year earlier. The results, which exceeded analysts estimates, fall in line with the record profits other Wall Street firms have shown over the past year, as mergers and acquisitions activity has risen to new heights.

title: Dead, Not Dead
description: The Hollywood Reporter suggests that the ancient film ratings system is in for an overhaul.

title: Grim Fairy Tale
description: Dave Poland, over at Movie City News, tells an L.A. fairy tale, which means that the characters who symbolize Betrayal, Arrogance and Deceit end up running a marathon on the Stairmaster. The Bagger didnt understand it all  allegory is often lost on him  but it seems that sometimes showbiz people are not always straightforward when it comes to taking and giving credit.

title: On the Ground Reporting
description: Unlike the Bagger, who has been letting that yucky newspaper work get in the way of his one true love  blogging night and day for your consideration  indieWIRE showed up early and often. They have a nice bit on the button of the moment: Focus on Film.

title: Sundance Folkways
description: The Bagger caught a break last night at Sundance. Instead of her annual contribution to the March of Dimes, a kindly movie exec took him to a private dinner where the cool people go in Deer Valley, above Park City. The food was really good, the people were indeed beautiful, and the Bagger did a fair job of pretending he had seen the movies everyone was talking about. He was, however, in a hurry to get back to the condo to practice his one authentic skill  typing. But there were not one, but two, Hummers in his way. (The Bagger, who did not get the memo about proper automotive accessories at Sundance, was driving his fathers Oldsmobile.) The scenario involved well-fed, well-wined people backing huge metal objects up a steep, snow-encrusted driveway. Driver number two failed after repeated efforts and then pronounced his vehicle out of gas. He used the incline and a bit of dicey navigation to get the behemoth down to the bottom of the drive and the Bagger made his escape. This opening ceremony of out of the way, the Bagger thought, yourre in.

title: On the Hill: Ethics Changes Stalled
description: Late last night, Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, tried to hold a vote on ethics changes. It was blocked. He charged Republican malfeasance. But Republicans said they would block the ethics bill unless it contained the presidential line-item veto, which they said would allow the president to cut out individual earmarks stuck into a bill. The Democrats hope to get the bill through today, but if it doesnt happen, there could be a sizeable nonpartisan coalition of secretly relieved lawmakers. Our favorite quote from the floor on Wednesday was uttered by Senator Trent Lott, the minority leader:

title: Has Rice Been Wronged?
description: Noting that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has lately seemed constantly perturbed when not downright angry, Kathleen Reardon, a professor of management at the University of Southern California and the author of Its All Politics, questions whether the bond between President Bush and Condoleezza Rice may be weakening. Blogging at The Huffington Post, Reardon says the president seems to be putting distance between the two of them. He has given more praise and nods of approval lately to Joe Lieberman than hes given to her.

title: Gay Slurs at Greys Anatomy  Cant We All Just Get Along?
description: Joining Michael Richards, who blew a fuse on stage late last year and began spewing racial slurs like a Grand Wizard, and before him, Mel Gibson, who saw in a police traffic stop an opportunity to call the worlds Jews out for their prolific war mongering, we now have Greys Anatomy star Isaiah Washington, whos drawn the ire of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.

title: Flashback: The Blackout
description: With winter finally upon us  and temperatures in the 20s  the July blackout in Queens might seem like a distant memory. But a blistering report from state regulators on Con Eds role in the ordeal brought it all back today.

title: The War Like Its 2008
description: Iraq has already become a central issue in the burgeoning 2008 race, and its extremely evident on Capitol Hill.

title: Ode to the R.I.A.A.
description: Ever since I phased out my career as a Broadway arranger and conductor, I've tried to keep my toe in the showbiz world in my own peculiar way: I write new, tech-industry lyrics to old melodies.

title: All of a Sudden, Warrants for Wiretapping
description: Bloggers on both the right and left express confusion over the Bush administrations surprise announcement that it has given a secret court jurisdiction over the National Security Agencys wiretapping program. At the National Review Online, Mark Levin says the move goes to the heart of the White Houses credibility. For the Bush administration to argue for years that this program, as operated, was critical to our national security and fell within the presidents Constitutional authority, to then turn around and surrender presidential authority this way is disgraceful.

title: After 20 Seasons, Testaverde Has a Shot at First Super Bowl
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 18  If the New England Patriots beat the Indianapolis Colts and advance to the Super Bowl, it will be a milestone for their 43-year-old backup quarterback, Vinny Testaverde, who has never reached the Super Bowl in 20 N.F.L. seasons.

title: Colts' Manning Keeps Quiet
description: Colts quarterback Peyton Manning has been noticeably quiet this week in Indianapolis, opting to address the news media only once  at a huge news conference scheduled for Friday afternoon. So it has fallen to the rest of the Colts to guess how Manning will be judged after Sunday's game against the Patriots.

title: Dolans Look to Malone after Second Cablevision Bid Rejection
description: Shortly after the rejection of their $8.9 billion second offer for Cablevision, the cable companys ruling Dolan family might be looking to John Malone for some solace, The New York Post reports. Unnamed sources said that the failed bid poses an opportunity for the two sides to talk about selling part or all of the networks Rainbow Media, home to the AMC and IFC channels, to Mr. Malones Liberty Media. As it previously reported, the Post said that the Dolans could use cash from the transaction to make a third run at Cablevision.

title: Dunn and Others Offered Pleas in Hewlett-Packard Case
description: The California attorney generals office has offered plea bargains to Patricia Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, and four other defendants, offering them the chance to accept a misdemeanor charge each for their role in a spying scandal at the company, The San Jose Mercury News reported Thursday. But federal prosecutors will continue with their own case, which the Mercury News said could endanger those deals through double jeopardy provisions in Californias penal code. (State attorneys are discouraged from pursuing cases in which defendants have been acquitted or convicted in federal court.)

title: Inch by Inch, Taking Democracy Online
description: The Pew Internet and American Life Project released its first report on the 2006 elections and the extent to which the Internet played a role in the transaction of politics. Seems it was a banner year  and if Lee Rainie, the organizations grand poo-bah and co-author of the report is to be believed, the 2008 election cycle may well prove something of a tipping point.

title: Mayor Defends Con Ed, Again
description: The New York State Public Service Commissions report [text in pdf] on Con Eds role [press release] in the nine-day Queens blackout urges that the utility pay $9.3 million in penalties  a number that could be far higher if the Public Service Commission launches what is known as a prudence proceeding, which could result in hefty fines.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "The Scene," "Fluke" and "Toys in the Attic."

title: Phillycars.com
description: An ad for Phillycars.com, a Web site intended to offer a Philadelphia-focused alternative to auto-shopping sites like Cars.com and Vehix.com.

title: Phillycars.com
description: An ad for Phillycars.com, a Web site intended to offer a Philadelphia-focused alternative to auto-shopping sites like Cars.com and Vehix.com.

title: We Land Where Others Fly
description: Still trying to be on vacation, but now that the topic lurches to lonelygirl, I had to share some fan fiction recommended by a reader.

title: J.P. Morgan Is Ready to Spend
description: After pulling in record-breaking profits for 2006, J.P. Morgan Chases chief executive, Jamie Dimon, wants to celebrate with a shopping spree. If something comes up, were prepared at this point to take a look, Mr. Dimon said on Wednesday.

title: Ode to the R.I.A.A.
description: Ever since I phased out my career as a Broadway arranger and conductor, Ive tried to keep my toe in the showbiz world in my own peculiar way: I write new, tech-industry lyrics to old melodies.

title: John Hall and Kiryas Joel
description: In an article on one of the states tighter congressional upsets in November, The Forward looks at the debt that John Hall, the Orleans frontman turned freshman congressman, owes to the Satmar Hasidic leaders of Kiryas Joel.With the backing of Mayor Abraham Wider, Mr. Hall won 88 percent of the villages vote  and defeated incumbent Sue Kelly. The rabbis basically hand out pieces of paper and tell people how to vote, a Hall spokesman says. They have a history of wanting to vote with winners. (Eliot Spitzer also got their endorsement.)

title: More on Pet Projects
description: Last weekend, we reported on the mountain of discretionary capital projects  critics would call most of it pork  that former Gov. Pataki and the legislature divvied up in the waning days of the Pataki administration.

title: For a Senator, Hedge Funds Are Close to Home
description: Joseph Biden has more than a passing familiarity with hedge funds. As a Democratic senator and a longtime member of that bodys judiciary committee, the Delaware native participated in hearings last year on issues ranging from regulation to naked short-selling.

title: Tech Companies Get Serious About Global Rights Issues. But Wheres Cisco?
description: It looks like after years of hollering, civil rights groups have nudged some technology companies into a dialogue over how to avoid stomping on human rights, freedom of speech, privacy and other concepts that arent considered quite so precious in some countries where the Western companies are aggressively doing business.

title: N.Y.S.E. Traders Back Suit Against Exchange
description: A lawsuit filed by former New York Stock Exchange seatholders against the exchange has gotten some backing, The New York Post reported Thursday. Filed by Allison Wey, the wife of an N.Y.S.E. broker with Bear Wagner Securities, the $4.5 million suit claims that at a breakfast in February of 2005, Mr. Thain denied the exchange was considering a merger or a public offering. The Weys then sold their seat for $1.54 million the next month. (The N.Y.S.E. eventually merged with the Archipelago electronic exchange, creating one of the worlds largest exchanges with a current market capitalization of $16 billion.)

title: Bruno Ramps Up Spitzer Attack
description: So much for the honeymoon.

title: Blogtalk
description: Schumer in his boxers: a terrifying mental image? [Owen Kellogg]

title: Taking Marriage Off the Pedestal
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Jan. 18 column, The Elusive Altar.

title: Did Hedge Funds Fall, or Just Stumble?
description: Is it possible that hedge funds, the media stars du jour, may have lost a little of their shine lately? Data from two reports suggests that may be the case  at least, temporarily. Bloomberg News writes of a new study by Hedge Fund Research showing that hedge fund inflows dropped 64 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006. And a separate report by Spectrem found that among the wealthiest investors, investment in that $1.3 trillion asset class dropped by more than 10 percent.

title: Heeding Dr. Kings Call
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Jan. 18 column, The Lost Voice of Protest.

title: Mehlman Says Goodbye
description: In his farewell speech to Republicans attending the annual G.O.P. winter meeting, the national partys outgoing chairman, Ken Mehlman, reflected a bit on the losses sustained by his party in the midterm elections and encouraged, even at times goaded, members on moving forward in different ways.

title: G.E. Buys Abbotts Diagnostics Unit for $8.13 Billion
description: General Electric will buy Abbotts laboratory diagnostics business for $8.13 billion in cash, the two companies announced Thursday afternoon. The acquisition will strengthen G.E.s own burgeoning diagnostics business as it absorbs the Abbott units. The sale does not include Abbotts lucrative molecular diagnostics and glucose monitoring businesses.

title: Reconstruction Hurdles in Lebanon
description: Many in Lebanon believe the current political crisis is slowing efforts to rebuild areas heavily damaged in last summer's war with Israel.

title: Art Buchwald: A Celebrity for Death
description: Buchwald surprised friends and doctors alike as he turned his "deathbed" into a lively social circuit. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

title: Art Buchwald: His Political Satire
description: In 1962, Buchwald gave up his comfortable expat life to chronicle Washington politics. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

title: Art Buchwald: The Herald Tribune Years
description: Landing a column at The Herald Tribune took all of the young Buchwald's wit and charm. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

title: Art Buchwald: I Just Died
description: Art Buchwald was one of the great American humorists. He delighted in skewering the powerful and the pompous. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

title: Consumer Reports Pulls Child Car Seat Report
description: Consumer Reports has withdrawn a bombshell report the magazine published earlier this month that suggested that many of the child car seats currently on the market performed badly at speeds just barely above the government test standard for child safety seats of 30 miles per hour.

title: Green Light
description: Will Mark Green have a second career in television?

title: Movie Minutes: 'Mafioso'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Mafioso," which has been re-released after more than 40 years.

title: CSpan: Back on the Road Again
description: CSpan announced today that its campaign bus, following the 2008 Like Its Today approach, will be back on the road again, beginning Sunday.

title: The Waif From Ipanema
description: My post on changing body fashions in Brazil prompted readers to raise and debate an excellent question: Why do women suffer to look like skeletons even when men dont want them to?

title: Another Hat in the Ring
description: The deadline is near for those New Yorkers who wish to be apply for the state comptrollers job, and some interesting candidates are already popping out of the woodwork. Among them: Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a leading black money manager and philanthropist who two years ago donated $50 million to institutions and individuals working towards racial equality.

title: First 100 Hours, or Something, Come to a Close
description: House Democratic leaders, flanked by new members, waxed triumphant today as they prepared to pass the last six for 06 measure during the first 100 hours. Of course, as has been much examined in the press and much derided by the Republicans, it wasnt actually 100 hours in the way that, you know, human beings experience the passing of time. And it wasnt even 100 hours from when the 110th session of Congress opened. But, whatever, they passed em pretty quickly.

title: Senate Ethics Impasse Broken
description: Update at 9:15 p.m. or so: The Senate passes ethics bill, 96-2.An amendment to create an independent office of Public integrity was defeated.This is without the amendment Republican Senator Judd Gregg and other G.O.P. senators wanted that would have given a president veto power over line items. Under an agreement reached earlier tonight, that will come up next week with the minimum wage legislation.

title: Is It Finally Time for Tax Reform?
description: The idea of tax reform has been off the table for a long time. Republicans used it effectively as a political issue when they were out of power, but once they got control of Congress they lost interest in the subject. It was too easy to enact every tax cut they wanted without worrying about how it was messing up the tax code.

title: An Epidemic of Misunderstanding About Childrens Mental Health
description: Roy Richard Grinker, a professor of anthropology at George Washington University, whose 15-year-old daughter is autistic, has just come out with a new book that calls into question what weve come to know as the autism epidemic. Its called Unstrange Minds, and it makes the argument that the dramatic rise in the incidence of autism in the past few decades is mostly  if not entirely  the result of more and better diagnoses. In other words, in the not-so-distant past, autism as a wide-ranging diagnostic category (a spectrum disorder) simply didnt exist, and it certainly wasnt consistently measured.

title: Arriving for Sundance
description: The Carpetbagger (a k a David Carr) arrives for the Sundance Film Festival for the first time and asks the veterans for some advice.

title: A Bombing in Baghdad
description: Witnesses at a wholesale vegetable market described how three bomb explosions killed at least 10 people and wounded 30. The Times's Damien Cave reports.

title: Maine City Bans Smoking in Cars Carrying Children
description: Bangor, Maines second-largest city, is banning smoking in cars if children are present. The ordinance has delighted some and angered others, leading to complaints about invasion of privacy and even threats to boycott the city.

title: Approach Boss With Caution
description: PHOENIX  On a scale of one to 10, with 10 being the most volatile personality, Jonathan G. Ornstein, chief executive of the Mesa Air Group, cheerfully admitted, I used to be an 11.

title: Giants Hope Gilbride Can Animate Manning
description: The power structure of the Giants, from the team president, John Mara, to the new general manager, Jerry Reese, to Coach Tom Coughlin, took turns recently expressing a general disappointment in the development of quarterback Eli Manning. Each stated an urgent goal of making him better.

title: Very Strange and Very Naked
description: I have seen the Glorious Future.

title: A Chance to Save Their Skin
description: BABY boomers are so last century.

title: Heaven and High Water in South Carolinas New Wilderness
description: ONE moment, the paddler was sliding through a narrow passageway between an ancient bald cypress and a towering tupelo gum tree. The next, the upturned yellow hull of his kayak was all any of us could see.

title: White House Shifting Tactics in Spy Cases
description: In a four-paragraph letter on Wednesday announcing that the Bush administration had reversed its position and would submit its domestic surveillance program to judicial supervision, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales used one phrase three times. A secret court, he said, had fashioned a way to allow the program to be monitored by the judiciary without compromising the need for speed and agility.

title: Art in Review
description: NEW YORK CERAMICS FAIR

title: Police Shooting Led Mayor to Bolster Review Board
description: Concerns about police-community relations following the Sean Bell shooting prompted the Bloomberg administration to examine the board that investigates claims of police abuse  a review that led the mayor to announce an increase in funds for it during his State of the City speech, city officials said.

title: Queens: Officer Hurt in Hit-and-Run
description: A police officer was injured last night in a hit-and-run involving a sport utility vehicle that he had stopped in Jamaica, the police said. The S.U.V., a black GMC Yukon, dragged the officer 30 feet to 122nd Avenue and Sutphin Boulevard about 8:30 p.m., they said. It then fled north on Sutphin Boulevard. The vehicle was found abandoned about an hour later on 139th Street. The officer, Sgt. John Pagnotta, 40, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. Investigators said that they had identified the vehicles owner and were looking to question him.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by an appeals court to strike down a Maryland law that required companies like Wal-Mart to spend more on employee health care misidentified the states attorney general, who has two weeks to appeal. He is Douglas F. Gansler  not J. Joseph Curran Jr., whom Mr. Gansler succeeded earlier this month.

title: Economy Seems to Be Holding Its Own, but Inflation Risk Persists
description: The economy seems to be shaking off a slowdown brought on by the precipitous drop in housing, the latest economic data suggested yesterday.

title: Nino and His Oh-So-Present Memories of Underdevelopment
description: In Mafioso, Alberto Lattuadas incomparable, half-forgotten 1962 crime comedy-travelogue (and then some), the divisions between northern and southern Italy are drawn in vivid, almost cartoonish relief. The hero, played by the great Italian comic actor Alberto Sordi  an irrepressible mixture of clown, blowhard and matinee idol  scrambles to reconcile the contradictions between his life in Milan and his Sicilian roots, an identity crisis that is clearly not his alone.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Independence at the Hammer
description: INDEPENDENCE

title: Departing Chief Warns G.O.P. on Outlook for 2008 Races
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Ken Mehlman, the departing chairman of the Republican National Committee, warned on Thursday that his party would suffer even more devastating losses in 2008 than it did in 2006 if it did not reach out to minorities and address voter concerns about ethics.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the crime and discontent that has accompanied prosperity for some in the Chinese city of Guangzhou referred incorrectly to the citys economic development. It has reached $7,800 per capita gross domestic product  not per capita income. (Go to Article)

title: The Races Will Go On (With Imported Snow)
description: The International Ski Federation yesterday gave a green light to the coming World Cup ski races in Kitzbhel, Austria, where organizers used a fleet of helicopters this week to import more than 100,000 cubic feet of snow from higher elevations.

description: To the Editor:

description: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Friday.

description: To the Editor:
