description: A selection of antiques events this weekend in Manhattan, including the two major shows reviewed today:

title: Housing Cost Takes a Bigger Leap Upward
description: The cost of putting a roof over ones head in the New York metropolitan region rose faster last year than at any other time since Edward I. Koch was mayor, the federal Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Reforms for Movie Ratings
description: The motion picture industry has announced that it is reforming its movie ratings system, which has been sharply criticized by moviemakers and by a recent hard-hitting documentary. The reforms are not perfect, and some details remain sketchy, but they are an important step toward making the movies rating more transparent and fair.

title: People
description: People

title: Four Singers, Playing Cards, Breaking the Rules of Opera
description: Robert Ashley has never worried that the works he calls operas bear little resemblance to the traditional variety, and theres no reason he should start now. Far more than Philip Glasss operas, which are considered revolutionary for their stripped-down narratives and vocal lines that are ritualistically repetitive rather than flighty and virtuosic, Mr. Ashleys works jettison the standard operatic yardsticks.

title: Groups Offer Health Plan for Coverage of Uninsured
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  A broad coalition of business and consumer groups, doctors, hospitals and drug companies laid out a major proposal on Thursday to provide health coverage to more than half of the nations 47 million uninsured by expanding federal benefit programs and offering new tax credits to individuals and families.

title: State Farm to Pay $1 Million to Settle Gulf Claim
description: On the eve of trial, State Farm agreed yesterday to pay an estimated $1 million to settle a lawsuit by a Mississippi Gulf Coast resident whose house was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. The settlement came a week after a jury ordered the insurer to pay $2.5 million in punitive damage to a homeowner with a similar case.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,031,850.29

title: A Middle Ground for Stem Cells
description: Washington

title: Secretary General Orders Audits of U.N. Programs
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 19  Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, called today for outside examination of all United Nations activities after a published report that the United Nations Development Program in North Korea was making unaccountable payments in hard currency to local staff members and the Pyongyang government.

title: Cost of Corn Soars, Forcing Mexico to Set Price Limits
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18  Facing public outrage over the soaring price of tortillas, President Felipe Caldern abandoned his free-trade principles on Thursday and forced producers to sign an agreement fixing prices for corn products.

title: With Democrats in Control, New York Awaits More Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  With Congress in the hands of their fellow Democrats, lawmakers and other officials from the New York metropolitan region are seeking to rewrite many of the aid formulas to funnel tens of billions of additional dollars to the region in the coming years.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Innovator and Master, Side by Side
description: In 1932 the young Henri Cartier-Bresson, lately returned from Africa, saw a photograph of African children charging into waves on a beach. I must say that it is that very photograph which was for me the spark that set fire to fireworks, he recalled years later. I couldnt believe such a thing could be caught with the camera. I said, Damn it, took my camera and went out into the street. What Cartier-Bresson produced during the next few years, as the curator Peter Galassi once wrote, became one of the great, concentrated episodes in modern art.

title: Putting Hitler on the Couch, and Finding Bees
description: The wise beekeeper does not wear dark clothing, lest it pick up light-colored pollen. Italian bees are gentler and more chic than the Austrian variety. The mating box, capping fork and spur-wheel embedder are essential tools for apiculture. And all power in the beehive rests with a treacherous but fragrant bitch.

title: After 42 Hours (or So), House Democrats Complete 100-Hour Push
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  House Democrats met the goals of their 100-hour legislative offensive with plenty of time to spare on Thursday, claiming that their successes proved they could govern.

title: More Room to Pirouette at Lincoln Center Studios
description: To the untrained eye, they may just be dance studios  albeit spanking new ones  with the requisite barres, mirrors and sprung floors. But to those who have followed Lincoln Centers ambitious, sometimes torturous, redevelopment project over the last eight years, they are a milestone: the first piece to be completed.

title: Surging and Purging
description: Theres something happening here, and what it is seems completely clear: the Bush administration is trying to protect itself by purging independent-minded prosecutors.

title: Correction: The $250,000 Question
description: An article last Friday about $250,000 second homes around the nation misstated a lake open to the public near Victorville, Calif., a popular second-home area. It is Silverwood Lake, which is in a state recreation area, not Lake Arrowhead, which is private.

title: Unlikely Pairing, on and Off Court, Helps Energize Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 17  Mikki Moore and Hassan Adams are separated by nine years in age, eight inches in height and eight seasons in N.B.A. experience. They were born on opposite coasts of the United States.

title: A Warning From the Garden
description: Well, so much for our daffodils! They all bloomed in our front yard last week. They now form a nice bright yellow cluster at the bottom of our driveway. Temperatures of 65 degrees in Washington in January will do that. Frankly, daffodils in January do brighten up the lawn. Maybe next year well try for roses in February.

title: The Raid on Raters
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about a positive drug test by Barry Bonds misstated the number of random drug tests allowed under an agreement between Major League Baseball and the players association. In addition to testing players on each 40-man roster, the agreement provides for 600 random tests, not 580.

title: Italy: Hungarian Move by Bank
description: Intesa Sanpaolo, the Italian bank, offered to buy shares in its Hungarian unit, Inter-Europa Bank Nyrt, also known as IEB. Intesa Sanpaolo, which owns 84.7 percent of IEB, which is based in Budapest, offered 4,074 forint ($21) a share, it said.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Spitzer and Corzine Appeal for Antiterrorism Aid
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan 19  Warning that it would be a grave mistake to further reduce antiterrorism financing to the nations busiest urban center, Govs. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey pressed the Bush administration today for a substantial increase in federal money to improve security for the regions highways and mass transit lines.

title: AT&T Plans Unity Strategy for Free Calls
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18  Only weeks after closing its deal for BellSouth, AT&T is embarking on an ambitious strategy to show customers the benefit of its owning 100 million phone lines.

title: Endorsement for Voting Machine Labs
description: The National Institute of Standards and Technology has recommended approval of two laboratories for testing electronic voting machines under a new federal oversight program. The institute, part of the Commerce Department, said SysTest Laboratories and iBeta Software Quality Assurance, both of Colorado, were the first to pass examinations, and the federal Election Assistance Commission is expected to grant them full accreditation. Voting machine experts have long been concerned about possible conflicts of interests, because the testing laboratories are paid by the companies that make the machines. When the oversight program started last summer, the commission found serious deficiencies at Ciber Inc. and held up the companys request for temporary certification. Officials said Ciber was still fixing those problems. Ciber and three other companies  Wyle Laboratories, InfoGuard Laboratories Inc. and BKP Security Labs  have also applied for full accreditation.

title: Perhaps Thinking of Legacy, Bush Has Rice on the Move
description: LONDON, Jan. 18  Two years from the end of his second term, President Bush  perhaps with his legacy in mind  sent his secretary of state to try to restart moribund peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians and to create a foundation of Muslim support for the administrations new strategy in Iraq.

title: Welterweight Bialystock Treads Softly on Big Shtick
description: Max Bialystock is many things  a stinking liar, a crook, a shameless noodge, a stud muffin for the elderly and infirm. And of course a big fat Broadway producer. But a mensch he is not.

title: Flexing Muscle, China Destroys Satellite in Test
description: China successfully carried out its first test of an antisatellite weapon last week, signaling its resolve to play a major role in military space activities and bringing expressions of concern from Washington and other capitals, the Bush administration said yesterday.

title: Vatican Meets to Discuss Relations With China
description: ROME, Jan. 19  The Vatican began two days of closed-door meetings today on the churchs relations with China, which have soured because of a dispute over the right to appoint bishops.

title: Partial Demolition Planned for a Reminder of Sept. 11
description: The only architectural vestige of the World Trade Center complex still standing aboveground, the survivors stairway, would be largely demolished under a proposal by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

title: Beneath the Glitz, a Middle-Class Aspen
description: WHEN Don Bird is on vacation or traveling away from his Aspen home, if someone asks him where he lives, he will answer, Colorado. If pressed to be more specific, he might admit that he lives in the mountains, but he will do anything to keep from confessing that he lives in Aspen.

title: Reverberations, No Charge
description: Ten Saturdays with Buxtehude, a free series of organ recitals by John Scott, begins tomorrow at 4 p.m. at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue, at 53rd Street. Other concerts in the series, all at 4 p.m., will be on Feb. 3, 10, 17 and 24; March 31; April 28; and May 12, 19 and 26.

title: Coke Executive to Resign Post
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its marketing chief, Mary E. Minnick, would leave the company, a month after the company promoted its international chief, Muhtar Kent, to chief operating officer.

title: Germany: Media Mogul Demands Redress
description: Deutsche Bank and its former chief executive, Rolf E. Breuer, are facing damage claims of 1.4 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from the media mogul Leo Kirch for comments made in 2002 about the creditworthiness of Mr. Kirchs media group. The claims have no substance, and well vigorously counter any legal action, a Deutsche Bank spokesman, Ronald Weichert, said. The bank received a letter from Mr. Kirchs lawyers demanding it pay the money by Jan. 30 or face a lawsuit, Mr. Weichert said. The dispute stems from a 2002 Bloomberg television interview in which Mr. Breuer said the financial sector was not prepared to provide new loans for Mr. Kirchs company. The company collapsed a few months later.

title: Israel Transfers $100 Million to Abbas
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19  Israel transferred $100 million in tax revenues to the office of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas as part of a plan to bolster him and keep money out of the hands of the Hamas government, officials said today.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Relocating, and Reclaiming a Mentors Legacy
description: NOT to nitpick, but somebody who worked for Ralph Nader in his Naders Raiders consumer advocate heyday and votes for him whenever he runs for president better be making a legitimate segue back to the New York City rental scene. Henriette Mantel, who has been in Hollywood the past 13 years and is about to release An Unreasonable Man, an Oscar-short-listed documentary about Mr. Nader and his devastating feud with the Democratic Party, swears that she is. Nothing under the table for her.

title: The Rules Are Different, but a Rivalry Remains
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18  When the Indianapolis Colts stepped into a bitterly cold New England night three years ago, after their last appearance in an American Football Conference championship game, Tony Dungy had words of consolation.

title: Time Inc. Cutting Almost 300 Magazine Jobs to Focus More on Web Sites
description: In a broad retrenchment, Time Inc. announced yesterday that it would cut nearly 300 employees at its top magazines, including the most profitable publication, People, as it moves to invest more in its Web sites.

title: Text of Letter to Secretary of Homeland Security
description: Following is the text of the letter that Govs. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Jon S. Corzine sent today to the secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff:

title: U.S. May Cut Troops in Iraq by Summer, General Says
description: TALLIL AIR BASE, Iraq, Jan. 19  Gen. George Casey, the top American commander in Iraq, said today that the additional troops being sent to Iraq could begin to be withdrawn by late summer if security conditions improve in Baghdad.

title: Homelessness, Abuse, Illnesses and Theft Yield to Perseverance
Deadly Wind and Rain Storm Sweeps Europe
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 18  A howling gale churned through the British Isles and Northern Europe on Thursday, killing at least nine people, uprooting trees, shattering windows, flooding beaches and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights at airports from London to Frankfurt.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Art Buchwald, Whose Humor Poked the Powerful, Dies at 81
description: Art Buchwald, who satirized the follies of the rich, the famous and the powerful for half a century as the most widely read newspaper humorist of his time, died Wednesday night in Washington. He was 81.

title: Stock Market in London Fights Nasdaq With Buyback
description: LONDON, Jan. 18  Clara Furse, chief executive of the London Stock Exchange, wants to keep its unwelcome suitor, Nasdaq, at bay  and now she has put money on it.

title: Continental Reports a 40% Narrower Loss
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it narrowed its fourth-quarter loss by 40 percent as it flew more passengers and increased fares.

title: Strong Merger Market Aids Merrill Lynchs 68% Profit Rise
description: Merrill Lynch, the nations largest brokerage house, capped a record earnings season for the major brokers yesterday by announcing a 68 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit.

title: I.B.M. Sales Beat Forecasts on Software and Services
description: I.B.M. reported quarterly profits and revenue yesterday that slightly surpassed Wall Street estimates, lifted by strong software sales and a solid performance from its big services unit.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) MS. ADVENTURE Rachel Reenstra will be the first to admit that shes no expert when it comes to animal behavior, although she does have a masters degree in spiritual psychology and some experience in the proverbial jungle. In the premiere of her series, Ms. Reenstra tries to glean insight into the world of human relationships by delving into animal relationships, starting with some basic instincts  or are they?  involved in parenting.

title: Decorative Tradition, Laced With Bursts of Eccentricity
description: Art fairs can put some fairly magnificent obsessions on display, where they function like traps. Step into a booth, and an unfamiliar area of visual culture suddenly exerts an irresistible force, changing your life.

title: Iraq Signals Changes in Protocols With Iran
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 18  Iraq is carrying out an extensive review of its diplomatic protocols with Iran and may place new restrictions on them, the Iraqi foreign minister said in an interview on Thursday, after Iranian military officials and diplomats were picked up in three separate American actions here.

title: A Light Bulb Goes on, and China Starts Thinking Alternative Energy
description: ON the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been alternative energy and China. Are the two worlds about to collide?

title: Newark: Rape Charge for City Official
description: A city housing official was charged with two counts of rape and one count of official misconduct yesterday after the authorities said he forced his way into the apartment of a woman and assaulted her. The official, Albert Foster, 44, of Somerset, who works as a Section 8 housing inspector, surrendered to the police yesterday, said Paula T. Dow, the Essex County prosecutor. Investigators said Mr. Foster was inspecting a Chadwick Avenue apartment building on Dec. 14 when he attacked a 31-year-old woman who lives there. After the assault, the victim contacted police, Ms. Dow said. Mr. Foster was being held at the Essex County jail yesterday afternoon. Information on bail was not immediately available.

title: Global Battle Against Measles Is Said to Save 2.3 Million Lives
description: Vaccinators scaled Himalayan peaks in Nepal, waded through Cambodian paddy fields, canoed up the Congo River and rode camels across Somalias hinterlands in an effort to immunize children against measles. New data released yesterday documents the scale of their success: the global campaign against measles has saved 2.3 million lives since 1999, mostly in Africa.

title: Shares Fall on Technology Sales Forecasts
description: Stocks fell for the second consecutive day, buffeted by declining oil prices that sent energy shares down and by sales forecasts from technology companies that fell below analysts estimates.

title: Prosecution Rests in Seeking Death for Killer of Detectives
description: Retired detectives with red eyes and untucked shirts faced the mens room wall and wiped their faces with brown paper towels. Back in the courtroom, the convicted man covered his eyes. In the front row, his mother, sister and cousins fell together and sobbed.

title: Overhaul of Schools Would Let Teachers Rate Principals
description: Pressing the case for Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs latest round of changes to the city school system, Chancellor Joel I. Klein detailed yesterday how the new powers being granted to principals would be accompanied by new evaluations of them: teachers for the first time would rate their supervisors.

title: Celebrating the Hard Stuff
description: IN 1955, a handful of mineral enthusiasts (O.K., call them rock geeks) from the Tucson Gem and Mineral Society got together to show off specimens from their personal collections at a local elementary school. From this small beginning, the annual Tucson Gem and Mineral Show has grown into the largest event of its kind in the country, a mega-celebration for rock lovers and a curiously mesmerizing attraction for spectators who dont know staurolite from Styrofoam. As many as 25,000 people are expected at this years show Feb. 8 to 11 in the Tucson Convention Center.

title: In Baghdad, Pressing to Meet, With Iraqi Help, Pentagons Own Standard for Force Levels
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  When Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus assumes his duties as the new American commander in Iraq, he will be guided by a new military doctrine on counterinsurgency that makes the security of the population a chief objective.

title: Never Mind the Age, Listen to the Numbers
description: If you look as fresh and unbowed as Rita Moreno at 75, you may as well flaunt your age. For her birthday, she announced at Tuesdays opening-night show of Little Tributes, her breezy new cabaret act at the Cafe Carlyle, her husband presented her with a bound copy of The New York Times from the day she was born, Dec. 11, 1931. On the front page was a story about Alphonse XIII, the recently deposed ruler of Spain. In show business Bing Crosby was the new kid on the block; the paper cost 2 cents then.

title: Ney Is Sentenced to 30 Months in Prison
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Former Congressman Bob Ney was sentenced to 30 months in prison today for accepting tens of thousands of dollars in illegal gifts in return for using his legislative influence to help his benefactors.

title: Top Blair Aide Arrested in Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: LONDON, Jan. 19  The police arrested and questioned a senior aide to Prime Minister Tony Blair today in what seemed a widening inquiry into allegations that political leaders traded high honors for campaign contributions made as loans.

title: All Together: Lets Go, Jack! Lets Go, Jill! (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Patron Saint of Sensible Sneakers
description: Went to the mall this week and purchased my first pair of Starburys, white low tops with many air holes in the front, paper balled up inside, the nickname of a wealthy N.B.A. player printed in the arch, and all for the unbelievably discounted price of $9.98.

title: North Korea and U.S. Differ on Nuclear Arms Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 19  The North Korean Foreign Ministry said today that it had reached a certain agreement with Christopher Hill, the lead American negotiator, during talks in Berlin this week over its nuclear arms program.

title: Manhattan: City Unemployment Drops
description: New York Citys unemployment rate dropped to 4.3 percent in December, the second-lowest level in the 30 years that extensive records have been kept for the city. The jobless rate, which is adjusted by the State Labor Department to account for seasonal fluctuations, was 4.5 percent in November after hitting a low of 4.1 percent in October. The number of private-sector jobs in the city increased by 45,500, or 1.5 percent, in 2006, the Labor Department reported. New York States seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 4 percent in December, down from 4.2 percent in November. Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the data suggest that the economy may have decelerated a bit at the end of last year.

title: France: Royal Ruffled by Aide and Partner
description: Sgolne Royal, the Socialist presidential candidate, suspended one of her two spokesmen for a month after he said she has only one flaw: her longtime partner and the father of their four children, Franois Hollande, who is the leader of the Socialist Party. The aide, Arnaud Montebourg, made the comment on a television program on Wednesday evening. When the audience reacted with silence, he quickly added, It was a joke. Last week, Mr. Hollande suggested that taxes be raised for the middle class, an idea Ms. Royal promptly brushed aside. The new strains on her campaign came as her rival on the right, Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy, outpaced her in two recent opinion polls.

title: Officials Say Theyll Break Up Latino Gang in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18  The authorities said Thursday that they would dismantle a Latino gang that has been accused of racially motivated violence, including the shooting death last month of a 14-year-old black girl.

title: Ambush Kills an American Teaching Democracy to Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 18  An American woman killed here on Wednesday when gunmen fired on her convoy of vehicles was ambushed just minutes after leaving the headquarters of a prominent Sunni Arab political party, where she had been teaching a class on democracy, party members said Thursday.

title: Small but Sufficient
description: WHO Wyndi Gundrum-Cooper, 47, a real estate agent from Ocean Isle Beach, N.C.

title: When the Visitors Are From Home
description: Most concerts presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center rely on players from the organizations standing roster. The societys International String Quartet Series, on the other hand, usually offers a steady supply of visiting groups. But at a recital by the Daedalus Quartet on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, the society had it both ways: Daedalus, founded in 2000, is part of the organizations CMS II program for young musicians. But it also enjoys a busy career independent from its work at Lincoln Center.

title: Miners Shacks, Mansions and the Real-Life West
description: FOR most Americans, Montana signifies the mythical West, a place to dream of buying a working ranch or a mountain hideaway. And Red Lodge is one of those places where Montana real estate fantasies can come true, and fairly cheaply.

title: Queens: Guilty of Crack House Murder
description: A South Ozone Park man was convicted yesterday of robbing a man inside a crack house in Jamaica and shooting the mans stepson to death during a subsequent confrontation, prosecutors said. The man, Timmy Lee Walker, 33, was convicted of murder, kidnapping and robbery in State Supreme Court, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Walker robbed James Hubbard, 48, at gunpoint on Sept. 5, 2004, while the men were in the crack house on 140th Street. About an hour later, Mr. Hubbard; his stepson, Tony Brunson, 22; and another man rushed into the house, and Mr. Walker shot Mr. Brunson to death, Mr. Brown said. The other two men subdued him until the police arrived, he said. Mr. Walker faces up to 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced on Feb. 8.

title: You Watch This Art. You Should Also Watch Out.
description: When books or paintings become too dizzying, you can walk away until youre ready for more. But performance art keeps coming at you, ready or not. Though audience members can practice some form of pacing, much of the works effect depends on the artists skill in knowing how much is too much, or when too much is just enough.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary last Friday about Maureen Orcutt, an outstanding golfer starting in the 1920s and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, attributed a distinction to her erroneously. She is not a member of the World Golf Hall of Fame.

title: A Mouthful and an Earful (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine City Bans Smoking in Cars With Children
description: BANGOR, Me.  Tonya Henderson will have to be more careful where she lights up her Marlboros.

title: Jury Spares Driver in Smuggling Deaths Case
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 18  The truck driver who carried 19 illegal immigrants to their deaths in his suffocating trailer in 2003 was spared execution on Thursday and sentenced instead to life in prison without parole.

title: U.S. Dominance in Space Challenged by Chinas Test
description: BEIJING, Jan. 19  Chinas apparent success in destroying one of its own orbiting satellites with a ballistic missile signals that it intends to contest American military supremacy in space, a realm many here consider increasingly crucial to national security.

title: Read This Flyer
description: Here is information about the events mentioned in this article. All take place at Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 840-2824.

title: Senate Passes Vast Ethics Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly passed sweeping changes to ethics and lobbying rules, overcoming bipartisan reluctance to ban many of the favors that lobbyists do for lawmakers and to illuminate the shadowy legislative practice of earmarking money for special projects.

title: Retelling Shakespeare With an Abundance of Tenors
description: If the main characters in Rossinis Otello were not named Otello, Desdemona and Iago, most of the audience would never guess that this opera is based on Shakespeares tragedy. The story is bowdlerized into a generic drama of romantic intrigue, jealousy and revenge.

title: A Personal Toll to Setting Aside the Umbrella
description: Ever since Citigroup said it was considering whether to retire its ubiquitous red umbrella logo, the mostly muted reaction has been surprising. For years, many in New York and beyond complained that the giant umbrellas affixed to many of the companys buildings cast a tacky glow.

title: Editor of Turkeys Armenian Paper Is Killed
description: ISTANBUL, Jan. 19  The editor of Turkeys only Armenian-language newspaper was assassinated today on an Istanbul street.

title: Classroom Distinctions
description: IN the past year or so I have seen Matthew Perry drink 30 cartons of milk, Ted Danson explain the difference between a rook and a pawn, and Hilary Swank remind us that white teachers still cant dance or jive talk. In other words, I have been confronted by distorted images of my own profession  teaching. Teaching the post-desegregation urban poor, to be precise.

title: Florida: Not-guilty Pleas in Boot Camp Death
description: Seven former guards and a nurse charged in the death of a 14-year-old boy at a boot camp in Panama City in January 2006 have pleaded not guilty. The guards and the nurse were charged in November with aggravated manslaughter in the death of the boy, Martin Lee Anderson. A security videotape from the camp showed the guards covering Martins mouth, forcing him to inhale ammonia and striking him repeatedly after he stopped running on his first day at the camp. The nurse is seen on the tape watching the guards. The defendants face up to 30 years in prison if convicted.

title: To Execute, or Not to Execute? That Is the Uneasy Question
description: There is no reason for you to recognize the name Gerhard Arthur Puff, but it looms rather large right now in New York jurisprudence.

title: No Clear-Cut Path for Tribunes Board
description: When members of the Tribune Company board assemble this weekend to review bids for the company, they will have a lot to consider but not much to be happy about.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: To Simplify, Allianz Will Acquire All of French Unit
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 18  Allianz, the largest insurer in Europe, announced Thursday that it would buy out the minority shareholders of its French subsidiary AGF for $12.6 billion, another step in a drive by Allianzs chief executive, Michael Diekmann, to reduce the complexity of his company.

title: A Coalition for Firm Limit on Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Ten major companies with operations across the economy  utilities, manufacturing, petroleum, chemicals and financial services  have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A television review in Weekend last Friday about 24 misstated the method the presidents sister uses to destroy personnel files sought by the F.B.I. She deletes them from a computer; she doesnt shred them.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about the New Orleans Saints financial situation gave the wrong day for the teams playoff game last week against the Philadelphia Eagles. The game was played on Saturday, not Sunday.

title: Russian, American-Style, and a Loner on a Quest
description: Hard to say what ballets fit into what categories on Wednesday night in Tradition and Innovation, the catch-all title of the second of 10 themed programs to be presented by the New York City Ballet during its winter season at the New York State Theater. Tradition was possibly best represented by Mauro Bigonzettis In Vento, a hit from last springs Diamond Project festival, and George Balanchines Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2, with Balanchines Mozartiana holding the fort for innovation.

title: Fed Chief Warns That Entitlement Growth Could Harm Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Warning against complacency over the federal deficit, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that recent positive trends on the budget were a calm before the storm, masking a long-term danger posed by looming deficits in Social Security and Medicare.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart on Tuesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the slowdown in the condominium market mislabeled the top line of the scale showing the number of condos for sale. It is 25,000, not 30,000. A corrected graphic can be found online.

title: Springfield, U.S.A., My Second Home
description: AS an actor, I never set out to work in the same place for decades. I certainly never intended to log hours in a fictional hospital among chiseled doctors and sultry patients. But playing a trusty orderly on Guiding Light  the longest-running soap opera in history  has been a ritual spanning my entire adult life.

title: Decorative Arts Galleries Offer Worthy Complements to the Armory Show
description: DECORATIVE ARTS GALLERIES

title: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
description: As the court-appointed guardian and self-described fixer of some of Americas most wayward companies, Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator, is considered a pillar of corporate ethics and governance.

title: Ron Carey, Comic Actor, Dies at 71
description: Ron Carey, the pint-sized, round-faced comic best known as the unjustifiably cocky Police Officer Carl Levitt on the long-running television situation comedy Barney Miller, died Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: Germany: Bavarian Leader Leaves the Stage
description: Edmund Stoiber, a leading conservative powerbroker and an ally and irritant to Chancellor Angela Merkel, said he would step down in September as Bavarias prime minister and leader of the Christian Social Union, a sister party of Mrs. Merkels Christian Democrats. Mr. Stoiber, the governor of Bavaria, Germanys largest state and its economic powerhouse, for almost 14 years, had been under attack from within his party as opinion polls showed his and the partys ratings sinking. Last month, he was forced to accept the resignation of his chief of staff after a party member critical of Mr. Stoiber accused the aide of snooping on her private life. The polls also shook Mrs. Merkels party, which relies on the muscle of the Bavarian conservatives in federal elections.

title: Pentagon Revises Its Rules on Prosecution of Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The Pentagon on Thursday unveiled its new courtroom rules for prosecuting prisoners held as terrorists, allowing military tribunals to consider hearsay evidence and testimony obtained through coercion, but not torture.

title: Rebuke in Iran to Its President on Nuclear Role
description: Correction Appended

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a 1906 Maxfield Parrish painting of Old King Cole, which was removed from the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan for its first extensive cleaning since the 1950s, misidentified the man who commissioned it and whose face is believed to have been the model for the kings. He is John Jacob Astor IV  not John Jacob Astor, his great-grandfather.

title: Lights-Out Science
description: The Museum of Natural History isnt the only museum to offer sleepover programs. All are popular; campers are advised to book early.

title: Keeping Their Distance, but Still Playing for the Homeland
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 18  It has been a rough week for Serbias image in the tennis world, with scores of young Serbian fans brawling with their Croatian counterparts in the usually more sedate alleyways of the Australian Open on opening day.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 11 by The New York Times Regional Newspapers about James C. Weeks, a former president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Regional Media Group, incorrectly described his postgraduate education. He was a graduate of the Program for Management Development at the Harvard Business School  not a recipient of a masters degree in marketing from the University of Florida, where he earned his undergraduate degree. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his wife. She is Toney Weeks, not Toni.

title: What's in a Name? $400 Million
description: When the Nets were a goofball franchise, it was impossible to imagine their owners consorting with a global financial power like Barclays. But the Nets arent laughable anymore, and yesterday, their principal owner, Bruce C. Ratner; some of his investors, like the rapper Jay-Z; and a few of their players were at the Brooklyn Museum to announce that Barclays will pay a record $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the teams new arena. Barclays is saying Brooklyn is the place to be, Ratner said at a luncheon in the elegant Beaux-Arts Court, accompanied on a platform by Jason Kidd, Vince Carter, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern. (Ratners company is the development partner on the new headquarters for The New York Times.)

title: A Place Where Hope Dies, and a Boy Who Escapes
description: A dark fairy tale from Russia, The Italian  more on that title in a moment  pulls you into a richly atmospheric, persuasively inhabited world teeming with foundlings and pathos. Directed by Andrei Kravchuk, making his feature debut, from a screenplay by Andrei Romanov, the film pivots on a 6-year-old stray, Vanya (the wonderful Kolya Spiridonov), who lives in an institution easily meriting that well-worn adjective Dickensian. Overcrowded and brutally underfinanced, it is the kind of place in which hope dies slowly but surely, vanishing a little more with each new birthday. It is a holding pen for young bodies with very old souls.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Campaign Finance Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The Supreme Court stepped back into the debate over campaign finance regulation today, announcing an expedited review of a ruling last month that substantially narrowed the application of a major provision of the McCain-Feingold federal campaign law.

title: Archdiocese Set to Announce Church Closings
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is set to announce today its final list of parishes that will close as part of a far-reaching reorganization plan, bringing to an end a decision-making process that has dragged on for more than five years and trapped many parishioners in uncertainty.

title: Con Ed May Face Millions in Penalties After Panels Finding That It Bungled Blackout
description: Consolidated Edison now faces the prospect of $9.3 million in penalties and tens of millions of dollars in additional sanctions as the result of a scathing state report into its handling of the nine-day blackout in Queens that left 174,000 people without power last summer.

title: Ordeal by Appliance: Weekend Home Tales
description: FOR some people, the most elusive aspect of owning a vacation home that sits beyond big-city borders isnt finding the time to enjoy it. Its finding someone to service the deluxe appliances inside.

title: Study on Nicotine Levels Stirs Calls for New Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  A Harvard study concluding that cigarette makers have for years deliberately increased nicotine levels in cigarettes to make them more addictive led to renewed calls Thursday for greater federal oversight of the industry.

title: Small Area Has Big-Time Talent
description: If a high school basketball team wanted to put an easy game on its schedule, it would be well-advised to stay out of northern New Jersey.

title: Williams Shakes Off Rust, Powers Herself to the Fourth Round
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 19  It was an unexpected joy ride on the relearning curve for Serena Williams in the third round of the Australian Open.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 4 about heart-valve problems linked to two drugs for Parkinsons disease misstated the year that one of them, Permax, added a black-box warning label, the strongest warning required by the Food and Drug Administration. It was 2006, not 2003.

title: Consumer Reports Retracts Article on Car Seats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Consumer Reports magazine today retracted an article on infant car seats, published two weeks ago, that said most of them had failed side-impact crash tests.

title: A Report Brings Back Memories of Living in the Dark
description: Just days before Dan Glassers future in-laws flew in from San Diego last summer, he and his fiance made the rounds of butcher and seafood shops in their Queens neighborhood, gathering fresh fish, shrimp and prime cuts of steak.
