description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: Reins Tighten on BBC Financing
description: The BBC said it might have to cut back on the creation of television shows and other programming after the government awarded it less public financing over the next six years than it had requested. The BBCs license fee, which every British household with a television is required to pay, will rise to 148 ($290) in 2012, from 131.50 last year. The fee will generate more than 20 billion ($39.4 billion) for the BBC over the six years, about 2 billion less than the BBC had requested, the broadcaster said. We now face not just a tight settlement but daunting investment challenges in distribution, infrastructure and technology that risk diverting money away from content creation, said Mark Thompson, above, the director general of the BBC.

title: Apology Not Accepted
description: Correction Appended

title: Jury Selection in Libby Trial Moves Slowly Because of Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The task of seating a jury for the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. did not get easier Thursday when a majority of the candidates interviewed were disqualified, mainly because they expressed deep distrust of the Bush administration and the Iraq war.

title: Manhattan: Heroin Ring Arrests
description: Three people have been extradited and charged with participating in an international heroin-smuggling operation, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The three, Yaya Yahayai, 50; Henry Sichone, 42; and Andrew Sarpong, 33, are charged with involvement in a smuggling operation that bought heroin in Thailand and moved it through various routes to cities in the United States, including New York, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said the ring recruited couriers who smuggled heroin by swallowing it or using false compartments in suitcases.

title: Sundance Dream Most Notable for an Absence
description: PARK CITY, Utah

title: The Good, the Bad and the Bush Baby: New Low on Idol?
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18  The season-opening episodes of American Idol are notorious for their auditions by untalented performers and the catty comments of the judges, particularly Simon Cowell, whose one-liners have been known to deflate the most confident of hopefuls.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Iraqi Draft Law on Oil Revenue Appears Close
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 19  After months of tense bargaining, a cabinet-level committee has produced a draft law governing Iraqs vast oil fields that would distribute all revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers in exploration, development and awarding of major international contracts.

title: Wall Street Is Betting on the Farm
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18  Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures.

title: Correction: In Texas, Monarchs Flutter and Admirals Alight
description: An article last Friday about observing butterflies in the Lower Rio Grande Valley misstated the trees that are hung with Spanish moss there. Many indigenous trees, including species of elm and ash, have Spanish moss there, but oaks are not among them.

title: Law Firms Are Urged Not to Force Retirements
description: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association is calling on law firms to end the practice of mandatory retirement for partners.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the crime and discontent that has accompanied prosperity for some in the Chinese city of Guangzhou referred incorrectly to the citys economic development. It has reached $7,800 per capita gross domestic product  not per capita income.

title: Consumer Reports Retracts Article on Car Seats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Consumer Reports magazine on Thursday retracted an article on infant car seats, published two weeks ago, that said most of them had failed side-impact crash tests.

title: Unfettered Debate Takes Unflattering Turn in Michigan Supreme Court
description: In a recent series of written dissents, Justice Elizabeth A. Weaver of the Michigan Supreme Court has accused four of her colleagues of bully tactics, abuses of power and grossly unprofessional conduct and trying to censor her.

title: China: Intel Considers Building Chip Plant
description: Intel is considering building its first semiconductor factory in Asia in the northeastern Chinese city of Dalian. Chinas central government has approved the project, said Gao Fujun, assistant counsel at the Dalian Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Bureau. An Intel spokesman, Mark Miller, said the company was in talks with several governments about its next chip factory. The company won approval to build a factory in the Dalian Economic and Technological Development Zone, Mr. Gao said. Intel has assembly and testing plants in Shanghai and Chengdu.

title: Williams, in Comeback, Ousts Petrova
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 19  It was quite a journey to victory for Serena Williams in the third round of the Australian Open.

title: G.E. Agrees to Buy an Abbott Laboratories Unit
description: The General Electric Company reached an agreement yesterday to buy part of the diagnostic-equipment unit of Abbott Laboratories for $8.13 billion to expand its line of testing devices.

title: Feminisms Fictional Powerhouse
description: Jane Eyre may not be the first feminist novel, but it is certainly one of the most enduring. There have been at least 20 movie and television versions of Charlotte Bronts gothic love story, even more than of Emma or Pride and Prejudice.

title: White Plains: Man Charged With Rape
description: A Manhattan man has been named in a 23-count indictment accusing him of kidnapping and raping a 12-year-old girl in Westchester County on Dec. 28, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, William Davis, 46, of 126th Street, is charged with rape, kidnapping and predatory sexual assault, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester district attorney. Mr. Davis is scheduled to be arraigned today. Ms. DiFiore said Mr. Davis is accused of luring a Brooklyn girl into his car by identifying himself as a police officer, taking her to Westchester and raping her.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Movie details with a film review of Arthur and the Invisibles in Weekend last Friday included an erroneous running time provided by the distributor and referred incorrectly to the movies rating. The film is 94 minutes, not 102, and it is rated PG; it is not unrated.

title: Grace Notes: To Be Young and in Paris in 1968
description: Regular Lovers was shown as part of the New York Film Festival in 2005. Following are excerpts from the review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 24, 2005; the full text is here. The unrated film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Senators Demand Details on New Eavesdropping Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Lawmakers demanded more information on new rules for governing a domestic surveillance program on Thursday, a day after the Bush administration announced that it had placed the National Security Agency eavesdropping under court supervision.

title: O Brave New World That Has Such Gamers in It
description: This week its likely that thousands of people cut school, called in sick and otherwise turned away from the real world so they could be among the first adventurers to traverse the Dark Portal and battle the demons of the Burning Legion in the broken world of Outland.

title: The Setai, New York, and the Trump Ocean Resort, Baja, Mexico
description: WHAT Metropolitan residential building.

title: Tell the Troops
description: It is bad enough for troops in Iraq to learn that their tours of duty have been extended. It is terrible for them to have to hear about it from loved ones at home rather than from their military commanders.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Personal Shopper column yesterday in House & Home, about the Americana at the Piers antiques show (55th Street and 12th Avenue), gave incorrect dates for the show. It will be open tomorrow and Sunday; it does not open today.

title: The Iraq War and the Trillion (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuisine Is Strictly Cajun, but Loyalty Is to Da Bears
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18  Like Mike Ditka, who coached the Chicago Bears to the Super Bowl and the New Orleans Saints to more misery, Jimmy Bannos has close ties to both cities that will be represented in Sundays National Football Conference championship game.

title: A Rapper, Backed Up by Brass
description: What do you get for the guy who has everything? You give him a sparkly evening to redefine American popular song, of course. But unless the guy is a brilliant performer and a born bandleader, you might want to add some accessories to that gift: a bunch of rehearsals, a merciless musical director.

title: Amid Chaos, Young Somalis Struggle to Get By
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 18  A week ago, Yoonis Issay Alin was riding around in the back of a pickup, part of a squad of tough-looking guys with big trucks and big guns.

title: Parents of 9/11 Victims Torn From Grandchildren
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.  Five years after their father was killed at the World Trade Center, two little girls, ages 7 and 5, sat crying in a car parked at the curb of their grandparents home here one December day, refusing to go inside for a court-ordered visit. It was a painful family tableau rooted in a hundred tangled details, but one overriding and uncontested reality: 9/11.

title: A U.S. Civilian in Baghdad: Standing Out, Even in Death
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 18  Andrea Parhamovich always stood out.

title: House Votes to Rescind Oil Drillers Tax Breaks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  House Democrats easily passed legislation on Thursday that would rescind $14 billion in tax breaks and subsidies for oil drillers and reserve the money to develop alternative energy projects and conservation technologies.

title: Bulldozers Hit the Beach in Los Cabos
description: IS Los Cabos the next Cancn?

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Big Brother Tumult Continues

title: Albany: Student Lender Investigated
description: The New York attorney generals office is looking into certain methods of student loan marketing by Sallie Mae, the nations largest lender to students, the lender said yesterday. The company disclosed in a regulatory filing that Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo had requested information and documents relating to preferred lender lists used by colleges and universities. A spokesman for Sallie Mae, Tom Joyce, said the company was cooperating with the request. We are confident that once the attorney generals staff has reviewed our marketing practices, he said, they will agree that they are in the best interest of students and schools. Some loan companies have criticized preferred-lender lists, contending that college officials steer students to particular lenders in exchange for payments or other benefits. The federal Education Department is also considering regulating the lists.

title: Parents Believe Abducted Son Was Abused
description: Appearing yesterday on The Oprah Winfrey Show, Craig and Pam Akers said they believed that their son, Shawn Hornbeck, had been sexually abused during the four years he was allegedly held captive in a suburban St. Louis apartment by Michael Devlin.

title: A Producer for All Seasons (Also Juggles)
description: A HUNGRY producer shivering in the snow outside a theater, handing out flyers to his latest event, is a far less glamorous image than that of a flamboyant impresario, flanked by chorus girls, holding court in a cloud of cigar smoke. But on many nights, rain or shine, outside a Broadway theater is where youll find Scott Siegel, a producer, writer, critic and aspiring show business entrepreneur, leafleting one of four events he puts on each year at Town Hall.

title: Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Gates Says U.S. Has Few Options to Halt Irans Atomic Plans
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, Jan. 18  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday played down the possibility of American military action against Iran but said it was not the right time for diplomatic engagement, either.

title: Organ Fanfare for Buxtehude. Who?
description: MEMO to Moravian College students: Come back.

title: Nowhere to Turn for Shelter
description: In the long and sordid story of Hurricane Katrina, a new low may be approaching. In Louisiana alone, tens of thousands of displaced families who rely on the government to provide trailers or rent will lose their temporary housing next month  unless the Bush administration extends the standard 18-month time limit for their federal aid.

title: As College Grows, a City Is Asking, Who Will Pay?
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.  For most of the last 40 years, this eclectic seaside city and its University of California campus have lived in relative harmony. With its beaches, bistros and relaxed intellectual vibe, Santa Cruz has long held an allure for those seeking a mellower college experience, a place where hiking trails, yoga mats and surfboards are as common as backpacks filled with books.

title: Government Forces in Sri Lanka Take Key Town
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 19  Thousands of civilians waving white flags fled from heavy fighting in eastern Sri Lanka today as government forces captured a strategic coastal town from rebel forces after an extended siege.

title: Lawmakers Wary of Talks With Iran and Syria
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The head of the bipartisan advisory group that urged a change in the American approach to Iraq insisted today, in the face of skepticism from Congressional leaders, that the United States should engage Iran and Syria diplomatically as it moves to reduce its role in Iraq.

title: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 18  Its goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at the Ford Motor Company.

title: Venezuela Wants Trade Group to Embrace Anti-Imperialism
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18  South American leaders began gathering here on Thursday for discussions focused on a single, contentious issue: should the Mercosur trade group continue to emphasize economic integration, as Brazil and Argentina prefer, or transform itself into a political alliance with an anti-imperialist tint, the path President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela favors?

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Uneasy at First, Mets Embrace Their New Orleans Connection
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18  A woman wearing a pink cowboy hat covered in rhinestones walked down Bourbon Street on Wednesday night and spotted a character with equally outrageous headgear.

title: Nepal: Rebels Disband Their Government
description: Prachanda, the leader of the Maoists, said that the rebels would scrap the parallel state of courts and government units they ran in rural areas under their control, another significant step in ending the countrys protracted civil war. Earlier this week, former rebels took their seats in a new interim Parliament.

title: Shanghai Bribery Inquiry Ensnares Big Firms
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 19  The Shanghai police have detained 22 people in a bribery investigation that has ensnared some of the worlds biggest companies, including McDonalds, Whirlpool, McKinsey and ABB, according to reports in the state-run news media.

title: Burmese Daily at Odds With Democracy Advocate
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 18  A state-run newspaper in Myanmar on Thursday accused the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of tax evasion for spending the money she won for the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize and other foreign awards outside the country.

title: Night of the Iguanas (and Dinosaurs and Whales) in the Museum Wilds
description: These days A Night at the Museum is one of the hottest tickets in New York. But dont be misled. This is not the hit movie in which Ben Stiller plays a security guard at a fictionalized American Museum of Natural History, only to discover that the fossils and specimens come to life at dusk, racing and rampaging through the galleries. This is a real overnight at the actual museum, and the racers and rampagers are not Tyrannosaurus rex skeletons and bloodthirsty barbarians, but kids.

title: Archdiocese  to Shut 21 N.Y. Parishes
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced today that it is closing 21 parishes as part of a far-reaching reorganization plan, bringing to an end a decision-making process that has dragged on for more than five years and trapped many parishioners in uncertainty.

title: A Talking Head Meets His Comic Doppelgnger, and Sparks Fail to Fly
description: The exchange was billed as the ultimate cable news vs. fake news smackdown: Stephen Colbert, who pretends to be a Bill OReilly-esque television pundit on his comedy show, The Colbert Report, was a guest on Mr. OReillys show on Fox News last night, and Mr. OReilly appeared on Mr. Colberts mock talk show on Comedy Central.

title: Free-Spirited Innocence, With a Hint of Menace
description: Mark Morris began the sold-out nine-performance run of the Mark Morris Dance Group Wednesday night by accepting a WQXR American Gramophone Award (WQXR is owned by The New York Times Company), which pays tribute to individual excellence in music. Music is a song and a dance, Mr. Morris said, quoting the late composer Lou Harrison. Enjoy the show.

title: Perspectives on Womanhood, in a Dialectic of Desire
description: Good Girl/Bad Girl, Maude Maggarts must-see new cabaret show, begins with a smirking musical question, written in the 1920s: How could Red Riding Hood/Have been so very good/And still kept the wolf from the door? The song goes on to comment with a raised eyebrow: Father and mother she had none/So where in the world did the money come from?

title: Treasure Hunt for Grown-Ups With Money
description: Mature is the word in the trade for fairs like the Winter Antiques Show, though time-honored, even venerable, would be closer to the mark. The show, which opens today, has been around forever (well, since 1955). It delivers substantial, sometimes spectacular retail; always has. Dealers and clients alike return, like swallows to Capistrano, year after year. So if solid tradition, rather than Art Basel Miami Beach-style blowouts, is what you want in a fair, this ones for you.

title: St. Benedicts Basketball Plays Two
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18  There were two home teams in the St. Benedicts Preparatory School gymnasium Thursday night. One was wearing its white home jerseys, trimmed in maroon and gray, and playing the Kima School from Washington. The other St. Benedicts team was wearing street clothes and cheering from the stands.

title: The French Know Where 007 Acquired His Savoir-Faire
description: PARIS, Jan. 18  James Bond has never seemed fascinated by the French, but the French certainly are fascinated by James Bond.

title: With Onion and Pickle, Please
description: The Onion, the humor Web site, has weighed in on Manning-versus-Brady, and seems to have the A.F.C. championship game figured out.

title: The Forecast
description: Weve concentrated on Patriots-Colts. Its a more compelling matchup, and the survivor will be expected to win the Super Bowl.

title: Greek Revival by the Gasworks
description: A burgeoning neighborhood in Athens attracts a cultured crowd.

title: A Time Traveler in Shanghai
description: Exploring the line between old China and new China in this global city's shops, restaurants and museums.

title: Traders Take a Bow
description: On Wednesday night, the biggest star of the first annual Trader Monthly Awards Reception was not any of the winners. It was a $369,000 car.

title: Wall Street Is Betting on the Farm
description: Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures. The flood of investment has raised concerns among grain traders and agricultural producers that speculative money is gaining an undue influence over their markets, which help set the prices of raw commodities for a host of consumer food products, according to The New York Times.

title: As Tribune Board Reviews Offers, Analysts Scratch Their Heads
description: When members of Tribune board assemble this weekend to review bids for the company, they will have a lot to consider but not much to be happy about. The company received at least two firm bids by Wednesdays deadline, one from the Los Angeles team of Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle, and another from the Chandler family, the companys largest shareholder. A third potential bidder, the Carlyle Group, has expressed interest but only in Tribunes television group. The company also owns 11 papers, including The Los Angeles Times.

title: Law Firms Are Urged Not to Force Retirements
description: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association is calling on law firms to end the practice of mandatory retirement for partners. In a strongly worded report that is to be released Friday, the committee concluded that mandatory retirement  requiring a partner to leave the firm upon reaching an arbitrary age  is not an acceptable practice.

title: Bank of New Yorks Profit Beats Expectations
description: The Bank of New York Company, one of the nations largest trust banks, reported an increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday on strength in its corporate trust business, depositary receipts and global custody services. The New York-based bank said net income totaled $1.79 billion, or $2.36 a share, in the October-December period, up from $405 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Bidding for ElkCorp Heats Up
description: The bidding for the roofing products maker ElkCorp heated up Thursday, with the Building Materials Corporation of America raising its bid to $865.2 million, topping a $834 million offer by a private equity firm, the Carlyle Group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Building Materials said it had raised its offer for ElkCorp to $42 a share in cash, from an earlier $40. Earlier in the day, Carlyle said it had started a tender offer on its previously disclosed bid of $40.50 a share.

title: How China Is Going Green
description: On the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been alternative energy and China. Are the two worlds about to collide? Seed investors are financing, or considering financing, start-ups in China that are developing equipment for wind and solar power, clean water and food alternatives and technology to promote energy efficiency. While this may seem to be an arbitrary combination of two of the hottest trends in venture capital  sort of like the first person who mixed peanut butter and chocolate  there is a growing number of investors who believe that the potential reward in China is worth the tremendous risk.

title: Shell Mulls Boosting Offer for Canadian Unit, Report Says
description: Royal Dutch Shell is dangling the prospect of a 15 percent-plus bump in its offer to buy oil patch subsidiary Shell Canada for C$7.7 billion ($6.6 billion), if minority shareholders agree to support its takeover bid, The Globe and Mail reported. Apparently frustrated in its attempts to drum up interest in a 40-Canadian-dollars -a-share offer made in October, and fearing a nasty takeover battle, Royal Dutch has been quietly meeting with the biggest shareholders in its Calgary-based offspring in recent weeks, the report said. Money managers in Toronto and Calgary told the newspaper that the parent company is holding out the promise of $46 to $48 a share if institutions agree to commit their shares.

title: Buyout Firm Reaches for Mace
description: Mace Security International, which owns a chain of car washes and makes the namesake pepper spray, has received an unsolicited $45.8 million buyout bid from a California-based private equity firm. The offer of $3 a share by Kelly Capital Management was disclosed in a regulatory filing yesterday and Mace said its board was reviewing the offer. While shares of the company soared on the news, Maces two largest shareholders, Lawndale Capital Management and Ancora Capital, said the offer seemed too low.

title:
We Have a Winner
Your Turn': The Darfur Genocide
description: Last month I launched a contest for readers to submit their own writing about Darfur, using my reporting or other source materials. I called it Your Turn and thought I would be inundated with earnest newspaper columns from college journalists. Instead, most entries were letters, essays or poems.

title: Firms Band Together for Emissions Market
description: Ten major companies, including industrial giants like General Electric, DuPont and Alcoa, have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years. Besides adding pressure on Congress to act, one of the groups major goals is the creation of a market in which allowances to emit carbon dioxide could be traded in a way that achieves the greatest reduction at the lowest cost.

title: As Fund Grows, Providence Cuts Fees
description: Providence Equity Partners is gearing up to play with the big boys. The media buyout specialist is looking to triple its fund size, and, in doing so, has agreed to cut its carried interest, or percentage of the funds profits, to 20 percent from 25 percent, according to press reports. The firm promised at the outset to do so if the new fund exceeded its initial $8 billion soft target, The Deal.com reported. And now it is now raising up to $12 billion, after recently holding a first close at $8 billion. The move puts Providence among $10 billion-plus mega-funds raised by the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: Whats In a Name? $400 Million
description: After the announcements of the twin $400 million naming-rights deals inked by British bank Barclays, for the Nets new arena, and Citigroup, for the Mets new stadium, the Jets and the Giants must be salivating as they look over the next year to sell the naming rights to their $1.2 billion stadium in the Meadowlands. They professional football teams have hired the Wasserman Media Group to handle the transaction, and yesterday, Jeff Knapple, the president of WMG Marketing told The New York Times: Weve watched with a keen eye toward what the Mets and the Nets have done. Its an indication of the power of the New York marketplace and its position in the nation and the world.

title: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
description: The leap into hedge funds by Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator, is making waves. As the court-appointed guardian and self-described fixer of some of Americas most wayward companies, Mr. Breeden, who also oversaw Securities and Exchange Commission from 1989 to 1993, is considered a pillar of corporate ethics and governance. Now he trying to become another paragon  that of savvy investor in troubled companies. And in the coming months he will face his first major test: taking on the Applebees International restaurant chain in a proxy fight.

title: Times Looks Set to Keep Boston Paper
description: Dampening the hopes of some investors, analysts, and potential bidders The New York Times Company seems to be in no hurry to sell The Boston Globe. The Times chief executive, Janet L. Robinson, said Thursday that the company remains committed to the New England market and The Globe, despite the financial difficulties roiling the newspaper and traditional media in general.

title: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
description: Its goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the companys private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

title: Silicon Valleys Sarbanes-Oxley Problem
description: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act might be meant to guard against massive white-collar scandals, but the resignation of a high-profile tech veteran suggests the law may also be restricting efficiency atop Silicon Valleys corporate ladder, CNet News.com suggests. Earlier this month, venture capitalist and Netscape founder Jim Clark announced his departure from the board of directors at photo-printing site Shutterfly, where he served as chairman. In his resignation letter, he cited the constraints imposed by Sarbanes-Oxley as one of the primary reasons for departure.

title: Morgan Stanley to Buy CNL Hotels in $6.6 Billion Deal
description: Morgan Stanley, the biggest real estate investor among Wall Street firms, agreed to buy CNL Hotels & Resorts Inc., adding eight luxury hotels and resorts throughout the U.S. in a transaction worth $6.6 billion. The move comes amid a hot market for hotel acquisitions, which booked a 38 percent jump in 2006 to reach $70 billion. Morgan Stanley Real Estate will pay $20.50 for each CNL share and assume CNLs debt. CNL, based in Orlando, Florida, will also sell 51 properties to Ashford Hospitality Trust for about $2.4 billion as part of the takeover.

title: After Dulcet Tones, Australian Clerics Fiery Rhetoric Stirs Controversy
description: The comments of an influential Australian Muslim cleric, revealed in a British TV documentary earlier this week, are fueling outrage, with authorities down under investigating whether the the cleric had broken anti-terrorism laws, according to various reports.

title: Pinault Move Makes Vinci Shares Pop
description: Shares of Vinci, the worlds biggest construction company, rose to a record after activist investor Francois Pinault bought a 1 billion euro ($1.3 billion) stake, prompting speculation he may seek to acquire the company. The stock jumped 6.4 percent to 104.9 euros, the most in seven months, and was trading at 103.3 euros as of 11:36 a.m. in Paris, giving a market value of 24.2 billion euros.

title: Citigroup Profit Falls in 4th Quarter
description: Citigroup said on Friday that fourth-quarter profit fell from a year earlier, when it took a one-time gain, although the company benefited from growth in investment banking. Net income for the New York-based company fell to $5.13 billion from $6.93 billion a year earlier, when Citigroup recorded a $2.1 billion gain from selling its asset management business.

title: Citadel and NBC Get Together on Ion Bid
description: In a bid to salvage its stake in the family friendly TV network formerly known as Paxson Communications, NBC Universal has found a buyer willing to pony up about $70.5 million to help it take the ailing company private. Hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, which, like NBC is a major investor in the company now called Ion Media Networks, is offering to buy out its common shareholders for $1.41 a share in cash.

title: Giuliani Hires a Rove-Linked Consultant
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has hired Olsen & Shuvalov, a prominent Texas consulting firm with ties to Karl Rove, to assist his presidential exploratory committee with fundraising, voter outreach, and development of his political message, according to campaign officials.

title: Can I Get a Receipt for That?
description: How cold are mornings at Sundance? The Bagger was out shooting video in cheap gloves, with foot warmers in his cheap boots, and his extremities soon turned into four different flavors of snow cone. The Bagger quickly found one of those upscale sportswear shops and got a vigorous cashectomy for real cold weather boots and mittens.

title: Just Plain Good?
description: Wouldnt you know that the year the Bagger finally gets to Sundance is the year that the stars who generally dapple the event decide to take a pass? The Hollywood Reporter suggests that while this may be a fine year for film, a lot of the wattage stayed home. The story also notes that the commercial side of the festival may not sparkle either.

title: The Ghost of This Machine
description: indieWire, which is all over Sundance to very excellent effect, talks to Rory Kennedy about Ghosts of Abu Ghraib, a hard look at what America is doing to others in the name of keeping the rest of us safe.

title: Hunting Big Game
description: Geoffrey Gilmore, the co-director of Sundance, explains to Zoom In Online, which is running a lot of video about the festival, how audiences here tend to mistake the tree for the forest, or more specifically, the tusk for the elephant.

title: Selling Iraqs Oil
description: -Mary Duenwald

title: Lotto Films
description: The game at Sundance is to suss out the must-see film and see it before anyone else so you can see them and talk about it. Peter Ranier of the Christian Science Monitor, a film fest vet, said that it can be a bit of a game  sometimes those in the know will terrorize their colleagues by going bonkers about a film that is no longer screening.

title: Radically Good Manners
description: One of the Baggers colleagues sent him a bit from the Q & A following the Chicago Ten screening. The Bagger would thank him by name, but hed probably just get the guy jammed up at work. Heres what the Bagger missed when he ran for one of the buses.

title: Redford Whispers, Times Up
description: The Bagger was thrilled to actually see a film at Sundance, in this case, the premiere of Chicago 10, the mashup of animation and archival material that serves as a modern tutorial on four days in recent American history when a major city turned into a police state, and a fairly brutal one at that.

title: Pinault Rules Out Bid for Suez
description: Francois Pinault on Friday dashed speculation that he would make a run for the utility Suez, but the French billionaire said he would seek alternatives to its proposed merger with Gaz de France. In a statement from his holding company, Artemis, Mr. Pinault said the conditions were not right for a Suez bid. Artemis remains convinced that an alternative solution to the merger can be found in the interests of the market and will continue to examine the possibility of such an operation, Artemis said.

title: Fortress Aims for $634 Million in I.P.O.
description: Taking another step toward making history as the first public hedge fund, New Yorks Fortress Investment Group said that it may raise as much as $634.3 million in its initial public offering. In a regulatory filing, Fortress said that it plans to sell 34.3 million shares for $16.50 to $18.50 a piece, with the funds principals controlling 78 percent of the firm after the sale.

title: China on Space Missile: Nothing To Worry About, If We Did It
description: One thing seems clear from todays coverage of Chinas recent display of missile muscle: it happened. From Bill Broad and David Sanger in todays Times:

title: Against Manning, Patriots Put the Pressure on Their Pass Rush
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 19  Harassing Peyton Manning with a consistent pass rush is a top priority for the New England Patriots.

title: Bears Banking on the Cold Against the Saints
description: Some of the Bears players grumbled this week about the fact that there were 6,000 empty seats at Soldier Field for their second-round playoff game last weekend against the Seattle Seahawks.

title: On the Hill: End of an (Ever So Brief) Era
description: With the passage of the first 100 hours and major ethics legislation, a brief period of bipartisanship may also have passed. Republicans in the House were mad because, they say, the Democrats muzzled them during their initial blitz of legislation, and G.O.P. and Democratic leaders in the Senate played the blame game over what had stalled the ethics bill.

title: Debate on Chinas Place in Space
description: Did China blow up a weather satellite this week in response to Americas greater weapons capability in space? Jeffrey Lewis, blogging at ArmsControlWonk.com, says he doesnt believe so, because the American space weapons programs have been mostly talk, not supported by real budgetary support.

title: The Secret Race for Comptroller
description: When the popularly-elected State Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, resigned late last year  leaving the choice of his successor to the State Legislature  state officials pledged to conduct an open and public process to select his replacement.

title: Fidelity Will Oppose Clear Channel Buyout, Report Says
description: Clear Channel Comunications largest shareholder, Fidelity Investments, plans to oppose the radio networks $19 billion buyut as too low, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing an unnamed source. Fidelity, which held an 11 percent stake as of Sept. 30, is seeking a higher price than the $37.60 that two buyout firms  Thomas H. Lee Partners and bain Capital Partners  offered last November.

title: Ney Sentenced to 30 Months
description: On the heels of the Senate passing wide-ranging lobbying and ethics legislation last night, a federal judge sentenced former Congressman Bob Ney to 30 months in prison in the wake of the Jack Abramoff corruption scandal that heavily influenced the new push for reforms to break the ties between lobbyists and lawmakers.

title: More Car Seat Fallout, Plus: What Was the Alternative, Anyway?
description: Updating now the news from Thursday that Consumer Reports had pulled its widely circulated study from two weeks ago suggesting that many child car seats on the market today may be unsafe at moderate speeds. Seems some of Consumer Reports tests  specifically the side impact tests  may have been grossly overstated, according to the Nation Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Can a Building Change Its Rules About Dogs?
description: Q My building went co-op 20 years ago, and we have always been allowed to have pets. But this month, the new board of directors adopted a change to the house rules that now states owners dogs can weigh no more than 50 pounds.

title: Regilding the Golden Guy
description: Its a very warm and I would say soothing feeling, Juliette Binoche said in her lilting French accent when the Baguette asked her what it felt like to win an Oscar. Ms. Binoche won a best supporting actress award in 1996 for The English Patient, which was nominated for 12 Oscars and won nine, including best director for Anthony Minghella.

title: Losers Go to Harvard?
description: Dad, what happens to politicians when they lose?

title: Equity Office Fight Suits Zell Just Fine
description: The battle for Equity Office Properties Trust may turn ugly  but from Samuel Zells perspective, its beautiful all the same. The founder of the REIT has seen the value of his stake in the company climb to $825 million as a group of three real estate companies offered a $38 billion bid earlier this week, The New York Post reported Friday.

title: Virtually Correct Still Means Correct
description: Not so long ago I wrote a post extolling chenin blanc wines, particularly those from the Loire Valley, which I love. I mentioned in passing that I had been hearing very good things about South African chenin blancs, and I offered a link to the South Africa entry in the Epicurious wine dictionary.

title: Chandler Bid Packs Big Payments for Tribune Executives
description: If Tribune is sold to the Chandler family, some executives could walk away with compensation totaling an estimated $269 million, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the family, which formerly owned the Times, notes a change of control payments. While it does not say how many executives would be eligible, the paper says that Tribunes chief executive, Dennis J. FitzSimons; publishing president, Scott C. Smith; and broadcasting president, John E. Reardon, are among those eligible if they are dismissed within three years of a Chandler takeover.

title: Layoffs Hit the N.Y.S.E. as Specialists Are Squeezed Out
description: Wall Street executives and office types may be enjoying record bonuses right now, but those who work the trading floor have increasingly little to celebrate. The New York Post reported Friday that Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs have laid off even more floor workers at the New York Stock Exchange, as the market increasingly moves to electronic trading via its so-called hybrid-trading system. Lehman laid off six and Goldman nine on Thursday, the paper said, adding that both laid off an unknown number of marketers who sell floor-trading screens and execution services.

title: Blogtalk: When I First Met Rudy
description: The Politicker quotes some first impressions of Rudy Giuliani from people interviewed for a new biography.

title: Reid Stands Between Bush and Iran
description: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, drew a battle line with President Bush on Iran today during a joint appearance with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the Democrats leader in the House. As part of the Democrats runup to Mr. Bushs address to the nation on Tuesday night, Mr. Reid reminded the commander in chief that his power does have limits when it comes to military engagement.

title: Shooting of Outspoken Editor Tests Turkeys Democratic Mettle
description: Hrant Dink, a prominent Turkish-Armenian editor who was convicted of insulting Turkeys identity under a controversial law that has been a stumbling block in its bid for membership in the European Union, was shot dead outside his newspaper office in Istanbul today.

title: A New Consultant for Giuliani
description: Over at our national sibblog, The Caucus, Patrick Healy reports that Rudy Giuliani has hired Olsen & Shuvalov, a prominent Texas consulting firm to assist his presidential exploratory committee. Mr. Giuliani seems to be expanding his inner circle, which is still dominated by people who worked for him at City Hall. Olsen & Shuvalov, a communications and political strategy firm in Austin, Texas, grew out of the old Karl Rove & Company direct-mail marketing firm. When he joined the Bush campaign in 1999, Mr. Rove sold the assets to two of his former employees and no longer has any official ties to it.

title: Hedge Fund Cries Foul in Openwave Proxy Contest
description: Harbinger Capital Partners declared victory in its battle against Openwave Systems on Friday, but said that the wireless software maker was taking action to thwart shareholders. The activist hedge fund, which owns more than 10 percent of the wireless software maker, said that it expects to win a seat on Openwaves board, based on a preliminary count of votes at a shareholder meeting.

title: You type. I type. Why bother with handwriting?
description: On the off chance you havent started preparations, dont forget: Only four days until National Handwriting Day!

title: Another Firm Settles in Market-Timing Inquiry
description: The mutual fund Fred Alger Management has agreed to pay $40 million to settle charges leveled against it by former New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer during his investigation of fraudulent mutual fund market-timing schemes, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday. Alger allowed such trading from 2000 to 2003, according to the S.E.C.

title: The Candidates for Comptroller
description: Lets get ready to comp-trol! The State Senate has released the list of 19 comptroller candidates, though the Assembly claims one candidate had a problem with his application, according to the Senate release. Some extra candidates may have applied only to the Assembly.

title: Valleywags Denton Tells Doerr: Retire Now
description: L. John Doerr, one of the big names at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, is a legendary investor, according to Valleywags Nick Denton. So legendary that Mr. Denton uses the phrase twice within 15 words. But, the Gawker media emperor concludes in an editorial, now is the perfect time for the veteran venture capitalist to retire.

title: War of Words Without End
description: Well, not that anyone is naive about the ever-growing divide between Democrats and President Bush over the war in Iraq and his new plan to send more troops into battle.

title: All Night Long for Mountain Dew
description: The most requested ad of the day, from AdForum.

title: Nipping Global Warming in the Bud
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 19 column, A Warning From the Garden.

title: McCain Powers Up His Media Team
description: Senator John McCain has enlisted the core players of President Bushs advertising team, adding them to what was already a group of bare-knuckled political advertising strategists working for his nascent campaign.

title: Defining a Dream Home
description: This morning I received an e-mail reminding me about the HGTV Dream Home 2007 Giveaway, which got me thinking: What exactly are the ideal characteristics of a dream home?

title: Raikkonens Red Tank
description: Im a bit late on this, but I found it to be one of the most baffling and yet possibly enlightening bits of news of the week  or the year. Reuters yesterday sent out a story quoting the German magazine Sport Bild which said that Mario Illien, of the McLaren-Mercedes Ilmor engine fame, said that Ferrari will have to build a car as strong as a tank to withstand Kimi Raikkonens driving style.

title: Blogtalk
description: Ben Smith has posted a spreadsheet of pork projects organized by zip code. [Room 8]

title: Rest Easy: Overt Religious Symbols Permitted for British Airways Employees
description: The Lede will be closed for business on Monday and Tuesday next week, but we leave you with this little tidbit to tide you over until then:

title: Vows: Brooke and Seth
description: After Brooke Lippmann met Seth Christian, she decided to enlist her friends' help in pursuing him.

title: The Week That Was
description: At weeks end, wed be remiss if we didnt mention some newsworthy items that keep popping up on our screen, but have failed to make the Caucus blog, until now.

title: The Conversation: 2006 Highlights
description: Excerpts from Times reporter Calvin Sims's interviews, including Larry Kramer, Elie Wiesel, Calvin Butts, Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, and Ruth Reichl.

title: Elderly Organ Donors (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Revisit Campaign Finance Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The Supreme Court stepped back into the debate over campaign finance regulation on Friday, announcing an expedited review of a ruling last month that substantially narrowed the application of a major provision of the McCain-Feingold federal campaign law.

title: A Product of the U.N. System
description: Benon Sevan no longer works for the United Nations. But his indictment on federal corruption charges stemming from his long maladministration of the Iraqi oil-for-food program points to a continuing problem in the U.N. appointments system that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon needs to tackle without further delay.

title: Belarus: Leader Warns of Hard Times
description: Confronted with higher natural gas and oil prices after a New Years confrontation with Russia, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said that energy conservation had become a national security priority. Belarus long enjoyed discounted prices for energy from Russia, subsidizing its industries and generating profits from the refining and export of gasoline and other oil products. Russia more than doubled the price of natural gas  $100 per cubic meter, compared with $46  beginning Jan. 1. Belarus imposed a retaliatory fee on the transit of oil, but backed down last week after Russia turned off its main oil pipeline through Belarus, disrupting supplies across Europe. Mr. Lukashenko appeared to be bracing the country for austerity as energy-saving measures are adopted. The next three, four years will not be an easy time, he said, according to Interfax, but we will have to bear it.

title: Sex and the Single-Minded
description: How to get a job in Washington, that balmy, bipartisan town: Direct an organization that opposes contraception on the grounds that it is demeaning to women. Compare premarital sex to heroin addiction. Advertise a link between breast cancer and abortion  a link that was refuted in 1997. Rant against sex ed. And hatch a loony theory about hormones.

title: Vatican and China Open Talks on Improving Ties
description: ROME, Jan. 19  The Vatican began two days of meetings on Friday over the churchs relations with China, which have soured because of a dispute over the right to appoint bishops.

title: Sri Lanka: Thousands Flee Fallen Rebel Town
description: Thousands of civilians waving white flags fled from heavy fighting in the east of the country as government forces captured a strategic town held by the separatist Tamil Tigers after weeks of fierce fighting. The town, Vakarai, on the northeastern coast, is a main link between the northern and eastern areas controlled by the rebels. Since dawn, 6,000 to 8,000 people have been moving on foot, by tractor and by sea, a United Nations spokeswoman, Ola Clinton, said. They were waving white flags and handkerchiefs. She said that as fighting intensified in recent weeks, 25,000 people had already fled Vakarai, and she estimated that another 2,000 to 2,500 civilians remained, with food in short supply.

title: Extra Innings Exclusively on DirecTV
description: Major League Baseball is close to announcing a deal that will place its Extra Innings package of out-of-market games exclusively on DirecTV, which will also become the only carrier of a long-planned 24-hour baseball channel.

title: Advice for Invaders (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Leading Senator Assails Bush Over Iran Stance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The new chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Friday sharply criticized the Bush administrations increasingly combative stance toward Iran, saying that White House efforts to portray it as a growing threat are uncomfortably reminiscent of rhetoric about Iraq before the American invasion of 2003.

title: Post-
description: It may seem odd to celebrate a prefix. After all, it isnt even a whole part of speech. It does for a word, visually, what a big cigar does for a small man. But even as prefixes go, post- is unusually adaptable. It signifies transcendence, surpassing, moving past, leaving behind, and yet it does all these things while remaining attached to the very thing the prefix is leaving in the dust.

title: Western Companies Caught Up in Chinese Bribery Inquiry
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 19  The police have detained 22 people in a bribery investigation that has ensnared several large companies, including ABB, McDonalds, McKinsey & Company and Whirlpool, according to reports on Friday in the state-run news media.

title: Dont Call. Dont Write. Let Me Be.
description: The fears of the direct marketing industry came true. Once a do-not-call list was created, people did register, in droves.

title: Armenian Editor Is Slain in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Jan. 19 A prominent newspaper editor, columnist and voice for Turkeys ethnic Armenians who was prosecuted for challenging the official Turkish version of the 1915 Armenian genocide, was shot dead as he left his office on a busy street in central Istanbul on Friday.

title: China Shows Assertiveness in Weapons Test
description: BEIJING, Jan. 19  Chinas apparent success in destroying one of its own orbiting satellites with a ballistic missile signals that its rising military intends to contest American supremacy in space, a realm many here consider increasingly crucial to national security.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about Muhammad Alis 65th birthday, rendered incorrectly an antiwar quotation from him in the 1960s. He said, I aint got no quarrel with them Vietcong  not I got nothin against them Vietcong.

title: Senior Aide to Blair Is Arrested in Graft Inquiry
description: LONDON, Jan. 19  The police arrested and questioned a senior aide to Prime Minister Tony Blair on Friday in what seemed to be a widening inquiry into allegations that political leaders had traded high honors for campaign contributions made as loans.

title: U.N. to Audit Its Activities After Reports on North Korea Program
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 19  Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, called Friday for outside examination of all United Nations activities after a published report that the United Nations Development Program in North Korea was making unaccountable payments in hard currency to local staff members and the North Korean government.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the chief executive of the Mesa Air Group referred incorrectly to the companys revenue for the years 2002 through 2006. It was in billions, not millions. A corrected graphic can be found online.

title: Easy Does It, the Next Stop Is a Killer. No, It Really Is.
description: The Hitcher isnt shy about declaring its intentions. The opening image is of a jackrabbit crossing a desert highway and being pulped by a car. Soon after, the vacationing young hero, Jim (Zachary Knighton), asks his girlfriend, Grace (Sophia Bush), to hold the wheel of his 1970 Oldsmobile 442 so he can hang out of the drivers side window and clean a splattered bug off the windshield. Message: Roadkill comes in all shapes and sizes.

title: Bush to Visit Democrats Retreat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Who says bipartisanship is dead? President Bush has accepted an invitation from House Democrats to travel to Williamsburg, Va., in February to speak at their annual issues conference, a move that might have been unthinkable a few short months ago, when Republicans ran Capitol Hill.

title: Richard A. Musgrave, 96, Theoretician of Public Finance, Dies
description: Richard A. Musgrave, an economist who has been called the father of modern public finance, died Monday in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 96.

title: The Quicksand of Debt (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Brothers in a Gumbo of Bayou and West Africa
description: Tarell Alvin McCraney, a third-year student at the Yale School of Drama, is one of the few playwrights in the Under the Radar festival who is actually under the radar  but not for long.

title: New Warnings on Climate Change
description: The main international scientific body assessing causes of climate change is closing in on its strongest statement yet linking emissions from burning fossil fuels to rising global temperatures, according to scientists involved in the process.

title: Showbiz Exporter Scores Goal
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 19  Simon Fuller has achieved remarkable success in Britain as an entertainment executive and manager, chiefly in the recording industry. But clearly he has finally found the area of his true business acumen: export.

title: Could the Contract Be Defeated? The Software Oracle Knows
description: When you play in a tournament that gives out deal records, under every board you see the highest contracts that each side can make in the five strains, assuming the play is double-dummy  everyone knows where the cards lie. (This is done using Bill Baileys Deep Finesse software.) Competitors in the Flight A/X Pairs last Saturday at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., were surprised to see that there was a way to defeat three no-trump by South in the diagramed deal. What leads by West work?

title: Senators to Offer Centrist Proposal on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Senator John W. Warner of Virginia is drafting a proposal on Iraq policy with two Senate centrists in an effort to provide an outlet for lawmakers uneasy with President Bushs troop buildup but unwilling to back a toughly worded resolution opposing the new strategy.

title: Senate Measure Puts Spotlight on Fund-Raising
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Of all the new rules passed in Congresss recent ethics overhauls, the most sweeping is a barely debated provision in a Senate bill passed Thursday night that could alter one of the most time-honored campaign fund-raising practices in Washington.

title: Coliseum Will Fall, Taking Grand-Scale Philosophy With It
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19  There are rooftop soirees and a city-sponsored official watching spot. One art gallery has scheduled an open-microphone night to encourage people to share their memories. People from near and far are making plans to witness the implosion, though the whole spectacle is expected to last less than 20 seconds.

title: Comfort Food Is in at London Theater Buffet
description: LONDON, Jan. 19  It is the eve of destruction, although everyone is pretending it is not. Hitler is on the horizon, storm troopers are in the wings, and betrayal has replaced friendship as the common social coin. So whom would you choose as your musical dream date for this Gtterdmmerung moment: the chaste nun-in-training who loves nature and children, or the sexy nightclub singer who loves a cabaret?

title: 3 From the Bush Advertising Team Join McCains 08 Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Senator John McCain of Arizona has enlisted strategists from President Bushs advertising team to work on the senators nascent drive for the Republican presidential nomination, aides with his campaign exploratory committee said Friday.

title: A Punch Line in Detroit, Milicic Finds a Niche in Orlando
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 19  The screaming blond streaks in Darko Milicics thick black hair have long since faded. He is back to his natural color.

title: Testimony to Be Heard on Shooting by the Police
description: A Queens grand jury that will weigh evidence in the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man on his wedding day in November will begin hearing testimony next week, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,014 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: An Unthinkable Crime, Until Someone Finally Thought of It
description: Three crumpled dollars and two quarters, tugged from the pocket of a puffy coat on a cold night, brings four hot chicken wings with French fries or fried rice. The most expensive dish on the restaurants menu is No. 71, the lobster meat chow mein, at $8.95 a quart.

title: Insurgents Attack Palace in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 19  Insurgents blasted Somalias presidential palace with heavy explosives on Friday night, Somali officials said, but it appeared that no one was hurt.

title: Denny Doherty, 66, Mamas and Papas Singer, Dies
description: Denny Doherty, a founding member of the 1960s folk-pop band the Mamas and the Papas, died yesterday at his home in Mississauga, Ontario. He was 66.

title: Totals
Giant Does Not Blame Bonds for Link to Positive Drug Test
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19  This should have been a feel-good event, part of a fanfest weekend being staged by the San Francisco Giants. Maybe some softball questions from reporters and some home run responses from the 14 Giants players who were taking part.

title: Figuring Out the P.E. Ratio of Steve Jobs
description: APPLES share price leaped to a record after the company unveiled its latest device to be hailed as the coolest thing ever, but investors are factoring more into their decision than a best guess on the number of iPhones Apple will sell.

title: A Trip Off the Beaten Path (for Everyone Involved)
description: With Broadway and Theater Row and the Villages beckoning, sometimes New York theatergoers need to remind themselves: its not the location, its the writing and the acting. West 21st Street may not be a theater hot spot, but The Dirty Talk, a delicious two-hander playing at Center Stage there, is as rewarding a trip off the beaten path as youll make.

title: Draft Law Keeps Central Control Over Oil in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 19  After months of tense bargaining, a cabinet-level committee has produced a draft law governing Iraqs vast oil fields that would distribute all revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers in exploration, development and awarding major international contracts.

title: Seeing Results in Darfur (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodeur Goes About His Business: Winning
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 19  His 35th birthday is less than four months away, and the Devils Martin Brodeur is beginning to sound like a goaltender who has been around a while. He says he now appreciates recognition much more.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a front-page article on Jan. 9 about the naming of Fred F. Fielding as the chief White House lawyer misspelled the surname of a woman, whose husband was killed in the Sept. 11 attacks, who spoke to Mr. Fielding at a meeting of the Sept. 11 commission when he was on that panel. She is Beverly Eckert, not Ecket.

title: Unhappy Quarterback Has Razorbacks Reeling
description: Coming off its best season in nearly 20 years, Arkansas is embroiled in a controversy involving the heralded quarterback Mitch Mustain that has bitterly divided Razorbacks fans.

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK Well, thats one way to save your life. The show picks up where it unexpectedly left off: with Michael (Wentworth Miller) and Lincoln (Dominic Purcell) forming a tenuous alliance with Kellerman (Paul Adelstein), who turned his gun on Mahone in revenge for ruining his life. Tonight, the threesome heads to Montana to track down Terrence Steadman, the presidents brother  and the man Lincoln was framed for murdering. Meanwhile, T-Bag insinuates himself into the Hollander household. And Bellick finds out what life is really like on the other side of the bars.

title: Muti Takes the Reins, a Classicist at His Core
description: The conductor Riccardo Muti grabbed international headlines in 2005 when he resigned as music director at La Scala Opera in Milan, expressing displeasure with working conditions and attitudes. But this exacting 65-year-old maestro, one of the towering musicians of our time, has always worked well with the New York Philharmonic. He is back with the orchestra for two programs over the next two weeks, and the first concert on Thursday night was predictably excellent, though in unpredictable ways.

title: The Guilt-Free Corporation
description: THE notion that the corporation should apply its assets for social purposes rather than for the profit of its owners  the shareholders  is an irresponsible use of assets, argues the venture capitalist Betsy S. Atkins.

title: Trade Deficit Stubbornly Defies the Dollars Slide
description: Jessica Heymans breakfast in Paris last month was nothing out of the ordinary: a modest repast of eggs, coffee and a side salad with her husband, Jonathan Podwil, at the popular Caf de Flore. But the bill was memorable  46 euros, or about $60, at the current exchange rate. Five years ago, when the dollar was strong, the same bill would have amounted to $42.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a move by Bangor, Me., to ban smoking in cars where children are passengers misstated the population ranking of the city. Bangor is the third largest city in Maine, not the second. (Portland is the largest, followed by Lewiston.)

title: Lessons for Living Found in Views of the Last Judgment
description: Eschatology is not exactly your everyday word. If you had read every word of this newspaper every day for the last five years, you would have encountered it fewer than 20 times. Half those times were somehow referring to fundamentalist religious beliefs about the final battles between good and evil, the coming of Jesus (or other messianic figures), the Last Judgment and the eternal assignment of the saved and the damned to heaven or to hell.

title: Israel Releases $100 Million Withheld From Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19  Israel transferred $100 million in Palestinian tax revenues to the office of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, as part of a plan to bolster him and keep money out of the hands of the Hamas government, Israeli officials said Friday.

title: Flames Flare Over Naked Shorts
description: UNSUSPECTING readers of certain stock message boards may be forgiven for believing they have stumbled into a flame war among 14-year-old boys. But the increasingly vicious online dispute actually involves, among others, the chief executive of a publicly traded corporation and a longtime business journalist.

title: Pennsylvania Governor Pushes Health Plan
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19  Gov. Edward G. Rendell arrived here Friday to rally support for his plan not only to extend health insurance coverage to the states 760,000 uninsured adults, but also to cut billions of dollars in heath care costs and ban smoking in restaurants, bars and workplaces.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the baseball roundup on Thursday about the status of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative steroids investigation misstated the number of men who have pleaded guilty and been sentenced in the case. It is five, not four. The article also gave an outdated academic position for Peter Keane, who commented on the outlook for the case. He is a law professor at Golden Gate University School of Law in San Francisco; he is no longer the dean of the law school.

title: At Murder Trial, Both Sides Portray Abusive Marriage
description: It was a surprising killing for the neighborhood, hidden behind the doors of a dignified town house in the same orbit as Gracie Mansion and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where affluence is high and the crime rate is low.

title: In the N.F.L., Violence Sells, but at What Cost?
description: By the time I reached him late Thursday afternoon, Gene Upshaw had already read the article in The New York Times about Andre Waters, the Philadelphia Eagles safety who committed suicide in November after years of battling depression. One neuropathologist said the condition might have been related to the concussions that Waters sustained as a professional football player.

title: Pacers ONeal Must Now Adjust to Roster Changes
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18  Jermaine ONeals head is spinning from the wholesale changes the Indiana Pacers made in this weeks trade that sent his friends Al Harrington and Stephen Jackson to the Golden State Warriors.

title: A Colossus Blocks the Colts Path to a Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 19  When snow flurries briefly fell Friday, it created a home-team dream tableau, the white flakes dusting buildings bathed in blue light as if the town had ordered up the weather, along with pep rallies and towering banners, to cheer on the Colts in the American Football Conference championship game.

title: Parents and 3 Children Found Slain in Burned Home
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 19  A family of five  two adults and three children  was found slain in its house in a working-class section of Dutchess County early Friday after firefighters responded to a blaze that gutted the home, the authorities said.

title: State Farm Settles One Hurricane Katrina Suit
description: On the eve of trial, State Farm agreed yesterday to pay an estimated $1 million to settle a lawsuit by a Mississippi Gulf Coast resident whose house was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. The settlement came a week after a jury ordered the insurer to pay $2.5 million in punitive damage to a homeowner with a similar case.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about the successful online ad campaign for LowerMyBills.com, misspelled the given name of a blogger who commented on the ads. He is Rogers Cadenhead, not Roger.

title: A Final Adventure for the Consummate Animal Hunter
description: Probably no creature in the history of the animal kingdom ever needed the image-enhancing public relations services of, say, a Hill & Knowlton, as much as the stingray that attacked and killed Steve Irwin off the Great Barrier Reef in Australia in September. Of all the naturalists to choose to make a victim! Mr. Irwin, of course, had gained celebrity engaging with unwieldy and lethal reptiles as if they were, on a scale of fearsomeness, roughly equivalent to a table of society matrons at tea.

title: Metaphysical Ruminations, Glowing With Winter Light
description: Jazz is the nominal domain of Fred Hersch, the ferociously prolific pianist and composer who sidelines as a first-class accompanist. But in all of his work, jazz invention and lyrical fancy are tethered to an analytical mind that bows to the structure and balance of formal, notated music; chaos is not allowed.

title: Extension Granted to Hurricane Victims
description: The federal government will allow the 110,000 families still living in trailers because of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita to stay through August, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency said. The housing program had been scheduled to expire at the end of February, and some community groups had been expecting FEMA to start issuing eviction notices as early as next week. The six-month extension, announced by Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, also applies to displaced families living in apartments paid for by FEMA.

title: Furor Over 12-Year-Old Actresss Rape Scene
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19  Dakota Fanning will turn 13 next month, and she has a short answer for anyone who questions her decision to play a 1950s girl who gyrates in her underwear, wakes up as her naked father climbs into her bed, demands that a prepubescent boy expose himself to her in exchange for a kiss and, finally, is raped by a teenager who lures her with tickets to an Elvis concert:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about the Brain Games exhibition at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, misstated the days the museum is open. It is open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., not Tuesdays through Fridays.

description: Members of the team that covered the 2007 North American International Auto Show for The New York Times were hardly in agreement on their favorite (and least favorite) cars. Here are their choices:

title: Playing Across the River, Jefferson Appears Right at Home
description: By the time the Nets make their scheduled arrival in Brooklyn for the 2009-10 season, Richard Jefferson could be the teams marquee player. Only 26, he already has a mixture of panache and intellect that is worthy of the sheen the Nets hope to have in their new arena in Atlantic Yards.

title: Czech Republic: Vote Ends Stalemate
description: Prime Minister Mirek Topolaneks newly appointed coalition cabinet narrowly won a critical vote of confidence, ending a political stalemate that had left the country without an active government since elections last June. Those elections left the 200-seat Parliament evenly divided between rival coalitions. The deadlock was broken when two legislators from Mr. Topolaneks opposition broke ranks and backed his cabinet in the vote. But Mr. Topolanek warned that the political crisis might not be over if the continued partisan split made it impossible for the new government to act effectively.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 8 P.M. (AMC) JEREMIAH JOHNSON (1972). An ex-soldier, played by a scruffily golden Robert Redford, opts out of civilized society in the 1850s to live alone in the Colorado wilderness, where he unwittingly violates an Indian burial ground and loses his wife and adopted child to vengeance. Will Geer plays the trapper who teaches Johnson how to survive in this stark meditation on the American West, directed by Sydney Pollack. Parts of the film were shot northeast of Provo, Utah, near the ski area Mr. Redford eventually bought and named Sundance, after his character in Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Jan. 2, about coastal shipping, misstated a provision of the Merchant Marine Acts. The acts bar non-American ships from loading and unloading merchandise at consecutive American ports; they do not prevent such ships from calling on consecutive ports.

title: Two Are Sentenced for Fraud Involving Trading of Stocks
description: Two former traders at the New York Stock Exchange were each sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and fined $250,000 for improper stock trading.

description: The hero of The Dresden Files, a new series on the Sci-Fi Channel that will make its debut tomorrow night, is Harry Dresden, and if his name reminds you of someone, his profession, wizardry, should confirm your suspicions of where inspiration for him might have been drawn.

title: Madison Avenue Calling
description: People often say they do not like advertisements, but that may change if the ads start lowering their cellphone bills.

title: 2 Men Are Found Dead in Brooklyn Garage Where Fire Broke Out
description: Two men were found dead yesterday evening in a garage in Brooklyn that was damaged by a fire, officials said.

title: Chinas Muscle Flex in Space
description: China spread alarm and consternation among space powers when it destroyed one of its own satellites last week with a missile fired from the ground, thus becoming the first nation in more than two decades to successfully test an antisatellite weapon. This aggressive show of force puts a wide range of United States military and intelligence satellites at risk and holds the danger of starting an arms race in space. Too bad the Bush administrations own bellicose attitudes  and adamant refusal to consider an arms control treaty for space  give it scant standing to chastise the Chinese. The administration needs to reverse course promptly and join in talks aimed at banning further tests or use of antisatellite weapons.

title: Pataki Will Soon Lose State Security Detail
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19  Former Gov. George E. Pataki will soon give up the taxpayer-provided security detail he has enjoyed since leaving office at the end of last year, a spokesman said on Friday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: 21 Parishes Face Shutdown in New York
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday issued a final list of 21 parishes that will close, ending a wrenching period of uncertainty for thousands of parishioners, some of whom had waited for several years to learn the fate of their church.

title: Georgia: Illegal Workers Found at Military Sites
description: Twenty-four illegal immigrants were arrested on Wednesday after trying to enter Fort Benning to do construction work, Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said. All but three are facing federal charges of identity theft, use of fraudulent documents or re-entering the United States after deportation. In Nevada, the authorities said, two illegal immigrants employed as masons were arrested on Thursday at Creech Air Force Base in Indian Springs. In Virginia, immigration agents on Thursday arrested Richard Eversole, 58, an American citizen, and Juan Martnez, 24, a Mexican, on federal harboring charges, accusing them of hiring illegal immigrants to work on a construction project at the Quantico Marine Corps Base, and leasing apartments for the men.

title: G.E. Says Profit Rose 11%, but Its Shares Still Fall
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings in 2006 were up 11 percent, buoyed by favorable tax rates and strong performance in several industrial and finance units.

title: General Sees Summer Deadline for Troops
description: TALLIL AIR BASE, Iraq, Jan. 19  Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the top commander in Iraq, said Friday that the additional troops being sent to Iraq under President Bushs new plan to stabilize the country could begin to be withdrawn by late summer if security conditions improve.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film column on Jan. 10 about the New York Jewish Film Festival misidentified the voice-over featured in the animated short Chronicles of a Professional Eulogist. While the film is based on interviews with a rabbi who is the stepfather of the writers wife, the voice is that of Jonathan Milder, not the rabbi.

title: Election Could Decide Serbias Role in Europe
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 19  While six years of democracy in Serbia have given its people ample opportunities to vote  in four presidential elections, two parliamentary elections and a nationwide referendum  many complain that the country has seen little change.

title: Patent Trial Near, Bristol-Myers Counts on Resilience
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 19  Bristol-Myers Squibb staggered, but the drug maker has remained on its feet.

title: Seton Hall Drops Game After Losing a Starter
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 19  Seton Hall announced a heaping portion of bad news before Friday nights game against Georgetown. Its starting center and tallest player, the 6-foot-10 Grant Billmeier, is out for the season.

title: Warm Days and Hard Times in Snowmobile Land
description: CHESTER, Vt., Jan. 18  For 24 winters, Bev and Butch Jelley, owners of the B&B Mobil station here, have provided legions of snowmobilers with fuel and chili. But this year the kitchen is quiet, and the snowmobiles are nowhere to be found.

title: Education Officials Faulted
description: State education officials in Georgia mishandled their part in Reading First, a $1-billion- a-year federal program intended to teach low-income children to read by third grade, a report by the federal Education Departments inspector general found. The report said officials set unwarranted restrictions on local districts, creating the appearance of preferential treatment for a handful of programs. The state also failed to protect against conflict of interest, hiring the author of one program competing for use in Reading First schools to screen grant applications submitted by districts. Kathy Cox, the state school superintendent, said several of the audits findings had been remedied.

title: Candidates for State Comptroller Line Up
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19  The strange race to become the next comptroller of New York State began in earnest on Friday as at least 18 candidates took the first step toward being considered by submitting their rsums to the State Legislature.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 6 about a police officer in Madison, Conn., who is accused of stealing lobster meat and shrimp from a local seafood restaurant, referred incorrectly to the towns location. Madison is 20 miles east  not south  of New Haven.

description: A woman crossing the street in Newark yesterday afternoon was struck and injured by a marked police car chasing robbery suspects, the authorities said.
