title: Manhattan: Call to Monitor Investment Decisions
description: Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat, left, a Manhattan Democrat, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to create an 11-member investment review commission to monitor certain investment decisions made by the state comptrollers office. The office is the sole trustee of the states Common Retirement Fund, which provides pension, death and disability benefits to public employees. Mr. Espaillat, chairman of a task force of black, Hispanic and Asian-American state lawmakers, said the commission would focus on social investment goals for the fund, like promoting economic development in urban and rural areas that are struggling economically.

title: New Somali Government Faces the Age-Old Problem of Clans
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 18  Fifteen men and one woman sat on the floor of a sunlit room. It was hot. Many people were sweating. The elders of the Ayr clan had called a political meeting, and very quickly it was clear that their attitudes toward the nations newly empowered transitional government were unanimous  and bitter.

title: Court Rules Against Sentencing Rules in Calif.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that Californias system of sentencing criminals is unconstitutional because it gives judges some authority that really belongs to jurors and thus deprives a defendant of a fair trial.

title: Sri Lankan Military Battles Rebels at Sea
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 21  A fierce battle erupted off Sri Lankas northern coast on Sunday when two clusters of Tamil Tiger rebel boats, including suicide craft, attacked a ship carrying food supplies.

title: Using the Newsroom to Represent Honesty
description: AT a time when many deem newspapers to be going the way of hair tonic, tail fins and land lines, Madison Avenue still uses reporters and editors as role models for consumer behavior  to a point.

title: Safely Back Home in Louisiana, Playing It Safe
description: We all know of the destruction caused by Hurricane Katrina in 2005. Apart from its far more serious consequences, the Louisiana Bridge Association premises were severely damaged. The club had to relocate temporarily to the American Legion Hall in Harahan. But in October it reopened at 2709 Edenborn Avenue, Metairie, eight miles from downtown New Orleans.

title: Bush Expected to Make Call for Improved Fuel Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  There is widespread anticipation, inside government and outside, that President Bush will call for better fuel economy in his State of the Union address on Tuesday.

title: Bulletin! Washington Post Decides to Go for the Satirical
description: In what might be taken as a sign that The Washington Post believes in keeping its enemies close, the paper will sell local advertising for the humor weekly The Onion and print and distribute it in the Washington area.

title: U.S. Financial Sector Is Losing Its Edge, Report Says
description: Adding to a chorus of concern that the United States is losing its edge as the leading financial center, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release a report today urging the country to take a series of steps to improve its legal and regulatory environment.

title: Colts Overcome Brady and Patriots to Reach Super Bowl
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 21  To reach the Super Bowl, to finally fill in the blanks on the glittering rsums that lacked postseason glory, even the Indianapolis Colts conceded it was only appropriate that they would have to vanquish their greatest tormentors.

title: Clinton Opens Her Campaign With Health Insurance Plan
description: With a 4-year-old girl clutching her hand, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began her newborn presidential campaign yesterday at a Manhattan health care clinic, announcing legislation that would significantly expand federal health insurance for Americans under age 18.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Washington Bureau Chief Philip Taubman
description: Philip Taubman, Washington bureau chief for The Times, answered reader questions during the week of Jan. 22.

title: Whats Past Is Prologue
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Harsh Winter for the Calves
description: The cycle of ranch birth exposes tangled emotions and ambivalent impulses that go far beyond the elements.

title: Figuring Out the P.E. Ratio of Steve Jobs
description: Apples share price leaped to a record after the company unveiled its latest device to be hailed as the coolest thing ever, but investors are factoring more into their decision than a best guess on the number of iPhones Apple will sell. Ultimately they are putting a price on the brilliance and creativity of Apples designers and engineers and especially on its founder and chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.

title: Swift Founder to Take Company Private
description: The founder of Swift Transportation, Jerry C. Moyes, plans to buy the company for $2.74 billion. Mr. Moyes, who founded Swift more than 40 years ago with his father and brother, announced a deal Friday to pay $31.55 a share in cash to take the company private. His group, which includes family members, will also assume $332 million in debt.

title: A Single Securities Regulator Is Approved
description: The NYSE Group and NASD have won approval from brokerage firms to form a single regulator for the United States securities industry, overcoming opposition from a group of small firms. Sixty-four percent of members of NASD approved combining its regulatory operations with those of NYSE to create a single watchdog, NASD said in a statement Sunday. NASD, a private-sector provider of financial regulatory services with 5,058 brokerage firms, said almost 83 percent of eligible members voted during a 33-day election period.

title: Industrial Bank of China Plans Sizable Share Sale in Shanghai
description: The Industrial Bank of China, partly owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, may raise up to 21.25 billion yuan ($2.74 billion) from a Shanghai share sale, making it the second-largest domestic initial public offering by a mainland Chinese bank. Industrial Bank plans to sell up to 1.33 billion class A shares at between 15 yuan and 15.98 yuan each to investors, the company said in a statement Sunday. The sale would top the Bank of Chinas 20 billion yuan offer in June 2006 and would be second only to the Industrial and Commercial Bank of Chinas sale of 46.6 billion yuan last year.

title: China to Revamp 4th Bank in Preparation for Offering
description: China said over the weekend that the last of four big state-owned banks, the Agriculture Bank of China, would be financially restructured to prepare it for a public stock listing. Three of the largest banks sold shares in 2005 and 2006, offerings that raised more than $40 billion and were among the most successful initial public stock issues anywhere.

title: Prosecutor in Apple Case Joins Law Firm
description: Christopher J. Steskal, a lead prosecutor of a federal task force investigating the backdating of stock options at Apple and other companies, is leaving his San Francisco post to join a law firm, the United State Attorneys office in San Francisco confirmed late Friday.

title: Caremark Shareholders Bitter Pill
description: Caremark Rxs proposed merger with CVS, and its rejection of a higher offer from Express Scripts, is a case where a companys management has put themselves totally ahead of the stockholders, Ben Stein argues in a column in The New York Times.

title: Why Backdated Options Might Be Contagious
description: Directors of corporations often form a tight-knit community, serving at more than one company and creating what are known as interlocking boards of directors. As a result of this chumminess, corporate practices that otherwise might remain confined to just a few companies can spread quickly. That appears to have been the case with the backdating of stock options, according to a new statistical study of publicly traded American companies.

title: Big Medias Crush on Social Networking
description: An invitation to join someones online social networking circle is fast becoming the new handshake among Internet savvy business folk, writes The New York Timess Richard Siklos, who describes himself as an antisocial networker. But, he notes, the level of engagement that social networking demands raises questions about politesse when navigating the seas of staying in touch.

title: Star-Struck on the Soccer Field, and in the Boardroom
description: Major League Soccers deal for David Beckham, whose salary with bonuses could exceed the entire payroll of the rest of the league, shows an overwhelming faith in star economics, where the leading lights of an industry wield disproportionate influence, according to The New York Times.

title: Big Game? An Enron Survivor Hunts for Riches
description: The South Pacific islands of Papua New Guinea, where canned mackerel occasionally serves as currency and cannibalism was once on the menu, are a long way from the corporate jungles where Enron was born.

title: H.P. Chief Defends Timing of Stock Sale
description: The chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd, told Congressional lawmakers that his sale of company shares on Aug. 25 was totally unrelated to the fact that he was questioned the same day about an ill-fated internal investigation. The sale of 100,000 shares of Hewlett-Packard was made during a scheduled window for trading by executives, Mr. Hurd wrote in a letter dated Dec. 21 that he sent to the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat. On the same day the trade was completed, Mr. Hurd was interviewed by lawyers from the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati. The lawyers were looking into techniques used by Hewlett-Packard to identify the source of boardroom leaks.

title: Flames Flare Over Naked Shorts
description: Unsuspecting readers of certain stock message boards may be forgiven for believing they have stumbled into a flame war among 14-year-old boys. But the increasingly vicious online dispute actually involves, among others, the chief executive of a publicly traded corporation and a longtime business journalist.

title: Business News for the Saucy (and Internet Savvy) Set
description: Tuning into the demand for for saucy, tongue-in-cheek treatment that financial news gets on the net via blogs like Valleywag.com, Dealbreaker.com and the like, a band of video producers and wannabe stars are pooling their talents and cheap digital cameras to create Wallstrip, a daily online television show examining top-performing stocks, BusinessWeek writes.

title: Two Former N.Y.S.E. Traders Sentenced for Fraud
description: Two former traders at the New York Stock Exchange were each sentenced Friday to six months in prison and fined $250,000 for improper stock trading. The two traders, Michael J. Hayward and Michael F. Stern, former managers at Van der Moolen Specialists USA, were each convicted of securities fraud at a trial in July, part of a crackdown on illegal trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sears C.F.O. Resigns
description: Sears Holdings chief financial officer resigned Friday after less than four months on the job, the latest in a string of high-level executive changes as billionaire Edward Lampert searches for ways to make money on one of his biggest, and most challenging, investments. The executive, Craig Monaghan, plans to leave at the end of January and return to Florida where his family lives, according to an announcement from the Hoffman Estates-based company. William Crowley, chief administrative officer and chief financial officer before Mr. Monaghans arrival, will assume the C.F.O. role while Sears looks for a replacement.

title: Online Gambling Underwriters Face Subpoenas in U.S.
description: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to at least four Wall Street investment banks as part of a widening investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry, The New York Times reported. The subpoenas were apparently issued to firms that had underwritten the initial public offerings of some of the most popular online gambling sites that operate abroad. The Times said that the banks involved in the inquiry include HSBC, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Kleinwort, these people said.

title: One to Go
description: Facts and links on the morning after the conference championship games:

title: Chicagos Hancock Center Changes Hands
description: Another iconic Chicago tower changed hands Friday with the closing of the approximately $385 million sale of Chicagos third-tallest skyscraper, the John Hancock Center. The buyer is a joint venture of hometown real estate firm Golub & Company and Whitehall Street Real Estate Fund, an affiliate of New York-based Goldman Sachs.

title: Bacons Six Degrees of Charitable Giving
description: Actor Kevin Bacon has finally embraced the fact that hes connected to most of the rest of the world by just six degrees, and hes parlaying the concept to help humanity. SixDegrees.org, a play on the popular, tongue-in-cheek Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon game based on the performers career, hopes to be more than just a social-networking site, but rather a site that motivates the public to be more charitable.

title: Canadian Banks Chided for Timid Approach to China
description: China wants Canadian banks to abandon their timid approach to the Asian market of 1.3 billion consumers and instead step up investment there, the Canadian finance minister, Jim Flaherty, said Sunday, passing on advice that he underlined should be heeded. One of the things I heard from officials in China is that our financial services sector  particularly our banks  have probably been too conservative, not aggressive enough, in the China market, Mr. Flaherty said during a conference call with reporters at the end of a week-long trip to Beijing and Shanghai.

title: Providence Equity to Open Offices in Asia
description: Providence Equity Partners said it would open offices in Hong Kong and New Delhi to support its growing investment activities in Asia. Andrew Rickards, chief executive of the investment bank N.M. Rothschild & Sons in Asia, will become a managing director at Providence in Hong Kong and will lead the firms Asian investments, Providence said.

title: Is Big Brother Ruckus Bad for Business?
description: It seems that the brouhaha surrounding the treatment of a Bollywood actress on the British version of Big Brother is not doing British business any favors. Richard Lambert, director-general of an employers organization, the CBI, has waded into the row over alleged racism on Channel 4s Celebrity Big Brother by describing the program as complete crap and unhelpful to British firms trying to establish themselves in India. The Guardian reported.

title: Google in Talks to Buy Internet Ad Firm, Report Says
description: Google is in talks to acquire Adscape Media in a move to expand beyond its traditional Internet search advertising business and into video games, according to The Wall street Journal. A deal for Adscape, a closely held San Francisco firm whose technology allows for the placement of ads over the Web in video games, could be reached as early as this week, the report said.

title: Salary.com Prices I.P.O.
description: Salary.com, which provides on-demand compensation management products, set its planned initial public offering Friday at 5 million shares for an estimated price of $8 to $10 each. The company said in an amended Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the underwriters, Thomas Weisel Partners, William Blair & Company, Needham & Company, Wachovia Securities, and Pacific Crest Securities, have the option to buy an additional 750,000 shares to cover over-allotments.

title: Credit Suisse Eyes Big Buyback and and Other Deals
description: The Credit Suisse Group, Switzerlands second-largest bank, plans a record share buyback and will seek takeovers after selling its Winterthur insurance unit for 12.3 billion Swiss francs ($9.8 billion). The bank plans to buy back as much as 8 billion Swiss francs of stock over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion Swiss francs for bolt-on acquisitions in areas including wealth management, the bank said in a presentation to investors today. Credit Suisse last month completed the sale of Winterthur to Frances Axa.

title: Bidders Circle Apaxs Moelnlycke Health Care
description: The Blackstone Group and Swedens billionaire Wallenberg family are the leading bidders for Moelnlycke Health Care, which may be sold for as much as 3 billion euros ($3.9 billion), according to Bloomberg News. The report said that Apax Partners, the buyout shop that acquired Moelnlycke, a maker of surgical products, two years ago, is considering whether to drop a planned initial public offering and pursue a sale after receiving offers that value Moelnlycke at 2.5 billion euros to 3 billion euros.

title: Stoke Raises $20 Million
description: Stoke, a provider of networking hardware and software, said Monday it had raised $20 million in a Series C funding round led by led by DAG Ventures. Previous investors including Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital also participated in the round, Stoke said.

title: Citigroup to Buy ABN Amro Mortgage Unit
description: Citigroup agreed to buy ABN Amro Holdings ABN Amro Mortgage Group for an undisclosed amount to strengthen its presence in mortgage origination and servicing in the United States. Citigroup will acquire about $9 billion in net assets and the mortgage groups $224 billion mortgage-servicing portfolio, the bank said on Monday. The mortgage group is unit of ABN Amros LaSalle Bank.

title: U.S. Financial Sector Is Losing Its Edge, Report Says
description: Adding to a chorus of concern that the United States is losing its edge as the leading financial center, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release a report Monday urging the country to take a series of steps to improve its legal and regulatory environment. If not, the report warns, it could lose 4 to 7 percent of the global financial services market over the next five years.

title: A Boss Takes to His Blog to Deny, Then Confirm
description: Blogging by a chief executive can be tricky business. Some executives, like Jonathan I. Schwartz of Sun Microsystems, pull it off with aplomb. Others, like Jason Goldberg of the online recruiting company Jobster, have had more difficulty. Last month, Mr. Goldberg took to his blog to knock down rumors that Jobster was in trouble. Everybodys all a speculating. A lot of falsehoods are being bandied about, he wrote on Dec. 22. He said that revenue was up 30 percent, and he vowed to drive the company to profitability in 2007. Amid rumors of pending layoffs, he assured the staff that there would be no news until after the new year.

title: Tribune May Reject Outside Bids
description: The Tribune Company indicated over the weekend that it might reshape its future without outside help. On the auction block since last fall, the company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and other media properties, received three bids last week for all or part of the company.

title: Sundance East Prospers
description: The Reeler points out that, so far, NYC is finishing in the money at Sundance. Hometown boy and BMOC Dan Klores has a doc, Crazy Love, that will be coming, soon or not, to a theater near you, by virtue of Magnolias interest in exploring the commercial possibilities of a love that has a name, but very little in the way of precedent.

title: Krawcheck to Lead Citigroups Wealth Management Arm
description: Sallie L. Krawcheck, the chief financial officer of Citigroup, will become head of the banking giants wealth-management division. The move, which Citigroup announced in a news release early Monday, comes several weeks after the bank announced a management shake-up that seemed to quiet speculation on Wall Street that Ms. Krawcheck was planning to resign from the firm.

title: An Expanding World
description: Every few years it seems there is a report out of South Korea, where gaming is practically a national religion, about some young man who sat down to play an online PC game, didnt get up for a few days, and literally keeled over dead.

title: Political Agitation and a Missing Person
description: The choice of Chicago 10 as the hood ornament for this years Sundance comes in for additional spanking from Hollwood Elsewhere. The blog also runs a cast and crew photo from the premiere of Waitress, a sweet movie that grows in depth and texture as it unfolds. Between the photo and the film the murder of director Adrienne Shelly seems all the more affecting.

title: Trying Not to Be Roadkill on the Schuylkill
description: Remember the jingle "Baseball, hot dogs, apple pie and Chevrolet"? A musical campaign for a new Web site offers a version that could be called "Phillies, cheese steaks, scrapple and all kinds of cars."

title: Prepping for Bush Speech
description: The White House is getting ready for what would, under normal circumstances, be the most important speech of the year (though some would argue that his way forward in Iraq speech has already supplanted the State of the Union address). President Bush will address a joint session of Congress  a less friendly one than usual  Tuesday evening.

title: Cushman to Sell Bankers Trust Building for $325 Million
description: Cushman & Wakefield has sold the former Bankers Trust building at 14 Wall St., with its iconic pyramid top, as office space for $325 million, The New York Post reported. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that the real estate firm approached John Zamir of Capstone Equities about buying the building, which was not then for sale. Its current owners bought the building, with 1 million square feet of space, for $215 million in 2005 with the intent of making it residential. Those plans have long since stalled.

title: How to Tell Clinton From Obama
description: -Mary Duenwald

title: M Dot Dot Dot
description: The Bagger spent some time doing a video interview of M dot Strange, the guy behind the animated feature, We are the Strange. Its idiosyncratic visual vocabulary and 8-bit soundtrack had Sundancers jogging for the exits, but M dot, as the Bagger has come to think of him, could care less. To find out why, check out this thought from the Bagger about the changing nature of the movie biz. Or you can always check with the man hisself.

title: State Street to Buy Currenex for $564 Million
description: State Street, the institutional investors service provider, said on Monday it would buy the Currenex electronic foreign exchange trading platform for $564 million. Founded in 1999, Currenex serves banks, hedge funds and other active traders and has offices in New York, Chicago, London, Singapore and Redwood City, Calif.

title: What About the Awakened-by-Seemingly-Meaningless-Events Genre?
description: The RiskyBiz blog pointed us to Richard Corlisss piece in Time, in which he gives Sundance the back of his hand for being too predictable  too conformist in its noncomformity.

title: And After That, He Invented the Internet
description: But for me, as much of a fan of awards season as I always was, the business of Oscar started with the birth of Movie City News in 2002.  Dave Poland, editor of Movie City News, in an annotation of the Los Angeles magazine piece on Oscar bloggers.

title: Supporting Data
description: The Bagger is pulling out tomorrow to cover the Oscar nominations on Tuesday, and he had a thought about what seems like just one more stutter step on the way to the real deal. Actually, it was someone elses thought, but he will just pick their pocket and keep moving.

title: Gross Points
description: There was happy news for the makers of Grace is Gone, the film about a newly widowed character, played by John Cusack, who cant bring himself to tell his two girls that their mother is not coming back from Iraq. Variety reported that the Weinstein Company bought the film for $4 million in negotiations that went through the night to the early morning.

title: This is the Hill. This is the Hill on Drugs.
description: Side effects may include irritation, drowsiness and nausea. But with a $4.5 billion spent on direct-to-consumer drug advertising last year, someone is clearly benefiting from the effort to win over consumers. Congress is likely to conduct its own clinical trials, so to speak, on the matter.

title: Congress and Bush in the Week Ahead
description: For the first time since President Bush took office, a Democratically controlled Congress will be the audience for his State of the Union address and the reception is likely to be noticeably different.

title: Bombing at a Baghdad Marketplace
description: A pair of bombs killed at least 75 people in a crowded Baghdad marketplace, capping a weekend in which at least 27 U.S. service members died.

title: First, Lets Remove All the Lawyers
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 19 column, Surging and Purging.

title: Some Hillary What Ifs
description: Time for some more speculation about what happens if Hillary proves the doubters wrong by returning to the White House and giving up her Senate seat:

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Apres Clinton, Le Deluge
description: We are drowning in news about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. So are the other candidates, including Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico. And Senator Clinton isnt just resting on the flood of press coverage. Her campaign is taking an aggressive approach. Her pollster sent a memo to reporters saying that the campaigns of Senator Barack Obama and John Edwards are stalled or failing. Nonetheless, many Democrats are worried about her general election prospects.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Kiran Advani joined Zapwater Communications, Chicago, as group director. She had been running her own media relations and specialty-marketing agency and before that managed public relations and special events for the Terra Museum of American Art, Chicago.

title: Carlyle Matches Rival Bid for ElkCorp
description: The Carlyle Group has raised its offer for ElkCorp, a maker of roofing products, to $42 a share, matching a competing offer from the Building Materials Corporation of America and extending a months-long battle for ElkCorp.

title: One-Man Assault on Citadel Ends in Quiet Retreat
description: An unusual lawsuit involving a secretive hedge-fund chief has come to a fittingly enigmatic finale. Last June, a Florida man claiming to be the mentor of Kenneth C. Griffin accused him of defrauding him and illegally breaking their partnership to form Citadel Investment Group, a hedge fund that now oversees more than $12 billion in assets.

title: Editor's Note
description: A review on Jan. 14 about "The Man Who Would Not Shut Up," by Marvin Kitman, and "Culture Warrior," by Bill O'Reilly, incorrectly attributed an anti-Semitic euphemism to Patrick J. Buchanan, whose populism was compared to O'Reilly's. Neither the reviewer, Jacob Heilbrunn, nor the editors of the Book Review have found evidence that Buchanan has ever denounced "rootless cosmopolitans." Some of Buchanan's ideological opponents have used the phrase in characterizing his views, and the reviewer wrongly assumed from their writings that Buchanan had used it himself.

title: Tapping the Stuff Dreams Are Made Of
description: The academy and its TV partner, ABC, are scheduled to start  their annual campaigns to encourage viewers to watch the Academy Awards show.

title: Senator Clinton Calls for Federal Help for Sick 9/11 Workers
description: Targeting President Bush for the first time in her new role as presidential candidate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton attended a news conference at Ground Zero this morning and called on the White House to seek funding to cover the health needs of ill first responders who worked at the Twin Towers during 9/11.

title: Out and About: Bistro Cassis
description: The other night I did something unusual.

title: Conquering the Burning Crusade
description: Wednesday, Jan. 31 FINAL THOUGHTS

title: In Stock Sales, UBS Narrows Gap With Goldman
description: You would have thought, one fund manager recently opined to Bloomberg News, it would be a U.S. bank thats nipping at Goldmans heels. But you would have thought wrong: It is Zurich-based UBS that appears to be doing the nipping. And if the bank keeps up its pursuit of the Chinese market, UBS may surpass Goldman Sachs as the top dog of global stock sellers, Bloomberg News reports.

title: A.F.C. Championship
description: Quarterback Peyton Manning led the Colts over the Patriots in the biggest comeback in championship game history.

title: Co-Head of Goldmans Distressed Debt Unit to Retire
description: Mark McGoldrick, the London-based co-head of Goldman Sachs Special Situations Group, will retire for personal reasons, Bloomberg News reported Monday. His New York-based partner, Stephen McGuinness, will assume control of the whole unit, a Goldman spokesman said. Mr. McGoldrick, 47, earned the investment bank $500 million last year after Goldman sold a stake in Accordia Golf, a company it formed to run a set of failed Japanese golf courses.

title: Will Citi Woo Bank of Americas Outgoing C.F.O.?
description: Mondays announcement that the Citigroup chief financial officer, Sallie Krawcheck, is getting a new assignment at the firm quickly ignited speculation about who might succeed her. One name that kept popping up was Alvaro G. de Molina, who announced in December that he would step down as Bank of Americas chief financial officer, telling The New York Timess Eric Dash that he was looking for something that will be more impactful.

title: 6 Billion Degrees of Separation
description: This one ranks right up there with some of the best Stunts the Internet Makes Possible, so I thought Id give it a little digital ink:

title: Will Blackstone Raise Its Equity Office Bid? Speculation Abounds
description: The Blackstone Group is apt to fight back in the bidding war over Equity Office Properties Trust by raising its $36 billion bid, Reuters reported Monday, citing industry sources.

title: The Gentle Soul of a Dictator
description: Forest Whitaker, who already has a Golden Globe for his role as Idi Amin in The Last King of Scotland, is on everyones list to receive a best actor Oscar nomination tomorrow

title: Travelport Said to Consider Orbitz I.P.O.
description: Less than six months after leaving the public markets, the travel Web site Orbitz.com may be contemplating a return trip.

title: More on Darfur
description: I just started to tap out the headline on this blog software, and as soon as I had typed the word more it offered up: More Bad News From Darfur. I guess I used that as a previous headline. Maybe I should autoprogram my F6 key to type that out, because its certainly a refrain.

title: Bidding War for Child Art
description: My Kid Could Paint That, the story of a four-year-old girl whose abstract paintings made others look at her as a prodigy  before authorship of the work was challenged, sold here early this morning to Sony Pictures Classics for just under $2 million for world rights, according to Tom Bernard, co-president of Sony Pictures Classics(A & E has limited broadcast rights). There was much back and forth throughout the night, and much standing by, but eventually Mr. Bernard and his co-president, Michael Barker, won the competition.

title: Looking in the Mirror at the Caremark Chiefs Strategy
description: In an attempt to put the brouhaha over Caremarks proposed deal with CVS in context, TheStreet.coms Melissa Davis offers a history lesson. Edwin M. Crawford, the chief of Caremark, was at the center of another health-care merger more than a decade ago that in many ways mirrors whats happening now. Although he is considered a turnaround king who has steered Caremark to solid returns during his tenure, Ms. Davis writes, Mr. Crawford has at least one black spot in his past.

title: Looking for Health Care and Finding Fools Gold
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 22 column, Gold-Plated Indifference.

title: Additional Notes on 1/22 Column, Gold-Plated Indifference.
description: As is often the case, I couldnt fully explain my views in the space available. So Id like to explain at a bit more length why Im so opposed to the direction Bush is going.

title: More Clinton Staff Assignments
description: Three hard-working New Yorkers are taking on some weighty assignments for Hillary 08.

title: Congress First Report Card
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Jan. 21 column, Mr. Chips Goes to Washington.

title: Paying the Balance for Life
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Jan. 22 column, Your MasterCard or Your Life.

title: Alaska Air May Become Takeover Target, Analyst Says
description: Thanks to its smallish size and its location on the West Coast, Alaska Air could make an attractive takeover candidate if airlines start merging, according to a Credit Suisse analyst, Daniel McKenzie. Mr. McKenzie initiated coverage of the airline with an outperform rating. Despite the dominance of larger carriers, he wrote, Alaska Air holds strong market positions in a number of routes and has a solid balance sheet that is second only to that of Southwest Airlines.

title: The Mystery of the Private-Equity Populists
description: Why are so many billionaires speaking out lately about income inequality and the plight of the middle class? Trend-mongering is part of it, to be sure. But Slates Daniel Gross also sees something else at work: fear that the hoi-polloi are mad as hell, and soon wont take it anymore. Should the middle class face continued hardship  while economic royalists like Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group keep growing richer  the free trade of goods, services and capital will lose political support. And who else does that hurt?

title: Blogtalk
description: Everybody talks about the weather, so why isnt Mike Bloomberg doing anything about it? [Wonkster]

title: Gaps Chief Resigns After a Poor Fourth Quarter
description: Gaps chief executive, Paul Pressler, resigned Monday following a miserable holiday shopping season that hurt the retail chains fourth quarter profit.

title: The State of Our Energy Policy
description: This is what I wish President Bush would say about energy in his State of the Union message:

title: Procrastinate Now!
description: Heres an even better way to put off work than reading my blog. You can take an on-line survey to measure how much of a procrastinator you are.

title: Kingston? Thats So Downstate.
description: Where is the line between upstate and downstate New York?

title: Your Invitation to Mingle With Bono
description: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland.

title: Hillary Clinton
description: Senator Clinton of New York announced her bid on Jan. 20.

title: War at Home: Another Senate Resolution
description: Several leading Republican senators, led by John W. Warner of Virginia, the former chairman of the Armed Services Committee, proposed their own language for a resolution today against President Bushs plan to send 21,500 more troops to Iraq.

title: Barack Obama
description: Senator Obama's announcement was one of the first Web videos to be widely distributed.

title: The View From 1,650 Meters
description: World leaders and corporate chiefs will spend the next few days in Davos debating issues that affect billions of people  the global economy, climate change and energy, just to name a few  in what the World Economic Forum describes as an attempt to set the global agenda.

title: Moguls Arrive, One Eye on the Sky
description: As well as a flurry of corporate bigwigs and policy makers, Davos can expect some snow later this week, if weather forecasts prove correct. Considering the unusually balmy winter the Alps is having this year, that is likely to be happy news for the conferences many skiing aficionados and especially for one mogul in particular: publishing executive Hubert Burda, who for several years has organized an invitation-only ski race to coincide with the annual conference.

title: Do You Believe in Magic?
description: Research indicates that the appetite for so-called magical thinking is rooted in the circuitry of the brain, Benedict Carey writes in todays Science Times. This helps explain why even people who fashion themselves skeptics cling to odd rituals that seem to make no sense, like lucky numbers and special game-day clothing.

title: Bronx: Teenager Charged With Two Murders
description: A Bronx teenager was indicted on murder charges yesterday in two deaths, including the contract killing of a drug dealer as part of a turf war over drug sales, the Bronx district attorneys office announced. The teenager, Alan Brown, 18, is charged with shooting Shawron Hughes, who prosecutors said was a drug dealer, as Mr. Hughes was driving in Fordham on July 7, 2005. Mr. Hughes lost control of his car, which struck and killed a bystander, Wellington Contrera. Mr. Hughes, who was shot in the head, did not die until Oct. 19, 2006. Prosecutors said that Mr. Brown had been hired by Terrance Degraffenreid, 33, to kill Mr. Hughes for $2,000. A second man, who has not been identified and who the authorities said was still at large, was also involved in hiring Mr. Brown, prosecutors said. Mr. Degraffenreid faces first-degree murder and other charges, prosecutors said, and a third man, Duane Heath, 19, faces conspiracy and weapons charges.

title: Williams Hangs on to Advance to Semifinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 23  Shahar Peer did not make it easy, tracking down big shots that others might not have bothered to chase and rallying from a 4-1 deficit in the third set. Serena Williams did not make it easy on herself, struggling with her movement and timing and never looking entirely comfortable.

title: Libby a Scapegoat, His Lawyer Tells Jurors
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  In his opening statement today, the chief defense lawyer for I. Lewis Libby Jr. set the stage for a nasty bout of finger-pointing in the Bush administration, asserting that Mr. Libby, the vice presidents former chief of staff, had been made a scapegoat to protect the presidents longtime political strategist, Karl Rove.

title: Ford Shows a Hybrid Car With 2 Modes: Electric or Electric
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  Move over, gas-electric hybrid. Ford has a new entry, the electric-electric hybrid.

title: Limits on Prison Suits Are Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  Twelve years ago, Congress passed a law intended to make it harder for prisoners to file lawsuits challenging prison conditions as illegal or unconstitutional. On Monday, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a federal appeals court had overstepped its bounds by making prisoner lawsuits even harder to file than Congress intended.

title: Jerome Robbins: One Toeshoe in Bach, the Other in Kern
description: Jerome Robbins choreographed two of his late ballets to Bach in the first few months of 1994, and both were on the third themed program of the New York City Ballets winter season, Jerome Robbins: An American Icon.

title: Eye on the Sky
description: Q. The optical Large Synoptic Survey Telescope is supposed to measure dark matter. Since dark matter is invisible, how can an optical telescope see it?

title: Rehabilitating Robert Moses
description: FOR three decades his image has been frozen in time. The bulldozing bully who callously displaced thousands of New Yorkers in the name of urban renewal. The public-works kingpin who championed highways as he starved mass transit. And yes, the visionary idealist who gave New York Lincoln Center and Jones Beach, along with parks, roads, playgrounds and public pools.

title: No Smokers, but Watch the Skies
description: It is illegal in this city to light up a cigarette in a bar because the secondhand smoke can be hazardous, and you never know. Someone across the room might end up with cancer in 25 or 30 years.

title: Icahn Backs Three for Cyberonics Board
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 22. (Reuters)  The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said on Monday that he planned to back three nominees by Metropolitan Capital Advisors to the board of Cyberonics, a medical device maker under investigation for its stock options dating practices.

title: Supreme Court Limits Judges Sentencing Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The Supreme Court invalidated Californias criminal sentencing law on Monday, ruling that the 30-year-old statute gave judges authority that the Constitution places with juries.

title: A Radical Step to Preserve a Species: Assisted Migration
description: The Bay checkerspot butterflys story is all too familiar. It was once a common sight in the San Francisco Bay area, but development and invasive plants have wiped out much of its grassland habitat.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the Pentagons new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantnamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administrations original plans for the commissions. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unconstitutional.

title: Suit Challenges Rent Jumps in Complexes MetLife Sold
description: The $5.4 billion sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village was hailed by Wall Street and the real estate industry as a bountiful coup for its owner, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: Outsiders Console the Underdogs
description: Nobody wants you, but we want you, Murray Lightburn of the Dears sang on Friday night at Webster Hall, heedless of the contradiction. The Dears have a mission. They are determined to console underdogs and befriend the alienated, and they stayed steadfastly on message throughout their set.

title: Restatement by Take-Two Over Problems With Options
description: Take-Two Interactive Software, maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, said yesterday that it let its former chief executive, Ryan A. Brant, control and dominate improper options backdating that began when the company went public in 1997.

title: Small Wonders: Understanding the Way of the Warrior Sperm
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The first thing that David E. Clapham of Harvard Medical School wants me to know as we meet for breakfast on a recent morning is that hes not a sperm specialist.

title: Meat Processor Considering a Buyout
description: Swift, the beef and pork producer, said yesterday that it was considering a possible buyout after receiving unsolicited inquiries during the last six months.

title: General Petraeuss Opening Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Following is the opening statement by Lieutenant General David H. Petraeus this morning before a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on his nomination to be the commander of U.S. forces in Iraq, as recorded by Federal News Service.

title: Watching the Energy Watchdog
description: A scathing report from the states Public Service Commission about last summers electrical blackout in western Queens took some well-deserved shots at Consolidated Edison. The utility certainly failed spectacularly as it left 174,000 people sweltering in the dark for as long as nine days. But the report ignored a critical part of the problem: the commission itself, which has been incompetently monitoring the energy monopoly.

title: An Alternative to Long Irons, and Its Legal
description: CARLSBAD, Calif.  In the early days of the 1999 golf season, two engineers from TaylorMade began showing up at tournaments with a golf club shaped like a weeding tool. The club was made from small, expensive pieces of titanium and tungsten, and by many accounts, it was ugly.

title: Making Sense of Time, Earthbound and Otherwise
description: More than three weeks have passed since the great Waterford disco ball dropped over Times Square, and most of us are taking 2007 in stride. The time is flying by, just as it does when were having fun, approaching a deadline or taking a standardized test on which our entire future depends, though not, oddly enough, when we ourselves are flying, especially not when we are seated in the last row, near the bathrooms.

title: Never Too Early for Pollsters
description: Let the hypotheticals begin. Conventional wisdom may say Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York is the Democrats prohibitive front-runner. But a Newsweek poll released over the weekend, which otherwise shows the candidates tightly bunched, indicates that former Senator John Edwards, below, is the only one to beat the top two potential Republican candidates in head-to-head matchups. The poll shows that Mr. Edwards, of North Carolina, Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama of Illinois all would beat Senator John McCain of Arizona by a few percentage points. But Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor, would narrowly defeat Senators Clinton and Obama while losing to Mr. Edwards, 45 percent to 48 percent. But the numbers are all close and fall within the polls margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

description: In last Fridays editorial about the administration official who urged corporations to punish lawyers for representing Guantnamo detainees: Charles Stimson is a deputy assistant secretary of defense, not state.

description: Now for a pause in Indianapoliss Super Bowl party.

title: Hoboken: Councilmans Lawyer Cites Lapse in Judgment
description: In a statement released yesterday, the lawyer for a Hoboken councilman charged on Saturday with drunken driving in Manhattan said his client realizes this was a lapse in judgment and admits he made a mistake. The councilman, Christopher Campos, 30, left, who is also a prosecutor in West New York, was charged with driving while intoxicated after he ran a red light on the West Side Highway at 43rd Street about 3 a.m., the police said. Yesterday, his lawyer, Francis S. Cutruzzula, released a statement in which he said Mr. Campos acknowledged that he had made a mistake and wants to assure everyone that this will never happen again. A spokesman for David Roberts, the mayor of Hoboken, said that the mayor was supportive of Mr. Campos and did not believe that the councilman would need to resign. Mr. Campos did not respond to requests for comment yesterday.

title: Rulings Effect on California Inmates Is Probably Modest
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22  The Supreme Court decision on Monday that invalidated Californias criminal sentencing law would probably affect only a small slice of the states convicted felon population.

title: New Scanners for Tracking City Workers
description: The Bloomberg administration is devoting more than $180 million toward state-of-the-art technology to keep track of when city employees come and go, with one agency requiring its workers to scan their hands each time they enter and leave the workplace.

title: Partial Bailout Offered in Book Bankruptcy
description: Small publishers left reeling by the major book wholesaler Advanced Marketing Services bankruptcy filing last month received a rare bit of good news yesterday.

title: Individualists, Straddling Cultures and Exporting Ideas
description: World music performers often present themselves as emissaries from a single exotic country. But at the fourth annual Globalfest, a world-music showcase with a dozen acts at Webster Hall on Sunday night, many of the musicians cited dual origins: Cape Verde and Lisbon for Sara Tavares, Colombia and New York City for Lucia Pulido, Cambodia and Los Angeles for the band Dengue Fever, Mexico and Minneapolis for Lila Downs. These are not traditional musicians; they are individualists who happily blend and straddle cultures.

title: At Princeton, a Parody Raises Questions of Bias
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22  Belda Chan, a senior at Princeton University, was stunned when she encountered an article in broken English in the annual joke issue of the student daily parodying an Asian-American student who had filed a civil rights complaint against Princeton.

title: 2 Car Bombs Kill Scores at Packed Market in Baghdad

title: Hezbollah Strike Brings Beirut to a Virtual Halt

The escalation brought the Lebanese capital to a virtual standstill and heightened fears that the nearly two-month long political crisis could burst into sectarian conflict.

description: Any doubts that the tobacco industry has surreptitiously raised the nicotine content of cigarettes should be laid to rest by a study from researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health. They confirmed last years discovery of the nicotine increase by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and went on to identify how the tobacco companies designed their cigarettes to accomplish this.

title: Thousands Mourn Slain Editor in Istanbul

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 23  The Ethiopian troops who helped install Somalias fledging government in Mogadishu, the capital, earlier this month began to pull out today, officials said.

title: Showcasing Talents for Those Who Write the Checks
description: Jazz  or what people can get away with calling jazz  is crucial to the world of American midsize theaters and subscription performing-arts audiences. So jazz becomes extra dynamic for a week in New York around the time of the annual conference of the Association of Performing Arts Presenters. Besides the panels and performances at the New York Hilton, the conferences home base, clubs around town set up dozens of showcases last week. The biggest was Winter Jazzfest, which took over the Knitting Factory on Saturday night.

title: Britain: BBC in Talks With YouTube
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBCs programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material.

description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 22  The mentor and the protg spoke briefly by telephone Monday. Nothing groundbreaking there. Bears Coach Lovie Smith keeps in touch with Tony Dungy, the Indianapolis Colts coach, who gave him his first N.F.L. job more than a decade ago.

title: Roddick Will Try to Make Semis Interesting for Federer
description: MELBOURNE -- Roger Federer was sitting comfortably, legs crossed, after vanquishing Tommy Robredo in less style than usual in the quarter final round of the Australian Open Tuesday. He was talking just a little wistfully about how great it had been to watch a five-set match the night before when Rafael Nadals staying power had gotten the better of Andy Murrays brain power.

title: Memo Pad
description: NOT A BAD YEAR FOR AIRLINES  After $35 billion in net losses from 2001 to 2005, the domestic airline industry is expected to earn about $4 billion in 2007 and to report earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion for 2006, the Air Transport Association said. But the Champagne corks are not popping yet. John Heimlich, the trade associations chief economist, noted that despite cost cutting, reduction in capacity and a decrease in the number of aircraft types flown, debt levels remain high, leaving airlines vulnerable to fuel spikes and other risks like a recession, natural disaster or another significant terrorist attack.

title: Brazil: Air Controllers Share Collision Blame
description: Government investigators looking into the cause of the midair collision over the Amazon in September that killed 154 people aboard a civilian airliner said for the first time that air traffic controllers were partly to blame. Previously, the authorities had assigned responsibility solely to the two American pilots of the other plane, an executive jet that managed to make an emergency landing without loss of life. The controllers should have adopted emergency procedures when the smaller plane could not be located on their radar screens, but that was not done, said Renato Sayo, the chief investigator.

title: Britons Harvest Ships Bounty, From BMWs to Bibles
description: LONDON, Jan. 22  Hundreds of people foraged among containers washed from a stricken cargo vessel on the southern English coast on Monday, ignoring health warnings and threats of prosecution and hauling off booty that included BMW motorcycles, shoes, diapers, beauty cream and carpets.

title: Plain Speaking and Singing on Coplands Family Farm
description: Aaron Copland worried about the durability of The Tender Land, his opera about a traditional, humble, rural 1930s family suspicious of outsiders and their morals. But it seems uncannily relevant: contemporary America is still often touted as a place whose small-town heartland, inhabited by plain-spoken, wary and conservative folk, is framed by cities teeming with deviants and elitists.

title: A Birds-Eye View of Ski Trails Perils
description: While a ski trail can provide plenty of enjoyment (at least when there is enough snow to cover it), from an environmental standpoint it is a scar on the landscape. This is especially true for trails constructed below the tree line, where large patches of forest must be clear-cut to make way for skiers.

title: All Around the Town, Piano Recitals With a Difference
description: The most obvious way to freshen a classical music program is through novel programming. The pianist Wu Han and the cellist David Finckel have proved adept at this so far as music directors of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. The title they devised for the societys program on Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall might have been trite  Pianos/Pianists: A Celebration of the Keyboard  but the concept was imaginative.

title: Eagles Assistant Joins the Giants
description: The Giants, whose championship hopes this season collapsed when their defense collapsed, turned to their bitter rivals, the Philadelphia Eagles, for a new defensive coordinator.

title: Bank of America Profit Rises 47%
description: Big gains in equity investments buoyed Bank of Americas earnings in the fourth quarter, which were up 47 percent from the same period in 2005, the bank reported today.

title: Albany: Increased Disclosure for Legislative Grants
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said yesterday that all future recipients of so-called member items  grants that lawmakers steer to community groups and pet projects in their home districts  would be required to meet detailed new disclosure requirements before the money was disbursed. The recipients would have to reveal any potential conflict of interest with the lawmaker. Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that such conflicts would not necessarily prevent groups from receiving money, but that the new requirements would lend transparency to what has been a highly secretive process. When people dont know, people get suspicious, Mr. Cuomo said.

title: Helicopter Crashes in Baghdad and 5 Are Killed
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 23  Five members of a private security detail protecting an American convoy were killed on Tuesday when their helicopter came under attack and plummeted to the pavement through a tangle of electrical wires in one of Baghdads most dangerous neighborhoods.

With his career cut short because of the fractured hind leg he sustained during the Preakness Stakes, voters for the Eclipse Awards decided he did not accomplish enough on the racetrack to merit any championship honors.

title: Abb Pierre, 94, French Priest Who Aided the Homeless, Dies
description: Abb Pierre, who in the 1950s as a gaunt priest with a crook-handled cane and a profoundly persuasive passion mobilized France to attend to its homeless, then kept pressing his crusade until he became known as the countrys moral compass, died yesterday in Paris. He was 94.

title: Italy: French Bank Reduces a Stake
description: Crdit Agricole, the French bank, sold a 3.6 percent stake in Intesa Sanpaolo for 2.51 billion euros ($3.23 billion), complying with a requirement by Italys antitrust authority. After the sale, Crdit Agricole, which is based in Paris, still has shares representing about 5.8 percent of the capital and 5.5 percent of the voting rights of Intesa, which is based in Milan. Crdit Agricole was ordered on Dec. 20 by the Italian antitrust regulator to reduce its stake in the Italian bank.

description: IN the last six months, media coverage, Congressional hearings, lawsuits by private citizens and a scathing report by the Interior Departments inspector general have exposed a litany of failures in the departments management of oil and gas leases on public lands and waters.

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22  There are no electric cars in Crazy Love. No presidential candidates. No cautionary tales about eating too much fast food and no penguins. Instead this latest offering from Dan Klores, the longtime New York publicist turned documentarian, looks squarely at something many of his peers have avoided of late: simple human emotions.

title: Do You Believe in Magic?
description: A graduate school application can go sour in as many ways as a blind date. The personal essay might seem too eager, the references too casual. The admissions officer on duty might be nursing a grudge. Or a hangover.

description: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 22  Bill Parcells dutifully kept regular office hours, even as he kept the Dallas Cowboys in the dark for the past 15 days.

title: Lack of Budget Could Hurt Nuclear Energy Revival, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The senior member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission warned on Monday that the failure of Congress to pass a detailed budget for the current fiscal year could damage the nuclear renaissance that the government tried so hard to encourage with the energy bill of 2005.

title: Bridgeport: Choir Director Admits Possession of Pornography
description: The former music director of Christ Church in Greenwich pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to possession of child pornography, a charge that carries a maximum penalty of 10 years. Assuring the court that he would check himself into a medical center pending sentencing, the former director, Robert F. Tate, was released after posting a $500,000 bond secured by rental property he owns in Stamford and the pledge of several supporters who agreed to cover the balance. Prosecutors told the court that they confiscated electronic materials that contained 150 to 300 sexually explicit images of young children from Mr. Tates housing at the Episcopal church. Asked by Judge Alan H. Nevas whether he was pleading guilty because he was guilty, Mr. Tate, 64, said that sad to say, I am. A woman whose husband co-signed the bond, Evelyn Bausman, told a reporter that she believed Mr. Tates admission of guilt. Asked then why she stood by him, she said, Well, were all sinners.

title: Manhattan: Ex-Guard Sentenced for Sex With Inmate
description: A former federal prison guard was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday for having sexual contact with an inmate and making false statements to investigators, prosecutors said. The former guard, Nicholas Defonte, 49, of Staten Island, was sentenced to 18 months in prison, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said Mr. Defonte had sexual contact with the female inmate while he supervised the kitchen at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan in 2001. A jury in April acquitted Mr. Defonte of two counts of sexual abuse, but convicted him of sexual activity with an inmate.

title: Somali Islamists No. 2 Leader Surrenders in Kenyan Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 22  The second in command of Somalias defeated Islamist forces has surrendered to the Kenyan authorities and is staying at a hotel in Nairobi, Western diplomats and Somali officials said Monday.

title: Bush Calls for Increase in Renewable Fuels
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Bush, vowing to reduce the nations thirst for foreign oil, called tonight for a huge government-mandated increase in renewable fuels  mainly ethanol  and tougher mileage standards for cars and light trucks.

title: Switzerland: Bank Plans a Share Buyback
description: The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss bank, will use proceeds from the sale of its Winterthur insurance unit to buy back a record amount of stock and make money-management acquisitions. The bank plans to repurchase as much as 8 billion francs ($6.4 billion) of shares over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion francs for possible takeovers in the United States, the Middle East and Asia. We have the requisite resources to grow our business, while at the same time returning capital to our shareholders, the chief executive, Oswald J. Grbel, told investors in Zurich. Credit Suisse completed the sale of Winterthur to Axa of France for 12.3 billion francs last month.

Wade, the president manages to be out of town, addressing protesters by telephone, not in person.

description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23  Israels attorney general plans to indict the countrys president, Moshe Katsav, on charges of rape and other sexual offenses, the Justice Ministry announced today.

title: Manhattan: Student Dies in Fall From Roof
description: A 21-year-old Hunter College student was killed yesterday in a fall from the rooftop of a 20-story college building on East 67th Street near Lexington Avenue, the police said. The student, Anton Frolov of Brooklyn, had been escorted from the roof moments before by security guards responding to an alarm that sounded when he went outside, the police said. But minutes later, he went back outside, the police said, and fell before the guards returned. The police said they were investigating the possibility that he had jumped. The students landing was so loud that 911 callers reported the sound of gunfire or an exploding bomb, the police said. David Sanchez, 45, a custodian in the building, said, I was inside on the first floor taking care of the trash when I heard a big bang, like a really loud noise.

title: In the Vortex of Baghdad, Staying Put This Time
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 22  Two blocks from the new American outpost in Ghazaliya, one of Baghdads most dangerous neighborhoods, a fight was raging. Shiites were battling Sunnis, the latest skirmish in a sectarian war that has left this area a wasteland.

title: Fighting Drug Abuse (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bachs Strolls and Puzzles in All Keys, Major and Minor
description: The two books of Bachs Well-Tempered Clavier contain an immense amount of music. Their 48 preludes and fugues touch not only on every major and minor key, twice, but also on just about every way an 18th-century musician might have conceived and executed either form.

title: Canadian to Remain on U.S. Terrorist Watch List
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  Despite a Canadian inquiry that cleared a Syrian-born Canadian citizen of any terrorist ties, the Bush administration has formally refused a Canadian government request that it remove the man, Maher Arar, from the terrorist watch list, saying that the United States has secret information justifying his inclusion.

title: E. Howard Hunt, Watergate Figure, Dies at 88
description: E. Howard Hunt, a cold warrior for the Central Intelligence Agency who left the spy service in disillusion, joined the Nixon White House as a secret agent and bungled the break-in at the Watergate that brought the president down in disgrace, died today in Miami. He was 88.

title: Five New Satellites With a Mission of Finding a Source of Color in Space
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  NASA will soon launch a fleet of five spacecraft in hopes of solving the mystery of how the greenish auroras above the Earths poles suddenly burst into shimmering multicolor lights.

title: Report Accuses Belfast Police of Collusion in Gang Killings
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 22  Northern Irelands police ombudsman, in a report on Monday, accused the provinces police force of collusion with at least one loyalist Protestant gang in a number of killings and attempted killings and serious drug crimes.

title: Yonkers: City Agrees to Bronx River Cleanup Plan
description: The City of Yonkers has agreed to end its four-year opposition to a state plan to clean up the citys discharge of sewage into the Bronx River, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The settlement, approved earlier this month by a State Supreme Court justice in Westchester County, calls for the city to pay $2.2 million for a study to identify sources of pollution and then to promptly clean up the sites identified by the study.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 4 and Wounds 23 in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 22  A suicide bomber rammed his explosive-laden car into a military convoy near Mirali in the restive North Waziristan tribal region on Monday, killing 4 people and wounding 23, witnesses said.

title: Record Labels Contemplate Unrestricted Digital Music
description: CANNES, France, Jan. 22  As even digital music revenue growth falters because of rampant file-sharing by consumers, the major record labels are moving closer to releasing music on the Internet with no copying restrictions  a step they once vowed never to take.

title: Police Tied to Murder of Russian Journalist
description: MOSCOW, Jan 23  Police officials in Chechnya are under criminal investigation for a possible role in the murder of Anna Politkovskaya, the prominent Russian journalist, a New York-based media rights group said here today.

title: Louisiana: Congressman to Run for Governor
description: Representative Bobby Jindal, Republican of Louisiana, said he would enter the 2007 governors race, his second attempt at winning the office. Mr. Jindal will be running against a weakened incumbent, Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco, a Democrat. Ms. Blanco defeated Mr. Jindal by four percentage points in 2003, but her standing was damaged after Hurricane Katrina. Mr. Jindal, 35, has also been the secretary of the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals and an assistant secretary at the federal Department of Health and Human Services in the Bush administration.

title: Veteran of Lebanon Campaigns Is Set to Lead Israeli Army
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 22  A former infantry officer who commanded Israeli troops against Hezbollah in southern Lebanon for many years was appointed Monday as the Israeli militarys new chief of staff.

title: General Calls Iraq Situation Dire
description: The situation in Iraq is dire, Lt. Gen. David Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee today. But he said the planned increase in troop levels and new tactics should enable American and Iraqi forces to provide security in Baghdad.

title: Detention Is Urged for African TB Cases
description: LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP)  A team of doctors has recommended forcibly detaining people in South Africa who refuse treatment for a drug-resistant form of tuberculosis, an extreme measure meant to keep the infected away from others to curb the spread of the disease, according to a paper published Monday in an international medical journal.

title: Expect Havoc Near Brooklyn Bridge, but Its Just for a Movie
description: Do not be alarmed, the police warned New Yorkers yesterday, should they see Army and Coast Guard helicopters or police and military vehicles swarming near the Brooklyn Bridge tonight. Its just a movie: in this case, a film starring Will Smith about the last human in New York.

title: State Farm Settles Katrina Claims in Mississippi
description: State Farm, the nations largest home insurer, reached an agreement today with Mississippi officials to pay hundreds of millions dollars to thousands of homeowners in the state who have been unable to rebuild in the nearly 17 months since Hurricane Katrina swept across the Gulf Coast.

title: A Humorist Illuminates the Blessings of Hospice
description: As the self-described man who would not die, the humor columnist Art Buchwald was a strange bedfellow with the hospice movement. But in the months between the end of his extended hospice stay and his death from kidney failure on Wednesday at age 81, Mr. Buchwald was a living testimonial to the benefits of hospice care.

title: Bloombergs School Push (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: European Trade Negotiator Sees Some Hope
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 22  The European Unions chief trade negotiator said Monday that efforts to restart stalled global trade talks were showing new vigor. But he sought to discourage expectations that a breakthrough could come during a meeting of trade ministers this week alongside the Global Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Here, There and in Iowa
description: One of the striking things about the 2008 presidential campaign is the number of stages it is being played on at once. Take today in Washington, for example, where things will be happening on two fronts. The afternoon brings a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee, a platform that could display the sharply contrasting views on Iraq of Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York. The evening brings the presidents State of the Union address, which many Democrats  notably Mrs. Clinton  view as providing an opportunity to tee off to advance their own presidential campaigns.

title: State Panel to Scrutinize 17 Hopefuls for Comptroller
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  If only Flavor Flav had thrown his oversize clock into the ring, it might have made a good reality television show.

title: In the Background, You Just May Hear the Past
description: When you listen to the songs of Michael Franks, a creator of impressionistic pop-jazz pastels, there is always the question of how to frame his exquisite, whimsical miniatures. On 16 albums recorded over more than three decades, the most common solution has been to present them as smooth jazz. But if you pay close attention to the lyrics of songs like The Cool School, a nostalgic ode to the jazz cats of the 50s and early 60s on his newest album, Rendezvous in Rio (Koch), you will realize that Mr. Frankss heart belongs to a purer musical era.

title: Manhattan: Call for Aid to 9/11 Workers
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer and Representatives Carolyn B. Maloney, Jerrold L. Nadler and Vito J. Fossella held a news conference at ground zero yesterday to urge President Bush to provide money for monitoring and treating rescue workers, volunteers and firefighters who became ill after helping with the 9/11 cleanup and recovery. This is an issue that demands attention from the president and the Congress, Mrs. Clinton said, adding, I believe this is a moral responsibility. Last month, officials warned that federal money set aside for treating the workers would run out in a few months. To draw attention to the issue, several of the lawmakers said they had invited 9/11 first responders and some of their relatives as their guests for the presidents State of the Union address tonight.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,022 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: 2 Nations Seek American Antimissile Defense
description: BERLIN, Jan. 23  The United States will start formal negotiations this year with Poland and the Czech Republic on the deployment of an antimissile defense system meant to protect them from possible attacks by rogue states or terrorist groups, government officials said today.

title: Armenian Editors Death Leads to Conciliation
description: ISTANBUL, Jan. 22  The killing of an Armenian-Turkish editor in Istanbul last week and the sorrow it has generated within Turkey are leading to rare conciliatory gestures between Turkey and Armenia, historic enemies, and to calls for changes in laws here defending Turkish identity.

title: Consequences: Gun Ownership Linked to Higher Homicide Rates
description: States with the greatest number of guns in the home also have the highest rates of homicide, a new study finds.

title: A Note to Women Travelers: Be Too Cute to Leave Behind
description: MOST frequent travelers like their passports, with all those exotic stamps. But the passport photo is another matter. Many people hate theirs. Mine, for example, looks like Dick Cheney after two hard days in a drizzly duck blind.

title: Death Knell May Be Near for Public Election Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The public financing system for presidential campaigns, a post-Watergate initiative hailed for decades as the best way to rid politics of the corrupting influence of money, may have quietly died over the weekend.

title: Grand Jury Weighs Case of a Killing by the Police
description: A Queens grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday in the police shooting of Sean Bell, an unarmed black man who was killed in a hail of police bullets on his wedding day in November.

title: The 2008 Race Heats Up Early (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Shuffle Roils Waters at Citigroup
description: Citigroup shuffled its management ranks yesterday for the second time in a little more than a month in a shake-up that raises questions about the banks ability to turn itself around.

title: Libby Jury Seated; Arguments May Start Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The judge in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. seated a jury of nine women and three men on Monday who are expected to spend a month or longer hearing the case against Vice President Dick Cheneys former top aide.

title: Allied Is Asked to Remove Management
description: Greenlight Capital, the hedge fund, asked the Allied Capital Corporation in a letter yesterday to replace senior managers after the indictment of an executive at an affiliated company.

title: Berkeley Township: Body Found in Woods Is Identified
description: A young woman found dead on Sunday under a pile of trash has been identified as Illeana Hess, 17, of Toms River, Thomas F. Kelaher, the Ocean County prosecutor, said yesterday. Ms. Hess was last seen alive by her father on Dec. 31 at her home on Morris Avenue and had been reported missing, said Capt. Jeff Harper of the Ocean County Prosecutors Office. Ms. Hesss body was discovered near 3 p.m. Sunday by a man scavenging through garbage in a wooded area near Dover Road. The body showed no signs of trauma, Captain Harper said. He added that because Ms. Hess was buried under trash, it appears she was put there. Her death is considered suspicious, he said, and a toxicology report is pending.

title: Acquisition Ban Lifted at Career Education
description: The Career Education Corporation, which operates more than 80 campuses in the United States and overseas, said yesterday that the Education Department lifted a ban imposed in June 2005 that limited acquisitions and expansion.

title: Two Power Plants Win a Lawsuit, and Property Taxes Rise Drastically in Several Towns
description: GARNERVILLE, N.Y. Barbara Bodnar, a retired nurse having lunch one recent afternoon at Sparkys Diner in this Rockland County hamlet of 9,000 people, saw her annual property tax jump $7,200 in the fall. David Clark, the owner of REC supply, a hardware store in Haverstraw, said his taxes doubled. Danny Lis rose 93 percent  and seven neighbors put their houses up for sale.

title: Chemical Insecurity
description: The new Democratic leadership in Congress has a chance to finally do what the Republican Congress and the Bush administration failed to do after Sept. 11: to protect the nations chemical plants from an attack. Lawmakers should stop the Homeland Security Department from adopting new regulations that would block state and local governments from doing more to protect their residents and should pass a federal law with teeth.

title: Vatican City: John Paul II Pondered Quitting in 2000, Aide Says
description: As his health grew worse, Pope John Paul II discussed with top aides the possibility of resigning in 2000, Cardinal Stanislaw Dziwisz, his personal secretary for 40 years, says in a new book. Among those he consulted was Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, who became Pope Benedict XVI after John Paul died in 2005. John Paul came to the conclusion that he had to submit to Gods will, that is, to remain as long as God wanted, Cardinal Dziwisz wrote in the book, called A Life With Karol, the popes given name.

title: Florida Acts to Lower Home Insurance Cost
description: MIAMI, Jan. 22  Struggling to fulfill a campaign promise made last fall by virtually every Florida lawmaker, the Legislature approved a series of measures Monday that would reduce home insurance rates  modestly, for the most part  by having the state take on billions of dollars in additional insurance risk.

title: A Dose of Maturity for a California Protest
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 22  It is not every day that tree-sitters are older than the tree, but on Monday three environmental activists with a combined age of 247 climbed into an oak tree here for an hour to protest a hotly contested building plan.

title: The Mystery of the Chinese Baby Shortage
description: McLean, Va.

title: Mayors Urge Crackdown on Illegal Guns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Mayors from some of the nations largest cities gathered here today to urge Congress to crack down on the sale of illegal firearms. But their expanding coalition, led by Mayors Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston, has begun to encounter resistance among some advocates for gun owners.

title: Outsider to His Kin, but a Ghost No More
description: Their flight from Los Angeles had arrived nearly three hours late, but travel fatigue couldnt keep Maria Ramirez-Miller, her six daughters and a granddaughter from scampering out of their Manhattan hotel rooms and onto West 53rd Street on Friday around midnight.

title: Europe Encouraging Clean Energy Industry
description: PARIS  The cloudy Welsh coast may seem an odd choice for making solar panels, especially for a bigwig like Robert M. Hertzberg, a Californian who has hobnobbed with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger. But a commitment by European governments to helping out clean energy entrepreneurs is creating a more welcoming environment than America, where erratic support, a lackluster market for taking companies public, along with more onerous financial rules, have given pause to some start-ups and investors.

title: REIT to Consider Another Takeover Bid
description: Equity Office Properties, which agreed in November to be bought by a private equity company, the Blackstone Group, for $36 billion, including debt, said yesterday that it would begin discussions with a rival group that has offered to top that price.

title: Bush Offers Broad Goals  for Last 2 Years
