description: Two excessively lenient court decisions have allowed the manufacturers of brand-name drugs to resume the underhanded practice of paying generic competitors to keep their drugs off the market. It is a costly legal loophole that needs to be plugged by Congressional legislation.

title: A Call for $1 Billion to Cut City Class Size
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23  The head of New York Citys teachers union implored state lawmakers on Tuesday to reserve at least $1 billion of new state education spending to reduce class sizes.

title: Poles and Czechs to Talk With U.S. About Missile Defense System
description: The United States will start formal negotiations this year with Poland and the Czech Republic on deploying ground-based antimissile defense systems in the countries, government officials said. The decision was made despite weak public support in each country and strong opposition from Russia. The United States says the system is intended as protection against a possible attack from the Middle East, not Russia.

title: Ryszard Kapuscinski, Polish Writer of Shimmering Allegories and News, Dies at 74
description: Ryszard Kapuscinski, a globe-trotting journalist from Poland whose writing, often tinged with magical realism, brought him critical acclaim and a wide international readership, died yesterday in Warsaw. He was 74.

title: State of the Union: Another Take
description: Randy Newman, the singer, songwriter and composer, performed this song at Carnegie Hall in 2006. It will be released soon online. This is an abridged version.

title: Sri Lanka: Report Accuses Government of Collusion in Child Soldiers
description: Human Rights Watch accused the government of colluding with Karuna, a renegade faction of the Tamil Tiger rebels, in rounding up children to fight against their former comrades. While the Tigers have long been accused of conscripting child soldiers, the rights group said the government was implicated in some of the same abuse by using the renegade group as a proxy force. The government denied both charges. Its report, based on interviews with parents and children, said that Karuna operated with impunity in government-controlled areas and that its abductions of hundreds of boys and young men were carried out in areas with a heavy military presence.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) RHINOCEROS Virtually unchanged over 25 million years, the rhinoceros once roamed the earth in millions. Today, it is one of the planets rarest animals, with three of the remaining five species headed toward extinction. This Nature special follows rangers through the savannahs of South Africa, the grasslands of India and the jungles of Indonesia to examine efforts to protect rhinos from poachers and relocate them to new habitats, and peers into a fertility lab at an American zoo to find out about attempts to breed them in captivity. It also zooms in on some startling behavior in the rhinos natural environments, including a nursery full of mothers and calves and a charge from an angry bull.

title: Williams Not Willing to Give Up Pinstripes
description: There is no spot on the Yankees roster for Bernie Williams, who is uncomfortable as a free agent after 16 seasons in New York. Williams does not want to retire, yet he does not want to leave the Yankees.

title: One Steel Cage Up, and Many More to Follow
description: It was hard to believe that the 70-foot-long steel cage lying rigidly on the ground yesterday at the World Trade Center site was about to become a 50-ton Slinky, in the words of Steven Plate, the director of priority capital programs at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Big Insurer Will Pay 640 Katrina Claims
description: In a move that is expected to jump-start rebuilding along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, State Farm Insurance said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with state officials to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to owners of homes along the coast that were wrecked by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Iraq Parliament Finds a Quorum Hard to Come By
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 23  Mahmoud al-Mashhadani, the speaker of Parliament, read a roll call of the 275 elected members with a goal of shaming the no-shows.

title: Big Question Unanswered in Scandal
description: For the fourth time in less than two years, Clarence Norman, the disgraced former head of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, sat in a courtroom yesterday, watching prospective jurors file in to sit in judgment of him.

title: A Commercial Landlords Biggest Sale May Be Itself
description: For several years, Equity Office Properties, the huge commercial portfolio assembled by the Chicago real estate magnate Samuel Zell, lagged other publicly traded office landlords.

title: Biotech Psoriasis Drugs Hit a Cost Ceiling
description: Are biotechnology companies reaching the limits of how much they can charge for their drugs? One sign of that is the sluggish sales of drugs for psoriasis.

title: On Snowbound Plains, Grim Fight to Save Calves
description: TOWNER, Colo., Jan. 17  The temperature outside was 10 degrees and falling as calf No. 207, just one hour old, lay on the floor of the warming shed, wheezing and fighting for life.

title: The State of the Union
description: The White House spin ahead of George W. Bushs seventh State of the Union address was that the president would make a bipartisan call to revive his domestic agenda with bold and innovative concepts. The problem with that was obvious last night  in six years, Mr. Bush has shown no interest in bipartisanship, and his domestic agenda was set years ago, with huge tax cuts for wealthy Americans and crippling debt for the country.

title: Two Long Island Boys Find Their Parents Shot to Death at Home
description: Two Long Island boys returning home from school yesterday discovered that their parents had been killed in what investigators believed was a double homicide, the Nassau County police said.

title: Invest in Cancer Research (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Menu
description: Whither Montrachet?

title: 60s Prejudice and Capitalism as a Big Blond Metaphor
description: Dutchman, the poet Amiri Barakas controversial 1964 race play, has always seemed an unwieldy and ineffective boxing glove jabbing at the malignancies of American capitalism, the kind of artless art James Baldwin had in mind 15 years earlier when he derisively coined the phrase protest fiction in The Partisan Review. The white person who goes to see this is supposed to leave feeling like a viper sent off to repent; the middle class African-American is meant to go home regarding any embrace of prosperity as weak, self-negating and lethal, both politically and spiritually.

title: Newark: New Buses to Be Purchased, Complete With Cameras
description: New Jersey Transit yesterday approved the purchase of 1,145 buses to replace its aging fleet over the next six years. At a cost of $409.9 million, the buses will begin to arrive later this year and be equipped with multiple closed-circuit cameras that can digitally record passengers and drivers, the agency said. The cameras are activated by the driver or in the event of an accident, and officials said the cameras would lead to increased security. Roughly 200 buses will be delivered each year, and the agency said the new fleet would be more accessible to handicapped passengers and have stricter emission standards.

title: For the Record
description: The Market Gauges chart in Business Day on Saturday for the snapshot of Schlumberger, the energy services company, provided incorrect market and financial results. The stock, trading under the ticker symbol SLB, closed at $61, not $14.98. It had a 52-week high of $74.75, not $15.37, and a 52-week low of $54, not $9.57. The price/earnings ratio was 20.27, not 35.7, and the market cap was $72.12 billion, not $3.8 billion. The 12-month E.P.S. was $3.01, not $2.56, with a yield of 1.15 percent, not 2.2 percent.

title: Minimum Wage Bill Suffers Setback in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Prospects for an increase in the minimum wage suffered a setback today in the Senate, where a move fell short, at least for now, to raise the minimum by $2.10 an hour without tax breaks for small businesses

title: Reworking the A-List
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 23  The World Economic Forum convenes its annual conference here Wednesday with the theme Shaping the Global Agenda: The Shifting Power Equation. To judge by the names on the guest list  and those not on it  the phrase aptly reflects the turnout at this high-altitude huddle.

title: The President and Moby-Dick (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 52 Mayors Unite to Curb Illegal Firearms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Mayors from some of the nations largest cities gathered on Tuesday to urge Congress to crack down on the trade of illegal firearms. But the mayors efforts, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston, generated a small protest by advocates for gun owners and dealers.

title: Blogging for Property Sales
description: Just as Web listings transformed international real estate a decade ago, new Internet tools are making even more information available  and not just from real estate agents.

title: EBay Profit Rises 24% on Strong Holiday Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24  EBay, the Internet auction giant, has scored at least a temporary victory over the mounting pressures facing its business.

title: Profit Down, Outlook Up at Yahoo
description: Yahoo closed the books on a tough year yesterday, reporting that its sales rebounded in the fourth quarter from an especially sluggish third quarter and promising investors that it would soon turn on technology that it hoped would close the widening gap with Google.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the waning reliance of presidential candidates on public financing for campaigns included an outdated reference to Michael E. Toner, who said the 2008 election will be the most expensive in American history. As of Jan. 1, Mr. Toner is a commissioner of the Federal Election Commission. He is no longer its chairman, his position in 2006.

title: Last Stalwart in Kleins Top Ranks Is Going
description: As longtime veterans of the New York City school system departed in droves in recent years, especially from the top leadership ranks where Chancellor Joel I. Klein has favored outsiders from the corporate and legal worlds, one stalwart remained in the inner circle: Rose Albanese DePinto, a lifelong city educator who for most of the 1990s was principal of William Cullen Bryant High School in Queens, Mr. Kleins alma mater.

title: Lisa E. Goldberg, 54, Foundation President, Dies
description: Lisa E. Goldberg, president of the Charles H. Revson Foundation, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 54.

title: Scientists Build Memory Chip as Small as Blood Cell
description: Scientists have built a working memory chip that is roughly the size of a white blood cell  about 1/2000th of an inch on a side.

title: Recipe: Onion Soup With Pretzel-Cheese Dumplings
description: Time: 11/2 hours, plus 1 hour's infusing

title: Strict Vegan Ethics, Frosted With Hedonism
description: ISA CHANDRA MOSKOWITZ, a vegan chef, does not particularly like to talk about tofu. Ditto seitan, tempeh and nutritional yeast.

title: Newark: Transit Officials Propose Fare Increase
description: New Jersey Transit officials yesterday proposed a 10 percent fare increase for bus and train passengers. The officials said the increase would help close a $60 million deficit in the agencys proposed $1.5 billion budget. The agencys board must first vote on the proposed increase, which would take effect in June if approved. Hearings will be held in February and March to give the public a chance to comment. The agency last raised bus and rail fares in July 2005. New Jersey Transit provides about 857,000 passenger trips each weekday on 240 bus routes, 3 light rail lines and 11 commuter rail lines, the agency said.

title: Red Storm Makes Its Last Shot Count
description: After two poor months, St. Johns has had two very good days.

title: Starstruck Mets Fan Fined for Impersonating Reporter
description: The twin passions in the life of Ryan Leli intersected last August when the San Diego Padres came to Shea Stadium to play the New York Mets.

title: The Price of Security (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Carpetbagger
description: David Carr reports on this years Oscar nominees, with reactions from many of those nominated:

title: State Leaders Ready to Merge 2 Ethics Panels
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders are expected to announce an agreement on Wednesday to combine two state commissions that look into lobbying and ethics, merging them in a bid to centralize investigations into corruption, people with knowledge of the discussions said.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Greece Seeks Cancellation of Christies Auction

title: Its a Deal: You Like Me and I Like Me Too
description: Forget about false modesty, not to mention its nonfalse counterpart. Jamie Foxx came to Madison Square Garden on Monday night to celebrate his favorite singer, his favorite actor, his favorite comedian, his favorite sex symbol and his favorite storyteller, who all happen to share his name. Near the end, Mr. Foxx morphed into Ray Charles  only to thank himself for doing such a good job playing himself in Ray.

title: At Brandeis, Carter Responds to Critics
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 23  In his first major public speech about his controversial book Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid, former President Jimmy Carter told an audience at Brandeis University on Tuesday that he stood by the book and its title, that he apologized for what he called an improper and stupid sentence in the book and that he had been disturbed by accusations that he was anti-Semitic.

title: Murdoch Said to Join Tribune Bid
description: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for the Tribune Company  Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post.

title: A State of the Union Tableau for the History Books
description: It was the annual State of the Union address, but the tableau looked more like a moment of reckoning on Judge Judy. Behind the president, the new speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, sat  and occasionally stood to clap  a mint green weathervane of the mood in the room.

title: New York Public Hospitals Fear Proposed Medicaid Changes
description: New York Citys public hospitals and clinics would lose billions of dollars over the next few years under changes President Bush proposes to make to Medicaid  far more than his plan would cost other parts of the country, according to local and state officials.

title: With DNA From Exhumed Body, Man Finally Wins Freedom
description: AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 23  Roy Brown, who spent 15 years in prison on a murder conviction and uncovered evidence while there that linked another man to the crime, was released from prison on Tuesday after DNA tests on the other mans exhumed body matched saliva on a nightshirt at the crime scene.

title: Cheesy Pasta, Redressed
description: THERE was a time when pasta dishes dressed with just cheese, cream or milk were popular, at least with me and my family, but today they seem stodgy and fat. Although these popular standbys almost always feature a strong hit of black pepper, they dont contain acidity or real spice, and seem one-dimensional despite the strong flavors. Theyre also almost always white, beige and yellow, not exactly a stunning color combination for what for us was often a weeknight main course.

title: A Case of Hearing Without Listening
description: WASHINGTON

title: Suns Work Hard to Make Their Games Look That Fun
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Playing in perpetual fast-forward, the Phoenix Suns have become the blur that cannot be beat.

title: A Relative Bargain in a Corner of the Village
description: In New York Citys sizzling commercial real estate sector, one of the rare submarkets where the statistics appear relatively weak is Hudson Square. In this wedge of the West Village, the office vacancy rate was 18.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006, compared with a rate of 6.7 percent for Manhattan as a whole, according to figures compiled by Cushman & Wakefield.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 12 about the producer and writer Steve Krantz misspelled the surname of his surviving sister. She is Sunny Onish, not Ornish.

title: 8 Arrested in 1971 Killing of San Francisco Police Officer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23  Eight men, including seven described as members of the radical Black Liberation Army, were arrested on Tuesday on charges of murdering a police officer here in 1971 and waging a violent five-year battle against the police and federal authorities.

title: After Getting Family Out of Shelter, Mother Has a New Challenge: Paying the Rent
description: In March, necessity moved Carmen Laureano and her two daughters from Florida to New York City.

title: Follow the Money All the Way to the Kitchen
description: IM in Utah, freezing, the chef Michelle Bernstein said over her cellphone.

title: Corrections
description: The DealBook column on Jan. 14 in Sunday Business, about what some chief executives say during takeover battles, referred incompletely to the position of Delta Air Lines and its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, on merger proposals. As the column noted, Delta has rejected a takeover offer from US Airways and says that it wants to come out of bankruptcy as an independent airline. Yet it has also been privately talking with Northwest Airlines. While Mr. Grinstein had not publicly commented on reports of the talks with Northwest until yesterday, he had indeed said that Delta had a fiduciary duty to consider all alternatives, including mergers. (Go to Article)

title: Martin Luther Al-King?
description: Its hard to know whats more disturbing: the barbaric sectarian murders by Sunnis and Shiites in Iraq, or the deafening silence with which these mass murders are received in the Muslim world. How could it be that Danish cartoons of Muhammad led to mass violent protests, while unspeakable violence by Muslims against Muslims in Iraq every day evokes about as much reaction in the Arab-Muslim world as the weather report? Where is the Muslim Martin Luther King? Where is the Million Muslim March under the banner: No Shiites, No Sunnis: We are all children of the Prophet Muhammad.

title: For N.H.L.s Top TV Producer, Big Picture, Small Screen
description: John Shannon is watching.

title: Smokers Welcome: Try This at Home
description: WINTER does strange things to grill lovers cooped up in city kitchens. They start daydreaming about smoldering hardwood.

title: A World Champion, Meissner Now Seeks National Title
description: In some ways, the United States Figure Skating Championships seem to be in a full post-Olympic-year swoon.

title: Man Convicted in Police Killings Offers Apology
description: A man who was convicted of killing two undercover detectives read an apology today in the sentencing phase of his trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: A Healthy, Well-Regulated Wall Street
description: A healthy financial sector is crucial to the economic well-being of this country and to New York City in particular. And it is true that Wall Street is facing ever stiffer competition from financial markets like Londons and Hong Kongs. But beware of the doomsayers who argue that American markets are in free fall and  not incidentally  contend that looser regulations are the only way to save them.

title: In Kiffin, Raiders Are Putting Young Face in Tough Job
description: At 3 months old, Pressley Kiffin already looks to be in the market for silver makeup, metal spikes and a Darth Vader mask.

title: In Venezuela, Chavismo Is Dissected by Fans and Foes
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  You and I know that, as some people say, Im only a lieutenant colonel, Im not a summa cum laude doctor, President Hugo Chvez casually told a few million viewers of his Sunday talk show, Hello President. I modestly contribute a few ideas.

title: Correction: An Italian Spot, Larded With Drive
description: A review last Wednesday of the restaurant Porchetta in Brooklyn misstated an ingredient in a chicken dish. They are cannellini beans, not cannelloni beans.

title: In Address, Bush Insists U.S. Must Not Fail in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Bush tried to resuscitate his ailing presidency Tuesday night, using his State of the Union address to present a modest agenda of energy and health care proposals while warning an increasingly assertive Congress against undercutting his new Iraq strategy.

title: Robinsons Relevance Spans the Decades
description: Since it is still football season, the eye could not help but notice a fleet, powerful running back from U.C.L.A. flickering on the video screen, accelerating down the left sideline and then instinctively veering back toward the middle, right past three hapless defenders rushing the wrong way.

title: The Oscar Nominees
description: BEST PICTURE

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup last Wednesday about reaction to the star player David Beckhams decision to leave Real Madrid for the Los Angeles Galaxy misstated the given name of Real Madrids president. He is Ramn Caldern, not Ral.

title: E. Howard Hunt, Agent Who Organized Botched Watergate Break-In, Dies at 88
description: E. Howard Hunt, a cold warrior for the Central Intelligence Agency who left the spy service in disillusionment, joined the Nixon White House as a secret agent and bungled the break-in at the Watergate that brought the president down in disgrace, died Tuesday in Miami. He was 88.

title: Move Over Silicon Valley, Here Come European Start-Ups
description: MUNICH, Jan. 23  A technology and media conference being held here this week provided ample evidence that Silicon Valleys dominance of Internet-style technology innovation is waning.

title: In Pittsburgh, a Music Director to Replace Three Conductors
description: Two seasons ago the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra announced it was moving in a bold new direction by hiring three conductors, rather than following the lone music director model that dominates American orchestras.

title: Nepal: U.N. Creates New Political Mission
description: The United Nations Security Council voted to set up a mission to oversee a disarmament and cease-fire accord between the government and former Maoist rebels and plan elections of a constitutional assembly in June. The vote creates a force of military monitors, police and civil administration teams and poll watchers, which was requested by each sides and will last a year.

title: Senators Say Resolutions on Troop Plan Should Merge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Senate critics of President Bushs troop buildup in Iraq suggested Tuesday that competing resolutions opposing the plan should be merged in an effort to attract the largest bloc of senators in a strong statement of Congressional dissent.

title: Fresh Faces Give U.S. Team a Boost and a Win
description: The youth of America served Bob Bradley well.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential candidacy misstated the name of the university whose president, former Senator Bob Kerrey, commented on campaign donors. It is the New School, not the New School University.

title: Youth to Be in Spotlight at N.H.L. All-Star Game
description: DALLAS, Jan. 23  The National Hockey League trotted out Oscar-style surroundings for its first All-Star Game festivities in three years, with a red carpet, paparazzi, fans clamoring for autographs behind barricades, a television interviewer, cheerleader escorts and an honor guard tapping hockey sticks on the cold cement in salute.

title: Israeli Prime Minister Urges President to Resign
description: HERZLIYA, Israel, Jan. 24  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert called this evening for President Moshe Katsav to resign after the Israeli attorney general announced his intention to indict Mr. Katsav on criminal charges including rape, abuse of power, obstruction of justice, fraud, sexual harassment and breach of trust.

title: China: One-Child Policy Spurred Gender Gap
description: Chinas top population official said that a worsening gender imbalance had been complicated by population control efforts and that it would take 15 years to redress. The official, Zhang Weiqing, head of the National Population and Family Planning Commission, said 118 boys were born for every 100 girls in China in 2005, largely because of a preference for male offspring, which has driven many families to abort female fetuses under the one-child policy.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,023 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Ethiopian Forces Start Leaving Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 23  The Ethiopian troops who helped install Somalias fledging government in Mogadishu, its capital, began to pull out Tuesday, officials from each country said.

title: Around the Clock, Beethoven Magnified
description: Never has listening to the Ninth Symphony of Beethoven required so much attention.

title: For the Record
description: A Classical Music entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure incorrectly described Decasia, being performed Thursday through Saturday at Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts. The concert consists of a score by Michael Gordon and a film by Bill Morrison, not a video. The entry also omitted information about advance tickets. They are available only through ticketmania.com, not at the center.

title: Nymex Abandoning Plans for British Futures Market
description: LONDON, Jan. 23  Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a lonely champion of open-outcry trading, is cutting its last ties to an ill-fated plan to set up a trading floor in Britain.

title: E-ZPass for Passports? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor and Lawmakers Offer Ethics Bill
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders announced a package of sweeping changes to existing ethics policies, but they were greeted coolly by civic groups who have long pushed for such changes.

title: Contributor to Gossip Column Wont Be Charged
description: Federal prosecutors have decided not to file charges against a former freelance contributor to The New York Posts Page Six gossip column after an investigation into whether he had demanded payments for favorable coverage, a lawyer for the contributor said yesterday.

title: Gimme an Oil Change and a Tankful of Ribs
description: TO get to Mo Gridders BBQ, go to the Bronx, then head to Hunts Point Avenue. Drive east under the Bruckner, through the more residential part of Hunts Point, where I spied a stroller tangled in barbed wire atop a rusted fence, where tied-together sneakers hung slung over tree branches overhead and where a wizened, weathered Chihuahua, loitering outside a bodega, eyed passers-by with suspicion.

title: A Promise on Immigration Now a Problem for Spitzer
description: In his campaign for governor, Eliot Spitzer repeatedly expressed support for the licensing of all New York drivers regardless of their immigration status. Now expectations are running high among those urging the governor to change policies that deny licenses to 250,000 drivers in the state, most because they cannot prove they are legal immigrants.

title: Kerry Bows Out of 2008 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who narrowly lost the presidency to George Bush in 2004, announced today that he would not proceed with a second bid for the White House because he preferred to use his position in the new Senate majority to press for an end to American involvement in Iraq.

title: Queens: 2 Dead, and Murder-Suicide Is Suspected
description: A 30-year-old man and his 21-year-old female companion were found fatally shot yesterday in an apartment in Sunnyside. The police believe the man shot the woman before turning a gun on himself. The womans mother, who lived with her daughter in the apartment on 49th Street, discovered the two shot in the head about 7 p.m. A .22-caliber gun was found near the man, whose name was not immediately released pending family notification, the police said. The woman, Gabriella Alcivir, had requested a restraining order against the man after she said he assaulted her in September, a law enforcement official said. But the two had since reconciled, the official said.

title: Pucker Up and Smile: A Bottle Full of Surprises
description: Here is a taste of sunshine just when you need it. The kitchen at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), is preparing preserved lemons, but with a bright, palate-pleasing departure from the salt-cured Moroccan recipe. It uses Meyer lemons, which are sweeter than regular lemons, and cures them not just with salt but also with a touch of sugar, then bathes them in olive oil.

title: Bush Revives Some Past Proposals and Offers a New Initiative on Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Bush delivered a domestic agenda to Congressional Democrats on Tuesday that was, in large part, modest and a reiteration of past proposals. Where he did break ground  on health care  his initiative was quickly dismissed by leading Democrats and seemed unlikely to form the basis of bipartisan action.

title: Tennessee Court Orders Return of Girl, 7, to Biological Parents
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 23  Almost eight years after a Chinese couple living in Memphis placed their daughter into what they thought was temporary foster care, the Tennessee Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered that she be returned to her biological parents.

title: As Her World Turns, Lonelygirl15 Seeks New Thrills
description: Lonelygirl15 wants a career. Shes considering becoming a forest ranger but lacks the stomach for herd-thinning. Teaching aerobics is another option, but shes worried shes too smart for that.

title: Dedication to Douglass
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Personal Shopper
description: The most ordinary household objects  even drawer pulls or measuring cups  can seem exotic when they are purchased in a foreign marketplace.

title: Currents
description: Getting the makeup table ready for its close-up, home and garden supplies, carefully pruned and more.

title: New In the Loo
description: New high-end urinals.

title: Holocaust Denier Deniers
description: More than 100 Iranian artists and intellectuals signed a statement condemning a Holocaust conference, largely given over to Holocaust deniers, that was sponsored by the Iranian government in Tehran in December. The statement, which appears in the forthcoming issue of The New York Review of Books and on its Web site (nybooks.com), begins by acknowledging our diverse views on the Israeli-Palestinian question. It condemns the conferences attempt to falsify history and pays homage to the memory of the millions of Jewish and non-Jewish victims of the Holocaust, as well as other victims of crimes against humanity across the world. Azar Nafisi, the author of Reading Lolita in Tehran, who helped to create the statement with Roya and Ladan Boroumand, the founders of a human-rights group in Iran, said in a telephone interview that many people could not voice their objections to the conference inside Iran for fear of reprisals, but that we felt that as Iranians, we should make a statement that the conference should not come out in our names.

title: Physical Culture
description: Gear test with Martinique Davis and Erik Aura, ski patrollers.

title: Global Warming? Whatever.
description: Speaking of climate change  and at this years World Economic Forum, they are  the springlike weather in Davos took a wintery turn as the conference began, as The New York Timess Mark Landler told us in this update:

title: Profit Down, Outlook Up at Yahoo
description: Yahoo closed the books on a tough year Tuesday, reporting that its sales rebounded in the fourth quarter from an especially sluggish third quarter and promising investors that it would soon turn on technology that it hoped would close the widening gap with Google.

title: Is Silicon Valleys Dominance Fading?
description: With New Yorks dominance as the worlds financial center being threatened by the likes of London and Hong Kong, some are beginning to wonder if Silicon Valley is next on the hit-list of American corporate mainstays. A technology and media conference being held in Munich this week provided ample evidence that Silicon Valleys dominance of Internet-style technology innovation is waning, according to The New York Times. The gathering, Digital Life Design, has become a showcase for a range of European entrepreneurs who have taken the start-up culture pioneered in Silicon Valley as a template and are successfully transplanting it across the Atlantic.

title: Bank of America Tones Down Deposit Cap Stance
description: Bank of Americas chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Tuesday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions. Just weeks after agreeing to initiate discussions with lawmakers to raise the possibility of lifting the 10 percent federal deposit cap, Kenneth D. Lewis told The New York Times that he had told bank representatives to back off from those plans.

title: Nymex Abandoning Plans for British Futures Market
description: Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a lonely champion of open-outcry trading, is cutting its last ties to an ill-fated plan to set up a trading floor in Britain. The commodities market has quietly applied for derecognition of exchange with British regulators, traders in London said.

title: Kerr-McGee Is Found Liable in Lawsuit Over Oil Royalties
description: A federal jury in Denver agreed Tuesday with a former top auditor for the Interior Department that Kerr-McGee had cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties on oil it produced in publicly owned coastal waters. The decision, reached by the jury after deliberations of about four hours, is a vindication for the auditor, Bobby L. Maxwell. He became a whistle-blower and sued Kerr-McGee as a private citizen after top officials at the Interior Department ordered him to drop his audit findings.

title: Sam Zells I-Told-You-So Moment
description: The battle over Equity Office Properties is sweet vindication for its founder, Samuel Zell, who has long argued that Wall Street has not given his company the respect it deserved. Many analysts have been scornful, or at best skeptical, of the Chicago real estate magnates strategy of creating a national brand of office buildings scattered among 37 metropolitan areas. But the bidding war by Vornado Realty Trust and the acquisition-hungry private equity firm Blackstone Group seems to be showing them up.

title: Man Drops Hostile Bid for Scania, Offering Honey Instead
description: Man dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid for the Swedish truck maker Scania after opposition emerged from Volkswagen, Scanias largest shareholder, and will seek a friendly merger instead. Man, Volkswagen and Scania see the industrial logic behind a combination of the three businesses, but such a combination is not possible under the existing offer, Man said.

title: The Davos Quiz
description: Whether you have followed World Economic Forum since it began in 1971 (as the Davos Symposium) or tuned in more recently (maybe the celebrity-focused Forum panel called Star Power and Social Change piqued your interest), we encourage Davos Diary readers to try their hand at our Davos trivia quiz. Theres no prize for getting all five questions right, other than a virtual pat on the back from the Davos Diary crew.

title: Warner and Sony Back Asian Music Venture
description: The Warner Music Group and Sony BMG have signed a deal to develop technology for distributing music downloads and multimedia entertainment to wireless customers throughout China and other Asia-Pacific markets. The two music companies are investing an undisclosed amount in Access China Media Solutions, a partnership created by Tokyo-based Access and Melodeo of Seattle. Western companies looking to enter Chinas music market have had to navigate piracy-laden territory and the deal represents the music majors efforts to encourage the growth a legitimate music business.

title: Broadcom Faults Chief in Options-Backdating Scandal
description: Broadcom said Henry T. Nicholas III, its co-founder and former chief executive, bore significant responsibility for improperly backdated stock options that led it to disclose $2.2 billion in unreported expenses on Tuesday. The computer-chip maker restated earnings to take the huge noncash charge, the largest reported so far by any of the nearly 200 companies caught up in the scandal over manipulating the timing of option grants.

title: Eisner and Wenner Team up for Celebrity TV
description: Michael Eisner and Jann Wenner, who once joined forces to save a celebrity magazine, are about to reunite in the world of Internet video. Wenner Media and Veoh Networks announced a partnership Monday between Usmagazine.com, the Web site for Wenners Us Weekly, and Veoh.com, a video-sharing Web site and a competitor of YouTube.com, to create a celebrity entertainment channel on Veoh. Mr. Wenner leads the privately owned Wenner Media, while Mr. Eisner, the former chief executive of Walt Disney, is a major investor in Veoh and brokered the deal.

title: Internet Capital Faces Battle With Hedge Fund
description: Internet Capital Group, whose market value eclipsed that of General Motors during the dot-com boom, may face a proxy fight with an activist hedge fund that is taking issue with companys management. Mason Capital Management, a New York-based hedge fund, said it had increased its stake to 9.5 percent from 8 percent and might seek board seats at Internet Capital.

title: College Students Get the I-Banking Pitch
description: For undergraduates majoring in business, intersession  the time after January exams, but before the commence of the second semester  is apparently not the hibernating, beer-guzzling extravaganza that their less-finance minded peers appear to be enjoying. At least some of the college students gearing up for a career in banking use the vacation to get a head start on the competitive summer internship process with a whirlwind tour of some of New Yorks most prestigious investment banks, according to BusinessWeek, which sent a reporter along with the students to check out the pitches the banks are giving. Advil, it seems, is a necessary component.

title: Wrigleys Doubles Its Pleasure With a Chocolate Buy
description: Wm. Wrigley Jr., the worlds largest chewing-gum maker, agreed to buy 80 percent of Russias A. Korkunov for $300 million in its first acquisition of a chocolate company. Closely held A. Korkunov, which was founded in 1999 by a pair of entrepreneurs, makes bonbons and chocolate bars and is Russias seventh-biggest chocolate maker. It had 2006 sales of $100 million, Chicago-based Wrigley said.

title: American Airlines Parent to Raise $500 Million in Share Sale
description: AMR plans to issue and sell 13 million shares of stock, an offering that would bring the parent of American Airlines about $500 million based on its offering price Tuesday of $38.70 a share.The company plans to use some of the proceeds to help pay off debt. Underwriters Credit Suisse, UBS and Merrill Lynch will also have a 30-day option to purchase an additional 1.95 million shares to cover any overallotments.

title: Yankee Candle Shareholders Say Yes to a Buyout
description: Madison Dearborn Partners $1.4 billion buyout of Yankee Candle moved one step closer to completion Tuesday after Yankee stockholders formally voted to accept the private equity firms all-cash $34.75-a-share proposal.

title: Microsoft Caught Trying to Buy Wikipedia Tweaks
description: Microsoft has apparently run afoul of the editors of the communal online reference Wikipeda, the peoples encyclopedia where anyone can edit entries on any topic, but where the overall integrity of the site is policed by an army of volunteer overseers who attempt to weed out destructive, trivial and agenda-driven entries and changes.

title: Black and Co-Defendants to Be Tried Together
description: Conrad Black will be tried along with co-defendants when his criminal trial begins in Chicago next month, and appropriate instructions will be given to the jury to avoid spill-over guilt, the judge presiding over the case has ruled. Judge Amy St. Eve said that because the counts are properly joined and because defendants have failed to establish any prejudice that would require severance, the court denies their respective motions to sever.

title: Kraft Serves Up Cream of Wheat to B&G
description: Kraft Foods said Tuesday it would sell its hot cereal business, including the popular Cream of Wheat products, to a subsidiary of B&G Foods for $200 million. Our decision to sell Cream of Wheat is part of a broader effort at Kraft to focus our portfolio, Rick Searer, president of Krafts North America commercial segment, said in a statement.

title: Williams-Sonoma Denies Hiring Goldman to Explore Options
description: Williams-Sonoma, the owner of kitchenware stores and the Pottery Barn home decor retail chain, denied Tuesday it had hired Goldman Sachs or any other investment bank to explore strategic options, calling it an absolutely incorrect rumor. Williams-Sonoma, whose shares rose more than 3 percent in after-hours trading following a Reuters report that the company had hired the investment bank, said in a statement it generally does not comment on market speculation, but it felt compelled to do so in this case because this rumor is absolutely incorrect.

title: Newbridge to Take Controlling Stake in Taiwan Insurance Firm
description: The buyout firm Newbridge Capital agreed to take control of Union Insurance of Taiwan, part of the troubled Rebar Asia Pacific Group, for $100 million, Union Insurance said. Union will use the money to increase its capital, and Newbridge, which will receive at least 50 percent of the companys stock in exchange, would become its controlling shareholder after the deal, Union Insurance said.

title: New York and Tokyo Exchanges Said to Be Near Deal
description: The Tokyo and New York stock exchanges are in the final stages of alliance talks and may come to an agreement as soon as the end of the month, the head of the Tokyo exchange told The Wall Street Journal. Taizo Nishimuro, president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, said the two exchanges may make an announcement on their tie-up details after a planned two-day trip to New York starting next Tuesday.

title: Goldman and Morgan Eye Dominion Bid, Report Says
description: The investing arms of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are working on a $15 billion private-equity play for the oil-and-gas assets of the utility company Dominion Resources, The Wall Street Journal reported. Goldman and Morgan are said to be part of a consortium that includes the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, Warburg Pincus, First Reserve and the Carlyle Group and its affiliate Riverstone Holdings. The Journal said that it may end up bidding against a rival consortium, made up of Blackstone Group, Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which is also exploring an offer.

title: New York Observer Owner Mulls New Jersey Paper
description: The New York Observers owner, Jared Kushner, could be just weeks away from making a decision about bankrolling a free weekly newspaper in New Jersey. A final decision will be made by the end of February or early March, Mr. Kushners spokesman, Howard Rubenstein, told The New York Post, adding that Mr. Kushner has been encouraged by the initial reaction to the proposed paper.

title: Times Shareholder Unhappy Over Vote Rebuff
description: The New York Times Company shareholder Morgan Stanley Investment Management, which has been pushing for changes in the voting structure of the Times, said the publisher rebuffed its effort to let investors vote on a proposal to scrap rules that cement family control of the company. Morgan Stanley Investment Management, owner of more than 10 million Times shares, said in a letter to the board that a vote would have let investors express their views on the companys performance and governance.

title: Will Murdoch Breathe Life into Tribune Auction?
description: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for Tribune, Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post. Mr. Murdochs goal, according to The New York Times, is to gain a stake in Newsday, the Long Island newspaper in Melville that is owned by Tribune, so that he can combine its back-office functions with those of the money losing Post as a way to cut costs.

title: Owner of Lavalife Said to Seek Buyer
description: Vertrue, which runs the matchmaking Web site Lavalife, has hired an investment bank, Jefferies Broadview, to help sell the company, The New York Post reported, citing sources close to the deal it did not identify.

title: We Have a Winner
description: Thanks for your patience as I procrastinated in choosing a winner. Now all of you know why Im in the newspaper business. Without deadlines, Im convinced I would never leave my couch. (If youre about to blow deadline at a newspaper, you get yelled at, and that somehow does the trick.)

title: Giuliani Is Expected to Sell His Investment Bank
description: the former Mayor of New York Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently taken steps to sell the biggest division of his consulting business as he considers running for the presidency, according to a person with detailed knowledge of the firms plans. The sale of the division, Giuliani Capital Advisors, a boutique investment bank, is being pursued to prevent its clients activities from being used against Mr. Giuliani in a heated political campaign, said that person, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.

title: Delta, US Air Executives to Testify on Airline Mergers
description: The Senate will hear testimony about the effects of potential airline mergers Wednesday morning, as the takeover feud between US Airways and Delta Air Lines comes to a possible head. Top executives of both airlines will field questions from lawmakers about US Airways unsolicited $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta  which Delta has opposed  as other players continue to try to influence the endgame.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Puts $700 Million Into Sun
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts announced a $700 million investment in Sun Microsystems, a maker of computer servers, and said it would take a seat on Suns board. The Financial Times called the investment one of the most striking deals yet in a wave of transactions that has brought private equity money into the tech industry. But a Sun executive said Tuesday that the company has no intention of going private.

title: Some Early, Smart Money?
description: And guess what? I think Letters From Iwo Jima wins this Best Picture race.  Kris Tapley at InContention, a guy who actually makes phone calls on the way to pronouncing. He reports, he decides.

title: Live from Davos: Day 2
description: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland, home of the annual conference of the World Economic Forum. Wall Street chief executives and private equity kings are here aplenty: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of J.P. Morgan Chase, Charles Prince of Citigroup, Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone Group and David Rubenstein of Carlyle Group, just to name a few. Several panels on this weeks agenda should provide some interesting grist for dealmakers, including Is Bigger Better in Private Equity? and The M&A Landscape: Developing the 2007 Heatmap.

title: A Taboo Link
description: If you thought there was something missing in the energy section of the State of the Union address, theres a new Web site to fill in the gap.

title: The  Splits
description: The Bagger remains torn between two worlds. Later on, you will see videos that make it appear that he is still at Sundance, but like all television, even Web TV, that is a lie. He stacked a few up while he was there and they will be doled out to justify his expenses.

title: Discovering Cold Fusion
description: Every once in a while here at the moveable feast that is Bagger HQ  he is currently at Le Meredien hotel in L.A., awaiting permission to stop typing  things get so quiet that the Bagger begins shouting down the blog, Haaaalooooooo. Nothing but echo. Or sure, there are a few comments here and there, but the Bagger often senses they are made out of pity, just to let him know that you are there for him, man. He sees the robust comment sections of other blogs and wonders what they have that he doesnt. He wonders what makes the noisy, exotic birds of the forest pipe up. Oh yeah, real news.

title: Davos in the Papers: Power Vacuums, C.E.O. Pay, Shrimp
description: Whos in charge here? That seems to be a question that more people are asking, on a global scale, heading into this years conference in Davos.

title: Dreams, Unfulfilled
description: The Bagger made a fool of himself bragging early on about a Dreamgirls sweep. By the time this Oscar is over, thats going to cost him some money on a bet he made with a wily industry vet. And say what you want about Nikki Finke, she serves up some mighty tasty crow.

title: Tempest in a Coffee Cup
description: A Chinese television news anchor, Rui Chenggang, has brought his campaign against the Starbucks coffee shop in Beijings Forbidden City to Davos.

title: Not Exactly a Slam Dunk, Mr. President
description: Opinionland is unimpressed with President Bushs State of the Union address. It is always tempting to take the State of the Union address seriously, begins The Los Angeles Times editorial page, before explaining why this particular address was particularly unserious.

title: Most Horrible Sound in the World
description: A professor at Britains Salford University, Trevor Cox, claims to have reached a new plateau in the understanding of human hearing and acoustics, based on a year of input from of over a million online test subjects: Vomiting is the worst sound ever.

title: Bushs Plan: A View From the 2008 Crowd
description: As the Senate Foreign Relations Committee begins considering resolutions opposing President Bushs plan to increase troop levels in Iraq by 21,500, many of the potential 2008 presidential contenders have weighed in with their own positions. At this juncture, heres how they stand:

title: Webbs Winning Reply
description: After turning their collective thumb down for President Bushs performance at the State of the Union, the nations political-theater critics give an approving thumbs-up, way up to the Democratic response delivered by Virginias new senator, James Webb. The New Republics Michael Crowley says it was the best Democratic speech of the past two and a half years. That response could do for Webb something akin to what Barack Obamas 2004 convention speech did for the Illinois senator, Crowley writes at The Plank. Maybe not on quite the same scale. But I cant think of another Democratic speech since Obamas that was half as good.

title: Ugly Bears and Bulls
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Can the Goldilocks Economy  one that is not too hot and not too cold  endure? And can any literary allusion be stretched any further?

title: Sabadell of Spain Buys a Florida Bank for $175 Million
description: Banco Sabadell of Spain said on Wednesday it had agreed to buy TransAtlantic Bank if Florida for $175 million, following other Spanish banks already in the United States.

title: The War at Home: A Disagreement Over How to Agree to Disagree
description: Right now, there are two competing Senate resolutions expressing disapproval of President Bushs new Iraq strategy to send more troops to Baghdad. Sponsors of the original bill are hoping to merge the two to present a united front against the president. But sponsors of the newer, milder bill, including Senator John Warner, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, are saying not so fast.

title: War at Home: Senate Begins Iraq Debate
description: Keep an eye on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today  the White House surely is  as the first Congressional resolution on President Bushs Iraq policy takes shape.

title: Senator Clinton: I Know What It Takes to Run The Country
description: It is Day 5 of her presidential campaign, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has shown near-total poise and confidence in public thus far, with nary an uncertain note about pursuing the most powerful job in the world.

title: Hail to the Chef
description: The restaurant Alain Ducasse at the Essex House isnt around anymore, but if you went before it closed at the turn of the year, you may remember the following details:

title: A (Nearly) Bear-Free Zone
description: Practitioners of the dismal science were anything but on Wednesday, as several prominent economists offered their outlooks in a Davos session called Update 2007: The Global Economy. As The New York Timess Floyd Norris told us, even the most pessimistic member of the panel expressed only mild concern about the possibility of a worldwide economic downturn.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardts Jan. 24 column on the economics of illness prevention:

title: A Graceful John Cusack
description: The Carpetbagger talks with John Cusack at the Sundance Film Festival about his new film, "Grace is Gone."

title: State of the Union Lullaby
description: Bloggers left and right are debating whether Sen. John McCain, the maverick Republican from Arizona and 2008 presidential hopeful, was nodding off during the Presidents State of the Union address last night, or merely perusing papers in his lap  a copy of the speech, perhaps.

title: Full Nelson
description: Ryan Gosling, whose extraordinary portrayal, in Half Nelson, of an idealistic school teacher who is also a crack addict earned a best actor nomination, said by telephone that his family was over the moon.

title: Solving a Video Chat Problem
description: So many products that I review fall into the category of, Solutions to problems nobody really has, that its a delight to find something that solves a real problem thats been driving a lot of people crazy.

title: New York Senators and the White House
description: Heres a history lesson  with help from an attentive reader who is a fan of New York political trivia.

title: Home Depots New C.E.O. to Receive $8.9 Million
description: Home Depot may pay its chief executive, Frank Blake $8.9 million this year, less than the $39.7 million it paid his predecessor, Robert Nardelli, who was ousted this month amid criticism of his compensation. Mr. Blake, who took over Jan. 2, received a base salary of $975,000. He will get the rest if he meets the boards profit and stock performance goals, the company said on Wednesday.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: New Hampshire vs. the Democratic Party
description: Another showdown is brewing. This time, its between the Democratic National Committee and the whole state of New Hampshire.

title: Obamas Religion and Schooling
description: For the past several days, charges and rumors  which appear to have been debunked  have been flying around that Senator Barack Obama attended a radical Muslim school as a child in Indonesia.

title: While the Senator Dozed
description: John McCain is a very dignified sleeper. Hes one of those who can probably stay upright, mouth in a neat, thin line, while in an airplane seat. And even wake refreshed. Is this a POW thing? Or a Senate thing?

title: From Tony Blair to Bill Gates
description: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin reports from the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Renting in Paradise
description: Weve had friends who rented a house in Cape Cod that was advertised as steps to the beach. They discovered that forced march to the beach would have been more accurate. (Although, technically, 4,000 steps does qualify as steps.)

title: Law-Firm Salary Watch: Who Else Will Go Higher?
description: Once again, the top New York law firms are leapfrogging each other to recruit talent by raising salary offers for first-year associates. The latest bump-up has attracted a lot of attention in legal circles, and raised some questions as well. For example: Will California firms follow? And what about the New York offices of California-based firms? Some of them are expected to come up with the extra cash  particularly the ones that consider themselves competitors with top firms either nationally or in New York.

title: The State of the Presidency
description: Some of the countrys best political minds have put the State of the Union speech on the couch for a probing analysis.The Caucus Question of the Day: Based on last nights address, whats your diagnosis of the Bush presidency? Let us know in the comments section below, and if you have a prescription, wed be especially interested in that, too.

title: 2008: Kerry Not Running
description: In these days when everyone and their brother seems to be running for president, someone today decided that he was not: Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who lost to President Bush in 2004.

title: Tech Companies and Global Rights: Cisco Responds
description: We have an update on our post last week about a union of technology companies, academics and human rights groups seeking to develop a set of principles for Western businesses operating in countries where it has proven all too easy for them to become  or at least appear to become  accomplices to regimes that repress free speech, privacy and other basic rights.

title: Edwards Appeals to Congress With Ad
description: John Edwards may have left Congress, but he doesnt necessarily want Congress to forget about him.

title: Ethics Day in Albany
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the legislative leaders rolled out their ethics reform plan at a press conference this morning to something of a mixed response from civic groups who have long pushed for change.

title: Valleywag: Steve Jobs Is in Jeopardy
description: Steve Jobs may have briefly distracted everyone from the options-backdating scandal at Apple by waving the iPhone around at MacWorld, but Valleywag is offering what it calls a reality check, in which it lists five reasons it thinks that Mr. Jobs is in jeopardy, more serious than has been acknowledged. Others have made similar warnings, but Valleywags comes one day after Bloomberg News reported that investigators from both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department questioned Mr. Jobs last week.

title: After A.I., Tune In to A.C.!
description: Nick is going to be on CNNs Anderson Cooper 360 Wednesday at 10 p.m. Eastern. The story is about Nicks recent trip to Cambodia and his search for Srey Mom, a teenage .

title: Superpowers and Blogger Power
description: This years overarching theme at Davos  the shifting power equation  apparently means many things to the throngs gathered here. For some, it crystallized a growing concern that established institutions are losing power. Rogue states and nonstate actors threaten disorder on the global stage, which could take the form of weapons proliferation, terrorism or the spread of AIDS and other deadly diseases. These threats create an environment in which the things we treasure cannot prosper, Richard N. Haas, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, said in a panel Wednesday called The Shifting Power Equation: Geopolitics.

title: Ethics Front-Runner  and Maverick
description: Eliot Spitzer and the executive director of the Lobbying Commission, David Grandeau, have had their dust-ups in the past, and one of the big questions in the ethics overhaul announced today is the future of Mr. Grandeau.

title: War at Home: Resolution Passes Senate Panel
description: As you may have heard, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in a 12-9 vote, passed a nonbinding resolution this afternoon opposing President Bushs plan to increase troop levels in Iraq by 21,500.

title: Ad Attacks Mayors 9/11 Memorial Plan
description: The three-year battle over the arrangement of victims names at the 9/11 memorial escalated today with the release of a TV ad denouncing Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan for the arrangement of victims names at the memorial.The family groups have their own plan for the arrangement of the names that would include more information about where the victims worked and where they died, as well as the ranks of uniformed rescuers. It would also included their ages.

title: Climate Change?
description: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin offers an overview of Day 1 at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: A Buyout Consortium  for Charity
description: Buyout firms often pool their resources together to make astronomical takeover offers for companies. But now it seems many of the biggest names in private equity are forming a consortium for a different reason. Reuters reports that about 800 people from throughout finance are stopping by London Wednesday evening to raise money for the Private Equity Foundation, a new nonprofit aimed at funding charities. Among those involved are top figures from the Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital, Permira Advisors and Texas Pacific Group, many scheduled to appear at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Merkel of Germany Says Nein to Protectionism
description: Addressing an audience of world leaders and top executives, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany opened this years Davos conference with a wide-ranging speech that touched on climate change, trade talks and hedge funds, among other topics. Ms. Merkel offered up her views on globalization, which carry special resonance because Germany this year took over the rotating presidency of the Group of Eight, the leading industrialized nations, which will hold a summit meeting in June.

title: The Private Equity Squeezeout
description: The boom in private equity will end either when big deals start to collapse or when banks start putting the squeeze on loans. So goes the conventional wisdom, according to Dan Primack of PEHub. But he sees a different end game: strategic buyers will crowd buyout firms out of the market. Both stockholders and strategic buyers, Mr. Primack believes, are already starting to see private equity offers as being too low.

title: Looking for a Leader
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 24 column, Martin Luther Al-King?

title: Kerry Bows Out Officially
description: From the Senate floor, Senator John Kerry officially announced this afternoon that he would not attempt another bid for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Apologies to Murray Hill
description: Readers who responded to my post about the restaurant Babouche  and to my statement, within it, that Murray Hill is a restaurant tundra  are right: that statement was sloppy, too broad and unfair.

title: Tijuanas Police Take Up Arms  With Slingshots
description: The police in Tijuana, Mexico, having been stripped of their firearms by federal officers earlier this month, have begun patrolling the streets with slingshots in a demonstration of their plight, according to news reports earlier this week.

title: Is Income Inequality Really a Problem?
description: With Democrats back in charge of Congress, it is not surprising that we are seeing a revival of interest in the issue of income inequality. In his response to President Bushs State of the Union address on Tuesday, Senator James Webb, Democrat of Virginia, complained that corporate C.E.O. compensation has risen from 20 times that of the average worker 40 years ago to 400 times today. Such obscenely large payouts may result from nothing more than the operation of Adams Smiths invisible hand, but even many conservatives are wary of defending it that way.

title: Airline Executives Discuss Mergers at Senate Hearing
description: The fight over US Airways proposed $9.8 billion takeover of bankrupt Delta Air Lines moved on Wednesday to Capitol Hill, where lawmakers questioned the top executives of both companies about what the deal would mean for consumers. US Airways chairman, W. Douglas Parker, defended the proposed bid, telling the Senate Commerce Committee that lower costs and operational efficiencies would cut fares in dozens of new markets for passengers. But Deltas chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, said fares would not go down because the two airlines directly compete in many markets.

title: Can Polyester Save the World?
description: Clothes are a large and worsening source of the carbon emissions that contribute to global warming because of how they are both produced and cared for, concludes a new report from researchers at Cambridge University titled Well Dressed?

title: For Rent: Patakis N.H. Office
description: A Boston Globe political blog notes that former Gov. George E. Pataki quietly packed up his Manchester, N.H., political action committee office in recent months and moved it to Peekskill, where he lives. He was one of the first presidential maybes to open up a New Hampshire office to some fanfare. The office is now listed on Craigslist. [The Primary Source]

title: All-American Author and Eater
description: The author Jim Harrison talks about writing, cooking and life on the land.

title: Giants-Broncos, Super Bowl XXI
description: Welcome to the first episode of Classic Times rewind, a periodic look at how The Times has covered Super Bowls. Were starting with the 1987 Super Bowl because Bill Parcells said this week that he was through with coaching, and he might have even meant it this time. This game was his first Super Bowl triumph.

title: Planes, Strains and Automobiles
description: The Times's Micheline Maynard speaks with Ford C.E.O. Alan Mulally about how his experiences at Boeing are shaping his approach to Ford's challenges.

title: New York City School Chief Outlines a Financing Plan
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday laid out the first specifics of his ambitious plan to change the school financing system so that schools of similar sizes and demographics get roughly the same amount of city money per student.

title: Conoco Posts First Decline in Earnings Since 2002
description: ConocoPhillips posted its first profit decline in four years yesterday after fuel prices dropped.

title: Ford Loses Record $12.7 Billion in 06
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 25  The Ford Motor Company had the worst year in its history in 2006, losing $12.7 billion and suffering sharp erosion of its share of the United States auto market.

title: Plush Animals With a Key to Enter Their Web World
description: A stuffed animal doubles as the key to a Web site with Webkinz, a collectible toy that has been enjoying some playground buzz lately.

title: Putin in India: Visit Is Sign of Durability of Old Ties
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25  A new nuclear accord, booming trade and an ever closer partnership with the United States notwithstanding, the guest of honor this week at Indias Republic Day ceremony, an annual display of military pomp, will be a symbol of New Delhis newest old friend: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

title: Angry Dispute Erupts Among Iraqi Lawmakers
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 25  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis presentation of a new Baghdad security plan to the Iraqi Parliament on Thursday broke down in bitter sectarian recriminations, with Mr. Maliki threatening a Sunni Arab lawmaker with arrest and, in response, the Sunni speaker of Parliament threatening to quit.

title: AT&T Posts 17% Rise in 4th-Quarter Earnings
description: Capping a whirlwind year of merging and rebranding that has come to characterize the telecommunications business, AT&T reported a 17 percent increase in quarterly profits today driven by a sizable increase in wireless subscribers.

title: Urging Teenagers to Rein in Careless Drivers
description: DRIVING with passengers is generally safer than driving alone, at least for adults, studies have found. But if the driver and passengers are teenagers, the risk of a fatal crash rises. Add more teenagers and the risk goes up more.

title: Senate Panel Rejects Bushs Plan for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  One day after President Bush implored Congress to give his Iraq strategy a chance to succeed, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a resolution on Wednesday denouncing the plan to send more troops to Baghdad, setting up the most direct confrontation over the war since it began nearly four years ago.

title: Editors Note
description: A front-page article on Jan. 5 about the tendency of criminal suspects in New York City to give revealing and usually damaging statements to the police, despite their right to remain silent, included excerpts from the statement of James Barbour, a Broadway actor accused of sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl. According to his statement, Mr. Barbour told the police that he had lain on a bed with the girl and that they had kissed.

title: Linda Harrisons Egg and Gruyre Polenta
description: Slightly adapted from a recipe in Splendid Fare by Albert Stockli (Knopf, 1970) Time: About 35 minutes

title: Online Nordic Banking Theft Stirs Talk of Russian Hacker
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24  Word has started spreading in Sweden about the discovery last week of a $1 million online banking theft traced to a Russian hacker who goes by the sobriquet the Corpse.

title: Knicks Avoid Rout, but Not Another Loss
description: A cruel sort of familiarity came over the Knicks last night, as they stared at the wrong end of a lopsided score and watched another star player limp away. A few more games like this could destroy their morale, if not their season.

title: Donors Pledge $7.6 Billion for Lebanon
description: PARIS, Jan. 25  Led by Saudi Arabia and the United States, more than 30 countries and agencies pledged $7.6 billion in aid for Lebanon today in a bold bid to try to prop up the government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora.

title: Chinese Leader to Visit Sudan for Talks on Darfur Conflict
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24  Chinese officials announced Wednesday that President Hu Jintao would visit Sudan in early February and would seek a diplomatic solution to the conflict in the countrys western Darfur region, which the United States has described as genocide.

title: SAP Plans New Venture for Serving Small Clients
description: BERLIN, Jan. 24  SAP, the biggest maker of business management software, said Wednesday that it would invest as much as $520 million over two years on an organization aimed at smaller business clients.

title: Bloomberg and Council Change Arts Financing
description: Declaring that they had wearied of their annual dance over arts financing, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council announced yesterday that they would make more money available to arts groups, award it on a merit basis and widen a peer-review process to level the playing field.

title: Debate Renewed: Did Moscow Free Estonia or Occupy It?
description: TALLINN, Estonia, Jan. 23  The Bronze Soldier stands in a small park near Tallinns lovely Old Town, staring mournfully at the snow-covered earth, helmet in hand. An inscription in Russian and Estonian says simply, To the fallen of the Second World War. It is far less conspicuous, as war monuments go, than the furor its fate has caused.

title: Boom! And an Impersonation Requires No Punch Line
description: Frank Caliendo, a short comic impressionist with a giant head and cherubic face (his descriptions), stood in his dressing room at CBSs Late Show With David Letterman studying his lines and waiting to become John Madden.

title: Queens: Man Convicted in 2003 Killing
description: Tony Sexton, 37, of Jamaica, was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for killing Maria Rogers, 57, his fiances mother, in 2003, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Ms. Rogers objected to Mr. Sextons moving into her home, and that after an argument on Feb. 14, 2003, Mr. Sexton bludgeoned her to death. He said Mr. Sexton then put her body in a garbage bag, placed the bag in her car and abandoned the vehicle about a mile away. Mr. Sexton faces up to 27 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, Mr. Brown said.

title: Vatican City: Pope Condemns Sex in Media
description: Pope Benedict XVI condemned as a perversion any entertainment that romanticizes violence or trivializes sex, especially animated cartoons and video games meant for children. I appeal to the leaders of the media industry to educate and encourage producers to safeguard the common good, to uphold the truth, to protect human dignity and promote respect for the needs of the family, the pope wrote in a brief address on the media and children.

title: Strong Profit at Corning Lifts Shares by Nearly 11%
description: Shares of Corning, the biggest maker of glass for liquid-crystal displays, rose sharply yesterday after the company posted a fourth-quarter profit that surpassed analysts estimates.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday, about Israeli-Syrian relations, misidentified the Bush administrations label for Syria in 2002. Syria was described as a rogue state; it was not part of the original axis of evil.

title: Its Tough for the Opposition When a Player Is in the Zone
description: If you would like to start with a test, look only at the West hand in the diagramed deal and the auction. What would you lead against six hearts?

title: EBay Beats the Estimates for 4th-Quarter Earnings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24  EBay, the Internet auction giant, has scored at least a temporary victory over the mounting pressures facing its business.

title: Plain Cellphones Can Overachieve, With a Little Help
description: IF you have an ordinary cellphone  the type that you got free, or cheaply, when you signed up for service  you might envy those with phones that are also personal digital assistants, like BlackBerrys, Treos, Sidekicks and Windows smartphones.

title: Pakistani Premier Faults Afghans for Taliban Woes on Border
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 24  Pakistans prime minister, Shaukat Aziz, acknowledged Wednesday that people sympathetic to the Taliban were active in the frontier regions near the border with Afghanistan. But he insisted that the root of the problem was the Afghan governments weak authority, not Pakistani support of the Taliban.

title: More Ethics Charges Brought Against Official in Duke Case
description: The North Carolina State Bar filed a second, more serious round of ethics charges yesterday against the district attorney in Durham, N.C., accusing him of systematic abuse of prosecutorial discretion in the sexual assault case against three former members of the Duke University lacrosse team.

title: Council Panel Interrogates Kelly on Police Treatment of Blacks
description: City Council members questioned Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday for more than three hours on diversity in the Police Department, standards for undercover operations and perceptions of the polices unequal treatment of black New Yorkers.

title: Pair Pleases the Crowd, but Not the Judges
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 24  After the last turn in their short program at the United States Figure Skating Championships Wednesday night, Naomi Nari Nam jumped into the arms of her pairs partner, Themi Leftheris, celebrating their program. The cheers raining down on them turned to boos when their score was finally announced.

title: A Toy That Sends Grown Men Into Orbit
description: IN the 1960s, when a toy inventor named Sol Friedman used to wake up at night with ideas that sent him running to what his family called his mad scientists lab, he could not have predicted the effect his actions would have on a generation of men.

title: Dressing Up Bryant Park
description: THIS week, just when it finally turned cold, the skating rink in Bryant Park was dismantled to make way for the tents of Fashion Week. You could almost hear the echoes of rosy-cheeked children hissing, Awww, fashionistas.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Italy Recovers Rare Marbles

title: N.F.L. and Union to Strengthen Steroid Testing
description: The National Football League and its players union said yesterday that they had agreed to strengthen the leagues testing program for performance-enhancing drugs, including increasing the number of tests and adding endurance-boosting EPO to the list of banned substances.

title: Dispute Threatens Trial of Khmer Rouge Leaders
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 25  _ The Cambodian judges were on one side and the foreign judges on the other this week, in a dispute that captures a decade of difficulties in bringing to trial the last surviving leaders of the murderous Khmer Rouge.

title: Hiking Club Spreads a Little Bit of Charlie on Every Peak
description: TUCSON, Jan. 24  Richard Kane stood on a large outcropping at Chimney Rock in the Santa Catalina Mountains northwest of here one day recently. He was holding an open prescription bottle and thinking about Charlie Whitmore, his hiking buddy who died in 2005.

title: A Halting Plea for Mercy, Heavily Edited
description: Ronell Wilson said he was sorry.

title: A Laptop Designed to Take a Licking and Keep on Ticking
description: All terrain is not usually a designation associated with things as delicate as hard drives and high-speed memory chips. Dell, however, is betting that its Latitude ATG D620  the ATG stands for All-Terrain Grade  can change that.

title: Visitors Come Calling, With Enthusiastic Friends in Tow
description: The Aspen Santa Fe Ballet usually arrives in New York with a full complement of home-base admirers, and they were out in force on Tuesday night when the company opened its third season at the Joyce Theater. Their excited adulation has a tinge of wonderment that might charm the most cynical of New York dance fans. They raise the bar, and then they jump over it, one audience member from Aspen, Colo., said of the company on Tuesday night.

title: Howard Stern Is Heard (Briefly) on Free Radio
description: Howard Stern, whose satellite radio show is typically available only to subscribers willing to pay $12.95 a month, has sworn that he will never return his morning show to the free commercial airwaves.

title: Helmut Wimmer, 80, Painter With Planetarium for a Canvas, Dies
description: Helmut K.
