Wimmer, whose vivid depictions of twirling planets, glowing comets, pulsing nebulas and space-bending black holes awed thousands of visitors craning their necks under the dome of the old Hayden Planetarium for more than 30 years, died on March 20, 2006, near his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 80.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,133,110

title: John W. Lavelle, Staten Island Assemblyman, Dies
description: John W. Lavelle, the assemblyman for the 61st District and chairman of the Democratic Party on Staten Island, died on Wednesday. He was 57.

title: Two Who Were in Foster Care Make Providing Stable Home a Priority
description: Stephanie Robinson Davis and Randy Davis are young parents just starting out. There can be a lot to learn, but in the Davises house, they already know that their children come first.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Yahoos quarterly earnings misstated the reason given for the departure of the companys chief operating officer, Daniel L. Rosensweig, which was announced last month. He resigned; he was not fired.

description: ADDENDUM APPENDED

title: A Stream of Movies, Sort of Free
description: If theres one sure thing about the future, its that it always takes longer to arrive than you think it will.

title: Smoking Ban at Casinos May Be Eased
description: Smokers will still be able to light up at Atlantic City casinos if a compromise measure introduced in the City Council last night gets final approval in two weeks.

title: McDonalds Says Latest Results Are Strongest in 30 Years
description: In the four years since McDonalds began a program to reinvent itself, the worlds largest restaurant chain has introduced several menu items, like chicken wraps, premium coffee, apple slices and Asian salads.

title: Man in Family Slain at Home Was Drug Dealer, Police Say
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 24  A man who was killed last week in his home here, along with his wife and three young sons, was a low-level crack cocaine dealer and user, state police officials said Wednesday.

title: France: Traders Fined in Bond Sale
description: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorit des Marchs Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecommunications-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.

title: Yanks Hope to Get a Jump in China
description: The Yankees are coming, the Yankees are coming. Thats what the Chinese are shouting in China today because the Yankees are heading there in their latest international exploration. Vasco da Gama and Magellan had nothing on them.

title: Britain: Economic Growth Picks Up
description: The British economy grew at the fastest rate since 2004 in the fourth quarter as the financial-services boom in London created jobs and pushed house prices to a record. Gross domestic product increased 0.8 percent from the previous three months, the most since the second quarter of 2004, the Office for National Statistics said. The annual growth rate increased to 3 percent from 2.9 percent. Accelerating growth in the economy drove inflation to the highest in 10 years in December, prompting the Bank of England to raise its benchmark rate in January.

title: Red Sox Owner Close to Deal to Join Roush Racing Team
description: CONCORD, N.C., Jan. 24  A deal that would make John Henry, the Boston Red Sox principal owner, a key investor in Roush Racing, a top Nascar team, is nearing completion.

title: Mets Reward Randolph With $5.65 Million Extension
description: There was once a time when no one wanted to hire Willie Randolph. He was interviewed 12 times for managerial openings, and 12 times he was turned down. One team, however, took a calculated chance, and now the Mets will not let Randolph go.

title: Smugglers Plot Highlights Fear Over Uranium
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Jan. 24  Last January, a Russian man with sunken cheeks and a wispy mustache crossed into Georgia and traveled to Tbilisi by car along a high mountain road. In two plastic bags in his leather jacket, Georgian authorities say, he carried 100 grams of uranium so refined that it could help fuel an atom bomb.

title: Series of Sordid Corruption Charges Nears Its Nadir in Israel
description: HERZLIYA, Israel, Jan. 24  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert called Wednesday for President Moshe Katsavs resignation, after Israels attorney general announced his intention to indict Mr. Katsav on criminal charges including rape, abuse of power, obstruction of justice, fraud, sexual harassment and breach of trust.

title: Soldier Pleads Guilty to Killing Two Unarmed Iraqis
description: FORT CAMPBELL, KY., Jan. 25 - An Army infantryman received an 18-year prison sentence today after pleading guilty to killing two unarmed Iraqis during an assault northwest of Baghdad last May.

title: Home Sales Figures Signal a Slowing Market
description: Sales of existing homes declined 0.8 percent in December, according to the National Association of Realtors, a sign of further slowing in the nations once-effervescent housing market.

title: Brooklyn: Arrest in Brooklyn Crash
description: Jiankai Huang of Alexandria, Va., was arrested yesterday after crashing his car into a pickup truck and a van and hitting three pedestrians in Brooklyn, the police said. Mr. Huang, 29, was charged with driving while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and driving with a suspended license, the police said. They said that Mr. Huang was driving east on 65th Street at 8:15 a.m. when he hit the truck, which was heading north on Fort Hamilton Parkway, and then the van, which was stopped at a red light. The three injured pedestrians, a woman of 26 and two boys, 13 and 11, were hospitalized, the police said. Mr. Huangs passenger, a 20-year-old woman, was hospitalized with head injuries, and the other drivers for evaluation, the police said.

title: Budget Office Forecasts Drop in U.S. Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office predicted on Wednesday that the federal budget deficit would shrink again this year and could actually swing into a surplus in 2012  but only if President Bushs tax cuts expire in 2010.

title: Cedar Grove: Rescue Effort Unsuccessful at House on Fire
description: A woman died in a house fire early yesterday despite her husbands efforts to save her, said Jeff Cartwright, director of the Essex County prosecutors arson task force. Prosecutors would not identify the woman, but neighbors said the single-family house at 60 Montclair Avenue belonged to Nick Fierro, 79, and his wife, Marge, 73. Mr. Cartwright said the fire was not considered suspicious. The womans husband was treated for smoke inhalation at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge and released, a spokeswoman said. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: For Nash, 3 M.V.P.s Cant Take Place of Title
description: Steve Nash wants no part of the debate. Nash, the Phoenix Suns point guard, is a top contender to win his third consecutive Most Valuable Player award, which would make him only the fourth N.B.A. player to accomplish the feat.

title: Love Is Up Against the Wall, So Now Its Time to Fight
description: Estimated Time of Arrival is not one play but five, a series of thin comic vignettes presented over the course of an economical 90 minutes that prize the sort of love consumed by its own inertia. Our sympathies are toward the couple who cant get out of the ring, the kind who break plates and scream into the night and fail to see in all their ostensible passion the dull routine to which theyve been condemned.

title: Big States Push for Earlier Vote Scrambles Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  As many as four big states  California, Florida, Illinois and New Jersey  are likely to move up their 2008 presidential primaries to early next February, further upending an already unsettled nominating process and forcing candidates of both parties to rethink their campaign strategies, party officials said Wednesday.

title: The State of the Union, and of the President (11 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Guilty Plea in Defrauding of Priests
description: Robert Riggio of Manhattan, who was charged with defrauding more than 60 priests over several years, pleaded guilty to wire fraud in Federal District Court yesterday, prosecutors said. Mr. Riggio, 60, faces up to 40 years in prison when he is sentenced in April, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said that Mr. Riggio stole more than $200,000 from 2004 to 2006 by calling priests with bogus pleas for help and requests for money. The funds often came from the priests personal savings, Mr. Garcia said. Mr. Riggio was arrested in September after he asked for money from an F.B.I. agent posing as the niece of a priest who had been defrauded, Mr. Garcia said.

title: Bush Proposes Broadening the No Child Left Behind Act
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Bush administration called on Wednesday for an array of changes to the presidents signature education law. The proposals would give local school officials new powers to override both teachers contracts and state limits on charter schools in the case of persistently failing schools.

title: Murder Victims Moved to Long Island for Safety of Suburbs
description: SYOSSET, N.Y., Jan. 24  In the 18 years since Jaspal and Geeta Singh arrived in New York from India, they prospered, had two sons and managed to join the wave of South Asians leaving behind New York Citys immigrant neighborhoods for more comfortable swaths of central Nassau County.

title: $48 Million Paid to Merrills Chief
description: Merrill Lynchs chief executive, E. Stanley ONeal, made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing .

title: Study Says Many Firms Cheat New York Workers Comp System
description: A new study estimates that employers cheat New York States workers compensation system by not paying $500 million to $1 billion a year in required insurance premiums, forcing other employers to pay higher premiums.

title: N.F.L. Reverses a Trend in Penalties
description: The number of penalty flags thrown in the N.F.L. declined 20 percent this season compared to a year ago, a drop that reversed a trend that had taken hold in recent seasons.

title: Kerry Will Not Enter Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who narrowly lost the presidency to President Bush in 2004, announced Wednesday that he would not proceed with a second bid for the White House, saying he preferred to use his position in the new Senate majority to press for an end to American involvement in Iraq.

title: Acquisitions Bolster General Dynamics
description: General Dynamics, the largest maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose on acquisitions. Sales missed analysts estimates.

title: Closing the Revolving Door
description: The United States is paying a heavy price for the mandatory sentencing fad that swept the country 30 years ago. After a tenfold increase in the nations prison population  and a corrections price tag that exceeds $60 billion a year  the states have often been forced to choose between building new prisons or new schools. Worse still, the country has created a growing felon caste, now more than 16 million strong, of felons and ex-felons, who are often driven back to prison by policies that make it impossible for them to find jobs, housing or education.

title: Once a Poor Student, Coach Is Now a Stickler for Academics
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Jan. 23  Not long ago, a freshman was kicked off the Manhattanville College mens basketball team because of poor grades. Now he is the head coach.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) FRIENDS OF GOD: A ROAD TRIP WITH ALEXANDRA PELOSI In 2000, Ms. Pelosi, a daughter of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, created Journeys With George, in which she spent 18 months on the road with George W. Bush as he campaigned for the presidency. In this new documentary, Ms. Pelosi traversed the country for a year in search of personal encounters with some influential members of the evangelical community  from Joel Osteen, the most-watched television minister in America, to Ron Luce, the founder of Battle Cry, a Christian conert tour that has drawn 2 million young people to its events. She also visited with the Rev. Ted Haggard before he stepped down as president of the National Association of Evangelicals, the largest evangelical group in the country, after accusations of buying illegal drugs from a male prostitute and paying him for sex.

title: For the High-End Bathroom, Something Unexpected
description: AMONG the features of the new 6,000-square-foot, $3 million entertainment wing in Kevin Scherers home in Plano, Tex., are two bars, a theater, a video game room, a shuffleboard table and a golf simulator that projects images of top courses onto a big screen.

title: New Offer Made for Control of Apn Media
description: An Irish media tycoon, Tony OReilly, has renewed an attempt to take complete control of APN News and Media of Australia. Mr. OReilly, who already owns 40 percent of APN, teamed his Independent News and Media, which is based in Dublin, with the Carlyle Group, the buyout group in Washington, and Providence Equity Partners, an investment firm in Providence, R.I. His group bid 3.4 billion Australian dollars ($2.65 billion) for APN. Mr. OReilly first teamed with Providence to buy the rest of the media group in October. Those talks were abandoned in November. APN owns regional newspapers in Australia and New Zealand and operates 125 radio stations in the two nations, with Clear Channel Communications.

title: Moving It All to Vista
description: Q. When the time comes, how can I move all of my bookmarks, music and other files from my old computer to a new Windows Vista PC?

title: Relatives Groups Use TV and Internet to Call for More Details With Names on 9/11 Memorial
description: Far from having been settled last month behind closed doors at the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, the three-year battle over the arrangement of victims names at the 9/11 memorial escalated yesterday to television and the Internet.

title: Childhood Poverty Is Found to Portend High Adult Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Children who grow up poor cost the economy $500 billion a year because they are less productive, earn less money, commit more crimes and have more health-related expenses, according to a study released on Wednesday.

title: Officer Charged in Car Crash That Injured Woman and Child
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24  An off-duty police officer was charged with drunken driving after critically injuring a woman and her 2-year-old child on the Pulaski Skyway, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Residential Sales: New York
description: Manhattan

title: Newark: Shooting Leaves Man Dead and Woman Hurt
description: A man was killed and a woman seriously injured yesterday afternoon in a shooting in the South Ward, the authorities said. Police officers responding to a report of shots fired around 3:15 p.m. on Shaw Avenue near Route 78 found a 23-year-old man dead near a tan sport utility vehicle, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant prosecutor with the Essex County prosecutors office. A woman nearby, who had been shot several times, was taken to University Hospital, where she was in critical condition last night. Neither was identified yesterday. The homicide was Newarks 10th this year.

title: Long on Rhetoric, Short on Sorrow
description: President Bush showed what he does well at the beginning of the State of the Union ceremony when he graciously acknowledged and introduced Nancy Pelosi as speaker of the House of Representatives. He seemed both generous and sincere, and it was the right touch for a genuinely historic moment.

title: Calendar
description: The Story of Moses

title: With Health Care Topic A, Some Sketches for a Solution
description: Start with the children and work up from there. For corporate America and Washington policy experts, that seems to be the emerging consensus about how to begin tackling the problem of the 47 million people in this country without health insurance: Start with the more than 8 million uninsured children.

title: Scientists Tie Part of Brain to Urge to Smoke
description: Scientists studying stroke patients are reporting that an injury to a specific part of the brain, near the ear, can instantly and permanently break a smoking habit, effectively erasing the most stubborn of addictions. People with the injury who stopped smoking found that their bodies, as one man put it, forgot the urge to smoke.

title: Greek Terror Group Claims It Bombed Embassy
description: ATHENS, Jan. 25  A Greek terror group claimed responsibility for the attack on the United States embassy in Athens two weeks ago, saying in a five-page proclamation published today that the attack was an act of retaliation against American military involvement in Iraq, Afghanistan, the Middle East and Somalia.

title: Mississippi Man Arrested in Killing of 2 Blacks in 64
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 24  A 71-year-old man was arrested Wednesday in Mississippi on federal kidnapping charges stemming from the 1964 killing of two black teenagers who were tied to trees, whipped and drowned.

title: Long-Lost Trove of Music Connects Brazil to Its Roots
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 24  From the mid-1930s onward, the American ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax led expeditions into the Deep South, searching for authentic blues and folk singers. Thanks to those efforts, Muddy Waters and Woody Guthrie made their first recordings and a template for American popular music was set.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about events surrounding President Bushs State of the Union speech misquoted his opening remarks. He said, And tonight I have the high privilege and distinct honor of my own as the first president to begin the State of the Union Message with these words: Madam Speaker.  He did not say, Tonight, I have the high privilege and distinct honor to begin a speech with the words Madam Speaker.  (Go to Article)

title: The Math Rookie Is a Girl, a Big Problem for the Geeks
description: Maybe there was a time when exaggerated high school-speak was amusing, but as the avalanche of awesome and totally in Victoria Martin: Math Team Queen buries you, you are hard pressed to remember when it was. The early 90s? Perhaps the 80s?

title: Sorrow and Reflection in Killers Housing Project
description: Everything feels colder here, on a forbidding patch of brick and glass on Staten Islands northeast side, just blocks from the harbor. The rest of the island, the vistas of suburban lawns and town houses, could be another planet.

title: Of Gay Sheep, Modern Science and Bad Publicity
description: Charles Roselli set out to discover what makes some sheep gay. Then the news media and the blogosphere got hold of the story.

title: China Strains to Fit Migrants Into Mainstream Classes
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24  It seemed like an ordinary day earlier this month at the Jianying Hope School for migrant children here, with fidgety students settling down in their modest classrooms as their teachers prepared for the days lessons.

title: Redesigned Toyota Pickup to Cost More Than Rivals Trucks
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24  Toyota is putting its reputation as a premium automaker to a test by pricing its redesigned pickup, the Tundra, several thousand dollars higher than comparable trucks made by General Motors and Ford.

title: Can Polyester Save the World?
description: WOKING, England

title: Rough (but Silly) Justice and Striking (Also Silly) Moves
description: When the judge in a murder case pronounces a defendant not guilty, I doubt that confetti streams from the ceiling. I also suspect that the prosecutor is rarely a foul-tempered teenager who carries a whip and curtsies when she presents compelling evidence. But if trials were as entertaining in the real world as in Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney Justice for All, it might be worth jury duty just see it all firsthand.

title: Researchers Go Molecular in Design of a Denser Chip
description: Scientists have built a memory chip that is roughly the size of a white blood cell, about one-2,000th of an inch on a side.

title: Hedge Fund Chiefs, With Cash,  Join Political Fray
description: Lisa Perry loves Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Blackstone Makes New Offer for Equity Office
description: The bidding war for Equity Office Properties Trust, one of the nations largest commercial landlords, escalated today when the Blackstone Group offered $54 a share in cash, or $38.3 billion, for all of Equity Offices stock.

title: Incomes and Inequality: What the Numbers Dont Tell Us
description: The growing inequality in wealth and income has led many people to question whether the contemporary American economy is rigged in favor of the rich. While there is little doubt that the gap between the wealthy and everybody else has widened in recent years, the situation is not as unfair as some of the numbers seem to imply.

title: Albany: New Head of Long Island Power Authority
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer appointed the Suffolk County executives chief deputy, Kevin S. Law, left, the new chairman of the Long Island Power Authority yesterday. Mr. Law succeeds Richard M. Kessel, who headed the agency under Govs. Mario M. Cuomo and George E. Pataki. Mr. Kessel is expected to take on the vacant post of chief executive officer for several months and then retire. Mr. Law is then expected to succeed him as the chief executive officer, at which point a new chairman will be appointed.

title: Bonus Pay by Medicare Lifts Quality
description: Paying a hospital to do the right thing is a lot harder than it looks.

title: Instead of Dollars, Some of the Squabbling Is Cut Out of Early Budget Negotiations
description: The annual New York City budget dance, a stylized ritual that has varied little over the past decade, took a different step forward yesterday. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in another sign of his good will toward the City Council, agreed to dedicate money to parks, child care and arts programs in the preliminary budget he plans to present today  instead of making the Council fight for those dollars as in the past.

description: Oregon

title: Siemens to Buy Software Maker
description: Siemens, the German engineering company, agreed yesterday to buy the software maker UGS for $3.5 billion, including debt, and separately announced plans to spin off its VDO automotive unit.

description: A Sarah Bernhardt Drama

title: Breakthrough for Gonzlez Means Early Exit for No. 2 Nadal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 25  Tommy Haas and Fernando Gonzlez took radically different paths to their upsets at the Australian Open on Wednesday.

title: What a View to Behold, and Its Really Something
description: YOU can see the progress of construction at the Freedom Tower.

title: First-Time All-Stars Put Their Stamp on Game
description: DALLAS, Jan. 24  Alex Ovechkin did not waste time in breaking down the race to become the National Hockey Leagues most valuable player. All he had to do was look to the seat next to him, which was occupied by Sidney Crosby.

title: Testimony by Former Cheney Aide Hurts Libby
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  A former spokeswoman for Vice President Dick Cheney gave testimony in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. today that directly contradicted Mr. Libbys version of events during a crucial period that is at the center of the perjury case against him.

title: Crochet Undergoes an Upgrade
description: DUMBO, the nickname for the neighborhood Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, sounds like an acronym made up by a developer. But theres nothing prefab or Disney-esque about the place.

title: Breaking the Clinch
description: Iraq is at the beginning of a civil war fought using the tactics of genocide, and it has all the conditions to get much worse. As a Newsweek correspondent, Christian Caryl, wrote recently from Baghdad, Whats clear is that were far closer to the beginning of this cycle of violence than to its end. As John Burns of The Times said on Charlie Rose last night, Friends of mine who are Iraqis  Shiite, Sunni, Kurd  all foresee a civil war on a scale with bloodshed that would absolutely dwarf what were seeing now.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: The Shepherd, the Sea Nymph and the Big Rock, Abridged
description: This can be short. Certainly the opera is.

title: Mayors Budget Plan Includes $2.9 Billion Surplus
description: With New York Citys treasury flush with unexpected revenue from an extraordinary surge in its real estate market, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg projected today a $2.9 billion surplus in his $60 billion budget plan, allowing him to grant $1 billion in tax cuts and set aside $1.9 billion for future expenses.

title: Several Casualties Reported in Beirut Clashes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Jan. 25  Violence erupted in Beirut today for the second time in three days, as a lunchroom altercation at a Beirut university escalated into rioting and gunfire.

title: Office Songs in the Unhip Keys of Life and Karaoke
description: If a song is popular now, dont expect to hear it on The Office until late next year.

title: Hershey Earnings Decline as Mars Cuts Into U.S. Market Share
description: The Hershey Companys fourth-quarter profit fell 9.9 percent, trailing analysts estimates, after sales at the company, the largest United States candy maker, declined for the first time in three and a half years.

title: Queens: Conviction in Police Officers Shooting
description: Lasana Philbert, 23, has been convicted in State Supreme Court of assault on a police officer for wounding Officer Christopher Wiesneski in 2005 by grabbing his gun during a struggle, causing it to fire, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. Prosecutors said that Officer Wiesneski had to retire as a result of his wound. Mr. Philbert, of Cambria Heights, faces up to 15 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, Mr. Brown said.

title: Stem Cell Research: When Does Life Begin? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mendy Samstein, 68, Dies; Championed Civil Rights
description: Mendy Samstein, who left graduate school to put himself in the forefront of the fight for black voting rights in Mississippi, enduring bombings and beatings in the crucial summer of 1964, died yesterday at his home in New Lisbon, N.Y. He was 68.

title: Returning to the Spy World to Uncover a Political Plot
description: In his first book, Overworld, Larry J. Kolb told a dizzying, spy-studded story of his lifelong adventures as the son of a senior United States intelligence official. It was an amazing account, almost too much so, filled with events far too strange for fiction. And it was packed with guest stars, from Muhammad Ali to Ronald Reagan. For a man who had lived so much of his life in the shadows, Mr. Kolb used this book to cast an improbably bright light.

title: In a New Joint U.S.-Iraqi Patrol, the Americans Go First
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 24  In the battle for Baghdad, Haifa Street has changed hands so often that it has taken on the feel of a no mans land, the deadly space between opposing trenches. On Wednesday, as American and Iraqi troops poured in, the street showed why it is such a sensitive gauge of an urban conflict marked by front lines that melt into confusion, enemies with no clear identity and allies who disappear or do not show up at all.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about events surrounding President Bushs State of the Union speech misquoted his opening remarks. He said, And tonight I have the high privilege and distinct honor of my own as the first president to begin the State of the Union Message with these words: Madam Speaker.  He did not say, Tonight, I have the high privilege and distinct honor to begin a speech with the words Madam Speaker.

title: A Dance-Party Niche in the Cruise Industry
description: Three years ago, Jason Beukema, a tour manager at a travel agency in Atlanta, thought he was just doing his friends a favor in organizing a group vacation.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,044 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Wendys Shifts Work to Three Agencies
description: Wendys International is unexpectedly changing agencies after working since August 2002 with two New York agencies that are part of the McCann Erickson Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Wendys spends about $300 million a year on local and national advertising in major media.

title: Donors Gather to Help Lebanons Government
description: PARIS, Jan. 24  After 50 days of Syrian- and Iranian-backed protests that culminated in Tuesdays daylong standoff in Beirut, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and officials from more than 30 other countries are gathering here to see if they can inject enough money into the Lebanese government to prop up the pro-Western prime minister, Fouad Siniora.

title: Jim Harrisons Mesquite Roasted Doves
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: Moment of Opportunity in Somalia
description: Thanks to an unusual and probably fleeting set of events, Somalia has a chance to return to the community of law-abiding and legitimate states. For a country that dissolved years ago into chronic clan warfare and became a way station for international terrorists, that would be an enormous gain  and an enormous gain for the rest of the world.

title: Bush Goes on the Road to Sell His Health Plan
description: LEES SUMMIT, Mo., Jan. 25  In what could be the opening salvo in a new partisan debate over his domestic agenda, President Bush urged Congress today to consider his new health care proposal and indicated he was ready for a fight.

title: Effort to Move on Minimum Wage Bill Falters in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Bloomberg)  Senate Republicans rejected an effort by Democrats to pass minimum-wage legislation without breaks for small businesses on Wednesday, setting the stage for a potential impasse with the House, where lawmakers are demanding a clean bill.

title: Ex-Officials Testify They Informed Libby of the Identity of a C.I.A. Operative
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Prosecutors in the perjury trial of the former White House aide I. Lewis Libby Jr. paraded a roster of former government officials before the jury on Wednesday to testify that they had informed him about the identity of the C.I.A. operative Valerie Wilson, contrary to Mr. Libbys claim that he had learned about her weeks later from reporters.

title: Iraqi Official Offers Terms From Militia to Avoid Fight
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 24  An Iraqi official authorized to speak on behalf of field commanders for the countrys most powerful militia has approached Western military officials and laid out a plan to avoid armed confrontation, senior Iraqi and American officials said this week.

title: At the Libby Trial, Hints of Intrigue and Betrayal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The assertion by lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. that White House aides had sacrificed him to protect Karl Rove, the senior political adviser, appears to be based primarily on Mr. Libbys own sense that the administration had failed to defend him adequately as the C.I.A. leak case unfolded.

title: Federer Overwhelms Roddick
description: MELBOURNE -- When the reinvigorated Andy Roddick stepped on court Thursday to face his longtime tormentor Roger Federer, the consensus at the Australian Open was that spectators were in for a special evening.

title: An Orchestra in Transition Tackles an Unfinished Work
description: Corporate success does not necessarily mean mutual admiration between worker and management. Some orchestras do best while actively disliking the person conducting them, but that is usually a short-term transaction. The Philadelphia Orchestra and its music director, Christoph Eschenbach, played Bruckner very well at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night with the full knowledge that Mr. Eschenbach will complete his contract next season and leave. His tenure has been too startlingly short to avoid the conclusion that players wanted him to go, and no news other than boilerplate press releases indicate that Mr. Eschenbach goes willingly.

title: George Wein Sells Company That Produces Music Festivals
description: George Wein, the producer of music festivals including the JVC-sponsored jazz festivals in New York and Paris and the Newport festivals of jazz and folk music, announced yesterday that he had sold his company, Festival Productions Inc.

title: U.S. Picks an Inauspicious Time to Restart Mideast Talks
description: HERZLIYA, Israel, Jan. 24  It would be hard to imagine a less promising moment for the United States to restart serious Palestinian-Israeli peace negotiations.

title: State Leaders Agree on Plan to Merge 2 Ethics Commissions and Tighten Lobbying Rules
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders announced a package of sweeping changes to state ethics policies on Wednesday, but the measures were greeted with a mixed response from civic groups that have long pushed for even broader changes.

title: A TV Family Bound by Blood and a Band
description: The Naked Brothers Band, an ebullient mock documentary about a kids rock band, is both a movie and a new series on Nickelodeon and a tween fantasy in which no one over 18 has much sense. The brothers have a classic bubble-gum sound, live in a very 21st-century video world and are the real-life offspring of entertainers from two television shows that had baby-boomer appeal.

title: Energy Rhetoric, and Reality
description: For six years, off and on, President Bush has been talking about the need for alternative fuels and conservation to make the country less beholden to unreliable sources of foreign oil. Yet all he has to show for it is a growing dependence on foreign oil, a growing climate problem and an increasingly cynical public. Mr. Bush talked the same game on Tuesday night, offering several impressively specific goals. But whether these new pledges turn out to be as empty as the old ones depends on his capacity for follow-through, and history is not encouraging.

title: 4th Major Hub for Air Traffic Moves Ahead
description: The plan to create a fourth major airport that could relieve crowding and delays in the metropolitan region will take a leap forward today, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Weight and Diabetes Are Focus of Health Foundation Grants
description: A health foundation created by New York State announced its first grants yesterday, devoting considerable attention to obesity and resulting problems like diabetes, and to asthma. It also addressed other ills as disparate as alcohol abuse and lack of dental care.

title: Political Meddling With Justice
description: The federal investigation into Congressional corruption is approaching a crucial deadline and potential dead end. Feb. 15 is the last day on the job for United States Attorney Carol Lam of San Diego, the inquirys dedicated prosecutor, who is being purged by the Bush administration.

title: ABC TV Star Is Seeking Counseling After Epithet
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24  Isaiah Washington, the Greys Anatomy star who twice used an anti-homosexual slur against one of that shows co-stars, is seeking counseling for behavioral issues at the suggestion of his employers, the ABC television network and Touchstone Television, both part of the Walt Disney Company.

title: House Restores Some Voting Rights to Congressional Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The Democratic majority in the House restored limited floor voting rights to the Congressional delegates from the District of Columbia and four territories on Wednesday after a rancorous debate with echoes of the days before the Republicans won the majority in 1994.

title: A Culture of Faith, Devoted Yet Complex
description: There is a God, and he punishes those who overreach on television.

title: Israeli Panel Approves Presidents Leave
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 25  An Israeli parliamentary committee today approved President Moshe Katsavs request to suspend himself for three months, as prosecutors prepare a case against him that could include charges of rape and other kinds of sexual misconduct.

title: When Resolutions Fail, the Exercise Enforcers Step In
description: JUDY McMILLIN used to be a perennial quitter. Every January, gym-going would become her new favorite hobby, and then, poof, she would abandon it. I just did not grow up exercising or enjoying it, said Ms. McMillin, 57, a homemaker in Dallas.

title: Bush Makes Sales Pitch for Proposal on Energy
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 24  President Bush made a big deal about ethanol, the fuel derived from plants, in his State of the Union address Tuesday night. Wednesday morning, he got up close and personal with it, poking his head through stalks of corn and wheat while scientists for DuPont gave him a crash course in ethanol production in a tour of their research greenhouse here.

title: Energy Research on a Shoestring
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  Thirty years after it was founded by President Jimmy Carter, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory at the edge of the Rockies here still does not have a cafeteria.

title: Balancing Act: Wins and Fatherhood
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 24  The latest phase of Tiger Woodss life has brought him to a new and unfamiliar place, where the quest for titles on the PGA Tour has been joined by the anticipation of his first child.

title: Strike a Pose: A Show Pony Choreographs His Obsession
description: Last year the choreographer Trajal Harrell was hit with an intense dose of post-performance depression. It wasnt that his dance, Before Intermission, was badly received (it wasnt), but that after months of rehearsal and a two-night run at the Kitchen, it was over. Around the same time he also observed how his nondance friends were progressing in their lives: getting married, having babies, buying homes.

title: On the Aegean, Stone and Steel Surrender to the Breeze
description: Assos, Turkey

title: A Life Lived in Fear, but Not Half Bad
description: BENNINGTON, Vt.

title: Whats Behind the Surplus? Taxes
description: The good news for New York Citys budget stems partly from the large taxes New Yorkers must swallow when buying property in the citys booming real estate market: the city, along with the state, is collecting a record amount in transfer taxes from the sale of residential properties, and those sales have been booming.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.What can I do to disguise an ugly steel door?

title: Its Roundball 2, Square Jaw 1
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Facing Strike Threat, British Air Cancels 1,300 Flights
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  British Airways said Thursday that it was canceling 1,300 flights from London for two days next week because of a planned strike by its cabin-crew workers.

title: Hezbollah Wont Topple the Lebanese Government, Its Leader Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Jan. 24  Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollahs leader, said Wednesday that Lebanons opposition movement had decided to stop short of toppling the government of Fouad Siniora, fearing civil strife. He warned, though, that Hezbollah and its allies would continue to ratchet up the pressure on Mr. Siniora in coming weeks and vowed not to back down on their demands.

title: The Irish, Young in Old Europe, Strain Schools and Housing
description: DROGHEDA, Ireland  Moving to a newly built seaside housing development north of Dublin seemed an obvious decision for Katrina Dooley and her partner.

title: For the Good of the Herd
description: Washington

title: Glasses Make the Nerd
description: ITS sad, but true: the only people who truly appreciate the fine-tuning it takes to get nerd style right are the fervently hip. Also sad but true: the long, thin rectangles edged in black plastic or silver wire, which have bridged the noses of so many architects and others who long to be seen as cerebral, have lost their edge. Perhaps that is why old-school 1950s glasses are making a comeback at fashionable spectacle shops like A. R. Trapp, Selima Optique and Myoptics.

title: China: Economy Grew 10.7%. in 2006
description: Chinas economy grew 10.7 percent in 2006, closing in on Germany as the worlds third largest, fueled by investment in manufacturing and a boom in exports. Gross domestic product expanded to 20.94 trillion yuan ($2.69 trillion) after growing 10.4 percent in 2005, Xie Fuzhan, chief of the National Bureau of Statistics, said in Beijing. Chinas economy expanded at more than twice the global average as record exports swelled foreign-currency reserves to more than $1 trillion. Premier Wen Jiabao wants to increase consumer spending to reduce the countrys reliance on shipments overseas and avoid igniting investment bubbles.

title: Dallas Suburb Amends Its Ban on Renting to Illegal Immigrants
description: DALLAS, Jan. 24  The City Council of a Dallas suburb has revised its proposed ban on renting apartments to illegal immigrants to allow landlords to rent to families with mixed citizenship or residency status.

title: Police Wont Use $140 Million Radio System
description: For more than 10 years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been working to correct a major hindrance to police work in the subway system: a radio network that keeps transit officers underground from talking with officers patrolling the streets above.

title: Home Depot Chiefs Pay in 2007 Could Reach $8.9 Million
description: Home Depot may pay its new chief executive, Frank Blake, $8.9 million this year, less than the $39.7 million it paid his predecessor, Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted this month.

title: Conflict Case at Hospitals Is Settled
description: Under pressure from the Connecticut attorney general, a consulting group owned by some of the countrys most influential hospital executives agreed yesterday to stop selling marketing advice to vendors who do millions of dollars in business with nonprofit hospitals across the nation, including their own.

title: How E.T. Might Phone Home, if Home Had a G.S.M. Network
description: The Palm Treo 750 is a Windows Mobile smartphone with a global agenda. The 5-ounce phone, which uses Cingulars cellular and wireless broadband networks in the United States, can connect in most countries that use the G.S.M. standard.

title: Official Ready to Re-examine Law Shielding Turks Identity
description: ISTANBUL, Jan. 24  Foreign Minister Abdullah Gul called Wednesday for changes in a controversial law that penalizes insults against Turkish identity.

title: An Electronic Watchdog Will Follow You to a New Home
description: Those who rent their homes are just as vulnerable to burglars as homeowners, but they are less likely to have burglar alarms. And who can blame them? What renter wants to pay to install a system that has to be left behind in a move, or be locked into a monitoring companys contract that is longer than the lease?

title: Pleasures of the Hard-Worn Life
description: PATAGONIA, Ariz.  Jim Harrison, author of rugged, outdoorsy books like True North and Legends of the Fall, is tough on vehicles. His current ride is a much-abused Chevy Tahoe that every day is pounded over terrain most S.U.V.s experience only in commercials: splashing through creeks, lurching down hills, bouncing over rock-strewn dirt roads in the back country of southern Arizona, where Mr. Harrison and his wife, Linda, spend the winter months in an adobe casita on the Sonoita Creek. The shock absorbers are so overstressed theyve gone a little spongy.

title: Barons Before Bedtime
description: ONE of Bradley Zieglers favorite days is the day after Christmas, when the bargain bins at Toys R Us and Wal-Mart are filled with marked-down DVDs and GameCube games. As he has done for the past two years, Bradley will pick up an armful of $3.99 games and movies and then auction them for up to 10 times that on eBay to regular customers from Kentucky to Cyprus.

title: At Sundance, Art and Journalistic Ethics on Trial
description: Amir Bar-Lev sat on a bench at The Art Is In, a gallery in Park City, Utah, looking at a series of very energetic acrylic abstract paintings with titles like Ocean and Lollipop House. Mr. Bar-Lev, who knows and likes the artist, chatted with Mark Weiler about their respective favorites in the showing of six pieces that was held during the Sundance Film Festival.

title: A Word From Our Sponsor
description: WHEN Clinique made its debut in 1968, the cosmetics brand altered Americas beauty landscape by using scientific language and clinical iconography at a time when highly perfumed, elaborately packaged creams dominated department stores.

title: James Farley, 76, Consultant Who Headed Insurance Firm, Dies
description: James B. Farley, an executive who moved seamlessly between the worlds of management consulting and corporate America, died on Saturday at his home in Gulf Stream, Fla. He was 76.

title: Williams Reaches Finals in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 25  After two years of waiting and not much playing, Serena Williams is back in a final, and it happens to be in a Grand Slam tournament.

title: 7 Megapixels and a 7X Zoom in a Rather Small Package
description: Casios 7-megapixel EX-V7 packs an inordinate number of features into its diminutive 2.4-by-3.8-by-1-inch body. The 7X zoom lens is long enough to catch action across the soccer field.

title: Help the Homeless (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Far From Hollywood
description: PARIS

title: In Unusual Move, Hu Demands Inquiry After Journalists Death
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24  In a rare response to a criminal incident, Chinas president, Hu Jintao, has ordered a speedy investigation into the killing of a journalist who was beaten to death recently while investigating conditions in an illegal coal mine, the semiofficial China News Service reported on Wednesday.

title: The New Hollywood
description: The iconic Los Angeles neighborhood seems to have finally achieved a comeback.

title: A More Perfect Union?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Weather Strikes Again
description: The practical effects of climate change continue to be the issue du jour here, if only because the weather seems to be making everyones trip to Davos difficult. The British opposition leader, David Cameron, arrived late Wednesday for a climate chnage dinner after his journey from London was disrupted by bad weather. Mr. Cameron said he had even tried to beat the delays by riding to Heathrow on the back of a motorcycle. Britain has been at the forefront of the climate change debate, but may have problems coping with hostile weather patterns.

title: Helping Europe Grow
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The aging of Western Europe is a continuing concern, leading to worries that there will not be enough workers to support generous public pension policies.

title: Theater Briefs
description: "Frost/Nixon," the new Peter Morgan play about the series of interviews David Frost, the British talk show host, conducted with former President Richard M. Nixon, has set its Broadway dates.

title: Stephen Kings Midnight Madness
description: Every week comic book fans look forward to Wednesdays, the day new issues go on sale. On Feb. 7, one of those comics will be the first issue of a new seven-part series based on the Stephen King novel The Dark Tower, from Marvel Entertainment. To commemorate the event, almost 150 comic book retailers across the country will begin selling the issue at the stroke of midnight. A list of participating stores can be found at www.marvel.com/news/comicstories. Fans who flock to Midtown Comics in Manhattan will see a couple of special guests: Peter David, who writes the dialogue for the series, and Jae Lee, the books artist. The store will open for one hour.

title: Fine Lines
description: Images from the Martin Ramirez retropective at the American Folk Art Museum.

title: Siemens to Buy Software Maker
description: Siemens, the German engineering company, agreed Wednesday to buy the software maker UGS for $3.5 billion, including debt, and separately announced plans to spin off its VDO automotive unit. Siemens said it would retain a majority stake in VDO, which makes electronic systems that help deploy air bags. The purchase and spinoff would accelerate an overhaul started by the chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld. He shed the companys mobile phone unit and is combining the communications network division with that of Nokia.

title: Acquisitions Bolster General Dynamics
description: General Dynamics, the largest maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, said Wednesday that fourth-quarter profit rose on acquisitions, but sales missed analysts estimates. Profit from continuing operations climbed 16 percent, to $463 million, or $1.13 a share, from $398 million, or 98 cents, a year earlier, the company said.

title: Teaming With Carlyle, Irish Media Mogul Revives APN Bid
description: The Irish billionaire Tony OReilly revived his 3.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.97 billion) takeover offer for APN News & Media, Australias fourth-largest media company, after luring the Carlyle Group to his buyout group. The bidders, led by Mr. OReillys Independent News & Media, offered 6.05 Australian dollars a share for the 60 percent of APN it does not already own. But shares of the publisher of the New Zealand Herald closed unchanged at 6.15 Australian dollars Thursday, signaling the group, which includes Providence Equity Partners, may have to increase its offer.

title: Nestle Frosts its Ice Cream Unit With Eskimo Pie
description: Nestle, the maker of Haagen-Dazs ice cream, agreed to purchase the Eskimo Pie and Chipwich ice-cream brands from CoolBrands International to increase its share of the global market. Nestle paid $18.9 million for the brands through a unit in the United States, Dreyers Grand Ice Cream Holdings.

title: TD Banknorth Post 50% Rise in Fourth Quarter Profit
description: TD Banknorth, the U.S. consumer banking unit of the Toronto-Dominion Bank, said fourth-quarter profit rose 50 percent on increased deposits from its purchase of Hudson United Bancorp. Net income climbed to $83.4 million, or 36 cents a share, from $55.6 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier.

title: The Death of Trade: Greatly Exaggerated?
description: Behold the good tidings of Davos: That wave of protectionism you heard about is a mirage.

title: Caremark Makes Its Case for CVS Deal
description: The pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx on Tuesday sent a letter to its shareholders urging them to vote for its pending merger with the drugstore operator CVS. Caremark says in the letter that the proposed $21.2 billion buyout by CVS will deliver immediate value to shareholders and has a high probability of being completed in about a month.

title: At H-P, More Spying Allegations Fly
description: Hewlett-Packard is once again at the center of a cloak-and-dagger brouhaha. A former Hewlett executive accused by the company of stealing trade secrets is now saying that he was instructed by the companys management to spy on a rival, Dell, CNet News.com reported. Karl Kamb, Hewletts former vice president of business development and strategy, was named as a defendant in a federal lawsuit filed by the computer maker in 2005 alleging that he used trade secrets to launch a rival flat-screen TV company of his own while still on the payroll.

title: Amaranth Returns Chunk of Capital to Investors, Report Says
description: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last year after losing more than $6 billion in energy markets, has returned more than half of its remaining capital, MarketWatch reports, citing a letter the firm sent to investors earlier this month. Almost 55 percent to 60 percent of the firms capital as of Sept. 30 was returned during the fourth quarter through investor redemptions and withdrawals, Amaranths founder, Nick Maounis, wrote in the letter obtained by MarketWatch. Apparently favorable market conditions allowed Amaranth to sell a swath of its remaining positions without incurring large losses.

title: Endesa Earnings Turns Up Heat in Takeover Scramble
description: Endesa, the target of a 36.5 billion euro ($47.4 billion) takeover battle, beat its 2006 profit forecast and laid out profit estimates for the next three years including a higher goal for 2009, days before the German utility E.ON and Gas Natural were to make their final offers. Net income was 2.95 billion euros, or $3.82 billion, topping the 2.9 billion euros that Endesa forecast in July, according to preliminary earnings reported in a filing Wednesday. The strong earnings puts pressure on the bidders to table richer offers.

title: Delphi in Deal With Hedge Fund Consortium
description: Delphi said it had signed an agreement for an investment of up to $3.4 billion by a bloc of funds that will take a controlling stake in the auto parts maker as it emerges from bankruptcy. The bankruptcy court overseeing Delphis reorganization approved the equity investment plan earlier this month over the objections of the hedge fund Highland Capital Management, which offered a rival $4.7 billion reorganization plan. Delphi said Tuesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had signed the agreement cleared by the court with investors led by Appaloosa Management and Cerberus Capital Management last Thursday.

title: Davos in the Papers: Hedge Funds, Iran, Snow
description: There was much ado in the press about German Chancellor Angela Merkels speech at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday, with several reports focusing on her stance on hedge funds. Ms. Merkel said proposals to shed more light on hedge funds operations would be a priority for her leadership of the Group of Eight industrial nations this year. We want to minimize the systemic risks in international capital markets and to raise their transparency  above all, I see the need to catch up with hedge funds, she said.

title: Shell Canada Investors Vow to Fight Royal Dutch
description: Disgruntled minority shareholders of Shell Canada threatened Wednesday to fight on in court if Royal Dutch Shell succeeds in buying out its Canadian subsidiary at $45 a share. Royal Dutch controls 78 percent of Shell Canada and wants the rest because of its position in the booming Alberta oil sands. Shell Canada outlined Wednesday even more ambitious plans for its exploitation of the resource.

title: Buyout Shop Takes Mattress Firm
description: Mattress Firm is getting new owners. J.W. Childs Associates, a Boston-based private equity firm, and members of Mattress Firms senior management team are acquiring the company from majority shareholder Sun Capital Partners.

title: I.B.M. Selling Printer Unit to Japanese Firm
description: The Japanese office equipment maker Ricoh will buy I.B.M.s digital commercial printer operations for about $700 million in April, the Nikkei reported. The acquisition, Ricohs largest ever, will make the firm the No. 1 player in the growing market for devices used by companies to print contracts and other documents quickly and in large volumes, the report said.

title: Bank of America Board Greenlights Buyback
description: Bank of America on Wednesday said its board of directors authorized the repurchase of up to 200 million additional common shares, and will allow management to spend $14 billion over the next 12 to 18 months to buy back stock. The No. 2 U.S. bank said it has 63 million shares remaining under a 200 million share buyback program authorized last April. Bank of Americas market capitalization is more than $200 billion.

title: LA Landlord Raises $400 Million in I.P.O.
description: Meruelo Maddux Properties, the largest landlord in downtown Los Angeles, raised $400 million Wednesday in an initial public stock offering intended to capitalize on investors widespread demand for commercial real estate. Meruelo Maddux sold 40 million shares at $10 each, well below the $12 to $14 a share the company was seeking. The stock was to begin trading Thursday on Nasdaq under the symbol MMPI.

title: GLG and Deutsche Fined by French Regulators
description: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorit des Marchs Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecom-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.

title: Adelphia Ruling to Delay Time Warner Cable Offering
description: The opening of Time Warner Cable shares on the public market faces yet another delay after a federal judge on Wednesday blocked Adelphia Communications, the cable television company, from moving ahead with its $15 billion plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection. The judge granted a request by an 11-member bondholder group, which includes Lehman Brothers and Bank of America, to appeal the Jan. 3 order approving the reorganization plan which they say undervalues their claims.

title: Merrill Chief Pocketed $48 Million in 2006
description: Merrill Lynchs chief executive, E. Stanley ONeal, made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said Wednesday in a regulatory filing. Mr. ONeal received $700,000 in salary for 2006, a cash bonus of $18.5 million and stock valued at $28.8 million. The previous year, Merrill gave Mr. ONeal $37 million in salary and bonuses.

title: Hedge Fund Money to Play Role in Political Races
description: Hedge fund money, which now exceeds $1 trillion, has emerged in the last several years as a potentially powerful force in politics, as underscored by the significant role it is playing in the presidential aspirations of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani, The New York Timess Landon Thomas Jr. says. During the 2006 election cycle, executives who work at the 30 biggest hedge funds made $2.8 million in contributions to political candidates or party committees, almost double the amount in 2000.

title: Greenberg Invests in China Buyout Fund
description: Maurice R. Greenbergs Starr International will take a 50 percent stake in a 1 billion yuan ($129 million) private-equity fund to invest in Chinese companies. In the first confirmed investment in China since he was ousted from the American International Group, Mr. Greenbergs company will invest alongside state-owned Citic Securities, Chinas biggest publicly traded broker. During his tenure at AIG, Mr. Greenberg, who ran the insurance giant for 38 years before getting the boot, won the first insurance license in China for an overseas company since the countrys communist revolution in 1949.

title: Ethnic Eats: Queens
description: A tour of this borough's global tables.

title: Sun and the Kohlberg Edge
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts recent deal to invest $700 million in Sun Microsystems shows how Kohlberg, a giant private equity firm, got special access to a public company the average Joe cannot hope for, Breakingviews writes.

title: Rarely Seen Sea Monster Captured, Then, Following Script, Dies
description: Yet another rare-freaky sea creature has made a rare-freaky video appearance  courtesy Japanese marine researchers  before being promptly declared dead.

title: Bush Plan May Support Clean Tech
description: Venture capitalists may have a new ally in their rush to invest in clean technologies: President Bush. As the president outlined an aggressive plan to reduce gasoline use by 20 percent within a decade through a mandatory fuels standard in his State of the Union speech, several V.C.s said that their investments in ethanol and other environmentally friendly fuels could pay off  and help the United States meet that goal. Companies like Khosla Ventures invested more than $2.9 billion in clean tech in 2006, according to the Cleantech Venture Network.

title: American Stock Exchange Hires Adviser
description: The American Stock Exchange said Thursday it had hired the investment bank Morgan Stanley to advise it on a demutualization plan, which would convert it to a for-profit corporation, as well as potential strategic future initiatives. Demutualization could be a step toward an initial public offering of the exchange.

title: Blackstone Raises Equity Office Bid to $38.3 Billion
description: The Blackstone Group increased its offer for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, or $54 a share, in cash, escalating the stakes in the pitched battle for the countrys largest office landlord. The new offer trumps a rival $37.6 billion, $52-a-share bid by a real estate consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust made earlier this month. Analysts and industry watchers had expected the private equity giant to top the Vornado groups bid, as the agreement it reached with Equity Office last November  for $48.50 a share  allowed Blackstone to match rival offers. If completed, the offer would set a record for a leveraged buyout.

title: Clinton Promises Health Care Plan
description: A day after saying that she would take on health care again, despite the political problems it caused her in the 1990s, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday evening that she would soon propose a plan about how we get to universal coverage.

title: 3i Targets U.S. With New Investment Team
description: The 3i Group, a private equity and venture capital firm based in London, said Thursday that it had formed a new division and opened a New York office as part of a plan to increase its investments in United States companies. The firm said its U.S. Growth Capital team will typically make investments of $20 million to $200 million in privately owned companies.

title: Fantasy and Farce From Far, Far Away
description: Aliens offer a cure for earthling ennui in "From Other Worlds," a limp sci-fi comedy with fewer laughs than a meeting of Abductees Anonymous. When Joanne (Cara Buono), a despondent wife and mother, develops a fascination with dead fish and a fan-shaped skin blemish, she naturally suspects an otherworldly cause. Grappling with blackouts and an unreliable Brooklyn accent, she heads for a U.F.O. support group at which neighborhood losers vie for the extraterrestrial-sighting record and, apparently, the title of Most Unfortunate Hair.

title: Conservatives Upset With Bushs Speech
description: Conservatives felt President Bushs speech left a lot to be desired, topic-wise.

title: The Bagger in Fifty Years
description: BoingBoing points to a blogger with a few miles on him who thinks about how many miles he has to go.

title: My Point, and I Do Have One
description: Okay, it was a long few days and the Bagger just wanted a little him-time. So he plopped on the hotel bed and hit the remote in an effort to get away from the Oscars. And there was Ellen DeGeneres with some freaky fitness guy who advised her to eat nothing but air, flax seed and free-range twigs so he could fit into her Oscar hostess frock. Yeow. And then she started mating with a Pilates ball as part of the regimen.

title: Cardinal Health Selling Unit to Blackstone for $3.3 Billion
description: Cardinal Health, a provider of products and services to the health care industry, said Thursday it had agreed to sell its pharmaceutical technologies and services business to the Blackstone Group for $3.3 billion.

title: Buyout Showdown Wows Davos Dealmakers
description: As many of the worlds buyout kings were gathered in Davos, Switzerland, to mix with leaders and moguls at the World Economic Forum, their attention turned to an audacious move by someone in their midst. Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group, who was seen casually roaming the halls of the convention center earlier in the day showing little sign of what was to come, and his firm announced Thursday that they had raised their bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, including debt, making the biggest leveraged buyout in history even bigger. Blackstone increased its offer to $54 a share from its previous bid of $48.50, leapfrogging a $52-per-share offer from a rival bidding group led by Vornado Realty Trust.

title: My Kid Could Write That
description: The Bagger has reverted to writing on dead trees of late, including this piece today on My Kid Could Paint That, directed by Amir Bar-Lev, which premiered at Sundance to instant acclaim and was bought for just under $2 million by Sony Pictures Classics.

title: Odds Are
description: OscarWatch points us to some odds for the Big Show. Best picture race looks tight, but Kate Winslet at 25-to-one for best actress? That aint right even if its right.

title: A Loud Outcry Against Genocide
description: Like Atom Egoyan's 2002 fiction film "Ararat," the documentary "Screamers" takes as its jumping-off point the 1915 massacre of Armenians by the Ottoman Turks. Unlike Mr. Egoyan, however, the director Carla Garapedian has a wider agenda: to show how continued refusal to acknowledge the genocide, by the United States and Britain as well as by Turkey, has given governments all over the world courage to instigate their own versions of ethnic cleansing.

title: An Audio  Labyrinth
description: Now that Guillermo Del Toros Pans Labyrinth has been nominated for best foreign film, El Gordo has become El Rey, or at least a prince. And boy, can the guy talk. The funniest man in film. Hear him talking more, ah, stuff, than a landlord on rent day in his interview with Terry Gross on Fresh Air.

title: Money Talks
description: The Bagger wishes he was still in Park City, pretending that celebrities are his friends, but he is instead at a hotel in Los Angeles, pretending that the doormen are his running buddies. Good evening, Mr. Bagger. Hey Rico, whats up with your bad self? Good night, Mr. Bagger.

title: One Degree
description: Last Saturday night, the Bagger went to a couple of parties at Sundance  one held by the Creative Coalition and the other by Entertainment Weekly  and at both of them ran into Kyra Sedgwick and Kevin Bacon. He wrote a story about them in New York a while ago and has since pretended that they know each other. The couple plays along.

title: Obamas Race Problem
description: Debra Dickerson, author of The End of Blackness, concurs with Stanley Crouch: Obama isnt black, she writes in Salon. She continues:

title: The Heartbreak of Cheap Labor
description: "China Blue," a heartbreaking and meticulous documentary about life inside a blue-jeans factory in China, reveals more than we may care to know about the provenance of our most beloved item of clothing. Employing smuggled equipment and outright deception, Micha X. Peled and his crew infiltrate a plant owned by Guo Xi Lam, a former police chief who is clearly proud of his success. "We are happy to make the jeans for the whole world," says his beaming sales manager, while clients like Wal-Mart suggest the factory is well on its way.

title: Scanias Profits Shore Up Bargaining Position with MAN
description: Shortly after a German competitor dropped its hostile bid, the Swedish truck maker Scania reported healthy profits for last year, giving it a position of strength to negotiate a better deal, the Financial Times reported Thursday. The German company, MAN, dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid earlier this week and instead proposed a friendlier alliance. But one of Scanias largest shareholders, the Investor holding vehicle of Swedens Wallenberg family, insisted that the company could stand alone. Scania posted an operating income of 8.75 million krona, up 28 percent for the year.

title: On the Hill: Minimum Wage Hike Faces Tough Going

title: Deutsche Bank Buys Stake in Private Equity Firm
description: Deutsche Bank will acquire a minority stake in a boutique asset management firm specializing in private-equity investments, the investment bank said Thursday. Deutsche Banks alternative-investment arm will pay an undisclosed sum for the interest in Aldus Equity, which manages more than $3 billion. The two will work together to create private-equity fund of funds products, Deutsches press release said. Both firms expect the deal to close in the first half of 2007.

title: War at Home: G.O.P. Under Pressure
description: With the anti-surge vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee falling along party lines, (Senator Chuck Hagel the lone Republican in favor), several G.O.P. senators have still expressed reservations about the presidents plan to increase troop levels in Iraq. And because many more Republican senators are up for re-election in 2008, low public opinion over the war in Iraq places them in a far more difficult space than their Democratic counterparts.

title: Saving the Nation Through Procreation
description: The aging of Western Europe is a continuing concern, leading to worries that there will not be enough workers to support generous public pension policies.

title: ABC to Greys Anatomy Star: Physician, Heal Thyself
description: Isaiah Washington, the Greys Anatomy star, has struggled recently with a certain anti-gay epithet, which has twice tumbled quite audibly out of his mouth in reference to fellow cast member T.R. Knight, who is gay  first on the set of the hit ABC show, and then again during a press conference after the Golden Globes last Monday.

description: Even the hackers show up in Davos.

title: Time Inc. to Sell Magazines to Swedish Publisher
description: Media conglomerate Time Warner will sell 18 magazines to the Swedish publishing company Bonnier Group, Bonnier said in a press release Thursday. The magazines to be sold include Field & Stream, Outdoor Life and Yachting.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: Primary Frenzy
description: With big states like Florida, New Jersey, California and Illinois looking to move up their primaries to shortly after New Hampshires, will it be a whole new nominating world? The Timess Adam Nagourney examines how the calendar could complicate candidates strategies.

description: Senator Clinton just walked out of a private meeting with the Rev. Al Sharpton, who is comparison shopping among likely 2008 candidates, sitting also with Senators Obama, Dodd, and Biden today.

title: Pernod Is Absolutely Interested in Swedish Vodka
description: Frances Pernod Ricard is interested in buying Swedish state-owned vodka Absolut when it comes up for sale, while talks on acquiring the Stolichnaya brand outside Russia continue, the company said on Thursday. When asked at a briefing in London if Pernod was interested in buying Vin & Sprits Absolut, managing director Pierre Pringuet said yes. Absolut, known for its long-running, pun-filled ad campaign, is the worlds second-bestselling vodka after Diageos Smirnoff. Analysts have valued the brand at more than $4 billion.

title: Streaming Movies
description: Netflix has rewritten the rules of the online movie-rental game.

title: Net Pioneer Settles Into Nerd Paradise
description: Having been a player in one of the most dramatic stories of the dot-com boom and bust, Joe Kraus seems happy to be safely ensconced at the Internet giant Google. Mr. Kraus founded Excite, which went from a university-sponsored search engine to (as Excite@Home) one of the biggest names in the Internet business before its spectacular crash and burn at the turn of the latest century. He went on to found JotSpot, a maker of collaboration software that Google acquired in October.

title: Kristof on Anderson Cooper 360
description: NYTimes.com footage of the columnist's most recent trip to Cambodia was included in a Jan. 24 segment on CNN's Anderson Cooper 360.

title: Seven or Eight Days in Paris (But Whos Counting?)
description: The spring haute couture collections have opened. At Dior, John Galliano has recreated the dove-gray look of the salon, with a pair of enormous chairs to remind us of his capacity to distort reality. Sure, the clothes evoked Madame Butterfly, but in their sugary colors and their playfulness (tailored jackets that morph into origami birds), they also told the story of Gallianos 10 years at Dior. He had the girls walk among the guests, so that you could touch the clothes, and he had all the top girls, including Shalom Harlow and Jacquetta Wheeler, who at one point was having so much trouble negotiating some steps in her enormous dress that I thought one of the ushers might have to perform a firemans lift.

title: Researchers Say Prehistoric Extinctions in Australia Were Mans Work, Not Natures
description: Sticking with the theme of bizarre prehistoric creatures today, we turn our attentions to the marsupial lion  one of several critters known collectively as Australias once-plentiful megafauna that vanished from the planet roughly 45,000 years ago.

title: Paradise Lost: Hedge Funds Flee from Island Tax Haven
description: Nearly half of the 49 hedge funds that had their headquarters in the Virgin Islands have left in the past two years. Its not the heat or the bugs that sent them packing, but the Internal Revenue Service. A set of new laws and regulations have dashed the hopes of people who had counted on their Virgin Islands address cutting their tax bills by 90 percent. The I.R.S. suspects rampant fraud, according to a Bloomberg News account of the situation on St. Croix and other islands.

title: Civil War, or War Against Civilians?
description: There has been great debate in recent months about whether the conflict in Iraq can accurately be called a civil war. Iraqi Vice President Adil Abdul Mahdi offered his view Thursday in a panel discussion at Davos chaired by Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.

title: How to Top It Off
description: First of all, the responses to my last post on unusual food and wine matches has been fascinating. Thank you! While I do like good dark chocolate, I am not really a chocolate lover, so Ive never really wondered about what wine, or whisky, to drink with it. But I was especially intrigued by Brooklynguys suggestion of a simple grilled hanger steak with a good Savennires, as I love Savennires and steak, but have never tried them at the same time. But I can see it intellectually and, more important, I started to salivate thinking about it.

description: Bill Miller, the legendary stock picker who manages the Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund, says he is often asked whether, on some level, he is relieved that his streak  15 years of besting the Standard & Poors 500  is over. The answer is no, he wrote in his latest letter to shareholders of the fund, which ended 2006 up 5.9 percent, far below the 15.8 percent gain in the S&P. He goes on to suggest that it is actually a silly question.

description: ANDRS SEGOVIA, widely known as the father of modern classical guitar, may have explained its sophisticated appeal better than anyone else. The guitar is a small orchestra, he said. It is polyphonic. Every string is a different color, a different voice.

description: Late last year, an executive from Citigroup phoned an official connected with CNBC, the cable business news channel. According to people with knowledge of the call, the Citigroup executive made it clear that Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, would not be permitted to fly on Citigroups corporate jet again.

title: On Long Island, More Are Priced Out of the Housing Market

title: In Lower Manhattan, the Echo of the Yiddish Stage Endures
description: REAL estate agents have a knack for investing any Manhattan neighborhood with romance, no matter how harsh or dowdy its past. The bloodstained meatpacking district in recent years has assumed a sudden charm. Then there's the Lower East Side, which has become a cradle to luxury condos after spending decades as a place where immigrants of all stripes strived to get to, then sought to leave as quickly as possible  a kind of perpetual springboard to a better life.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The new rocket that will replace the space shuttle for carrying crews to the International Space Station is on schedule and within weight guidelines, NASA officials said Thursday.

It was Eric Axley  not Justin Rose, who shared the lead in the Chrysler Classic at one point, but is still seeking his first PGA Tour victory.

description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 25  Iraqs Shiite prime minister and Sunni lawmakers hurled insults at one another during a raucous session of Parliament on Thursday, with the prime minister threatening a Sunni lawmaker with arrest and the Sunni speaker of Parliament threatening to quit.
