description: Microsoft yesterday reported strong sales for its latest quarter and a profit that slightly surpassed Wall Street estimates, but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.

title: Distinguishing the Remarkable From the Merely Old
description: AS de facto custodian of everything within the built city that bears sprucing up and saving for posterity, Robert B. Tierney, chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, is instantly miffed when a photographer gives his office the once-over and offhandedly remarks that there is nothing in it worth preserving on camera. Well, maybe him. But only if he puts on the silly paper party hat crowned by a cartoonish depiction of the Chrysler Building sitting on the bookcase next to two  likewise ceremonial  hard hats from Lincoln Center and the High Line.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Aug. 31 about a decision by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to give some priests accused of child sexual abuse the choice of leaving the priesthood or moving to supervised housing in Westchester County  an option that was later canceled  misstated the jurisdiction of the archdiocese. It covers Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx in New York City, and seven other downstate counties  not all of New York City and five other downstate counties. The error was discovered recently by a reporter reviewing The Timess archives.

title: Suspended Guard Wants to Return to Notre Dame
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 26  Kyle McAlarney, the starting point guard for Notre Dame before he was arrested last month for possession of marijuana and suspended from the university, notified Coach Mike Brey on Friday morning that he intended to return to the program.

title: Queens Now Has Less Feta, More Jellyfish
description: LIKE most New York immigrant stories, mine started with a long trip, a small apartment in a humble neighborhood and hope for a better life. Sure enough, I graduated from the little apartment to a bigger one, and then a house. I got a better job and a better life. But 27 years later, the neighborhood remains the same: Astoria, Queens.

title: Groups Head to Capital to Step Up Antiwar Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Tens of thousands of demonstrators are set to arrive in the capital this weekend for a major antiwar march, staging the first of several protests intended to persuade the new Democratic-controlled Congress to do more than simply speak against President Bushs Iraq policy.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 8 P.M.(Turner Classic Movies) PARIS WHEN IT SIZZLES (1964). Paris isnt just for springtime. Tonight, TCM takes a winter break in the City of Light, starting with this William Holden and Audrey Hepburn vehicle about a boozy writer who has two days to deliver a script to a Hollywood producer and hires a temporary secretary to help him get the job done. They fall in love, but of course. At 10, Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron trip the light fantastic to a luscious Gershwin score in the grand musical An American in Paris (1951). And at midnight, Alec Guinness and Vernon Gray play a Scottish father and son who visit the city and tumble into mild infatuations  the son with an older woman, the father with a girl  in To Paris, With Love (1955).

title: Reality Check for a Generation That Knows Best

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about Senator John Kerrys announcement that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2008 incorrectly described what he called a botched joke he told before the November midterm elections. In telling the joke, which was assailed as an attack on American troops fighting in Iraq, Mr. Kerry not only dropped a word from his prepared remarks, but he also rephrased his opening sentence extensively and omitted a reference to President Bush. Mr. Kerrys aides said that the prepared text read: Do you know where you end up if you dont study, if you arent smart, if youre intellectually lazy? You end up getting us stuck in a war in Iraq. Just ask President Bush. What he actually said: You know, education, if you make the most of it, you study hard, you do your homework and you make an effort to be smart, you can do well. If you dont, you get stuck in Iraq.

title: How Transfer Taxes Work
description: The good news for New York Citys budget stems partly from the taxes New Yorkers must pay when buying property in the citys booming real estate market. The city, along with the state, is collecting a record amount in transfer taxes from the sale of residential properties, and those sales have remained strong.

title: Aid Conference Raises $7.6 Billion for Lebanese Government
description: PARIS, Jan. 25  Led by Saudi Arabia and the United States, international donors from more than 30 countries on Thursday pledged $7.6 billion in aid for Lebanon, in a bold effort to try to prop up the government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora.

title: Seeing Future of Britain, and Blair, in the Snow
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25  As a subplot to the annual rite here of the World Economic Forum, there is what might be billed as the Little Britain show, or, perhaps more diplomatically, Britains big picture writ small in the snows of Switzerland.

title: Randolph Gets Expensive as Mets Expectations Rise
description: Coffee, gasoline and real estate cost a small fortune in New York. And now, the Mets have learned, so does a manager with two years of experience.

title: Mayor Sees $3.9 Billion Surplus Fed by Booming Real Estate Market
description: With New York Citys treasury flush with unexpected revenue from an extraordinary surge in the real estate market, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg projected yesterday that the city would have a $3.9 billion surplus to carry over into its $57.1 billion budget next fiscal year, allowing him to cut taxes and set aside money for future expenses.

title: Gains in Wireless Customers Help Lift AT&Ts Earnings 17%
description: Capping a whirlwind year of merging and rebranding that has come to characterize the telecommunications business, AT&T reported a 17 percent increase in quarterly profits yesterday driven by a sizable increase in wireless subscribers.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about sharp spikes in property taxes in northern Rockland County, N.Y., stemming from a settlement of $275 million that several municipalities and a school district agreed to pay to a power company as compensation for tax overcharges, misidentified the state agency that deregulated electric utilities in the 1990s. It is the Public Service Commission  not the New York State Power Authority, which is an electricity producer.

title: Ask Science
description: Natalie Angier answered readers questions regarding her first column for Science Times, about the nature of time.

title: In Clue to Addiction, Brain Injury Halts Smoking
description: Scientists studying stroke patients are reporting today that an injury to a specific part of the brain, near the ear, can instantly and permanently break a smoking habit. People with the injury who stopped smoking found that their bodies, as one man put it, forgot the urge to smoke.

title: Bush Backs Force Against Iranians in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- American soldiers will do what they must to protect themselves from Iranian agents operating inside Iraq, the White House said today, following a report that President Bush had authorized the killing of Iranian agents.

description: AROUND TOWN

title: Illinois: Bias Claimed in Contest
description: A woman who won a car in a contest sponsored by a Spanish-language radio station is suing the station and its parent company, saying they withheld the car from her because she is an illegal immigrant. The woman, Maribel Nava Alvarez, filed suit in late November in Chicago against the local station, WLEY 107.9 FM, and the Spanish Broadcasting System, said her lawyer, Robert M. Romero. The suit, only now being reported in English-language news media, alleges breach of contract because the station refused to give Ms. Alvarez the Corvette she won in a raffle at a fair on July 4, 2005, Mr. Romero said. In a statement, the station and its parent company said they could not give Ms. Alvarez the car because they were unable to verify the tax-reporting information required by the Internal Revenue Service in awarding prizes valued at more than $500.

The immigrants negotiate an annual payment based on five times the monthly rental value of their Swiss homes. They do not make a one-time payment based on the value of their Swiss homes.

title: Nokia Net Up 19%, Topping Estimates
description: Nokia, the maker of mobile phones, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 19 percent, beating analysts estimates, as a push into emerging markets drove handset sales to a record.

title: Meissner Thrives in Starring Role
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 25  Though Kimmie Meissner has had time to get used to the role as the top American figure skater since she won a world title last year, she said the pressure that goes with being the favorite at the United States Figure Skating Championships hit her only this week.

title: Hotel in Pakistani Capital Is Bombed
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 26  A man blew himself up today outside a major hotel used by government officials and foreign dignitaries, killing himself and a security guard, police and security officials said. Three other people were wounded.

title: Knicks Are Depleted as Heat's Stars Return
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 25  The Miami Heat defeated the Knicks handily Monday without Shaquille ONeal and Dwyane Wade. On Friday, the teams will meet again, but this time it may be the Knicks who are short-handed.

title: A Game? No, Its a Life.
description: AT this time of year there isnt a lot to do in Warroad, Minn., a little town at the southwestern end of the Lake of the Woods, just a few miles from the Canadian border. There is no movie theater, the one bowling alley closed a while ago and the nearest shopping mall is in Grand Forks, N.D., two and half hours away across a windswept plain. You can snowmobile, but the snowfall has been a little skimpy so far this winter. Or you can ice fish, though until just a couple of weeks ago, when the temperature finally plunged to double digits below, it might have been unwise to drive a pickup out onto the lake.

title: Once Upon a Time in a Very Familiar West
description: Archetypes and symbols solemnly parade through Seraphim Falls, a handsome, old-fashioned western of few words and heavy meanings that unfolds with the sanctimonious grandeur of a biblical allegory. In this drama of pursuit, revenge and forgiveness, set in 1868, Pierce Brosnan and Liam Neeson are soldiers who fought on opposite sides of the Civil War and are now engaged in a life-and-death chase that takes them from the Ruby Mountains of Nevada to a final showdown in the desert.

title: G.I. Gets 18-Year Prison Term for Killing 2 Captive Iraqis
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Jan. 25  An Army infantryman received an 18-year prison sentence on Thursday after pleading guilty to killing two unarmed Iraqis during an assault northwest of Baghdad last May.

title: Spitzer to Outline Plans for Cuts in Health Spending
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25  Gov. Eliot Spitzer will preview his first executive budget in a speech on Friday afternoon, laying out his plan to rein in Medicaid and other health care spending, setting the stage for a battle with politically powerful health care providers and unions.

title: Love Means Always Having to Say Youre Sorry
description: Breaking and Entering, the latest film by Anthony Minghella, climaxes in a welter of apologies. Everyone in London, it seems, has cause for remorse  the burglar, the philanderer, the seamstress, the budding gymnast  and for my part I regret that I lost count of the number of times the words Im sorry were uttered on screen.

title: The Name Is Power and It Fits
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 23  The narrow stone building on Victoria Square here has an unusual dark green door with prominent brass handles and hinges. But no signs on its exterior or anywhere in the marble lobby behind it indicate that it is the headquarters of the Power Corporation of Canada, one of the countrys largest financial services companies and Quebecs pre-eminent newspaper publisher.

title: No Frivolity: Davos Tries Fewer Stars
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25  Snow was not the only thing in short supply as moguls and world leaders rolled into this ski resort town this week.

title: A Year After Her Olympic Fall, Winning Is Jacobelliss Revenge
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 25  Competitors cannot keep pace with her on the snowboardcross course, but shaking questions about her famous fall at the Winter Olympics has been more vexing for Lindsey Jacobellis.

title: Salvadorans Death in Iraq Leaves His Mother Fuming
description: SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 21  From her hillside home in western El Salvador, Herminia Ramos sobbed and sobbed the other day as she recalled her fallen son.

title: Spitzer Names 2 Members of His Environmental Team
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer nominated Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis of Manhattan yesterday to be the new commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, a sprawling agency that in recent years has lost hundreds of employees who handle critical matters like dam safety inspections and pollution permit reviews.

title: Teaneck: Bus Hits and Kills Pedestrian
description: A man was struck and killed last night by a New Jersey Transit bus turning left from Teaneck Road onto State Street, the Teaneck police said. The man, whose identity was not immediately released, was declared dead at the scene around 8:30 p.m. The police said that the death appeared to be an accident and that they did not expect charges to be filed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Get Inside the Lives of Children in Urban Poverty
description: Its virtually impossible for a mainstream journalist, in print or on film, to explore poverty without sounding condescending, and its certainly impossible for Diane Sawyer. Her treacliness works against the good intentions of Waiting on the World to Change, a 20/20 segment tonight on ABC that looks at some particularly impoverished young lives in Camden, N.J., one of the countrys most distressed cities.

title: Building Boom May Mean Jobs Cant All Be Filled, Report Says
description: Amid one of the biggest building booms in New York Citys history, the construction industry may soon have trouble finding enough young workers to fill all the jobs, a leading industry group said yesterday.

title: British Airways Cancels Flights as Strike Nears
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  British Airways said Thursday that it was canceling 1,300 flights from London for two days next week because of a planned strike by its cabin-crew workers.

title: Calling Blue: And on That Farm He Had a Cellphone
description: Stephen Colbert, listen up. If any minority lifestyle is overrepresented in the early education of children in the United States, its farm life.

title: Consumer Reports Apologizes for Botched Tests
description: Just a few weeks after an alarming report on the safety of infant car seats in Consumer Reports magazine that it later admitted was a result of botched tests, the magazine sent letters of apology yesterday to its readers and promised an investigation.

title: A No Vote on Senate Raises Just Might Count
China Says Its Economy Grew by 10.7% in 2006, With Little Inflation
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 25  In the last 30 years, no major economy in the world has grown at the speed of Chinas, and no other country has been able to do it year after year, for over a decade.

title: Why Iraqs a Mess: Just Count the Ways (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Stern, Short Story Writer, Dies at 79
description: Daniel Stern, who sifted through his careers in jazz and symphonic music, advertising, movies and academia for psychic grist for the bittersweet, tightly crafted novels and short stories that were his crowning achievement, died Wednesday in Houston. He was 79.

title: Ex-Cheney Aide Contradicts Libby
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  A former spokeswoman for Vice President Dick Cheney gave testimony in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on Thursday that directly contradicted Mr. Libbys version of events during a crucial period that is at the center of the perjury case against him.

title: Bush Pushes Health Care Plan
description: LEES SUMMIT, Mo., Jan. 25  President Bush urged Congress on Thursday to consider his new health care proposal and indicated he was ready for a fight.

title: New India Accords With Russia Include More Nuclear Power Plants
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25  India sealed a wide-ranging package of agreements with Russia on Thursday, the first day of a summit meeting intended to demonstrate that their longstanding relationship had not deteriorated as a result of Indias growing engagement with the United States.

title: Secrecy Is at Issue in Suits Opposing Spy Program
description: The Bush administration has employed extraordinary secrecy in defending the National Security Agencys highly classified domestic surveillance program from civil lawsuits. Plaintiffs and judges clerks cannot see its secret filings. Judges have to make appointments to review them and are not allowed to keep copies.

title: Time Comes to a Standstill in a Courtroom Journey
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The most politically charged criminal trial in the capital in nearly two decades crackles to life each morning in a bland sixth-floor courtroom with a stopped clock.

title: Eloquent Tongues but Anguished Irish Hearts
description: Quite a few languages are spoken in Brian Friels play Translations. There is a fair amount of Latin and Greek. Gaelic makes frequent appearances. And English is of course the plays official lingua franca.

title: North Korea: U.N. Stops Projects and Cash
description: The United Nations Development Program agreed to cease $1.7 million in new projects in North Korea until completion of what Alejandro D. Wolff, the acting United States ambassador, called a real, full, thorough, independent, investigative audit and to end direct payments in hard currency to local staff members and vendors and recruitment through the North Korean government. The $2.7 million in programs that will go forward are those that directly benefit the people of North Korea, officials said. The action followed complaints from the United States and Japan that some money could be diverted to the government, a claim that North Korea dismissed as ridiculous and nonsense.

title: A Triangle Equal to the Sum of Its Hoops
description: THE gentle hills of the Triangle region of North Carolina are spangled with the prim brick McMansions of migrant techies lured by opportunity and temperate weather  almost any day is good for squeezing in 18 holes. Out on the wandering back roads, tall pines still cast thin shadows, turning a sunny-day drive into a sparkling strobe-light show. Just roll down the window to air out your soul. The Triangle, bounded by the cities of Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill, is an easy place to live and an even easier place to visit. Refill your sweet-tea glass and sit a while.

title: Drug That Treats Vision Problems May Increase Stroke Risk
description: Use of Genentechs new eye drug, Lucentis, might raise the risk of stroke, according to a letter the company has begun sending to doctors.

title: Food Pantry Needs Help, Even Holiday Fruitcake
description: FREEPORT, N.Y., Jan. 24  That cellophane-wrapped holiday gift food package with the 12 different cheeses and three tins of pat. And that two-ton fruitcake. And the unopened Whitmans Sampler. You could live without the calories contained in those gestures of good will from the season just passed  and people at the emergency food pantry here are willing to help.

title: Afghan Lawmaker Is Killed in Shooting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 26  A member of Afghanistans Parliament was gunned down while he was walking from his home to a mosque for Friday prayers, officials said.

title: Beirut University Dispute Escalates Into Rioting, Killing 4
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25  Violence erupted in Beirut on Thursday for the second time in three days, as an altercation in a university cafeteria escalated into rioting and gunfire.

title: Greece: Militants Claim U.S. Embassy Attack
description: The leftist guerrilla group known as Revolutionary Struggle claimed responsibility for the rocket attack on the American Embassy in Athens two weeks ago, saying it was in retaliation for the criminal U.S. war on terrorism. The claim was made in a five-page statement to the weekly newspaper Pontiki. Since September 2003, Revolutionary Struggle has claimed responsibility for a number of attacks, including bombings at a courthouse and police station and an assassination attempt against the culture minister. In its statement, the group warned: There is no doubt that the American Embassy would be the first building we would wreck. The second would be Parliament. It singled out Foreign Minister Dora Bakoyanni and Public Order Minister Vyronas Polydoras as praetorians of the American administration.

title: Outspoken Catholic Pastor Replaced; He Says Its Retaliation
description: In his last Mass as pastor at the inner-city parish in Detroit where he had served for 23 years, Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. Gumbleton told his parishioners that he was forced to step down as pastor because of his lobbying efforts on behalf of the victims of sexual abuse by members of the clergy, a stance that put him in opposition to his fellow bishops.

title: Watching a History Lesson Thats Told Through Tango
description: Miguel Angel Zotto re-entered New York society on Wednesday when his company, Tango X 2, performed for the first time in a decade at City Center. The group, formed in 1988, presented Su Historia, a two-act show tracing the companys history and paying homage to Mr. Zottos tango heroes.

title: Jack Kerouac, in His Cups, on a Tear and on TV
description: No Great Society, which opened at Performance Space 122  in February, reopened last night and runs through Feb. 11 at the New York Theater Workshops Fourth Street Theater, 83 East Fourth Street, East Village; (212) 239-6200. Following are excerpts from Jason Zinomans review, which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 11; the full text is online here.

title: Hartford: Senate Health Care Plan
description: Democratic leaders of the State Senate offered a $450 million plan yesterday to increase publicly financed health care programs for the uninsured. The plan would make 140,000 uninsured people eligible for programs like Medicaid and insurance plans for children. It would leave an estimated 260,000 residents without health insurance, but Donald E. Williams, the Senate president, said it was a first step toward a universal health care program.

title: Bush to Seek More Aid for Afghanistan as Taliban Regroups
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 25  President Bush plans to ask Congress for $10.6 billion in aid for Afghanistan, primarily to beef up the countrys security forces, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Thursday.

title: More Willful Indifference
description: Mark Foley fled his seat in the House of Representatives last September when his sexual approaches to teenage pages finally reached the news media after years of a shameful cover-up in the halls of Congress. Now it turns out that the F.B.I. was just as phlegmatic about the scandal as Mr. Foleys Republican colleagues. An inspector generals report excoriates F.B.I. agents for brushing aside troubling evidence of the lawmakers flirtatious message-writing, and then falsely blaming their inaction on the watchdog group that tried to alert the government in the first place.

title: A Convocation of the Visionary and Disenfranchised
description: Now in its 15th round, the robust extravaganza known as the Outsider Art Fair might almost be called Establishment. To be sure, compared with uptown fairs its still a little short on amenities: no carpets, no-frills booths, a loosey-goosey layout. But this annual event at the Puck Building has longevity and staying power, and its now-classic artists  among them Henry Darger, Bill Traylor, Joseph E. Yoakum, Adolf Wlfli, Scottie Wilson, Howard Finster, James Castle and Elijah Pierce, to name a few  keep returning. (Martn Ramrez, who is starring uptown in a major retrospective at the American Folk Art Museum, appears here, too, at several dealers booths.)

title: Fun When It Freezes
description: WHO Doug Kolner, 47, owner of a biotech manufacturing company and commodore of the Four Lakes Ice Yacht Club

title: Gold Rush Mentality at a Hustlin Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah, Jan. 25  Midway through this years Sundance Film Festival, the festival sent out a news release that underscored why so many now swarm around this mountain resort town every January without a ski lift ticket: several films that were first shown here had been nominated for Academy Awards, including Little Miss Sunshine. It was, said the director of the festival, Geoffrey Gilmore, refreshing that the academy had recognized the quality of the storytelling and the talent of the actors in independent films that originally premiered here.

title: Fearing Protectionism, in India
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Israeli Panel Approves Suspending President in Sex Scandal
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 25  An Israeli parliamentary committee on Thursday approved President Moshe Katsavs request to suspend himself for three months as prosecutors prepare a case against him that could include charges of rape and other sexual misconduct.

title: G.M. Holds Results and Plans Big Restatement
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25  General Motors said Thursday that it expected to post a profit for the fourth quarter but that it would delay reporting the results because its finance arm needs more time to complete calculations.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,053 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: From a Rough, Nomadic Childhood to Young Motherhood
description: Mirza Norales remembers waiting for her mother to pick her up from the emergency room as midnight approached one summer night in 2000, but she never came.

title: Making Car of Tomorrow With Robotics of Today
description: CONCORD, N.C., Jan. 25  For all the technology that goes into stock-car racing, Nascar remains a labor-intensive competition, as each race car chassis is welded together by hand. That will change this year when Evernham Motorsports becomes the first Nextel Cup team to use robotics to aid in building racecars.

title: Some Pieces of Church Silver Dont Go Gently to the Auction Block
description: It is often controversial when an American church sells its antique church silver, as reaction to a Christies sale of early American silver shows once again. Its Jan. 18 auction included 14 pieces of church silver consigned by the First Church in Salem of Salem, Mass., all of which sold.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Two picture captions on Sunday with an article about the transformation of East Harlem from a Puerto Rican enclave to a more heterogeneous neighborhood misidentified the location of buildings being renovated or constructed. They are on 117th Street, not 116th.

title: At Last, Red Sox Will Sign Drew
description: The Boston Red Sox and outfielder J. D. Drew have resolved issues surrounding his five-year, $70 million contract, and Drews signing is expected today, The Boston Globe reported yesterday.

title: A Friendly Face With a Foul Mouth That Sings
description: Bridget Everett is, without a doubt, the life of the party. Whether its a party youd be interested in attending  or one youd instantly flee in search of Xanax  depends on your affection for big-boned, loudmouthed, dirty-talking girls with attitudes stretching from here to Kansas.

title: Acceptance Notices Sent, Mistakenly, to 2,700 University Applicants
description: Oops. The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill sent e-mails to 2,700 undergraduate applicants earlier this week, congratulating them  mistakenly  on their admission to the school.

title: Tour Rookie Ties Course Mark and Best PlayStation Score
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 25  It is a bold golfer who can upstage Tiger Woods in his first tournament round of the year, but Brandt Snedeker has vowed to make inroads into Woodss television time.

title: Seeking Edge in China, Yankees Put Baseball First
description: The Yankees consider themselves the most driven team in a competitive sport, so their push to boost baseball in China is not purely altruistic. They believe there is talent to be cultivated in China, and when future prospects have a choice of where to sign, the Yankees want their brand and reputation to stand out.

title: Letters: Second-Home Appliances
description: To the Editor: Gadzooks! Ordeal by Appliance: Weekend Home Tales (Jan. 19) implies that only the wealthy with remote second homes have problems with appliance repair. Remember, lots of Americans with only one home live in equally remote areas. The problems you nicely detail are common to all of us: appliances dont last as long as they once did, hi-tech features exacerbate the problem, service is slow and decidedly low-tech. The rich, at least, are able to return home to their maids and housekeepers for solace. David Pevear Houston

title: Outside In
description: The American Folk Art Museums transporting exhibition of the scroll-like drawings of the Mexican artist Martn Ramrez (1895-1963) should render null and void the insider-outsider distinction.

title: EMI Merging Record Labels and Ousting Capitols President
description: EMI Group, the flagging British music conglomerate, reorganized its American unit yesterday by merging the operations of its two main record labels and ousting the president of Capitol Records, the bigger of the two.

title: A Mystery Heard on Radio: Its Sterns Show, No Charge
description: Howard Stern, whose satellite radio show is typically available only to subscribers willing to pay $12.95 a month, has sworn that he will never return his morning show to the free commercial airwaves.

title: Showing Young Skiers That Really Cool Athletes Wear Helmets
description: FIVE years ago, Dr. Robert Williams, a Vermont pediatrician and critical care specialist, lay in his own hospitals intensive care unit after a nasty mountain biking accident. Dr. Williams had a variety of serious injuries, including internal bleeding, but he had not sustained a head injury.

title: United Ways Top Executive Says He Will Retire in the Summer
description: Lawrence Mandell, president and chief executive of the United Way of New York City, stunned the staff of the organization yesterday by announcing that he would be retiring in June.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: A Return Trip to a Faraway Place Called Underground
description: Time is forever. Love is the goal. Art is what you are, not what you do. Many young artists and poets in California in the 1950s and 60s felt and lived this way. And a traveling band of them, trailing a cloud of marijuana-fragrant air, has arrived at the Grey Art Gallery in Semina Culture: Wallace Berman & His Circle.

title: Rules Dispute Imperils Khmer Rouge Trial
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 25  The Cambodian judges were on one side and the foreign judges on the other this week in a dispute that captures a decade of difficulties in bringing to trial the last surviving leaders of the murderous Khmer Rouge.

title: What a Teacher Needs (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Get 5-Year Sentences in Seton Hall Fire
description: NEWARK, Jan. 26  Two former Seton Hall students were sentenced today to five years in prison after they admitted that they set a fire in a dormitory that killed three students and injured several others  an act one of them called a prank that got out of hand.

title: A Tough Quarter for Some Drug Makers
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday and ImClone Systems said its profit was lower than expected; both companies cited increased competition for their biggest drugs.

title: Old San Juan, for the Young
description: PUERTO RICO is a lush island, 100 by 35 miles, outlined by long stretches of white beach, which, for most tourists, are reason enough to visit. But on a recent trip with my husband and three children, I was struck by how much the island offers in addition to its coastline. As we discovered an array of historical sights and opportunities for natural adventures, I quickly concluded that giving up my beach chaise  at least part of the time  was a smart move.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,213,701.25

title: Federer Finds New Ways to Torment Roddick
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 26  When the reinvigorated Andy Roddick stepped onto the court Thursday to face his longtime tormentor Roger Federer, the consensus was that it was going to be a special evening at the Australian Open.

title: Bronx: Boy Dies After Night in Container
description: A 2-year-old boy was found dead in his Kingsbridge home yesterday after spending the night trapped inside a plastic storage container that he had climbed into during a hide-and-seek game with his siblings, the police said. The boys mother, whom neighbors identified as Rosa Lopez, discovered the 2-year-old, Anthony Pena, unconscious around 5 a.m., the police said, and he was pronounced dead when medics arrived at the apartment, at 3034 Albany Crescent. Ms. Lopez told the police that she put Anthony, his 6-year-old brother and his 3-year-old sister to bed about 9 p.m. on Wednesday, the police said. The siblings are believed to have shut the container with their brother inside, the police added. No charges have been filed. Neighbors reported hearing loud noises and fighting coming from the apartment during the night. The medical examiner is expected to conduct an autopsy today.

title: New Yorkers Feel an Unusually Frigid Day
description: So you dont like how frigid it is today in New York because youve gotten used to practically balmy, all but snow-free winter days. Well, dont run out yet to buy a new heavy parka.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Hollywood, the Sequel: Less Shabby, More Chic
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  For decades, tourists deposited themselves at one of the most famous intersections in America  Hollywood and Vine  and looked around in puzzlement, wondering what exactly they were supposed to be seeing.

title: 2nd Republican Enters Race for Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Representative Duncan Hunter, Republican of California, announced his bid for the presidency on Thursday in Spartanburg, S.C., then boarded a motor home to tour the state, where he hopes to gain support from a conservative electorate.

title: Wal-Mart Settles U.S. Suit About Overtime
description: The United States Labor Department announced yesterday that Wal-Mart Stores had agreed to pay $33.5 million in back wages plus interest to settle a federal lawsuit that accused the company of violating overtime laws involving 86,680 workers.

title: State Senate Approves Creating a Comptroller in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25  New Jersey could, for the first time, have a state comptroller with broad powers to audit and conduct performance reviews of state agencies, authorities, local governments and school districts under a bill that was narrowly approved by the Senate on Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture credit with an article on Sunday about criticism of the pace of an investigation into a crash in which a New Jersey State Police car struck a minivan in September, killing two teenage sisters, misidentified the source of one of two photographs. Only the picture on the right, of a memorial to the victims, was by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times. The other picture, of the victims and their mother, was provided by the family.

title: Manhattan: Prostitution Arrests at Scores
description: Seven people were arrested on prostitution charges at Scores West Side, a Chelsea nightclub, after an undercover operation on Wednesday night, the police said yesterday. Several dancers at the club engaged officers in sexual conversation and said sexual acts could be performed in rooms rented inside the club, the police said. The operation followed a complaint of prostitution at the club. Four women were arrested on charges of prostitution, and one woman and two men were charged with permitting prostitution, the police said. Mark Bederow, a lawyer for all seven, said his clients pleaded not guilty during their arraignments yesterday.

title: Option to Rent: Great New Jersey Views, Many Lanes, Tollbooths Included
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24  The New Jersey Turnpike has long been the subject of song and an object of scorn. And now Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who earned a reputation as a shrewd negotiator on Wall Street, is thinking seriously about leasing it out, banking on the hope that it and two other toll roads could fetch as much as $30 billion and hold the key to solving some of the states nagging fiscal difficulties.

title: Mama Was a Rolling Stone
description: To a certain kind of aesthetic traditionalist there is certainly no more alienating set of words in the artists vocabulary than the phrase mixed-media performance. Such an individual hears those words and fears, more often than not justifiably, the very worst  indulgence, discord, facile earnestness. The mixed-media performer can be prone to masquerading platitude (war is trying; love, unattainable; materialism, rampant) as position. And in delivering the masquerade in several formats with instruments, computer monitors, acrobats  the performer is suggesting that a mere barrage of images will compensate for all crimes of intellectual ambition committed.

title: Artistic Revival Takes Root Amid Relics of Copper Mines
description: BUTTE, Mont.  This is the city that copper built, in the mountains atop the Continental Divide.

title: Canada Reaches Settlement With  Torture Victim
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 26  Maher Arar, the Canadian software engineer who was detained by American officials in 2002 and deported to Syria, where he was kept captive for nearly a year and regularly tortured, will receive more than 10.5 million Canadian dollars ($8.9 million) in compensation from the Canadian government, under a settlement announced today.

title: Sharpton Goes to Washington to Talk to Partys 08 Hopefuls
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The Rev. Al Sharpton, a man who says he knows a well-tailored suit from a fake, went to the United States Senate on Thursday to do some comparison shopping, meeting separately with four Democrats who are seeking the 2008 presidential nomination to discuss civil rights.

title: A Familiar Rembrandt at a Formidable Price
description: A Rembrandt portrait of the Apostle St. James the Greater, his hands clasped in prayer, sold at Sothebys yesterday for $25.8 million. The winning bid was taken by Takako Nagasawa, a Sothebys representative in Asia, who was acting on behalf of a client identified by Sothebys only as a non-American old-master painting collector.

title: Louisiana: Federal Officials Pledge Help on Crime
description: Responding to an increase in violent crime in New Orleans, the Department of Justice announced it would assign agents to the Police Department around the clock to help identify cases that could be prosecuted by federal officials. In other federal efforts to help beleaguered local law enforcement officials, the department also said it would send more agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, expand the authority of Drug Enforcement Administration agents and extend financing for six additional federal prosecutors temporarily posted to the city.

title: John Lavelle, 57, New York Assemblyman, Dies
description: John W. Lavelle, the assemblyman for the 61st District and chairman of the Democratic Party on Staten Island, died Wednesday. He was 57.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Reich and Rollins Win Polar Prize

title: Women Pay for a Chance to Play
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22  They certainly looked like professionals, even if they werent.

title: Colleges Regroup After Voters Ban Race Preferences
description: With Michigans new ban on affirmative action going into effect, and similar ballot initiatives looming in other states, many public universities are scrambling to find race-blind ways to attract more blacks and Hispanics.

title: Renewal, in Real Estate and in Culture, for Ancient People
description: ROME, Jan. 25  As a boy, in October 1943, Pacifico Disegni watched from his window as two German trucks hauled people from the ghetto in Rome, a city where Jews have lived for 2,000 years.

title: The Presidents Risky Health Plan
description: The new health care proposals announced by President Bush this week purport to tackle the two toughest problems confronting the American health care system: the rising number of uninsured Americans and the escalating costs of medical care.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about changes in the National Football Leagues testing program for performance enhancing drugs misstated the mandatory suspension for a player who fails a second drug test. It is eight games, not one year.

title: Ford Chief Sees Small as Virtue and Necessity
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 25  Just 10 months ago, William Clay Ford Jr. vowed that his auto company, despite its mounting losses, would reclaim our legacy in the American car market and emerge stronger than weve ever been.

title: Running on Empty
description: Sorry to repeat myself, but I have the same reaction to this years energy proposals in the State of the Union that I had to last years. President Bush had the opportunity to launch America on a transformative new path for clean, efficient power. He had a chance for a Nixon to China moment  as the Texas oilman who leads us into a greener future. Instead, he gave us Nixon to New Mexico  right direction, but not nearly far enough.

title: Judge Urges U.S. to Drop Plan to Seek Death Penalty in Case
description: A federal judge, at the close of the death penalty trial of a convicted drug trafficker with ties to the rap music industry, called the governments effort to seek his execution absurd and a waste of money and urged prosecutors to ask their Justice Department superiors in Washington to abandon the endeavor.

title: Blackstone Raises Ante in Battle for Equity Office
description: The biggest leveraged buyout ever got bigger yesterday.

title: People
description: People

title: Amgen Finds Anemia Drug Holds Risks in Cancer Use
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  Amgen, the biotechnology company, said Thursday that its anemia drug Aranesp increased the risk of death when used to treat certain cancer patients, a finding that will probably raise more questions about it and similar drugs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart in Business Day last Friday about recommendations by industry and environmental groups on how to limit greenhouse emission misstated a goal of the coalition. The group wants to cut greenhouse emissions to 20 to 40 percent of current levels by 2050, not 60 to 80 percent of current levels.

title: Grading the Principal (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A New England Lakes Area as a Back-to-Basics Getaway
description: FEW souls roamed the normally busy byways of Ossipee, N.H., earlier this month, as 65-degree temperatures and a complete lack of snow beset this mountainous, lake-rich territory near the Maine border. A tiny group of young snowboarders in T-shirts rode the sole lift running at the King Pine Ski Area in nearby East Madison. But Main Street in Center Ossipee was empty, and Ossipee Lake itself seemed uncertain whether to keep its scrim of ice.

title: Manhattan: Drug Gangs Broken Up, Police Say
description: The Police Department announced yesterday that it had dismantled two drug organizations that were selling crack cocaine and marijuana in Washington Heights. One group was operating out of eight apartments in the Polo Grounds Houses, on Eighth Avenue near 155th Street, the police said. The other group, a subset of the Bloods street gang known as the Best Out, was earning about $10,000 a week from street-level sales in the same area, the police said. Officers began investigating the two groups last year, the police said. In raids yesterday, the police arrested more than two dozen people and seized cash, narcotics and two .22-caliber revolvers.

title: Nets Lose Close One, Again
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  For the third game in a row, the Nets lost by 1 point on their opponents final shot, this time falling to the Los Angeles Clippers, 102-101, at the Staples Center. The Nets are now 0-3 on their five-game trip out West, and they have yet to win a road game against a Western Conference team this season.

title: Debate in India: Is Rule on Yoga Constitutional?
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25  Hollywood celebrities swear by it. Yuppies the world over have fallen on their knees to embrace it. Now, the question of whether public school students in India should be required to take up the sun salutation, or surya namaskar as the common yoga exercise is known in Sanskrit, has engendered a legal and political row in this country, revealing lingering questions about how secularism is practiced and challenged in Indian politics.

title: Rodolfo and Mimi Soar Again
description: Not many tenors these days excel in the full-bodied, lyric Puccini and Verdi repertory once owned by the likes of Carlo Bergonzi, Giuseppe Di Stefano and Luciano Pavarotti. The closest we have may be the Italian tenor Marcello Giordani, who took over the role of Rodolfo on Wednesday night for the first of four final performances in the Metropolitan Operas current revival of Puccinis Bohme. His Mimi was the Chilean soprano Cristina Gallardo-Doms, which united the stars of the Mets acclaimed Anthony Minghella production of Puccinis Madama Butterfly.

title: Manhattan: New Post for Public Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday announced the creation of a new administrative position: chief executive for parent engagement, charged with ensuring a greater level of collaboration with parents and community groups that serve them. The chief executive, who is expected to be named this spring, will report directly to the chancellor. The announcement came at Mr. Kleins testimony at a City Council hearing, at which he was questioned on plans to change the school system.

title: Schumer to Democrats: Challenges Ahead
description: New Yorks senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, was a chief architect  along with Representative Rahm Emanuel in the House  of the Democrats 2006 campaign strategy that helped lead to their take-back of Congress in November, persuading incumbent Democrats in red states not to retire; countering Karl Roves much ballyhooed Republican machine with a hefty war chest and aggressive on-the-ground tactics of their own; and perhaps most important, recruiting and backing candidates (like Jon Tester in Montana, Bob Casey in Pennsylvania and James Webb in Virginia) who could compete in red-leaning states.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: On Being Partisan
description: American politics is ugly these days, and many people wish things were different. For example, Barack Obama recently lamented the fact that politics has become so bitter and partisan  which it certainly has.

title: Park, He Said
description: IT was only a matter of time before someone was able to spot the test driver deep within me. O.K., test parker: I was asked if I would do a road test of the self-parking device on the new Lexus LS 460 L. Although I like to think that I was being perceived as a laconic man with steel nerves and steady hands, I suspect that the invitation had something to do with my authorship of Tepper Isnt Going Out, which is considered by most scholars to have been the first parking novel. It might even have had something to do with the fact that in 1964 I was the founding co-editor of Beautiful Spot: A Magazine of Parking, which Ive seen referred to as a one-issue publication even though we prefer to say that the second issue hasnt come out yet. (Weve had some production difficulties.)

title: Immigration Raid Draws Protest From Labor Officials
description: An immigration raid at a huge North Carolina pork-packing plant provoked protests yesterday from union officials, who said the company, Smithfield Foods, had collaborated with the authorities searching for illegal immigrants to discourage its workers from organizing.

title: A Rocky Mountain Road to Happily Ever After
description: The Chamber of Commerce of Boulder, Colo., should be over the moon about the portrait of that city presented by the warm and fuzzy romantic comedy Catch and Release. It appears to be a clean, prosperous bohemian paradise where everyone is happy 90 percent of the time; even visitors from big, bad Los Angeles quickly mellow.

title: Days of Decision in Ulster
description: The militant Irish republican Gerry Adams and the fire-breathing unionist preacher Ian Paisley have long symbolized the irreconcilable extremes of Ulster politics. But over the next few days, they have the chance to lead the province into a new era of democratic self-rule.

title: Extra Innings Throws a Curve, and Fans Cry Foul
description: Jeanette Bottone cried last week when she heard that the Extra Innings package of major league baseball games that she has diligently watched on cable since 2002 was about to migrate to DirecTV in April.

title: Tremors at the Door
description: Wall Streets big bet on risky mortgages may be souring a lot faster than had been previously thought.

title: Nets Take Two Steps Back After a Big Step Forward
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  The Nets squandered double-digit leads in the fourth quarter and lost each of their first two games of their trip out West, a reflection of their inability to maintain a steady course this season.

title: Sharp Decline in Union Members in 06
description: Union membership dropped sharply last year in the United States, as the percentage of manufacturing workers in unions fell below the percentage of American workers in unions for the first time in modern history.

title: Pork Producer Says It Plans to Give Pigs More Room
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25  The worlds largest pork processor said on Thursday that it would phase out confinement of pigs in individual gestation crates over the next decade, a move animal welfare advocates said would end one of the cruelest practices in the agriculture industry.

title: Suspension Over, Albert Pirro Is Readmitted to Practice Law
description: After a federal conviction and suspension of his law license, Albert J. Pirro Jr., the husband of the former Westchester district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, was readmitted to practice law in New York this week, the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court said yesterday.

title: NATO Allies Wary of Adding Troops in Afghanistan
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26  Americas European allies remained noncommittal about sending additional troops to Afghanistan today, even as the Bush administration sought to inject new energy into the NATO mission against the Taliban by offering more American soldiers and money.

title: State Panel Selects 3 Likely Comptrollers
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25  Setting up a potential showdown with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a panel charged with picking the next state comptroller went against Mr. Silvers wishes in naming three finalists on Thursday, none of them members of the State Legislature.

title: About Those Fears of Wall Streets Decline ...
description: A LOT of smart people have spent a lot of time talking to a lot of important people about whether the financial services sector is becoming less competitive.

title: Art in Review
description: STEPHEN G. RHODES  Recurrency Guild & Greyshkul 28 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Queens: Community Center Audit
description: The city is considering legal action against employees of a Queens community center after an audit revealed that they received $178,530 in questionable payments, officials said. The audit, released yesterday by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., was ordered after suspicions of financial irregularities at the center, the Pomonok Neighborhood Center in Flushing, surfaced in 2005. The center has city and state contracts to provide after-school programs, housing assistance and other services. According to the audit, the centers youth program director may have padded the time sheets for himself, his daughter, his live-in companion and her son, who were hired in violation of rules against nepotism. The audit also questioned salary payments to 27 other people.

title: Lessons at Princeton (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Caliendo, Madden, Sandomir and Cosell
description: For those who read Richard Sandomirs article on Frank Caliendo but havent seen Caliendos impersonations of John Madden and others, click on the YouTube link.

title: Bears-Patriots, Super Bowl XX
description: Welcome to another episode of Classic Times Rewind. This selection, on Super Bowl XX in 1986, should make Bears fans happy. Theyve been a little cranky lately about their team being considered underdogs against the Colts. That wasnt a problem against the Patriots, of course, and the Bears are back in the Super Bowl after a 21-year absence.

title: This Land: Here Lies Sitting Bull...
description: Stand before the monument of the world-famous Native American and wonder, along with the rest of the Dakotas: Is Sitting Bull here?

title: Do Co-op Candidates Have to Give Notice?
description: Q Is there a law that says that someone who wants to run for office on a co-op board must give notice before the annual shareholders meeting? Recently, at our annual meeting, a shareholder was told she could not run because she did not tell the president before the meeting that she wanted to.

title: Federer and Roddick
description: A pause during a football dead spot to ask this question:

title: A Showdown on Ice
description: For two small towns in northwest Minnesota, hockey is not just a sport, it's a way of life.

title: Put Me In, Coach
description: Choose your team colors and have a field day. Shoulder pads optional.

title: Spyker on the Heals of Ferrari and McLaren
description: in the luxury car market, that is

title: The Sounds of Music
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pulse
description: Digital puppetry, a new holistic canine grooming, what Manuela Testolini Nelson is wearing now and more.

title: The Making of 'Lily'
description: A behind-the-scenes look at how a dress is made at Lanvin.

title: The Davos View on Iraq
description: Ive been running around the World Economic Forum here in Davos and havent had much of a chance to post here. Sorry about that.

title: Tremors at the Door for Subprime Mortgage Lenders
description: The once booming market for home loans to people with weak credit  known as subprime mortgages and made largely to minorities, the poor and first-time buyers stretching to afford a home  is coming under greater pressure. The evidence can be seen in rising default rates, increasingly strained finances at mortgage lenders and growing doubts among investors. Now, Wall Street firms, which had helped fuel the growth in the market by bankrolling and investing in subprime mortgage lenders, have begun to pinch off the money spigot.

title: EMI to Merge Record Labels
description: EMI Group, the flagging British music conglomerate, reorganized its American unit Thursday by merging the operations of its two main record labels and ousting the president of Capitol Records, the bigger of the two. The moves were the most notable so far in a worldwide revamping that started two weeks ago, when EMI, which releases music from acts including Coldplay and Norah Jones, forced out the global chief of its music division.

title: The Name Is Power and It Fits
description: As the Power Corporation closes in on a $3.9 billion deal with the Marsh & McLennan Companies to acquire its Putnam Investments Mutual Fund unit, The New York Times takes a look at one of Canadas largest financial services companies and Quebecs pre-eminent newspaper publisher.

title: Ex-NBC Official Charged in Theft
description: Federal authorities have arrested a former treasurer of the media conglomerate NBC Universal on charges of stealing more than $800,000 to finance private jet flights, liquor and a vacation home. The former treasurer, Victor Jung, is charged in the indictment with two counts of wire fraud, according to the statement from the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. He pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in Manhattan and was released on a $250,000 bond. He plans to vigorously defend himself against these charges, Mr. Jungs lawyer, Christopher Brennan, told Reuters.

title: Icos Shareholders Approve Eli Lilly Deal
description: Shareholders of Icos approved a $2.3 billion buyout offer on Thursday from Eli Lilly, a deal that would combine the companies behind the impotence drug Cialis. The transaction is expected to close on Jan. 29. ICOS said 77 percent of the shares that were voted in a special meeting favored the takeover.

title: The New Media World, According to Eisner
description: Former Walt Disney Chairman and Chief Executive Michael Eisner has been exercising his deal-making skills since leaving the Mouse House more than a year ago. Through his investment vehicle Tornante, which is backed by the $1 billion he pocketed during his tenure at Disney, Mr. Eisner has been trying his hand at new media. He bought Team Baby Entertainment, which makes sport-themed DVDs for children, and, most recently, purchased in a a stake in YouTube challenger Veoh Networks.

title: Lay and Others Dropped from Enron Suit
description: A judge granted a request by former shareholders and investors suing Enron to drop several individuals and firms, including Enrons late founder, Kenneth L. Lay, from the lawsuit. The regents of the University of California, the lead plaintiffs in securities litigation against Enron and several banks, asked for the dismissals last year. Judge Melinda Harmon of the U.S. District Court approved the request Wednesday in the class-action lawsuit.

title: Midwest Board Urges Shareholders to Fly Alone
description: Taking a page out of Delta Air Lines managements playbook, the board of Midwest Air Group has recommended shareholders reject a buyout offer worth $345 million by AirTran Holdings, saying that it would be better off alone. The Milwaukee-based parent of Midwest Airlines said Thursday the board unanimously recommended that shareholders reject the revised $13.25-per-share offer and not tender their shares to AirTran.

title: On One YouTube Competitor, All Joking Aside
description: One of the gazillion online video start-ups trying to take on YouTube has apparently come up with an new angle: serious thought. Instead of humorous videos of people dancing around their living rooms in their underpants, FORA.tv offers clips from a V.I.P. dinner the night of the State of the Union address, a talk by former President Jimmy Carter on C-SPAN and a presentation on global warming by a quantum physicist, CNEt News.com says.

title: From Davos, NYSE Chief Says Tide Will Turn on Private Equity
description: John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, offered up some sobering words Friday about the explosive rise of private equity, which has swept many publicly traded companies off of the worlds major exchanges. He said, in effect: Theyll come back to us.

title: Time Warner Elects Motorola Chief and Its Own President to the Board
description: Motorola Chairman and Chief Executive Ed Zander and Time Warner President and Chief Operating Officer Jeffrey Bewkes have both been elected to join Time Warners board, the company announced Thursday. Richard Parsons, Time Warners board chairman and C.E.O., credits Mr. Bewkes with helping him turn around Time Warner and leading the AOL transition, while Mr. Zander brings mobile communications expertise to the table.

title: Macquarie Buys Dallas Publisher
description: American Consolidated Media, a Dallas-based publisher of 40 local newspapers in Texas and Oklahoma, said Thursday that it has agreed to be acquired by Australias Macquarie Media for $80 million. The privately held newspaper group, whose owners include founder Jeremy Halbreich, BancBoston Ventures and Halyard Capital and Arena Capital Partner, will receive either cash or stock from the buyer, a subsidiary of Macquarie Bank.

title: Canadian Grain Company Ups Offer for Rival
description: Saskatchewan Wheat Pool added a cash component to its C$700 million ($591 million) hostile offer for Agricore United late Thursday in a move to persuade Agricore shareholders to back a proposed merger of Canadas two biggest grain handlers. Under the new bid, Agricore shareholders may receive C$11.33 in cash or 1.3601 SaskPool shares or any combination of the two.

title: Credit Suisse Said to Overhaul Bonus Plan
description: Credit Suisse has revamped its stock-based bonus plan in an attempt to retain staff earning more than $100,000 a year, Financial News reported. The new plan will affect more than 25 percent of the firms employees, mostly those working in the investment banking unit, the report said.

title: F.T.C. Approves Kinder Buyout, on One Condition
description: Pipeline giant Kinder Morgans plan to go private through a $22 billion management-led buyout cleared a major regulatory hurdle Thursday when the Federal Trade Commission gave its blessing after settling antitrust issues that the agency said could have fueled higher gasoline prices in the Southeast. The F.T.C. approved the buyout on the condition that the Carlyle Group and Riverstone Holdings, two of the investment firms participating in the deal, become passive investors in Kinder Morgan competitor Magellan Midstream Partners.

title: Many Who Can Invest in Hedge Funds Dont
description: Theres no question that hedge funds and private equity investments have dominated the business headlines for the last year. But, asks Fortune, does that mean that individuals are actually flocking to these high-risk, high-return funds? The, answer, says the magazine: Not as much as you might think. It cites a recent study that shows that 40 percent of millionaire investors surveyed had no allocation whatsoever in alternative investments, including private equity, hedge funds and commodities.

title: Eddie Bauer Buyout Delayed Due to Accounting Glitches
description: Eddie Bauer said Thursday that it delayed a shareholder meeting to vote on a $286 million buyout plan after finding tax accounting errors. The errors, which cover 2005 and earlier years, relate to the determination of deferred tax assets and goodwill on its balance sheets, arising from the treatment of leasehold improvements. In November, Eddie Bauer agreed to a buyout by private-equity firms Sun Capital Partners and Golden Gate Capital for $286 million, plus the assumption of $328 million in debt.

title: Schwab C.F.O. to Step Down
description: Discount brokerage Charles Schwab said Thursday that its chief financial officer since 1999, Christopher Dodds, will retire on May 18. Mr. Dodds, who is 47, joined the company in 1986. He will be succeeded by senior vice president and treasurer Joseph Martinetto. Forbes.com notes that Mr. Dodds is just the latest finance chief at a Wall Street firm to leave the post behind.

title: Lazard Chiefs Stock Rises
description: Lazard awarded Chairman and Chief Executive Bruce Wasserstein $18 million in restricted shares, 80 percent more than a year earlier, after the stock rose 48 percent in 2006, according to a federal filing. Mr. Wasserstein, received 359,425 shares on Jan. 23, when the stock closed at $50.08, the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission said. He can sell half of the shares on March 31, 2010, and the other half a year later.

title: Equity Office Bids May Go Higher, Analysts Say
description: As the biggest leveraged buyout ever got bigger Thursday when the Blackstone Group increased its bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to a whopping $54 a share, market watchers fell over themselves trying to guess if a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust would be forced to up its bid. But even more than that, analysts and other industry watchers, who can sometimes take a been-there-done-that attitude toward bidding battles, seemed on the edge of their ringside seats, caught up in the high-stakes (and high-price) war for the nations largest office landlord, with nearly 600 buildings across the country.

title: Morgan Stanley and Swedish Group Buy Healthcare Firm
description: Investor, the holding company of the Swedish billionaire Wallenberg family, teamed up with Morgan Stanley to buy Moelnlycke Health Care for 2.85 billion euros ($3.7 billion) including debt. Stockholm-based Investor and Morgan Stanley will buy the maker of surgical gloves from London-based Apax Partners. Investor said it is financing the purchase mainly with debt

title: About Those Fears of Wall Streets Decline
description: What has become of the Sheriff of Wall Street? In what the New York Times Jenny Anderson describes as an interesting about-face, Eliot Spitzer, the newly-elected governor of New York, has added his voice to the growing battle cry that New York risks losing its pre-eminence if the Sarbanes-Oxley Act is not amended and litigation not curtailed. Interesting, Ms. Anderson says, because the enforcer turned laissez-faire governor was not long ago a prosecutor blazing through Wall Streets boardrooms and ridiculing regulators for not cracking down enough.

title: Anchors Ties to Citigroup Attract Scrutiny
description: The connection between the ouster of Todd S. Thomson, long viewed as a possible future chief executive of Citigroup, and his relationship with Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, has been the talk of the financial services community since the banking giant announced this week that Mr. Thomson would be leaving the company. Much ink has been spilled on reports of Citigroup executives being pushed off overseas flights on the corporate jet so that Mr. Thomson could fly alone with Ms. Bartiromo, expensive dinners at Daniel and other juicy tidbits.

title: Delta Creditors May Ask US Airways to Extend Deadline
description: Delta Air Liness creditors may ask US Airways Group to extend the Feb. 1 deadline on its hostile takeover bid as they study competing plans for the bankrupt carriers future, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources. The nine-member unsecured creditors committee is split between those favoring a quicker payback of their claims through a US Airways merger and those benefiting more if Delta stays independent, the unnamed sources said. An extension would give the creditors panel more time to debate US Airways merger plan as well as Atlanta-based Deltas bid to leave bankruptcy as a stand-alone airline by mid-2007. Kelly Sullivan, a spokeswoman for US Air, said that the committee has not asked for an extension of the deadline.

title: Industrial Bank Wins Record I.P.O. Subscriptions
description: Industrial Bank, a midsize Chinese lender, attracted a record 1.16 trillion yuan ($150 billion) in subscriptions to its Shanghai initial public offering, reflecting the current mania for Chinese stocks.

title: Nasdaq Will Not Raise L.S.E. Offer
description: Nasdaq said it will not raise its 2.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion) offer for London Stock Exchange, as the clock runs down on the bid. The U.S. stock market said Friday that the L.S.E. has not responded to its offer, and now there is now insufficient time to effect any revision of the final offers via constructive dialogue. Nasdaq had previously said it would only consider raising the bid if the British markets board recommended the offer by Jan. 27. But the L.S.E. has repeated rejected the offer as inadequate.

title: KB Home Says It Faces S.E.C. Options Inquiry
description: KB Home said Friday that the Securities and Exchange Commission has launched a formal investigation into how it granted stock options to employees. The homebuilders chief executive, Bruce Karatz, stepped down in November after it was disclosed that he received favorably dated option awards.

title: Davos in the Papers: Second Life, W.T.O. Talks, C.E.O. Pay
description: Virtual world Second Life is a hot topic at the World Economic Forum this year, according to The Independent. Indeed, even the forums founder and chairman, Klaus Schwab, has his own avatar, or virtual identity, and Reuters is conducting interviews with major players at Davos at its virtual bureau in the Second Life realm.

title: The War at Home: Modes of Objection
description: President Bush is meeting with House Republicans today in Cambridge, Md., at their annual retreat. White House officials said he would cover a broad range of issues, but he also is expected to try to garner broader support for his troop-increase plan for Iraq. (Meanwhile, CNN is reporting this morning that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is leading a delegation on a trip to Iraq.)

title: Filmfest in Room 777 Brought to You by an IBM Laptop
description: You dont have to be in Sundance these days to enjoy a moody, serio-comic film school short. Now if the Bagger can just get some popcorn from room service, hell be all set.

title: Davos Diary
description: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin offers an overview of Day 2 at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: This  American Television Show
description: indieWIRE brings us news from off the movie grid, but still very much worth knowing. Showtime will be bringing This American Life, the home of the best stories on radio, to a television screen near you.

title: Davos Tries Fewer Stars
description: There has been some grumbling on the ground here at Davos about this years celebrity-free (or nearly so) approach. The no-celebrity thing was a big mistake, one of the worlds largest financiers, who asked for anonymity, told The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin at a party sponsored by Forbes. The celebs added a sense of energy and spice to the forum.

title: The Best Sundance Ever
description: French director Luc Bresson, he of La Femme Nikita, brought Angel-A, his new film, to Sundance and called it a very pleasant experience.

title: Posting the Mortem
description: All of the crows are coming off the wire, caw-cawing about how the parade float that was Dreamgirls wound up in a muddy ditch. No one really knows why it didnt get nominated for best picture, but it may be some consolation to its backers that they saved the $10 million or so they would have spent flogging the film for an award that, its now clear, it wouldnt have won, even if it had snuck in as the fifth nominee.

title: Smoke, Mirrors & the Size of Women
description: Spain will, for the first time, be standardizing its clothing for women. Seems until now, it was something of a crapshoot when shopping for a blouse in, say, Barcelona  where as BBC News points out today, a European size 40 in one shop (roughly a size 10 in the United States) could mean something completely different in another.

title: Where it All Began
description: Defamer points us to The Smoking Gun, which has uploaded, from a copy of the script, the scene from Hounddog that kicked up all the fuss.

title: Inside the Burning Crusade
2008 Like Its Today: Race and the Race
description: Dont limit your presidential campaign because of race, Harold Ford Jr. advised Senator Barack Obama. Some speculate that race contributed to Mr. Fords defeat in the Tennessee Senate election. Mr. Obama told The Chicago Tribune that hes not sweating race, when it comes to wooing the black vote.

title: Five Not-So-Easy Pieces
description: Without Dreamgirls, the little juggernaut that couldnt, Oscar Ninnies have been staring at the revised Final Five: Babel, The Departed, Little Miss Sunshine, The Queen and Letters From Iwo Jima. Which one will win for best picture?

title: Outsourcing the War
Bushs Disastrous Omission
description: Do you know what it means to miss New Orleans? President Bush does, after omitting the subject of the Crescent Citys post-Katrina catastrophe entirely in his State of the Union address. Congress and the nation heard nothing, zilch, nada, not a single, solitary word about New Orleans, the Gulf Coast and the devastation that remains from the worst natural disaster in United States history, writes Washington Post columnist Eugene Robinson. A disaster that happened on his watch. Robinson continues:

title: Marsh Chief May Withdraw Putnam from Sale
description: Marsh & McLennans chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, might yet throw a wrench into the insurance brokerage giants plans to sell its Putnam Investments unit. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Cherkasky said that he is keeping all options on the table  even backing away from selling the unit to Canadas Power Corporation. Mr. Cherkasky told Reuters: It is always complicated. It is a terrific company.  At the same time, if someone had the structure of a deal and the certainty for our shareholders, we would be interested. It is about weighing a number of factors. Several analysts said they see an effort by Marsh to negotiate better terms from Power; specifics of that deal have not been publicly disclosed.

title: Frances Lyonnais to Kick Off I.P.O.
description: Frances top soccer club, Olympique Lyonnais, plans to raise up to 103 million euros ($132.9 million) through the countrys first soccer-based I.P.O. soon, the Financial Times reported Friday. The Lyons-based club said that it hopes to sell up to 4.24 million new shares at 21 euros to 24.40 euros apiece. At the top end of the range, the I.P.O, would value parent company OL Group at 331 million euros, the paper said. The companys two top shareholders, Chief Executive Jean-Michel Aulas and the French movie company Path, will retain control of the team.

title: Court Dismisses Claims of Additional Spying by H.P.
description: A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard by a former executive who claimed the computer maker obtained his phone records illegally. H.P. has accused Karl Lamb of stealing trade secrets to start up his own flat-panel display company. Mr. Lambs lawsuit briefly re-raised the specter of pretexting, or the obtaining of personal information under false pretenses. Former H.P. executives, including ex-chairwoman Patricia C. Dunn, still faces charges that they authorized private investigators to pretext board members and reporters in the course of a leak investigation.

title: NYSE Chief Says Tide Will Turn on Private Equity
description: John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, offered up some sobering words Friday about the explosive rise of private equity, which has swept many publicly traded companies off of the worlds major exchanges. He said, in effect: Theyll come back to us.

title: The Pushback
description: Assemblyman  and passed-over comptroller candidate  Joseph D. Morelle was up on Fred Dickers radio show this morning, and between what hes saying, and what various members told us last night, you can get a pretty good sense of the Assemblys talking points about yesterdays selection of three finalists for the comptrollers job, none of them state lawmakers.

title: The Web Cuts Both Ways
description: The expanding reach of the Internet has allowed communities such as MySpace to flourish, but it has also created a global platform for extremists and terrorists to spread their views. That was one of the themes to emerge from a Friday session called Who Will Shape the Agenda?, whose panelists included media magnate Rupert Murdoch and Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein.

title: Gremlins Crack Copy Protections  Again
description: Demonstrating once again that even the best anti-copying schemes can succumb to the ravages of dedicated scofflaws who dont quite subscribe to the same philosophy regarding intellectual property as, say, the movie and recording industries, a renegade programmer going by the name muslix64 has figured out a way to bypass the encryption on high-definition DVDs and on another type of high-density optical media disc, known as Blu-ray.

title: More From Vanguard Chief John Brennan
description: In October, investments in mutual funds passed the $10 trillion mark, according to the Investment Company Institute. The mutual fund company, Vanguard in Valley Forge, Pa, has more than $1.1 trillion of that amount under management.

title: Bush on Congress and Anti-Surge Moves
description: In a brief Q & A at the White House this morning, President Bush thanked the Senate for unanimously confirming Army Lt. Gen. David Petraeus as his new commander of United States forces in Iraq.

title: Spinning Google and YouTube Into Gold
description: Riding two of the Internets big success stories, Google and YouTube, venture capitalist Michael Moritz of Sequoia Capital took the No. 1 spot on Forbess latest Midas List, an annual ranking of the top 100 dealmakers in technology and the life sciences.

title: Concerns Over Ethics Reform
description: Albany Wonk Watch!

title: Real Technology, Dismal Movie
description: I saw the Harrison Ford movie Firewall in a hotel room the other day. The moviegoing public at IMDB.com (Internet Movie Database, the Internets headquarters for movie ratings) gave it an average rating of only 5.8 out of 10, which is shockingly low for IMDB. Ford has a loooooooooooong, boring resume of playing dull bourgeois men who are attempting to find their misplaced wives or prove they didnt kill someone; Presumed Innocent, Frantic, The Fugitive, this, writes one commenter.

title: As Housing Slumps, Deal Talk Builds
description: Consolidation may be coming among publicly traded homebuilders as the housing market continues to sink, according to an article in BusinessWeek. As if to reinforce the point, the Commerce Department on Friday reported that sales of new homes last year fell by the largest amount in 16 years, though sales rose by a better-than-expected 4.8 percent in December.

title: War at Home: Hoyers Turn to Talk
description: This is probably going to be a fairly heavy weekend of anti-war speeches and protests, with more than the usual pundits weighing in.
