With President Bush promoting his way forward, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi touching down in Baghdad, and several 2008 potential contenders on the road, the war of words is heating up.

title: Show Us Your Carbon
description: Chief executives at Davos are ballyhooing the time and resources they devote to fighting climate change. But investors at the World Economic Forum say they want to see more evidence that these titans of industry will be able to turn a profit in a warmer  and more heavily regulated  world.

title: The Other Breakfast of Champions  Now Even Easier
description: Whether necessity truly gave birth to this invention is an open question, but at least one molecular scientist in Durham, N.C., apparently felt the traditional coffee-and-a-doughnut breakfast was just too much of a time-suck.

title: F1 on About.com  and Yours Truly
description: I wanted to let you know that as of today, a project that I have been working on for the past couple of months went live on the web: I have become the Formula 1 Guide at About.com. I think the two sites fit nicely together: In addition to this anything-goes F1 blog, the IHT web site runs my stories that appear in the newspaper. The About.com F1 space is also a reference site with links to information and above all, original content written by me, the Guide, specifically for that site. It has several other features as well, including a blog and a forum, so if you dont see something here, you may see it there  and vice versa. Actually, the best way to understand it, is to go and check it out at http://formula1.about.com  so Ill stop talking about it here!

title: After the Gold Rush
description: The last time the Bagger saw his colleague Manohla Dargis at Sundance, she was speed walking to what was probably her fourth film of the day. (A Sundance vet, she ignores the transport system, which zips along with all the speed of a dark examination of the human soul by a first-time filmmaker.) Today, she teases apart the good, the bad and the downright ugly, and finds a few that were worth the walk. Oh yeah, and an empty box.

title: How Our Kids Spent Our Winter Vacation
description: Alison and I thought we were renting a house in the tiny town of Anna Maria, Fla., to have a chance to relax, soak up some sun on a deserted beach, and read a few novels.Silly us.

title: Can Tech and Private Equity Make a Happy Couple?
description: The recent increase in private-equity deals in the technology sector raises what the Red Herring calls a fundamental question: Is private equity good for an industry in which research and development, capital investment, and recruiting and retaining top talent are critical elements for long-term success? It sounds like begging the question. Private equity players  rightly or wrongly, the Herring says  have a reputation for working against all those elements in one way or another, at least in the way they normally operate (piling on debt, slashing costs and taking a big payday for themselves upon their quick-as-possible exit).

title: Perella Lures 2 Morgan Stanley Bankers, Report Says
description: In potentially another coup for Joe Perella, his boutique investment bank has snatched two high-level bankers from his old stomping grounds at Morgan Stanley, Reuters reported Friday. The newswire said that Perella Weinberg Partners had poached Scott Bruckner, who was co-head of the European technology group, and Arnaud Dassy, an executive director on the telecom team. Mr. Bruckner was to have transferred to New York from London to take the helm of the East Coast technology team.

title: Its My Party
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Jan. 26 column, On Being Partisan.

title: Getting Off the Ground
description: As part of the U.S. effort to make the Iraqi military independent, American advisors are working with veteran Iraqi helicopter pilots.

title: Taking the Lame Duck to Task on Energy
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 26 column, Running on Empty.

title: Shandling Spars With Baldwin
description: An excerpt from "Not Just the Best of the Larry Sanders Show," featuring a sparring scene between Garry Shandling and Alec Baldwin.

title: Credit Check
description: Theres big news in the little world of Oscarville. The producers wing of the Academy Awards had some nasty math to work through last night, and the Bagger just got an e-mail from the Academy announcing that it will credit only one person as the producer of The Departed, while little Miss Sunchine will have three.

title: Nasdaq Extends Deadline for L.S.E. Bid
description: In what is its really, truly, final offer, Nasdaq said Friday that it would extend its deadline for London Stock Exchange shareholders to accept its 2.7 billion pound ($5.3 billion) merger offer. That bid will now expire Feb. 10, pushed back from Feb. 1. Earlier Friday, the U.S. exchange said that it would not raise the price it was offering for its British counterpart. Now, Nasdaq cannot raise its offer unless the L.S.E. agrees, or if it comes in response to another party. The U.S. exchange already owns almost 30 percent of the L.S.E.; but under British law, if this deal fails it must wait six months before it can bid again.

title: A Polite Protestor (Virtually) Barges In
description: Demonstrators are usually kept far from the action at the World Economic Forum in Davos, where security measures include barricades and barbed wire.

title: Spitzer: Choose From the Three
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, cornered for a moment in the capitols cafeteria, has this to say about the comptroller process:

title: Midnight on the Rue Cambon
description: I leave the Valentino show (dreamy white dresses in Robert Ryman textures) and go with my driver, Bernard Alloux, to Chanel. It is cold, nearly 10 p.m., and the lights in the house are ablaze. Two models are ahead of me at the door. Karl Lagerfeld is still doing fittings, and the show is in 24 hours. For once I am glad Lagerfeld is running late. The studio wont be as crowded with editors. Andre Leon Talley and Michael Roberts, of Vanity Fair, will be there. But everyone else will be at Giancarlo Giammettis buffet dinner for Valentino, or tucked into their beds at the Ritz.

title: In the Living Room
description: Dries van Noten has opened a new boutique, at 7 Quai Malaquais, and apart from a few meals, I cant think of a better reason to come to Paris. The place is gorgeous, so unlike a store  with one room done as a kind of salon and another as a library, and without any pretense  that I think executives at LVMH across the Seine should pay attention.

title: Armani at the Moderne
description: Giorgio Armanis Priv show, at the citys modern art museum, starts almost an hour late, and probably thats because he has invited 600 people and arranged to have Katie Holmes and Cate Blanchett in his front row. The collection was inspired by India, with jewels and scimitars worked into the Italian silks, and everyone says it is Armanis best. Afterward, there is a dinner. Armani has placed himself between Holmes (in a sari-like green dress) and Blanchett (glamorous in a tight-fitting black suit, her hair in a flip). An English editor whispers that Armani will be dressing Blanchett for the Oscars. She had her fitting this afternoon, the editor says and rushes off.

title: Friends and Foreigners
description: Alber Elbaz, the Israeli-born, American-trained designer at Lanvin, received the Lgion dHonneur today in a small ceremony at the Ministry of Culture. After the red ribbon was pinned on Elbazs chest, he said he no longer knew where he belonged  not in Israel, not in America, and, he admitted with a smile, he had doubts about France. He then offered that he belonged to the world of women. Yet, wherever Elbaz has gone in his career he has had the support of two men: Ralph Toledano, the Chlo chief executive, who hired him years ago at Guy Laroche; and Pierre Berg, who put him at Yves Saint Laurent. They attend his Lanvin shows, and they were in the crowd today.

title: Google Guys Arent Writing Off Old Media
description: The sight of Larry Page and Sergey Brin is enough to strike fear into a newspaper editors heart. After all, the giant Internet company they founded, Google, has become a powerful force for democratizing the distribution of news, blogs and other forms of information, a trend that has left many in the industry bracing for the day when the print newspaper is dead.

title: Spitzer on Health: Lets Save Billions
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer delivered a healthcare policy address today ahead of his executive budgetwhich comes out Wednesdaycalling for an overhaul that would save taxpayers billions of dollars.

title: Wheres the Decider?
description: Goodbye, decider. Hello, decision-maker.

title: Memorial for Disabled Vets
description: Gary Sinise, the actor/musician known widely for his iconic role as Lt. Dan Taylor in Forrest Gump, was in Washington today to celebrate the planned construction of a new memorial that would recognize 3 million disabled military veterans.

title: BofA and Countrywide Said to Discuss Alliance
description: Bank of America and Countrywide Financial have held discussions about an alliance that could eventually lead to an acquisition of Countrywide by Bank of America, The Financial Times reported Friday afternoon, citing unnamed sources. Such a deal would create the biggest mortgage lending group in the United States, joining Bank of Americas size and Countrywides significant lending business. Analysts said a Countrywide buyout could cost BofA about $30 billion.

title: Pentagon Debuts a Non-Lethal Ray Gun
description: The Defense Department has, for more than a decade, been quietly working on a non-lethal crowd dispersal weapon that is best understood in comic book terms: yes, it is, in form and function, a heat ray, and apparently it works pretty darn well  that is, if making people feel momentarily like theyre on fire, so theyll skedaddle, is the objective.

title: Pataki: If Iraqis Stand Up, Then Well Stand Up
description: New Yorks former governor staked out his own space in the middle of the Iraq debate today.

title: Cerberus May Pull Out of Delphi Deal, Report Says
description: Facing heat from the United Auto Workers over proposed pay cuts, hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management may withdraw a planned $3.4 billion investment in Delphi, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Cerberus, which agreed last month to lead an investment in the bankrupt auto parts maker, has been wrangling with the U.A.W. since then. If discussion stall, Delphi can ask a bankruptcy judge to void the unions contract, potentially leading to a strike that would cripple Delphis biggest customer, General Motors.

title: Movie Pitches From Sundance
description: The Carpetbagger solicits movie pitches at the Sundance Film Festival and tries to 'hit the slopes' before leaving town.

title: A Hedge Fund By Any Other Name
description: Fairly or not, hedge funds have a bit of a reputation problem in some circles. They are often used as cultural shorthand for fast, risky money. Just this week, German Chancellor Angela Merkel referred to hedge funds a headache in a speech to the World Economic Forum in Davos.

title: HOWJADOTHAT?
description: From time to time on this blog, Id like to show you how something is done, in the hopes of better explaining the creative process. Not long ago in New York, over lunch with the now-pinned Alber Elbaz, we got to talking about the trouble with futurism. At the spring 07 shows in Milan and Paris, futurism was suddenly the buzz word. But, as Elbaz pointed out, tomorrow is actually a difficult place to reach.

title: Blogtalk: A General Approval
description: As several states consider the merits of moving up their presidential primaries, as candidates declare themselves viable a year and 10 months before Election Day and voters wade through a historic field of potential presidents, blogs have no shortage of topics to ponder and insights to provide. And then of course theres Iraq.

title: Vows: Amanda and Duncan
description: Amanda Boyd found out that Duncan Yin was thinking about proposing to her when he was over an hour late to pick her up from the train station.

title: Davos Diary
description: Follow The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Giuliani, in New Hampshire, Discusses Iraq, but
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, ardent supporter of President Bush, the Iraq war and the presidents recent decision to send more troops to Baghdad, may have opened just a sliver of daylight between himself and the president tonight, in his first New Hampshire appearance since the November election. At the very least, he showed something less than the absolute confidence about the increase in troop strength that emanates from the White House, referring repeatedly to the prospect that more soldiers will not lead to success.

title: Suicide Bomb Erases a Fading Vestige of Joy in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 26  There used to be two great joys on Fridays for Iraqis in Baghdad: browsing the ancient bookshops, and exploring the Ghazil animal market, home to an extraordinary array of creatures.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture in some copies on Sunday about a 10-alarm fire that gutted a block of buildings in Elizabeth, N.J., carried an erroneous credit. It was by Aaron Houston for The New York Times, not Colin Archer of The Associated Press.

title: In Game of Risk and Reward, Tour Rookie Is a Good Bet
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 26  In two days at the Buick Invitational, Brandt Snedeker has become a favorite of the grandparents and the gamblers.

title: Taking Another Global Step, Minaya Leads Group to Ghana
description: On a continent teeming with untapped potential, on a sandy field that doubles as a soccer pitch, a cadre of baseball officials and former players hope to discover the next breeding ground for major league talent. But first, they have to teach its children how to play.

title: A Fund Giant Not Fretting About No. 1
description: In October, investments in mutual funds passed the $10 trillion mark, according to the Investment Company Institute. The mutual fund company Vanguard, based in Valley Forge, Pa, has more than $1.1 trillion of that amount under management. Last year, Congress passed the Pension Protection Act, which aims to encourage savings for education and retirement. For instance, the tax benefits for 529 plans, due to expire in 2010, are now permanent, as are the recent increases for yearly individual retirement account and 401(k) contributions.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the death of a shipyard worker at the Brooklyn Navy Yard misstated the given name of a spokesman for the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration who said the accident was being investigated. He is John Chavez, not Juan.

title: Carlos Lezama, 83, Dies; Shaped West Indian Parade
description: Carlos Lezama, who as president of the West Indian American Day Carnival Association transformed a Brooklyn block party into the citys largest parade, with millions of spectators lining two miles of Eastern Parkway each Labor Day to enjoy throbbing steel-pan bands, ostrich-plumed dancers and fantastical floats, died on Monday. He was 83.

title: Episcopal Leader Taking Over Newarks Flock
description: NEWARK, Jan. 26  When the Rev. Mark Beckwith becomes the 10th bishop to lead the Episcopal Diocese of Newark on Saturday, parts of the service will be read in English, Spanish, French, Korean and Malayalam, an Indian language, to reflect the tongues spoken by the dioceses 27,600 parishioners.

title: Daffy Does Doom
description: WASHINGTON

title: Trying to Keep Divinity ...
description: Depending on the day at her Methodist seminary, Jennifer Wilsford wants to be either a parish minister or a professor. Her seminary, for its part, has tweaked its curriculum, brings in speakers and tries to hold her hand through the logistics of ordination  all designed to nudge Ms. Wilsford and other seminarians toward the pulpit.

title: NATO Allies Wary of Sending More Troops to Afghanistan
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26  Americas European allies on Friday remained noncommittal about sending additional troops to Afghanistan, even as the Bush administration sought to inject new energy into the NATO mission against the Taliban by offering more American soldiers and money.

title: Hate Crime of Beatings Divides a Campus
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 26  In this business-minded Southern city that looks more like a sprawling suburb, Guilford College stands out like a hippie commune, a Quaker liberal arts school where students call professors by their first names and regularly stage antiwar protests.

title: Tennessee: Man Killed in Building Collapse
description: One construction worker was killed and another injured when a one-story brick building collapsed in Nashville, the police said. The workers  Richard Whiteshield, 57, of Clewiston, Fla., who was killed, and John Kemper of Hendersonville, Tenn., who was injured  were part of a crew that was using a jackhammer to dig up a gas main to the building, which was being demolished, said Kristin Mumford, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Police Department. The building, in the citys Berry Hill neighborhood, had been closed for some time, said Kim Lawson, the deputy fire chief.

title: Deadly Suicide Bomber Attack at Hotel in Pakistans Capital
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 26  A suicide bomber blew himself up outside a Marriott hotel here on Friday afternoon, killing himself and a security guard, the police and security officials said. At least five other people were wounded.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 9 about Momofuku Ando, the founder of the Nissin Food Products Company and the inventor of instant ramen, misstated his national origin. He was born in Taiwan during the Japanese occupation of Taiwan to Taiwanese  not Japanese  parents; he became a Japanese citizen after World War II.

title: Eye Drug Might Raise Risk of Stroke, Genentech Says
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26  Use of Genentechs new eye drug, Lucentis, might raise the risk of stroke, the company said Friday.

title: If Beauty Is Only Skin Deep, Look Really, Really Hard
description: Rhinos dont enjoy the household privileges of dinos and hippos. They make no claims of cuteness. They dont smile broadly on mugs, T-shirts and the bedsheets of toddlers; they dont pervade the work of Sandra Boynton. Surely it cant be that rhinos are the scariest of the three: nearly all of those big beasts can get ugly, and none would make good pets.

title: Feeling Healthy and Ready, Webb Takes Aim at the Mile
description: In 2001, Alan Webb broke the high school indoor and outdoor records for the mile and became the first prep runner to run a sub-four-minute mile indoors. Then came six years of occasional fast times interrupted by too few good races and too many injuries and illnesses.

title: Judge Puts Settlement on Katrina in Question
description: A federal judge in Mississippi, citing the need for more information, has rejected  at least temporarily  a settlement by State Farm Insurance that was expected to provide several hundred million dollars to help policyholders rebuild homes destroyed by Hurricane Katrina 17 months ago.

title: Sights Set on Title, Meissner Is All Smiles
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 26  Watching Kimmie Meissner practice her long program Friday afternoon, it was impossible to tell that she was less than a day from the finale of the United States Figure Skating Championships. She glided through her program, fell trying a few jumps, but picked herself up and skated back to her coach with a smile.

title: One NATO Is Not Enough
description: Carlisle, Pa.

title: Reserved Seats, and Tone, as a New Defense Chief Meets the Press
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates held his first Pentagon press conference on Friday, and it was nothing like those of his predecessor, Donald H. Rumsfeld.

title: Nasdaq Holds Firm on a Bid for London Stock Exchange
description: LONDON, Jan. 26  Nasdaq said on Friday that it did not plan to raise its offer for the London Stock Exchange, just before a deadline to do so, damping investors expectations. Investors have until Feb. 10 to tender their shares for a deal, but any changes in the bid would have to happen this weekend unless a rival bidder emerges.

title: Five Arrested in New Jersey in Illegal Sales of Painkillers
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26  Five people have been arrested on charges that they ran a drug ring that had sold more than $20 million worth of painkillers, or one million pills, law enforcement officials in New Jersey announced on Friday.

title: A Rocker Whos Come to Terms With Time
description: Bob Seger is 61, with gray hair and glasses. But he still goes to work in a T-shirt and bluejeans.

title: BMW Reports Record Sales; Porsche Posts Revenue Drop
description: BERLIN, Jan. 26 (Bloomberg News)  BMW, the German carmaker, posted record sales last year with new versions of the 3 Series car and X3 sport utility vehicle. Revenue at a German rival, Porsche, dropped for the first time in 14 years as demand for the Cayenne sport utility vehicle slumped.

title: The Dangers of Swinging for the Fences
description: There was once a pharmaceutical company that could do no wrong. It had the best-selling drug in the world. It saturated the airwaves with its ads, and swarmed doctors offices with its army of good-looking sales representatives. It had mastered the art of turning drugs into blockbusters. It made many billions in profits. Wall Street analysts loved it.

title: Pakistan and the Taliban (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: On Your Toes, Blokes, 2 Highnesses Coming  Charles and Camilla
description: It has been just over a year since their Wellington boots last sloshed about on these shores, and its not as though that trip  billed as their first official overseas tour since being married in April 2005  came off so smashingly that they, or an adoring American public, ought to be crying out for another.

title: Not Much Market for Worry Beads in the Executive Suites
description: To chief executives, the threat of global warming seems very real in Asia, but not in the United States or Russia.

title: At Rice, a Scorers Patience Is Starting to Pay Off
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 26  When Morris Almond chose to attend Rice four years ago over such traditional basketball powers as Indiana, Notre Dame and Virginia, everyone seemed to have the same quip.

title: Change Comes, Gradually, to the San Francisco Opera
description: Significant changes are happening in Americas opera landscape as new directors take over some of the countrys major companies. But in a field in which artists are booked several years in advance, it takes a while for season programs to reflect those changes.

title: Riding Perseverance to Finals in Australia
description: For Asha Price, watching from afar as her youngest sister made a remarkable run at the Australian Open has been a nerve-racking, eye-opening experience.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Weekend on Jan. 19 about the film Waitress, which was shown at the Sundance Film Festival, misidentified the role played in Mission: Impossible III by Keri Russell, the star of Waitress. She was a protge of Tom Cruises character, not his love interest. (That role was played by Michelle Monaghan.)

title: A Saxophonist Known for New Ideas Meets an Organist From the Old School
description: The saxophonist Greg Osby is one of the most specific writers and arrangers in jazz. He makes small-group music that can be aslant with odd or long meter, and serenely played; its not battering or superexpressive, but glows within its own tight structure. Always, he comes with a grid.

title: Relatives of Dorm Fire Victims Lash Out
description: NEWARK, Jan. 26  Anger, at once therapeutic and corrosive, along with memories still tender and painful were in the air of a crowded courtroom on Friday.

title: Williams Shocks Sharapova to Win in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 27  It has been two weeks of turning back the clock for Serena Williams, and under a closed roof during Saturdays Australian Open womens final, she completed her astoundingly quick trip back to dominance against the top-seeded Maria Sharapova.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map last Saturday showing parishes affected by the reorganization plans of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misidentified a Bronx parish scheduled for closing. It is St. Anthonys at 4505 Richardson Avenue, in the northern part of the borough  not St. Anthonys at 1496 Commonwealth Avenue, in the central Bronx. A corrected version of the map can be found at www.nytimes.com/2007/01/20/nyregion/20churches.html.

title: What Can Money Buy?
description: SEVERAL news reports, all relying on anonymous sources, have suggested that the Federal Communications Commission will soon announce a settlement with four major radio broadcasters over payola.

title: Curfew Is Lifted in Beirut, but Tension Lingers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26  Lebanese Army soldiers reinforced checkpoints and maintained a heavy presence in tense neighborhoods in Beirut on Friday, lifting a rare nighttime curfew that had been imposed to stop the worsening violence between pro- and antigovernment crowds.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart yesterday with an article about declining union membership gave outdated information on the states with the highest and lowest membership in 2006. The top states were Hawaii (24.7%), New York (24.4%), Alaska (22.2%), New Jersey (20.1%) and Washington (19.8%); the bottom states were Texas (4.9%), Georgia (4.4%), Virginia (4.0%), and North and South Carolina (both with 3.3%). The chart listed the 2005 rankings. (As the article noted correctly, the national average is 12 percent, based on 2006 figures.) (Go to Article)

title: An Open Job Opens a Rift in Albany
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26  It took less than a month for Gov. Eliot Spitzer to find himself on the precipice of an all-out political war with the man he replaced as the top Democrat in New York State government, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

title: Operetta and Weill in Front; Moving Shadows in Back
description: A silhouette of old lace blows across a screen above the stage, tangling with the shadows of the performers singing below. Then the shadows free themselves of the singers and begin to dance, as if giving life to the dreams in the music.

title: A Breadwinner Rethinks Gender Roles
description: WHEN my son was born last fall, my husband and I had a plan. After a short maternity leave, I would continue to work, and he would quit his job to take care of the baby.

title: At Lawmakers Retreat, G.O.P. Plots a Comeback
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md., Jan. 26  President Bush tried to rally House Republicans on Friday as the lawmakers hunkered down on the Eastern Shore and struggled to come to grips with their new minority status and the challenge of the continuing war in Iraq.

title: A New Wave Now Knits for the Rebellion of It
description: In 2000 the GetCrafty.com Web site offered a pattern for a crocheted skull (not for the faint of heart, or needle), recasting traditional womens work for the post-riotgrrrl era. That same year groups of women and the occasional sensitive guy began gathering on Sundays to swap ideas and patterns in an organization called the Church of Craft.

title: At Ease, Mr. President
description: Evanston, Ill.

title: Illegal Sublets Put Private Eyes on the Case
description: The house was one of those stucco numbers that grow in the suburbs like crab grass. The woman in question was a cagey brunette suspected of chiseling her landlord. She had a rent-regulated apartment in Manhattan that she seemed to be subletting illegally for twice what she was paying, while sleeping in the stucco house just outside the city.

title: Tokyo Cuts Aid, and Hinterland Withers in Japan
description: YUBARI, Japan  Buried in chest-deep snow, History Village sprawled across a valley here, undisturbed by the tourists it was supposed to attract.

title: In Fighting Disorder, Family Stays Vigilant
description: Norma Turner, 14, is her mothers daughter. Her mother, Kareen Brown, held a recent portrait of the two of them, which showed their striking resemblance. The same eyes, same face, same tendrils of hair, the same happiness shines out of the picture.

title: Touching a Nerve: Carter at Brandeis (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) NORA ROBERTS ANGELS FALL Heather Locklear plays Reece Gilmore, the sole survivor of a Boston restaurant massacre, who moves to a remote Wyoming town in the hope of rebuilding her life in this adaptation of a novel by Ms. Roberts. But one day, while hiking alone, she witnesses a murder  though no one can find evidence of a crime when they return to the scene. As more strange events start to occur, Reece begins to question her sanity. Now only Brody (Johnathon Schaech), her new love, believes in her.

title: Chemical Security: How the Industry Sees It (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Teenagers Convicted in Beating of 3 White Women
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 26  A juvenile court judge found nine black teenagers guilty Friday of beating three young white women with pumpkins, newspapers and a skateboard last Halloween in an attack that has shined a spotlight on racial tensions here.

title: Yes, She Has a Sweet Tooth, but Shes a Major Carnivore
description: Interspecies mating is always a challenge, particularly when one species likes to eat the other. In the lupine love triangle Blood & Chocolate, a reluctant Romanian werewolf named Vivian (Agnes Bruckner) spends her days making chocolates in a Bucharest candy store. If her customers could see how she celebrates the full moon, they would think twice before letting her handle their macaroons.

title: Bush Defends Moving Against Iranians Who Help Shiites Attack U.S.-Led Forces in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  President Bush and his senior aides on Friday justified American actions against Iranian operatives inside Iraq as necessary to protect American troops and Iraqis, and said they would continue as long as Tehran kept up what they called its support for Shiites involved in sectarian attacks.

title: Adrenaline on Display at Sports Convention
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 26  Wandering the teeming halls of the San Diego Convention Center on Friday afternoon, the former professional surfer Peter King said of the goings-on at an action sports trade show, Id say its a lot more fun than a Dell computer convention.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about the Juilliard Schools Focus Festival misstated the surname of the festivals longtime director. He is Joel Sachs, not Cohen.

title: Turning 60, and Doing So With 1,500
description: Not every Wall Street titan can celebrate his birthday in a place that holds 1,500 people. Unless, of course, that titan is Stephen A. Schwarzman, who is on the verge of clinching the biggest buyout deal ever.

title: In Battle to Bring in Catch, an Imaginative Angler Learns to Win by a Neck
description: Casting a fly properly is among the most beautiful movements in all of sport. Landing a hooked fish, on the other hand, has all the elegance of attempting a limbo dance on a roller coaster. Having a friend or guide net your fish is often the more practical approach.

title: Mexicos Latest War on Drug Gangs Is Off to a Rapid Start
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25  If any image can sum up President Felipe Calderns first eight weeks in office, it would be the sight of him dressed in military fatigues addressing troops he had sent into the state of Michoacn to corral narcotics traffickers.

title: In New Batch of 9/11 Calls, Confusion and Courage
description: The city yesterday released 19 recordings of telephone calls made to 911 operators from the World Trade Center on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: At Churches Set to Close, Faithful Dig In for Battle
description: A week after the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York released its final list of 21 parishes to be closed as part of a broad reorganization, some parishioners are digging in for a battle, enlisting help from parishioners in the Boston Archdiocese who successfully resisted some church closings there with round-the-clock sit-ins.

title: Driving the Precious Little Darlings (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Proposes Drafting Poll Workers to Ease Problems
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 26  The chronic shortage of election workers in Ohio could be solved by requiring residents to work at the polls the way they fulfill jury duty, the newly elected secretary of state says.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: In Last Three Games, Nets Are Missing the Point
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26  The Nets margin of error over the past three games can essentially be measured in three possessions and 3 points. The resulting burden has manifested itself in blank stares, mumbled answers and an unusually quiet locker room.

title: Porn Filmmaker Finds Out a K Can Be Owned
description: The cast was entirely Israeli. The script was entirely in Hebrew. The film was entirely treif.

title: Democrats Try to Increase Leverage Over Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Representative Steny H. Hoyer, the House majority leader, said Friday that Congress might consider legislation revising the authorization it gave President Bush in 2002 to use military force in Iraq.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 12 about Staten Island Chuck, a groundhog being prepared for his first Groundhog Day duty by commuting home with his trainer on weekends, included an outdated reference to the train system that Chuck travels on. Since 1994, it has been called the Staten Island Railway, not Staten Island Rapid Transit.

title: New Permits for Mass Bike Rides
description: The New York Police Department has adopted rules that require parade permits for bicyclists and others who take to the streets in groups of 50 or more for processions, races and protests.

title: Donald E. Osterbrock, 82, Who Studied the Cores of Galaxies, Dies
description: Donald E. Osterbrock, an astronomer and historian of science who studied the birth of stars and luminous clouds of gas at the core of galaxies outside the Milky Way and wrote an influential textbook about the subject, died on Jan. 11 in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 82.

title: In Top Shape, Gonzlez Aims to Topple Federer
description: MELBOURNE, Saturday, Jan. 27  Roger Federer has already snuffed out the hopes here of one longtime foil who thought that his improved backhand, soaring confidence and new American coach might help him break the habit of losing to the worlds No. 1 player.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 9 P.M. (Hallmark) TROY (2004). Pump me up: Brad Pitt flexes his muscles as the warrior Achilles in this action-heavy historical drama from Wolfgang Petersen, adapted by David Benioff from The Iliad by Homer and other sources, about the assault on Troy by Greek forces. The glossy cast includes Orlando Bloom as Paris, Diane Kruger as Helen, Brendan Gleeson as Menelaus, Eric Bana as Hector, Brian Cox as Agamemnon, Sean Bean as Odysseus and Peter OToole as Priam.

title: Mr. Bushs Oil Security Blanket
description: One of the stranger and so far unexplained items in President Bushs energy program is his proposal to double the capacity of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to 1.5 billion barrels, over the next 20 years. The proposal carries a $65 billion price tag  one of several reasons Congress should question Energy Secretary Samuel Bodman closely when he comes looking for the money.

title: Is Dividing Iraq Our Best Way Out? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Colorado: Ranchers Getting Loans
description: Farmers and ranchers in storm-plagued areas of southeastern Colorado who lost livestock in recent back-to-back blizzards will be able to obtain low-interest emergency loans of up to $500,000 from the United States Agriculture Department, federal officials said. As many as 10,000 head of cattle may have been killed by the storms, but the final count remains uncertain because many animals remain buried in snow. Losses are also mounting from the deaths of weakened animals. President Bush signed a declaration this month qualifying parts of Colorado, Kansas and Nebraska for federal disaster relief.

title: Art From Russia With Love (Cest Franais, Naturellement)
description: LONDON  The British have long conceded that the French invented the art of love. London, then, might offer the most receptive audience for The Triumph of Eros: Art and Seduction in 18th-Century France, a show that demonstrates through paintings, engravings and sculptures how the French turned loving into an amusing pasttime.

title: O.K., Financial Planners, Grab a Calculator and Lets Get Started
description: The only way to know whether you have saved enough for retirement is, when you suck in your last breath, for someone to show you your bank statement.

title: Flamenco That Finds Its Fit in a Space Between Two Styles
description: Not everyone wants to perform pure traditional gypsy flamenco. A grass-roots genre of flamenco Latino has sprung up in New York in recent years. The program presented by Andrea Del Conte Danza Espaa on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo fits somewhere between those styles, but never created the crucial flamenco feeling of an internal fire reaching up into the soul from the core of the earth.

title: Countdown to the Census
description: The accuracy of the census is determined in the planning stages, and planning for the 2010 count is already imperiled. The dangers fall into two categories: money (too little) and politics (too much). The new Congress will have to manage both vigilantly.

title: Romanias King Without a Throne Outlives Foes and Setbacks
description: BUCHAREST, Romania

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Oprahs New Reading Recommendation

title: Labor Union, Redefined, for Freelance Workers
description: Herding freelancers is a bit like herding cats. Both are notoriously independent.

title: The Bait-and-Switch White House
description: We often wonder whether there is a limit to the Bush administrations obsession with secrecy, its assault on the rule of law, its disdain for the powers of Congress, its willingness to con the public and its refusal to heed expert advice or recognize facts on the ground. Events of the past week suggest the answer is no.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart yesterday with an article about declining union membership gave outdated information on the states with the highest and lowest membership in 2006. The top states were Hawaii (24.7%), New York (24.4%), Alaska (22.2%), New Jersey (20.1%) and Washington (19.8%); the bottom states were Texas (4.9%), Georgia (4.4%), Virginia (4.0%), and North and South Carolina (both with 3.3%). The chart listed the 2005 rankings. (As the article noted correctly, the national average is 12 percent, based on 2006 figures.)

title: Finding a Famous Pairs Intensity and Sensitivity
description: Four men, their backs to the audience, stand in a line upstage at the beginning of George Balanchines Agon. Then they turn, and Stravinskys bright fanfare of trumpets heralds the start of the ballet that, in Balanchines words, used history as the takeoff point.

title: Ex-Executive of Computer Associates Receives Prison Sentence
description: A former executive with Computer Associates who pleaded guilty to securities fraud and who prosecutors said was instrumental in the prosecution of the companys former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced to seven months in prison and seven months of home detention.

title: Offering Help for Former Foster Care Youths
description: DETROIT  When current and former foster children formed a group to help youths who had turned 18 and were aging out of the system, one of the first things they did was hold a luggage drive.

title: U.N. Plan Paves Way for Kosovo Independence
description: PARIS, Jan. 26  The United Nations mediator Martti Ahtisaari presented his proposals for the final status of Kosovo on Friday, most likely setting the tiny war-torn territory on its way toward independence.

title: Picking New Yorks Comptroller
description: New Yorks Legislature is expected to choose a replacement soon for Comptroller Alan Hevesi, who resigned after pleading guilty last year to a felony. To inject some quality control into a process that could have been all political horse-trading, legislative leaders and Gov. Eliot Spitzer set up an excellent vetting process. Three former comptrollers  two Democrats and a Republican  screened candidates and were asked to pick up to five finalists.

title: U.N. Atomic Chief  Cites Iran Enrichment Plan
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 26  The head of the United Nations nuclear inspection agency said Friday that Iranian officials had told him that they planned to begin installing equipment next month in an industrial-scale plant to enrich uranium.

title: Woman Killed by Husband Provoked Family, Son Says
description: The son of an Upper East Side landlord accused of killing his wife in 2005 by stabbing her testified on behalf of his father yesterday, telling the story of a marriage that unraveled into madness.

title: Sgt. Preston, Where Are You? Dog Sledding Isnt Easy
description: I MOUNTED the runners of a dogsled on Eden Mountain in northern Vermont, bracing for my first solo mush. The sun sparkled on a snow-covered field framed by stands of sugar maple, beech, birch, spruce, pimlock and pine. A few yards away, my wife, Alison, and my son, Harrison, stared at me with disbelief.

title: Chinese Pipa Joins Russian Strings
description: Why a Russian string orchestra spent two hours playing Japanese and Chinese music at Zankel Hall on Thursday has one obvious answer. Everyone is across the street from everyone else these days and sends instant cultural messages back and forth. Differences remain. If Toru Takemitsus movie music is the last word in restrained elegance, the Moscow Soloists executed it sounding like 17 fine young performers who sort of play together.

title: X Games Veteran Is More Motivated, Not Mellowed, With Age
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 26  He was born for speed. In November 1968, his father sped a Camaro containing his mother through the San Diego night to a hospital, where Shaun Palmer was born. And so began a wild ride for one of the most accomplished and versatile action-sports athletes.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a pointed exchange between CNN and Fox News over a Web site report that said Senator Barack Obama had attended an Islamic school or madrassa in Indonesia as a child referred imprecisely to madrassas. While some teach a radical version of Islam, most historically have not. (Mr. Obamas office has said the report is untrue.)

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,060 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Arena Fit for Quinnipiacs Ambition
description: Last Saturday, New Haven Coliseum, once home to the popular but long ago dismantled Knighthawks of the American Hockey League, was demolished in favor of downtown redevelopment.

title: For TVs Trixie, the Honeymoon Lives On
description: It is 5:01 p.m. and Joyce Randolph, a k a Trixie Norton, is holding forth in the downstairs bar at Sardis, sipping her favorite formulation of the White Cadillac, Dewars and milk. I think it does your stomach good, she is saying. The Scotch. The milk.

title: Intel Says Chips Will Run Faster, Using Less Power
description: Intel, the worlds largest chip maker, has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for a new generation of faster and more energy-efficient processors.

title: Assembly Condemns Denial of Holocaust
description: The General Assembly adopted a resolution condemning the denial of the Holocaust, with only Iran, which was the host to a conference last month that cast doubt on the existence of the Holocaust, disassociating itself from the measure, which was drafted by the United States, co-sponsored by 103 countries and agreed to by consensus. Hossein Gharibi, the delegate from Iran, said that Israel exploited the sufferings of Jews as a cover to commit new genocide and crimes against the Palestinians. Dan Gillerman, the ambassador of Israel, responded, While the nations of the world gather here to affirm the historicity of the Holocaust with the intent of never again allowing genocide, a member of the Assembly is acquiring the capabilities of carrying out its own.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $7,363,501.28

title: Crawfords 52 Points Tie 5th-Best Knick Mark
description: When you are as hot, as brilliant and as close to perfect as Jamal Crawford was last night, the record shattering does not end at the final buzzer. An hour after Crawford lit up the Madison Square Garden scoreboard and the Miami Heat, he picked up his cell phone.

title: Pataki Opposes More Troops Unless Iraqis Do Their Part
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican who has steadfastly supported President Bushs Iraq policies, said on Friday that he would oppose Mr. Bushs plan for sending more troops to Baghdad unless Iraqi leaders took clearer steps to build a nonsectarian government.

title: 2 Face Charge of Murder in Deaths of 5
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 26  One week after a couple and their three young sons were killed in their home here, the New York State Police announced on Friday that they had arrested two men, one a close family friend, and charged them with second-degree murder.

title: Lyman Wynne, 83, a Leader in Research on Mental Illnesses, Dies
description: Dr. Lyman C. Wynne, a psychiatrist and psychologist whose research helped lay the foundation for family-based therapies for mental disorders, died on Jan. 17 in Bethesda, Md. He was 83.

title: Dan Christensen, 64, Painter of Abstract Art, Dies
description: Dan Christensen, an abstract painter best known for his unfettered use of color in various styles, including Color Field painting and lyrical abstraction, died last Saturday in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 64.

title: Spitzer Sees Health Savings; Hospitals Call Them Cuts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26 Gov. Eliot Spitzer said on Friday that he would seek billions of dollars in Medicaid and health care cost savings when he unveils his first executive budget on Wednesday.

title: Fashion Rituals and Runway
description: As any nature show will demonstrate, mammals use several methods for marking their territory.

title: Gap Is in Need of a Niche
description: In the fall of 2004, Gap put on a splashy ad campaign called, How do you wear it? with Lenny Kravtiz and Sarah Jessica Parker. It featured the pair dancing in customized Gap jeans  his with metal studs down the seam; hers with a waist-to-cuff velvet ribbon.

title: Giuliani Is Cautious as He Weighs 08 Decision
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who developed a national reputation for decisive and reassuring leadership after 9/11, now faces the odd challenge of having to reassure some supporters that he can be decisive about a very different issue: running for president.

title: Costs Increase for Building N.F.L. Stadium
description: Nothing seems to come cheap these days, particularly new athletic stadiums.

title: Onos Driver Complained About Stress on Recording
description: Yoko Onos chauffeur was so stressed by his job that eight of his teeth fell out because he was grinding them at night, according to court papers filed by his lawyer.

title: Cracking the Books for Financial Aid to College
description: As the price of a degree at a private college shoots toward the cost of a Lamborghini, parents and grandparents are looking for a leg up as well as to correct mistakes that could cost them dearly when applying for need-based financial aid.

title: Washington and Detroit Share Some Issues
description: ENERGY and health policy dominated the news this week, both directly, in the form of President Bushs State of the Union address, and indirectly, in the huge loss at the Ford Motor Company last year. Fords problems were attributed largely to the flagging sales of its gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles and the crushing burden of providing health care to its employees and retirees.

title: Canada to Pay $9.75 Million to Man Tortured in Syria
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 26  Maher Arar, the Canadian software engineer who was detained by American officials in 2002 and deported to Syria, where he was jailed and regularly tortured, will receive 11.5 million Canadian dollars ($9.75 million) in compensation from the Canadian government, under a settlement announced Friday.

title: Best-Seller Big Bang: When Words Started Off to Market
description: I hate publishing! Alfred Tennyson complained as he assembled his poems for London publication in 1842. Among his gripes was having to chase down pirated American versions of his verse, while trying to earn his keep from books and magazines. But those earnings came far more easily to him than to todays poets. In Memoriam sold 25,000 copies in England in less than two years; in 1864 Enoch Arden sold 40,000 copies in just a few weeks.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article by The Associated Press last Saturday about a fatal stabbing at the Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School in Massachusetts misstated the schools location. It is in Sudbury, not Framingham.

title: Italian Romanticism From a Rarely Heard Source
description: Riccardo Mutis streamlined readings of the Russian and German repertory are an acquired taste (though one worth acquiring), and his relatively rare forays into American repertory have been well meaning, if unpersuasive. But there is no one to touch him in Italian music, and that was what he brought to the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening, the start of his second week of subscription programs with the orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Luxury by the Fraction
description: THE good life can be acquired in limited pieces. What works for vacation homes and private planes  fractional ownership  is rapidly becoming available for pleasure boats and wineries.

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) RHINOCEROS Virtually unchanged over 25 million years, the rhinoceros once roamed the earth in hordes. Today, it is one of the planets rarest animals, with three of the remaining five species headed toward extinction. This Nature special follows rangers through the savannahs of South Africa, the grasslands of India and the jungles of Indonesia to examine efforts to protect rhinos from poachers and relocate them to new habitats, and peers into a fertility lab at an American zoo to find out about attempts to breed them in captivity. It also zooms in on some startling behavior in the rhinos natural environments, including a nursery full of mothers and calves and a charge from an angry bull.

title: Venezuela: U.S. Envoy Says Bags Are Packed
description: Diplomatic relations with the United States appeared to become more fragile as William Brownfield, the American ambassador, responded to a threat of expulsion from President Hugo Chvez by saying, My bags are always packed and ready. Mr. Brownfield, in a visit to Maracaibo, also emphasized that he hoped to avoid further confrontation and to focus instead on issues of political and economic importance to both Caracas and Washington. Mr. Chvez, who has threatened to expel Mr. Brownfield before, said on Thursday night that he could declare the ambassador persona non grata if he continued to comment on such issues as Venezuelas plan to nationalize companies controlled by foreign investors.

title: A Contrarian View: Save Less and Still Retire With Enough
description: Could it be possible that you are saving too much for your retirement?

title: Young Lovers, a Vespa and a Frolic by Rossini
description: If Rossini had been in the audience on Thursday night at the Harry de Jur Playhouse, he would surely have found the stylish and witty new production of Il Signor Bruschino by the Gotham Chamber Opera as cheekily funny as everyone else did.

title: Get Organized Now Month? Maybe in the Red States
description: Donald Keyser, the Asia expert and former senior State Department official, was finally sentenced to prison this week. Among other things, Mr. Keyser confessed to keeping more than 3,000 sensitive documents  3,559 to be exact, ranging from the classified to the top secret  in his basement. His wife had pointed this out to him. Im going to go out on a limb here: in the history of the world, no one has ever been happy to be told to clean up his room.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Saturday about complaints by some nonprofit groups of a class divide in philanthropy among Chinese-Americans misstated the given name of the executive director of the Ong Family Foundation, which makes annual grants to such groups, including the Chinese-American Planning Council, a social service agency. The executive director is Nelson Louis, not Norman. The article also misstated the association that Mr. Louis and Danny Ong Yee, the foundations founding trustee, once had with the council. They are former staff members; they did not attend the councils child-care programs as children.

title: Defending a Slam Again, Only This Time Its Grand
description: In Thursdays column you had the chance to pick Wests opening lead against a small slam. Now you can select something against a grand slam, seven spades. What would be your choice?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 19 about the humor columnist Art Buchwald misspelled the place of residence in Virginia of one of his surviving children, and a correction in this space yesterday misidentified that survivor. The town is Culpeper, not Culpepper. And it is Connie Marks Buchwald who lives there  not Joel Buchwald, who lives in Washington.

title: In the Tennessee Senate, a Historic Shift of Power
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 26  Over the last year, members of the Tennessee legislature have witnessed a number of updates. Plasma televisions that broadcast legislative sessions now line corridors in Legislative Plaza, where many lawmakers have their offices. Smoking has been banned from the building although the two activities it used to cloud, lobbying and political arm-twisting, remain.

title: Bravely Setting Out to Mock Others
description: I cant say that I was surprised to learn that Epic Movie would not be screened in advance for critics, but I must say that my feelings were a little bit hurt. A crude, scatological parody of a handful of big-budget, inexplicably popular movies from the past two years  what would be more likely to warm a critics withered, cynical heart?

title: Flair and Flash, Not Frumpiness
description: Long viewed as the domain of grandmothers, needlework has undergone an image makeover in the last decade. Snowboarders, the old torchbearers of alt.culture, have embraced crocheting, making beanies to wear on the slopes; coffeehouses and subways are filled with fashion-conscious types busily knitting or doing needlepoint. And contemporary artists like Andrea Zittel, Lisa Anne Auerbach, Orly Genger and Jim Drain and the Forcefield collective have given crafts a coolly conceptual edge.

title: Fighting Between Hamas and Fatah Continues
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27  At least two more Palestinians were killed in Gaza today in continuing fighting between fighters loyal to Fatah and the Islamic Hamas movement, which has been celebrating its victory a year ago over Fatah in legislative elections.

title: New York Wont Replace Voting Machines by the Fall
description: New York officials have given up on replacing the states aging voting machines by the fall elections, and some would like to put off buying new electronic voting systems until after the 2008 presidential election, state officials said yesterday.

title: Carpet Cleaner
description: This weekend, the Bagger will again sublimate his by-now sour soul and battered ego by crawling onto the red carpet, this time at the Screen Actors Guild Awards, which given the free-for-all in the Oscar hunt, seems to have some implications beyond the usual festive time had by all. He likes the wide-open vibe of the awards and that glitzerati always seems to be on their funnest behavior. But when it comes to carpet duty, he never knows what to say to the attendees. Love your work is fine and all, but it always brings a version of the same retort, which is a version of, Well, I dont know yours, but my publicist asked me to imitate a human being tonight, so here we are.

title: Womens Australian Open Final
description: Serena Williams proved she is once again a force to be reckoned with after defeating Maria Sharapova.

title: Correction: The Week in New Jersey
description: A report in The Week column last Sunday, about the availablility of season tickets for Rutgers University football games next season, carried incorrect information from the university about the number of people on a waiting list for the tickets. It is 1,600, not 9,600.

title: Correction: Works to Touch by Artists Who Can't See
description: An article last Sunday about an exhibition by blind artists misspelled part of the name of the college in Hartford where it is being held. It is Capital Community College, not Capitol.

title: Keeping Track of Steve Ballmer
Correction: Badillos World, One Tenements Tale and Eau N.Y.C.
description: A review of New York books on Dec. 31, in appraising Water- Works: The Architecture and Engineering of the New York City Water Supply, referred incorrectly to the origin of the octagonal logo used by JPMorgan Chase & Company. Ivan Chermayeff, who designed the logo with Tom Geismar, said the design was intended to be distinctive and geometric; he said the design was not related to a New York water provider that was the forerunner to JPMorgan Chase & Company. The logo was not intended to resemble a cross-section of a wooden water pipe, and any such resemblance was not the decisive factor in the selection of the logo from several proposed designs.

title: Correction: Chairs With Airs: On Arty Streets, a Cluster of Hip Furniture Stores
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about furniture stores in Dumbo, Brooklyn, misstated the context of a quotation by Robert Siewert, the manager at Wonk, one of the stores. When Mr. Siewert said, This building, before they started getting kicked out, was mostly artist studios, he was referring to a building at 68 Jay Street, where his store is located  not to the nearby J Condominiums.

title: Correction: F.Y.I.
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last week about a luminaire at Verdi Square misstated the given name of the director of art and antiquities for the Department of Parks and Recreation, who commented on the luminaires history. He is Jonathan Kuhn, not John.

title: Its Up, Its Good, Maybe Too Good
description: We received quite a few responses to John Branchs article last Sunday on rising field-goal accuracy and what the league should do, if anything, about it. (I pasted his article on the bottom of this file.)

title: Soros Likes Obama, Is Worried About Leverage
description: George Soros, the billionaire former hedge fund manager, met with a group of reporters over lunch today  he paid the check  and offered views on everything from markets to American politics to Bill Gates as a philanthropist.

title: Perilous Journey
description: Mexico has taken measures to slow the flow across its southern border, but much remains to be done.

title: Lies, Fallacies and Truths
description: Lawrence Summers, the former U.S. Treasury Secretary and Harvard University president, delivered some harsh criticism of the way globalization has been pitched to the public. Making the intellectual case for free trade and then simply paying off some of the losers in globalization, Mr. Summers said, will not work for world leaders trying to sell the current round of global trade talks to a skeptical polity.

title: Powerful Women and Their Admirers
description: Heads of state, ministers and chief executives were among those who attended a ForbesErnst & Young co-sponsored Powerful Women reception here at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

title: Asia Takes Lessons, and Teaches Some Too
description: Call it the third-mover advantage.

title: The Password Is Everywhere
description: There is no more coveted party than the Google Party in Davos.

title: Green For a Day?
description: Climate change is one of the big topics at this years World Economic Forum, so it is no surprise that delegates are parading their green credentials. But the worthies and grandees at Davos should watch out: There are watchdogs about.

title: George Soros Backs Obama (But Hedges His Bets)
description: George Soros, the billionaire former hedge fund manager, met with a group of reporters over lunch on Saturday  he paid the check  and offered views on everything from markets to American politics to Bill Gates as a philanthropist.

title: Crowd Turns Out for Blairs Not-Quite-Farewell
description: For Tony Blair, it was a valedictory Davos moment  his final appearance at the World Economic Forum as Britains prime minister after almost 10 years in office (but probably not his last time at the conference). Despite his poor ratings and limited political shelf-life at home, Blair still packed the auditorium with listeners Saturday as he addressed three main issues: climate change, trade and Africa.

title: Father of the Bride
description: Hail Mary, did Jean-Paul Gaultier have a Jesus hallucination?

title: Clinton Packs a Crowd in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  If its turning into a battle of who can score the biggest early Democratic primary crowds, let the record show that Senator Hillary Rodham Cinton from New York at least matched - and may have beat  Senator Barack Obama from Illinois at her rally here this morning, compared to the turnout Mr. Obama drew in New Hampshire last month.

title: In Her Own Time, Like Her Spouse
description: DES MOINES  Its called Clinton Time. Its a reference to Bill Clintons notorious habit of being late to every campaign event, caused by his desire to linger behind to shake every hand, grant every request for an autograph.

title: Clinton: The X Factor
description: DES MOINES  The conversation and themes of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons town hall visit can be boiled down to one word thus far: Women.

title: Happy Birthday, Cognitive Dissonance
description: So these five hundred social psychologists walk into a ballroom. They sit through a symposium entitled Cognitive Dissonance Theory Celebrates 50th Birthday. Afterwards there is birthday cake for everyone  two birthday cakes, actually. One is chocolate; ones white. Neither looks particularly better than the other.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Jan. 28
description: Well, in keeping with announcements that seem to pop up on the Sunday news shows, word has it that former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee may say on NBCs Meet the Press that hell file exploratory papers for a 2008 bid for the Republican nomination as early as Monday. Hes the lead guest; the schedule for Tim Russerts program otherwise includes Senators David Vitter and Chuck Schumer as well as former Bush speechwriter Michael Gerson.

title: Your Ideas for Darfur
description: In my Sunday column, I invite readers to send me ideas for addressing the crisis in Darfur, at DarfurSuggestions@gmail.com. Those can be ideas for helping people or for pressuring the Sudanese government. Youre also welcome to post those suggestions here  and to comment on other peoples suggestions or on my column itself.

title: Big Dreams Under G.M.s New Tent
description: ONE of the most intriguing concept cars of recent years was never seen at an auto show. In fact, it was banned from them  by the company that created it.

title: Dale Noyd, Vietnam Objector, Dies at 73
description: Dale E. Noyd, who as a decorated Air Force captain and fighter pilot attracted worldwide attention in the 1960s as a conscientious objector who objected to only one war, the one in Vietnam, died Jan. 11 in Seattle. He was 73.

title: Bitter Spirits
description: In daily life, obsessive, all-consuming, world-annihilating rage is not a healthy emotion, but for horror fiction its mothers milk. In horror, very bad things have to happen to people  or, at the least, to impend ominously  and the perpetrators of those atrocities tend to be in extraordinarily foul moods, especially when, as in the case of ghosts and zombies, they have recently risen from the dead. They always wake up cranky.

title: Biden Encourages Debate Over Iraq Troop Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that no more than 20 senators would voice support for the presidents troop increase in Iraq when the Senate debates resolutions opposing that plan.

title: Recently Published
description: THE GREAT KISSER

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: Jets Along the Hudson
description: Turning Stewart International Airport in New Windsor into the New York metropolitan areas fourth major air hub is a bold proposition that sets the mind racing at the grand possibilities, though it can also prompt a sinking feeling when one remembers the many ways that big ideas can fall flat.

title: Judging Goalies, Ranking Brodeur
description: Martin Brodeur has been the rock-solid foundation of the Devils since his rookie season in 1993-94, when he backstopped them to the second overtime of an unforgettable Game 7 against the Rangers in the conference finals. Now, with his name engraved on the Stanley Cup three times to ease the memory of Stphane Matteaus series-winning goal that wild night at Madison Square Garden, Brodeur is having what may be the best season of his career.

title: Inside the Minds of Your Employees
description: WITH all the targeted marketing out there, and the customer satisfaction surveys and opinion polls that companies seem to offer at every turn, you might think that employers could get a handle on which employee benefits are most popular among their workers.

title: For a Pavilion With a Past, Grumbling Over the Future
description: IN the heyday of the New York Left, the limestone pavilion at Union Square Parks north end was a common backdrop for hundreds of Socialist, Communist and labor union demonstrations, its columned arms seeming to embrace the swelling crowds. Until the 1980s, it also served as a bandstand and an unofficial play space.

title: New Lords of the (Downtown) Dance
description: WHEN Cathy Edwards stepped down as artistic director of Dance Theater Workshop last summer, experimental dance lost a general. Ms. Edwards had the essential ingredients of a good curator: experience and guts. She put a slew of young artists on the map in her outstanding 2005-6 season, and her daring curatorial choices showed her to be as creative and imaginative as many of the artists she booked. Others in the field took note.

title: These Kids Never Say Yech!
description: ON Saturdays at Paradou, a small French restaurant in the meatpacking district, the bed-headed brunch crowd slogs in after noon, ready for mimosas. The morning crew is rowdier: a gaggle of apron-wearing children, mostly under 5, who come for the Mini Chef cooking lessons.

title: With Lines Like These, Who Needs Words?
description: Introduced on Sunday: Lamborghini Murcilago LP640 Roadster

title: 3 Killed as Hamas and Fatah Fight On
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27  At least three more Palestinians were killed Saturday in Gaza in continuing battles between fighters loyal to Fatah and Hamas, which has been celebrating its victory a year ago over Fatah in legislative elections.

title: Hate the House? Then Renovate
description: LOVE the neighborhood, hate the house. That is a common enough complaint from both current homeowners and prospective homeowners.

title: Hey Now: Its Garry Shandlings Obsession
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Between A.F.C. and N.F.C., Parity Is Only a Six-Letter Word
description: The Chicago Bears won one more game than the Indianapolis Colts in the 2006 regular season. The Bears outscored their opponents by 172 points, and the Colts outscored theirs by 67. The Bears won the National Football Conference championship in a blowout, while the Colts needed a late comeback to beat New England in the American Football Conference title game.

title: They Are Refugees. Who Are We? (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Iran?
description: The Mahestan mall in South Tehran is sometimes called the honeycomb of the Basij, the Iranian youth militia, because it is here that Basijis, as the militia members are known, buy and sell banners for the Shiite festival of Ashura, as well as religious books and posters. Somber, bearded young men in collarless shirts linger over tea behind stands selling tapes of religious singers  cult celebrities who belt out tear-jerking laments for the martyrdom of Hussein and make a small fortune performing at memorial services. Omid Malekian, a 28-year-old employee of a Tehran petrochemical refinery and the son of a carpenter, was shopping at Mahestan on Dec. 16, the day after Irans elections for city councils and for the Assembly of Experts, the 86-member clerical board that will select the next supreme leader should anything happen to the current leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. In the 2005 presidential election, Malekian voted for the winner, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and when I asked if he was happy with the president, he answered frankly.

title: A Chevy in Saturns Orbit
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2008 Chevrolet Malibu

title: Red Carpet Syndrome
description: It is late January. The year is still fresh. So why do you feel so stale?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Going, Going, Gone?

title: You Listening to Me?
description: You have just written your first book, Positively American: Winning Back the Middle-Class Majority One Family at a Time, in which you try to produce a functional platform for the famously unfocused Democratic Party. What do Democrats stand for? No one has a good answer. I felt anguish about that. I felt a burning need to have us thinking beyond the immediate.

title: Pfizers Birthplace, Soon Without Pfizer
description: When the morning shift ends and the afternoon light thins, workers stream out of the Pfizer pharmaceutical plant on Flushing Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Dont Feed the Poets
description: I recently wandered through my home library in Montana and rediscovered Karl Shapiros Bourgeois Poet (1964), a book of prose poems I first read during the vile winter of 1966. My wife and I had moved back to northern Michigan, after Id left behind a good job in Boston on the promise of my first book of poems, Plain Song, having been accepted by Norton. I dont recall what shape I expected the promise to arrive in: I ended up trimming Christmas trees and working construction for two and a half bucks an hour. Our rented house was only $35 a month, but it was drafty, the furnace was faulty and frequently the place couldnt be brought up to 55 degrees. All of these numbers can actually describe a life.

title: Saving Lebanon
description: It is good that international donors have pledged $7.6 billion to help rebuild Lebanon after last summers devastating Israeli air strikes. The democratically elected government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora needs all the help it can get. Clashes between Shiite supporters of Hezbollah and the governments mainly Sunni supporters threaten to overwhelm Mr. Sinioras fragile coalition.

title: Up Front
description: The only really bold thing Ive ever done, Thomas Mallon insisted in a recent telephone conversation, was to give up tenure at Vassar and start trying, in my mid-30s, to live the kind of life I might have had in my 20s. Although his aim was to be a novelist (his first, Arts and Sciences, was published in 1988; his seventh, Fellow Travelers, is due in May), it was literary journalism, not novel-writing, that set him free from the constraints of academic prose. Mallons informed but accessible style, evident in his cover review of Claire Tomalins biography of Thomas Hardy, has been a feature of his contributions to the Book Review, The New Yorker, The Atlantic Monthly and other publications for the past 20 years  and in Doubting Thomas, the column he wrote for GQ magazine through much of the 1990s.

title: The Curse of Geography in the 08 Race
description: CALDWELL, N.J.

title: Correction

title: Making a Good System Better
description: New Yorks campaign finance system has been a model for cities seeking ways to insulate politicians from special interest money while shoring up public confidence in the political system. But this enviable system is hardly free of loopholes, and gaming it has become commonplace. With Mayor Michael Bloomberg, the City Council and the Campaign Finance Board having expressed a desire to strengthen the program, this seems an especially auspicious time for reform.

description: The Bronx House of Detention was reduced to little more than a mountain of rubble by last week. A high-reach excavator clawed ferociously at the last of its steel beams, adding them to a heap of brick and stone.

title: With Leading Scorer on Bench, Irish Help Erase Cruel Memories
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 27  The banner hanging above the Notre Dame basketball teams bench shows that the last time the Irish reached the N.C.A.A. tournament was in 2003. Since then, Notre Dame has endured a long string of close calls, cruel losses and trips to the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Truly Indie Fans
description: WHEN Douglas Martin first saw the video for Nirvanas Smells Like Teen Spirit as a teenager in High Point, N.C., it blew my mind, he said. Like many young people who soothe their angst with the balm of alternative rock, Mr. Martin was happy to discover music he enjoyed and a subculture where he belonged.

title: Alexandra Ostrow, Richard Bruskoff
description: Alexandra Hille Ostrow, the daughter of Marjorie Grossman and Eric B. Ostrow, both of New York, was married last evening to Richard Michael Bruskoff, the son of Ilene D. Helfand of Boca Raton, Fla., and Dr. Bruce Larry Bruskoff of Gladwyne, Pa. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in New York.

title: Toy Story
description: The (variously) one-eyed, one-horned, purple, red and green people eaters called Uglydolls are among the most successful of a new wave of vinyl, plastic and plush designer toys. Originally conceived by the New York design school graduates David Horvath and Sun-Min Kim, the Uglydoll line has grown into a monstrous franchise with dozens of iterations, collected (ostensibly for their kids) by baby boomers, like me, who have yet to fully embrace maturity. Uglydolls are, however, but one brand among scores  if not hundreds  of patently quirky and deliberately unsightly toy/object characters that have exploded into a minor global phenomenon.

title: Hillary Clintons Mission Unaccomplished
description: HILLARY CLINTON has an answer to those who suspect that her Im in to win Webcast last weekend was forced by Barack Obamas Webcast of just four days earlier. I wanted to do it before the presidents State of the Union, she explained to Brian Williams on NBC, because I wanted to draw the contrast between what weve seen over the last six years, and the kind of leadership and experience that I would bring to the office.

title: Mollie Hanna, Thomas Lang
description: Mary Anne Hanna, a daughter of Mary Anne Duffy Hanna and Howard William Hanna III of Pittsburgh, was married last evening to Thomas Justin Lang, a son of Aimee J. Lang of Deerfield, Ill., and Richard A. Lang of Chicago. Rabbi Emanuel Baum officiated at the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh. The Very Rev. Drew Morgan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: In the East End, Riesling Legacy
description: AT a tasting in 1984 at the International Wine Center, a wine school in Manhattan, Peter M. F. Sichel, a seasonal South Fork resident, pointed to a bottle labeled Vin de lIle Blanc and said, Try that. Mr. Sichel, then a major figure in Germanys wine industry (he has since retired), has a masterly understanding of whites. I tried it, and was charmed.

title: Here Come Chinas Women (and One Rising Star Is Just 12)
description: For decades, the best women in chess came from Eastern Europe, partly a result of state support of chess. But since the Soviet Unions collapse, while Eastern European men have maintained their place among the elite, the women have slipped. Of the top 10 active women, half are from Eastern Europe.

Hes taking you to LAmi Jean, and soon you will be grateful.
