description: Lottery Numbers

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,061 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

title: New School Bus Routes Confuse New Yorkers
description: George A. Bonanno, a Manhattan professor, was startled to learn that under New York Citys new school bus routes that took effect today he would have to deposit his two children at separate bus stops about a mile apart, at different times, only so they could be ferried to the same elementary school.

title: Its Wild Heart Broken, a City, Like Its Eagles, Rebuilds
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 24  No matter how high the office towers and condominiums get in this fast-growing city, those who live here still cling to the laid-back way of life that draws so many to Canadas west coast, where spandex and a yoga roll are as common a sight as a suit and briefcase.

title: Sounds of the Past Echo in Miami
description: Lombardi, Namath, Swann, Bradshaw, Montana, Young and Elway. Each famous and familiar name put his imprint on a Super Bowl in Miami, where XLI will engrave another name into pro football history Sunday night.

title: Scientists Gather to Finalize Climate Report
description: PARIS, Jan 29  Scientists from across the world gathered here today to hammer out the final details of an authoritative report on climate change that is expected to project centuries of rising temperatures and sea levels unless curbs are placed on emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.

title: Iranian Reveals Plan to Expand Role in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28  Irans ambassador to Baghdad outlined an ambitious plan on Sunday to greatly expand its economic and military ties with Iraq  including an Iranian national bank branch in the heart of the capital  just as the Bush administration has been warning the Iranians to stop meddling in Iraqi affairs.

title: Barbaro Is Euthanized After Struggle With Injury
description: Barbaro, who rocketed to a six-and-a-half-length victory in the Kentucky Derby last May but sustained a catastrophic injury two weeks later in the Preakness Stakes, was euthanized early this morning in Pennsylvania.

title: Man Sold Drugs to Two Accused in His Death, Friend Says
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 28  Manuel A. Morey kept his drugs in a lockbox under his bed, his friend said. When his three young boys were asleep, the people he sold cocaine to could use drugs in any room of his two-story house on Route 82. When the boys were awake, his customers had to go to the bedroom and close the door, or head to the basement.

title: In Operas Famous Pair of One-Acts, Tenor Doubles His Workload
description: The traveling sideshow of Pagliacci added a strongman act to its clowns, acrobats and derailed theatrical entertainments on Friday night. Salvatore Licitra was scheduled to sing Leoncavallos Canio at the Metropolitan Opera, while Frank Porretta would be Mascagnis Turiddu in Cavalleria Rusticana. On Thursday Mr. Porretta reported in sick. Rather than let a cover singer be called for, Mr. Licitra said he would sing both operas.

title: On a Trip Through History, Students Join Freedom Riders
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 28  More times than he remembers, LaMarkus Cook has traveled south on Interstate 65 from Nashville, where he attends American Baptist College, to his home outside Montgomery, Ala. But never, he said, as he did this weekend.

title: Bronx: Man Found Dead in Room
description: A 53-year-old man was found dead yesterday morning in his small room inside a nine-story building run by a nonprofit group in Morrisania, the police said. The man, whom the authorities did not identify, was killed by blunt trauma to the torso, the police said. The killing occurred shortly before 4 a.m. at a building, known as Webster House, at 1075 Webster Avenue, the police said. The building is run by the group, Volunteers of America, under an agreement with the city. Residents said the man, who they said was named Thomas and was also known as Mac, was found lying with the door to his room open. I heard rumbling and fighting, said Umberto Sanchez, who lives in a nearby room. A spokeswoman for Volunteers of America referred calls to the citys Department of Homeless Services. Nobody at that agency could be reached yesterday.

title: Egyptian Paper Accuses Iranians of Complicity in Envoys Death
description: CAIRO, Jan. 28  A front-page article in Egypts semiofficial state newspaper on Sunday accused Iranian intelligence of involvement in the 2005 killing of Egypts ambassador to Iraq.

title: Girls Friendship, Renewed Choreographically
description: Two young girls are best, best friends. They grow up, grow apart, then rediscover their friendship as adults. Oh, and one of them is Claire Danes.

title: Nasty Fall at Games Isnt Keeping Kildow Down
description: KITZBHEL, Austria, Jan. 28  It has been almost a year since Lindsey Kildow had one of the ugliest Olympic downhill crashes since Hermann Maier flew upside down into worldwide fame at the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan. She returned to competition a few days later, but was badly bruised and failed to win a medal.

title: 250 Are Killed in Major Iraq Battle
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28  At least 250 militants were killed and an American helicopter was shot down in violent clashes near the southern city of Najaf on Sunday, Iraqi officials said.

title: Feminist Art Finally Takes Center Stage
description: Well, this is quite a turnout for an ism,  said the art historian and critic Lucy Lippard on Friday morning as she looked out at the people filling the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater at the Museum of Modern Art and spilling into the aisles. Especially in a museum not notorious for its historical support of women.

title: Finding Consolation in a Consolidation
description: ALBANY  David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, has been reading fine print lately.

title: 3 Weeks to Pitchers and Molinas
description: The energetic, young children scampered along a bumpy dirt infield, chased baseballs around an outfield that was missing almost as much grass as it contained and sidestepped a leaning light tower that was a miniature Tower of Pisa. Still, to them, this tattered field in Vega Alta, P.R., is hallowed ground.

title: Restless Quick-Draw McGraws
description: Impatience is a virtue, and an organizing principle, for Deerhoof, the San Francisco band that headlined at Irving Plaza on Friday night.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Novelty Rules the Box Office

title: Gump Worsley, 77, Hall of Famer Who Won Four Titles, Is Dead
description: Gump Worsley, the pudgy but agile Hall of Fame goaltender who spent a decade with the Rangers, played on four Stanley Cup championship teams with the Montreal Canadiens and was among the last goalies to play without a mask, died Saturday in Beloeil, Quebec. He was 77.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC BAROMETERS Two critical economic events are scheduled to take place this week. First, on Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to meet and issue its decision on short-term interest rates; expectations are that the federal funds rate will remain at 5.25 percent. Investors have been hoping that rates would be lowered, but positive economic reports last week about new home sales and big factory orders have made that less likely. On Friday, the government is expected to report on unemployment for December, with forecasters predicting an increase of 140,000 jobs.

title: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Vocal Minority Wants the Stock Tables Back
description: In an effort to survive industrywide financial straits, many newspapers have made cuts both large and small, reducing newsroom staff, paper sizes and even the daily printed stock listings that are readily available online. But after torrents of reader complaints, two major papers said last week that they would restore some of those listings.

title: Congress, the Constitution and War: The Limits on Presidential Power
description: President Bush doesnt seem to care that Congress wants a bigger role in guiding the Iraq war. Talking about his plan to send in 20,000 additional troops, he said on 60 Minutes that he knows Congress can vote against it, but Ive made my decision and were going forward.

title: Ex-Bush Aide Contradicts Libby on C.I.A. Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The former White House spokesman Ari Fleischer today contradicted the account of I. Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheneys former chief of staff, on when Mr. Libby first learned the identity of a C.I.A. agent.

title: The Sum of All Ears
description: For those hoping for real action on global warming and energy policy, the State of the Union address was a downer. There had been hints and hopes that the speech would be a Nixon-goes-to-China moment, with President Bush turning conservationist. But it ended up being more of a Nixon-bombs-Cambodia moment.

title: Deutsche Telekom Trims Its Profit Forecast
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europes largest telephone company, cut its forecast for profit this year as competition in Germany intensifies and the dollars decline against the euro erodes revenue in the United States.

title: Respect Is Nice, but Principals Want a Raise
description: Alejandro Soto, the principal of Intermediate School 184 in the South Bronx, is willing to accept the wider authority Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants to give to school leaders. He is willing to weather further reorganization of the school system. He is willing to be held responsible for his students scores and to face the scrutiny of outside evaluators and surveys of parents.

title: The Prince, in the City, Dribbles and Scores
description: Prince Charles and Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, were a bit later than expected in arriving at the gymnasium of the Harlem Childrens Zone yesterday, where two teams of seventh and eighth graders were nearing the end of a basketball scrimmage.

title: Skiercross a Great Place to Bump Into Olympians
description: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 28  Added to the Winter X Games 10 years ago as an appeal to youth, skiercross has instead come to be dominated by retired Alpine racers creating a second act to their competitive careers.

title: Liz Renay, Cult Film Star and Stripper With Mob Connections, Dies at 80
description: Liz Renay, a boisterous, buxom cult film actress who worked as a stripper, wrote several books and got a little too close to some mobsters in the late 1950s, leading to a three-year prison term, died last Monday near her home in Las Vegas. She was 80.

title: Death Upstate Renews Phone-Tower Controversy
description: An accident on Thursday that resulted in a Brooklyn man freezing to death while he and his wife were trapped in their car for 32 hours has renewed the discussion for cellphone service along a mountainous stretch of highway in Adirondack Park.

title: Hasbro Severs Relationship With Grey After 30 Years
description: Hasbro is ending its relationship with Grey Worldwide in New York after 30 years by consolidating the creative account for its toys and games at Uproar, an agency in Dallas and New York that specializes in campaigns aimed at children and teenagers.

title: Giants to Name Palmer as Quarterbacks Coach
description: In trying to create a brighter future for quarterback Eli Manning, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin continues to reach into his own past.

title: The City That Never Walks
description: FOR the past two decades, New York has been an inspiration to other American cities looking to revive themselves. Yes, New York had a lot of crime, but somehow it also still had neighborhoods, and a core that had never been completely abandoned to the car. Lately, though, as far as pedestrian issues go, New York is acting more like the rest of America, and the rest of America is acting more like the once-inspiring New York.

title: The True State of C.S.I. Justice
description: Modern DNA testing is steadily uncovering a dark history of justice denied. More than 190 DNA exonerations in 18 years show ever more alarming patterns of citizens, wrongly convicted, suffering in prison. Consider the eight felons finally exonerated through DNA challenges in New York State in just the last 13 months. Or the 12 people who had to fight long and hard to prove their innocence in Dallas County, Tex., alone in the past five years. New York and Texas are, in fact, the leading states in yielding these hard-fought exonerations. This is hardly a credit to their justice systems since the victories are won by dedicated pro bono lawyers, not by state monitors charged with finding injustice.

title: Iraqi Forces in Fierce Battle With Gunmen
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28  Iraqi forces backed by American helicopters and tanks battled hundreds of gunmen hiding in a date palm orchard near the southern city of Najaf on Sunday, exchanging fire for 15 hours in what appeared to be one of Iraqs deadliest battles in years, Iraqi officials said.

title: Miles and Decades Away, Quiet Queens Neighbor Is Linked to a Violent Era
description: On Aug. 29, 1971, two armed men, members of the Black Liberation Army, walked into a San Francisco police station.

title: Queens Officer Stops Fight and Shoots One Assailant
description: An off-duty police lieutenant interrupted two men beating a third on a corner in Jackson Heights, Queens, early yesterday, and shot and wounded one of the assailants, the police said.

title: In Los Angeles, Antigang Efforts Start on the Street
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28  At twilight on Friday, in the heart of the territory of the latest notorious Los Angeles gang, a woman in a passing car calls out a tip to Officer Dan Robbins, sending him racing toward a corner and a man he believes is a member of the 204th Street gang.

title: Billboards That Know You by Name
description: Each day, it seems, marketers go further in their quest to deliver messages so engaging and personalized that one cannot help feeling special. The latest step will be seen today in four cities when Mini USA begins delivering custom messages to Mini Cooper owners on digital signs the company calls talking billboards.

title: Courts Turn to Wikipedia, but Selectively
description: When a court-appointed special master last year rejected the claim of an Alabama couple that their daughter had suffered seizures after a vaccination, she explained her decision in part by referring to material from articles in Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia.

title: Suicide Bomb Kills 3 in Bakery in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29  After nine months without a suicide bombing in Israel, a Palestinian walked from Egypt across the open desert border, hitched a ride from a suspicious Israeli motorist and then blew himself up today inside a bakery in the Red Sea resort town of Eilat, Israeli officials said.

title: Tech Barons Take on New Project: Energy Policy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28  President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valleys technology investors.

title: Silicon Valley Rebounds, Led by Green Technology
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28  After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology.

title: Acting Governor Gets Permanent Portrait in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  Richard J. Codeys son Kevin thought the bright smile was just right. His wife, Mary Jo, agreed but suggested that his teeth were not quite as white in reality.

title: A Public Memorial
description: For a while, it seemed as if the emotional issue of how to place the names of the dead at the 9/11 memorial had finally been resolved. And for nearly everyone, including most of the 9/11 families, it has, thanks to a compromise engineered last month by Mayor Michael Bloomberg. But a small group of victims families has regrettably decided to mount a public campaign against the compromise.

title: Marilyn Horne Puts Her Protgs on Parade in Song
description: The standing ovation came before a note of music had been sung. The Marilyn Horne Foundations annual gala recital is supposed to focus on song, but it also focuses on Marilyn Horne. Looking radiant in gold lace, apparently undaunted by a years struggle with cancer, she played host to Friday evenings event at Zankel Hall, a night after giving a master class there, with every bit of her star flair. And at her first entrance the audience stood, with applause and shouts of Brava, to greet her.

title: In Politics, the Camera Never Blinks (or Nods)
description: BEYOND its fulfillment of a constitutional requirement, the presidents annual State of the Union address has come to provide much pomp. Its a prime-time gala where Washingtons best and brightest gather for an evening in the media spotlight, and where the nation tunes in with varying degrees of interest, cynicism or boredom at the bloated spectacle of it all.

title: Shell Hits Baghdad Girls School, Killing 5 Students
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28  The girls had just finished taking an exam and were gathering in an inner courtyard at a school in a mainly Sunni section of western Baghdad on Sunday when a mortar shell crashed down.

title: In Iowa, Candidate Clinton Takes a New Tack, and Talks
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Jan. 28  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was in a Cedar Rapids living room crammed with Iowa voters on Saturday night when a voice from the back asked why the Clintons were such polarizing figures in American politics. The room grew still, except for the crackle of the fireplace.

title: Opposition Party Barred From Regional Vote
description: A summary of the leading articles in Russian newspapers on Monday.

title: N.Y. Officials Seek $50 Million to Upgrade Courts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  New York States top court officials plan to ask the Legislature for at least $50 million over five years to upgrade the states threadbare system of town and village courts, more than five times the amount they had previously discussed, the states chief administrative judge said today.

title: A Serbian Region Unravels With Its Textile Industry
description: LESKOVAC, Serbia  The crumbling factory walls and idle smokestacks that dominate this town are replicated across Eastern Europe: symbols of once proud industrial centers that fell into decline almost as soon as the Berlin Wall came down.

title: At a Position Known for Greatness, Pretty Good Can Be Enough
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28  On one side of the field Sunday will be a quarterback who completed more passes this season than Joe Namath in 1968, for more yards than Roger Staubach in 1977, at a higher percentage than Johnny Unitas in 1970.

title: Ex-Arkansas Governor Joins Race for G.O.P. Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas announced Sunday that he was forming a presidential exploratory committee, mounting an underdog campaign for the Republican nomination with a message of hope and optimism for restoring America.

title: With Quad, Lysacek Gives U.S. Men a Lift
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 28  With his spectacular performance in the long program at the United States Figure Skating Championships on Saturday night, Evan Lysacek did far more than wow a crowd and a set of judges to win a national title. He helped the mens field upstage the womens, a rarity in a sport in which tiny girls generally dominate the spotlight.

title: New York Investor Plans to Buy Air America
description: Air America Radio, the liberal network that filed for bankruptcy in October, said today that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell itself to Stephen L. Green, the chairman of a New York office real estate investment trust.

title: Bernie Friedkin, 89, a Pro Boxer Who Fought Ex-Champs to Draws, Is Dead
description: Bernie Friedkin, a native of Brownsville, Brooklyn, who was known as Schoolboy and who as a professional boxer in the late 1930s and early 40s battled many of his opponents to a draw  including three former lightweight champions  died Jan. 18 in Brooklyn. He was 89.

title: Beyond a Shadow of a Doubt, Nights Are Noir in Fog City
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28  The orange and blue neon lights of the Castro Theater shone blurrily on the damp asphalt beneath the crisscrossing catenary wires of the streetcars. The words on the marquee in the Friday night gloom, read: Marsha Hunt: In Person.

title: Google Halts Miserable Failure Link to President Bush
description: It has been a bad month for anti-Bush snarkiness.

title: Brooklyn: Council Endorsement
description: Representative Yvette D. Clarke, a Brooklyn Democrat who resigned from the City Council after she was elected to Congress in November, endorsed Mathieu Eugene yesterday to succeed her on the Council. Mr. Eugene, a Haitian immigrant who runs a youth recreation center in Flatbush, faces 12 other candidates in a special election on Feb. 20. At a news conference, Ms. Clarkes mother, Una S. T. Clarke, an influential former councilwoman, and the Haitian-American Association for Progressive Action, a political group, also endorsed Mr. Eugene. His main rivals for the seat include Jesse E. Hamilton III, a Democratic district leader with support from several unions; Jennifer N. James, a political activist who raised money for Ms. Clarkes Congressional race; and Wellington Sharpe, who runs a child care company.

title: At Last, Television Ratings Go to College
description: For decades, Nielsen Media Research has affixed the same value to every college student watching television while away at school: zero. As a result, industry executives have complained for years that shows appealing to a younger audience have been underrated.

title: Hollywood Parables, Retold and Rehashed
description: Tonight a show about disappointment begins just right.

title: Tale of Survival Quickly Turns Into Lesson on Fragility of Life
description: The news out of Kennett Square, Pa., is not promising.

title: Hollywood Monster Rampage: Art vs. Egos
description: David Mamets Bambi vs. Godzilla takes its title from a two-minute animated short (actually Bambi Meets Godzilla) in which the monster crushes the innocent little fawn. This would make a fine metaphor for the way the film business treats artists if it didnt mean miscasting Mr. Mamet in Bambis role. As the lacerating essays in this uneven but icily hilarious collection make clear, he is far better suited to stomping on Tokyo.

title: Rivera to Step Down as President of Powerful Union
description: Dennis Rivera, the president of New Yorks largest health care union as well as its most politically powerful union, announced today that he would be stepping down, but not without issuing a broadside against Gov. Eliot Spitzers planned cuts in health care spending.

title: Saudi King Invites Palestinian Factions to Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28  King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia called Sunday on the rival Palestinian factions to hold emergency talks in the holy city of Mecca in the latest bid to halt some of the worst ever Palestinian internal fighting.

title: More Than Antiwar
description: Washington

title: Manhattan: Power Line Proposal
description: Elected officials from Manhattan and the Bronx urged Consolidated Edison yesterday to reconsider plans to install a 9.5-mile underground electric transmission line that would extend from Yonkers, along Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx, under the Harlem River and into Inwood, in northern Manhattan. In a statement, the officials said the power line would have a severe negative impact on vital neighborhood services and residents overall quality of life and identified an alternative route that they said would be less disruptive. Michael S. Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman, said that the line was essential to expand the capacity of the networks serving the area and that the proposed route was the most feasible. The State Public Service Commission is expected to decide the issue shortly.

title: Sinn Fein Endorses Plan for Ulster Police Reforms
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 28  Sinn Fein, the main Catholic republican party in Northern Ireland, voted Sunday to endorse the police force in the divided province, opening the way toward restoring local rule through a government shared by Protestants and Catholics.

title: Officer in Jersey City Faces Stiffer Charge
description: A 2-year-old injured in Jersey City, when a vehicle driven by an off-duty police officer struck his mothers car, died and the officer, who was out on bail on drunken driving charges, now faces manslaughter charges and was being sought by the police last night, officials said.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Clock Expires as Comeback by Knicks Falls Short
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 28  On the play that essentially decided the game, Knicks guard Stephon Marbury did everything right defensively. He stepped around a high screen set by Ruben Patterson, Milwaukees muscular forward, and forced the right-handed guard Mo Williams to dribble left.

title: Citigroup and CNBC Cozy Up
description: Commerce runs on the favor bank. That is simply how things work when the body shop owner notices that your car is running a little loud and sends you to his pal Ricky the muffler guy, or when big drug companies play nice with friendly doctors. When it comes to business, its a natural reflex to favor those who favor us.

title: Nets Tinkering Keeps Reserves on Their Toes
description: DENVER, Jan. 28  Bostjan Nachbar said he must have heard the message 1,000 times. Mikki Moore said he was hearing it before he even arrived in New Jersey.

title: Manhattan: Rent-to-own Stores
description: Rent-to-own stores charge exorbitant prices for televisions, appliances, mattresses and other items and disproportionately take aim at black, Hispanic and low-income consumers who have limited access to credit, according to an investigative report that the City Council released yesterday. A 1986 state law exempted rent-to-own companies from small-loan usury caps; and under the law, because the stores retain legal title to rented items until the final payment is made, the product can be repossessed if a payment is missed. Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, introduced a bill in Congress last year that would force the industry to disclose more information about prices and hidden fees, and to abide by state limits on interest and financing charges. Assemblyman J. Gary Pretlow, a Westchester Democrat, introduced a similar bill last year in the Legislature. The Council members who released the report  Maria del Carmen Arroyo of the Bronx and Leroy G. Comrie and Eric N. Gioia of Queens  said they supported both bills. Officials at Rent-A-Center of Plano, Tex., the countrys leading rent-to-own operator, did not respond to e-mail and phone messages requesting comment.

title: Spitzer to Tie School Funds to Performance
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York said today that he would allocate more money to the states public education system in his 2008 budget proposal, but he said the increased spending would be tied to better results from schools, educators and students.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Wendy Arnon joined the Omnicom Media Group, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, as managing director at the Direct strategic business unit. She succeeds Tom Benelli, who left to pursue other endeavors, the agency said. Ms. Arnon had been senior vice president and media director at G2 Direct and Digital, New York, part of the Grey Global Group unit of the WPP Group.

title: Monumental Questions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Spin Around League
description: A look at what others are writing about:

title: Citigroup Shells Out $1.13 Billion for Egg
description: Citigroup, moving to bolster its consumer business in the United Kingdom, said Monday it would buy Egg, the online bank, from the British insurer Prudential for 575 million pounds ($1.13 billion) in cash. Prudential, Britains second largest insurer, has been reviewing its underperforming British operations since last summer.

title: Two Drug Giants Said to Consider Merger
description: Sanofi-Aventis and Bristol-Myers Squibb could announce a friendly merger deal in the next few weeks to create the worlds largest pharmaceuticals company, according to an unsourced report from the French financial newsletter La Lettre de lExpansion. The report said a premerger deal was thought to have been signed last week.

title: Once Rivals, European Banking Groups Become Band of Brothers
description: Four of Europes national lobbying groups for the investment banking industry, hoping to coordinate their responses to issues before European legislators and international regulators, plan to create a joint body called the European Forum of Securities Associations, The Financial Times reported.

title: Altria Expected to Announce Kraft Spin-Off This Week
description: The Altria Group will formally announce its plan to spin off its Kraft Foods unit Wednesday, according to The Financial Times, marking the end of a 20-year era marked by tobacco litigation. Altria, which acquired Kraft in 1988 for $13.1 billion cash, will release details of what will be one of the largest tax-free corporate spin-offs on the day it reports fourth-quarter earnings, The newspaper said. It added that Altria is likely to spin its 88.6 percent stake in Kraft by giving its shareholders 1.46 billion Kraft shares.

title: Deals Ahead for Traffic-Optimization Firms?
description: Riverbed Technology parlayed its ability to help speed up network traffic into last years hottest initial public offering. What is next for the remaining vendors? A report from The 451 Group concludes that others are more likely to join the growing list of trade sales.

title: Deutsche Banks Achilles Heel
description: Deutsche Bank  has a problem in equities that is not going away soon enough, says Bloomberg News. While the bank, Germanys largest, earned more revenue last year trading bonds than any competitor except Goldman Sachs, income from stocks rose at the slowest pace of the 10 biggest securities firms, Bloomberg says, citing company reports and analysts estimates. Two years after he started his revamp of the equities division, the managing director, Anshu Jain, is still searching for the winning hand in the United States and a golden touch with hedge funds.

title: Texas Pacific Preps J.Crew Offering
description: After J.Crews impressive initial public offering last summer, the Texas Pacific Group is gearing up again to sell a big part of its stake in the retailer in a move that The Deal.com estimates will bring the buyout shops return to seven times its original investment nine years ago.

title: Tech Stocks Are Back (With Caveats)
description: For the first time since the Internet bubble burst at the start of this decade, technology stocks really matter  even to investors who are wary of them. Tech has turned in the worst performance of any group of stocks over the past five years, but investment managers are more bullish on tech than they are on any other segment of the economy, according to a survey by the Russell Investment Group.

title: Mayfield Fund Cements China Venture
description: The Mayfield Fund of Menlo Park, Calif., raised a $200 million early-stage venture fund dedicated to investment in China, formalizing a two-year relationship with Chinas GSR Ventures to become a general partner in GSR Ventures II. GSR Ventures II will be a Menlo Park- and Beijing-based fund to succeed GSR Ventures I, a $75 million Beijing-based fund in which Mayfield was a limited partner.

title: Now You, Too, Can Enter the World of 007 Finance
description: Compared with buttoned-down stock jockeys at Fidelity or T. Rowe Price, hedge fund managers may be the James Bonds of the financial world. They have a reputation for being secretive risk takers who use an array of specialized financial weaponry like derivatives and short-selling. (No license to kill, of course, though their lightly regulated funds do allow managers tremendous, nonlethal latitude.)

title: 3i Walks Away from Countrywide After Rebuff
description: A British buyout shop, the 3i Group, doesnt seem to be having much luck lately closing deals on its home turf. On Friday 3i walked away from its proposed acquisition of the British real estate concern, Countrywide, after shareholders rejected its 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) offer, without further raising its 490 pence a share bid. The private equity shops offer garnered 57.8 percent of votes at the extraordinary meeting, falling short of the 75 percent needed under British takeover rules. On Jan. 18, a British support services group, Enterprise, also rejected a 528 million pound offer from 3i Group, arguing the proposal undervalued the company.

title: Greenlight Files Suit Claiming Loan Fraud
description: Greenlight Capital, a hedge fund that has been locked in a dispute with Allied Capital, filed a lawsuit on behalf of the United States alleging that Allieds Business Loan Express unit submitted fraudulent loan documents to the Small Business Administration. Last week, after a former executive at Business Loan Express was indicted in Michigan, Greenlight called on Allied to replace its management team.

title: Sterling Stops By Fairway to Pick Up a Stake
description: Sterling Investment Partners has agreed to buy a majority stake in Fairway Markets, one of New York Citys best-known food institutions, in a deal that The Deal.com reports is worth about $150 million. CapitalSource Finance is providing $87 million of debt financing, and Sterling is putting in about $50 million of equity, The Deal said. Fairways managers will retain a significant stake. From its roots as a produce market on the citys Upper West Side, the chain has morphed to become a much larger, specialty food purveyor to the citys foodies, offering fresh fruits and vegetable and gourmet fare.

title: Gap Is in Need of a Niche
description: As buyout firms cast an eye over Gap and the retailers interim chief executive, Robert Fisher, passes out memos to improve business, The New York Times looks at at the anachronism that is the Gap: a single chain, selling only its own brand, with one point of view, chasing shoppers from birth to death. Mr. Fisher passed out a memo last week entitled How well be great again, according to The New York Post. But retail analysts, it seems, have their own list of how the struggling chain could bring back its cachet. First, they told The Times, the chain could start by shrinking. Next, its should experiment with brands. And finally, they said, Gap could focus on a narrow group of consumers, and tailor clothing to meet their needs.

title: SunPower Executive Accused of Insider Trading
description: As SunPower announced explosive growth in the fourth quarter Thursday, the solar-power company also disclosed that a senior-level employee is under federal scrutiny for actions he took while working for a former employer. Peter Aschenbrenner, currently vice president of marketing, has been accused of playing a role in the bankrupt AstroPowers allegedly improper recognition of revenue, and regulators accuse him of insider trading, according to SunPowers amended quarterly filing.

title: Comcasts Web of Ventures
description: Comcasts venture-capital arm, Comcast Interactive Capital, is helping the company create an ecosystem of businesses that advance new cable technologies and, if all goes well, boost Interactive Capitals bottom line. The Philadelphia Inquirer takes a look at the venture, which backs about six to eight start-ups a year with initial investments ranging from $2 million to $10 million.

title: For Web 2.0 Start-Ups, the Fat Lady Is Waiting
description: The scores of Web 2.0 start-ups trying to hit the MySpaceYouTube jackpot may be living on borrowed time, says BusinessWeek. The magazine predicts that 2007 will be the make-or-break year for these businesses and to make it, they are going to have to put their money where their mouths are. That means raising significant money to spend on nuts and bolts.

title: Proxy Adviser Gets Behind Blackstone in Equity Office Bid
description: The Blackstone Groups $38.3 billion bid for the Equity Office Properties Trust won another supporter Sunday when a proxy adviser, Institutional Shareholder Services, said it had recommended that its shareholders vote for the buyout shops proposed merger, dealing a blow to a rival offer from a group headed by Vornado Realty Trust.

title: Monotype Imaging Files for Stock Offering
description: Monotype Imaging Holdings, a maker of text-imaging software, filed with regulators Friday for an initial public offering of as much as $135 million in stock. Monotype, a former unit of Agfa, is backed by a private equity firm, TA Associates.

title: Silicon Valley Rebounds, Led by Green Technology
description: After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology. In Silicon Valley, investment in clean technology  from alternative energy products, like solar panels and hybrid cars, to the use of nanotechnology to solve environmental problems  went from $34 million in the first quarter of 2006 to $290 million in the third quarter, according to an annual report released Sunday by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network, a research organization in San Jose, Calif.

title: Management Group to Take Laureate Education Private
description: Laureate Education, a for-profit operator of universities, said Sunday it had agreed to be acquired for about $3.1 billion by a group led by its chairman, Douglas L. Becker. The buyout group also included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the hedge fund SAC Capital.

title: Indonesian Oil Giant May Hold I.P.O. in 2008
description: Pertamina, Indonesias state oil company, said it might be ready for an initial public offering by the end of 2008 after weeding out corruption and improving accounting procedures. It would have a market value of $30 billion, making it the biggest stock on the Jakarta Stock Exchange, the companys president, Ari Soemarno, said last week.

title: A One-Time Denim King Turns to the Courtroom
description: Levi Strauss is becoming a leader in a new arena: lawsuits. The company, once the undisputed king of denim and now a case study in missed opportunities, has emerged as the most litigious in the apparel industry when it comes to trademark infringement lawsuits, firing off nearly 100 against its competitors since 2001. Thats far more than General Motors, Walt Disney or Nike, according to an analysis by a research firm, Thomson West.

title: Citigroup and CNBC Cozy Up
description: Ah, the corporate jet. Like $6,000 shower curtains and the nickname Kenny Boy, the corporate jet lives large in the public imagination, writes The New York Times David Carr. And it may be the reason, he suggests, that the ethically questionable relationship between Maria Bartiromo, the popular anchor on the business news channel CNBC, and the ousted Citigroup executive, Todd S. Thomson, has garnered so much attention.

title: Credit Suisse Eyes Trust Banks in U.S.
description: A Credit Suisse private-banking executive said his firm is interested in buying a trust bank in the United States, Financial News reported. The investment bank could use funds from the recent sale of its insurance unit, Winterthur.

title: Tech Barons Take on Energy Policy
description: President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valleys technology investors. These venture capitalists, backers of giants like Google and Genentech, have traditionally been free-market advocates, favoring ideas and innovation over government intervention. Now they are heading to Washington on a crusade to influence energy policy because they have a big stake in the outcome.

title: Former CA Executive Is Sentenced
description: A former executive with Computer Associates who pleaded guilty to securities fraud and who prosecutors said was instrumental in the prosecution of the companys former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced to seven months in prison and seven months of home detention. The executive, Ira Zar, the former chief financial officer, pleaded guilty in 2004 and has cooperated with authorities in the prosecution of Mr. Kumar and the companys former sales chief, Stephen Richards.

title: Tribune Management Mulls Bid of Its Own, Report Says
description: Tribunes top management team is talking with private-equity companies about crafting a new deal to restructure the company and will likely begin discussing its ideas with the companys special board committee Saturday in Chicago, The Chicago Tribune reported. The newspaper said that the media companys board has decided that the two offers tabled for the company by the Chandler family, Tribunes largest shareholder, and the Los Angeles billionaires Eli Broad and Ron Burkle are too low.

title: Barbaro, a Champion
description: Before his accident, Barbaros rsum summoned memories of Affirmed, Seattle Slew and Secretariat.

title: News Quiz: Memorials
description: Good morning good readers of The Lede! Yes, yes, weve received your letters alerting us to the fact that we skipped the quiz last week  even though we had promised one the week before. Well, we apologize for that, but listen: does the term fly-by-night operation mean anything to you people? Yeah, its sorta like that.

title: The Hard Rain Thats Falling on Capitalism
description: Bad corporate behavior, including avaricious management-led buyouts and options backdating, is undermining the trust that is the bedrock of capitalism, Ben Stein writes in The New York Times. Among the offenses that Mr. Stein sees being perpetrated are backdating and management buyouts, both of which he says fleece shareholders.

title: Private Equity Stirs Canadas Record Mergers Boom
description: Foreign buyers have stoked the biggest mergers-and-acquisition boom in Canada ever, snaring once untouchable Canadian trophy companies such as Inco, Dofasco, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts and Four Seasons Hotels. According to Thomson Financial, the value of mergers and acquisitions involving Canadian companies soared to $230 billion last year, nearly doubling the action a year earlier. The biggest player: private equity firms.

title: Which of These Things is Not Like the Other?
description: The red carpet is a test of reporting fortitude. Physical challenges, plus an absence of meaningful stakes, makes it place where your soul can come in for some wear and tear. View the videohere. This is kind of a young persons game, isnt it? said someone he knows, giving a long stare at the Baggers crows feet. Just then, the Bagger spotted Todd Field, the director of Little Children and perhaps the only person less qualified by disposition to be on the carpet than he. The Bagger gave him a beseeching look from behind the hedge and Mr. Field came over. They each played their part, the Bagger offering inane questions and Mr. Field doing his best to answer. They shared a moment of complete nothingness and mutual understanding. The beast, such as it is, must be fed.

title: North American Paper Companies to Merge
description: Abitibi-Consolidated of Canada and Bowater of the United States said Monday that they would merge, creating the third-largest paper company in North America. The combined entity would have annual revenue of about $7.9 billion, the companies said.

title: Mixed Bagger
description: The Bagger had the wisdom to see Little Miss Sunshine coming. Then again, he also picked Alan Arkin and Peter OToole to win the honors actually awarded to Eddie Murphy and Forest Whitaker. Of course, he picked Helen Mirren and Jennifer Hudson too, which was bold and unexpected of him, right?

title: Data Machine
description: At the Globes, the Bagger sat next to this guy who opened up file after file on his laptop and kept going all night long, every once in a while piping up to ask a question. A few of us sitting by him watched him pound away and asked, Who is that guy? Turns out its Greg Hernandez from the Los Angeles Daily News and, well, the dude likes typing.

title: A Growing Aversion to Ticker Symbols
description: Everyone, it seems, is hopping on the buyout bandwagon these days. Even the big public companies once thought untouchable are now wistfully talking about the success of firms like the Blackstone Group, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his DealBook column. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Blackstones Stephen A. Schwarzman  whose firm has now offered $38.3 billion to take Equity Office Properties private  told Mr. Sorkin that the head of a major public company confided that he wished he could go private.

title: The Van Refuels
description: Closer readers of the blog, all four of you not counting blood relations, know that the Bagger is a heatseeking missile when it comes to free groceries. So you will be unsurprised to learn that he made it into the gala thrown by People magazine after the Screen Actors Awards, even though media types were not especially welcome. Lets just say that he knew a guy who knew a guy who knew a guy. The beef Wellington was dainty but satisfying and what exactly is not to like about those little hamburgers that are all the rage?

title: Merrill Lynch to Buy First Republic
description: Merrill Lynch said Monday it would acquire the First Republic Bank, a bank that specializes in serving wealthy individuals, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock. Merrill said its offer for San Francisco-based First Republic represented a price of $55 a share, or 44 percent more than First Republics closing stock price on Friday. The deal would be Merrills largest acquisition in almost 10 years, Bloomberg News reported.

title: 70 Years of Music
description: Photographs of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, from past to present.

title: The War at Home: Existential Conflict
description: In an interview with Newsweek, Vice President Dick Cheney defended the decision to invade Iraq but predicted a very, very long haul:

title: On the Hill: Slicing the Pork
description: When it comes to earmarks, the difference between pure pork and legitimate spending can be awfully subjective. But with President Bushs call to cut such spending in half and a deadline to approve a new appropriations bill to fund the federal government looming on Feb. 15, Congress had better figure it out soon. Democratic leaders also wrote a letter to Mr. Bush asking him to cooperate on adopting fiscally responsible policies, including giving a more accurate account of the costs of wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Congress: One-Stop Spending Bill
description: First it was the 100-hour blitz. Now those House Democrats plan to do a whole years worth of work in one day.

title: Davos 2007 in Review
description: Tycoons, politicians and big thinkers climbed into limousines, trains and private planes on Sunday as this years World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, came to an end. Among dealmakers and corporate executives there, the push to go private was a major topic of discussion. Strolling out of a session called Is Bigger Better in Private Equity? Blackstone Groups Stephen Schwarzman told DealBook an anecdote about how the chief executive of an unnamed company worth more than $125 billion recently remarked, Geez, I wish you could buy us, but were too big. Amid all this talk about going private, John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, predicted that the tide would eventually turn and companies would make their way back to the public markets.

title: Subscribe to the Videos!
description: OK, so this is totally great: my weekly Times videos are now available on YouTube AND from the iTunes Store. For free!

title: Stephen Schwarzmans Big Bash
description: Not every Wall Street titan can celebrate his birthday in a place that holds 1,500 people. Unless, of course, that titan is Stephen A. Schwarzman, who is on the verge of clinching the biggest buyout deal ever. Then this would be the moment to keep thinking big, writes The New York Times Landon Thomas Jr.

title: From the Print World
description: In todays Empire Zone column, David Grandeau of the state Lobbying Commission wonders if the overhaul that would merge his panel would ultimately give him some stong new powers, at least in the short term, to take on lobbying violations.

title: Guess It Finally Froze Over
SAG Awards
description: David Carr catches up with Forest Whitaker and other stars on the red carpet at this year's Screen Actors Guild Awards.

title: For Relaxing Times, Make It Suntory Time
description: Tommy Lee Jones takes his coffee canned. Or so hed have you believe in the camp-o-kook ads hes been doing in Japan.

title: Sudan Snubbed for African Union Post. Will a Peacekeeping Plan Hold?
description: The African Union decided today that John Kufuor, the president of Ghana, would be next to hold the rotating chairmanship of the union, snubbing Sudan for a second year, and resisting what looked like a bargaining chip for Sudans president, Omar al-Bashir, who signaled that he was owed the slot.

title: Post-Enlightenment Enemies of Pure Evil
description: Johns Hopkins historian David A. Bell, who has written a new book, The First Total War: Napoleons Europe and the Birth of Warfare as We Know It, takes to the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times to argue that the attacks of Sept. 11, in the context of the broad sweep of military history, just werent that big of a deal. As an instance of mass murder, the attacks were unspeakable, but they still pale in comparison with any number of military assaults on civilian targets of the recent past, from Hiroshima on down, Bell writes. Even if one counts our dead in Iraq and Afghanistan as casualties of the war against terrorism, which brings us to about 6,500, we should remember that roughly the same number of Americans die every two months in automobile accidents.

title: Mars Photos
This Campaign Thinks Pink
description: An organization that has fought breast cancer for 25 years is marking its anniversary with a new name and a new logo as well as a new campaign that demonstrates a new attitude.

title: Merrill Analyst Turns Cautious on Cowen
description: Shares of the Cowen Group have risen nearly 30 percent from last years initial public offering, but Merrill Lynch analyst Guy Moszkowski is concerned that there may be little upside left. On Monday, Mr. Moszkowski cut his rating on Cowen to neutral from buy, writing that, at Fridays close of $20.70, the investment banks stock had topped his $18 price target. He also said that Cowens merger advisory business looks weak, especially in the fourth quarter of 2006.

title: GOP Money Edge on Long Island
description: Steve Zissou, the tortured undersea explorer bent on finding the shark that ate his best friend,* has donated $250 to Long Island Senate candidate Craig Johnson.

title: LinkedIn, Social Network for Suits, Gets Funding
description: Venture capitalists have infused $12.8 million into LinkedIn, a Web site that allows users to create online networks of business contacts. The funding comes as last years flood of investments in social-networking startups  it seems all of Silicon Valley hopes to back the next YouTube or MySpace  has many in the industry wondering when the shakeout will begin.

title: Davos Diary
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin reports.

title: Montoyas Daytona 24-Hour Victory
description: Although this is news that everyone has certainly heard or read by now, I just could not let it pass without some kind of a photo celebration and comment. After poking fun at Juan Pablo Montoyas Nascar debut, heres some history with the Colombians victory in the Daytona 24-hour race yesterday.

title: What, Me? Oldest Living Person? No, Not Me. Please
description: Being recognized as the worlds oldest living person is something of an honor  at least as measured by the competititive spirit that often seems to underlie the quest for the most super of planets supercentenarians.

title: Rivera Leaves, Too
description: Recenty, the powerful heath care union Local 1199/SIEU lost its political director, Jennifer Cunningham. Now comes word that the unions longtime leader, Dennis Rivera, a major force in state politics, is taking a job with the national union.

title: Private Times: Imagining a Newspaper Buyout
description: For months, certain outside investors have criticized the New York Times Company over its two-tiered stock structure. If the Sulzberger family, which controls the Times, ever decides that they have had enough of such badgering, they might conceivably try to take the company private. Slates Daniel Gross considers such a hypothetical and concludes that the publisher is an excellent target for a management-led buyout.

title: Hooray! Sudan Loses AU Election.
description: The African Union just announced that it has chosen John Kufuor, president of Ghana, to lead it for the coming year. That means that Omar al-Bashir, the genocidal president of Sudan, lost his bid to win the job. As I wrote in Sundays column, it had seemed that Bashir might get the job, and Im glad that African leaders came to their senses and realized that would have been a catastrophe for Africas image.

title: Jet Use Leaves Bad Taste With Applebees Investor
description: Earlier this month, DealBook noted that Richard C. Breeden, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was already making waves during his short tenure as a hedge-fund manager. On Monday, footnoted.orgs Michele Leder continued the maritime theme, noting Mr. Breedens latest attack on Applebees International and writing that it didnt take him long to find his sea legs.

title: My Planes Bigger Than Your Plane
description: A couple of people are interested in buying A-380s as personal planes, according to a Bloomberg report. Airbus calls it a flying palace.

title: Air America Finds a Buyer
description: Air America Radio, the liberal talk radio network, said Monday that it had reached a tentative agreement to be sold to Stephen Green, the founder of SL Green Realty, a deal that could breathe life into the bankrupt venture. The network also said that longtime marquee host Al Franken would leave next month.

title: Mapping Ozone
description: With ozone polluting cities around the world, scientists are using low-cost balloons as one way to map and target ozone hot spots.

title: Bristol Shares Jump Amid Merger Speculation
description: Shares of the drug giant Bristol-Myers Squibb, which has been the subject of takeover speculation for months, soared to near a three-year high Monday after a French financial publication said it might be close to merging with Sanofi-Aventis. The report did not name its sources, and both companies declined to comment. Nevertheless, shares of Bristol-Myers, which sells the blockbuster anticoagulant drug Plavix, were up 4.6 percent to $27.41 in late-afternoon trading, giving it a market capitalization of nearly $54 billion.

title: A  Little Town All Our Own (for the Week)
description: Part of the reason we had so much fun during our Christmas vacation had to do with where we rented.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: New Yorkers Weekend in Iowa, NH
description: A Des Moines Register Iowa Poll shows 68 percent of respondents think the country is ready for a black president, 55 percent a woman and 40 percent a Hispanic.

title: Tijuana Police Are Packing Heat Again
description: The police in Tijuana, Mexico, having worked the last three weeks without weapons, have obtained their firearms back after they had been seized by federal troops sent to address the citys lawlessness.

title: Maria Who?
description: Business journalists, myself included, have been fascinated by the Maria Bartiromo-Citigroup story, which David Carr discussed in todays Times. When I was in Davos at the World Economic Forum last week, it was a major topic of coversation. Government officials and business leaders asked me if she would keep her job. Some were amazed when I said I thought she would.

title: The Dukes of Hazzard
description: Rei Kawakubos Comme des Garons show, on Saturday, featured four men who played various roles in London of the 60s and 70s. One was called Sebastian Horsley, a self-described middle-aged loser poncing around in make-up, fixing up drugs. He headed up the tailored section. Of course, to most of the people in the room these men meant nothing. I dont suppose they minded or noticed the blank looks of incomprehension. And, anyway, you get enough of those at an ordinary fashion show. But I dont know. I think I know what people would think if, in 20 years time, I put on a pair of platforms and ponced down a runway: old bag.

title: Bon Mot Dept.: Figures of Speech
description: On Saturday, on my way into the Raf Simons show at Bercy, the big sports stadium, I decided to kill a few moments at a hockey game that was going on next door. It was strange that two completely different male experiences were taking place just a few meters apart: the dark, esoteric venue of the Simons show and the crowded, bright, boisterous world of the competitive arena. As I stood watching the players chase the puck, my friend Klaus Stockhausen, the fashion director of German GQ, came in with his editor-in-chief, Manuel Frei.

title: Romney: Clintons Wrong About Bush
description: COLUMBIA,S.C.  Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts seeking the Republican nomination for president, has no shortage of criticism of the way the war in Iraq has been handled. And he questions whether President Bush was sending enough troops in, and dispatching them quickly enough, to accomplish the stabilization of Bagdad.

title: Prodigiously Prodigal: Mens Fashion in Paris
description: Everything has simmered down since the couture shows ended and the boys took over. Twice a year this happens, in January and July, and twice a year I am reminded of what a nervous wreck women make things. The men seem to have such minimal expectations, and more fun. Its like the perfect date. On Friday night, I went backstage to say hello to John Galliano before his mens show. He was in his private dressing room have his hair curled into long ringlets. The guys are great, he said. They arrive on their skateboards. No cars, no dramas. I saw some of them taking a nap earlier.

description: In many ways, the war in Iraq is looking more and more like the last days of the Vietnam War. It is becoming increasingly clear that the situation is hopeless and the administrations strategy is incapable of achieving victory. Yet the president insists that additional resources can still turn the situation around. Although he has little credibility left, many continue to support him in some vain hope that the sacrifices of our soldiers can somehow be vindicated and given meaning.

description: A topic that is on many minds today.

title: Barbaro Is Euthanized After Struggle With Injury
description: The eight-month effort to nurse Barbaro back to health after he sustained a catastrophic injury in the Preakness Stakes came to an end on Monday morning, when doctors euthanized the horse. Barbaros owners said it had become clear that he could not live without pain after a setback over the weekend.

title: Sunday Morning on the Web

Id particularly welcome any thoughts on individuals or groups that are particularly making a difference and could serve as models for others. If you can, include links so others can find out more information.

title: Senators at Louisiana Hearing Criticize Federal Recovery Aid
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29  Three United States senators sounded off on Monday about the slow pace of recovery from Hurricane Katrina at a hearing in the French Quarter, criticizing federal officials for perceived inequities in aid to Louisiana and for imposing rules that are halting government assistance.

title: Raid at Hells Angels Club Leads to Dispute Over Arrest
description: A member of the New York chapter of the Hells Angels plans to file suit against the city contending that he was illegally taken into custody after a search of the motorcycle clubs East Village headquarters on Monday.

description: Four people were killed and five injured today in an explosion at a gasoline station and convenience store near Ghent in southern West Virginia.

title: Recalling a Literary Family, and Phobias
description: As he notes in his remarkable new memoir, Wish I Could Be There, the composer Allen Shawn suffers from a veritable rainbow of phobias: I dont like heights, he writes. I dont like being on the water. I am upset by walking across parking lots or open parks or fields where there are no buildings. I tend to avoid bridges, unless they are on a small scale. I respond poorly to stretches of vastness but do equally badly when I am closed in, as I am severely claustrophobic. When I go to a theater, I sit on the aisle. I am petrified of tunnels, making most train travel as well as many drives difficult. I dont take subways. I avoid elevators as much as possible. I experience glassed-in spaces as toxic, and I find it very difficult to adjust to being in buildings in which the windows dont open.

title: Symantec to Buy Software Tracker
description: Symantec, a maker of computer antivirus products, will buy Altiris for about $1.03 billion to gain programs that track corporate software use.

title: In Survival Mode, 2 Newsprint Makers Merge
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29  Two leaders of the struggling North American newsprint industry, Abitibi Consolidated and Bowater, announced on Monday that they would merge through a stock-based transaction.

title: One Horse Dies
description: Why should we feel so much grief at the loss of one horse? After all, this is a world in which horses are sacrificed again and again for the sport of humans. Barbaro was euthanized yesterday, eight months after he shattered his right hind leg at the start of the Preakness Stakes. After an injury like that, most racehorses would have been put down minutes later. But every race is a complex equation  a balance of economics, athleticism, equine grace and conscience. Conscience often comes in last, but not in this case. Barbaros owners gave that horse exactly what he had given them, which is everything. It was the very least they could do, and yet it seemed truly exceptional in a sport that is barbarous as often as it is beautiful.

title: Fed Has Yet to Set Target on Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  When Ben S. Bernanke took over as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board one year ago this week, he brought with him a long-held conviction that the central bank should be more explicit about its goals and less personalized than it had been under Alan Greenspan.

description: Lottery Numbers

This is morning in Hoover, Ala., home of sublime high school football, as well as of MTVs pious reality series Two-a-Days, which begins its second season tonight. The song is a wake-up call.

Corzine vowed to provide relief for the highest property tax rate in the nation, the Assembly voted on Monday evening to give a 20 percent credit to most homeowners and to put a 4 percent cap on future local property tax increases.

title: Suicide Attack Is First in Israel in 9 Months
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Jan. 30  After nine months without a suicide bombing in Israel, a Palestinian walked from Egypt across the open desert border, hitched a ride from a wary Israeli motorist and then blew himself up on Monday inside a bakery in the Red Sea resort town of Eilat, Israeli officials said.

Grungy-looking college students, office workers, retirees and even a pregnant woman in suede boots all jostled into the brokerage on a recent morning, eager to buy stocks and buy them now.

Starting on May 27, Flyglobespan, a low-cost carrier based in Scotland, will run three weekly direct flights between Kennedy International Airport and Ireland West Airport Knock in County Mayo for as little as $259 each way, including tax. title: ... And I Want to Thank That Same Bunch. Again.
description: As the awards season lumbers toward the Oscars, you can almost envision what might happen when the Academy Awards are finally given out on Feb. 25. Forest Whitaker will fumble for words and mumble; Eddie Murphy will robotically deliver his list of industry thanks; Jennifer Hudson will work in a hokey use of the word dream; and Helen Mirren will pay tribute to the actual queen. Because this season has already brought three televised awards shows without a single surprise in the acting categories, the winners acceptance speeches have been hemmed in by an unusual problem: The same old people to thank and too many opportunities to do it.

title: Brooklyn: City Cancels Golf Course Deal
description: Parks Commissioner Adrian Benepe canceled an agreement yesterday under which East Coast Golf was to pay the city a minimum of $9.6 million in fees over 20 years to renovate and operate a golf course in Marine Park. The cancellation, effective in a month, came after William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller, raised concerns about the companys president, Domenick Logozzo, and his financial relationship with Craig Marino, whom federal prosecutors have described as a soldier in the Colombo crime family. Mr. Marino was one of 10 people indicted in March on federal racketeering and conspiracy charges. According to prosecutors, Mr. Logozzo lent Mr. Marino and his father money and a car but has not been implicated in any criminal activity in the indictment. Calls to Mr. Logozzos place of business were not returned yesterday.

title: Memo Pad
description: SHOELESS IN RENO? Unisys plans to open its first Registered Traveler program kiosk at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport in mid-February. But it is unlikely that the program will initially offer shoe-scanning technology, said Larry Zmuda, the companys partner for homeland-security-related business. In an interview, Mr. Zmuda said the major concern for Unisys was ensuring the programs predictability for members, who will undergo a federal background check and pay an annual fee to receive biometrically encoded I.D. cards and access to a special lane for expedited passage through the security checkpoint. Mr. Zmuda cited early snags with shoe-scanning technology being tested in Orlando by Verified Identity Pass, which already operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear at Orlando and four other airports. The Clear shoe-scanning technology, developed by General Electric Security, was intended to detect traces of explosives and suspicious metal, and to allow most travelers to pass through Clear lanes without having to remove their shoes. But the scanner rejected an unexpectedly high number of travelers shoes in Orlando, requiring members to remove their shoes just as they would at regular checkpoints. Mr. Zmuda said Unisys, which plans to be operating in 6 to 10 airports within a year, will probably offer only a special lane for the I.D. cards in Reno while the company continues to study options that will provide more benefits. Steven Brill, the founder of Verified Identity, has said that not having to remove shoes is the biggest potential benefit sought by customers. But Mr. Zmuda said that all of our survey data show that not having to remove laptops from cases is the biggest benefit sought by potential members.
