description: Tyson Foods, the meat processor, reported yesterday that it made its first profit in a year on improving beef and pork sales and the closing of plants to save money.

title: Admiral Calls for New and Different Approach in Iraq
description: The admiral who has been nominated to be the next head of the United States Central Command said today during a Senate confirmation hearing that a new and different course of action was needed in Iraq and he warned about Irans support for terrorism beyond its borders.

title: Ways to End the Nightmare in Iraq (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Economist Wants Business and Social Aims to Be in Sync
description: Dani Rodrik, a trade economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, received his introduction to the idiosyncrasies of globalization while growing up in Turkey.

title: Highway Exhaust Stunts Lung Growth, Study Finds
description: A new study suggests that children who grow up within a third of a mile of a freeway may be sustaining permanent respiratory problems.

title: Mountain Glaciers Melting Faster, U.N. Says
description: The melting of mountain glaciers around the world continues to accelerate, the World Glacier Monitoring Service reported. According to the United Nations Environment Program, a partner with the service, surveys of 80 glaciers in mountain ranges around the world show they lost, on average, about two feet of ice thickness in 2005. Comprehensive data from 2006 were not yet available, the United Nations said, but since that year was one of the warmest on record, the accelerated shrinking is believed to be continuing. Since 1980, 30 reference glaciers in nine mountain ranges have lost, on average, the equivalent of more than 30 feet of ice thickness, the United Nations said. In a statement, Achim Steiner, executive director of the environment program, said the ice loss resulted from human-induced global warming.

title: After 8 Hours on the Taxiway, You Might Want a Bill of Rights
description: THE air traffic system around Dallas basically snapped on Dec. 29.

title: National Primary Needed (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: State Is Investigating Lobbyist About Source of Contributions
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  The state lobbying commission is investigating whether an Albany lobbyist masked the source of some of his clients political contributions by charging the clients for appearing at fund-raisers and then making campaign donations in his own name, according to court papers filed here Monday.

title: Japan: Factory Output Rose to a Record in December
description: Japans factory output in December rose more than expected, to a record, fueled by higher overseas demand for automobiles and machinery. Industrial production climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.7 percent, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said in Tokyo. In the labor market, Japans seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 4.1 in December, slightly more than the 4.0 percent that was expected. In a sign of an improving employment market, the jobs-to-applicant ratio was 1.08 in December, meaning 108 jobs were available per 100 applicants.

title: Eye on Cosmos Is Lost to Short Circuit on Hubble
description: The Hubble Space Telescope is flying partly blind across the heavens, a result of a short circuit on Saturday morning in its most popular instrument, the Advanced Camera for Surveys.

title: Art Fowler, 84, Who Coached for Yankees Again and Again, Is Dead
description: Art Fowler, who became George Steinbrenners sixth, ninth, 17th and 26th Yankees pitching coach in a turbulent baseball pairing with his often hired and fired manager and drinking buddy Billy Martin, died yesterday in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 84.

title: Dash of Success Spices Up Goulds Neighborhood
description: GURNEE, Ill., Jan. 23  If Robbie Gould, the Chicago Bears place-kicker, was feeling the heat, he did not show it. Two days after kicking three field goals against the New Orleans Saints to help the Bears reach Super Bowl XLI, Gould was standing over a gas stove, stirring the alfredo sauce that was simmering in a pot.

title: Queens: Wounded Teenager Is Charged
description: A 17-year-old who was shot on Sunday when he tried to grab an off-duty police officers pistol during a struggle in Jackson Heights was charged yesterday with attempted third-degree robbery, the police said. The teenager, Edwin Guaman, remained at Elmhurst Hospital Center last evening, the police said. The officer, Lt. Jose Jacome, a 16-year veteran assigned to the 110th Precinct, came upon Mr. Guaman and another man early Sunday beating a third person who was yelling that he was being robbed, the police said. Lieutenant Jacome identified himself as a police officer and tried to stop the robbery, the police said. It remained unclear yesterday whether the shot was accidental and who fired it, the police said.

title: Odd Dish for a Diet
description: As former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas heads to Iowa this week in his quest for the Republican presidential nomination, one piece of his platform may be unique: his weight loss.

title: Pursuing Happiness, Greeks and Turks Find One Another
description: ATHENS  A short decade ago, a blink in the centuries of bad blood between Greeks and Turks, there was no way a Turkish store could have opened at a fancy mall in Athens. So said Elena Kanellopoulou, 60, as she meandered through Athens first megamall, stopping a few steps from an upscale womens shop with a clock in the display window showing the time in Istanbul.

title: Rumors Fly About Bristol, Lifting Stock
description: Ever since Bristol-Myers Squibb named an interim chief executive last fall, the market has been primed for a takeover of the drug company. So yesterday, all it took was one rumor printed as fact to incite a buying frenzy.

title: Williams and Federer Look to Stay on the Right Path
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29  It was a cool summer night Down Under, and Serena Williams, the new womens champion at the Australian Open, was sitting in the stands under a floppy hat watching Roger Federer carve up Fernando Gonzlez in straight sets in the mens final.

title: Baquet Rejoins Times as Washington Bureau Chief
description: Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, effective March 5.

title: Playing Mozart and His Pal, Funky Funky, uh, Mozart
description: Duke Ellingtons quip that there are only two kinds of music  good and the other kind  was apposite on Saturday night at Merkin Concert Hall in a concert celebrating Mozarts 251st birthday. The uninitiated might have heard two kinds of music, classical and jazz. But in Ellingtons terms there was only one: excellent.

title: Digging Past the Familiar to Find Beethoven Treasures, Some Knotty and Some Nice
description: Beethovens three most famous piano sonatas have names. You know what they are. The more-than-casual listener will identify three, arguably four more, also with poetic titles attached. Add to these the last three sonatas, which no one interested in this composers late period will have avoided. This leaves 22 Beethoven piano sonatas that, aside from music students, hardly anyone knows at all.

title: 6-Month Home Detention for Executive
description: A former executive at Computer Associates was sentenced to six months of home detention yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiracy charges in connection with a scheme to bolster the companys quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

title: Poison Begets Poison
description: Poison Begets Poison

title: Agency Says Higher Casualty Total Was Posted in Error
description: For the last few months, anyone who consulted the Veterans Affairs Departments Web site to learn how many American troops had been wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan would have found this number: 50,508.

title: Family Copes With a Disease It Well Knows Can Be Fatal
description: She lost Joey to asthma shortly before he was to turn 11  a searing memory for Earline Sierra, who recalls that as her son was having another of his many asthma attacks, he was talking to me, and he turned blue, and he stopped breathing.

title: Battle Pits Patent Rights Against Low-Cost Generic Drugs
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 29  The supply of low-cost generic versions of cancer and AIDS treatments for the developing world could be blocked if Novartis wins a legal challenge to Indias patent law, patients rights groups have contended.

title: In Queens Blackout, Report Finds Some Fault With Regulators
description: The staff size at the New York State Public Service Commission declined by nearly one-third under the Pataki administration, and the reduction contributed to a failure by the agency to adequately monitor Consolidated Edisons performance, according to a report to be released today by a State Assembly task force.

title: Turks Arrest 47 on Suspicion of Terror Links
description: TRABZON, Turkey, Jan. 29  In simultaneous operations carried out in five Turkish cities on Monday, the police arrested 47 people suspected of being Islamic militants, including the leader of Al Qaeda in Turkey, the semi-official Anatolian news agency reported.

title: Using Quickness, Colts Freeney Is Spinning Into Control
description: Dwight Freeney remembers trembling as he stood on the manicured grass, so anxious he could barely focus on his target.

title: Merrill to Buy First Republic, Seeking to Add Wealthy Clients
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday it had agreed to buy the First Republic Bank for $1.8 billion in cash and stock to gain clients with an average net worth of $20 million.

title: Mad About Mary
description: Once upon a time, asking about someones children was like talking about the weather. Then again, once upon a time talking about the weather was also like talking about the weather  not a portal into the political or the apocalyptic. But thats another story. The point is that children made for the kind of paltry social currency you could exchange with your in-flight neighbor, back when the only other option might have been: As youre carrying that knife and wearing full camouflage, is it safe to conclude that the vegetarian meal is mine? Then came children as designer accessories and politically charged pawns, appendages and admissions statistics.

title: Bonds and Giants Complete a Deal Worth $15.8 Million
description: Almost two months after Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants agreed on the financial part of a one-year, $15.8 million contract, the two sides finally completed the remaining aspects of the deal last night. So Bonds will return to San Francisco for 2007, needing 22 home runs to break Hank Aarons career record of 755.

title: Barbaros Desperate Fight for Life Gripped a Nation in Anguish
description: We fretted over this horse as if we all had a piece of him. The news media covered him like a saddle, from the moments after he shattered his right hind leg last spring in the Preakness Stakes. The country seemed to pause for reflection, and in many cases for prayer, with every bulletin from Kennett Square, Pa., where Barbaro was nursed for the past eight months and was finally euthanized yesterday in a medical surrender to the harsh realities of thoroughbred racing.

title: Veterinarian Says Goodbye to a Patient
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 29  In the minutes before an overdose of an anesthetic was given to Barbaro on Monday morning to terminate his life, Dr. Dean Richardson took a moment to say goodbye. For Richardson, the surgeon who worked so hard to save Barbaros life and who developed an emotional attachment to his famous patient, it was a final, and intensely poignant, moment.

title: G.M. Shifts Saturn Ad Account to Deutsch
description: General Motors, once reluctant to change agencies on its principal brands, is doing so again for the second time in four months.

title: Bobby Ross, Citing Lack of Energy, Retires at 70
description: Bobby Ross, who improved Armys football program in his three years as the coach but could not produce a winning season, retired yesterday at 70. He will be succeeded by Stan Brock, an N.F.L. offensive lineman for 16 years and Rosss offensive line coach at Army.

title: Reporter Disputes Libby in Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A former New York Times reporter testified today that I. Lewis Libby Jr. disclosed the identity of a C.I.A. agent to her more than two weeks before Mr. Libby has said he learned of the agents identity.

title: World Scientists Near Consensus on Warming
description: PARIS, Jan. 29  Scientists from across the world gathered Monday to hammer out the final details of an authoritative report on climate change that is expected to project centuries of rising temperatures and sea levels unless there are curbs in emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.

title: Deborah Orin-Eilbeck, 59, Political Reporter, Dies
description: Deborah Orin-Eilbeck, the Washington bureau chief and a columnist for The New York Post, died on Sunday at a hospital near her home in Manhattan. She was 59.

title: When the Simple Solution Is the Right One
description: I had run way too far for my level of training, and I knew it. But I had gotten lost, and the fastest way back to my car was to run. The next day, my left forefoot hurt so much I could hardly walk, so I did just what you might expect  I checked the Internet to see what sort of injury I might have and what to do about it.

title: As Airlines Surge, Pilots Want Share
description: Now its the pilots turn.

title: A Countrys Cultural Centerpiece Comes Calling
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29  The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, celebrating its 70th anniversary, is one of the burnished centerpieces of Israeli cultural life, a distinguished institution that resonates powerfully with the Jewish diaspora whose sympathy and support remain so important to this small Jewish state.

title: Computer Gets It Wrong in Medical Admission Test
description: When Daniel Sonshine, a senior at Brown University, took the Medical College Admission Test on Saturday, he was asked to read a passage on robotic fish in the verbal reasoning part of the exam. Then he was presented with a series of questions about songbirds.

title: Mattel Profit Rises 2.6%
description: Mattel Inc., the worlds largest toy maker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit unexpectedly rose 2.6 percent on holiday sales of Barbie dolls and Fisher-Price toys.

title: Robert Drinan Dies at 86; Pioneer as Lawmaker Priest
description: The Rev. Robert F. Drinan, the first Roman Catholic priest to become a voting member of Congress, and the first congressman to call for the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 86.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Snow, No Mush
description: An annual dog sled race across the Pyrenees and taking in Spain, France and Andorra was canceled because of a lack of snow. Its the first time in its 17 years of existence that it has ever been canceled, Cristina Lopez, the events spokeswoman, told Reuters. About 50 teams from eight countries had signed up to participate.

title: Robert Wilson, Beckett and a Celebrity From the Neck Up
description: A long-anticipated encounter between two giants of avant-garde theater is currently taking place in New York City  not on a stage but at an art gallery.

title: No Offense, but ...
description: President Bush says he had no intention of offending members of the other party when he said in his State of the Union address, I congratulate the Democrat majority. In an interview yesterday, Juan Williams of NPR asked Mr. Bush about dropping the ic, something the president does regularly, to the intense annoyance of many Democrats.

title: Bronx: Man Is Charged in Fatal Attack
description: A man has been charged with fatally stabbing a fellow resident of an apartment building run by a nonprofit group in Morrisania, the police said yesterday. The man, Lee Ruffin, 29, of the Bronx, was charged with murder, the police said. He is accused of repeatedly stabbing an unidentified 53-year-old man shortly before 4 a.m. on Sunday at Webster House, at 1075 Webster Avenue, the police said. The building is operated by Volunteers of America under an agreement with the city.

title: Transportation Chief Takes a CUNY Post
description: New York Citys transportation commissioner, Iris Weinshall, is leaving her post to become a vice chancellor of the City University of New York, officials said yesterday.

title: Looking to the Hudson for Rocklands Water Needs
description: STONY POINT, N.Y., Jan. 24  There was a time not long ago when the Hudson River was little more than a convenient dump site, a river so heavily used and contaminated that a state commission once referred to it as New Yorks open sewer. But Rockland County residents may soon be drinking its water.

description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Asks Russia to Join Alliance of Gas Producers
description: A summary of top stories in Russian newspapers on Tuesday.

title: Child Care: Ear Tubes Not Found to Affect Development
description: Inserting tubes in children with persistent fluid in the ear does not lead to better developmental outcomes as the children age, a new study reports.

title: Jersey City: Officer Surrenders After Officers Boys Death
description: A Jersey City police officer who had been sought on a manslaughter charge in a drunken driving case surrendered to prosecutors yesterday, the authorities said. The officer, Kevin Freibott, 38, of Red Bank, was charged with drunken driving and assault by automobile after critically injuring a 2-year-old boy and his mother on Jan. 23, the police said. Prosecutors upgraded the charges to manslaughter after the boy died on Saturday night, but Officer Freibott could not be found, they said. John A. Young Jr., Officer Freibotts lawyer, said the officer moved his family on Sunday morning to another location after receiving disturbing calls at his home. He was never a fugitive, Mr. Young said. He wasnt running. His family is here. His children are here. He wasnt going anywhere.

title: Tethers to the Senate
description: The senators eyeing the White House  there are six or seven, depending on whether one counts Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska  face a scheduling problem that does not torture their non-Senate rivals. Because of the Senates close partisan divide, most members are reluctant to miss votes to hit the campaign trail.

description: Its high time that the Department of Homeland Security investigated Hannitys America.

title: Oh, the Rivalry! And Thats Off the Field.
description: RENSSELAER, Ind., Jan. 24  The happy couple, Indianapolis Colts fans, bounded into the tattoo shop on the main square of this small city, unaware they had just crossed into enemy territory.

description: Washington

title: Japan: Fury Over Ministers Comment on Women
description: An uproar over a cabinet minister who called women baby-making devices sent Prime Minister Shinzo Abe scrambling to control damage to his already falling popularity. In Parliament, Mr. Abe said the remark by his health minister, Hakuo Yanagisawa, left, was inappropriate and said he had reprimanded him. Mr. Yanagisawa also apologized for the remark, made Saturday at a political rally while calling on women to reverse Japans declining birthrate by bearing more children. The remark was the second recent slip of the tongue by a member of Mr. Abes administration. Last week, the defense minister, Fumio Kyuma, said President Bush made a mistake in attacking Iraq, contradicting Tokyos official pro-Washington stance. An opinion poll released yesterday by the newspaper Mainichi Shimbun showed Mr. Abes approval has fallen to 40 percent, down from almost 70 percent when he took office in September.

title: Air America to Be Acquired by New York Investor
description: Air America Radio, the liberal network that filed for bankruptcy protection in October, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to be acquired by Stephen L. Green, the chairman of a real estate investment trust specializing in office buildings.

title: Views of a Neighbor
description: The instruments aboard NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, now in the third month of its scientific mission, have taken expansive global images, like a downward look at Mars' north polar region and colorful close-ups. The orbiter's high-resolution camera was able to spot not only where the Opportunity rover is exploring, but even its tracks in the sand. Elsewhere, the sharper-than-ever images have revealed large boulders in areas that previously looked smooth, which led NASA to reconsider the landing site for its Phoenix mission, scheduled to set down in 2008.

title: In the Rockies, Pines Die and Bears Feel It
description: Jesse Logan retired in July as head of the beetle research unit for the United States Forest Service at the Rocky Mountain Laboratory in Utah. He is an authority on the effects of temperature on insect life cycles. That expertise has landed him smack in the middle of a debate over protecting grizzly bears.

title: In Connecticut, Worlds Oldest Woman Dies at 114
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 29  To say Emma Faust Tillman lived a full life would be an epic understatement.

title: Non-Celebrities on the Web, Seeming to Make Non-Pitches
description: THE commercials are rambling musings by the comedian Demetri Martin that seem to have little to do with the product, Microsofts new Windows Vista operating system.

title: Headstrong or Pigheaded, Carter Paces the Irish
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 29  Russell Carter has been thrown out of basketball practice at Notre Dame for a variety of reasons the past four years. There has been bad body language, a lack of interest in defense and a few confrontations with Coach Mike Brey, who laughingly refers to the incidents as good theater for the players and staff.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about China Blue, a documentary about life inside a bluejeans factory in China, referred incorrectly to its clients. Levi Strauss does not buy jeans from it.

title: Totals
Can Humanity Survive? Want to Bet on It?
description: Sixty years ago, a group of physicists concerned about nuclear weapons created the Doomsday Clock and set its hands at seven minutes to midnight. Now, the clocks keepers, alarmed by new dangers like climate change, have moved the hands up to 11:55 p.m.

title: Baby Found Dead in Bronx Trash Chute
description: The body of an infant girl was discovered yesterday afternoon at the bottom of a trash chute in a Bronx apartment building, the police said.

title: Harvard Analysis Casts Doubt on Works Said to Be Pollocks
description: A yearlong scientific analysis by the Harvard University Art Museums of three paintings discovered in 2003 and considered to be possible works by Jackson Pollock has found that some of the pigments used in the paints were not patented or commercially available until long after Pollock died in 1956.

description: To the Editor:

title: House, Already Strong, Gets a Boost
description: LOS ANGELES  Even after a couple of weeks of giddy two-hour ratings for American Idol on Tuesday nights, the Fox network has no trepidation in turning to a drama to follow Idol at 9 this Tuesday, because the drama in question, House, is already the strongest scripted hour that Fox has to offer.

title: Moore Looking to Shed Journeyman Tag as a Net
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 29  Road games are often a homecoming for Nets center Mikki Moore.

description: Q. How do researchers know the pronunciation of the languages of long-gone peoples?

title: An Effort to Get More Fans to Meet the Mets
description: For more than an hour, five of the Mets better-known players had been posing for photographs, signing autographs, shaking hands and exchanging high-fives, when Judi Millar made a slightly less common request of Tom Glavine. Her co-worker Paul is a huge Braves fan and, well, it would mean a lot to him if you said hi, she told Glavine. Millar handed Glavine her cellphone.

title: A Researcher for Microsoft Is Reported Missing at Sea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  The Coast Guard is searching for a computer scientist from Microsoft who left for a daylong sailing trip off the coast of San Francisco on Sunday and did not return.

title: Seeking to Help Those Without Enough Food (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Serial Child Molester Receives Maximum Term in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  A man who the authorities said had sexually abused hundreds of young boys in several states was sentenced Monday in a California courtroom to 152 years to life in prison for molesting two 12-year-olds.

title: Francis Returns, and So Do Questions and Doubts
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 29  Steve Francis reappeared at the Knicks training center Monday morning, and for the second time in a year, he joined a team in disarray, with no clear sense of where or how  or if  he fits in.

title: After 8 Months Filled by Hope, Setback Ends Barbaros Battle
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 29  In eight months of waiting for Barbaros shattered bones to heal, the horses owners and his veterinarian said they had not seen the Kentucky Derby-winning colt become so uncomfortable that he would refuse to lie down and rest. Until Sunday night.

title: Ex-Bush Aide, in Testimony, Disputes Libby
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Ari Fleischer, the former White House press secretary, recounted to a jury on Monday his experience at an unusual lunch on July 7, 2003, during which he said that I. Lewis Libby Jr. passed on detailed information about the identity of a Central Intelligence Agency operative.

title: The Claim: The Pill Can Make You Put On Weight
description: THE FACTS Quick weight gain may be among the birth-control pills most dreaded side effects. But how much does it really add to your waistline?

title: Peace on Earth
description: Why bet against doomsday? I give a few reasons in my Findings column today (about my wager against a prophet of doom, Martin Rees). If youd like more cause for cheer, take a look at Edge, the Web site dedicated to a third culture bridging the gap between scientists and other intellectuals.

title: Health Literacy Test
description: How many of these words can you read aloud and pronounce correctly, each within five seconds? Start with the first column, reading down. Skip those you cannot read.

title: Profit Slips at Sony on Losses for PlayStation 3
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30  Sony, the Japanese electronics maker, said today that its profit had slipped in the third quarter as it took large losses on its new PlayStation 3 game console.

title: The Town Is a Changing
description: A weekend in Aspen, a town that looks to its past to define its future.

title: Rewind/Fast-Forward
description: Spring 2007s dueling personalities  and the beauties who embody them.

title: Readers Respond With a Library of Ideas
description: Last week, Nick wrote that we should go the classics to find better analogies than Vietnam for the situation in Iraq. This blog asked readers what other classics beyond Moby-Dick or the Aeneid that they thought would be appropriate analogies for President Bush and Iraq.

title: The Midnight Train to Strasbourg
description: With the arrival of a high-speed train, this Alsatian city may become a weekend destination for partygoers.

title: Do You Know Your Health I.Q.?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Jews of Cuba
description: A small group, of 1,500 Jews works to keep tradition alive on the island.

title: Shakespeare in the Park
description: Those crazy Veronese lovebirds have scheduled a date in Central Park this summer.

title: Boost in London Ticket Sales
description: For London theaters it was a very good year, Reuters reported.

title: Theres a Lot Happening On the Ground
description: This blog has become a hive of activity in the last week and, since the following post is so long, heres a recap of whats going on here. We dont want things to get lost or forgotten.

title: Cyberonics Capitulates in Proxy Battle
description: Metropolitan Capital Advisors won its proxy battle for control of Cyberonics, a maker of medical devices, on Monday when, days before its annual shareholder meeting, the company said it had appointed three directors backed by the dissident shareholders.

title: MBIA to Pay $75 Million in Settlement
description: MBIA, the large insurer of municipal bonds, has agreed to pay $75 million to settle civil securities-fraud charges by federal and New York State authorities over what they said was a sham $170 million transaction in 1998, the company and regulators announced Monday.

title: Giants-Bills, Super Bowl XXV
description: (Classic rewind: How The Times covered Super Bowl XXV. Where were you when Scott Norwood missed his 47-yard field-goal attempt wide right?)

title: Strange Buyout-Fellows: Henry Kravis and Steven Cohen
description: SAC Capital Partners, the giant hedge fund managed by Steven Cohen, grew to prominence by making fast trades for quick profits. In recent years, it has sometimes taken larger positions in companies and held them longer, occasionally even playing the role of activist investor. Now it has teamed up with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, a veteran of the relatively long-term business of private equity investing, as well as a slew of other firms in the $3.1 billion, management-led buyout of Laureate Education, which runs campus-based and online universities.

title: CNet Restatement Goes Back to 1996
description: CNet Networks, the online publisher of technology news and reviews, has restated earnings going back to 1996 to reflect $105.7 million in costs for backdated stock options. The company also amended a million stock options granted to executives to reflect market prices. Shelby W. Bonnie, the former chief executive, agreed to reprice 700,000 unexercised shares, the company said on Monday.

title: Hedge Fund Pans Northwests Bankruptcy Plan
description: A hedge fund that owns 5 percent of Northwest Airlines is calling for the bankrupt carrier to meet with shareholders to develop a reorganization plan that returns their investment. To start, the company must agree to give its stockholders a voice in the bankruptcy, said Jeffrey Altman, founder of the hedge fund, Owl Creek Asset Management, in a letter to Northwest dated Jan. 26. Under its reorganization plan, Northwest will cancel existing stock and current shareholders are expected to receive nothing.

title: 2 Producers Without A Home Hang Their Own Shingle
description: Gail Berman and Lloyd Braun, two Hollywood executives who formerly ran network entertainment divisions, have created a company to produce entertainment for television, films and the Internet, according to press reports. No details of the partnership have yet been announced, but The New York Times reported that the duo has been meeting with potential partners in Hollywood and seeking office space.

title: Symantec to Buy Software Tracker
description: Symantec, a maker of computer antivirus products, will buy Altiris for about $1.03 billion to gain programs that track corporate software use. Altiris shareholders will receive $33 a share in cash, 22 percent more than Altiriss closing price of $27.14 on Friday. The purchase price includes about $200 million Altiris has in cash on hand and short-term investments.

title: 6-Month Home Detention for Executive
description: A former executive at Computer Associates was sentenced to six months of home detention yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiracy charges in connection with a scheme to bolster the companys quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts. Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court sentenced David Kaplan, former senior vice president for finance, at a hearing in Brooklyn. Mr. Kaplan was also ordered to serve three years of supervised release

title: Tesoro to Buy Shell Refinery
description: Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it would sell its Los Angeles refinery and related assets to Tesoro. Tesoro will pay $1.63 billion, plus the value of oil inventory at closing. Tesoros chief executive, Bruce A. Smith, said the purchase would give Tesoro earnings growth even as it faces flatter gasoline margins.

title: 2 Former Cendant Executives Spared Prison Sentences
description: Two former executives of Cendant were spared prison time on Monday for their roles in an accounting scandal that cost the company and its investors more than $3 billion. One of them, Anne Pember, 47, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy in 2000, was sentenced to two years probation and 200 hours of community service. The other, Casper Sabatino, 54, a former accountant who admitted wire-fraud charges and cooperated with federal prosecutors, was sentenced to two years probation.

title: I.B.M. Gobbles Up Softek
description: I.B.M. has agreed to buy Softek Storage Solutions, which provides software for data storage management, for an undisclosed amount. Softek will become part of the storage and data services unit of IBM Global Technology Services.

title: HealthSouth Sells Outpatient Division
description: HealthSouth, seeking to focus on its inpatient business, said Monday it sold its outpatient rehabilitation division to privately held Select Medicalfor about $245 million in cash. Investors cheered the sale of the division, which some analysts said fetched about 20 percent more than expected.

title: Shareholder Information Goes Online
description: Companies issuing information to shareholders will at last be allowed to use the Internet as a legal method of delivery beginning July 1, 2007, according to new rules published by the Securities and Exchange Commission last week. Under the current rules, proxy materials and annual reports must be delivered in hard-copy form unless a shareholder specifically requests electronic delivery.

title: Rumors Fly About Bristol, Lifting Stock
description: Ever since Bristol-Myers Squibb named an interim chief executive last fall, the market has been primed for a takeover of the drug company. So on Monday, all it took was one rumor printed as fact to incite a buying frenzy. A report in the French weekly La Lettre de LExpansion said that Bristol-Myers had signed a premerger agreement to join forces with Sanofi-Aventis, a significantly larger French company, in a deal that would close this year.

title: Steel Makers Prepare to Duke It Out Over Corus
description: The furnaces are stoked for a red-hot finish to the sale of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus Group, The Deal.com says Indias Tata Steel and its Brazilian rival Cia. Siderrgica Nacional, are preparing to face off in a 10 hour, nine-round auction that begins Tuesday. The battle could spark offers dramatically higher than the 5.78 billion pounds ($11.33 billion) already on the table, according to The Deal.

title: British Venture Capital Investor Raises Record Biotech Fund
description: A British venture capital investor, Abingworth, has raised Europes largest ever life sciences venture fund, worth 300 million pounds ($589 million), according to The Guardian. The news is a boon for the industrys start-ups, which, according to the paper, have been lamenting the lack of venture capital funds for biotech firms in Britain.

title: News Corp. Puts Cash Into Roos Pocket
description: The News Corporation is investing $1.3 million in an Australian Web video company, Roo, which provides technology for distributing and syndicating video content. News Corporation will initially take a 5 percent stake in the company, which already powers video services for several News Corporation Web properties, and an additional 5 percent if News Corporation reaches various revenue targets through Roos products and services.

title: Former Coca-Cola Employee Denies Trade Theft
description: A former Coca-Cola aide said at her federal trial on Monday that, although she routinely took copies of company documents and e-mails home, she did not conspire to steal and sell trade secrets about the beverage company to its chief rival. No. We never talked about anything like that whatsoever, Joya Williams said when asked if she planned with two other defendants to steal and sell Coca-Cola documents to PepsiCo.

title: NASD Fines Bank of America $3 Million
description: Bank of America was fined $3 million by the NASD Monday to settle charges it failed to follow rules designed to stop money laundering in its handling of accounts held by a single family. While the NASD did not identify the family, Reuters said that the accounts are identical to those held by Dallas billionaire Sam Wyly and his brother Charles, as described in an August 2006 report, Tax Haven Abuses: The Enablers, the Tools and Secrecy, by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

title: United Bankshares Takes Premier for $200 Million
description: United Bankshares , a Charleston, W.Va., banking company, said Monday it agreed to buy Premier Community Bankshares for about $200.7 million to add more deposits in Virginia and the Washington, metropolitan area. Premier shareholders will receive 0.93 of a United share, equivalent to $33.73 based on Fridays closing prices, or $34 in cash for each of their shares, with 50 percent to 65 percent paid in stock.

title: Behind the Scenes of the Battle for Delta
description: Will another billion dollars make the difference between a stand-alone airline and a willing merger partner? Thats what US Airways may find out this week after some behind-the-scenes negotiating with Delta Air Lines creditors. According to press reports, US Air was asked over the weekend by some Delta creditors to again raise its $9.87 billion bid. The pro-merger creditors, which include a group of hedge funds, reportedly suggested that the airline raise its offer by $2 billion. US Air has been frustrated because the official creditors committee in Deltas bankruptcy, the only party that can force Delta to allow due diligence by US Airways and otherwise get the merger talks started, has been silent.

title: Providence Equity Said to Raise $12 Billion Fund
description: Providence Equity Partners raised $12 billion for its biggest-ever fund to buy media and communication companies, Bloomberg News said, following reports that the buyout shop had outstripped its original target of $8 billion. Highlighting increasing amount of cash coursing through the private equity industry, the latest fund would be three times bigger than the $4.25 billion Providence Equity collected in 2004.

title: Texas Pacific One of 11 Bidders for Alitalia
description: Shares of Alitalia, Italys largest airline, jumped as much as 4.9 percent as a plan to sell the states stake in the unprofitable carrier attracted 11 possible bidders, including the Texas Pacific Group and UniCredit. The stock gained as much as 5.4 cents to 1.15 euros ($1.49) a share and was up 3.4 percent in Milan, valuing Rome-based Alitalia at 1.57 billion euros ($2 billion). Texas Pacific, which is part of a consortium buying Qantas Airways Ltd., Australias biggest carrier, said it would invite Italian and foreign investors to join an eventual offer to buy the company.

title: Quattrone Takes the Stage, but Act II Remains a Mystery
description: What Frank P. Quattrones next act will be has become a parlor game among industry watchers. Is the former technology banker teaming up with former Credit Suisse colleagues to start an investment firm? Is he planning a tech-focused buyout shop? Will he join some of his biggest Silicon Valley supporters in venture capital?

title: News Quiz: Laurels
description: Good morning, gang. No need to dilly-dally. Here are the answers to yesterdays quiz:

title: BAA Plans Mammoth Asset-Backed Bond Sale
description: BAA, the worlds biggest airport operator, will pledge at least $15.7 billion of assets from Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted to back a sale of bonds in the largest deal of its kind. BAA will sell the securities in March or early April to pay for debt that funded its takeover last year, according to Michael Wilkins, head of infrastructure finance at Standard & Poors. Bloomberg News said that BAAs deal would exceed the record $12 billion of bonds and loans that Japans richest man, Masayoshi Son, issued last October to fund the acquisition of the cellphone operator Vodafone K.K. by pledging the companys assets, income and shares as security.

title: Shares of Kraft Foods Expected to Fall After Spinoff From Altria
description: The Altria Group is expected to announce the terms of the long-awaited spinoff of its stake in Kraft Foods on Wednesday, and several analysts said they expected Krafts shares to decline in the near term. Altria owns more than 88 percent of Kraft, the largest maker of food products in the United States, and is expected to disburse shares among Altria shareholders.

title: Excerpt: 'On the Road in America'
description: Lara Abou Saifan, the series's production assistant, and cameraman Guy Livneh have a discussion about Israelis while visiting the Hamptons.

title: Stock-Picker Showdown: Blodget vs. Cramer
description: Henry Blodget has some harsh words for James Cramer, the popular market pundit who hosts CNBCs Mad Money show. Writing in a column for Slate, Mr. Blodget, the former Internet analyst, calls Mr. Cramer perhaps the worst thing to happen to the financial security of average Americans since the crumbling of the Social Security system. And thats before he really gets going.

title: On the Hill: Pay Raise Threat
description: Democrats are pushing Republicans to put their, um, mouths where their money is by threatening to block the annual congressional pay raise until legislation to increase the minimum wage is passed.

title: Little Miss Hit and Miss
description: Scott Feinberg argues both for and against Little Miss Sunshine as a best picture winner. And when he finally runs out of hands, he decides the vans on a roll that may not stop.

title: Motorola Says Icahn Will Seek Board Seat
description: Motorola, Carl Icahn is calling.

title: A Fine Wrestler and a Very Natty Dresser
description: The British version of GQ ranked men shaping the fabric and direction of the nation and put Sacha Baron Cohen at number 19, just behind Prince William.

title: Tethers to the Senate
description: The senators eyeing the White House  there are six or seven, depending on whether one counts Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska  face a scheduling problem that does not torture their non-Senate rivals. Because of the Senates close partisan divide, most members are reluctant to miss votes to hit the campaign trail.

title: Hanoi Janes Back and Rocking
description: Presidential spokesman Tony Snow is a huge fan of Jane Fonda, who has been nominated seven times for a best actress Oscar, and won for Klute and Coming Home. You know, I mean, its nice to see Jane Fonda in front of a camera again, Mr. Snow said of her appearance at an antiwar rally held on Saturday. The Bagger followed the rally closely and is glad that Ms. Fonda, 69, chose not to reprise her photoop mounted on an anti-aircraft gun or her time doing the tomahawk chop as a Braves fan.

title: No Offense, but
description: President Bush says he had no intention of offending members of the other party when he said in his State of the Union address, I congratulate the Democrat majority. In an interview yesterday, Juan Williams of NPR asked Mr. Bush about dropping the ic, something the president does regularly, to the intense annoyance of many Democrats.

title: Odd Dish for a Diet
description: As former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas heads to Iowa this week in his quest for the Republican presidential nomination, one piece of his platform may be unique: his weight loss.

title: The Defeated: Where Are They Now?
description: Where do former lawmakers end up after being voted out of office? Farhana Hossain of The Times Washington bureau took a look at the paths taken by politicians who lost some of the most contested races in 2006. Heres what she found:

title: The Song  That Never Ends
description: The Bagger is in the smoking cage at LAX, an extremely crowded exterior patio surrounded by high bars. The last time the Bagger lent out this many ciggies, his jail name was Pop Tart. Not that he is complaining; the tobacco ceremony means that he is going home for the first time in almost three weeks.

title: The War at Home: Nothing But Hearings in Sight
description: The Capitol is about Iraq today.

title: Go Ahead, Front-load the Primaries
Battle Over the AIDS Memorial Quilt
description: The creator of the AIDS Memorial Quilt is locked in a legal tug of war with the quilts caretaker.

title: Give the Hamburger Back to Wichita
description: Who invented the hamburger? Earlier this month, The New York Times Jennifer Medina explored whether the Edison of edibles hailed from Texas or New Haven, Conn. (Yale historian Andy Horowitz cast his vote for New Haven in the Times.) On the op-ed page of the Los Angeles Times, Josh Ozersky  online food editor for New York magazine and author of a forthcoming book, Hamburgers: A Cultural History  settles the debate: Theyre both trying to hamburgle one of the claims to fame of Wichita, Kan. Ozersky writes:

title: Wake Me When Davos Is Over
description: Michael Lewis is too busy for Davos, but he isnt too busy to complain about it. Examine the public statements extruded by the World Economic Forum any year and youll find the same warmed-over prudence, the same dreary feeling that someone is about to punctuate the nebulous tedium with a proposal to create a commission, Lewis writes in his Bloomberg News column. He adds:

title: The Schumer Book (No, Hes Not Running For President)
description: At Steve Rattners party in Manhattan last night to celebrate Senator Charles Schumers new book, Positively American: Winning Back the Middle Class Majority One Family at a Time, probably the best bit of ribbing belonged to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who urged the crowd to buy on Amazon.com to help the books ascent toward No. 1.

title: The Insufferable Schumer?
description: For the inside word on last nights book party for Chuck Schumer at Steve Rattners apartment, heres Pat Healys take.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: New Ohio Poll and Cash Reports
description: Even though she has higher negative ratings, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is ahead of Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain in Ohio, the ultimate swing state, according to a new Quinnipiac Poll.

title: Global Climate Panels First Report Looks Dire, but Wait for Part 2
description: Tidbits of the much-anticipated report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change have trickled out over the last week or so  ahead of its official Friday release  and experts on the outside have dickered over whether the findings were spot-on. An early sense that the report would estimate rises in sea levels not quite as dramatic as had been predicted in the past, for instance, caused some chatter  and charges that the panel had failed to include the recent melt-off of large chunks of Greenland and Antarctica.

title: Teacher Lands in Headlines With Bid for Alitalia
description: An Italian high school aviation teacher earning 1,200 euros ($1,500) a month became a minor celebrity in Italy on Tuesday by slipping through a fake plan to buy the ailing airline Alitalia as a protest against years of mismanagement, Reuters reports.

title: Kellers Announcement on Baquet and Taubman
description: Following is Executive Editor Bill Keller's memo to the newsroom this morning.

title: Birth Video
description: A good-sized chip of Greenland has broken loose, and when Dennis Schmitt discovered it in 2005, it was probably the worlds newest island. Earlier this month, my colleague John Collins Rudolf illuminated climate change, snow-and-ice physics, and Greenlands new cartography here.

title: Feingold Tugs on Iraq Purse Strings
description: Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin is leading a hearing today in the Judiciary Committee about a topic that makes many of his fellow Democrats squirm: using the power of the purse to bring an end to the Iraq war.

title: A Look at the Libby Trial
description: From witness to witness, the interplay between the Bush White House and the press has taken center stage at the trial of I. Lewis Libby.

title: Analyst Cuts Rating on Clear Channel Stock
description: Another analyst is advising caution to shareholders of Clear Channel Communications  as the radio giant continues to seek support for a proposed $18.7 billion buyout. Jonathan Jacoby of Banc of America Securities on Tuesday cut his rating on Clear Channel to neutral from buy, writing that, even in the most optimistic scenarios, there is little room for the stock to continue rising. The downgrade comes amid reports that some major Clear Channel shareholders, including mutual-fund giant Fidelity, will vote against the $37.60-per-share offer to take it private.

title: Survey: Young Muslims in Britain Are More Politicized. Blame Multiculturalism?
description: Results of a survey released yesterday by the Policy Exchange, a center-right British think tank, are causing a bit of a stir  chiefly for findings suggesting that 37 percent of young Muslims age 16 to 24 would prefer to live under Shariah law, the strict Muslim codes that govern every area of life, from prayers to style of dress.

title: Brunos Budget Worries
description: Eliot Spitzers first budget hasnt even been unveiled yet (that happens tomorrow) but the skirmishing has already begun with Senate Republicans. At a press conference this morning, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said he had concerns with much of what the governor has already said about the budget.

title: $3.9 Million Homes
description: Tour a house on Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island, a log home in the Vail Valley in Colorado and a 20-acre estate in Napa, Calif.

title: Static Clouds Time Warner Cable Offering
description: The long-awaited listing of shares in Time Warner Cable  the United States No. 2 cable provider after Comcast  could be delayed until March because of the legal wrangling in Adelphia Communications bankruptcy case. That is one of the possibilities considered by Bear Stearns analyst Spencer Wang, who wrote in a research note Tuesday that, if the internecine battles among Adelphias creditors continue, Time Warner could decide to try a traditional initial public offering as opposed to floating the stock through a court-approved reorganization plan.

title: Comptroller Rumblings
description: We caught up with Joseph L. Bruno, the GOP majority leader in the Senate, this morning at a conference of state county executives, when he was asked about the comptrollers fight now underway. He briefly, and characteristically, addressed the angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question now dominating the comptroller selection process, to wit: Were the three wise men supposed to pick precisely five finalists for the job, or up to five finalists?

title: (Almost) 107 Men and Women in a Room
description: The Assembly Democrats just filed into their conference room to decide, behind closed doors, what to do about the comptroller situation.

title: Smoking PIPEs and Getting Burned
description: Private investments in public equities, known as PIPEs, can be a valid source of financing for publicly traded companies. But they also have a controversial reputation, in part because of their susceptibility to stock manipulation. Forbes Nathan Vardi  in an article colorfully headlined Sewer Pipes  describes some particularly troubling examples. This weeks magazine offers a litany of cases of hedge-fund managers involved in PIPEs who allegedly duped investors, ran afoul of regulations and were convicted of fraud. When it comes to dicey partners, though, few are as accomplished as the Grins, Mr. Vardi writes.

title: Wall Streeters Make Crains Under-40 List
description: Nasdaqs head of trading services and the co-head of Merrill Lynchs United States financial institutions group were among the Wall Street up-and-comers highlighted in this years 40 Under 40 list from Crains New York Business. The weekly newspaper said the winners were selected by Crains editorial staff, which closely scrutinizes each applicant, and leverages their comprehensive, multidisciplinary knowledge of New Yorks business, culture and politics.

title: And You Thought That Rest-Area Mens Room Was Repulsive
description: Citing estimates that put the cost of cars slamming into deer on American roadways at $1.4 billion a year, including property damage and bodily injury  not to mention the 200 human deaths each year from such crashes  officials and researchers from a number of states are pooling their resources to find ways to keep deer off the highway.

title: Lebanon's Soothsayers
description: Clairvoyants have become Lebanon's unlikely political players as the country is racked by sectarian tension and political instability.

title: Is Wall Street Really Losing Its Edge?
description: The people who are warning that New York is losing its dominance as a global financial center because of overregulation make up a chorus of Cassandras, James Surowiecki writes in the latest issue of The New Yorker. The articles skeptical stance echoes Jenny Andersons Insider column in last weeks New York Times, in which she suggested there was some undue panic over the flight of companies to overseas markets.

title: No White Smoke
description: The Assembly Democrats just took a brief break from their closed-door conference, where they are trying to figure out what to do about picking a comptroller.

title: A Pre-Super Bowl Wardrobe Malfunction?
description: How cold is it in Chicago? Well, heres an answer to that question you wont hear every day: Its cold enough to crack a giant fiberglass football helmet off the head of a bronze lion.

title: A Sense of Place
description: Call it a Russian River Valley wine, not a cabernet sauvignon, says Appellation America. (Lars Klove for The New York Times ).

title: Are Jobs Easy to Get?
description: One thing that changed after Sept. 11, 2001 is that it became a lot harder to persuade Americans that the employment situation looks good.

title: Blogtalk: Evil Men and Wounded Democrats
description: Over the weekend Hillary Clinton made a joke about evil men, President Bush caught heat for his State of the Union reference to the Democrat Party, and the Iraqi Army fought a fierce battle with Shiite militants, a battle the president held as an example in the development of Iraqi soldiers. Today these topics, and new revelations about the battle, gave blogs lots of prime material.

title: Baker and Hamilton on Troop Increase
description: James A. Baker 3d testified before the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee today amid speculation that he would criticize the troop increase proposed by President Bush, with whose family Mr. Baker has long been allied. Though he did not endorse the new strategy, the Iraq Study Group co-chairman did not condemn the plan, either.

title: The Upside-Down Grill
description: New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, reintroduces the broiler.

title: Our Secret Stash of Oil
description: Last week, in his State of the Union address, President Bush proposed to spend $65 billion from the governments general fund to double the size of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. For most Americans, the reserve, where 700 million barrels of oil have been stored since the late 1970s, is mostly an article of faith: Few know that its located deep underground in four sites on the Gulf Coast, and because those sites are considered vital to national security, hardly anyone has seen it. But its time to take a closer look at the reserves purpose, its usefulness and its cost. Before we invest another $65 billion in this underground bank of oil, we should ask ourselves what were really getting for the money.

title: Games That Sell While Others Languish
description: The Nintendo Wii, which uses an innovative wireless controller to translate the players motions onto the screen, has upset the order of the video game world. In electronics stores and elsewhere, there are growing signs that the Wii has taken the lead in buzz and sales over another new console, the Sony PlayStation 3, which offers new superlatives in processing power and graphics.

title: For Hungarys Avant-Garde, a Memorial and (Almost) a Birthday
description: Joel Sachs does nothing by half measures, it seems. Last year Mr. Sachs, the director of the Juilliard Schools annual Focus! festival and a mainstay of New Yorks new-music scene, felt it was time to present a series devoted to contemporary Hungarian music. Soliciting the advice of colleagues was not enough, nor was traveling to Budapest: Mr. Sachs, according to his program note, spent July learning Hungarian.

title: Senate Adds Tax Breaks as It Moves Ahead on a Wage Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to move ahead on a bill to increase the minimum wage, signaling that the measure is likely to pass this week.

title: Tata Steel Buying Corus for $12 Billion
description: BANGALORE, India, Wednesday, Jan. 31  When the bidding was over, Tata Steel stepped away as the winner in a heated battle for its European rival, the Corus Group, topping an offer from Brazils Companhia Siderrgica Nacional. Tata agreed to at least pay $12.2 billion for Corus.

title: Times Sharply Drops Value of New England Papers
description: The New York Times Company said today that it was writing down by $814.4 million the value of its New England newspapers, The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, which have suffered from sluggish advertising and a migration of readers to the Internet.

title: Honesty in Elections
description: On Election Day last fall in Maryland, fliers were handed out in black neighborhoods with the heading Democratic Sample Ballot and photos of black Democratic leaders  and boxes checked off beside the names of the Republican candidates for senator and governor. They were a blatant attempt to fool black voters into thinking the Republican candidates were endorsed by black Democrats. In Orange County, Calif., 14,000 Latino voters got letters in Spanish saying it was a crime for immigrants to vote in a federal election. It didnt say that immigrants who are citizens have the right to vote.

title: Not-So-Strange Bedfellow
description: Heres a little foreign policy test. I am going to describe two countries  Country A and Country B  and you tell me which one is Americas ally and which one is not.

title: Bryant Barred for One Game After Hard Hit
description: In slow motion on computer screens around the country, especially in the N.B.A. offices, flashed the supposed Los Angeles crime scene from last weekend.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Jan. 13 about the writer Harold L. Humes misstated the time frame during which he served as campaign manager for Norman Mailer. He was the manager for Mr. Mailers aborted campaign for mayor of New York in the early 1960s, not in 1969. (Joe Flaherty was the manager of the campaign in that year.)

title: Barbaros Plight Shined a Light on Advances
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 30  Even after enduring eight months of searing emotions, the people most involved in attempting to save the Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro said the costly and complicated effort was a worthwhile pursuit.

title: A Threat to Defy Spitzer on Comptroller Selection
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  Democratic lawmakers were leaning on Tuesday toward reneging on the deal they made with Gov. Eliot Spitzer and choosing one of their own as state comptroller  a stance that drew a furious reaction from the Spitzer administration.

title: Iraqs Refugees
description: To calculate the price that Iraqis have paid for the American misadventure in their country, you have to deal in big, round, horrifying numbers. Civilians killed last year: 34,000. Driven from their homes within Iraq: 1.8 million. Fled to other countries: an additional 2 million, and growing. The number of Iraqis who have found refuge in the United States is easier to pin down. This country has admitted a grand total of 466 Iraqi refugees since 2003.

title: Manning Handles Questions as Easily as a Pass Rush
description: Miami

title: Reyna Joins M.L.S., and Says He Hopes Others Will Follow
description: Claudio Reyna said it was time to come home.

title: The Endlessly Maddening (for Liberals) Case of Ralph Nader
description: Early in the documentary An Unreasonable Man, it is noted that Ralph Nader is more likely to be remembered for his 2000 presidential campaign than for the decades of advocacy that preceded it. And the movie, an admiring but hardly uncritical portrait of Mr. Nader, confirms this suspicion by devoting nearly half of its more than two-hour running time to the 2000 election and its aftermath.

title: G.M. Changes Agencies, Assigning Saturn to Deutsch
description: General Motors, once reluctant to change agencies on its principal brands, is doing so for the second time in four months.

title: Lost Souls, and Puppets, in a Tour of the Afterlife
description: Walk into a New York theater at random and you have a decent chance of encountering a story about sex and its consequences, or a parody of some pop-culture phenomenon, or a tale of war and power. You have very little chance of encountering a play that looks beyond the earthly realm to the spiritual one. Life after death? Puh-lease; dont be so unfashionable.

title: Bush Promotes His Free Trade Initiatives
description: EAST PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 30  With Democrats making the case that his economic policies have benefited the rich more than the middle class, President Bush struck back on Tuesday, in the first of back-to-back speeches promoting what the White House characterizes as 41 consecutive months of economic growth.

title: For a Nation of Debaters, One Court to Rule Them All
description: A four-part program on PBS about the Supreme Court does not have to be boring, or so I believed as I sat down to watch a review copy of The Supreme Court, which begins tonight.

title: U.P.S. Profit Is Up; Slower Growth Seen
description: United Parcel Service Inc. reported a 7.5 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, but said that profit growth would slow this year.

title: A Hotel Room With Views of 5 Couples Relationships
description: Room 314 cracks open the door of an anonymous hotel room where, at different times, five couples navigate critical moments in their relationships. But whether dealing with unrequited love, suicidal depression or what appears to be a booty call gone awry, no one is permitted to check out without a dose of self-knowledge. You certainly dont get that at a Holiday Inn.

title: New Products and Demand in Emerging Markets Fatten Profits at P.& G. and Colgate
description: Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive reported profits yesterday that exceeded analysts estimates on consumer demand for new razors and soap and increased sales to emerging markets.

title: Vista Arrives With Limited Fanfare
description: Twelve years ago, Microsoft introduced a new operating system, Windows 95, in a frenzied global marketing blitz that was unlike anything the industry had ever seen.

title: Megastores March Up Avenue, and Paris Takes to Barricades
description: PARIS, Jan. 30  There was a time when the Champs-lyses stood for grand living, high style and serendipity. With the Arc de Triomphe on one end and the Tuileries Gardens on the other, you could discover an underground jazz band at midnight and down oysters and Champagne at dawn.

title: Expert Parking (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn Seeks Board Seat at Motorola
description: Motorola, Carl C. Icahn is calling.

title: Florida Gators on Top of Supercharged SEC
description: The basketball was a blur as it was passed among the Florida Gators. They were looking for the best shot, not merely a good shot. Open 18-footers were surrendered for open 10-footers, and Florida shot 58 percent in a rout of host Auburn last Saturday.

title: Sally Mann Portrait in Which Shes the Star
description: Sally Mann came to the worlds attention in the early 1990s with her book and exhibition Immediate Family, a series of luminous, haunting photographs of her young children, Emmett, Virginia and Jessie, that evoked the languid anxiety of preadolescence, the sense of somnolent August days soon to vanish with the coming winds of maturity, sex and longing.

title: Legislators Tell Coast Guard to Revamp Rebuilding Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Frustrated by reports of ships with cracking hulls, design flaws, cost overruns and construction delays, lawmakers demanded Tuesday that the Coast Guards leadership overhaul its $24 billion effort to rebuild its fleet or risk the programs cancellation.

title: Cheney and Critics: No Love Lost (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Countryside, Just as Imagined
description: PERUGIA, Italy  Unlike many Americans who decide to follow their dream of restoring an abandoned Italian house in the countryside, Douglas Andrews knew exactly what he was getting into.

title: To 08 Hopefuls, Media Technology Can Be Friend or Foe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Some of the nations most enduring memories of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton  memories she would happily erase  were etched on television more than a decade ago: She didnt stay home and bake cookies in her marriage. She wasnt some little woman, standing by my man, like Tammy Wynette. The headband. The hairstyles.

title: Raid at Hells Angels Club Leads to Dispute Over Arrest
description: A member of the New York chapter of the Hells Angels plans to file a suit against the city contending that he was illegally taken into custody after a search of the motorcycle clubs East Village headquarters on Monday.

title: Jurors Cant Be Excluded by Nationality, Judge Says
description: A federal magistrate judge has ruled that excluding prospective jurors because of their national origin is no more justified than barring them because of their race or sex.

title: Biden Unwraps His Bid for 08 With an Oops!
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  In an era of meticulous political choreography, the staging of the kickoff for this presidential candidacy could hardly have gone worse.

title: Nintendos Wii,  Radiating Fun, Is Eclipsing Sony Machine
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30  Some of the video game industrys smartest minds thought that couch potatoes wanted richer graphics and more challenging virtual worlds. It turns out that a lot of potatoes simply wanted to get off the couch.

title: Reporter Who Was Jailed Testifies in Libby Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Judith Miller, a former reporter for The New York Times, testified Tuesday as a witness for the prosecutor who had put her in jail for 85 days, recounting details of her once-confidential interviews with I. Lewis Libby Jr.

title: Brooklyn: Worker Killed in Fall
description: A day laborer doing tile work at a Brooklyn construction site died yesterday after he lost his bearings and fell four stories through an open elevator shaft, officials said. The man, whose identity was not immediately known, was pronounced dead at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center at 11:18 a.m., an hour after the accident, the police said. The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the citys Buildings Department are investigating. A Buildings Department spokeswoman, Kate Lindquist, said that a stop work order was issued because no guardrails were in place, as required, around elevator openings. A superintendent at Nesher Construction, the general contractor, said that the victim worked for a subcontractor and that protective plywood had been in place over all the elevator openings at the start of work.

title: Accord on Increasing Pell Grants
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The maximum federal grant for middle- and low-income students to attend college would increase for the first time in four years under a catchall spending bill that House and Senate Democrats agreed to on Tuesday.

title: Manhattan: Waiters Sue Steakhouse
description: Four employees of the Old Homestead steakhouse in Chelsea filed a lawsuit yesterday in Federal District Court charging the restaurant with improperly operating a tipping pool, and with denying them minimum and overtime wages. The plaintiffs charge that the restaurant, at 56 Ninth Avenue, deprived its waiters of more than $1 million in income over the past six years. The suit, filed by Louis Pechman of the law firm of Berke-Weiss & Pechman LLP, claims Old Homestead operated a tipping pool for employees and managers who were not eligible to receive tips. According to federal and state labor laws, only those employees connected with the actual serving of food and beverages are eligible for participation in a tip pool. Marc Sherry, who owns the restaurant, said he was unaware of the suit and declined to comment.

title: Second Schmertz for Millrose Hall
description: Of the 35 members in the Millrose Hall of Fame, all but one are renowned athletes. The only exception is Fred Schmertz, the meet director for 41 years. Now, Schmertz will be joined by his son, Howard, 81, who succeeded him and directed the Millrose Games, the worlds most celebrated indoor track and field meet, for 29 years, until 2003.

title: From Arms to Art
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  Two years ago, when the Noisette Company began its $3.5 million transformation of an abandoned warehouse at the shuttered United States Navy shipyard here, there were few takers for the 14 artists studios under construction.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 14 about A. I. Bezzerides, who wrote several novels that were adapted for films, omitted part of the title of one film and misidentified its director. The title is On Dangerous Ground, not Dangerous Ground, and the director was Nicholas Ray, not James Dassin.

title: Essay Linking Liberal Jews and Anti-Semitism Sparks a Furor
description: The American Jewish Committee, an ardent defender of Israel, is known for speaking out against anti-Semitism, but this advocacy group has recently stirred up a bitter and emotional debate with a new target: liberal Jews.

title: Songs From Sweden by Way of Britain and Two Epochs
description: Peter Bjorn and John kept flipping between two eras  the Merseybeat mid-1960s and the new wave early 1980s  during their sold-out set at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night. Both were times of crisp, upbeat, tuneful pop-rock: the first bright-eyed and fresh, the second more knowing and self-conscious. Peter Moren (on guitar), Bjorn Yttling (on bass) and John Eriksson (on drums) dont set out to revolutionize their chosen styles, only to give them a brisk, smart workout.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Dec. 18 about Herbert Gursky, an astrophysicist who studied the sources of X-rays from outside the solar system, referred imprecisely to some of these sources. A distant star he discovered is in the constellation Scorpius, not Scorpio, and the star was designated Scorpius X-1, not just Scorpius. The first recorded example of a black hole, which he and others discovered in 1971, was designated Cygnus X-1 or Cygnus XR-1  not just Cygnus. The errors were pointed out on Dec. 19 in an e-mail message that was misdirected within The Times. The correction was further delayed for research.

title: 4 Killed in Gas Explosion Near West Virginia Resort
description: An explosion at a store near a West Virginia ski resort yesterday killed four people and injured five others, the authorities said.

title: Google Posts Sharp Rise in Sales and Profits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31  Continuing its blockbuster growth, Google this afternoon reported a sharp rise in both sales and profits in the fourth quarter.

title: The Interest Was There, but Not the Money
description: Kobe Bryants only Madison Square Garden appearance of the season was nullified yesterday by a suspension. Had the Knicks managed their payroll better, Bryant sightings at the Garden might not be so rare.

title: Taking a Two-Century Voyage Through the Music of France
description: Theres something unfairly disarming about an all-French vocal recital. Both the language and the way French composers have woven music around it are so inherently seductive that, given a singer who has internalized both, resistance  or even detatchment  is futile. This repertory has always been high ground for the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, and for her recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening she and her pianist, Malcolm Martineau, explored it in an unusual way.

title: Opening the Gates at an Army Base
description: PICATINNY ARSENAL, N.J., Jan. 24  This huge military base in Morris County boasts that it has developed and deployed virtually all the lethal weaponry currently used by the United States Army. Now, the base will become a generator of revenue for itself by turning some of its vast real estate holdings into a high-tech research and development park.

title: What You Get for ... $3.9 Million
description: Portsmouth, R.I.

title: Summer Rentals: The Forecast Is Calm
description: The summer rental market used to be fairly predictable on the southern coast of Maine.

title: Harrison Opens Up on the Field, Not Off It
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30  Close to the end of the hour, Marvin Harrison was perched on the edge of his seat, asking all the questions.

title: Senate Allies of Bush Work to Halt Iraq Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Bush administrations allies in the Senate began a major effort on Tuesday to prevent a potentially embarrassing rejection of the presidents plan to push 20,000 more troops into Iraq.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about the extravagant 60th-birthday party planned for Stephen A. Schwarzman, a founder of the Blackstone Group, referred incorrectly to Katharine Grahams presence at Truman Capotes Black and White Ball, the New York social event of 1966. Mrs. Graham was the guest of honor; she was not simply one of Mr. Capotes guests.

title: An Ode to All the Magnificent Horses (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mystery Freight Train Out of Queens? It May Soon Be a Familiar Sight
description: EASTPORT, N.Y.  Gritty freight trains may be a familiar sight out West and in cowboy movies, but in Queens and Brooklyn and the neat suburbs of Long Island, they are a roaring, sooty cause for a big double take.

title: Bidding War for Roofing Products Maker Is Over
description: ElkCorp, a maker of roofing and building products, said yesterday that it planned to accept a bid for the company from Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group.

title: N.Y. Stock Exchange Chief Determined to Go East
description: The Village People sang Go West. John Thain, the chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, seems determined to go east.

title: Iran May Have Trained Attackers That Killed 5 American Soldiers, U.S. and Iraqis Say
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 30  Investigators say they believe that attackers who used American-style uniforms and weapons to infiltrate a secure compound and kill five American soldiers in Karbala on Jan. 20 may have been trained and financed by Iranian agents, according to American and Iraqi officials knowledgeable about the inquiry.

title: Scientists Criticize White House Stance on Climate Change Findings
description: Under its new Democratic chairman, Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform took on the Bush administrations handling of climate change science yesterday, and even the Republicans on the panel had little good to say about the administrations actions.

title: Deal Struck on Claims of Nazi Era
description: After nearly 10 years of struggling to have a big Italian insurance company pay claims on life insurance policies sold to victims of the Holocaust, lawyers who say they represent most of the victims are giving up the fight.

title: Staten Island: Woman Shot Dead in Her Car
description: A woman was fatally shot in the head as she sat in the drivers seat of her car last evening at a park-and-ride lot near Pleasant Plains Avenue, the police said. The woman, Jean Kane, 58, was declared dead on arrival at Staten Island South Hospital, the police said. An officer who was nearby heard the shot shortly before 6 p.m. and arrived at the scene to find Ms. Kanes body slumped in her four-door gray Volkswagen. Investigators say that someone probably drove up to Ms. Kanes car, got out, shot her through a window and drove away.

title: A Soviet Agricultural Success: Vast Greenhouse Complex
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29  In a city starved for winter light, little could seem more out of a place than this: on a day dimmed to gray by a canopy of clouds, Russian workers in short sleeves picking green lettuce and fresh herbs, all while illuminated by brilliant light.

title: Christies to Raise Its Fee
description: Taking a leaf from its rival Sothebys, the auction house Christies plans to raise the commission it charges buyers.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about an auction of silver that had been owned by the First Church in Salem, in Massachusetts, attributed an erroneous distinction to the church. The Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan, founded in 1628, is the oldest continuously operating Protestant congregation in the United States  not the First Church in Salem, which was founded a year later.

title: Democrats Spending Plan Would Raise Some Budgets
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Bloomberg News)  Education, veterans health care, international AIDS relief and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are among the government programs that would receive more money this year under a spending plan released Tuesday by House Democrats.

title: Dead Officers Son Asks Bush to Increase Aid to 9/11 Workers
description: After meeting with President Bush today, the son of a former police officer who died last week from an illness that may have been linked to his rescue work at the World Trade Center on 9/11 said Mr. Bush had assured him that he wanted to expand federal financing for the medical needs of people injured at ground zero.

title: Fighting Eases on First Day of a Cease-Fire by Gaza Factions
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30  After five days of clashes in the Gaza Strip, Palestinian factions on Tuesday mostly observed the latest cease-fire, though one Hamas member was shot dead.

title: Wall Street Finds a Lot to Like About Tobacco
description: There are plenty of reasons cigarettes would seem to be a terrible business.

title: Murder Trial Hears Account of Marital Wars Last Fight
