description: An Upper East Side man testified at his murder trial yesterday, describing what he saw as his wifes decade-long mental breakdown and admitting that he grabbed a knife and stabbed her in the kitchen of their home.

title: Cooking Under Pressure, Thats Reality
description: THE final two contestants on Top Chef didnt get this far on character or charm.

title: Big Trouble for a Small-Town Ingnue
description: As sopranos age, it is natural to expect their voices to mature, to grow darker and thicker. Karita Mattila is now 46. And, as her riveting portrayal of the title role of Janaceks Jenufa on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera made vibrantly clear, Ms. Mattilas artistry is maturing.

title: A Changing Battle on AIDS Is Reflected in a Quilt
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30  It has been 20 years since Cleve Jones started the AIDS Memorial Quilt here, painting the name of a friend who had died from the disease on a simple piece of fabric.

title: Bing Devine, Builder of World Series Winners, Dies at 90
description: Bing Devine, who transformed the St. Louis Cardinals and the Mets into World Series champions in the 1960s in a career spanning seven decades as a baseball executive, died Saturday in St. Louis. He was 90.

title: A Little Bit of a Bad Thing Can Be Good
description: Forgive that older gentleman in Malibu, Calif., if he was not among the millions mesmerized by American Idol last night. For one thing, it was his 85th birthday, and he might have had better things to do. For another, this notion of singers so wincingly bad that you cant turn away? Been there. Done that. About 40 years ago.

title: Knicks Inject the Garden With a Buzz and a Win
description: The Los Angeles Lakers missed Kobe Bryants other-worldliness, fans at Madison Square Garden missed his showmanship and the Knicks, for once, did not miss the golden opportunity that was handed to them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about efforts by public colleges to attract minority students misstated the name of the organization headed by Roger Clegg that opposes racial preferences. It is the Center for Equal Opportunity, not the Council for Equal Opportunity.

title: ESPN and the Tennis Channel Strike Deal on TV Rights
description: ESPN and the Tennis Channel agreed yesterday to share the rights to televise the French and Australian Opens, an arrangement that will bring a far higher profile to the Tennis Channel, which has 10 million subscribers.

title: Britain: Top Blair Fund-Raiser Arrested Again
description: The Labor Partys chief fund-raiser, Lord Levy, was arrested as part of an investigation into whether the party elevated people to the House of Lords in exchange for loans. It was the second time that Lord Levy, left, a close ally of Prime Minister Tony Blair, has been arrested in the inquiry; he has not been charged with a crime. The police have arrested three others, none of whom have been charged, in their investigation, and have spoken to more than 90 people, including Mr. Blair and Michael Howard, the former leader of the Conservative Party. A spokesman for Lord Levy said he completely denies any allegations of wrongdoing whatsoever.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the future of relations between Turkey and Armenia following the funeral for Hrant Dink, a Turkish-Armenian newspaper editor killed in Istanbul on Jan. 19, misidentified the issue between the two countries that Turkey has said should be examined by a governmental history commission. It is the 1915 Armenian genocide  not the political status of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that Armenia claims but that Turkey recognizes as part of Azerbaijan. (Go to Article)

title: Fed Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged today, as it has since last June, and it signaled that it will continue its holding pattern for some time to come.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,070 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: A Top Editor Returns to Times to Lead Washington Bureau
description: Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, effective March 5.

title: Once a Dream Fuel, Palm Oil May Be an Eco-Nightmare
description: AMSTERDAM, Jan. 25  Just a few years ago, politicians and environmental groups in the Netherlands were thrilled by the early and rapid adoption of sustainable energy, achieved in part by coaxing electrical plants to use biofuel  in particular, palm oil from Southeast Asia.

title: Mary Cheney Publicly Defends Her Pregnancy
description: Mary Cheney, the lesbian daughter of Vice President Dick Cheney, today for the first time publicly defended her decision to become pregnant and asserted that same-sex couples are equally capable of raising children as heterosexual couples.

title: Ukraine: Pro-West Foreign Minister Quits
description: Boris I. Tarasyuk, the foreign minister, resigned after a constitutional dispute over his post. Mr. Tarasyuk has been a close ally of President Viktor A. Yushchenko and the most vocal proponent of leading Ukraine closer to the European Union and NATO. Parliament voted to dismiss him in December and later moved to remove the presidents power to appoint ministers overseeing foreign and defense matters, a move a weakened Mr. Yushchenko declared unconstitutional. Mr. Tarasyuk, in televised remarks reported by news agencies, said he resigned after a court hearing in the dispute was postponed. Mr. Yushchenkos office declared that he would appoint a successor.

title: Carter Harman, 88, Composer, Music Critic and Record Producer, Dies
description: Carter Harman, a composer, music critic, author and record producer, died on Jan. 23 in Stowe, Vt. He was 88 and lived in Waterbury, Vt.

title: Mixed News for Wolves
description: The Interior Departments decision on Monday to remove the gray wolves that inhabit the western Great Lakes region from the endangered species list represents yet another triumph for the much-maligned Endangered Species Act. First listed in 1974, when their numbers had dwindled to the low hundreds, the wolf population there now numbers about 4,000, thanks almost entirely to the acts prohibitions on hunting and trapping. State and tribal governments will now be responsible for keeping their numbers at healthy levels.

title: 50 Iraqis Die as Holiday Brings Spasm of Sectarian Killing
description: BAGHDAD, Jan. 30  Women dressed in black had just set out large caldrons to cook the traditional feast on the holy day of Ashura, a simple meal of rice and lamb in a tomato-based sauce. Children crowded around the pots as men wailed in a ritualistic mourning ceremony and guards scanned the crowd at the Shiite mosque near Baquba for would-be killers.

title: Kellogg Profit Falls 5% as Wheat Cost Rises
description: The Kellogg Company, the largest United States cereal maker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 5.2 percent as wheat costs soared and the company spent more on advertising.

title: Israeli Court Convicts Ex-Minister in Sex Scandal
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31  An Israeli court convicted Haim Ramon, a former justice minister, today on charges that, while in office, he forcibly kissed a young female soldier. The outcome in the highly publicized case has added to the cloud of scandal surrounding the countrys leadership.

title: After Shooting, Amish School Embodies Effort to Heal
description: NICKEL MINES, Pa., Jan. 30  Nearly four months ago, a milk delivery-truck driver lined up 10 girls in a one-room schoolhouse in this Amish farming community and opened fire, killing five of them and wounding five others before turning the gun on himself.

title: Judge Puts Mayo Back in Big Game
description: A West Virginia judge ordered an injunction yesterday that allowed the high school basketball star O. J. Mayo to play last night in a game featuring two of the countrys top teams.

title: Her Deadly Illness Becomes Her Familys Struggle
description: The quinceaera photo hangs high up on the living room wall: Wanda Reynoso, at 15, in a sparkling white dress and a tiara, radiant against the pink backdrop.
Chefs on the Move

title: 12 New Yorkers Among Finalists for National Science Prize
description: As a first grader, Kathryn Blair Friedman was so allergic to wheat, peanuts and sesame that she had to settle for carrots whenever her schoolmates celebrated class birthdays with cupcakes.

title: State Farm Is There, Right by the Backboard
description: ALTHOUGH it seems that the only thing Madison Avenue is doing this week is making commercials for the Super Bowl, marketers are still finding ways to fill other sports spaces with advertising. If you doubt that, look up the next time you attend a college basketball game or watch one on television, and study the framework behind the backboard.

title: American Road Trip Through Arab Eyes
description: On the Road in America looks, on first viewing, like the sort of television show that Al Jazeera and MTV might produce if they could be coaxed together in front of an editing terminal. A 12-part reality series, currently being broadcast throughout the Middle East, On the Road features a caravan of young, good-looking Arabs crisscrossing America on a mission to educate themselves and the people they encounter along the way.

title: Molly Ivins, Populist Texas Columnist, Dies at 62
description: Molly Ivins, the liberal newspaper columnist who delighted in skewering politicians and interpreting, and mocking, her Texas culture, died today at her home in Austin. She was 62.

title: Killing Puts Focus on Corruption in Chinese News Media
description: SHANGHAI, Jan. 30  Lan Chengzhang sat in a car outside the office of a mining company while a colleague ventured inside to make inquiries.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Athens Protest Seeks Return of Elgin Marbles

title: Economy Sped Up at End of 2006
description: The economy gained speed in the final three months of 2006, as Americans shrugged off the slump in the real estate market by spending more money on everything from computers to food.

title: The Human Rights of a Disabled Child (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoo Planning to Add 100 Web Sites for Entertainment
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 30  Yahoo said Tuesday that it planned to build individual Web sites around 100 entertainment brands this year that would pull together content from Yahoos sprawling array of online properties.

title: Hobbled by Disappointing Sales and a Loss at the Game Unit, Sonys Profit Drops 5%
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30  The dip in Sonys quarterly earnings released early Tuesday underscores what many analysts call the biggest single challenge now facing the recovering Japanese electronics conglomerate: the shaky start of its long-awaited PlayStation 3 game console.

title: Bears Anderson Likes Being in a Rush
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30  As a rookie, Mark Anderson of the Chicago Bears has never played against Peyton Manning. Anderson hopes to introduce himself on Sunday. Because when Anderson meets quarterbacks, they often end up lying on the ground.

title: U.S. Judge Ends 20-Year Case to Deport 2 Tied to Terrorists
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30  Chastising the government with poetry and blunt language, an immigration judge on Tuesday ended 20-year-old deportation proceedings against two of eight men who had been accused of ties to a Palestinian organization classified as a terrorist group.

title: Two Donations, Deep in Tradition, Given to Neediest Cases Campaign
description: As the current campaign for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund entered it final days, two large donations from two different groups were being tallied yesterday.

title: Libbys Lawyers Question Reporters Memory
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  A lawyer for I. Lewis Libby Jr. tried to portray a former New York Times reporter today as having a fuzzy memory of her conversations with Mr. Libby about a C.I.A. agent whose husband was a critic of the Bush administration.

title: White House to Release Details on Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Bowing to bipartisan pressure from lawmakers, the Justice Department announced today that it was turning over to select members of Congress secret documents detailing the National Security Agencys domestic eavesdropping program.

title: Choice for No. 2 at State Dept. Defends Bushs Stance on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  John D. Negroponte, nominated as deputy secretary of state, defended the Bush administrations more confrontational policy with Iran in a Senate confirmation hearing that was peppered with demands from both sides of the aisle that the United States show restraint in dealing with Tehran.

title: All Over America, Wines Search for Identity
description: MAYBE it was the 2004 Peninsula Cellars riesling that I tried last fall out in San Francisco. It was dry and delicious with a minerally flavor that I dont find so often in American rieslings. What surprised me most of all, though, was the wines provenance: Old Mission Peninsula, north of Traverse City, Mich.

title: Ex-Enron Executive Reports to Prison
description: Michael J. Kopper, a former Enron Corporation finance executive who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt off its balance sheets, started serving a three-year prison sentence yesterday in Big Spring, Tex.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,409,805.46

title: Joining China to Find a Yao Who Can Hit
description: BEIJING, Jan. 30  Two of the worlds most closely watched empires signed a deal here Tuesday. China wants a half-decent national baseball team. The Yankees want a toe in the Chinese sports market, and the chance to find  better yet, develop  Major League Baseballs Yao Ming.

title: Spitzer Unveils $120.6 Billion Budget Proposal
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31  Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed a $120.6 billion budget today that would increase spending by 6.3 percent over the current fiscal year, a higher spending increase than many expected but one that allows the new governor to pay for his major campaign promises, including billions of dollars of property tax cuts and new education aid.

title: In Killers Courtyard, Drawing Their Own Conclusions
description: On the sidewalk outside the Stapleton Houses on Staten Island, the dreary complex where Ronell Wilson once lived, people talked about the sentence that was handed up yesterday without mentioning the footnote.

title: New York Lawmakers Obtain $25 Million for Ill 9/11 Workers
description: After impassioned pleas by members of New Yorks Congressional delegation, the White House agreed yesterday to spend $25 million for the care and treatment of 9/11 rescue workers who became ill after being exposed to toxic dust at ground zero.

title: F.D.A. Widens Safety Reviews on New Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced changes yesterday that were intended to ensure that marketed drugs are as safe as advertised, including the first effort to do a comprehensive assessment of the safety of drugs 18 months after introduction.

title: German Court Seeks Arrest of 13 C.I.A. Agents
description: FRANKFURT, Jan. 31  In the most serious legal challenge yet to the Central Intelligence Agencys secret transfers of terrorism suspects, a German court has issued an arrest warrant for 13 people in connection with the mistaken kidnapping and jailing of a German citizen of Lebanese descent.

title: Now, for $35, an Insiders Access to Hot Tables
description: PEOPLE who go out to eat in New York can be divided in plenty of ways, but the division that matters most is this: You are either someone who can get a great table on a Saturday night, or youre not.

title: Jury Agrees on Death Sentence for the Killer of Two Detectives
description: A federal jury sentenced a 24-year-old Staten Island man to death yesterday for killing two undercover police detectives in 2003. It was the first successful federal capital punishment prosecution in New York in more than 50 years.

title: Day 2 of New School Bus Routes Fails to End Confusion
description: For the second day, widespread confusion over changes in school bus routes roiled the New York City school system, leaving parents exasperated and bewildered.

title: All Areas Open in New Blueprint for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30  No neighborhoods would be off limits for development in a new $14 billion plan for this citys recovery introduced Tuesday, the latest foray in a process that has been going on since shortly after Hurricane Katrina flooded New Orleans 17 months ago.

title: Growing the Winter Tomato
description: Imagine a poem that is perfect in shape but refuses to say anything. And yet it sells well because it is the only kind of poem available for more than half the year, and people insist on reading poetry, even out of season. That is the winter tomato. In redness and roundness it says tomato, in every way except the one that matters: flavor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Sunday about Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy gave the incorrect name in some copies of the city where one of his former assistants now coaches in the National Football League. Rod Marinelli is the head coach in Detroit, not Green Bay.

title: Florida: $75 Million Donated to Hospital
description: The Boca Raton Community Hospital announced that it had received $75 million from the Schmidt Family Foundation, one of the largest gifts given to a hospital. The money will help underwrite a new academic medical center focusing on hospital safety. The center will expand Florida Atlantic Universitys two-year medical training program to four years, qualifying students for a degree from the Miller School of Medicine at the University of Miami.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) WHAT REMAINS: THE LIFE AND WORK OF SALLY MANN It never occurred to me to leave home to make art, says the photographer Sally Mann, who built a career chronicling the lives of her children. The things that are close to you are the things that you can photograph the best. In this documentary from Steven Cantor, Ms. Mann embarks on a new project: a provocative photo series that explores the subject of death and decay through images of not only her son and two daughters but her husband, Larry, whose body is changing because of a rare form of muscular dystrophy. She also looks at how nature assimilates the body once life has left it, and in doing so confronts American attitudes toward death, through photographs examining the scars left on her property after an armed fugitive, being hunted by police, shot himself; landscapes from the Civil War battlefield of Antietam; a forensics study showing human decomposition; and images of the bones and skin of a pet greyhound long since departed.

title: When Life Hands You Lemons, Make Pasta and Confit
description: WITH winter having unmistakably arrived, the sunny presence of lemons is more welcome than ever. Each year, demand for lemons peaks with the temperatures, as millions are squeezed for lemonade. But this is the time of year you need their brightness the most.

title: Architectural Skills: Excellent. Personal Skills: Not So Good.
description: Listening to friends complain about their contractors is a familiar trial of New York living. But how many can claim to have heard a bona fide genius hold forth on this riveting topic?

title: Italy: Minister Pleads for End to Party Squabbling
description: Foreign Minister Massimo DAlema issued an urgent plea to his political allies for an end to the bickering among parties that he worries could bring down the center-left government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi. I am going to Japan, he said in an interview in the newspaper La Repubblica. I humbly ask our allies: Let there still be a government on my return. Since taking power from Silvio Berluconi last spring, Mr. Prodi has faced deep divisions in his diverse, nine-party coalition. In recent days, a proposed law allowing for same-sex unions has added tension.

title: Letters
description: Always Time for Her Baby

title: The Many Roads Not Taken on the Way to Civil War
description: Historians tell stories. That is their profession. And the goal of storytelling is to impose order on a disorderly array of facts, to steer events toward a conclusion that seems satisfyingly final, even inevitable. In Cry Havoc! Nelson D. Lankford disrupts the process. He unravels the events that led the North and the South to war in the weeks after Lincolns inauguration in March 1861, disturbing the time-honored march of history with a series of provocative what-ifs. At every turn in a now familiar story, he suggests alternatives, missed opportunities and roads not taken.

title: Mama Hugs Iowa
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa

title: F.A.A. to Propose Letting Airline Pilots Fly Until Age 65
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Federal Aviation Administration will propose allowing airline pilots to fly until they are 65 years old, dropping a 47-year requirement that they retire at 60, the agencys administrator said on Tuesday.

title: A Sitcom Thats All About Me, Sarah
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30  Those who know Sarah Silverman only from her much discussed star turn in the 2005 comedy film The Aristocrats and from her one-woman concert movie, Sarah Silverman: Jesus Is Magic, might bristle at the notion that another overnight wonder has been granted that holy grail of comedy, the self-titled sitcom.

title: You Want Innovation? Offer a Prize
description: Besides the fact that both are considered great movies, The Wizard of Oz and Silence of the Lambs dont have much in common. One is the story of a girl from Kansas whos transported to a magical land where animals dance and sing, and the other is about a serial killer who eats his victims. You wouldnt necessarily expect people to have similar reactions to the two movies.

title: Small Schools to Be Added by September
description: The city Education Department yesterday announced that it would open 20 small secondary schools in September, including five schools for students at serious risk of dropping out. But the department, which has struggled to find sites for new schools, did not announce the locations for 10 of them.

title: Staten Island: Citys Electrical Capacity to Increase
description: G.E. Energy Financial Services, part of General Electric, plans to announce a deal today that will expand New York Citys electrical capacity by 300 megawatts, the equivalent of a midsize power plant. The city currently uses roughly 12,000 megawatts at peak consumption times. The deal involves transferring power from a General Electric plant in Linden, N.J., by a cable, in use since 1992, that runs through the bedrock under the Arthur Kill and connects to a Consolidated Edison substation on Staten Island. In an auction on Jan. 16, four companies, including Con Edison, bought transmission rights. The deal requires construction of three transformers by the end of 2009.

title: Nets End 5-Game Trip by Making Their Point
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 30  Everything the Nets would like to be was wrapped into their 116-115 victory over the Utah Jazz on Monday night.

title: Queens: Hit-and-Run Leaves Man Dead
description: A 69-year-old man was killed in a hit-and-run accident yesterday while he was crossing a street in Springfield Gardens, the police said. The man, whose identity was not released last night, was walking across 140th Avenue near 156th Street about 6 p.m. when he was hit by a dark-colored jeep, which drove off. The man was declared dead on arrival at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said.

title: Mobility Was an Early Game Plan for Bears Tillman
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30  Charles Tillman was born in Chicago and plays for the Bears. Those bare facts of his life cover up the reality of his peripatetic existence. Between kindergarten and 12th grade, Tillman, whose father, Donald, was a sergeant in the Army, attended 11 schools.

title: For Those Who Think They Know Sushi, a Delectable Lesson in Trust
description: A preciously intricate sushi omakase, or chefs choice  the term literally means trusting the chef  is now available to go from Sushi of Gari (402 East 78th Street, 212-517-5340) and the new Sushi of Gari 46 (347 West 46th Street, 212- 957-0046). This collection of items is an indulgence, not your usual sushi takeout.

title: Food Calendar
description: Beer and Tapas

title: Rising Costs Put N.Y. Transit Projects at Risk
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority faces surging costs that could force it to eliminate or postpone badly needed projects less than halfway through a five-year, $21 billion program to expand and improve its transit system. By one estimate, the program is now $1.4 billion over budget.

title: History Teacher Becomes Podcast Celebrity
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the possibility of Rupert Murdoch joining the Chandler familys bid for the Tribune Company misstated the source of a comment by Alfonse DAmato, the former Republican senator from New York, about the merits of such a move by Mr. Murdoch. Mr. DAmatos comment was from a column in The Long Island Business News, not Newsday.

title: As the Sun Beats Down, So Can the Stress
description: MIAMI

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Jan. 19 about two shows at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, featuring the works of Henri Cartier-Bresson and Martin Munkacsi, referred imprecisely to some of the countries Munkacsi visited on assignment for the German publisher Ullstein. Algeria and Egypt are part of Africa; he did not visit them in addition to Africa.

title: Recycle, but Dont Iron (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Bad Boy Chef, Hes Certainly Polite
description: THE chef Gordon Ramsay has a British television show called The F Word, an American television show called Hells Kitchen and, by all accounts and appearances, the kind of foul mouth and foul temper those titles suggest.

title: In a Yale Dining Hall, Independent Study at the Microwave
description: AS students streamed into a towering Gothic dining hall at Yale University last week, appraising the plats du jour on a cafeteria buffet, one of their classmates was concocting his own sauce from peanut butter and a dark liquid.

title: Fire Department Relents on Locker Policy
description: The New York Fire Department bowed to its largest union yesterday by amending a policy that prohibited firefighters from having anything but their names and locker numbers on the outside of their lockers. The policy was intended to keep racist and pornographic material out of the citys firehouses after a string of complaints. But the Uniformed Firefighters Association said the ban had been carried too far when unit commanders began clearing locker doors of flag stickers, Mass cards commemorating fallen colleagues, and other items. The union threatened to sue if the policy was not changed by today. Late yesterday, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta issued new regulations spelling out prohibited material, including sexually explicit photographs and any discriminatory or obscene material.

title: Big Investors Breathing New Life Into Gasping Auto Parts Suppliers
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30  These are dire times for Detroits automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of largely invisible companies that make steering wheels, transmissions and other components for the vehicles that roll off the assembly lines.

title: Ecuador: Presidents Supporters Try to Storm Congress
description: Hundreds of protesters tried to storm Congress, forcing violent clashes with the police. The protesters, largely supporters of President Rafael Correa, a leftist economist, had gathered to criticize an effort by lawmakers to raise their own salaries and to show support for a plan by Mr. Correa to convene an assembly to rewrite parts of the Constitution. Tensions have been building between Mr. Correa and Congress.

title: Talks to Resume on North Korea and Weapons
description: BEIJING, Jan. 30  China announced Tuesday that talks over North Koreas nuclear weapons would resume in Beijing next week, the latest in a long series of negotiations that have failed to curb its nuclear program.

title: British Police Arrest 9 in Alleged Kidnapping Plot
description: LONDON, Jan. 31  British police conducted a series of raids today, starting before daybreak, to arrest nine people whom the authorities said were terrorists conspiring to kidnap and torture a British Muslim soldier, behead him and broadcast video images of his execution on the Internet.

title: Maureen Cannon, 84, a Poet of the Everyday, in Light Verse, Dies
description: Maureen Cannon, a heavy hitter in the world of light verse who in the last four decades published more than 1,000 poems, most written in under a minute, died on Thursday at her home in Wyckoff, N.J. She was 84 and had lived in Ridgewood, N.J., for many years.

title: You Won. Now Legislate! (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Is Not Above the Law
description: Washington

title: Schoolboy Friedkin, Boxer, Dies at 89
description: Bernie Friedkin, a native of Brownsville, Brooklyn, who was known as Schoolboy and who as a professional boxer in the late 1930s and early 40s battled many of his opponents to a draw  including three former lightweight champions  died Jan. 18 in Brooklyn. He was 89.

title: The Boring Old Broiler Turns Out to Be a Superstar
description: ITS right there, invisible, inside your oven, the most underappreciated, taken-for-granted appliance in your kitchen: the broiler.

title: Following a Blue-Collar Dude, on the Road and in the Nude
description: The Naked Trucker & T-Bones Show, which has been appearing on Comedy Central for the last few weeks, is a kind of road and variety show, a cousin, in spirit, to the Blue Collar Comedians. But its a dopier, unwelcome cousin  more wayward and unhinged  with far less investment in the virtue of common sense.

title: Spitzer to Offer Larger Budget, but With Property Tax Cuts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  Gov. Eliot Spitzer will propose a budget of more than $120 billion Wednesday that would increase overall spending by more than 6.3 percent, a larger increase than his predecessor, George E. Pataki, proposed last year but significantly lower than the budget enacted by the Legislature, people briefed on the plan said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The front-page Your Money column on Saturday, about the possibility that people might be saving too much for retirement, misstated the parameters of a calculator from Fidelity Investments that helps consumers determine their future financial needs. Social Security payments are included  not excluded  in Fidelitys calculations.

title: Sosa Agrees to Minor League Deal With Rangers
description: Sammy Sosa returned to baseball yesterday, agreeing to terms on a minor league contract with the Texas Rangers. The deal carries no guarantees except the opportunity to add a chapter to his once-prominent career.

title: Village May Have Housed Builders of Stonehenge
description: New excavations near Stonehenge have uncovered hearths, timbers and other remains of what archaeologists say was probably the village of workers who erected the monoliths on Salisbury Plain in England.

title: Manhattan: Hells Angels Member Says Hell Sue City
description: Richard West, a member of the New York chapter of the Hells Angels, says he will file a lawsuit against the city, claiming that he was illegally taken into custody after a search of the motorcycle clubs East Village headquarters at 77 East Third Street on Monday. Dozens of police officers, backed by sharpshooters, helicopters and heavy equipment, used a search warrant to seek evidence connected to the beating of a woman outside the building on Sunday night. Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer for the Hells Angels, said the police used excessive force. The club had refused to allow several officers to enter the heavily fortified building, so the larger contingent arrived.

title: One in Eight Adults in the City Has Diabetes, a Study Finds
description: One in eight adults in New York City has diabetes, and nearly twice as many appear to be developing it  a picture even grimmer than that of the nation as a whole, according to the citys first attempt to definitively measure the rate of the disease.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Step Up Plan to Attract More Visitors
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  One year after the Bush administration vowed to try to slow the decline of overseas visitors to the United States, travel industry executives and some Democratic lawmakers say that the initiative needs to be stepped up.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the future of relations between Turkey and Armenia following the funeral for Hrant Dink, a Turkish-Armenian newspaper editor killed in Istanbul on Jan. 19, misidentified the issue between the two countries that Turkey has said should be examined by a governmental history commission. It is the 1915 Armenian genocide  not the political status of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that Armenia claims but that Turkey recognizes as part of Azerbaijan.

title: For Ruland, Reading Is Therapeutic
description: Jeff Ruland gave his winless basketball team the day off yesterday. But things got worse anyway.

title: An Irish Bar, Defying Time, Manages to Cheat It
description: GARRISON, N.Y.

title: Sharing Romanian Under a Sphinx
description: MARIGOLD walls, goldenrod tablecloths, egg yolks spilling into moist corn-colored mamaliga: yellow, yellow, yellow at Acasa in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: State Finds Serious Problems at Gibbs School in Manhattan
description: The New York State Education Department said yesterday that it had found serious problems at a two-year commercial college in New York City, Katharine Gibbs School - New York, and that it would close the college if the deficiencies were not corrected.

title: Guest Columnist Patrick Schmitt
description: (One of our medalists in the reader column contest was Patrick Schmitt, and as a reward he has this space to write a column. He chose to write about Rex Grossman. But first he answered a few questions from the Fifth Down)

title: US Airways Withdraws Offer for Delta
description: US Airways said Wednesday that it would withdraw its $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta Air Lines out of bankruptcy after the offer failed to win the support of the official committee of Delta's creditors.

title: Country Chic in Umbria
description: Tour Douglas Andrews's exquisitely renovated farmhouse in Perugia, Italy.

title: Istanbul (Not Constantinople!)
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bush's Visit to New York
description: The president spoke at Federal Hall and visited the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Your Turn to Tell the Story: Cambodia
Currents
description: Playful objects with an Argentine flavor, shaping Parisian style in fantasy and food and more.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Looking forward to snow days.

title: Tata Steel Wins Corus With $12 Billion Bid
description: When the bidding was over, Tata Steel stepped away as the winner in a heated battle for its European rival, the Corus Group, topping an offer from Brazils Companhia Siderurgica Nacional. Tata agreed to pay at least $12.2 billion for Corus.

title: Publishing Deal Maker Sells Cambium Learning
description: The former chief executive of Houghton Mifflin, Nader F. Darehshori, who engineered the book publishers 2001 sale to Vivendi Universal for $2.2 billion, has sold his five-year old education publishing start-up, Cambium Learning, to a private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson of New York.

title: Motorola: How Far Will Icahn Go?
description: Carl C. Icahns announcement Tuesday that he would be seeking a seat on Motorolas board had industry observers wondering what the well-known activist investor was up to this time. Motorola shares jumped 6.9 percent, to $19.58, in a sign that investors hoped Mr. Icahn might force a showdown with Motorola to make significant changes.

title: Big Investors Bail Out Gasping Auto Parts Suppliers
description: In these are dire times for Detroits automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of auto-parts suppliers, why are big name investors like Carl C. Icahn, Wilbur L. Ross and Cerberus Capital pouring their cash into what seems like a losing proposition? The answer, suggests The New York Times, is that, while business for auto suppliers has evaporated in Detroit, it is expanding in the rest of the world as vehicle sales increase globally. Of course, the cheap price tags and low interest rates are not hurting either.

title: Altria Spinoff Highlights Tobaccos Charms
description: In what at first glance may seem counterintuitive, Wall Streets enthusiasm for Altrias plans to spin off its Kraft Foods unit is not because Kraft, the worlds second-largest food company, will finally shed the taint of tobacco, but rather that the tobacco giant will finally be rid of Kraft. Altria is expected to announce a timetable for the spinoff on Wednesday. After cutting Kraft loose, Altria may step up the pace of its tobacco-related takeovers, analysts told Bloomberg News.

title: Ex-Enron Executive Reports to Prison
description: Michael J. Kopper, a former finance executive at Enron who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt, started serving a three-year prison sentence Tuesday in Big Spring, Tex. Mr. Kopper, 42, entered the prison about 11 a.m. yesterday, a United States Bureau of Prisons official said. The former executive, a top lieutenant of Enrons chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, managed daily operations for Fastow-controlled partnerships in the fraud that ultimately destroyed the company.

title: Sonys Big Banking I.P.O.
description: Sonys financial chief reconfirmed Tuesday that the company was eyeing an initial public offering of its banking and insurance unit, Sony Financial Holdings, in what analysts say could be one of the years biggest offerings. Analysts are predicting that the I.P.O. of the consumer-electronics and entertainment giants financial arm could be worth $4 billion and take place as early as this summer according to press reports.

title: ElkCorp Accepts Rival Offer, Pressuring Carlyle
description: ElkCorp, a maker of roofing and building products, said Tuesday that it planned to accept a bid for the company from the Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group. ElkCorps board has determined that the binding offer of $43.50 a share by Building Materials is superior to Carlyles $42-a-share bid. The move gives the buyout firm five days to raise its latest bid.

title: Chip Maker Admits Falsification in Options Backdating
description: Admitting for the first time that former officials intentionally priced stock options retroactively and falsified documents, KLA-Tencor restated its past results on Monday to include $370 million in charges related to those backdated options. The company, which makes chip-inspection equipment, handed out misdated options largely between 1997 and 2002, it said in its annual report for fiscal 2006, which it belatedly filed with regulators Monday.

title: Owner of Hedge Fund Firm Is Sentenced
description: The owner of the hedge fund management firm Durus Capital Management was sentenced Tuesday to three years in prison and three years of supervised release, federal prosecutors said. Scott Sacane, who owned and controlled Durus, waived indictment in December 2005 and pleaded guilty to one count of violating the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.

title: MySQL Mulls I.P.O.
description: MySQL, one of the leading open source database vendors, is preparing itself for an initial public offering and could be ready to go public before the end of the year, the Swedish companys chief executive, Marten Mickos, told Computer Business Review. We are planning to go public, Mr. Mickos told the publication. However, he added that the company was in no hurry to go public after raising $18.5 million in venture capital at the beginning of last year.

title: It Takes a Book Party: Hillary Ribs Colleagues
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took a good-natured poke at Senators Barack Obama and Chuck Schumer Tuesday night at a book party she threw for Mr. Schumer at Hunan Dynasty on Capitol Hill, as she reviewed some of the potential titles for his new tome about the way forward for the Democratic Party.

title: Power Plant Protesters Descend on Merrill Headquarters
description: Perhaps emboldened by the emergence of climate change as one of the top issues at this years World Economic Forum, global-warming activists stepped up their fight against Merrill Lynch for its role in financing TXUs $10 billion plan to build 11 coal-fueled power plants in Texas. TXUs plans for the plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air, and Merrills involvement have already drawn sharp criticism from environmentalists, as well as a coalition of institutional investors and politicians.

title: Chicago Mercs Profit Falls Short of Expectations
description: Shares of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell after the company said fourth-quarter profit was below some analysts estimates because of higher-than-anticipated costs. Net income rose 35 percent to $102.6 million, or $2.91 a share, from $76.3 million, or $2.18 a share a year earlier. Higher operating expenses and equity losses in unconsolidated subsidiaries cut 11 cents a share from earnings, the exchange said.

title: Bristol-Myers Hires Bankers for Bidding War, Report Says
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, is beefing up its banking team ahead of possible takeover approaches from rivals, notably Sanofi-Aventis, by retaining the services of three Wall Street banks, The Financial Times reported. Bristol-Myers in the past week appointed Lehman Brothers to work alongside Citigroup and Morgan Stanley to examine its options ahead of an expected takeover approach from Sanofi, the paper said.

title: London Honors for Kathleen Turner
description: Kathleen Turner was chosen best actress yesterday when the 18th Critics Circle Theater Awards were announced in London. Ms. Turner won for her performance in Edward Albees Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

title: NYSE in a Deal With Tokyo Exchange
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Stock Exchange have sealed a pact that could point the worlds two largest financial markets toward an eventual combination. The broad agreement will allow both sides to cooperate on joint developments, such as financial products, mutual listings and technology, according to The Associated Press. Further, it sets into motion the possibility of a true combination once Japans biggest stock exchange becomes a public company in 2009.

title: Ford Expects Aston Martin Bids Today, Report Says
description: Ford Motor is expected to receive revised offers on Wednesday for its Aston Martin brand, which it hopes to sell for more than 450 million pounds ($879 million), according to The Financial Times. Bidders left in the auction include Simon Halabi, the Syrian-born property tycoon; a British private equity firm, Doughty Hanson; Magna, the Canadian car parts group; and a consortium including James Packer, the Australian media billionaire, the report said. The paper said that there may be a third round of bidding if several of the offers come in at the same level.

title: Private Firm Joins Citi in Big Hollywood Bet
description: Relativity Media, the privately held firm that helped finance Smokin Aces and Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby, has joined with Citigroup in a deal to fund at least 45 studio films in the next five years, and possibly as many as 100, according to reports. Variety said the overall investment could reach $1.1 billion, and The New York Post said the co-financing agreement could be one of the largest pools of outsider money to make its way to Hollywood.

title: As Tribune Considers Offers, a Former Editor Moves On
description: As Tribune reviews bids for its assets, management at one of its crown jewels, The Los Angeles Times, is trying to keep its employees from running for the door. The announcement that Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, has the L.A. newspaper worried that the move will spark a mass exodus from its newsroom.

title: Physical Culture
description: Gear test with Tristan Greszko of Jackson Hole Mountain Resort.

title: On the Hill: Frozen Pork
description: Although most programs budgets would be frozen at their 2006 levels in a large spending bill scheduled to be put to a vote today, education, veterans health care, international AIDS help and the Federal Bureau of Investigation would receive more. The bill was made available yesterday and is expected to be voted on today, drawing the ire of Republicans.

title: The Good, the Bad, the Amusing
description: In Paris, puffed hair, masked faces, even a light sculpture.

title: A Class Struggle in Paradise
description: A labor union has set its sights on Fisher Island, Fla., one of the most concentrated pockets of wealth in the nation.

title: US Airways Stands Firm As Deadline Looms for Delta Bid
description: As the clock ran down on US Airways $10 billion bid for bankrupt Delta Air Lines, US Airways chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, said in a conference call Tuesday that the offer, a mix of cash and stock, was firm, and that he had no intention of extending the Thursday deadline for the the official committee of Deltas creditors to respond. Also on Tuesday, US Airways reported a $12 million profit for the fourth quarter of 2006, and Delta said it had secured $2.5 billion in financing to fund its emergence as a standalone airline.

title: Congressmen Back Up Mitchells Steroid Warnings
description: Two weeks after George J. Mitchell warned baseball owners that Congress could become involved in his steroids investigation if he did not receive more cooperation from those within the sport, two congressmen offered their backing for Mitchell's efforts.

title: The War at Home: So Many Resolutions
description: They wouldnt be binding, but as Senate Republicans come to perceive a power behind several resolutions harshly critical of President Bushs new troop increase plan, theyve been stepping up efforts to squelch them.

title: Stand By Your Man, Part II?
Handicapped Guessing
description: Little Miss Sunshine apparently has the edge going into the Oscar homestretch, according to the watchers that Reuters checked with, but it is worth noting that last year, it was all Brokeback all the time among the experts, so best to keep that shaker of salt handy.

title: Study: Western Troops Need to Battle for Arab Hearts and Minds
description: The International Institute for Strategic Studies, the London-based military and political think-tank, has suggested in its annual report that the United States and its allies need to pay more attention to the hearts and minds of local populations in the battle against terrorism.

title: Punching in at the Factory
description: Im just glad its finally opening, Jimmy Fallon told the Baguette last night at the after-party for Factory Girl. It was held, natch, at the Chelsea Hotel. The movies release had been delayed while George Hickenlooper, the director, made last-minute changes until a week before its qualifying run for Oscar consideration, which took place in L.A. at the end of December.

title: The Price of Fame
description: Ubiquity may have its rewards for movie stars, but FilmExperience is betting that by the end of this year you will be pretty sick of a few soon-to-be famous faces.

title: A Boost from Borat?
description: The Los Angeles Times writer Scott Collins suggested that the Oscars need Sacha Baron Cohen as much as he needs them. With Ellen DeGeneres as host and a group of movies that many young people have not seen, Mr. Baron Cohens brand of humor might be just the thing to help Oscar find his edge. Mr. Collins points out that Mr. Baron Cohens soliloquy on bodily functions and odors gave the Golden Globes a bump in the ratings and that he could do the same thing for the Academy Awards.

title: In Vogue and On the Carpet
description: The Bagger has only himself to blame for falling so hard for Dreamgirls, but when he is in the mood to spread it around, he always remembers that he was seated just in front of Andre Leon Talley, an editor at large for Vogue, at the premiere. Mr. Leon Talleys vocal, not to say inescapable, support of the show at its signature moment was contagious. He has since, btw, seen the film seven times.

title: Taking the Short Leap From High Falls
description: After flying home on the red-eye and then face-planting for 18 hours, the Bagger unpacked from his Sundance-and-awards marathon and found some artistic swag at the bottom of his suitcase, including a DVD of High Falls, a short directed by Andrew Zuckerman and starring Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard that premiered at Sundance. The Bagger assumes that any filmmaker accessorized by Gyllenhaal and Sarsgaard would know what he is doing, but High Falls is a great little movie. It hangs on this question, among others: Is there a moral equivalence between accidentally running over your husbands dog and said husband getting an anonymous happy ending without the pretense of a massage while on a business trip to Japan?

title: A Visit to the Off-Season Virtual Paddock
description: A feature of this blog from the racing season has been revived for a moment during this off-season thanks to a question by a loyal reader and, above all, thanks to the Renault team and its head of engine track operations, Denis Chevrier, who accepted to answer the readers question.

title: Obama the Clintonian
description: Obama: More Clintonian than Hillary Clinton. Thats the judgment of Washington Post columnist Ruth Marcus, who writes, The truly Clintonian figure running for the Democratic nomination is Barack Obama. She uses the word Clintonian not as a slur but as a description of the mixed gifts Bill Clinton brought to the presidency.

title: 2008 Like Its Today: More Democratic Word-Slinging
description: John Edwards appears to have abandoned his 2004 trademark of positive campaigning. From The Politico:

title: Biden Says Hes InAgain
description: Weve lost track of how many times Senator Joseph R. Biden has announced that hes running for president in 2008, but we think this might be the last one. The Delaware Democrat, who first sought the presidency in 1988, filed papers with the Federal Election Commission today and will appear on Comedy Centrals The Daily Show with Jon Stewart tonight.

title: How Jobless Rates Forecast the Super Bowl
description: At last the Federal Reserve is using its economic expertise to do something worthwhile: forecast the Super Bowl.

title: Public Access Wine Tasting
description: Have any of you checked out Wine Library TV? Im a little late to the game, but its a lot of fun in short bursts, basically the video blog equivalent to cables low-budget public-access TV.

title: Purported Pollock Paintings: Still a Pickle
description: As Randy Kennedy reported on Tuesday, an analysis by researchers at the Harvard University Art Museums is casting new doubt on the authenticity of three paintings attributed to Jackson Pollock.

title: Reclaiming Video Resumes For the Forces of Good
description: The operators of career Web site Vault.com are encouraging would-be investment bankers to produce video resumes, but they have no intention of inspiring Impossible Is Nothing II. Dont wax philosophical, they advise, and please  no feats of strength.

title: US Airways Withdraws Delta Offer
description: US Airways said Wednesday that it would withdraw its $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta Air Lines out of bankruptcy after the offer failed to win the support of the official committee of Deltas creditors.

title: Pogue Gets Airbrushed
description: Wow, wait till I tell you about the makeup I wore yesterday.

title: An Uneven Playing Field
description: In the Timess Dining section today, my colleague Kim Severson writes about the emergence of  and mild uproar over  a service that sells hard-to-get restaurant reservations for at least $35 a table. Its called PrimeTime Tables, and thats what it offers: tables at the kinds of times that are almost impossible to secure, at least at restaurants that book up a month or two in advance, restaurants whose phone lines are constantly busy.

title: On Lieutenant Governors
description: Lieut. Gov. David Paterson, speaking today at the budget briefing, thanked Gov. Eliot Spitzer for giving him something to do. He added:

title: Sunset of a Midnight Appointment
description: Remember that midnight appointment Gov. George E. Pataki made, giving his top aide, John Cahill, a part-time job with the Temporary State Commission on Investigation that paid more than $100,000 a year?

title: The Bike Ride
description: Have you heard of people with photographic memories? Well, my dear husbands memory can best be described as a negative that never developed.

title: Senator Clinton: Compromise Not a Dirty Word
description: At a conference devoted to big ideas for the nations future, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said this morning that compromise need to be a goal  not a dirty word in politics and government, remarks that reflect her own pragmatic style but that are more moderate than the views of some of her rivals and hard-core elements of the Democratic primary electorate.

title: Could This Be the Place?
description: In Mondays post, titled Readers React, I included portions of an e-mail to me from someone reminiscing about a restaurant on the central coast of California, a restaurant he didnt name. I openly wondered whether any of the readers of this blog recalled the restaurant and could in fact fill in the blank.

title: What Went Wrong at Goldmans Hedge Fund?
description: In introducing its long article about Global Alpha, Goldman Sachs highly secretive flagship hedge fund, Bloomberg News writer Richard Teitelbaum recounts how one of the funds managers, Mark Carhart, recently made fun of Warren Buffett for insisting on investing on solid companies with good management and well-known brands. During an investor conference, Mr. Carhart cited several studies showing that big companies with high price-earning ratios make for poor bets, as Mr. Teitelbaum put it.

title: Seeking an Unlikely Ally
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Jan. 31 column, Not-So-Strange Bedfellow.

title: A Year Later, Victims of Storm in Guatemala Are Unearthed
description: After a week-long search for survivors, and later, bodies, in the aftermath of Hurricane Stan, which ravaged Guatemala in October 2005, government authorities threw in the towel. They told families that any victims buried in the landslides caused by the storms heavy rains would, to put it simply, have to stay buried.

title: Ashura in Baghdad
description: Baghdad's Shiite Muslims staged their own celebration of an ancient holy day.

title: Kohlberg Kravis and Sun: Just Friends
description: Sometimes an investment is just an investment.

title: Isnt That Special? Copernicus Meets Doomsday
description: With apologies to Dr. Johnson: When a reader knows the world is about to end, it concentrates his mind wonderfully. Or at least inspires him to post a comment. My bet that humanity will avert doomsday provoked plenty of intelligent disagreement. But there were a few optimists, too, and my favorite argument is the one by M. Skinner:

title: BofA Chief Says Big U.S. Deal Is Unlikely
description: Asked about recent reports that Bank of America was in talks that might lead to an acquisition of Countrywide, Bank of America Chief Executive Kenneth Lewis said Wednesday his company would follow a mortgage strategy of organic growth. Speaking at a financial-services conference, he also said the odds were pretty low that his company would buy a large United States bank this year, Reuters reported.

title: Afterworld
description: A video clip from Bud.TV, Anheuser-Busch's new entertainment Web site.

title: Truly Famous

title: What Girls Want
description: A video clip from Bud.TV, Anheuser-Busch's new entertainment Web site.

title: Flushes and Flashes at Ramsay
description: There are stray, non-essential observations about Gordon Ramsay at the London that I didnt put into todays review, but I wanted to share them nonetheless. How handy is a blog at a time like this?

title: Biden Makes Nice to Obama
description: Sen. Joseph Biden, under fire for remarks to the New York Observer describing his Senate colleague and potential presidential rival Barack Obama as the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright andclean, was bending over backward on Wednesday to kiss and make up.

title: Clinton Postpones New Hampshire Trip
description: The New Hampshire bloggers can stand down.

title: Boycotting the Beijing Olympics?
description: I had a long note from aid workers in Sudan who must, of course, remain anonymous. Theyre still steaming over the attack on aid workers in Nyala on Jan. 19, and theyre proposing tough international responses. One of the measures they propose is blockading Sudanese ports, and another is a boycott of the Chinese Olympics or even of Chinese goods. Im not sure what I think of these steps, and Id welcome your comments  just hit the comment button at the end of the post. Heres the note they sent (everything below is from them, not from me):

title: Maliki Tells Iran & U.S. to Chill Out; Plus: Think-Tank Thinks About Irans Nukes
description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq warned Iran and the United States to not make Iraq a proxy battlefield for growing tensions between the two countries.

title: A Bumpy Rollout for Biden
description: What Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware intended to do on Wednesday was to declare his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination. There was the video posted on his new Web site, with Mr. Biden seated by a fireplace, the conference call with reporters and the denunciation of the war in Iraq and the heralding of his own foreign policy credentials.

title: Advertising Campaign Causes Terror Scare
description: From the major Oops department, Turner Broadcasting has claimed responsibility for a slew of suspicious packages, scattered around various American cities, that caused a terrorism scare in Boston, provoked the closure of major roadways and part of the Charles River, and mobilized local and federal law enforcement.

title: On the Boulevard de Clich: Mens Fashion
description: At six oclock tonight I went down to the street to find my driver, Bernard Alloux, and go and buy a baguette for the trip home. On the way I stopped and bought a pair of stilettos at a place called Ernest, a real dump, but the ladies were nice and I left with the shoes in a gold plastic bag that said:

title: The Future President Clinton
description: As I survey the political scene, I dont think its too soon to make a firm prediction about the 2008 presidential race. I think Hillary Clinton will be the next president of the United States.
